title: Putin Extends Rule in Preordained Russian Election After Harshest Crackdown Since Soviet Era | Military.com
content:
President Vladimir Putin sealed his control over Russia for six more years on Monday with a highly orchestrated landslide in an election that followed the harshest crackdown on the opposition and free speech since Soviet times.
While the result was never in doubt, Russians attempted to defy the inevitable outcome, heeding a call to protest Putin's repression at home and his war in Ukraine by showing up at polling stations at noon on Sunday. But from the earliest returns, it was clear Putin would extend his nearly quarter-century rule with a fifth term.
With nearly all the precincts counted Monday, election officials said Putin had secured a record number of votes — an unsurprising development underlining the Russian leader’s total control of the country’s political system.
Putin has led Russia as president or prime minister since December 1999, a tenure marked by international military aggression and an increasing intolerance for dissent. At the end of his fifth term, Putin would be the longest-serving Russian leader since Catherine the Great, who ruled during the 18th century.
As early results came in, Putin hailed them as an indication of “trust” and “hope” in him — while critics saw them as another reflection of the preordained nature of the election.
“Of course, we have lots of tasks ahead. But I want to make it clear for everyone: When we were consolidated, no one has ever managed to frighten us, to suppress our will and our self-conscience. They failed in the past and they will fail in the future,” he said at a meeting with his campaign staff after polls closed.
Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled.

Putin has led Russia as president or prime minister since December 1999, a tenure marked by international military aggression and an increasing intolerance for dissent. As early results came in, Putin hailed them as an indication of “trust” and “hope” in him — while critics saw them as another reflection of the preordained nature of the election.

Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled.

title: Путин победил на выборах президента России
content:
Председатель российской ЦИК Элла Памфилова сообщила, что Владимир Путин победил на выборах президента России с результатом 87,28% голосов
ДУШАНБЕ, 21 мар — Sputnik. Владимир Путин победил на выборах президента России, которые состоялись с 15 по 17 марта.
Об этом официально сообщает Центральная избирательная комиссия после обработки 100% протоколов.
Путин набрал 87,28% голосов в России. Всего за действующего президента отдали свои голоса более 76 млн россиян.
Другие кандидаты набрали соответственно: Харитонов - 4,31%, Даванков - 3,85%, Слуцкий - 3,20%.


Явка на выборах составила 77,49%, всего приняли участие более 87,5 млн граждан.
За рубежом работало 269 избирательных участков, на них пришли свыше 388,7 тыс. человек. За Владимир Путина проголосовали более 281,8 тыс. или 72,54% избирателей.
В Таджикистане проголосовать на выборах президента России выразили желание более 9,5 тыс. граждан РФ, которые проживают на территории республики.
Избирательные участки открылись в стране 17 марта с 08:00. Всего работало 6 пунктов - в здании консульского отдела Посольства России, на территории Генерального консульства России в Худжанде, а для военнослужащих 201-й военной базы и членов их семей - четыре участка в Душанбе и Бохтаре.

Путин набрал 93,89% голосов избирателей, проголосовавших в Таджикистане.
За Владислава Даванкова отдали голоса 1,38%, Николая Харитонова - 0,69%, Леонида Слуцкого - 0,37%.
После переизбрания Путин будет находиться в президентском кресле еще 6 лет.

Инаугурация президента России пройдет 7 мая. На следующий день, 8 мая, состоится рассмотрение депутатами нижней палаты парламента вопроса о назначении председателя Правительства РФ.
Напомним, что Совет Федерации назначил президентские выборы на 17 марта 2024 года. Голосование на территории России проходило 3 дня - 15, 16 и 17 марта. Всего в стране действовало более 94 тыс. участков.
На пост главы государства претендовали четыре зарегистрированных ЦИК РФ кандидата: Леонид Слуцкий, Николай Харитонов, Владислав Даванков и Владимир Путин.
translation:
Chairman of the Russian Central Election Commission Ella Pamfilova reported that Vladimir Putin won the presidential elections in Russia with 87.28% of the votes.
DUSHANBE, March 21 – Sputnik. Vladimir Putin won the Russian presidential elections, which took place from March 15 to 17.
The Central Election Commission officially reports this after processing 100% of the protocols.
Putin won 87.28% of the vote in Russia. In total, more than 76 million Russians cast their votes for the current president.
Other candidates scored accordingly: Kharitonov - 4.31%, Davankov - 3.85%, Slutsky - 3.20%.


The turnout in the elections was 77.49%, in total more than 87.5 million citizens took part.
There were 269 polling stations abroad, and over 388.7 thousand people came to them. More than 281.8 thousand or 72.54% of voters voted for Vladimir Putin.
In Tajikistan, more than 9.5 thousand citizens of the Russian Federation who live on the territory of the republic expressed a desire to vote in the Russian presidential elections.
Polling stations opened in the country on March 17 from 08:00. A total of 6 points operated - in the building of the consular department of the Russian Embassy, on the territory of the Russian Consulate General in Khujand, and for military personnel of the 201st military base and members of their families - four sites in Dushanbe and Bokhtar.

Putin won 93.89% of the votes cast in Tajikistan.
Vladislav Davankov received 1.38% of votes, Nikolai Kharitonov - 0.69%, Leonid Slutsky - 0.37%.
After re-election, Putin will remain in the presidential chair for another 6 years.

The inauguration of the Russian President will take place on May 7. The next day, May 8, deputies of the lower house of parliament will consider the issue of appointing the Chairman of the Government of the Russian Federation.
Let us recall that the Federation Council has scheduled presidential elections for March 17, 2024. Voting in Russia took place over 3 days - March 15, 16 and 17. In total, more than 94 thousand sites operated in the country.
Four candidates registered by the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation were vying for the post of head of state: Leonid Slutsky, Nikolai Kharitonov, Vladislav Davankov and Vladimir Putin.

The turnout in the elections was 77.49%, in total more than 87.5 million citizens took part.
There were 269 polling stations abroad, and over 388.7 thousand people came to them. More than 281.8 thousand or 72.54% of voters voted for Vladimir Putin.
In Tajikistan, more than 9.5 thousand citizens of the Russian Federation who live on the territory of the republic expressed a desire to vote in the Russian presidential elections.

title: 俄罗斯大选在即，“除了普京还有谁”的思维在弥漫 - BBC News 中文
content:
普京表现出色还有另一个原因。
“我们都支持您参选的决定，因为从我有记忆以来，您就一直掌权。”在普京的年终新闻发布会上，一位年轻的俄罗斯电视台记者亚历山大（Alexander）说。
我见过很多像亚历山大的俄罗斯人，他们无法想象克里姆林宫里还有其他人。这并不是因为他们崇拜普京，只是觉得别无选择。
我经常听到有人说： “好吧，除了普京还有谁？”
这是克里姆林宫精心布局的。当局在过去近四分之一个世纪，铲除了政治版图上所有潜在的挑战者。如此，它确保“不然谁能做？”的问题没有答案。
在俄罗斯南部、距离莫斯科225公里的城市勒热夫（Rzhev），我与人们谈论对选举的期望，许多人似乎都希望看到改变——但不包括改变领导人。
名叫伊利亚（Ilya）的年轻人说：“我希望事情会变得更好，因为现在停滞不前。但如果选新人，他可能无法承担政府的重任。像普京这样经验丰富的人，能让国家即使在现在所处的困境中也能够有发展。”
养老金领取者莉迪亚（Lidiya）则说：“我对选举抱有很大希望。我希望战争结束，经济好转。但我尊敬普京。”
我问：“没有其他人能胜任他的工作吗？”
莉迪亚回答：“现在没有，也许普京以后会找到合适的人选。但我认为他还会掌权很久。”
普京是俄罗斯总统和总司令，即使该国在乌克兰战争中有重大军事损失，似乎也没有让民众对他期望幻灭。
发动全面入侵是普京的决定，但部分俄罗斯人认为在战争时期有责任支持本国领导人，不会质疑其动机或后果。其他人则接受官方论述，即发动战争的是西方而非俄罗斯。
勒热夫有一位女士希望看到克里姆林宫有改变。她是前电视台记者、地区议员邓佐娃（Yekaterina Duntsova），最近试图竞选总统。她呼吁在乌克兰实现和平，释放政治犯，建立一个“人道的”俄罗斯。
俄罗斯中央选举委员会拒绝接受她的提名，理由是她文件有误。
邓佐娃说：“我觉得这里的政治体制把我视为某类外来物种，不知道该拿我怎么办。因为我是突然冒出来的，政治系统不知道我是谁。所以它决定拒绝我，不要构成危险。”
现在她成立了一个新政党。她不害怕当局会报复吗？
“我们没有做任何违法的事。我们依法行事。至于是否害怕，恐惧不能支配我。我相信我所做的一切。这种信念让恐惧退居其次。”
回到普京的竞选活动现场，我采访了“今日俄罗斯”（RT)电视台主编玛格丽塔·西蒙尼扬（Margarita Simonyan）。
我问道：“一个领导人掌权四分之一个世纪甚至更久......却没有制衡。这不危险吗？”
她回答说：“这是你们多年来一直在宣传的口头禅。一个人长期掌权，并不一定比每四年换一个领导人更糟糕。柬埔寨的波尔布特三年内就消灭了三分之一的人口。”
这似乎让人感到有些宽慰。
translation:
There is another reason why Putin is doing so well.
"We all support your decision to run because you have been in power for as long as I can remember," said Alexander, a young Russian television reporter, at Putin's year-end press conference.
I've met a lot of Russians like Alexander who couldn't imagine there was anyone else in the Kremlin. This is not because they admire Putin, they just feel they have no choice.
I often hear people say: "Well, who else but Putin?"
This was carefully planned by the Kremlin. The authorities have spent nearly a quarter of a century eliminating all potential challengers from the political landscape. As such, it ensures that there is no answer to the question "Who else could do it?"
When I talked to people in Rzhev, a city in southern Russia 225 kilometers from Moscow, about their expectations for the election, many seemed to want to see change — but not a change of leadership.
A young man named Ilya said: "I hope things will get better because they are stagnant now. But if a new person is elected, he may not be able to shoulder the heavy responsibilities of the government. An experienced person like Putin can Let the country develop even in the current difficult situation.”
Pensioner Lidiya said: "I have high hopes for the election. I hope the war will end and the economy will improve. But I respect Putin."
I asked, "Isn't there anyone else who can do his job?"
Lydia replied: "Not now, maybe Putin will find the right person in the future. But I think he will be in power for a long time."
Putin is the president and commander-in-chief of Russia. Even though the country suffered heavy military losses in the Ukrainian war, it seems that the public's expectations of him have not been disillusioned.
It was Putin's decision to launch a full-scale invasion, but some Russians feel they have a duty to support their country's leaders in times of war and will not question its motives or consequences. Others accept the official narrative that it was the West, not Russia, that started the war.
There's a woman in Rzhev who wants to see change in the Kremlin. She is Yekaterina Duntsova, a former TV reporter and regional councillor, who recently tried to run for president. She called for peace in Ukraine, the release of political prisoners and the creation of a "humane" Russia.
Russia's Central Election Commission refused to accept her nomination, citing errors in her documentation.
"I feel like the political system here sees me as some kind of alien species and doesn't know what to do with me," Duntsova said. "Because I came out of nowhere and the political system doesn't know who I am. So it decided to reject me. Don't pose a danger."
Now she has launched a new political party. Isn’t she afraid of retaliation from the authorities?
"We didn't do anything illegal. We acted within the law. As for fear, fear doesn't control me. I believe in everything I do. That belief takes a backseat to fear."
Returning to Putin’s campaign, I interviewed Margarita Simonyan, editor-in-chief of Russia Today (RT).
I asked, "Isn't it dangerous when a leader stays in power for a quarter of a century or more...without checks and balances?"
She replied: "This is the mantra you have been preaching for years. Having one person in power for a long time is not necessarily worse than having a different leader every four years. Pol Pot wiped out a third of Cambodia in three years s population."
This seemed to provide some relief.

title: Putin extends rule in preordained Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era - ABC News
content:
President Vladimir Putin has extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring his determination to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West
President Vladimir Putin extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring his determination Monday to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West.
After the harshest crackdown on dissent since Soviet times, it was clear from the earliest returns that Putin's nearly quarter-century rule would continue with a fifth term that grants him six more years. Still, Russians heeded a call to protest Putin’s repression and his war in Ukraine by showing up at polling stations at noon Sunday. 
With all the precincts counted Monday, election officials said Putin had secured a record number of votes, underlining his total control over the political system. U.S. and other Western leaders denounced the election as a sham.
U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan said there was “nothing free or fair" about the election but seemingly resisted calls from Russia's opposition to not recognize Putin as the winner.
Ahead of the election, Putin's greatest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic penal colony, anti-war candidates were barred from the ballot and independent voices were silenced in a Kremlin-backed media blockade. No independent monitoring organizations were able to observe the election and analysts said online polling meant the vote was highly susceptible to manipulation. Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled.
input:
President Vladimir Putin has extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring his determination to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West
President Vladimir Putin extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring his determination Monday to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West.

Still, Russians heeded a call to protest Putin’s repression and his war in Ukraine by showing up at polling stations at noon Sunday. 
With all the precincts counted Monday, election officials said Putin had secured a record number of votes, underlining his total control over the political system. U.S. and other Western leaders denounced the election as a sham.
U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan said there was “nothing free or fair" about the election but seemingly resisted calls from Russia's opposition to not recognize Putin as the winner.
Ahead of the election, Putin's greatest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic penal colony, anti-war candidates were barred from the ballot and independent voices were silenced in a Kremlin-backed media blockade. No independent monitoring organizations were able to observe the election and analysts said online polling meant the vote was highly susceptible to manipulation. Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled.

title: Russian presidential election 2024: Putin extends one-man rule after stage-managed election devoid of credible opposition | CNN
content:
One video from Luhansk showed an elderly woman inside her apartment filling out an election paper and putting it in the ballot box, while a man in army fatigues stands over her with a rifle slung across his chest.
    

            After the release of preliminary results Sunday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky called Putin a “dictator” and Russia’s election a “sham.”
    

            “It is clear to everyone in the world that this individual, as has happened so often in history, is simply sick with power and is doing everything he can to rule for life. There is no evil he will not commit to prolong his personal power. And there is no one in the world who is immune to this,” Zelensky said.
    

            The election comes after more than two years of war which have exacted huge costs on the Russian population. The Kremlin keeps its casualty numbers shrouded in secrecy, but Western officials believe more than 300,000 Russian troops have been killed or injured on the battlefields of Ukraine.
    

            Responding Sunday to a journalist’s question about French President Emmanuel Macron’s comments last month that he would not rule out sending European forces to Ukraine, Putin said such a move would be “one step from the third World War.”
    

            Putin’s invasion has reshaped the world’s post-Cold War geopolitical axes, prompting the West to treat Russia as a pariah state after decades of more amicable relations. The war has also shrunk Putin’s world, after the International Criminal Court last year issued a warrant for his arrest for alleged war crimes committed in Ukraine, obliging more than 100 countries to arrest the Russian leader if he sets foot on their soil.
    

            But the war has also opened new avenues for Russia, which has sought to forge new partnerships and strengthen existing ones. Russia’s relations with China, North Korea and Iran – which have not condemned the invasion – have deepened, and Putin has attempted to court countries in the Global South as he pitches a vision of a world not led by the West.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举：普京、权力与抗议的可能性 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
另一位候选人则是俄罗斯民族主义的自民党领导人列昂尼德·斯卢茨基。他曾被指控性骚扰一名记者。但斯卢茨基称，这些指控是针对他的“阴谋”之一。
斯卢茨基取代日里诺夫斯基成为了自民党的总统候选人。日里诺夫斯基是一位个性张扬的民粹主义者，曾四度成为普京的竞选对手，并被广泛与美国前总统特朗普相提并论。他已于2020年去世。
来自共产党和自民党的总统候选人相对知名，而第三位注册候选人、新人党党员弗拉迪斯拉夫·达万科夫却在莫斯科以外几乎不为人所知。
这三名候选人都是“系统性反对派”的一部分，来自少数在俄罗斯国家杜马（议会下院）拥有席位的政党。
这三名候选人都支持对乌克兰的战争，并且普遍支持克里姆林宫的党派路线。
根据VtsIOM机构进行的民意调查结果，预计将有2%至4%的俄罗斯人投票给他们。
自由反对派候选人鲍里斯·纳杰日丁被拒绝注册，理由是其在候选人申请中的支持签名“无效”。
公开批评乌克兰战争的纳杰日丁表示，他将招募独立选举监督员，并承诺继续反对最高法院针对他的裁决。但他已没有机会参选。
他在今年2月初告诉半岛电视台记者，他被排除在外是因为他的选举评级——准备投票给他的人数每周增加 5%。
在2011-2012年的冬天，俄罗斯在后苏联时代取得胜利，但在被广泛认为存在舞弊行为的议会和总统选举之后，出现了一些最大规模的反对派集会。
克里姆林宫以大规模的镇压作为回应。而现在，它拥有更为先进的工具来压制反对派——通过面部识别软件和手机数据来识别每一名抗议者。
任何抗议活动“都将被取消而且组织糟糕”，来自西部城市梁赞的反对派活动人士谢尔盖·比济尤金这样说道，据悉，他在试图登记参加2018年总统选举后被迫离开俄罗斯。
他告诉半岛电视台记者，“无论大多数民对普京的态度如何，这场选举看起来都像是一场演出。”
translation:
The other candidate is Leonid Slutsky, leader of the Russian nationalist Liberal Democratic Party. He has been accused of sexually harassing a journalist. But Slutsky said the charges were part of a "conspiracy" against him.
Slutsky replaced Zhirinovsky as the Liberal Democratic Party's presidential candidate. Zhirinovsky is a flamboyant populist who has been Putin's election opponent four times and has been widely compared to former U.S. President Trump. He passed away in 2020.
While the presidential candidates from the Communist Party and the Liberal Democratic Party are relatively well-known, the third registered candidate, Vladislav Davankov, a member of the Novosibirsk Party, is virtually unknown outside Moscow.
All three candidates are part of the "systemic opposition" and come from a handful of parties with seats in Russia's State Duma, the lower house of parliament.
All three candidates support the war in Ukraine and generally support the Kremlin's party line.
According to the results of a poll conducted by the VtsIOM agency, 2% to 4% of Russians are expected to vote for them.
Liberal opposition candidate Boris Nadezdin has been refused registration on the grounds that his supporting signature on his candidacy application was "invalid".
Nadezdin, a public critic of the war in Ukraine, said he would recruit independent election monitors and pledged to continue to fight the Supreme Court ruling against him. But he has no chance to run.
He told Al Jazeera in early February that he was being excluded because of his electoral rating - a 5% weekly increase in the number of people prepared to vote for him.
The winter of 2011-2012 saw some of the largest opposition rallies in Russia's post-Soviet era following parliamentary and presidential elections that were widely seen as rigged.
The Kremlin responded with a massive crackdown. Now, it has even more sophisticated tools to silence opposition—identifying individual protesters through facial recognition software and cell phone data.
Any protests "will be canceled and poorly organized," said Sergei Bizyyudin, an opposition activist from the western city of Ryazan who was reportedly forced to leave Russia after trying to register to run in the 2018 presidential election. .
He told Al Jazeera, “Whatever the attitude of the majority of the population toward Putin, this election looks like a show.”

title: With the election behind him, Putin says Russia aims to set up a buffer zone inside Ukraine | AP News
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin said after extending his rule in an election that stifled opposition that Moscow will not relent in its invasion of Ukraine and plans to create a buffer zone to help protect against long-range Ukrainian strikes and cross-border raids.
The Kremlin’s forces have made battlefield progress as Kyiv’s troops struggle with a severe shortage of artillery shells and exhausted front-line units after more than two years of war. The front line stretches over 1,000 kilometers (620 miles) across eastern and southern Ukraine.
Advances have been slow and costly, and Ukraine has increasingly used its long-range firepower to hit oil refineries and depots deep inside Russia. Also, groups claiming to be Ukraine-based Russian opponents of the Kremlin have launched cross-border incursions.
“We will be forced at some point, when we consider it necessary, to create a certain ‘sanitary zone’ on the territories controlled by the (Ukrainian government),” Putin said late Sunday.
This “security zone,” Putin said, “would be quite difficult to penetrate using the foreign-made strike assets at the enemy’s disposal.”
He spoke after the release of election returns that showed him securing a fifth six-year term in a landslide in an election devoid of any real opposition following his relentless crackdown on dissent.
Monday marks the 10th anniversary of Russia’s seizure of Ukraine’s Crimea Peninsula, which set the stage for Russia to invade its neighbor in February 2022. However, Putin has been vague about his goals in Ukraine since that full-scale invasion floundered.
Putin again warned the West against deploying troops to Ukraine.

Advances have been slow and costly, and Ukraine has increasingly used its long-range firepower to hit oil refineries and depots deep inside Russia. Also, groups claiming to be Ukraine-based Russian opponents of the Kremlin have launched cross-border incursions.
“We will be forced at some point, when we consider it necessary, to create a certain ‘sanitary zone’ on the territories controlled by the (Ukrainian government),” Putin said late Sunday.
This “security zone,” Putin said, “would be quite difficult to penetrate using the foreign-made strike assets at the enemy’s disposal.”
He spoke after the release of election returns that showed him securing a fifth six-year term in a landslide in an election devoid of any real opposition following his relentless crackdown on dissent.
Monday marks the 10th anniversary of Russia’s seizure of Ukraine’s Crimea Peninsula, which set the stage for Russia to invade its neighbor in February 2022. However, Putin has been vague about his goals in Ukraine since that full-scale invasion floundered.
Putin again warned the West against deploying troops to Ukraine.

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
content:
3月18日，普京在俄罗斯首都莫斯科的竞选总部回答记者提问。新华社记者 曹阳 摄
 
提到正在进行中的“特别军事行动”，普京说，俄军每一天都在前进，目前其战略“不仅仅是积极防御”，“总的来说，俄罗斯武装力量完全占据了主动。”他还表示，在新任期内，他首先要实现“特别军事行动”的目标，加强俄罗斯的防御能力和武装力量。
 
此次大选也再次凸显了俄罗斯和西方的矛盾。据报道，许多西方国家对俄罗斯大选进行了抨击。美国白宫国家安全委员会发言人称，俄罗斯的大选“既不自由，也不公平”，指责普京镇压反对派。乌克兰总统泽连斯基3月17日表示，俄罗斯这次投票是非法的。
 
普京在记者会上则表示，俄罗斯的选举是民主的，比美国的更加透明。他说“全世界都在嘲笑（美国）正在发生的事情”，称美国的选举“是灾难，而非民主”。对于西方对俄罗斯大选的抨击，普京表示对此并不意外，“你对他们能有什么期待？起立鼓掌？他们正在与我们作战，进行军事战斗。”
 
普京说，随着对当前局势有着更现实看法的新一代专家逐渐取代旧专家，西方“将以更复杂的方式”对俄罗斯采取行动。他还表示，不能排除俄罗斯与北约爆发全面冲突的可能性，如果出现那种情况，“我们距离一场全面的第三次世界大战仅一步之遥……我想大概没有人会想看到这一点”。
 
本月稍早，瑞典结束持续两百余年的“军事中立”政策，正式加入北约。俄方当天表示，北约扩张是对俄罗斯安全和利益的破坏，俄方将采取反制措施，在战术和战略上确保自身安全。
translation:
On March 18, Putin answered questions from reporters at the campaign headquarters in Moscow, the Russian capital. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
 
Referring to the ongoing "special military operations", Putin said that the Russian army is advancing every day, and its current strategy is "not just active defense." "In general, the Russian armed forces have completely taken the initiative." He He also stated that during his new term, he must first achieve the goals of "special military operations" and strengthen Russia's defense capabilities and armed forces.
 
This election has once again highlighted the contradiction between Russia and the West. According to reports, many Western countries criticized the Russian election. A spokesman for the National Security Council of the White House said that Russia's election was "neither free nor fair" and accused Putin of suppressing the opposition. Ukrainian President Zelensky said on March 17 that the vote in Russia was illegal.
 
Putin said at the press conference that Russia's elections are democratic and more transparent than those in the United States. He said that "the whole world is laughing at what is happening (in the United States)" and called the U.S. election "a disaster, not a democracy." Putin said he was not surprised by the West's criticism of the Russian election. "What can you expect from them? A standing ovation? They are fighting us, conducting military battles."
 
Putin said the West "will act in a more sophisticated way" against Russia as a new generation of experts with a more realistic view of the current situation gradually replaces the old ones. He also said that the possibility of a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO cannot be ruled out. If that happens, "we are only one step away from a full-scale World War III... I think no one would want to see this." a little".
 
Earlier this month, Sweden ended its "military neutrality" policy that had lasted for more than 200 years and officially joined NATO. Russia stated that day that NATO expansion is damaging to Russia's security and interests, and Russia will take countermeasures to ensure its own security tactically and strategically.

On March 18, Putin answered questions from reporters at the campaign headquarters in Moscow, the Russian capital. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
 
Referring to the ongoing "special military operations", Putin said that the Russian army is advancing every day, and its current strategy is "not just active defense." "In general, the Russian armed forces have completely taken the initiative." He He also stated that during his new term, he must first achieve the goals of "special military operations" and strengthen Russia's defense capabilities and armed forces.
 
This election has once again highlighted the contradiction between Russia and the West. According to reports, many Western countries criticized the Russian election. A spokesman for the National Security Council of the White House said that Russia's election was "neither free nor fair" and accused Putin of suppressing the opposition. Ukrainian President Zelensky said on March 17 that the vote in Russia was illegal.
 
Putin said at the press conference that Russia's elections are democratic and more transparent than those in the United States. He said that "the whole world is laughing at what is happening (in the United States)" and called the U.S. election "a disaster, not a democracy." Putin said he was not surprised by the West's criticism of the Russian election. "What can you expect from them? A standing ovation? They are fighting us, conducting military battles."
 
Putin said the West "will act in a more sophisticated way" against Russia as a new generation of experts with a more realistic view of the current situation gradually replaces the old ones. He also said that the possibility of a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO cannot be ruled out. If that happens, "we are only one step away from a full-scale World War III... I think no one would want to see this." a little".
 
Earlier this month, Sweden ended its "military neutrality" policy that had lasted for more than 200 years and officially joined NATO. Russia stated that day that NATO expansion is damaging to Russia's security and interests, and Russia will take countermeasures to ensure its own security tactically and strategically.

title: 盘点｜2024年全球有哪些重要选举？
content:
俄罗斯大选
俄罗斯联邦总统选举投票将于2024年3月17日举行。届时距离俄乌冲突爆发已超过两年，俄罗斯进入战时社会“新常态”为时已久。总统选举在很大程度上被视为俄罗斯民众对克里姆林宫领导的“特别军事行动”的一次表决。根据目前多方预计，总统普京料将以高得票率赢得选举，继续领导俄罗斯。
在西方，很多观察家曾预计，随着经济制裁的深入和军事冲突的延宕，俄民众的日常生活将受到越来越多的限制，最后导致针对克里姆林宫的普遍不满，俄罗斯可以从内部“瓦解”。但现实已经证明这些预言全部落空。
俄中央选举委员会（中选委）主席埃拉·帕姆菲洛娃表示，“到目前为止，我们已收到16人成为俄罗斯总统职位候选人的申请。”中选委还表示，届时，俄罗斯将在其控制的乌克兰四个地区以及克里米亚半岛举行大选投票。
2023年12月18日，普京曾向俄中央选举委员会提交以独立候选人身份参加2024年总统选举的文件，正式登记为总统候选人。2000年3月26日，普京正式当选总统，首个任期结束后，普京又在2004年、2012年、2018年三度出任俄罗斯总统，掌舵这个横跨欧亚的北方大国。
translation:
Russian election
Voting in the Russian Federation's presidential election will be held on March 17, 2024. By then, it will have been more than two years since the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out, and it has been a long time since Russia entered the "new normal" of wartime society. The presidential election is largely seen as a vote by the Russian people against the Kremlin-led "extraordinary military operations." According to current predictions from many parties, President Putin is expected to win the election with a high vote rate and continue to lead Russia.
In the West, many observers had predicted that with the deepening of economic sanctions and the prolongation of military conflicts, the daily lives of the Russian people would be increasingly restricted, eventually leading to widespread dissatisfaction with the Kremlin and that Russia could "disintegrate" from within. . But reality has proven that all these predictions have failed.
Ella Pamfilova, chairperson of the Russian Central Election Commission (Central Election Commission), said, “So far, we have received applications from 16 people to become candidates for the Russian presidency.” The Central Election Commission also stated that Russia will The four regions of Ukraine and the Crimean peninsula under its control held general elections.
On December 18, 2023, Putin submitted documents to the Russian Central Election Commission to participate in the 2024 presidential election as an independent candidate and officially registered as a presidential candidate. On March 26, 2000, Putin was officially elected as president. After his first term, Putin served as the president of Russia three times in 2004, 2012, and 2018, taking the helm of this large northern country that spans Europe and Asia.
input:
Russian election
Voting in the Russian Federation's presidential election will be held on March 17, 2024. By then, it will have been more than two years since the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out, and it has been a long time since Russia entered the "new normal" of wartime society. The presidential election is largely seen as a vote by the Russian people against the Kremlin-led "extraordinary military operations." According to current predictions from many parties, President Putin is expected to win the election with a high vote rate and continue to lead Russia.
In the West, many observers had predicted that with the deepening of economic sanctions and the prolongation of military conflicts, the daily lives of the Russian people would be increasingly restricted, eventually leading to widespread dissatisfaction with the Kremlin and that Russia could "disintegrate" from within. . But reality has proven that all these predictions have failed.
Ella Pamfilova, chairperson of the Russian Central Election Commission (Central Election Commission), said, “So far, we have received applications from 16 people to become candidates for the Russian presidency.” The Central Election Commission also stated that Russia will The four regions of Ukraine and the Crimean peninsula under its control held general elections.
On December 18, 2023, Putin submitted documents to the Russian Central Election Commission to participate in the 2024 presidential election as an independent candidate and officially registered as a presidential candidate. On March 26, 2000, Putin was officially elected as president. After his first term, Putin served as the president of Russia three times in 2004, 2012, and 2018, taking the helm of this large northern country that spans Europe and Asia.

title: Putin claims victory in election with no serious competition – DW – 03/17/2024
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin was slated to win the country's presidential election, state-run exit polls showed Sunday.
The government-run VTsIOM pollster showed the 71-year-old had won a landslide, having secured an estimated 88% of the vote in the three-day election that included no real opposition candidates.
The exit polls were released following the closure of polling stations in Russia's westernmost region of Kaliningrad on Sunday evening.
If confirmed, the result would be a record for Putin, who received 76.7% of the vote in the last presidential election in 2018.
The former KGB spy would become Russia's longest-serving leader in more than 200 years, overtaking Josef Stalin.
Putin is now poised to extend his nearly quarter century of rule for six more years having presided over a thorough crackdown on dissent.
International observers did not monitor the election across the vast country which reaches across 11 time zones.
The election took place just over two years since Putin triggered the deadliest European conflict since the Second World War by ordering the full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which he labels a "special military operation."
During the poll, several Russian regions were allegedly attacked by Ukrainian missiles and drones, which killed several people.
After the exit poll was announced, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy described Putin as a power-hungry "dictator."
"It is clear to everyone in the world that this figure — as has happened so often in history — is simply sick from power and is doing everything he can to rule forever. There is no evil he will not commit to prolong his personal power," Zelenskyy said on social media.
The White House denounced the Russian election as "obviously not free nor fair given how Mr. Putin has imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running against him."
Germany's Foreign Ministry said the election result would "surprise nobody."
"Putin's rule is authoritarian, he relies on censorship, repression & violence. The "election" in the occupied territories of Ukraine are null and void & another breach of international law," the ministry wrote on X, formerly Twitter.
The Tagesspiegel newspaper cited a spokesperson for German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier as saying he would not send a letter of congratulations to Putin.
UK Foreign Secretary David Cameron dismissed the exit polls, saying on X, formerly Twitter: "This is not what free and fair elections look like."
Former Russian leader Dmitry Medvedev congratulated Putin on his "splendid victory," while Russian state-run television praised "colossal support to the president" and the "unbelievable consolidation" of the country behind its leader.

title: How does Putin stay in power? - National | Globalnews.ca
content:
There’s an old Soviet joke. An aide of the General Secretary and ruler Leonid Brezhnev rushes into his office during an election. Brezhnev’s communists secured 99.8 per cent of the vote but the aide is still worried.
“We’ve been robbed!” he yells. “Someone broke into the Kremlin vault and stole next year’s election results!”
More than one hundred million people, including those in Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine, are eligible to cast a ballot in Russian elections, which take place over three days until March 17.
But how they vote doesn’t matter. Vladimir Putin will win.
‘We have a very similar situation (to the joke),” University of Professor Aurel Braun says, adding Putin will not only win but determine the vote’s percentage.
“And therefore, this is a sham election.”
Putin has been president since 2000, pausing between 2008 and 2012 to take the lesser prime minister role and only because the Russian constitution bans anyone from serving more than two terms in a row.
Through plebiscites and reform, the former KGB agent has changed the rules. He’s due to be elected for two more six-year terms (instead of the usual four) and hold on to power until at least 2036. By then he would have ruled longer than Soviet dictator Josef Stalin.
input:
There’s an old Soviet joke. An aide of the General Secretary and ruler Leonid Brezhnev rushes into his office during an election. Brezhnev’s communists secured 99.8 per cent of the vote but the aide is still worried.
“We’ve been robbed!” he yells. “Someone broke into the Kremlin vault and stole next year’s election results!”
More than one hundred million people, including those in Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine, are eligible to cast a ballot in Russian elections, which take place over three days until March 17.
But how they vote doesn’t matter. Vladimir Putin will win.
‘We have a very similar situation (to the joke),” University of Professor Aurel Braun says, adding Putin will not only win but determine the vote’s percentage.
“And therefore, this is a sham election.”
Putin has been president since 2000, pausing between 2008 and 2012 to take the lesser prime minister role and only because the Russian constitution bans anyone from serving more than two terms in a row.
Through plebiscites and reform, the former KGB agent has changed the rules. He’s due to be elected for two more six-year terms (instead of the usual four) and hold on to power until at least 2036. By then he would have ruled longer than Soviet dictator Josef Stalin.

title: 再干6年，普京能带出一个强大的俄罗斯吗？
content:
毫无悬念，普京再次当选。


	根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会网站当地时间3月18日发布的数据，2024年俄罗斯总统选举全部选票均已计票完成。初步数据显示，现任总统普京得票率为87.28%，压倒性领先其他候选人。


	俄罗斯即将开启“普京5.0时代”。接下来，普京将在俄罗斯总统的位置上至少再干6年，也有可能是12年。


	而在这之前，普京已经做了20年的俄罗斯总统。


	2000年，普京首次赢得总统选举，并于2004年成功连任，一口气先当了两届共计8年的总统。由于俄罗斯宪法规定总统只能连任一次，2008年普京没有参与总统选举。时任总理梅德韦杰夫当年赢得竞选出任总统，并提名普京为总理。


	在出任总统的第一年，梅德韦杰夫就推动并签署了宪法修正案，将俄罗斯总统任期每届由4年延长到6年。梅德韦杰夫的任期结束后，2012年普京再次竞选总统，以绝对优势的得票率开启了自己的第三任总统生涯，并于6年后的2018年顺利连任至2024年。


	根据2020年俄罗斯宪法修正案“任期清零”条款，既有总统当选次数“清零”并重新计算。因此本届选举在“法律意义”上可以算是一次“全新的”选举，普京胜选后可以在此次任期结束后寻求连任至2036年。


	“给我二十年，还你一个强大的俄罗斯。”这是坊间一直盛传的普京豪言，虽然很多专家考证后发现这句话并非出自普京之口，但关注普京和俄罗斯的人可能都会有这样的感觉，这确实是普京的“俄罗斯梦”。


	如今，普京治下，20年已经过去了，俄罗斯强大了吗？再给他6年或者12年，他会将俄罗斯带向何方？能带出一个强大的俄罗斯吗？
translation:
There is no suspense, Putin was re-elected.


According to data released on the website of the Russian Central Election Commission on March 18, local time, all votes for the 2024 Russian presidential election have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 87.28% of the vote, overwhelmingly leading other candidates.


Russia is about to begin the "Putin 5.0 Era". Next, Putin will serve as President of Russia for at least another 6 years, and possibly 12 years.


Before that, Putin had been the president of Russia for 20 years.


In 2000, Putin won the presidential election for the first time and was successfully re-elected in 2004. He served as president for two terms for a total of eight years. Since the Russian constitution stipulates that the president can only be re-elected once, Putin did not participate in the 2008 presidential election. Then Prime Minister Medvedev won the election to become president that year and nominated Putin as prime minister.


In his first year as president, Medvedev pushed for and signed a constitutional amendment to extend the term of the Russian president from four to six years. After Medvedev's term ended, Putin ran for president again in 2012 and started his third presidential career with an overwhelming vote rate. He was successfully re-elected six years later in 2018 until 2024.


According to the "term clearing" clause of the 2020 Russian Constitutional Amendment, the number of times the existing president has been elected is "cleared" and recalculated. Therefore, this election can be regarded as a "new" election in a "legal sense". After Putin wins the election, he can seek re-election until 2036 after the end of this term.


"Give me twenty years and I will give you a strong Russia." This is Putin's bold statement that has been widely circulated in the market. Although many experts have verified that this sentence did not come from Putin's mouth, people who follow Putin and Russia may have it. This feeling is indeed Putin’s “Russian dream”.


Now, 20 years have passed under Putin's rule. Is Russia strong? Give him another 6 or 12 years, where will he take Russia? Can it bring out a strong Russia?

Before that, Putin had been the president of Russia for 20 years.


In 2000, Putin won the presidential election for the first time and was successfully re-elected in 2004. He served as president for two terms for a total of eight years. Since the Russian constitution stipulates that the president can only be re-elected once, Putin did not participate in the 2008 presidential election. Then Prime Minister Medvedev won the election to become president that year and nominated Putin as prime minister.


In his first year as president, Medvedev pushed for and signed a constitutional amendment to extend the term of the Russian president from four to six years. After Medvedev's term ended, Putin ran for president again in 2012 and started his third presidential career with an overwhelming vote rate. He was successfully re-elected six years later in 2018 until 2024.


According to the "term clearing" clause of the 2020 Russian Constitutional Amendment, the number of times the existing president has been elected is "cleared" and recalculated. Therefore, this election can be regarded as a "new" election in a "legal sense". After Putin wins the election, he can seek re-election until 2036 after the end of this term.


"Give me twenty years and I will give you a strong Russia." This is Putin's bold statement that has been widely circulated in the market. Although many experts have verified that this sentence did not come from Putin's mouth, people who follow Putin and Russia may have it. This feeling is indeed Putin’s “Russian dream”.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Результаты выборов президента России. Инфографика
Политика
В Москве по итогам онлайн-голосования Путин набирает 89,1%, сообщила председатель Мосгоризбиркома Ольга Кириллова. У Даванкова — 4,4%, у Харитонова — 3,3%, у Слуцкого — 3,2%. На участках после обработки 100% протоколов Путин в Москве набирает 85,13%, сообщила ЦИК. На втором месте — Даванков с 6,65% голосов, далее идут Харитонов (3,84%) и Слуцкий (2,83%).
В Санкт-Петербурге после обработки 99,29% протоколов Путин набирает 81,65% голосов, сообщил председатель горизбиркома Максим Мейксин. Даванков получает 7,01%, Слуцкий — 5,13%, Николай Харитонов — 3,49%.
Во всех новых регионах обработаны 100% протоколов участковых избирательных комиссий. В Херсонской области у Путина 88,12%, в Запорожской — 92,83%, в ЛНР — 94,12%, в ДНР — 95,23%. Явка на подконтрольной России части Харьковской области составила 92%, сообщил глава военно-гражданской администрации Виталий Ганчев.
После обработки 100% в Якутии Путин получает 87,79%, на Чукотке — 90,49%, в Хакасии — 85,28%, на Колыме — 84,89%, в Хабаровском крае — 80,06%, в Забайкальском — 87,71%. В Чечне после обработки всех протоколов он набрал 98,99%. В Крыму — 93,60%.
На выборах в 2018 году Путин набрал 76,69%, и это был рекордный для него показатель.
Явка по всей России составила рекордные 77,44%, в голосовании приняли участие 87 млн 113 тыс. россиян, сообщила глава ЦИК Элла Памфилова. По ее словам, 15 марта явка превысила 36%, 16-го — 22%, 17-го — 18%. Досрочно проголосовали 2,6 млн человек.
За рубежом по состоянию на 8:30 мск 18 марта в голосовании приняли участие свыше 372,7 тыс. человек, сообщила представитель МИДа Мария Захарова.
translation:
Results of the Russian presidential elections. Infographics
Policy
In Moscow, according to the results of online voting, Putin gains 89.1%, said Olga Kirillova, Chairman of the Moscow City Election Commission. Davankov has 4.4%, Kharitonov has 3.3%, Slutsky has 3.2%. At the polling stations, after processing 100% of the protocols, Putin in Moscow gains 85.13%, the Central Election Commission reported. In second place is Davankov with 6.65% of the votes, followed by Kharitonov (3.84%) and Slutsky (2.83%).
In St. Petersburg, after processing 99.29% of the protocols, Putin gains 81.65% of the votes, said Maxim Meiksin, chairman of the city election commission. Davankov receives 7.01%, Slutsky - 5.13%, Nikolai Kharitonov - 3.49%.
In all new regions, 100% of the protocols of precinct election commissions have been processed. In the Kherson region, Putin has 88.12%, in Zaporozhye - 92.83%, in the LPR - 94.12%, in the DPR - 95.23%. The turnout in the Russian-controlled part of the Kharkov region was 92%, said the head of the military-civil administration Vitaly Ganchev.
After processing 100% in Yakutia, Putin receives 87.79%, in Chukotka - 90.49%, in Khakassia - 85.28%, in Kolyma - 84.89%, in the Khabarovsk Territory - 80.06%, in Transbaikal Territory - 87 .71%. In Chechnya, after processing all the protocols, he scored 98.99%. In Crimea - 93.60%.
In the 2018 elections, Putin won 76.69%, which was a record figure for him.
The turnout throughout Russia was a record 77.44%, 87 million 113 thousand Russians took part in the voting, said the head of the Central Election Commission Ella Pamfilova. According to her, on March 15 the turnout exceeded 36%, on the 16th - 22%, on the 17th - 18%. 2.6 million people voted early.
Abroad, as of 8:30 Moscow time on March 18, over 372.7 thousand people took part in the voting, said Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova.
input:
Results of the Russian presidential elections. Infographics
Policy
In Moscow, according to the results of online voting, Putin gains 89.1%, said Olga Kirillova, Chairman of the Moscow City Election Commission. Davankov has 4.4%, Kharitonov has 3.3%, Slutsky has 3.2%. At the polling stations, after processing 100% of the protocols, Putin in Moscow gains 85.13%, the Central Election Commission reported. In second place is Davankov with 6.65% of the votes, followed by Kharitonov (3.84%) and Slutsky (2.83%).
In St. Petersburg, after processing 99.29% of the protocols, Putin gains 81.65% of the votes, said Maxim Meiksin, chairman of the city election commission. Davankov receives 7.01%, Slutsky - 5.13%, Nikolai Kharitonov - 3.49%.
In all new regions, 100% of the protocols of precinct election commissions have been processed. In the Kherson region, Putin has 88.12%, in Zaporozhye - 92.83%, in the LPR - 94.12%, in the DPR - 95.23%. The turnout in the Russian-controlled part of the Kharkov region was 92%, said the head of the military-civil administration Vitaly Ganchev.
After processing 100% in Yakutia, Putin receives 87.79%, in Chukotka - 90.49%, in Khakassia - 85.28%, in Kolyma - 84.89%, in the Khabarovsk Territory - 80.06%, in Transbaikal Territory - 87 .71%. In Chechnya, after processing all the protocols, he scored 98.99%. In Crimea - 93.60%.
In the 2018 elections, Putin won 76.69%, which was a record figure for him.
The turnout throughout Russia was a record 77.44%, 87 million 113 thousand Russians took part in the voting, said the head of the Central Election Commission Ella Pamfilova. According to her, on March 15 the turnout exceeded 36%, on the 16th - 22%, on the 17th - 18%. 2.6 million people voted early.
Abroad, as of 8:30 Moscow time on March 18, over 372.7 thousand people took part in the voting, said Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
普京在2月29日发表的国情咨文中，虽然在开头和结尾处赞扬了俄武装力量所取得的成就，但咨文的大部分内容——这是他自1999年首次担任总统以来发表的19篇咨文中最长的一篇——主要罗列了内政的成就、计划和目标，与“特别军事行动”本身几乎没有直接关联。
另外，普京的高支持率一定程度上掩盖了总理米舒斯京的受欢迎程度。西方大举经济制裁的背景下，米舒斯京也拿到了较高的支持率。因此一些观察家认为，俄民众对米舒斯京的接受度其实显示了他们对俄内政和民生的关心。
根据列瓦达等民调机构的调查，真正热衷于支持军事行动的俄罗斯人并没有想象的多。调查结果显示大多数俄罗斯人倾向于开始和谈，尽管他们口中的和谈与乌克兰人所设想的和谈可能在内容上大相径庭。
从长远来看，农村地区的俄罗斯人还会有更多麻烦需要担心：人口更少的下一代可能会看到一个功能日益衰退的俄罗斯，其道路、住房、学校、医疗保健和其他基础设施都将持续恶化。
因此，对于持续渲染“乌克兰倒了会轮到欧洲”的西方舆论，尼基塔和很多村民们一样感到有些可笑。“西方人到底是搞不对这个道理：俄罗斯的问题不是想占领世界，获得无穷无尽的土地。我们现在的问题是，从哪里弄来足够的人，把现在已有的广袤土地填满，让它不至于荒芜。”尼基塔说。
新“领土”上的新“选民”
与2018年的选举相比，今年又有四个新的“州”加入其中，分别是卢甘斯克、顿涅茨克、扎波罗热和赫尔松。这些土地上的人口首次参加俄总统选举。
顿涅茨克人卡丽娜来自一个典型的苏联式多民族家庭，祖辈从苏联各地迁居而来，家庭成员没有缺席卫国战争和工业建设等苏联的标志性历史时刻。她的身上有鞑靼、俄罗斯和中亚血统。
“五湖四海的苏联人来到顿巴斯，在这里抗击德国法西斯、参与采矿和工业建设，最后结婚生儿育女。这不光是我自己的‘家庭神话’，更是成千上万顿巴斯人真实的家族史。
translation:
In his State of the Union address delivered on February 29, although Putin praised the achievements of the Russian armed forces at the beginning and end, most of the content of the address—the 19 he has delivered since he first became president in 1999— The longest part of the speech - mainly listing the achievements, plans and goals of domestic affairs, has almost no direct connection with the "special military operations" itself.
In addition, Putin’s high approval rating has to some extent concealed the popularity of Prime Minister Mishustin. Against the background of massive Western economic sanctions, Mishustin has also received high approval ratings. Therefore, some observers believe that the Russian people's acceptance of Mishustin actually shows their concern for Russia's internal affairs and people's livelihood.
According to surveys conducted by polling organizations such as Levada, not as many Russians are really keen on supporting military action as imagined. The survey results show that most Russians prefer to start peace talks, although the content of the peace talks they say and the peace talks envisioned by Ukrainians may be very different.
In the long term, rural Russians will have more troubles to worry about: The next generation with a smaller population may see an increasingly functional Russia with roads, housing, schools, health care and other infrastructure. will continue to worsen.
Therefore, Nikita, like many villagers, feels a little ridiculous about the Western public opinion that continues to exaggerate that "if Ukraine falls, it will be Europe's turn." "Westerners have failed to understand this truth: Russia's problem is not to occupy the world and obtain endless land. Our problem now is where to get enough people to fill the existing vast land and make it It won’t be deserted,” Nikita said.
New “voters” in new “territory”
Compared with the 2018 election, four new "regions" have joined this year, namely Luhansk, Donetsk, Zaporozhye and Kherson. For the first time, the population of these lands participated in the Russian presidential election.
Karina, a native of Donetsk, comes from a typical Soviet-style multi-ethnic family. Her ancestors moved from all over the Soviet Union. Family members have not been absent from the Soviet Union's iconic historical moments such as the Great Patriotic War and industrial construction. She is of Tatar, Russian and Central Asian descent.
"Soviet people from all over the world came to Donbas, where they fought against German fascism, participated in mining and industrial construction, and finally got married and had children. This is not only my own 'family myth', but also that of thousands of Donbass A person’s true family history.

Against the background of massive Western economic sanctions, Mishustin has also received high approval ratings. Therefore, some observers believe that the Russian people's acceptance of Mishustin actually shows their concern for Russia's internal affairs and people's livelihood.
According to surveys conducted by polling organizations such as Levada, not as many Russians are really keen on supporting military action as imagined. The survey results show that most Russians prefer to start peace talks, although the content of the peace talks they say and the peace talks envisioned by Ukrainians may be very different.
In the long term, rural Russians will have more troubles to worry about: The next generation with a smaller population may see an increasingly functional Russia with roads, housing, schools, health care and other infrastructure. will continue to worsen.
Therefore, Nikita, like many villagers, feels a little ridiculous about the Western public opinion that continues to exaggerate that "if Ukraine falls, it will be Europe's turn." "Westerners have failed to understand this truth: Russia's problem is not to occupy the world and obtain endless land. Our problem now is where to get enough people to fill the existing vast land and make it It won’t be deserted,” Nikita said.

Karina, a native of Donetsk, comes from a typical Soviet-style multi-ethnic family. Her ancestors moved from all over the Soviet Union. Family members have not been absent from the Soviet Union's iconic historical moments such as the Great Patriotic War and industrial construction. She is of Tatar, Russian and Central Asian descent.

title: Set to win presidential election, Putin vows to achieve national goals
content:
MOSCOW - Russia's incumbent President and presidential candidate Vladimir Putin, who is set to win reelection, said he would do his utmost to achieve national development goals on Monday morning.

Putin has won 87.32 percent of the vote after 95.04 percent of all ballots were counted, according to data from the Russian Central Election Commission as of Monday morning.

Under Russia's presidential election regulations, a candidate who receives more than 50 percent of the votes will secure victory.

Putin said at the campaign headquarters in Moscow that he would do his best to achieve the national development goals in all directions.

Russia kicked off its three-day presidential election on Friday. The final results will be confirmed no later than March 28 by the CEC and will be announced within three days of confirmation.
input:
MOSCOW - Russia's incumbent President and presidential candidate Vladimir Putin, who is set to win reelection, said he would do his utmost to achieve national development goals on Monday morning.

Putin has won 87.32 percent of the vote after 95.04 percent of all ballots were counted, according to data from the Russian Central Election Commission as of Monday morning.

Under Russia's presidential election regulations, a candidate who receives more than 50 percent of the votes will secure victory.

Putin said at the campaign headquarters in Moscow that he would do his best to achieve the national development goals in all directions.

Russia kicked off its three-day presidential election on Friday. The final results will be confirmed no later than March 28 by the CEC and will be announced within three days of confirmation.

title: 俄罗斯大选：普京宣布压倒性胜利，赞俄罗斯民主优于很多西方国家 - BBC News 中文
content:
普京在选举后的记者会上提到纳瓦尔尼，是他数年来首次公开提及其名字。
普京证实此前的报道，指他曾考虑用纳瓦尔尼交换被关押在西方的囚犯，前提是纳瓦尔尼永远不回俄罗斯。
“我说过我支持，但不幸的是，发生的事情就发生了。你能做什么？人生就是这样。”
外界解读普京这番言论，是想反驳他杀害纳瓦尔尼的广泛指控。
纳瓦尔遗孀尤利娅·纳瓦尔纳娅(Yulia Navalnaya)在俄罗斯驻柏林大使馆排队六个小时投票，她形容这是抗议选举的一部分，说自己将已故丈夫的名字写在选票上，并感谢所有到场的人，指他们给了她希望，“一切都不是白费”。
在伦敦，一名抗议选民说她排队七小时才能投票。
在美国华盛顿，活动人士兼律师索博尔（Lyubov Sobol）表示，抗议选票不会反映在克里姆林宫的选举结果中，"但这种团结、这种象征仍然很重要”。
俄罗斯总统选举从来不是公平的竞争。克里姆林宫严格控制政治制度、媒体和选举。
共产党候选人哈里托诺夫 (Nikolai Kharitonov) 得票率仅略高于4%，其他候选人更低。
三人都难以被称为认真的候选人，哈里托诺夫甚至在选举前称赞总统“努力巩固国家在所有领域的胜利”。
数百万俄罗斯人投票支持普京第五次担任总统，部分原因是他们认为没有可信的替代人选。
但这完全是因为克里姆林宫已经将任何可能的挑战者从政治舞台上清除。反对者要么入狱，要么流亡，要么丧生。
此前，反战政客纳杰日丁（Boris Nadezhdin）有意参选，但上月获得大量俄罗斯人排队登记支持后，中央选举委员会就取消了他的参选资格。
translation:
Putin mentioned Navalny at a post-election press conference, the first time he has mentioned his name publicly in several years.
Putin confirmed previous reports that he had considered exchanging Navalny for prisoners held in the West, provided that Navalny never returned to Russia.
"I said I supported it, but unfortunately, what happened happened. What can you do? That's how life goes."
The outside world interpreted Putin's remarks as an attempt to refute widespread accusations that he killed Navalny.
Navalnaya's widow, Yulia Navalnaya, queued for six hours to vote at the Russian embassy in Berlin, describing it as part of a protest against the election, saying she put her late husband's name on the ballot and She thanked everyone present, saying that they gave her hope that "everything is not in vain."
In London, one protesting voter said she queued for seven hours to cast her vote.
In Washington, US, activist and lawyer Lyubov Sobol said the protest votes would not be reflected in the Kremlin's election results, "but this solidarity, this symbol is still important."
Russian presidential elections are never a fair contest. The Kremlin tightly controls the political system, media and elections.
Communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov received just over 4% of the vote, with other candidates even lower.
None of the three could be called serious candidates, with Kharitonov even praising the president before the election for his "efforts to consolidate the country's victory in all areas."
Millions of Russians voted for Putin to become president for a fifth term, in part because they saw no credible alternative.
But that's all because the Kremlin has eliminated any possible challengers from the political scene. Opponents were imprisoned, exiled or killed.
Previously, anti-war politician Boris Nadezhdin intended to run, but after a large number of Russians lined up to register for support last month, the Central Election Commission disqualified him.
input:
Putin mentioned Navalny at a post-election press conference, the first time he has mentioned his name publicly in several years.
Putin confirmed previous reports that he had considered exchanging Navalny for prisoners held in the West, provided that Navalny never returned to Russia.
"I said I supported it, but unfortunately, what happened happened. What can you do? That's how life goes."
The outside world interpreted Putin's remarks as an attempt to refute widespread accusations that he killed Navalny.
Navalnaya's widow, Yulia Navalnaya, queued for six hours to vote at the Russian embassy in Berlin, describing it as part of a protest against the election, saying she put her late husband's name on the ballot and She thanked everyone present, saying that they gave her hope that "everything is not in vain."
In London, one protesting voter said she queued for seven hours to cast her vote.
In Washington, US, activist and lawyer Lyubov Sobol said the protest votes would not be reflected in the Kremlin's election results, "but this solidarity, this symbol is still important."
Russian presidential elections are never a fair contest. The Kremlin tightly controls the political system, media and elections.
Communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov received just over 4% of the vote, with other candidates even lower.
None of the three could be called serious candidates, with Kharitonov even praising the president before the election for his "efforts to consolidate the country's victory in all areas."
Millions of Russians voted for Putin to become president for a fifth term, in part because they saw no credible alternative.
But that's all because the Kremlin has eliminated any possible challengers from the political scene. Opponents were imprisoned, exiled or killed.
Previously, anti-war politician Boris Nadezhdin intended to run, but after a large number of Russians lined up to register for support last month, the Central Election Commission disqualified him.

title: 俄罗斯中选委：已有16名候选人报名参加明年俄总统选举
content:
据《参考消息》援引法新社20日报道，俄罗斯官员于20日表示，已有16名候选人报名参加明年3月15日举行的总统选举。
报道称，俄中央选举委员会（中选委）主席埃拉·帕姆菲洛娃表示，“到目前为止，我们已收到16人成为俄罗斯总统职位候选人的申请。”中选委还表示，届时，俄罗斯将在其控制的乌克兰四个地区以及克里米亚半岛举行大选投票。
据悉，俄罗斯自由民主党本周提名俄罗斯国家杜马国际事务委员会主席列昂尼德•斯卢茨基(Leonid Slutsky)为候选人。斯卢茨基表示，他的参选不会“夺走普京的选票”。今年10月，前俄国家杜马（议会下院）议员鲍里斯·纳杰日丁宣布通过其现所在的“公民倡议党”参选，该党不在俄国家杜马的五党之中。今年11月，来自莫斯科北部特维尔州的记者叶卡捷琳娜·邓佐娃则宣布将以独立候选人的身份参选，并宣布将开始征集签名。
根据俄联邦总统选举法，总统候选人可以政党提名和自荐两种方式参选。政党在各自代表大会上推举候选人。独立候选人则必须召集一个不少于500人的倡议小组，并收集来自40个或更多地区至少30万个支持者签名。独立候选人收集的签名将递呈俄中央选举委员会，该委员会在收到签名10日内完成签名认证工作并决定是否登记该独立候选人为总统候选人。
据中新社此前报道，12月8日，普京在克里姆林宫举行的一场活动上和与会者对话时表示，自己将竞选总统。据克里姆林宫网站18日消息，普京当天前往俄罗斯联邦中央选举委员会，提交了以自荐方式参加2024年总统选举的相关文件。
translation:
According to "Reference News" citing a report from Agence France-Presse on the 20th, Russian officials stated on the 20th that 16 candidates have signed up to participate in the presidential election to be held on March 15 next year.
According to the report, Ella Pamfilova, chairperson of Russia’s Central Election Commission (Central Election Commission), said, “So far, we have received applications from 16 people to become candidates for the position of President of Russia.” The Central Election Commission also stated that by then, Russia will hold general elections in four regions of Ukraine it controls, as well as the Crimean peninsula.
It is reported that the Russian Liberal Democratic Party nominated Leonid Slutsky, chairman of the Russian State Duma's International Affairs Committee, as its candidate this week. Slutsky said his candidacy would not "take votes away from Putin." In October this year, former Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament) member Boris Nadezdin announced his candidacy through his current "Citizen Initiative Party", which is not among the five parties in the Russian State Duma. In November of this year, journalist Ekaterina Duntsova from Tver Oblast north of Moscow announced that she would run as an independent candidate and announced that she would start collecting signatures.
According to the Presidential Election Law of the Russian Federation, presidential candidates can run for election in two ways: nominated by political parties or self-recommended. Political parties nominate candidates at their respective congresses. Independent candidates must convene an advocacy group of no less than 500 people and collect at least 300,000 signatures from supporters in 40 or more regions. The signatures collected by independent candidates will be submitted to the Russian Central Election Commission, which will complete signature verification within 10 days of receiving the signatures and decide whether to register the independent candidate as a presidential candidate.
According to a previous report by China News Service, on December 8, Putin stated that he would run for president during a conversation with participants at an event held in the Kremlin. According to the Kremlin website on the 18th, Putin went to the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation that day and submitted relevant documents to participate in the 2024 presidential election by self-recommendation.

It is reported that the Russian Liberal Democratic Party nominated Leonid Slutsky, chairman of the Russian State Duma's International Affairs Committee, as its candidate this week. Slutsky said his candidacy would not "take votes away from Putin." In October this year, former Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament) member Boris Nadezdin announced his candidacy through his current "Citizen Initiative Party", which is not among the five parties in the Russian State Duma. title: 俄大选最后一天：“中午反普京”行动引爆全球-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
content:
这家俄罗斯通讯社还说，乌克兰“破坏分子”星期六也试图从苏梅州居民点波波夫卡方向以及从别尔哥罗德州斯波达柳什诺和科津卡方向越境向俄罗斯渗透，但是被俄军击退，乌军因此损失30名官兵、两辆装甲车、三辆坦克和两套多管火箭炮发射车。
与此同时，乌克兰七个州星期天凌晨陆续拉响防空警报。俄罗斯对乌克兰关键基础设施实施空袭已经成为家常便饭。
乌克兰军方周日表示，在黑海的港口城市敖德萨，俄罗斯的连夜空袭摧毁了农业企业和几个工业建筑。
乌克兰防空部队在电报社媒平台上说，俄罗斯发动了16架无人机和7枚导弹袭击，14架无人机在敖德萨地区被击落。
路透社说，尽管此次大选的选票上根本没有普京的对手，克里姆林宫还是希望看到超高的投票率，以表明普京发动的乌克兰战争得到绝大多数民众的支持。俄罗斯官员表示，在星期五、六两天的投票中，全国选民的投票率已经冲到60%。
两位反对乌克兰战争并且真正得到许多俄罗斯民众支持的候选人被克里姆林宫禁止参选，而对普京威胁最大的反对派领导人奥列克西·纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）上个月在西伯利亚北极圈内的一个监狱中突然离奇死亡。
纳瓦尔尼的支持者呼吁俄罗斯民众在投票日的最后一天中午前往各地的投票所，但是不投票，只是现身表达无声的抗议。这项得到纳瓦尔尼生前认可的抗议行动被称为“中午反普京”示威活动。
translation:
The Russian news agency also said that Ukrainian "saboteurs" also tried to infiltrate into Russia on Saturday from the direction of Popovka, a settlement in Sumy Oblast, and from the direction of Spotlyushno and Kozinka in Belgorod Oblast, but were blocked by Russia. The army was repelled, and the Ukrainian army lost 30 officers and soldiers, two armored vehicles, three tanks and two sets of multiple rocket launchers.
At the same time, air defense sirens were sounded in seven Ukrainian states early Sunday morning. Russian air strikes on critical infrastructure in Ukraine have become routine.
Ukraine's military said on Sunday that overnight Russian air strikes destroyed agricultural businesses and several industrial buildings in the Black Sea port city of Odessa.
The Ukrainian Air Defense Force said on the Telegram social media platform that Russia launched 16 drones and 7 missile attacks, and 14 drones were shot down in the Odessa area.
Reuters said that although there is no opponent for Putin on the ballot in this election, the Kremlin still hopes to see a very high turnout to show that Putin’s war in Ukraine has the support of the vast majority of the people. Russian officials said that in the two-day voting on Friday and Saturday, the national voter turnout rate had reached 60%.
Two candidates who oppose the war in Ukraine and have real support from many Russians have been banned from running by the Kremlin, while Alexei Navalny, the opposition leader who poses the greatest threat to Putin, was in the Siberian Arctic last month. A sudden and mysterious death occurred in a prison within the circle.
Navalny's supporters called on Russian people to go to polling stations around noon on the last day of voting, but not to vote, but to show up to express silent protest. This protest action, which was approved by Navalny during his lifetime, was called the "Noon Anti-Putin" demonstration.
input:
The Russian news agency also said that Ukrainian "saboteurs" also tried to infiltrate into Russia on Saturday from the direction of Popovka, a settlement in Sumy Oblast, and from the direction of Spotlyushno and Kozinka in Belgorod Oblast, but were blocked by Russia. The army was repelled, and the Ukrainian army lost 30 officers and soldiers, two armored vehicles, three tanks and two sets of multiple rocket launchers.
At the same time, air defense sirens were sounded in seven Ukrainian states early Sunday morning. Russian air strikes on critical infrastructure in Ukraine have become routine.
Ukraine's military said on Sunday that overnight Russian air strikes destroyed agricultural businesses and several industrial buildings in the Black Sea port city of Odessa.
The Ukrainian Air Defense Force said on the Telegram social media platform that Russia launched 16 drones and 7 missile attacks, and 14 drones were shot down in the Odessa area.
Reuters said that although there is no opponent for Putin on the ballot in this election, the Kremlin still hopes to see a very high turnout to show that Putin’s war in Ukraine has the support of the vast majority of the people. Russian officials said that in the two-day voting on Friday and Saturday, the national voter turnout rate had reached 60%.
Two candidates who oppose the war in Ukraine and have real support from many Russians have been banned from running by the Kremlin, while Alexei Navalny, the opposition leader who poses the greatest threat to Putin, was in the Siberian Arctic last month. A sudden and mysterious death occurred in a prison within the circle.
Navalny's supporters called on Russian people to go to polling stations around noon on the last day of voting, but not to vote, but to show up to express silent protest. This protest action, which was approved by Navalny during his lifetime, was called the "Noon Anti-Putin" demonstration.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
content:
Как проходили выборы
Впервые в истории президентские выборы проходили в России в течение трех дней. Соответствующая законодательная норма была закреплена в законе «О выборах президента Российской Федерации» 14 марта 2022 года. По этому документу решение о многодневном голосовании (не более трех дней) принимает ЦИК, который 8 декабря 2023 года постановил провести голосование именно в таком формате — 15, 16 и 17 марта. Это объяснялось целями «создания дополнительных возможностей реализации избирательных прав граждан».

Избирательное законодательство разрешает проведение досрочного голосования на участках в труднодоступных или отдаленных местностях, на находящихся в плавании судах, на полярных станциях, а также в странах, где нет российских дипломатических миссий. 14 марта 2024 года председатель ЦИК Элла Памфилова сообщила, что в 42 регионах проголосовали досрочно свыше двух миллионов избирателей. Для сравнения: на президентских выборах 2018 года, по данным ЦИК, в досрочном голосовании приняли участие 268 163 человека.
translation:
How the elections took place
For the first time in history, presidential elections were held in Russia over three days. The corresponding legislative norm was enshrined in the law “On the elections of the President of the Russian Federation” on March 14, 2022. According to this document, the decision on multi-day voting (no more than three days) is made by the Central Election Commission, which on December 8, 2023 decided to hold voting in exactly this format - on March 15, 16 and 17. This was explained by the goals of “creating additional opportunities for the implementation of citizens’ voting rights.”

Election legislation allows for early voting at polling stations in hard-to-reach or remote areas, on ships at sea, at polar stations, as well as in countries where there are no Russian diplomatic missions. On March 14, 2024, CEC Chairman Ella Pamfilova reported that more than two million voters voted early in 42 regions. For comparison: in the 2018 presidential elections, according to the Central Election Commission, 268,163 people took part in early voting.
input:
How the elections took place
For the first time in history, presidential elections were held in Russia over three days. The corresponding legislative norm was enshrined in the law “On the elections of the President of the Russian Federation” on March 14, 2022. According to this document, the decision on multi-day voting (no more than three days) is made by the Central Election Commission, which on December 8, 2023 decided to hold voting in exactly this format - on March 15, 16 and 17. This was explained by the goals of “creating additional opportunities for the implementation of citizens’ voting rights.”

Election legislation allows for early voting at polling stations in hard-to-reach or remote areas, on ships at sea, at polar stations, as well as in countries where there are no Russian diplomatic missions. On March 14, 2024, CEC Chairman Ella Pamfilova reported that more than two million voters voted early in 42 regions. For comparison: in the 2018 presidential elections, according to the Central Election Commission, 268,163 people took part in early voting.

title: 俄议会通过宪法修正案二读草案，普京再度参选总统出现可能
content:
当地时间3月10日，俄罗斯国家杜马（议会下院）通过《俄罗斯联邦宪法》修正案（以下简称“宪法修正案”）草案二读。
据俄新社3月10日消息，俄国家杜马当日对宪法修正案草案进行二读，参加国家杜马全会的382名代表对草案投出赞成票，44名代表弃权，无人反对。在为二读草案做筹备时，国家杜马就国家建设和立法收到了近400项宪法修正案意见，其中约200条被纳入考量。
10日当天，俄罗斯总统普京赴国家杜马发表讲话，表示不同意在俄宪法中取消俄罗斯总统任期次数限制，但也流露出在宪法修订后再度参选总统的意思。
据俄新社，在普京抵达会场前，“统一俄罗斯党”议员、世界首位女性宇航员瓦莲京娜·捷列什科娃提议称，应在宪法修正案中取消总统任期次数限制，或者在宪法修正案生效后，现任总统的任期应从零开始计算。
“提议取消总统任期次数限制，或者在修正案中加入一条：新宪法生效后，现任总统与其他公民一样，有权竞选国家总统。”捷列什科娃说道。
普京就此回应称，从宪法中去除总统任期限制并不合理。从长远来看，社会应该保证权力更迭的发生，这是国家发展所必需的。
“我相信并深信，强大的总统权力对我们国家绝对必要。但是，公众应该保证选举（包括总统选举）是公开的、具有竞争性的。”普京进一步说道。
另据“今日俄罗斯”（RT）10日报道，普京不反对在2024年再度竞选总统的这种可能性。他认为权力更迭对于俄罗斯的动态发展至关重要，但他也表示，如果修正案获得宪法法院的批准，前国家元首应该能够根据更新后的宪法参加新的总统竞选。对于这一设想，普京强调，在4月22日即将举行的全民公投中，“只有公民支持这样的提议”，这样的提议才能成为现实。
普京还说：“鉴于修宪的倡议来自我，我想在这里表达我的立场。宪法修正案早已成熟，我坚信修正案将对我们的公民有用，它将加强我们的主权、我们的传统和我们的价值观。”他表示希望能和国家杜马议员齐心协力为国家做事，直到2024年，“到时候再看事态如何发展”。
据俄媒此前报道，若二读进展顺利，俄国家杜马将于莫斯科时间3月11日10时对宪法修正案草案进行三读。然后由联邦委员会表决通过，之后须有三分之二的俄联邦主体立法会议（地方议会）通过，再经宪法法院审查具体条款，最后提交全民公投。
全民公投定于4月22日举行。若有超半数参与投票公民支持，则宪法修正案于投票结果公布之日起生效。
普京1月15日向俄议会两院发表国情咨文时提议修改宪法，并于当天组建修宪工作组。1月20日，普京向俄国家杜马提交宪法修正案草案。3月2日，普京向国家杜马提交宪法修正案二读草案。
translation:
On March 10, local time, the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament) passed the second reading of the draft amendment to the Constitution of the Russian Federation (hereinafter referred to as the "Constitutional Amendment").
According to RIA Novosti news on March 10, the Russian State Duma held a second reading of the draft amendment to the constitution that day. 382 deputies who participated in the State Duma plenary session voted in favor of the draft, 44 deputies abstained, and no one objected. In preparation for the second reading of the draft, the State Duma received nearly 400 opinions on constitutional amendments regarding state construction and legislation, of which about 200 were taken into consideration.
On the 10th, Russian President Vladimir Putin went to the State Duma to deliver a speech, expressing his disagreement with the removal of the limit on the number of Russian presidential terms in the Russian constitution, but also revealed his intention to run for president again after the constitution is revised.
According to RIA Novosti, before Putin arrived at the meeting, Valentina Tereshkova, a member of the "United Russia Party" and the world's first female astronaut, proposed that the limit on the number of presidential terms should be removed from the constitutional amendment, or that the limit on the number of presidential terms should be removed. After the constitutional amendment takes effect, the current president's term of office shall be counted from zero.
"It is proposed to remove the limit on the number of presidential terms, or to add a clause in the amendment: after the new constitution takes effect, the current president, like other citizens, has the right to run for president of the country." Tereshkova said.
Putin responded by saying that removing presidential term limits from the constitution was unreasonable. In the long run, society should ensure that the change of power occurs, which is necessary for national development.
"I believe and am convinced that strong presidential power is absolutely necessary for our country. However, the public should guarantee that elections (including presidential elections) are open and competitive." Putin further said.
According to a report by "Russia Today" (RT) on the 10th, Putin is not opposed to the possibility of running for president again in 2024. He considered a change of power crucial to Russia's dynamics, but also said that if the amendments are approved by the Constitutional Court, the former head of state should be able to run for office in a new presidential election under the updated constitution. Regarding this idea, Putin emphasized that in the upcoming referendum on April 22, "only if citizens support such a proposal" can such a proposal become a reality.
Putin also said: "Since the initiative to amend the constitution comes from me, I would like to express my position here. The constitutional amendment has long been mature, and I firmly believe that the amendment will be useful to our citizens, it will strengthen our sovereignty, our traditions and Our values." He said he hopes to work together with members of the State Duma to work for the country until 2024, "and we will see how things develop then."
According to previous reports by Russian media, if the second reading goes well, the Russian State Duma will conduct a third reading of the draft constitutional amendment at 10:00 Moscow time on March 11. It will then be voted upon by the Federation Council, followed by approval by two-thirds of the legislative assemblies (local assemblies) of the subjects of the Russian Federation, and then reviewed by the Constitutional Court for specific provisions, and finally submitted to a referendum.
The referendum is scheduled for April 22. If more than half of the citizens who vote support it, the constitutional amendment will take effect on the day the voting results are announced.
Putin proposed amending the constitution when delivering a State of the Union address to both houses of the Russian Parliament on January 15, and a constitutional amendment working group was formed on the same day. On January 20, Putin submitted a draft constitutional amendment to the Russian State Duma. On March 2, Putin submitted the second reading draft of the constitutional amendment to the State Duma.
input:
On March 10, local time, the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament) passed the second reading of the draft amendment to the Constitution of the Russian Federation (hereinafter referred to as the "Constitutional Amendment").
According to RIA Novosti news on March 10, the Russian State Duma held a second reading of the draft amendment to the constitution that day. 382 deputies who participated in the State Duma plenary session voted in favor of the draft, 44 deputies abstained, and no one objected. He considered a change of power crucial to Russia's dynamics, but also said that if the amendments are approved by the Constitutional Court, the former head of state should be able to run for office in a new presidential election under the updated constitution. Regarding this idea, Putin emphasized that in the upcoming referendum on April 22, "only if citizens support such a proposal" can such a proposal become a reality.
