title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Реакция кандидатов
Николай Харитонов: «Мы отработали честно и добросовестно нашу программу в ходе выборов». «Россияне на выборах президента показали, как можно сплотиться всей страной», — сказал он. Лидер КПРФ Геннадий Зюганов сообщил, что Харитонов встретится с Путиным в понедельник, а сам он — в среду.
Владислав Даванков: «Я оцениваю эти выборы очень позитивно».
Владимир Путин приехал в свой избирательный штаб: «Я вас всех хочу поблагодарить за совместную работу. Очень важная для страны работа, которая позволяет консолидировать общество, показать правильность нашего выбора, пути и создать условия для дальнейшего движения вперед. Чтобы Россия была крепче, сильнее, эффективнее и имела возможность решать все те задачи, о которых я говорил в послании». Он также назвал целями нового срока решение задач военной операции и укрепление обороноспособности и армии России.
Леонид Слуцкий: «Мы работаем над тем, чтобы выявить малейшие нарушения, если они будут. Пока то, что нам поступает, — какие-то шероховатости очень незначительные, об этом даже говорить как о нарушениях не приходится».
translation:
Candidates' reaction
Nikolai Kharitonov: “We worked out our program honestly and conscientiously during the elections.” “The Russians showed in the presidential elections how the whole country can unite,” he said. Communist Party leader Gennady Zyuganov said that Kharitonov will meet with Putin on Monday, and he himself on Wednesday.
Vladislav Davankov: “I assess these elections very positively.”
Vladimir Putin arrived at his election headquarters: “I want to thank you all for your joint work. This is very important work for the country, which allows us to consolidate society, show the correctness of our choice and path, and create conditions for further movement forward. So that Russia is stronger, stronger, more efficient and has the opportunity to solve all the problems that I spoke about in the message.” He also named the goals of the new term to solve the problems of the military operation and strengthen the defense capability and army of Russia.
Leonid Slutsky: “We are working to identify the slightest violations, if any. So far, what we receive are some very minor irregularities; we can’t even talk about it as a violation.”
input:
Candidates' reaction
Nikolai Kharitonov: “We worked out our program honestly and conscientiously during the elections.” “The Russians showed in the presidential elections how the whole country can unite,” he said. Communist Party leader Gennady Zyuganov said that Kharitonov will meet with Putin on Monday, and he himself on Wednesday.
Vladislav Davankov: “I assess these elections very positively.”
Vladimir Putin arrived at his election headquarters: “I want to thank you all for your joint work. This is very important work for the country, which allows us to consolidate society, show the correctness of our choice and path, and create conditions for further movement forward. So that Russia is stronger, stronger, more efficient and has the opportunity to solve all the problems that I spoke about in the message.” He also named the goals of the new term to solve the problems of the military operation and strengthen the defense capability and army of Russia.
Leonid Slutsky: “We are working to identify the slightest violations, if any. So far, what we receive are some very minor irregularities; we can’t even talk about it as a violation.”

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
content:
据俄中央选举委员会公布的数据，约有1.1亿俄罗斯公民具有选举权，其中超过180万人常年居住在国外。
受访的西方观察人士认为，尽管普京会把一场选举胜利塑造成俄选民对特别军事行动的“背书”，但他把竞选活动的主要焦点都放在了国内议题上，譬如教育、经济、人口等民生问题。
“2023年地区和市选举的证据表明，热情支持战争的叙事无法动员选民，甚至会产生相反的效果。”出生于匈牙利的俄罗斯事务政治分析师András Tóth-Czifra不久前观察认为，执政的“统一俄罗斯党”于是收缩了提名战争参与者的努力；亲政府的现任竞选者通常会避免在竞选中进行战争宣传，而是将重点放在民生问题、对战场士兵的社会援助以及军事冲突带来的潜在投资机会上。
2023年，为确保社会稳定，俄执政当局采取了用重金为俄乌军事冲突招募志愿者参军的方式，不再强制征兵。此前一年的9月，俄罗斯宣布征召30万预备役人员入伍执行军事任务，一度引发大范围的社会恐慌。 
而在今年新年假期期间，在大多数装点喜庆的俄罗斯城市中，几乎没有什么东西会让人联想到乌克兰正在发生的事情。
不过，对俄罗斯边境炮击和乌克兰无人机袭击的担忧仍未消除。民众对长时间的特别军事行动在2023年年底开始显露出疲态。
但就在2月中旬，乌克兰宣布从顿涅茨克地区重镇阿夫杰耶夫卡撤军——这是乌克兰防御体系中的重要关键点，成为了俄军去年5月攻克交通要地阿尔乔莫夫斯克（乌方称巴赫穆特）以来前线发生的最大变化。俄方在战场上显现出一定优势和主动权。
“军事上，俄罗斯的势头相当明显。
translation:
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission, approximately 110 million Russian citizens have the right to vote, of which more than 1.8 million live abroad year-round.
Western observers interviewed believe that although Putin will portray an election victory as Russian voters' "endorsement" of special military operations, he has focused his campaign mainly on domestic issues, such as education, economy, Population and other livelihood issues.
“Evidence from the 2023 regional and municipal elections shows that narratives of enthusiastic support for war fail to mobilize voters and can even have the opposite effect.” András Tóth-Czifra, a Hungarian-born political analyst on Russian affairs, observed not long ago that the ruling “unity The Russian Party then scaled back its efforts to nominate war participants; pro-government incumbents typically avoided war propaganda in their campaigns, focusing instead on livelihood issues, social assistance to soldiers in the field, and the consequences of military conflicts potential investment opportunities.
In 2023, in order to ensure social stability, the Russian ruling authorities adopted the method of spending heavily to recruit volunteers for the military conflict between Russia and Ukraine, and no longer forced conscription. In September of the previous year, Russia announced the recruitment of 300,000 reservists to perform military tasks, which once triggered widespread social panic. 
And during this New Year's holiday, in most festively decorated Russian cities, there was little to suggest what was happening in Ukraine.
However, concerns about Russian border shelling and Ukrainian drone strikes remain. The public's fatigue with long-term special military operations began to show at the end of 2023.
But in mid-February, Ukraine announced its withdrawal from Avdeyevka, an important town in the Donetsk region. This was an important key point in Ukraine’s defense system and became the reason why the Russian army conquered the important transportation area Arthomo in May last year. The biggest change on the front line since the war in Fusk (called Bakhmut in Ukraine). Russia has shown certain advantages and initiative on the battlefield.
“Militarily, Russia’s momentum is quite obvious.
input:
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission, approximately 110 million Russian citizens have the right to vote, of which more than 1.8 million live abroad year-round.
Western observers interviewed believe that although Putin will portray an election victory as Russian voters' "endorsement" of special military operations, he has focused his campaign mainly on domestic issues, such as education, economy, Population and other livelihood issues.
“Evidence from the 2023 regional and municipal elections shows that narratives of enthusiastic support for war fail to mobilize voters and can even have the opposite effect.” András Tóth-Czifra, a Hungarian-born political analyst on Russian affairs, observed not long ago that the ruling “unity The Russian Party then scaled back its efforts to nominate war participants; pro-government incumbents typically avoided war propaganda in their campaigns, focusing instead on livelihood issues, social assistance to soldiers in the field, and the consequences of military conflicts potential investment opportunities.
In 2023, in order to ensure social stability, the Russian ruling authorities adopted the method of spending heavily to recruit volunteers for the military conflict between Russia and Ukraine, and no longer forced conscription. In September of the previous year, Russia announced the recruitment of 300,000 reservists to perform military tasks, which once triggered widespread social panic. 
And during this New Year's holiday, in most festively decorated Russian cities, there was little to suggest what was happening in Ukraine.
However, concerns about Russian border shelling and Ukrainian drone strikes remain. The public's fatigue with long-term special military operations began to show at the end of 2023.
But in mid-February, Ukraine announced its withdrawal from Avdeyevka, an important town in the Donetsk region. This was an important key point in Ukraine’s defense system and became the reason why the Russian army conquered the important transportation area Arthomo in May last year. The biggest change on the front line since the war in Fusk (called Bakhmut in Ukraine). Russia has shown certain advantages and initiative on the battlefield.
“Militarily, Russia’s momentum is quite obvious.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
这是一种孤岛感。玛莎，叶利尼亚镇，或者说整个俄罗斯，就像一座孤零零的堡垒，独自面对全新的外部环境。从叶利尼亚的居民视角来看，过去俄罗斯遭受了太多的不公，从苏联解体到2010年代，尊严在西方面前掉落一地。如今生活困顿，前途黯淡也就罢了，现在似乎他们一直引以为豪的伟大历史也受到了威胁。
“苏联人民——我们的祖父母们——为了卫国战争胜利奋战了四年，千万条生命被吞噬。他们不仅解放了自己的土地，还解放了整个东欧。但现在，正是那些被解放的欧洲人的后代们，竟然不敢承认他们的父母、祖父母曾经饱含感激亲吻了红军士兵的面颊和T-34坦克的履带。他们应该为健忘症感到羞耻！”在一场统一俄罗斯党的集会上，叶利尼亚镇的镇长背靠红军战士雕像和刻有“永志不忘”字样的纪念碑，面对一排排手持祖父辈照片的“不朽军团”游行人群，发出了对欧洲的愤怒指责。
“西方从来没有接受过我们，也永远不会这么做。”2022年开战之后，在数百公里之外的A村，尼基塔的邻居谢尔盖也对西方发出了类似的不满。
“但乌克兰毕竟有我们的亲人，这真的是最好的方式吗？”尼基塔试图把话头转回每日的新闻头条。
“哦，是吗？或许你会给我大谈国际法，或许你还可以讲述乌克兰人的遭遇，但没有人切身体会过我们的屈辱感，知道吗？没有人。”谢尔盖预判了话题的方向，用带着愤懑的眼神回应着尼基塔有些“出格”的言论，“先是戈尔巴乔夫，后来又是叶利钦，现在是普京，我们总是在后退，你看不到吗？”
俄罗斯坐拥世界面积最大国土，军队规模庞大，还有威慑力十足的核武库，其民众普遍对自身军事力量感到自信。因此，外人并不容易设身处地体会俄罗斯的安全困境。
当地时间2023年5月9日，俄罗斯莫斯科，在纪念二战结束78周年的红场胜利日阅兵式上，军人列队行进。

尼基塔如此向澎湃新闻记者解释这种对安全的“偏执”：“我不和你说一大堆历史了，就一条，在俄语里‘安全’这个词是безопасность，字面构词上是‘没有危险’，这和英语、法语、德语的构词方式都不一样，恐怕也和中文不一样吧。”
“语言能反映人下意识的思维方式。所以，你可以看到俄罗斯人观念中有多么害怕外来的危险。”他说。
事实上，这种心态也体现在了俄罗斯官方的话语之中。为了应对西方制裁和外部风险，俄政府制定了一揽子策略，其中被命名为“俄罗斯堡垒”（Fortress Russia）的计划旨在加大俄经济和社会的自身韧性，进一步降低对西方依赖。其实，早在与西方尚处于“蜜月”的2005年，就有俄罗斯官方智库在题为“俄罗斯堡垒”的政策文件中建议，一种有效降低对外依赖的“孤立主义”政策（乃至世界观）从长远来看是可行的。
“所谓‘孤立主义’是指一种国家存在模式，政府仅仅建立和维系相对有限的对外接触。
translation:
It’s a sense of isolation. Masha, the town of Yelnya, or Russia as a whole, is like a lonely fortress, facing a new external environment alone. From the perspective of residents of Yelniya, Russia has suffered too many injustices in the past. From the disintegration of the Soviet Union to the 2010s, dignity fell to the ground before the West. Nowadays, life is difficult and their future is bleak. Now it seems that the great history they have always been proud of is also threatened.
"The Soviet people - our grandparents - fought for four years to win the Great Patriotic War, with tens of millions of lives devoured. They not only liberated their own land, but also all of Eastern Europe. But now, it is those who were liberated The descendants of Europeans dare not admit that their parents and grandparents once kissed the cheeks of Red Army soldiers and the tracks of T-34 tanks. They should be ashamed of their amnesia. "At a United Russia party rally! With his back to the statue of a Red Army soldier and a monument engraved with the words "Never Forget", the mayor of Yelniya Town faced rows of "Immortal Legion" marchers holding photos of their grandparents, expressing his anger against Europe. Accusation.
"The West has never accepted us and will never do so." After the war started in 2022, in Village A hundreds of kilometers away, Nikita's neighbor Sergey also expressed similar dissatisfaction with the West.
"But after all, we have our relatives in Ukraine, is this really the best way?" Nikita tried to turn the conversation back to the daily news headlines.
"Oh, really? Maybe you can talk to me about international law, and maybe you can talk about what happened to the Ukrainians, but no one has experienced our humiliation, you know? No one." Sergey predicted the topic. direction, responding to Nikita’s somewhat “outrageous” remarks with angry eyes, “First it was Gorbachev, then Yeltsin, and now Putin, we are always retreating, can’t you see? "
Russia has the largest land area in the world, a large military, and a powerful nuclear arsenal. Its people generally feel confident in its military power. Therefore, it is not easy for outsiders to put themselves in Russia’s security dilemma.
On May 9, 2023 local time, in Moscow, Russia, soldiers lined up during the Victory Day military parade on Red Square to commemorate the 78th anniversary of the end of World War II.

Nikita explained this "paranoia" about security to The Paper reporter: "I won't tell you a lot of history, just one thing. The word 'security' in Russian is безопасность, which literally means ' "There is no danger." This is different from the way words are formed in English, French, and German, and I'm afraid it's also different from Chinese. "
"Language can reflect people's subconscious thinking. So you can see how afraid Russians are of external dangers," he said.
In fact, this mentality is also reflected in Russian official discourse. In order to deal with Western sanctions and external risks, the Russian government has formulated a package of strategies. Among them, the plan named "Fortress Russia" aims to increase the resilience of Russia's economy and society and further reduce its dependence on the West. In fact, as early as 2005, when relations with the West were still in the "honeymoon", a Russian official think tank suggested in a policy document titled "Fortress Russia" that an "isolationist" policy (and even a world view) that would effectively reduce foreign dependence would be It is feasible in the long run.
“The so-called ‘isolationism’ refers to a mode of national existence in which the government only establishes and maintains relatively limited external contacts.

title: Putin ‘wins’ rigged Russian election with 87 percent of the vote – POLITICO
content:
Authorities assert that the assailants — many of whom were elderly women — were acting on instructions from abroad. All involved now face the prospect of being sentenced to up to five years in prison. 
The most significant pushback against Putin occurred on Sunday at noon, when the Russian opposition rallied its supporters for a “Noon Against Putin” protest. The initiative encouraged people to go to the polls at 12 p.m. and simultaneously vote for any candidate other than the incumbent.
The noon demonstration was aimed at challenging Putin’s legitimacy, both domestically and internationally. Navalny’s widow Yulia Navalnaya joined a protest in Berlin after encouraging the noon opposition move. She told journalists after voting herself that she had written her late husband’s name on the ballot paper. 
“It cannot be that a month before the election, during the campaign, that Putin’s main opponent, who was already in prison has been killed,” she said. 
Thousands joined in similar action around the world. Unusually large crowds were seen at polling stations across Russia, from the smallest Siberian towns to Moscow and St. Petersburg, as well as at Russian embassies and consulates worldwide — from Phuket to Paris and Brussels.
“This is a great opportunity to create the appearance that there are people who are not satisfied with the current state of affairs, who are willing to unite for collective action, and there are many of them,” said Daniel, who voted in the Russian consulate in Almaty, Kazakhstan. He declined to give his full name amid concerns over potential reprisals.
input:
Authorities assert that the assailants — many of whom were elderly women — were acting on instructions from abroad. All involved now face the prospect of being sentenced to up to five years in prison. 
The most significant pushback against Putin occurred on Sunday at noon, when the Russian opposition rallied its supporters for a “Noon Against Putin” protest. The initiative encouraged people to go to the polls at 12 p.m. and simultaneously vote for any candidate other than the incumbent.
The noon demonstration was aimed at challenging Putin’s legitimacy, both domestically and internationally. Navalny’s widow Yulia Navalnaya joined a protest in Berlin after encouraging the noon opposition move. She told journalists after voting herself that she had written her late husband’s name on the ballot paper. 
“It cannot be that a month before the election, during the campaign, that Putin’s main opponent, who was already in prison has been killed,” she said. 
Thousands joined in similar action around the world. Unusually large crowds were seen at polling stations across Russia, from the smallest Siberian towns to Moscow and St. Petersburg, as well as at Russian embassies and consulates worldwide — from Phuket to Paris and Brussels.
“This is a great opportunity to create the appearance that there are people who are not satisfied with the current state of affairs, who are willing to unite for collective action, and there are many of them,” said Daniel, who voted in the Russian consulate in Almaty, Kazakhstan. He declined to give his full name amid concerns over potential reprisals.

title: Yes, the Russian election is rigged – but there could still be surprises in store for Putin | The Independent
content:
In a bumper year for elections, with more than 60 countries, including the United States, India and probably the UK, all going to the polls, Russia’s presidential contest has drawn relatively little attention outside the country. And it is true that the vote this weekend will be among the least savoury and most predictable renditions of the democratic process.
It will be among the least savoury because, for a start, it is being held not just across Russia’s vast territory, but in some territories – Crimea and four regions of eastern Ukraine – that are not recognised as belonging to Russia at all.
It is unsavoury, too, because the process itself is defective in so many ways. Vladimir Putin is standing for a fifth term that would make him – in a parallel much cited by his detractors – Russia’s longest ruling leader since Stalin. He can do this, thanks to a 2020 referendum that amended the constitution essentially to restart the clock on presidential term limits – a change that seemed expressly designed to facilitate at least one more term for Putin.
In 2008, as his second term closed, Putin had taken a different approach to constitutional constraints, arranging to swap places with his prime minister, Dmitry Medvedev, to comply with the consecutive two-term limit. He returned to the presidency in 2012 – a move, it is worth noting, that triggered the biggest protests of his tenure. The changes of 2020 were largely unopposed, and Putin, now 71, could, in theory, still be in the Kremlin in 2036.

And it is true that the vote this weekend will be among the least savoury and most predictable renditions of the democratic process.
It will be among the least savoury because, for a start, it is being held not just across Russia’s vast territory, but in some territories – Crimea and four regions of eastern Ukraine – that are not recognised as belonging to Russia at all.
It is unsavoury, too, because the process itself is defective in so many ways. Vladimir Putin is standing for a fifth term that would make him – in a parallel much cited by his detractors – Russia’s longest ruling leader since Stalin. He can do this, thanks to a 2020 referendum that amended the constitution essentially to restart the clock on presidential term limits – a change that seemed expressly designed to facilitate at least one more term for Putin.
In 2008, as his second term closed, Putin had taken a different approach to constitutional constraints, arranging to swap places with his prime minister, Dmitry Medvedev, to comply with the consecutive two-term limit. He returned to the presidency in 2012 – a move, it is worth noting, that triggered the biggest protests of his tenure. The changes of 2020 were largely unopposed, and Putin, now 71, could, in theory, still be in the Kremlin in 2036.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出,普京迎接“硬核”挑战
content:
2022年乌克兰危机升级后,俄罗斯遭到西方超万项制裁,大量西方企业退出俄市场。随后普京签令决定与“不友好国家”改用卢布结算天然气账单,俄经济表现出“稳定性和韧性”,抵御住了冲击,GDP在2023年扭转颓势,实现3.6%的增长。
陈玉荣指出,当下俄罗斯面临着复杂的国际环境,其经济面临持续稳定发展问题。这就意味着,在新的任期内,普京还将面对西方全方位经济制裁带来的各种难题,例如,俄内外经济结构调整等问题。

在2024年的国情咨文中,普京提出了很多具体的目标,如增加本国高科技产品和服务在国内市场的份额、提高非资源非能源出口、降低进口比重、实现更多技术自主等。
“普京看上去有干劲、精力充沛,他对情况掌握充分,即便是细节也有所了解。”《俄罗斯报》写道。
“这些任务十分艰巨。”陈玉荣表示,“普京连任将有利于俄罗斯内外政策的连贯性,也有助于推动俄罗斯经济社会改革措施的落实。”
translation:
After the Ukrainian crisis escalated in 2022, Russia was subject to more than 10,000 Western sanctions, and a large number of Western companies withdrew from the Russian market. Subsequently, Putin signed an order to switch to using rubles to settle natural gas bills with "unfriendly countries". The Russian economy showed "stability and resilience" and withstood the impact. GDP reversed the decline in 2023 and achieved 3.6% growth.
Chen Yurong pointed out that Russia is currently facing a complex international environment and its economy is facing the problem of sustained and stable development. This means that during his new term of office, Putin will also face various difficulties brought about by Western all-round economic sanctions, such as the adjustment of economic structure inside and outside Russia.

In his 2024 State of the Union address, Putin proposed many specific goals, such as increasing the share of the country's high-tech products and services in the domestic market, increasing non-resource and non-energy exports, reducing the proportion of imports, and achieving more technological independence.
"Putin seems motivated and energetic. He has a full grasp of the situation, even the details." "Russia Rossiya" wrote.
"These tasks are very arduous." Chen Yurong said, "Putin's re-election will be conducive to the coherence of Russia's domestic and foreign policies and will also help promote the implementation of Russia's economic and social reform measures."

GDP reversed the decline in 2023 and achieved 3.6% growth.

title: Путин победил на выборах на фоне сообщений о нарушениях
content:
Некоторые избиратели признавали, что голосовали за действующего президента из-за отсутствия реальной альтернативы

МОСКВА – В воскресенье россияне пришли на избирательные участки, чтобы принять участие в президентских выборах, в исходе которых мало кто сомневался.

Даже предварительные результаты, обнародованные вскоре после закрытия участков в Калининградской области, показали, что действующий глава государства Владимир Путин обеспечил себе победу на выборах, которые, по мнению критиков, были срежиссированны.

По последним данным Центризбиркома России, опубликованным утром в Москве, Путин получил более 76 процентов голосов – рекордный результат за все время его правления, как о том объявила председатель ЦИК России Элла Памфилова. Неясно, удалось ли Кремлю добиться своей цели и довести явку до 70 процентов – по последним данным ЦИК России, она составила 67,7 процента от всех избирателей России. Однако эти данные еще не окончательные, а сотрудники Кремля настаивали, что этот показатель после всех подсчетов будет достигнут.

В ходе голосования поступали сообщения о сотнях нарушений с бюллетенями на избирательных участках в разных уголках страны. Представители избирательных комиссий не придавали им большого значения, отмечая лишь, что эти сообщения расследуются.

Ближайший соперник Путина, кандидат от КПРФ Павел Грудинин, как сообщила Памфилова, по данным обработки более 99 процентов бюллетеней набрал 11,8 процента голосов.

Кремль, вероятно, побуждал некоторых кандидатов к участию в выборах, чтобы придать им видимость состязательности. В окружении слабых соперников Путину, который находится у власти с 1999 года, когда он сменил Бориса Ельцина, изначально была гарантирована победа на выборах, которые совпали с четвертой годовщиной российской аннексии Крыма.

Единственному реальному сопернику Путина, блогеру и активисту Алексею Навальному, не позволили баллотироваться из-за судимости, которая, как он считает, была подстроена, чтобы не допустить его к участию в выборах в качестве кандидата. Навальный и его сторонники заявили в воскресенье, что по всей России избирателей подвозили к участкам на автобусах.

Заместитель главы Центризбиркома Николай Булаев отверг заявления о нарушениях, заявив: «Ни в одной стране мира нет той открытости, как у нас. При такой степени открытости видны все малейшие нарушения».

Однако на видео, размещенных активистами в сети, видны грубые нарушения. На одном из участков в Республике Саха член избирательной комиссии вбрасывает бюллетени в урну, в то время как избиратели ждут в очереди, чтобы проголосовать. В Дагестане избили наблюдателя, когда он отказался прекратить съемку неправомерного голосования. Еще на одном видео молодая женщина вбрасывает бюллетени, в то время как внимание наблюдателей отвлекают.

Пока граждане России голосовали, главный вопрос был – какой будет явка?

Представители Кремля были недвусмысленно нацелены на достижение огромных результатов для Путина, чтобы продемонстрировать его легитимность, и к середине дня, за несколько часов до закрытия избирательных участков, члены избирательных комиссий допускали, что явка составит 70 процентов.

Кремлевские инсайдеры перед днем голосования говорили, что желаемым исходом стал бы результат «70 на 70»: 70 процентов голосов за Путина при 70-процентной явке.

Еще вечером воскресенья ЦИК объявил, что более половины взрослого населения России уже проголосовали, и явка превысила показатель предыдущих выборов, которые прошли в 2012 году.

Некоторые аналитики считают, что отравление бывшего российского шпиона Сергея Скрипаля с помощью нервно-паралитического агента 4 марта, в котором британские власти обвиняют Россию, было спланировано так, чтобы спровоцировать конфронтацию с Западом для повышения явки и поддержки Путина на патриотической волне.

Это предположение было категорически отвергнуто накануне выборов помощниками Путина, который заявил, что Россия не причастна к отравлению. Некоторые чиновники утверждают, что инцидент был подстроен британскими властями.

Ухудшение британо-российских отношений стало поводом для размышлений для некоторых избирателей. На избирательном участке в московской школе №1250 бизнесмен Алексей сказал: «Думаю, что все эти утверждения были состряпаны британским правительством. Думаю, никто не отравлял Скрипаля. Наша страна никого не травила».

Через дорогу от школы бродили полицейские, готовые отреагировать на акции протеста, о которых говорили, но которые так и не материализовались.

Большинство москвичей, с которыми побеседовал корреспондент «Голоса Америки», заявили, что Путин является идеальным кандидатом. Некоторые избиратели поясняли, что поддерживают его, потому что он восстановил мощь России и превратил страну из региональной державы в глобальную.

Перед голосованием Путин подчеркивал восстановление российской мощи. Это было особенно заметно в его послании Федеральному собранию, в котором он заявил, что теперь мир вынужден прислушиваться к России.
translation:
Some voters admitted that they voted for the incumbent president due to the lack of a real alternative

MOSCOW - Russians went to the polls on Sunday to take part in a presidential election whose outcome few doubted.

Even preliminary results, released shortly after polling stations in the Kaliningrad region closed, showed that incumbent head of state Vladimir Putin had secured victory in an election that critics say was staged.

According to the latest data from the Russian Central Election Commission, published this morning in Moscow, Putin received more than 76 percent of the vote - a record result for his entire reign, as announced by Ella Pamfilova, chairman of the Russian Central Election Commission. It is unclear whether the Kremlin succeeded in achieving its goal of raising turnout to 70 percent - according to the latest data from the Russian Central Election Commission, it was 67.7 percent of all Russian voters. However, these data are not yet final, and Kremlin officials insisted that this figure would be achieved after all the calculations.

During the voting, there were reports of hundreds of irregularities with ballot papers at polling stations in different parts of the country. Election officials played them down, saying only that the reports were being investigated.

Putin's closest rival, candidate from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Pavel Grudinin, as Pamfilova reported, according to the processing of more than 99 percent of the ballots, he received 11.8 percent of the votes.

The Kremlin may have encouraged some candidates to run in the elections to make them appear competitive. Surrounded by weak rivals, Putin, who has been in power since 1999 when he succeeded Boris Yeltsin, was initially guaranteed victory in the election, which coincided with the fourth anniversary of Russia's annexation of Crimea.

Putin's only real rival, blogger and activist Alexei Navalny, was barred from running due to a criminal record that he believes was staged to prevent him from running as a candidate. Navalny and his supporters said on Sunday that across Russia, voters were being bused to polling stations.

Deputy head of the Central Election Commission Nikolai Bulaev rejected claims of violations, saying: “No country in the world is as open as we are. With such a degree of openness, every slightest violation is visible.”

However, videos posted by activists online show gross violations. At one polling station in the Republic of Sakha, a member of the election commission throws ballots into a box while voters wait in line to vote. An observer was beaten in Dagestan when he refused to stop filming an illegal vote. Another video shows a young woman stuffing ballots while observers are distracted.

While Russian citizens were voting, the main question was: what will the turnout be?

Kremlin officials were clearly focused on achieving huge results for Putin to demonstrate his legitimacy, and by mid-afternoon, hours before polls closed, election officials were projecting turnout to be as high as 70 percent.

Kremlin insiders said before voting day that the desired outcome would be a “70-70” result: 70 percent of the vote for Putin with a 70 percent turnout.

On Sunday evening, the Central Election Commission announced that more than half of Russia's adult population had already voted, and turnout exceeded that of the previous elections, which took place in 2012.

Some analysts believe the March 4 nerve agent poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal, which British authorities blame on Russia, was planned to provoke a confrontation with the West to boost turnout and support for Putin on a patriotic wave.

This suggestion was categorically rejected on the eve of the election by Putin's aides, who said Russia was not involved in the poisoning. Some officials claim that the incident was staged by British authorities.

The deterioration of British-Russian relations has given some voters pause. At a polling station in Moscow school No. 1250, businessman Alexey said: “I think all these allegations were concocted by the British government. I don't think anyone poisoned Skripal. Our country did not poison anyone.”

Police officers roamed across the street from the school, ready to respond to protests that had been talked about but never materialized.

Most Muscovites interviewed by the Voice of America correspondent said that Putin is the ideal candidate. Some voters explained that they support him because he has restored Russia's power and transformed the country from a regional power to a global one.

Before the vote, Putin emphasized the restoration of Russian power. This was especially noticeable in his message to the Federal Assembly, in which he stated that the world was now forced to listen to Russia.

title: 普京“连任”，西方国家谴责，中朝伊电贺
content: 俄罗斯总统普京在一场没有真正对手的总统大选中以压倒性优势获胜、赢得下一个六年任期。西方国家纷纷谴责俄罗斯的选举不公平、不自由；中国、伊朗和朝鲜则祝贺普京连任，并表示将加强与莫斯科的关系。
translation: Russian President Vladimir Putin won a landslide victory in a presidential election with no real opponent, winning a second six-year term. Western countries have condemned Russia's election as unfair and unfree; China, Iran and North Korea congratulated Putin on his re-election and said they would strengthen relations with Moscow.
input: Russian President Vladimir Putin won a landslide victory in a presidential election with no real opponent, winning a second six-year term. Western countries have condemned Russia's election as unfair and unfree; China, Iran and North Korea congratulated Putin on his re-election and said they would strengthen relations with Moscow.

title: Putin extends rule in predetermined Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era | KSL.com
content:
No independent monitoring organizations were able to observe the election and analysts said online polling meant the vote was highly susceptible to manipulation. Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled.
Putin appeared Monday evening on Red Square in the heart of Moscow at a concert to mark the tenth year since he annexed Crimea from Ukraine. Putin's three token challengers for the presidency appeared on stage beside him and publicly supported him after campaigns in which none of them criticized him.
Putin has led Russia as president or prime minister since December 1999. At the end of his fifth term, he would be the longest-serving Russian leader since Catherine the Great, who ruled during the 18th century.
Emboldened by his sweeping victory, Putin said he planned to carve out a buffer zone in Ukraine to protect Russia from cross-border shelling and attacks. Asked if an open clash could erupt between Russia and NATO, Putin responded curtly by saying: "Everything is possible in today's world." He added, "It's clear to everyone that it will put us a step away from full-scale World War III."
Russian officials said they recruited over 500,000 volunteers for the army last year, but many expect Putin to mobilize more forces to attempt to push deeper into Ukraine. Analysts say that in the post-election period, Russian authorities could also introduce unpopular measures such as raising taxes.
The Kremlin is now "increasingly confident," because it has "learned just how passive the population is and how effective their own repression is," said Nigel Gould-Davies, a senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.
Russia's Central Election Commission said Monday that with all the precincts counted, Putin got 87% of the vote. Central Election Commission chief Ella Pamfilova said that nearly 76 million voters cast their ballots for Putin.
In illegally annexed regions of Ukraine, at least 249 people were detained for refusing to take part in the vote and for criticizing Russian authorities according to the Ukrainian Eastern Human Rights Group.
"Voting in the occupied territories took place literally at gunpoint, when members of election commissions walked from door to door accompanied by military men with weapons," said Pavlo Lysianskyi, head of the group.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy slammed the election and voting in the illegally annexed regions saying "everything Russia does on the occupied territory of Ukraine is a crime."
Germany also sharply criticized the vote. "Russia, as the chancellor has already said, is now a dictatorship and is ruled by Vladimir Putin in an authoritarian manner," said Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokeswoman, Christina Hoffmann.
input:

Analysts say that in the post-election period, Russian authorities could also introduce unpopular measures such as raising taxes.
The Kremlin is now "increasingly confident," because it has "learned just how passive the population is and how effective their own repression is," said Nigel Gould-Davies, a senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.
Russia's Central Election Commission said Monday that with all the precincts counted, Putin got 87% of the vote. Central Election Commission chief Ella Pamfilova said that nearly 76 million voters cast their ballots for Putin.
In illegally annexed regions of Ukraine, at least 249 people were detained for refusing to take part in the vote and for criticizing Russian authorities according to the Ukrainian Eastern Human Rights Group.
"Voting in the occupied territories took place literally at gunpoint, when members of election commissions walked from door to door accompanied by military men with weapons," said Pavlo Lysianskyi, head of the group.

title: Ukraine appeals to citizens under Russian occupation to ignore Putin’s ‘pseudo elections’ | CNN
content:
Ukraine’s government has told citizens living in Russian-occupied territories to turn their backs on what they call Moscow’s pseudo-elections, which culminate on Sunday and are widely assumed to see Vladimir Putin returned as president for six more years.
    

            For Kyiv and its international allies, the voting exercise is seen among other things as a further attempt by Russia to give the appearance of legitimacy to its control over the Ukrainian territory it holds.
    

            “Ukrainian citizens should avoid participating in this farce in every way possible,” government minister Iryna Vereshchuk said - which meant no one should be helping to organize the polling, campaigning, voting, or acting as an observer of the elections, the government said in a statement.
    

            “Do not engage in collaboration, do not help the occupiers to hold fake elections,” Vereshchuk added, warning that those who did so willingly were breaking Ukrainian law, though forced participation was not unlawful.
    

            In-person voting has been underway since Friday, but Sunday is expected to see the largest number of polling stations open in Crimea as well as those parts of Kherson, Zaporizhzhia, Donetsk and Luhansk regions that are also under Russian occupation.
    

            In an indication of the importance attached by Moscow to optics, Russian state-run news agency RIA Novosti ran a report Saturday on its Telegram channel which purported to show a mobile election team setting up in Avdiivka, a town captured by Russian forces last month in an important territorial gain.
    

            “Our team is mobile to give the residents of Avdiivka the opportunity to vote in the presidential election. We have everything that is necessary for voting - ballots, a ballot box, a screen,” a man called Danil, described as an election commission head, says, a scarf around his face hiding his identity.
    

            As several people are shown casting their votes, a woman, who says she is an Orthodox Christian of the Russian Church, expresses her gratitude.
    

            “We’ve been waiting for this. I’m very glad. Thank you very much for coming to us,” she says.
    

            Russian Telegram channels have showed other mobile election teams across the occupied territories, including some which appear to clearly show Russian soldiers accompanying election officials as they go house to house.

            In-person voting has been underway since Friday, but Sunday is expected to see the largest number of polling stations open in Crimea as well as those parts of Kherson, Zaporizhzhia, Donetsk and Luhansk regions that are also under Russian occupation.

We have everything that is necessary for voting - ballots, a ballot box, a screen,” a man called Danil, described as an election commission head, says, a scarf around his face hiding his identity.

title: Реакция мировых СМИ на победу Владимира Путина
content:
Правительства других стран Глобального Юга также стремятся укрепить партнерские связи с Россией.
Наконец, газета Ouest-France, как и CNN, обратилась к моделированию будущего и насущным политическим вопросам, решение которых напрямую зависит от главы российского государства:
Будет ли этим летом введено "олимпийское перемирие" по инициативе Франции, которая принимает Олимпийские игры 2024 года? Похоже, эта идея набирает обороты, тем более что недавно переизбранный президент Российской Федерации выразил готовность обсудить ее в своем заявлении в воскресенье 17 марта.
Владимир Путин заявил, что французское предложение об олимпийском перемирии будет изучено "исходя из интересов России и ситуации в зоне боевого соприкосновения".
translation:
Governments in other countries in the Global South are also seeking to strengthen partnerships with Russia.
Finally, the newspaper Ouest-France, like CNN, turned to modeling the future and pressing political issues, the solution of which directly depends on the head of the Russian state:
Will an "Olympic Truce" be introduced this summer on the initiative of France, which is hosting the 2024 Olympic Games? The idea appears to be gaining traction, especially since the recently re-elected president of the Russian Federation expressed a willingness to discuss it in a statement on Sunday, March 17.
Vladimir Putin said that the French proposal for an Olympic truce would be studied “based on the interests of Russia and the situation in the combat contact zone.”
input:
Governments in other countries in the Global South are also seeking to strengthen partnerships with Russia.
Finally, the newspaper Ouest-France, like CNN, turned to modeling the future and pressing political issues, the solution of which directly depends on the head of the Russian state:
Will an "Olympic Truce" be introduced this summer on the initiative of France, which is hosting the 2024 Olympic Games? The idea appears to be gaining traction, especially since the recently re-elected president of the Russian Federation expressed a willingness to discuss it in a statement on Sunday, March 17.
Vladimir Putin said that the French proposal for an Olympic truce would be studied “based on the interests of Russia and the situation in the combat contact zone.”

title: «Россия – это Путин»: политические последствия 87% президента
content: «Россия – это я» - по итогам президентских выборов 2024 года Владимир Путин получил полное моральное и политическое право на заявление подобного рода. 87% за действующего президента – ничего подобного в современной истории России еще не было, не было даже близко. Выборы 2000 года (ВВП на тот момент был не действующим президентом, а действующим и.о. президента, но не суть важно): за Путина – без малого 53% голосов. Выборы 2004 года: за Путина – 71% голосов. Выборы 2012 года – за Путина 63% голосов. Выборы 2018 года – за Путина 76% голосов. Многочисленные злопыхатели, сконцентрированные сейчас главным образом за пределами российских границ, с абсолютной вероятностью поставят (поправка: уже поставили) путинский результат под сомнение. Но в нынешней политической реальности значение имеет то, что происходит внутри России. А внутри России Путин – абсолютный победитель и абсолютный рекордсмен: и формальный, и реальный.
translation: “Russia is me” - following the results of the 2024 presidential elections, Vladimir Putin received full moral and political right to make a statement of this kind. 87% for the current president - nothing like this has ever happened in the modern history of Russia, it wasn’t even close. Elections of 2000 (GDP at that time was not the current president, but the current acting president, but that doesn’t matter): for Putin - almost 53% of the votes. Elections of 2004: for Putin - 71% of votes. Elections 2012 – 63% of votes for Putin. 2018 elections – 76% of votes for Putin. Numerous spiteful critics, now concentrated mainly outside Russian borders, are absolutely likely to call (correction: they have already called) Putin’s result into question. But in the current political reality, what matters is what happens inside Russia. And inside Russia, Putin is the absolute winner and the absolute record holder: both formal and real.
input: “Russia is me” - following the results of the 2024 presidential elections, Vladimir Putin received full moral and political right to make a statement of this kind. 87% for the current president - nothing like this has ever happened in the modern history of Russia, it wasn’t even close. Elections of 2000 (GDP at that time was not the current president, but the current acting president, but that doesn’t matter): for Putin - almost 53% of the votes. Elections of 2004: for Putin - 71% of votes. Elections 2012 – 63% of votes for Putin. 2018 elections – 76% of votes for Putin. Numerous spiteful critics, now concentrated mainly outside Russian borders, are absolutely likely to call (correction: they have already called) Putin’s result into question. But in the current political reality, what matters is what happens inside Russia. And inside Russia, Putin is the absolute winner and the absolute record holder: both formal and real.

title: 连任后一片喊打！普京透露与习的关系-万维视频-万维读者网（电脑版）
content:
欧盟还在一份新闻稿中强调，它不会承认在俄罗斯控制下的乌克兰领土上举行的“非法”选举的结果。
波兰周日定调谴责说，“俄罗斯的总统选举不合法、不自由、不公平”。 波兰外交部表示，这次投票是在“严厉镇压的背景下”在乌克兰被占领地区进行的，违反了国际法。
捷克共和国谴责俄罗斯总统选举是“一场闹剧和一场作戏。” 捷克外交部长扬·利帕夫斯基周日在 X 上表示，希望“有一天俄罗斯人将在自由民主的选举中投票。”
意大利外交部长安东尼奥·塔亚尼周日表示，“俄罗斯的选举既不自由也不公平，而且还涉及非法占领的乌克兰领土。”他说：“我们将继续努力实现公正的和平，引导俄罗斯根据国际法结束对乌克兰的侵略战争。”
法国周一上午对俄罗斯没有满足自由、多元化和民主选举的条件表示遗憾。 法国外交部赞扬了“许多俄罗斯公民的勇气，他们以和平方式表达了对这一对他们的基本政治权利遭剥夺攻击的反对”。
德国谴责“一场没有选择的选举”，显示出“普京针对本国人民的臭名昭著的行为”。 此外，外交部长安娜莱娜·贝尔博克说，“在乌克兰、格鲁吉亚和摩尔多瓦部分地区举行所谓的选举都违反国际法。”
由于国际压力大，普京便拉上习近平背书，强调他和习近平的关系，还说：“最重要的是我们的国家利益是一致的，为我们解决共同任务创造有利环境，在国际关系背景下，俄中关系是稳定的因素。”
虽然并非正式结盟，但是中共国和俄国已经建立“无上限”伙伴关系，而俄国和美国等乌克兰盟友的紧张关系升温也导致俄中越走越近。
现在中共国已经取代欧洲成为俄国最大的能源出口国，而俄国对于中国产品的依赖也不断增加。
translation:
The EU also stressed in a press release that it would not recognize the results of "illegal" elections held on Ukrainian territory under Russian control.
Poland set the tone on Sunday by condemning "Russia's presidential election as illegal, unfree and unfair." Poland's foreign ministry said the vote took place "in the context of severe repression" in occupied areas of Ukraine and violated international law.
The Czech Republic denounced the Russian presidential election as "a farce and a show." Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavski expressed the hope on Sunday that "Russians will one day vote in free and democratic elections." "
Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said on Sunday that "Russia's elections were neither free nor fair and also involved illegally occupied Ukrainian territory." He said: "We will continue to work towards a just peace that guides Russia in accordance with international law." End the war of aggression against Ukraine.”
France expressed regret on Monday morning that Russia did not meet the conditions for free, pluralistic and democratic elections. The French foreign ministry praised "the courage of the many Russian citizens who peacefully expressed their opposition to this attack on their fundamental political rights."
Germany condemned "an election without choice" that showed "Putin's notorious behavior against his own people." Furthermore, Foreign Minister Annalena Berbok said that "the holding of so-called elections in Ukraine, Georgia and parts of Moldova violates international law."
Due to high international pressure, Putin drew Xi Jinping's endorsement, emphasized his relationship with Xi Jinping, and said: "The most important thing is that our national interests are consistent and create a favorable environment for us to solve common tasks. In the context of international relations, Russia-China relations are a factor of stability.”
Although there is no formal alliance, China and Russia have established an "unlimited" partnership, and the rising tensions between Russia and Ukrainian allies such as the United States have also led to Russia and China getting closer.
Now China has replaced Europe as Russia's largest energy exporter, and Russia's dependence on Chinese products is also increasing.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
尼基塔告诉澎湃新闻（www.thepaper.cn）。
选择来到莫斯科东南部坦波夫州的A村后，尼基塔成了一名“乡村教师”，薪水已不只是“腰斩”，而是变为原先的五分之一甚至十分之一。这令他的老父亲着实有些恼火。每次回到莫斯科，都要受到父亲的好一顿数落。
小村子只有六七条道路，居民满打满算不过600多人。按照一些政治学者的说法，这类村庄的居民构成了总统普京的选票基本盘。在尼基塔所在的A村，情况正是如此。不需要专业民调，也不用社会学家来做田野调查，只要走在村里坑坑洼洼的土路上，随便问两个上了年纪的居民，就能得到这个结论。
“他们会告诉你，我儿子在打仗，他是在保家卫国，而且他还会寄钱来补贴家用。”尼基塔说。
当地时间2024年3月3日，俄罗斯克麦罗沃州，一名选举官员走在塔什塔戈尔区的卡尔巴利克村。
translation:
Nikita told The Paper (www.thepaper.cn).
After choosing to come to Village A in Tambov Oblast, southeast of Moscow, Nikita became a "rural teacher" and her salary was not only "cut in half", but became one-fifth or even one-tenth of the original one. . This really annoyed his old father. Every time he returned to Moscow, he would be scolded by his father.
There are only six or seven roads in the small village, and the number of residents is only more than 600. According to some political scientists, residents of such villages form President Vladimir Putin's voting base. This is exactly the case in Village A, where Nikita is located. There is no need for professional polls or field surveys by sociologists. You can get this conclusion just by walking on the bumpy dirt road in the village and asking two elderly residents.
"They will tell you that my son is fighting, he is defending his family and the country, and he will also send money to support his family," Nikita said.
On March 3, 2024 local time, an election official walked in the village of Karbalik in Tashtagor District, Kemerovo Oblast, Russia.
input:
Nikita told The Paper (www.thepaper.cn).
After choosing to come to Village A in Tambov Oblast, southeast of Moscow, Nikita became a "rural teacher" and her salary was not only "cut in half", but became one-fifth or even one-tenth of the original one. . This really annoyed his old father. Every time he returned to Moscow, he would be scolded by his father.
There are only six or seven roads in the small village, and the number of residents is only more than 600. According to some political scientists, residents of such villages form President Vladimir Putin's voting base. This is exactly the case in Village A, where Nikita is located. There is no need for professional polls or field surveys by sociologists. You can get this conclusion just by walking on the bumpy dirt road in the village and asking two elderly residents.
"They will tell you that my son is fighting, he is defending his family and the country, and he will also send money to support his family," Nikita said.
On March 3, 2024 local time, an election official walked in the village of Karbalik in Tashtagor District, Kemerovo Oblast, Russia.

title: Western leaders denounce Putin's election 'victory,' fall short of refusing to recognize results
content:
Following the death of Alexei Navalny in February, the Russian opposition is fractured and largely leaderless. 
The U.S. could declare that the Russian election was illegitimate and insist on new voting to be held openly under international observation, but there is no opposition figure waiting in the wings to emerge as even a representative of the government in exile like Tsikhanouskaya. 
Despite the heavily managed election, polls conducted in July 2023 by the Levada Center, a Russian independent polling organization, found that almost 70% of respondents wanted Putin to be reelected.  Another Levada Center poll released in February 2024 found that 77% of respondents supported the full-scale war in Ukraine. 
While accurate polling information in Russia is difficult to obtain due to the clampdown on public expression and the possibility of real consequences for dissent, numerous media reports have illustrated that a majority of Russians still support Putin. 
Even as the West delivers punishing sanctions against Russia and supplies increasingly advanced weapons to Ukraine, there is a hesitance to fully isolate Russia and commit to its defeat.
French President Emmanuel Macron raised eyebrows and drew quick rebuttals from other Western partners when he suggested in February that he would not rule out troops being sent to Ukraine.
Alongside the small group of autocratic leaders aligned with Russia that congratulated Putin on his electoral "victory" were leaders of India, China and Turkey, countries holding substantial economic and political power.
The Russian state-run media outlet RIA Novosti, citing church leader Leonid Sevastyonov, claimed that Pope Francis congratulated Putin as well, but the assertion was not supported elsewhere.
In a congratulatory message on Twitter, Modi said, "(I) look forward to working together to further strengthen the time-tested special & privileged strategic partnership between India and Russia in the years to come."
Beyond failing to attract important players like India and Turkey, there is also the question of what the practical implications would actually be if the West decided to declare Putin an illegitimate leader.
Despite the declarations of their illegitimacy, Lukashenko remains in power in Belarus, and Maduro is set to run essentially unopposed in a presidential election scheduled for July 2024. 
Venezuela's opposition removed Guaido as head of the interim government in December 2022, largely because it "had lost faith in (his) ability to oust Maduro."
The decision to declare Putin's reelection illegitimate could also lead to accusations that the West ignores electoral rigging when it is convenient.
Labeling Putin as an illegitimate president may have symbolic value and be an accurate reflection of the unfair circumstances in which the election was held. But as long as the West treats Putin as the leader of Russia, rhetorical choices will likely have little practical impact.
input:

Despite the heavily managed election, polls conducted in July 2023 by the Levada Center, a Russian independent polling organization, found that almost 70% of respondents wanted Putin to be reelected.  Another Levada Center poll released in February 2024 found that 77% of respondents supported the full-scale war in Ukraine. 
While accurate polling information in Russia is difficult to obtain due to the clampdown on public expression and the possibility of real consequences for dissent, numerous media reports have illustrated that a majority of Russians still support Putin.

title: Будет ли Владимир Путин переизбран в 2024 году, сколько голосов наберёт президент
content:
В победу нашего президента на предстоящих выборах главы государства верят даже западные эксперты.

Так, репортер The New York Times передал на страницах своего издания слова Дмитрия Пескова о том, что Владимир Путин в случае участия в выборах наберет больше 90% голосов. Однако сам пресс-секретарь опроверг его трактовку, заявив, что американский журналист исказил его слова и цитата некорректна: «Уровень консолидации общества вокруг президента абсолютно беспрецедентный, и уже сейчас можно с уверенностью сказать, что если Путин будет выдвигаться, он будет переизбран с огромным преимуществом, никаких сомнений нет», изрёк тогда Песков.

По оценкам отечественных экспертов, Путин пойдет на выборы-2024 и переизберется президентом, считает политолог Дмитрий Бадовский. Его мнение разделяет и другой специалист — политтехнолог и президент холдинга «Минченко Консалтинг» Евгений Минченко, пояснивший в беседе с RTVI, что избирательная кампания Путина уже ведется. Сценарий базовый, плановый, из которого исходят и в рамках которого делается большое количество действий на разных административных уровнях.

Что касается рейтинга Путина в России, то, согласно данным опроса Всероссийского центра изучения общественного мнения, уровень доверия россиян российскому лидеру в текущем году составил 77,4 %.
translation:
Even Western experts believe in the victory of our president in the upcoming presidential elections.

Thus, a reporter for The New York Times reported on the pages of his publication the words of Dmitry Peskov that Vladimir Putin, if he participates in the elections, will receive more than 90% of the votes. However, the press secretary himself denied his interpretation, saying that the American journalist distorted his words and the quote was incorrect: “The level of consolidation of society around the president is absolutely unprecedented, and now we can say with confidence that if Putin is nominated, he will be re-elected with a huge advantage “There is no doubt,” Peskov said then.

According to domestic experts, Putin will go to the 2024 elections and be re-elected president, says political scientist Dmitry Badovsky. His opinion is shared by another specialist - political strategist and president of the Minchenko Consulting holding company Evgeny Minchenko, who explained in a conversation with RTVI that Putin’s election campaign is already underway. The scenario is basic, planned, from which a large number of actions are taken and carried out at different administrative levels.

As for Putin’s rating in Russia, according to a survey by the All-Russian Center for the Study of Public Opinion, the level of Russians’ trust in the Russian leader this year was 77.4%.
input:
Even Western experts believe in the victory of our president in the upcoming presidential elections.

Thus, a reporter for The New York Times reported on the pages of his publication the words of Dmitry Peskov that Vladimir Putin, if he participates in the elections, will receive more than 90% of the votes. However, the press secretary himself denied his interpretation, saying that the American journalist distorted his words and the quote was incorrect: “The level of consolidation of society around the president is absolutely unprecedented, and now we can say with confidence that if Putin is nominated, he will be re-elected with a huge advantage “There is no doubt,” Peskov said then.

According to domestic experts, Putin will go to the 2024 elections and be re-elected president, says political scientist Dmitry Badovsky. His opinion is shared by another specialist - political strategist and president of the Minchenko Consulting holding company Evgeny Minchenko, who explained in a conversation with RTVI that Putin’s election campaign is already underway. The scenario is basic, planned, from which a large number of actions are taken and carried out at different administrative levels.

As for Putin’s rating in Russia, according to a survey by the All-Russian Center for the Study of Public Opinion, the level of Russians’ trust in the Russian leader this year was 77.4%.

title: Russia election: calls for massive protests as Vladimir Putin set to extend his rule | South China Morning Post
content:
There have also been acts of protest in the first days of polling, with a spate of arrests of Russians accused of pouring dye into ballot boxes or arson attacks.
Before he died in an Arctic prison last month, opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who galvanised mass anti-Putin rallies, urged Russians to protest on Sunday.
His widow, Yulia Navalnaya, has reiterated his call in the run-up to the election and said protesters should show up in large numbers at the same time to overwhelm polling stations.
She called for protesters to spoil ballots by writing “Navalny” on them or vote for candidates other than Putin.
A Moscow resident in his twenties said he would take part in the protest at noon (9 am GMT) in the capital “just to see young supportive faces around … feel some support around me, and see the light in this dark tunnel”.
The man, who declined to give his name for security reasons, said he hoped the demonstration would show the authorities “that there are people in this country against the conflict … against the regime”.
The 71-year-old Putin, a former KGB agent, has been in power since the last day of 1999 and is set to extend his grip over the country until at least 2030.
If he were to complete another Kremlin term, he would have stayed in power longer than any Russian leader since Catherine the Great in the 18th century.
He is running without any real opponents, having barred two candidates who opposed the conflict in Ukraine.
The Kremlin has cast the election as an opportunity for Russians to show they are behind the assault on Ukraine, where voting is also being staged in Russian-held areas.
In a pre-election address on Thursday, Putin said Russia was going through a “difficult period”.
“We need to continue to be united and self-confident,” he said, describing the election as a way for Russians to demonstrate their “patriotic feelings”.
The voting will wrap up in Kaliningrad, Russia’s westernmost time zone, at 6 pm GMT and an exit poll is expected to be announced shortly after that.
A concert on Red Square is being staged on Monday to mark 10 years since Russia’s annexation of Ukraine’s Crimea peninsula – an event that is also expected to serve as a victory celebration for Putin.
Ahead of the election, Russian state media have played up recent gains on the front and portrayed the conflict as a fight for survival against attacks from the West.
Moscow has sought to press its advantage on the front line as divisions over Western military support for Ukraine have led to ammunition shortages although Kyiv says it has managed to stop the Russian advance for now.
In Ukraine, a Russian missile strike on the Black Sea port city of Odesa on Friday killed 21 people including rescuers responding to an initial hit – an attack President Volodymyr Zelensky described as “vile”.
On the Russian side, the army has reported repeated attempts by Ukrainian sabotage groups to cross into Russia and the local governor in Belgorod region on Saturday decreed that shopping malls and schools would be shut for two days in the main city Belgorod and the surrounding district following recent strikes.

His widow, Yulia Navalnaya, has reiterated his call in the run-up to the election and said protesters should show up in large numbers at the same time to overwhelm polling stations.
She called for protesters to spoil ballots by writing “Navalny” on them or vote for candidates other than Putin.
A Moscow resident in his twenties said he would take part in the protest at noon (9 am GMT) in the capital “just to see young supportive faces around … feel some support around me, and see the light in this dark tunnel”.
The man, who declined to give his name for security reasons, said he hoped the demonstration would show the authorities “that there are people in this country against the conflict … against the regime”.
The 71-year-old Putin, a former KGB agent, has been in power since the last day of 1999 and is set to extend his grip over the country until at least 2030.
If he were to complete another Kremlin term, he would have stayed in power longer than any Russian leader since Catherine the Great in the 18th century.
He is running without any real opponents, having barred two candidates who opposed the conflict in Ukraine.
The Kremlin has cast the election as an opportunity for Russians to show they are behind the assault on Ukraine, where voting is also being staged in Russian-held areas.
In a pre-election address on Thursday, Putin said Russia was going through a “difficult period”.
“We need to continue to be united and self-confident,” he said, describing the election as a way for Russians to demonstrate their “patriotic feelings”.

Moscow has sought to press its advantage on the front line as divisions over Western military support for Ukraine have led to ammunition shortages although Kyiv says it has managed to stop the Russian advance for now.

title: 普京胜选！最新讲话回应这些问题
content:
除了普京以外，此次选举还有3位候选人。最新结果显示，俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫以4.24%的得票率位居第二，俄新人党的达万科夫得票率为3.99%名列第三，俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基以3.16%的得票率位列第四。
值得注意的是，根据目前不完全的统计结果，普京的得票率已远远超过2018年大选结果。当时，普京的得票率为76.69%。
未来六年还有这些挑战
普京还表示，将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。他说，国家发展的所有主要任务都已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述，将竭尽所能完成既定目标。
在选前的年度国情咨文演说中，普京详细勾勒了未来六年俄罗斯在政治经济领域的目标。比如，在未来六年内，俄罗斯非资源和非能源出口应该增加三分之二；到2030年，俄罗斯进口占GDP的比重应下降至17%；俄罗斯国产高新技术产品在国内市场的份额应提高1.5倍。同时，普京也提到俄罗斯要大力发展AI。
对于这份国情咨文，中国社会科学院俄罗斯东欧中亚研究所研究员张弘告诉第一财经记者：“普京通过介绍内政和外交的未来规划，给俄选民传递信心，勾勒俄社会的整体规划。”
俄联邦国家统计局日前公布的最新数据显示，2023年俄经济同比增速为3.6%，规模达171.04万亿卢布；俄罗斯民众实际工资同比增长7.8%；实际可支配收入同比增长5.4%。后两者为近5年来最高。此外，俄去年失业率为3.2%，为1992年以来最低水平。
展望未来，兰州大学政治与国际关系学院副教授韦进深认为，对于未来六年，俄罗斯面临的主要挑战不少，比如如何应对因俄乌冲突而恶化的国际和地区环境，从而为俄罗斯的发展创造较为有利的空间；同时俄罗斯政府还需要考虑，如何推动国内经济结构的优化和调整，以应对因制裁而受到冲击的国内经济，将目前的战时经济转变为常态经济。
此外，采取什么样的措施进行社会动员，加强俄罗斯国内社会的团结，也是未来普京新政府的重任之一。
translation:
In addition to Putin, there are three candidates in this election. The latest results show that Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.24% of the vote, Davankov of the New People's Party of Russia ranked third with 3.99%, and Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked third. Ranked fourth with 3.16% of the vote.
It is worth noting that according to the current incomplete statistics, Putin’s vote share has far exceeded the results of the 2018 general election. At that time, Putin's vote rate was 76.69%.
There are still these challenges in the next six years
Putin also said that he will continue to promote national development in the new term. He said that all major tasks for national development have been spelled out in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of Parliament and that every effort will be made to achieve the set goals.
In his annual State of the Union address before the election, Putin outlined in detail Russia's political and economic goals for the next six years. For example, in the next six years, Russia's non-resource and non-energy exports should increase by two-thirds; by 2030, Russia's imports as a share of GDP should drop to 17%; and the share of Russian domestic high-tech products in the domestic market should increase by 1.5 times. At the same time, Putin also mentioned that Russia should vigorously develop AI.
Regarding this State of the Union address, Zhang Hong, a researcher at the Institute of Russian, Eastern European and Central Asian Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, told China Business News: "By introducing future plans for domestic and foreign affairs, Putin conveys confidence to Russian voters and outlines the overall plan for Russian society."
The latest data released by the Russian Federal State Statistics Service show that the Russian economy will grow at a year-on-year rate of 3.6% in 2023, reaching 171.04 trillion rubles; the real wages of Russian people will increase by 7.8% year-on-year; the real disposable income will increase by 5.4% year-on-year. The latter two are the highest in the past five years. In addition, Russia's unemployment rate was 3.2% last year, the lowest level since 1992.
Looking to the future, Wei Jinshen, associate professor at the School of Politics and International Relations at Lanzhou University, believes that Russia will face many major challenges in the next six years, such as how to deal with the international and regional environment worsened by the Russia-Ukraine conflict, thereby creating a better environment for Russia's development. Favorable space; at the same time, the Russian government also needs to consider how to promote the optimization and adjustment of the domestic economic structure to cope with the impact of sanctions on the domestic economy and transform the current wartime economy into a normal economy.
In addition, what measures to take for social mobilization and strengthening the unity of Russian domestic society will also be one of the important tasks of Putin's new government in the future.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选：普京为何大费周章举行这次选举 - BBC News 中文
content:
71岁的普京（Vladimir Putin）已经掌权超过20年。他最初被前总统叶利钦任命为看守总统，并于2000年3月赢得首次大选。
2008年至2012年间，他换了角色成为总理，但仍完全掌控政权。当时俄罗斯宪法规定总统只能连任两届，转为总理让他得以再次参选。
2020年修改宪法後，外界普遍预期普京将继续执政到2036年。
届时，他将成为俄罗斯执政时间最长的统治者，超越共产党领导人斯大林和18世纪的凯瑟琳大帝（Empress Catherine the Great），两人都执政超过30年。
俄罗斯选举很少是令人紧张的事件，但选举对于执政者的合法性和表明民意非常重要。
这次对普京来说尤为重要，他不仅要获胜，还要看到高投票率和支持率，因为俄罗斯正卷入一场全面战争，这场战争将对俄罗斯和整个世界产生持续影响。
translation:
Vladimir Putin, 71, has been in power for more than 20 years. He was initially appointed caretaker president by former President Yeltsin and won his first general election in March 2000.
Between 2008 and 2012, he changed roles and became prime minister, but still maintained full control of the government. At that time, the Russian constitution stipulated that the president could only serve two consecutive terms, so switching to prime minister allowed him to run again.
After amending the constitution in 2020, Putin is widely expected to remain in power until 2036.
He will then become Russia's longest-serving ruler, surpassing Communist leader Joseph Stalin and 18th-century Empress Catherine the Great, both of whom ruled for more than 30 years.
Russian elections are rarely nerve-wracking events, but they are important for the legitimacy of those in power and for signaling public opinion.
This time it is particularly important for Putin not only to win, but to see high turnout and support, as Russia is embroiled in an all-out war that will have lasting consequences for Russia and the world at large.
input:
Vladimir Putin, 71, has been in power for more than 20 years. He was initially appointed caretaker president by former President Yeltsin and won his first general election in March 2000.
Between 2008 and 2012, he changed roles and became prime minister, but still maintained full control of the government. At that time, the Russian constitution stipulated that the president could only serve two consecutive terms, so switching to prime minister allowed him to run again.
After amending the constitution in 2020, Putin is widely expected to remain in power until 2036.
He will then become Russia's longest-serving ruler, surpassing Communist leader Joseph Stalin and 18th-century Empress Catherine the Great, both of whom ruled for more than 30 years.
Russian elections are rarely nerve-wracking events, but they are important for the legitimacy of those in power and for signaling public opinion.
This time it is particularly important for Putin not only to win, but to see high turnout and support, as Russia is embroiled in an all-out war that will have lasting consequences for Russia and the world at large.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content:
Дорогие читатели, вы наверняка уже слышали о главном политическом событии этой весны - выборах президента России, которые прошли с 15 по 17 марта 2024 года. Эта кампания войдет в историю нашей страны как одна из самых ярких, противоречивых и судьбоносных.

Выборы президента России 2024 года завершились ожидаемой победой Владимира Путина, который набрал рекордные 87,29% голосов при явке в 77,44%. Однако эта кампания запомнится не только цифрами, но и многочисленными скандалами, протестами и обвинениями в нарушениях.
translation:
Dear readers, you have probably already heard about the main political event of this spring - the Russian presidential elections, which took place from March 15 to 17, 2024. This campaign will go down in the history of our country as one of the most striking, controversial and fateful.

The 2024 Russian presidential election ended in the expected victory of Vladimir Putin, who received a record 87.29% of the votes with a turnout of 77.44%. However, this campaign will be remembered not only for its numbers, but also for its numerous scandals, protests and accusations of violations.
input:
Dear readers, you have probably already heard about the main political event of this spring - the Russian presidential elections, which took place from March 15 to 17, 2024. This campaign will go down in the history of our country as one of the most striking, controversial and fateful.

The 2024 Russian presidential election ended in the expected victory of Vladimir Putin, who received a record 87.29% of the votes with a turnout of 77.44%. However, this campaign will be remembered not only for its numbers, but also for its numerous scandals, protests and accusations of violations.

title: West condemns ‘undemocratic’ Russian election as results show Putin landslide | Russian presidential election 2024 | The Guardian
content:
”
In a victory speech on Sunday, Putin dismissed western criticism of the election as unfair and undemocratic, telling his supporters it was “expected”. He also for the first time addressed Navalny’s death, which he called a “sad event”.
At a concert on Moscow’s Red Square on Monday evening to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the annexation of Crimea, Putin basked in his election win, singing the national anthem with a crowd waving Russian flags.
“Hand in hand, we will move forward and this will make us stronger ... Long live Russia,” Putin said.
Putin’s swift seizure of Crimea in March 2014 is seen as the beginning of 10 years of military action against Ukraine and a cornerstone of Putin’s reimagined Russia.
Putin told the crowd that Crimea was the “pride of Russia” and that the Black Sea peninsula had “come back to its native harbour” when Moscow annexed the region.
He attended the concert alongside the three loyalist presidential candidates who ran against him.
The Russian president usually speaks at the annual celebration that marks the Crimea annexation, a speech that was preceded on Monday by patriotic songs performed by pro-Putin singers.
Several independent Russian outlets reported that state employees and students had been ordered to attend the celebrations. Russia has a long history of state employees being coerced to attend pro-government rallies.
Together with the crowd, Putin sang the Russian national anthem before leaving the stage.
Putin’s vote share, which equates to 76 million votes and is by far the biggest in post-Soviet Russian history, follows an election described as a mockery by an independent monitor group.
The independent Russian election watchdog Golos said it had found unprecedented levels of fraud in the presidential elections. “Never before have we seen a presidential [election] campaign that fell so far short of constitutional standards,” said Golos, whose co-director is now in jail in Russia.
“The elections failed to fulfil their main function: to reflect ​​the real mood of citizens, and they did not allow [citizens] to independently and freely make decisions about the future of their country,” it added.
While shunned by the west, there were congratulations for Putin from the leaders of China and North Korea, two countries that have propped up Moscow in its fighting in Ukraine. Iran’s president, Ebrahim Raisi, hailed Putin’s “decisive victory”, the state news agency IRNA reported. Russia has deployed Iran-made drones against Ukrainian cities.
Putin also received messages from India and the United Arab Emirates, two traditional western allies that Moscow has successfully courted since the start of the war in Ukraine more than two years ago.
India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, offered his “warm congratulations” to Putin, adding that he looked forward to developing their “special” relationship. Russia is India’s biggest arms supplier.
