title: 普京第五度当选俄罗斯总统 投票率超七成创下新高_世界频道_财新网
content:
【财新网】在实际主政俄罗斯24年后，今年将满72岁的俄罗斯总统普京在3月15日至17日举行的新一届俄罗斯大选中顺利赢得连任，为自己开启了又一个六年总统任期。
　　据俄罗斯中央选举委员会在当地时间3月18日凌晨发布的数据，在迄今已完成统计的85%选票中，普京以87.19%的得票率大幅领先于其他候选人，实际已赢得此次总统选举。按照俄罗斯现行法律，在第一轮投票中获得超过半数选票的候选人即立即当选总统。
　　这也是普京在历届俄罗斯总统选举中得票率最高的一次。在2018年的上一次总统选举中，他获得了约76.7%的选票。俄罗斯自1991年从苏联独立以来，包括本届选举在内迄今共举行过八次总统大选。
translation:
[Caixin] After actually ruling Russia for 24 years, Russian President Vladimir Putin, who will turn 72 this year, successfully won re-election in the new Russian general election held from March 15 to 17, opening another six-year period for himself. years of presidential term.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of March 18, local time, of the 85% of votes that have been counted so far, Putin is significantly ahead of other candidates with 87.19% of the votes, and has actually won the presidential election. According to current Russian law, the candidate who obtains more than half of the votes in the first round of voting is immediately elected president.
This is also Putin’s highest vote share in all previous Russian presidential elections. In the last presidential election in 2018, he received about 76.7% of the vote. Since Russia gained independence from the Soviet Union in 1991, it has held eight presidential elections, including this one.
input:
[Caixin] After actually ruling Russia for 24 years, Russian President Vladimir Putin, who will turn 72 this year, successfully won re-election in the new Russian general election held from March 15 to 17, opening another six-year period for himself. years of presidential term.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of March 18, local time, of the 85% of votes that have been counted so far, Putin is significantly ahead of other candidates with 87.19% of the votes, and has actually won the presidential election. According to current Russian law, the candidate who obtains more than half of the votes in the first round of voting is immediately elected president.
This is also Putin’s highest vote share in all previous Russian presidential elections. In the last presidential election in 2018, he received about 76.7% of the vote. Since Russia gained independence from the Soviet Union in 1991, it has held eight presidential elections, including this one.

title: Russian President Putin projected to win re-election as dissidents protest at polling sites
content: Russian President Vladimir Putin is projected to win re-election to another 6-year term as dissidents voiced their opposition to his continued leadership. At some polling locations, protesters threw Molotov cocktails and poured dye into ballot boxes.
input: Russian President Vladimir Putin is projected to win re-election to another 6-year term as dissidents voiced their opposition to his continued leadership. At some polling locations, protesters threw Molotov cocktails and poured dye into ballot boxes.

title: Yes, the Russian election is rigged – but there could still be surprises in store for Putin | The Independent
content:
Yes, Putin benefits from what are called “administrative resources” – otherwise known as the incumbent’s advantage – to dominate the campaign, as well as the restrictions on free speech introduced after the 2022 invasion of Ukraine, the barring of opposition candidates and the repression against opposition, especially Navalny supporters. But in a free vote, given his political dominance and longevity, Putin would still be a near-certainty to win.
So why, you might ask, doesn’t Putin just hold a free vote, or avoid all risk and ditch the electoral facade altogether? Why go to all the trouble of amending the constitution, allowing alternative candidates, and then holding a vote at all? At the very least, he could have declared a state of emergency, invoking the war, and delayed the whole thing for as long as he chose. And why, you might also ask, given the predictability of the result, should the outside world take any notice?
That Putin – and, it must be said, so many other leaders – works so hard to create a semblance of electoral democracy, has to be seen as a massive victory for the Western way – even if many genuine democracies fall short. And among those democracies, the US system of checks, balances, term limits and (mostly) orderly and consensual changes of power, is widely seen as the gold standard. That is partly why the Russian constitution pre-Putin had a limit on presidential power of two four-year terms, and why it took Putin 20 years to amend it.
There is much in the post-Soviet Russian state, including much of the ceremony, the president’s state of the nation address and breathless election night TV coverage, that betrays an envy of the US way of doing things. Borrowed in form, if not in substance, these are the hallmarks of a “proper” state. However spurious his election might look from the outside, Putin craves the validation of a vote. And yet, however carefully arranged both the process and the result, an election still contains tiny slivers of risk, which is why – defective as this election will be – the outside world should take notice.
In all, from the Pacific to the Baltic and the Black Sea, 113 million people have the right to vote this weekend – and for all the precautions taken by the Kremlin, there are uncertainties to watch for.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出,普京迎接“硬核”挑战
content:
这一时期,恰逢国际油价攀升,相对稳定的政治经济环境下,俄罗斯抓住机会,快速发展。21世纪的前八年,俄罗斯GDP增长约70%,工业增长75%；2005年,俄罗斯跻身世界前十大经济体。
随着经济实力提升,俄罗斯的国际影响力也逐渐提高。2014年索契冬奥会、2018年世界杯相继在俄举办。
这些年来,俄罗斯贫困问题得到改善,从2000年到2023年,贫困人口从至少4200万减少到1350万。普京还提出,到2030年,俄罗斯的贫困水平要进一步下降至7%以下。
“普京的这些政绩给俄罗斯民众带来了实实在在的利益,得到了民众的喜爱和支持。”中国国际问题研究院研究员陈玉荣向中新网表示。
translation:
During this period, which coincided with the rise in international oil prices and a relatively stable political and economic environment, Russia seized the opportunity and developed rapidly. In the first eight years of the 21st century, Russia's GDP grew by about 70% and its industry grew by 75%; in 2005, Russia ranked among the top ten economies in the world.
With the improvement of economic strength, Russia's international influence has gradually increased. The 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics and the 2018 World Cup were held in Russia.
Over the years, Russia's poverty problem has improved, with the number of poor people reduced from at least 42 million to 13.5 million from 2000 to 2023. Putin also proposed that by 2030, Russia's poverty level will further drop to below 7%.
"Putin's political achievements have brought tangible benefits to the Russian people and have won the love and support of the people." Chen Yurong, a researcher at the China Institute of International Studies, told China News Service.
input:
During this period, which coincided with the rise in international oil prices and a relatively stable political and economic environment, Russia seized the opportunity and developed rapidly. In the first eight years of the 21st century, Russia's GDP grew by about 70% and its industry grew by 75%; in 2005, Russia ranked among the top ten economies in the world.
With the improvement of economic strength, Russia's international influence has gradually increased. The 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics and the 2018 World Cup were held in Russia.
Over the years, Russia's poverty problem has improved, with the number of poor people reduced from at least 42 million to 13.5 million from 2000 to 2023. Putin also proposed that by 2030, Russia's poverty level will further drop to below 7%.
"Putin's political achievements have brought tangible benefits to the Russian people and have won the love and support of the people." Chen Yurong, a researcher at the China Institute of International Studies, told China News Service.

title: Итоги выборов президента России
content: 17 марта завершились трехдневные выборы президента России. ЦИК зафиксировал рекордную явку – более 70%, явка на платформе ДЭГ составила 94%. Владимир Путин, который баллотировался самовыдвиженцем, получил 87,33% голосов избирателей, обновив свой же рекорд 2018 года. Николай Харитонов (КПРФ) — 4,3%, Владислав Даванков («Новые люди») — 3,81%, Леонид Слуцкий (ЛДПР) — 3,2%.
translation:
Results of the Russian presidential elections
On March 17, the three-day presidential elections in Russia ended. The CEC recorded a record turnout - more than 70%, the turnout on the DEG platform was 94%. Vladimir Putin, who ran as a self-nominated candidate, received 87.33% of the vote, updating his 2018 record. Nikolai Kharitonov (Communist Party of the Russian Federation) - 4.3%, Vladislav Davankov (New People) - 3.81%, Leonid Slutsky (LDPR) - 3.2%.
input:
Results of the Russian presidential elections
On March 17, the three-day presidential elections in Russia ended. The CEC recorded a record turnout - more than 70%, the turnout on the DEG platform was 94%. Vladimir Putin, who ran as a self-nominated candidate, received 87.33% of the vote, updating his 2018 record. Nikolai Kharitonov (Communist Party of the Russian Federation) - 4.3%, Vladislav Davankov (New People) - 3.81%, Leonid Slutsky (LDPR) - 3.2%.

title: Реакция мировых СМИ на победу Владимира Путина
content:
И британский The Guardian, в свою очередь, отдельно остановился на словах Путина относительно стран Запада и их обвинительных заявлений:
Выступая вечером в воскресенье в своем предвыборном штабе, Путин отмахнулся от западной критики выборов, сказав своим сторонникам, что это было "ожидаемо".
"А вы что хотели, чтобы они встали и аплодировали? Они же борются с нами, причем вооруженным путем. Они же [Запад] ставят перед собой цель сдерживать наше развитие. Конечно, они будут говорить вам все, что угодно", — сказал он.
Отвечая на вопрос о возможности прямого конфликта с НАТО, он сказал: "Я думаю, что все возможно в современном мире. Но я же говорю, и это понятно для всех, что это будет в одном шаге от полномасштабной третьей мировой войны. Думаю, что вряд ли в этом кто-либо заинтересован".
translation:
And the British The Guardian, in turn, separately focused on Putin’s words regarding Western countries and their accusatory statements:
Speaking at his campaign headquarters late Sunday, Putin brushed off Western criticism of the election, telling his supporters it was "expected."
“What did you want them to stand up and applaud? They are fighting us, and by armed means. They [the West] set themselves the goal of restraining our development. Of course, they will tell you whatever they want,” he said .
Answering a question about the possibility of a direct conflict with NATO, he said: “I think that everything is possible in the modern world. But I say, and this is clear to everyone, that this will be one step away from a full-scale third world war. I think that It’s unlikely that anyone is interested in this.”
input:
And the British The Guardian, in turn, separately focused on Putin’s words regarding Western countries and their accusatory statements:
Speaking at his campaign headquarters late Sunday, Putin brushed off Western criticism of the election, telling his supporters it was "expected."
“What did you want them to stand up and applaud? They are fighting us, and by armed means. They [the West] set themselves the goal of restraining our development. Of course, they will tell you whatever they want,” he said .
Answering a question about the possibility of a direct conflict with NATO, he said: “I think that everything is possible in the modern world. But I say, and this is clear to everyone, that this will be one step away from a full-scale third world war. I think that It’s unlikely that anyone is interested in this.”

title: Exit polls show Putin winning huge majority in Russian presidential election with only one possible result – as it happened | Russia | The Guardian
content:
Reuters reporters have been out interviewing Russian voters in Latvia.
Earlier today, about 100 anti-Putin protestors gathered in front of the polling station at the Russian embassy in Riga.
Vladimir, a permanent resident in Latvia who gave only his first name, said he came to cast a blank ballot. “I don’t want war, I don’t want things like in Ukraine,” he added.
Andrei, a 28-year-old voting in the Russian election for the first time, said he would vote against Putin even though the result of the election is “probably obvious”, as he felt it was a way he could oppose the war.
Kirill Martynov, editor in chief of Novaya Gazeta Europe, an independent Russian media outlet founded in Riga in April 2022 after the introduction of wartime censorship in Russia, said he planned to oppose this elections by spoiling the ballot.
Older Russian citizens were more reticient with reporters. Some elderly voters interviewed outside the polling station merely said it was their civic duty to vote, but did not reveal which candidate they would support.
Latvian police and border guards were checking voters’ documents outside the polling station. The Latvian State Police chief, Armands Ruks, said the controls were to ensure Russian citizens taking part in the voting did not break the law.
By noon, 351 people were checked at the entrance of the Russian embassy in Riga and 14 were found with expired residency permits, the State Police told local media.
One voter said she was afraid to speak to the media or give her name for fear her residence permit in Latvia might not be extended.
The Russian embassy condemned cases of confiscation of Latvian identity documents from Russian voters, with some citizens now required to appear at the migration service to receive an order to leave.
input:
Reuters reporters have been out interviewing Russian voters in Latvia.
Earlier today, about 100 anti-Putin protestors gathered in front of the polling station at the Russian embassy in Riga.
Vladimir, a permanent resident in Latvia who gave only his first name, said he came to cast a blank ballot. “I don’t want war, I don’t want things like in Ukraine,” he added.
Andrei, a 28-year-old voting in the Russian election for the first time, said he would vote against Putin even though the result of the election is “probably obvious”, as he felt it was a way he could oppose the war.
Kirill Martynov, editor in chief of Novaya Gazeta Europe, an independent Russian media outlet founded in Riga in April 2022 after the introduction of wartime censorship in Russia, said he planned to oppose this elections by spoiling the ballot.
Older Russian citizens were more reticient with reporters. Some elderly voters interviewed outside the polling station merely said it was their civic duty to vote, but did not reveal which candidate they would support.
Latvian police and border guards were checking voters’ documents outside the polling station. The Latvian State Police chief, Armands Ruks, said the controls were to ensure Russian citizens taking part in the voting did not break the law.
By noon, 351 people were checked at the entrance of the Russian embassy in Riga and 14 were found with expired residency permits, the State Police told local media.
One voter said she was afraid to speak to the media or give her name for fear her residence permit in Latvia might not be extended.
The Russian embassy condemned cases of confiscation of Latvian identity documents from Russian voters, with some citizens now required to appear at the migration service to receive an order to leave.

title: Putin addresses Red Square crowds after claiming landslide election win - BBC News
content:
Zhanna Bezpiatchuk
BBC Ukrainian Service reporter
Standing
amid the ghastly ruins and grey-coal ashes of the Ukrainian city Avdiivka,
representatives of Russia's central election commission and parliament said
they were "invited" by local people.
As
if they received the invitation as "liberators" from those who were
longing to vote for Putin.
The
locals have been living without any electricity, water supply and central
heating, in the ghost city which was destroyed by four months of relentless Russian attacks.
Avdiivka, in eastern Ukraine, was finally seized by Russian forces at the end of February 2024. 
Apart
from the depressing backdrop of the debris, bomb craters, mud and rubble - a
common picture in many Russia-captured towns - there is one more detail to pay
attention to. Russian gunmen are seen everywhere in the videos of people voting in the Ukrainian territories occupied by Russia.
Armed men were guarding Russian high-ranking representatives and checking Ukrainian passports of Avdiivka residents, mostly elderly people who
became emaciated shadows of themselves after months of suffering and
fear.
Normally,
if you are invited as honorary guests on a noble mission, you don't need soldiers to accompany you everywhere.  
If
you are welcomed, you don't need gunmen at all.

amid the ghastly ruins and grey-coal ashes of the Ukrainian city Avdiivka,
representatives of Russia's central election commission and parliament said
they were "invited" by local people.
As
if they received the invitation as "liberators" from those who were
longing to vote for Putin.
The
locals have been living without any electricity, water supply and central
heating, in the ghost city which was destroyed by four months of relentless Russian attacks.

Apart
from the depressing backdrop of the debris, bomb craters, mud and rubble - a
common picture in many Russia-captured towns - there is one more detail to pay
attention to. Russian gunmen are seen everywhere in the videos of people voting in the Ukrainian territories occupied by Russia.
Armed men were guarding Russian high-ranking representatives and checking Ukrainian passports of Avdiivka residents, mostly elderly people who
became emaciated shadows of themselves after months of suffering and
fear.
Normally,
if you are invited as honorary guests on a noble mission, you don't need soldiers to accompany you everywhere.  
If
you are welcomed, you don't need gunmen at all.

title: Vladimir Putin claims landslide Russian election victory | Vladimir Putin | The Guardian
content:
Vladimir Putin has claimed a landslide victory in Russia’s presidential vote, as thousands in the country and around the world protested against his deepening dictatorship, the war in Ukraine and a stage-managed election that could have only one winner.
In a vote denounced by the United States as “obviously not free nor fair”, Putin won 87% of the vote, according to exit polling published by the state-run Russian Public Opinion Research Center and the Public Opinion Foundation.
In a speech at his campaign headquarters on Sunday evening, Putin brushed off western criticism of the elections, telling his supporters it was “expected”.
“What did you want, for them to applaud us? They’re fighting with us in an armed conflict … their goal is to contain our development. Of course they’re ready to say anything,” he said.
input:
Vladimir Putin has claimed a landslide victory in Russia’s presidential vote, as thousands in the country and around the world protested against his deepening dictatorship, the war in Ukraine and a stage-managed election that could have only one winner.
In a vote denounced by the United States as “obviously not free nor fair”, Putin won 87% of the vote, according to exit polling published by the state-run Russian Public Opinion Research Center and the Public Opinion Foundation.
In a speech at his campaign headquarters on Sunday evening, Putin brushed off western criticism of the elections, telling his supporters it was “expected”.
“What did you want, for them to applaud us? They’re fighting with us in an armed conflict … their goal is to contain our development. Of course they’re ready to say anything,” he said.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举正式投票开始举行
content:
当地时间3月15日8时，俄罗斯总统选举正式投票从楚克奇自治区和堪察加边疆区开始。
俄罗斯横跨11个时区，投票从远东地区最先开始，最后投票的将是加里宁格勒州的选民。选举投票日共3天，将于17日结束。
此前，俄罗斯总统选举提前投票于2月25日启动，一些交通不便和偏远地区的选民从当天开始投票。居住在国外的俄罗斯选民也可以从3月1日开始提前投票。此外，受俄乌冲突影响，3月10日，俄罗斯别尔哥罗德州邻近俄乌边境的9个地区已提前开始总统选举投票。
按照俄罗斯中央选举委员会公布的数据，此次大选的注册选民约1.12亿，共设有9.4万多个境内投票站，在140多个国家和地区设立了295个境外投票站。来自独联体、上海合作组织、集体安全条约组织等国际机构的观察员监督选举。1400多名俄罗斯和其他国家的记者报道大选。
此次总统选举共有现任总统普京在内的4名候选人参选。
translation:
At 8:00 local time on March 15, official voting for the Russian presidential election began in the Chukotka Autonomous Region and the Kamchatka Krai.
Russia spans 11 time zones, and voting will begin in the Far East first, with voters in the Kaliningrad region voting last. There are three voting days in the election and will end on the 17th.
Previously, early voting for the Russian presidential election was launched on February 25, and some voters in inaccessible and remote areas began to vote on that day. Russian voters living abroad can also vote early starting March 1. In addition, affected by the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, voting for the presidential election began in advance on March 10 in 9 regions in Russia's Belgorod region adjacent to the Russian-Ukrainian border.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission, there are approximately 112 million registered voters in this election, with more than 94,000 domestic polling stations and 295 overseas polling stations in more than 140 countries and regions. Observers from international institutions such as the Commonwealth of Independent States, the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, and the Collective Security Treaty Organization monitored the elections. More than 1,400 journalists from Russia and other countries covered the election.
There are four candidates running in this presidential election, including current President Putin.
input:
At 8:00 local time on March 15, official voting for the Russian presidential election began in the Chukotka Autonomous Region and the Kamchatka Krai.
Russia spans 11 time zones, and voting will begin in the Far East first, with voters in the Kaliningrad region voting last. There are three voting days in the election and will end on the 17th.
Previously, early voting for the Russian presidential election was launched on February 25, and some voters in inaccessible and remote areas began to vote on that day. Russian voters living abroad can also vote early starting March 1. In addition, affected by the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, voting for the presidential election began in advance on March 10 in 9 regions in Russia's Belgorod region adjacent to the Russian-Ukrainian border.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission, there are approximately 112 million registered voters in this election, with more than 94,000 domestic polling stations and 295 overseas polling stations in more than 140 countries and regions. Observers from international institutions such as the Commonwealth of Independent States, the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, and the Collective Security Treaty Organization monitored the elections. More than 1,400 journalists from Russia and other countries covered the election.
There are four candidates running in this presidential election, including current President Putin.

title: Putin says his election win will allow Russian society to consolidate
content:
MOSCOW - Russian President Vladimir Putin on Sunday thanked Russians who had come out to vote, saying that the result of the presidential election would allow Russian society to consolidate and become stronger.

Putin was speaking at his election headquarters late on Sunday after patial results showed he had won a record post-Soviet landslide.
input:
MOSCOW - Russian President Vladimir Putin on Sunday thanked Russians who had come out to vote, saying that the result of the presidential election would allow Russian society to consolidate and become stronger.

Putin was speaking at his election headquarters late on Sunday after patial results showed he had won a record post-Soviet landslide.

title: Vladimir Putin will predictably win the Russian election, but it still matters - here's why | World News | Sky News
content:
It is better to be mute, to follow the rules."
This was a message also driven home by the fact that Boris Nadezhdin, the only independent candidate campaigning on an anti-war ticket, was not even allowed to run.
The three alternative candidates on the ballot from Kremlin-supplicant parliamentary parties have all declared themselves supportive both of the president and of his war.
They may secure some votes from those who cannot bring themselves to vote for Putin, but that vote will end up counting for little given the various ways and means by which both over-zealous electoral officials administering the polling stations and electronic voting can be massaged to fit the Kremlin's requirements.
For the majority in Russia, it is easier to stay passive, to go along with the Kremlin's voracious messaging, to tick the boxes on all things including at the ballot box and to hope that Putin's shiny new economic promises filter down their way.
Money in this militarised economy is flooding into regions which haven't traditionally seen much of it by way of army salaries and payouts to soldiers' families.
Click to subscribe to the Sky News Daily wherever you get your podcasts
The military-industrial complex is working apace, bringing employment and salaries in its wake. Russia's economy is robust and Putin mentions it at every chance he has.
Kolesnikov calls it Putin's Barbieland, an imaginary, happy Russia flush with cash that is buying people's silence.
"It is not just money as a factor of silencing," he says.
"Fear is also significant. Not in every case, for sure. Some people can't say that they are scared of persecution. But the atmosphere in the country is not pleasant."
Remember that when you see the government's turnout numbers, when you see polling for Putin at 80% which is reportedly the Kremlin's target.
This is a country purporting to be normal, holding normal elections, crushing, imprisoning, even killing its opposition, waging war on its next-door neighbour in the name of "self-defence".
But people know and feel that there is something wrong. The war is a disquieting factor. The atmosphere is not normal and it is not pleasant.
Read more:Navalny ally attacked with hammerCommunists ask FSB to probe 'West's role' in Stalin's death
"We will no longer tolerate criticism of our democracy. Our democracy is the best," Dmitry Peskov, the Kremlin spokesman, told a youth forum last week, as though democracy is anything the Kremlin wants it to be.
But it is not. Democracies allow for a free and fair vote, they do not encourage state workers to vote a certain way, knowing that their jobs hang in the balance if they do not.
Democracies do not change the constitution to allow the incumbent to stay in power into his third decade. Democracies allow for vibrant competition and here there is none.
Black is not white, whatever the Kremlin says.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
content:
然而，当话题转向战争，安德烈的情绪总会急转直下。虽然他并未亲身体会到战火的残酷，但持续两年的战争仍然在他的心中留下了深深的烙印。在他的身边，有人正在前线战斗，直面鲜血与死亡，也有人的生命在子弹之下永远停留在了25岁。“恐怖”与“可怕”，是他在谈到战争时最常挂在嘴边的形容词。
一面是看不到尽头的战火，另一面则是必须要继续下去的生活。如何在割裂的现实中继续探寻自己的人生，是年轻的安德烈与许许多多俄罗斯普通人必须面对的课题。
对于未来，安德烈有着朴实而又略显天真的期许：“我希望每个人都生活在和平中，希望乌克兰人来俄罗斯喝一喝我们的红菜汤，我们也能去乌克兰那里喝一喝他们的红菜汤。我希望我们的餐桌上有美国汉堡，他们的餐桌上也有我们的煎饼。老实说，我不想找出谁对谁错，我只想结束这一切。”
谈到战争时，安德烈首先想到的是自己现在正在前线战斗的朋友萨沙。“现在几乎每个俄罗斯人都有认识的人在前线，”安德烈说道，“萨沙是我儿时的好友，他从冲突开始就一直在前线战斗。我们已经很久没联系了……我希望他能活下来。”
2022年9月，俄罗斯总统普京签署局部动员令，宣布将征召30万名预备役军人，这也是俄罗斯二战以来首次展开军事动员。普京当时表示，“首先是那些曾在武装部队中服役、有一定军事专业和相关经验的人将被征召服兵役”，“被征召服兵役的人在被部署到部队之前必须接受额外的军事训练”。
与在战时被征召的俄罗斯民众不同，安德烈的朋友萨沙在俄乌冲突爆发前就已经自愿加入军队，并成为了一名合同兵。参军前，萨沙只是一名普通的建筑工人，家中还有一个妹妹。当时，对于没有接受过高等教育、身体素质好的人来说，参军是一个获得较高薪资的好选择。也有一些受过高等教育的人选择参军，他们得到的工资更高，职责也会与其他人有所不同。
“2022年2月前，当一个合同兵没有那么可怕。他们那时不需要去作战，军队给合同兵的工资又一向很高。”安德烈说道。
安德烈另外补充说，战争期间，合同兵的报酬更高，最低也有2000美元（约合人民币1.4万元）左右的月薪，有些人甚至能拿到3000-5000美元（约合人民币2.2万-3.6万元）。如果摧毁了敌方的一些武器装备，还会获得额外的奖励。
translation:
However, Andre's mood always took a turn for the worse when the topic turned to the war. Although he did not personally experience the cruelty of the war, the two-year war still left a deep mark on his heart. Around him, there were people who were fighting on the front line, facing blood and death, and there were also people whose lives were stuck at the age of 25 forever under bullets. "Terror" and "terrible" are the adjectives he most often uses when talking about war.
On one side is the war with no end in sight, on the other side is life that must go on. How to continue to explore one's own life in a fragmented reality is a question that young Andrei and many ordinary Russians must face.
For the future, Andrei has simple and slightly naive expectations: "I hope everyone can live in peace. I hope Ukrainians will come to Russia and drink our red cabbage soup, and we can also go to Ukraine and drink theirs." Beetroot soup. I want American burgers on our table and our pancakes on their table, honestly, I don’t want to find out who’s right and who’s wrong, I just want this to end.”
When Andre talks about the war, the first thing he thinks of is his friend Sasha, who is currently fighting on the front line. "Almost every Russian today knows someone on the front line," Andrei said. "Sasha is a childhood friend of mine who has been fighting on the front line since the beginning of the conflict. We haven't been in touch for a long time... I Hope he survives."
In September 2022, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a partial mobilization order, announcing that 300,000 reservists would be recruited. This is the first time Russia has launched military mobilization since World War II. Putin said at the time that "first of all, those who have served in the armed forces and have certain military expertise and relevant experience will be called up for military service." "Those who are called up for military service must receive additional military training before being deployed to the troops. ".
Unlike the Russian people who were conscripted during the war, Andrei's friend Sasha had already voluntarily joined the army before the outbreak of the Russian-Ukrainian conflict and became a contract soldier. Before joining the army, Sasha was just an ordinary construction worker and had a younger sister at home. At that time, for those who did not receive higher education and were in good physical condition, joining the army was a good option to obtain a higher salary. There are also some highly educated people who choose to join the military, where they receive higher wages and different responsibilities than others.
"Before February 2022, being a contract soldier is not that scary. They don't need to fight at that time, and the army's salary for contract soldiers has always been very high." Andre said.
Andre also added that during the war, contract soldiers were paid higher, with a minimum monthly salary of around US$2,000 (approximately RMB 14,000), and some even received US$3,000-5,000 (approximately RMB 22,000- 36,000 yuan). If you destroy some enemy weapons and equipment, you will get additional rewards.
input:

For the future, Andrei has simple and slightly naive expectations: "I hope everyone can live in peace. I hope Ukrainians will come to Russia and drink our red cabbage soup, and we can also go to Ukraine and drink theirs." Beetroot soup. I want American burgers on our table and our pancakes on their table, honestly, I don’t want to find out who’s right and who’s wrong, I just want this to end.”
When Andre talks about the war, the first thing he thinks of is his friend Sasha, who is currently fighting on the front line. "Almost every Russian today knows someone on the front line," Andrei said. "Sasha is a childhood friend of mine who has been fighting on the front line since the beginning of the conflict. We haven't been in touch for a long time... I Hope he survives."
In September 2022, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a partial mobilization order, announcing that 300,000 reservists would be recruited. This is the first time Russia has launched military mobilization since World War II. Putin said at the time that "first of all, those who have served in the armed forces and have certain military expertise and relevant experience will be called up for military service." "Those who are called up for military service must receive additional military training before being deployed to the troops. ".
Unlike the Russian people who were conscripted during the war, Andrei's friend Sasha had already voluntarily joined the army before the outbreak of the Russian-Ukrainian conflict and became a contract soldier. Before joining the army, Sasha was just an ordinary construction worker and had a younger sister at home. At that time, for those who did not receive higher education and were in good physical condition, joining the army was a good option to obtain a higher salary. There are also some highly educated people who choose to join the military, where they receive higher wages and different responsibilities than others.
"Before February 2022, being a contract soldier is not that scary. They don't need to fight at that time, and the army's salary for contract soldiers has always been very high." Andre said.
Andre also added that during the war, contract soldiers were paid higher, with a minimum monthly salary of around US$2,000 (approximately RMB 14,000), and some even received US$3,000-5,000 (approximately RMB 22,000- 36,000 yuan). If you destroy some enemy weapons and equipment, you will get additional rewards.

title: Putin extends rule in predetermined Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era | KSL.com
content:
Chinese President Xi Jinping, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan congratulated Putin, as did North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and the presidents of nations that have historic and current ties to Russia, such as Azerbaijan and Belarus.
Navalny's associates urged those unhappy with Putin or the war to go to the polls at noon Sunday — and lines outside a number of polling stations both inside Russia and at its embassies around the world appeared to swell at that time.
Navalny's widow, Yulia Navalnaya, who spent more than five hours in the line at the Russian Embassy in Berlin, told reporters that she wrote her late husband's name on her ballot.
Asked whether she had a message for Putin, Navalnaya replied: "Please stop asking for messages from me or from somebody for Mr. Putin. There could be no negotiations and nothing with Mr. Putin, because he's a killer, he's a gangster."
Putin referenced Navalny by name for the first time in years at the news conference, declaring that he had been ready to release him in a swap for unidentified inmates in Western custody just days before the opposition leader's death.
Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, disputed those claims. He told reporters during a White House briefing Monday that U.S. officials had spoken to Russia for "months and years" about releasing American detainees but "have not heard a Russian official raise Navalny as part of a prisoner swap in any of these conversations."
Supporters of Navalny streamed to his grave in Moscow, some bringing ballots with his name written on them.
The Russian leader brushed off the effectiveness of the apparent protest and rejected Western criticism of the vote. Instead, he tried to turn the tables on the West, charging that the four criminal cases against former President Donald Trump were a use of the judiciary for political aims.
"The whole world is laughing at it," he said.
Some people told the AP that they were happy to vote for Putin — unsurprising in a country where state TV airs a drumbeat of praise for the Russian leader and voicing any other opinion is risky.
Dmitry Sergienko, who cast his ballot in Moscow, said, "I am happy with everything and want everything to continue as it is now."
Voting took place over three days at polling stations across the vast country, in illegally annexed regions of Ukraine and online.
Several people were arrested, including in Moscow and St. Petersburg, after they tried to start fires or set off explosives at polling stations while a few others were detained for throwing green antiseptic or ink into ballot boxes. Many more were rounded up by police for attempting to protest.
The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that about 90 people were arrested in 22 cities across Russia on Sunday.
Stanislav Andreychuk, co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said Russians were searched when entering polling stations, there were attempts to check filled-out ballots before they were cast, and one report said police demanded a ballot box be opened to remove a ballot.
Huge lines formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin's invasion of Ukraine.

title: Six more years of Putin will worry many countries. But not China | CNN
content:
Beijing, however, says it is working “tirelessly” to bring the conflict to a close as it seeks to carve out an image as peacemaker. It sent special envoy for Eurasia Li Hui on two tours to Russia, Ukraine and other parts of Europe to promote a negotiated end to the conflict, the second of which concluded last week.
    

            Chinese foreign policy thinkers such as Wang Yiwei of Renmin University say Beijing is concerned about nuclear escalation – a threat recently raised again by Putin – and the potential for more European countries to become directly involved in the war. “How to avoid escalating the conflict … that’s Li Hui’s special concern this time,” he told CNN.
    

            But Li, a former ambassador to Russia, and other Chinese officials are seen in much of Europe as merely presenting a plan whose outcome would benefit Putin. That’s in line with European views on Beijing’s stance since the war’s opening days, when it insisted that all sides’ “legitimate security concerns” must be resolved.
    

            For now, as pressure from across the world to end the conflict grows, the foregone results of this weekend’s Russian election will likely only bolster the view in Beijing – and some other non-Western capitals – that they were right to back Putin.
    

  This story has been updated with additional information.


  CNN’s Josh Pennington, Anna Chernova and Wayne Chang contributed to this report.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出，普京迎接“硬核”挑战_新闻频道_中国青年网
content:
“普京看上去有干劲、精力充沛，他对情况掌握充分，即便是细节也有所了解。”《俄罗斯报》写道。
　　“这些任务十分艰巨。”陈玉荣表示，“普京连任将有利于俄罗斯内外政策的连贯性，也有助于推动俄罗斯经济社会改革措施的落实。”
　　平叛强军
　　1999年，普京重拳出击，出动10万大军和新型装备，历时三年基本肃清了车臣境内非法武装，取得第二次车臣战争胜利。
　　在某一年的年度记者会上，普京曾讲过一个“佩剑换表”的故事，强调发展军事力量的重要性：一位前军官问他的儿子，原有的一把佩剑去哪了？儿子回答把它拿去跟邻居小孩换表了。军官看了看换来的表，对儿子说，“不错，但如果有一天强盗来了，打我、妈妈还有你的兄弟，欺侮你的姐妹。你该怎么办？跟他说‘晚上好，现在是莫斯科时间12点30分？’”
　　近些年来，俄罗斯的军事现代化水平不断提升。2012年，俄军现代化武器装备所占比例只有16%，2021年底，这一比例达到了71.2%。
　　2022年后，尽管俄罗斯在对乌克兰的特别军事行动中投入了大量军事资源，但仍保持了对“三位一体”战略核力量的投入力度，将其中现代化武器装备的比例提升至95%，以确保对北约进行有效战略威慑。
　　同时，俄罗斯的新式武器系统也在不断突破，“锆石”海基高超音速巡航导弹已投入使用，“先锋”洲际高超音速导弹等已进入战斗值班，“海燕”核动力巡航导弹的试验已接近完成。
　　外交破局
　　“你什么时候邀请俄罗斯加入北约？”普京2001年造访北约总部时，曾向时任北约秘书长罗伯逊询问。
　　俄罗斯与北约一度有过“蜜月期“。但随着北约不断东扩，双方关系几番起落，2014年克里米亚事件发生后，北约停止与俄一切军事交往，关系全面恶化。
　　时至今日，北约已实现新一轮扩张，吸纳了俄罗斯的邻国芬兰和瑞典。加上美西方不断“拱火”乌克兰危机，地缘政治博弈愈演愈烈，俄与美西方关系一跌再跌，滑入冰谷。
　　陈玉荣指出，当前俄美、俄欧关系陷于冷战后最糟糕的境地。普京连任后，短期内，俄西方紧张对峙关系很难改变。“未来俄西方关系的变化，很大程度上还要取决于乌克兰危机如何解决。”
　　不过，面对西方的围堵，俄罗斯努力破局，积极拓展与全球南方国家关系。
　　2023年12月，普京顶住美国和欧洲一些国家竭力孤立俄的压力，出访阿联酋和沙特，商讨石油合作与巴以冲突问题；这一年，俄罗斯继续与独联体国家密切合作，与印度开展密集政治对话，召开俄罗斯-非洲峰会与非洲多国互动。
　　在普京2023年批准的新版《外交政策构想》中，俄罗斯还计划将优先发展同伊朗、土耳其、沙特阿拉伯、埃及和叙利亚的关系，在经济、安全等领域与东盟国家加强合作。
　　“多极化的国际关系体系正在形成，是不可逆的过程。”普京多次表示，“我们会努力联合世界大多数国家，以应对全球性挑战。”
translation:
"Putin seems motivated and energetic. He has a full grasp of the situation, even the details." "Russia Rossiya" wrote.
"These tasks are very arduous." Chen Yurong said, "Putin's re-election will be conducive to the coherence of Russia's domestic and foreign policies, and will also help promote the implementation of Russia's economic and social reform measures."
Counterinsurgency and strengthen the army
In 1999, Putin struck hard, dispatching 100,000 troops and new equipment. It took three years to basically eliminate the illegal armed forces in Chechnya and win the second Chechen War.
At the annual press conference of a certain year, Putin once told a story about "exchanging swords for watches" to emphasize the importance of developing military power: A former military officer asked his son where the original sword went. Already? The son replied that he took it to exchange watches with a neighbor's kid. The officer looked at the exchanged watch and said to his son, "Yes, but if one day a robber comes and beats me, my mother and your brothers, and bullies your sisters. What should you do? Say to him 'Good evening' , is it 12:30 Moscow time?'"
In recent years, Russia's military modernization level has continued to improve. In 2012, the proportion of modern weapons and equipment in the Russian army was only 16%. By the end of 2021, this proportion reached 71.2%.
After 2022, although Russia invested a large amount of military resources in the special military operation against Ukraine, it still maintained its investment in the "Trinity" strategic nuclear force and increased the proportion of modern weapons and equipment to 95% to ensure that it NATO conducts effective strategic deterrence.
At the same time, Russia's new weapon systems are also making continuous breakthroughs. The "Zircon" sea-based hypersonic cruise missile has been put into use, the "Pioneer" intercontinental hypersonic missile has entered combat duty, and the test of the "Haiyan" nuclear-powered cruise missile is approaching. Finish.
Diplomacy breaks down
"When will you invite Russia to join NATO?" Putin asked then NATO Secretary-General Robertson when he visited NATO headquarters in 2001.
Russia and NATO once had a "honeymoon period." However, as NATO continues to expand eastward, relations between the two sides have experienced ups and downs. After the Crimea incident in 2014, NATO stopped all military exchanges with Russia, and relations deteriorated overall.
Today, NATO has achieved a new round of expansion, absorbing Russia's neighbors Finland and Sweden. Coupled with the fact that the United States and the West continue to "fire up" the Ukraine crisis, the geopolitical game has intensified, and the relationship between Russia and the United States and the West has fallen again and again, slipping into an icy valley.
Chen Yurong pointed out that the current relations between Russia, the United States, and Russia and Europe are in the worst situation since the Cold War. After Putin's re-election, it will be difficult to change the tense confrontation between Russia and the West in the short term. "Future changes in Russia-Western relations will largely depend on how the Ukraine crisis is resolved."
However, in the face of Western encirclement, Russia has worked hard to break through the situation and actively expanded its relations with countries in the Global South.
In December 2023, Putin resisted the pressure of the United States and some European countries to isolate Russia and visited the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia to discuss oil cooperation and the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. During this year, Russia continued to cooperate closely with the CIS countries and carried out cooperation with India. Intensive political dialogue, convening a Russia-Africa summit to interact with many African countries.
In the new version of the "Foreign Policy Concept" approved by Putin in 2023, Russia also plans to give priority to developing relations with Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria, and strengthen cooperation with ASEAN countries in economic, security and other fields.
"A multipolar international relations system is taking shape, which is an irreversible process." Putin has said many times, "We will work hard to unite most countries in the world to respond to global challenges."

title: Hundreds line up at Russia’s embassy in Brussels to vote against Putin – POLITICO
content:
Some 400 to 500 people queued at the Russian embassy in Brussels on Sunday to vote in Russia’s presidential election, most of them participating in the “Noon Against Putin” protest action called by opposition groups. 
While President Vladimir Putin is certain to win the vote, Russians in the capital of the EU were doing their part to show their distaste for the leader who has spent years cracking down on all forms of dissent against his rule.
“I came here to vote. To vote against Putin,” said Olga, who brought along her family. “The action is a pure demonstration of disagreement with what is happening in our country,” she said.
The “Noon Against Putin” initiative, supported by virtually all Russian opposition groups as well as the late Alexei Navalny, encouraged voters to go to polling stations, whether in Russia or abroad, at noon on Sunday and vote for any of the non-Putin candidates or spoil the ballot.
It contributed to a backup at the embassy in Brussels. 
“Get ready to wait at least 40 minutes more. We didn’t expect that amount of people,” an embassy employee told POLITICO after people had already spent 30 minutes in the queue. 
People were openly happy and inspired to come together with so many others who shared their dissenting views. Many of them were taking selfies, showing themselves in the 200-meter line.
“I have no ‘my candidates’ on the list,” said Kirill, who described himself as a Russian poet-in-exile. “Still, it is very important to get here to establish connections [with other opposition-minded Russians],” he said. 
“I can see people sending photos of spoiled ballots with different mottos on them. That is very important,” said Kirill, who came to vote with his partner, child and their dog. “We’re all in a situation where we have to redefine some agendas. And I think that’s what this election is for,” he said.
Putin, first elected president in 2000, has spent the better part of two decades clamping down on opposition and tightening his grip over Russian society. Moscow’s all-out invasion of Ukraine in 2022 sparked even greater domestic repression.
“The ‘Noon Against Putin’ is a good way of protesting,” said Sergey, a Russian political analyst, while he waited to cast his vote.
“At the very least, we met like-minded people. In a situation where people no longer believe anything or anyone and are at the lowest point of disillusionment in decades, this is a big deal,” Sergey said. 
Denis Leven is hosted at POLITICO under the EU-funded EU4FreeMedia residency program.

title: Russian presidential election 2024: Putin extends one-man rule after stage-managed election devoid of credible opposition | CNN
content:
Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, had urged Russians to turn out collectively as a show of opposition on Sunday, the final day of voting across Russia’s 11 time zones and 88 federal subjects. In the runup, the Kremlin warned against unsanctioned gatherings.
    

            A CNN team in Moscow saw the line outside a polling station grow rapidly at midday as part of the so-called “Noon Against Putin” demonstrations inspired by Navalny. A woman waiting in line told CNN: “This is the first time in my life I have ever seen a queue for elections.” Asked why she had come at that hour, she replied: “You know why. I think everybody in this queue knows why.”
    

            Similar protests were staged at Russian embassies across Europe, with large crowds gathering at noon in London, Paris and elsewhere. Navalnaya attended a demonstration in Berlin, waiting in line with other voters in a display of opposition.
    

            The election was also marred by more graphic acts of defiance. As of Saturday, Russia had filed at least 15 criminal cases after people poured dye in ballot boxes, started fires or lobbed Molotov cocktails at polling stations. Ella Pamfilova, the head of Russia’s CEC, said 29 polling stations across 20 regions in Russia were targeted, including eight arson attempts.
    

            More than 60 Russians were detained across at least 16 cities on the final day of voting, according to independent human rights group OVD-Info.
    

            Russia also held the presidential election in four Ukrainian regions it annexed during its full-scale invasion. Ukraine said the elections violated international law and would be designated “null and void.”
    

            Russian-installed authorities in occupied Ukraine reported high turnout of more than 80%. But evidence has emerged of voter coercion. Russian Telegram channels have shown Russian soldiers accompanying election officials as they go house-to-house to collect votes.

Ella Pamfilova, the head of Russia’s CEC, said 29 polling stations across 20 regions in Russia were targeted, including eight arson attempts.
    

            More than 60 Russians were detained across at least 16 cities on the final day of voting, according to independent human rights group OVD-Info.
    

            Russia also held the presidential election in four Ukrainian regions it annexed during its full-scale invasion. Ukraine said the elections violated international law and would be designated “null and void.”
    

            Russian-installed authorities in occupied Ukraine reported high turnout of more than 80%. But evidence has emerged of voter coercion. Russian Telegram channels have shown Russian soldiers accompanying election officials as they go house-to-house to collect votes.

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
content:
据英国广播公司（BBC）报道，纳瓦利内的支持者在俄罗斯总统选举期间确实举行了象征性的抗议活动，但并未对大选结果造成任何影响。
 
普京在胜选演讲中也首次提到了纳瓦利内去世一事。他说，俄罗斯的选举是民主的，纳瓦利内去世引发的抗议活动对选举结果没有影响。他还称，纳瓦利内的去世是一个“悲伤的事件”。
 
实际上，俄罗斯此次大选的投票率创下新的历史纪录。据“今日俄罗斯”报道，俄罗斯中央选举委员会3月17日表示，在为期三天的大选中，俄罗斯1.12亿选民中有超过74%参加了投票，这是俄罗斯现代史上的最高投票率。


3月15日，选民在俄罗斯圣彼得堡登记参加总统选举投票。新华社记者 安晓萌 摄
 
俄罗斯上一次有如此高的投票率还是在1991年的第一次总统选举中，那一届总统选举的投票率大约也为74%。此后的几届大选投票率基本都在64%-69%之间。2018年的大选投票率为67%。
 
在首次参加俄罗斯总统选举的四个地区——俄罗斯控制的乌东“顿涅茨克人民共和国”、“卢甘斯克人民共和国”、赫尔松地区和扎波罗热地区，投票率也处于高位。四个地区的投票率分别为88%、87%、83.7%、85%。2022年9月，这四个地区举行“公投”，同意加入俄罗斯联邦。
 
此次大选是俄罗斯首次举行为期三天的总统选举，俄罗斯各地选民可以在3月15日至17日这三天内任意一天的早八点至晚八点前去投票。
translation:
According to the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), Navalny's supporters did hold symbolic protests during the Russian presidential election, but they did not have any impact on the election results.
 
Putin also mentioned the death of Navalny for the first time in his victory speech. He said Russia's elections were democratic and the protests triggered by Navalny's death had no impact on the results. He also called Navalny's death a "sad event."
 
In fact, the turnout for this election in Russia hit a new historical record. According to "Russia Today", Russia's Central Election Commission stated on March 17 that in the three-day general election, more than 74% of Russia's 112 million voters participated in the vote, which was the highest turnout in Russia's modern history.


On March 15, voters registered to vote in the presidential election in St. Petersburg, Russia. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter An Xiaomeng
 
The last time Russia had such a high turnout was in the first presidential election in 1991, when the turnout was about 74%. The turnout rate in subsequent general elections has generally been between 64% and 69%. The turnout rate for the 2018 general election was 67%.
 
Voter turnout was also high in the four regions participating in Russia's presidential election for the first time - the Russian-controlled Donetsk People's Republic in eastern Ukraine, the Lugansk People's Republic, the Kherson region and the Zaporozhye region. . The voting rates in the four regions were 88%, 87%, 83.7%, and 85% respectively. In September 2022, these four regions will hold a "referendum" and agree to join the Russian Federation.
 
This election is the first three-day presidential election held in Russia. Voters across Russia can vote from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. on any of the three days from March 15 to 17.

title: 普京胜选表态:竭尽所能实现国家主要任务和目标
content:
中新社莫斯科3月18日电 (记者 田冰)俄罗斯总统候选人、现任总统普京18日在选举投票结束后召开的首场记者会上表示,将竭尽所能实现国家主要任务和目标。
莫斯科时间18日7时,俄中央选举委员会公布对99.43%选票的计票结果,普京在2024年总统大选中获得87.32%的支持。实际上普京已经赢得大选。
俄联邦共产党提名的候选人哈里托诺夫获得4.32%的选票,俄新人党提名的候选人达万科夫获得3.79%的选票,俄自民党提名的候选人斯卢茨基得票率为3.19%。
普京在18日凌晨来到克里姆林宫附近的竞选总部发表讲话,并随后召开记者会。
普京表示,俄罗斯权力的来源是人民,每个俄罗斯公民的选票构成了人民的统一意志。他将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。
普京指出,俄罗斯发展的所有主要任务和目标已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述,他将竭尽所能完成既定目标。俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展,变得更强大、有力、高效。
针对乌克兰问题,普京表示,对乌特别军事行动前线的主动权完全掌握在俄军手中。特别军事行动问题和加强俄国防能力是其新任期的主要任务之一。他说,俄方支持和平谈判,但不能只是因为对方的子弹快用完了,而是他们如果确实地、认真地、长期地希望两国建立和平,俄罗斯支持就乌克兰问题进行谈判。“这是非常严肃的问题”。
普京同时表示,考虑到乌军对俄罗斯别尔哥罗德州等地的攻击,俄罗斯不排除将于某个时候在边境地区建立“安全区”的可能性。
对于美国,普京再次表示,俄方对任何一位美国总统候选人都没有偏好,俄罗斯准备与美国选民投票支持的任何美国领导人合作。
在回答俄罗斯与北约之间是否有可能爆发全面冲突以及有多大可能性问题时,普京说,“在现代世界一切皆有可能”。他指出,乌克兰目前有北约国家的军事人员存在,而且他们正在“大量死亡”。
对于中俄关系,普京表示,俄中关系经过多年发展,非常稳定,具有很强互补性。普京指出,俄中两国在经济、外交等领域有诸多契合点。就亚欧地区发展而言,俄中关系是一个重要稳定因素,中方提出的共建“一带一路”倡议非常重要。
普京积极评价中国的发展成就。他认为,中国正在非常自信地实现飞速发展,并向创新型经济转型；中国在国际舞台上日益活跃并取得巨大成功,在世界各地拥有许多朋友。
普京强调,台湾是中国不可分割的一部分；那些在台湾周围进行挑衅并采取种种措施迟滞中国发展的企图,无疑会彻底失败。
俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。俄中选委宣布,将不晚于3月28日确认本届总统选举最终结果,并在确认后3日内公布。
translation:
China News Service, Moscow, March 18 (Reporter Tian Bing) Russian presidential candidate and current President Vladimir Putin said at his first press conference after the election voting on the 18th that he would do his best to achieve the country's main tasks and goals.
At 7:00 a.m. Moscow time on the 18th, the Russian Central Election Commission announced the counting results of 99.43% of the votes. Putin won 87.32% of the support in the 2024 presidential election. Putin has actually won the election.
Kharitonov, the candidate nominated by the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, received 4.32% of the votes, Davankov, the candidate nominated by the Russian New People's Party, received 3.79% of the votes, and Slutsky, the candidate nominated by the Russian Liberal Democratic Party, received 3.19% of the votes.
Putin came to the campaign headquarters near the Kremlin to deliver a speech in the early morning of the 18th, and then held a press conference.
Putin said that the source of Russian power is the people, and the votes of every Russian citizen constitute the unified will of the people. He will continue to promote national development in his new term.
Putin pointed out that all the main tasks and goals of Russia's development have been elaborated in the recent State of the Union address to both houses of parliament, and he will do his best to achieve the set goals. Russia will move forward and become stronger, more powerful and more efficient.
Regarding the Ukrainian issue, Putin stated that the initiative on the frontline of the special military operation against Ukraine lies entirely in the hands of the Russian army. The issue of special military operations and strengthening Russia's defense capabilities are one of the main tasks of his new term. He said that Russia supports peace negotiations, but not just because the other side is running out of bullets, but if they truly, seriously and long-term hope that the two countries can establish peace, Russia supports negotiations on the Ukrainian issue. "This is a very serious issue."
Putin also said that considering the Ukrainian army's attacks on Russia's Belgorod region and other places, Russia does not rule out the possibility of establishing a "safe zone" in the border area at some point.
Regarding the United States, Putin once again stated that Russia has no preference for any American presidential candidate and that Russia is ready to cooperate with any American leader that American voters vote for.
When answering the question of whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO is possible and how likely it is, Putin said, "Everything is possible in the modern world." He pointed out that there are currently military personnel from NATO countries in Ukraine, and they are "dying in large numbers."
Regarding Sino-Russian relations, Putin said that after years of development, Russia-China relations are very stable and highly complementary. Putin pointed out that Russia and China have many points of convergence in economic, diplomatic and other fields. As far as the development of the Eurasian region is concerned, Russia-China relations are an important stabilizing factor, and the joint construction of the "Belt and Road" initiative proposed by China is very important.
Putin spoke positively of China's development achievements. He believes that China is achieving rapid development with great confidence and transforming into an innovative economy; China is increasingly active on the international stage and has achieved great success, and has many friends around the world.
Putin emphasized that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China; those who seek provocation around Taiwan and take various measures to delay China's development will undoubtedly fail completely.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. The Russian-Chinese Election Commission announced that it will confirm the final results of this presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after confirmation.

title: In Post-Election Speech, Putin Threatens NATO With World War | TIME
content:
Vladimir Putin warned that a direct confrontation between Russia and NATO would be “one step away from a full-scale World War III” in a speech following his reelection on Monday. 
“I think hardly anyone is interested in this,” Putin added. 
The three-day vote, which wrapped up Sunday, saw Putin face no credible opposition. Western countries and election watchdogs have been quick to call it a “sham” contest.
Putin’s comments come after French President Emmanuel Macron said last week he could not rule out the deployment of French troops in Ukraine if Russia’s invasion continues. 
Putin also raised the prospect of taking Ukraine’s Kharkiv region as a buffer zone between the two countries. Ukraine had reportedly increased its shelling on Russian border regions during the vote. 
With no viable alternative candidates permitted to participate in the three-day election, Putin claimed 87% of the vote, according to exit polling published by the state-run Russian Public Opinion Research Center and the Public Opinion Foundation. That figure is an increase from 2018, when Putin claimed 76.7% of the vote with a voter turnout of 67.5%. The latest result extends Putin’s nearly 25-year rule with a fifth term that will last until 2030. 
The White House said the election was “obviously not free nor fair,” while Ukrainian President, Volodymyr Zelensky, said Sunday that Putin had become “addicted to power.”  
During his Monday address, Putin also acknowledged Alexei Navalny for the first time since the opposition leader’s death in a Russian penal colony on Feb. 16. Putin said the 47-year-old “passed away” and that he had agreed to a prisoner swap with the U.S. that would see Navalny freed on the condition that he never returns to Russia. U.S. President Joe Biden has blamed Putin for Navalny’s death, saying last month, “Make no mistake, Putin is responsible.”
Navalny’s death had sparked unprecedented protests in Russia and his widow Yulia Navalnaya had called for demonstrations at polling booths dubbed “noon against Putin.” The plan had been endorsed by her late husband before his death.  
On Sunday, Navalnaya shared that she had written “Navalny” on her election ballot paper. “You give me hope that everything is not in vain, that we will still fight,” she said of her supporters.

title: 普京胜选后有人公开唱反调,俄共候选人:社会主义俄罗斯才有前途
content:
3月18日,2024年度的俄罗斯总统大选终于落下帷幕,普京以87.82%的得票率,一共拿走了全国7600多万张选票,毫无悬念地登上了俄罗斯总统宝座。本次俄罗斯总统大选一共有四位候选人参选,除了普京之外还有斯卢茨基、哈里托诺夫、达万科夫等人参选,但很明显三个人都是“陪跑”的角色。不过这三个人中,哈里托诺夫还算是比较引人关注,因为他是俄联邦共产党推出的候选人,同时也是俄罗斯国家杜马的副主席。在普京胜选后,他公开唱反调称,只有社会主义的俄罗斯才有前途。
哈里托诺夫此前曾多次参选,但每一次都被普京击败了。2024年的这场总统选举结束之后,他又开始了老一套的宣传。在接受俄罗斯媒体采访时,哈里托诺夫宣称俄罗斯只有恢复了社会主义制度,国家的发展才有前途可言。对于他这样的说辞,普京自然是不会在乎的。因为现在普京才是真正的政坛“话事人”,对于旁人这种无关痛痒的发言自然不用过多理会。但要说哈里托诺夫的话在俄罗斯社会激不起任何一点浪花,恐怕也并不绝对。
translation:
On March 18, the 2024 Russian presidential election finally came to an end. With 87.82% of the vote, Putin took away a total of more than 76 million votes nationwide and ascended to the throne of Russia's president without any doubt. There are a total of four candidates running in this Russian presidential election. In addition to Putin, there are also Slutsky, Kharitonov, Davankov and others running, but it is obvious that all three of them are "running with them" character of. However, among these three people, Kharitonov is relatively eye-catching because he is a candidate promoted by the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and is also the deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma. After Putin won the election, he publicly sang the opposite tune and said that only a socialist Russia has a future.
Kharitonov has run for office several times before, but was defeated by Putin each time. After the 2024 presidential election, he started his old propaganda again. In an interview with Russian media, Kharitonov claimed that only when Russia restores its socialist system can the country's development have a future. Putin naturally doesn't care about his rhetoric. Because Putin is now the real "talker" in the political arena, he naturally doesn't need to pay too much attention to other people's irrelevant remarks. But it is probably not absolute to say that Kharitonov's words will not stir up any waves in Russian society.
input:

With 87.82% of the vote, Putin took away a total of more than 76 million votes nationwide and ascended to the throne of Russia's president without any doubt. There are a total of four candidates running in this Russian presidential election. In addition to Putin, there are also Slutsky, Kharitonov, Davankov and others running, but it is obvious that all three of them are "running with them" character of. However, among these three people, Kharitonov is relatively eye-catching because he is a candidate promoted by the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and is also the deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma. After Putin won the election, he publicly sang the opposite tune and said that only a socialist Russia has a future.
Kharitonov has run for office several times before, but was defeated by Putin each time. After the 2024 presidential election, he started his old propaganda again. In an interview with Russian media, Kharitonov claimed that only when Russia restores its socialist system can the country's development have a future. Putin naturally doesn't care about his rhetoric. Because Putin is now the real "talker" in the political arena, he naturally doesn't need to pay too much attention to other people's irrelevant remarks. But it is probably not absolute to say that Kharitonov's words will not stir up any waves in Russian society.

title: Раз, два, три, четыре, пять — честность я иду искать. Как прошли выборы-2024 в цифрах
content:
Президентские выборы в России шли три дня. С 15 по 17 марта россияне обливали урны зеленкой, поджигали скатерти, переодевались в императоров и царей и даже молились. Пока избиркомы подгоняли результаты под «нужный» уровень, «7х7» тоже решил подсчитать результаты выборов. 

Они выливали зеленку, йод, краску и чернила в урны, чтобы испортить бюллетени. По словам главы Центризбиркома, им обещали за это деньги и инструктировали по телефону из-за рубежа. Мы заметили такие случаи в 16 регионах. Рейтинг возглавляет Воронежская область и Москва. Там жители трижды красили урны, подробнее — на нашей карте. По 33 случаям МВД возбудило уголовные дела по статье о «воспрепятствовании осуществлению избирательных прав».

Избиратели жгли урны для бюллетеней, скатерти, кабинки для голосования и другие предметы на избирательных участках. Они бросали дымовые шашки, коктейли Молотова и петарды. В семи случаях поджоги удались.

Причины задержаний разные: силовикам не понравился шарф с цитатой Оруэлла, попытка бросить фото Навального в урну и детские каракули в бюллетени матери, которая пришла на участок с полуторагодовалым ребенком.

Треть из них — по статье «о воспрепятствовании работе избирательной комиссии» (ст. 141 УК РФ).

Изображение или упоминание кого-либо из кандидатов на УИК считается незаконной агитацией. В Алтайском крае и Мурманской области отказались снять портреты, потому что они — «государственный символ».

В Краснодаре члена УИК Руслана Хубаева и наблюдателя Дмитрия Королева после сообщения о вбросе задержали и составили на них несколько административных протоколов. Хубаева обвинили в мелком хулиганстве и демонстрации экстремистской символики в соцсетях, а Королева — в неповиновении полиции.

Павел Сычев, наблюдатель в Воронеже, уговорил комиссию вытащить из урны вброшенные бюллетени.

Одной из них оказалась Надежда Пинегина, член комиссии с правом решающего голоса. 15 марта она вылила зеленку на электронную урну для голосования. Глава ЦИК Элла Памфилова назвала ее «уродом».

В Забайкальском крае избиратели пришли на участки в образах Ивана Грозного, Иосифа Сталина, Екатерины II, Александра II, Александра Невского и Петра I. В Чите Александр II Освободитель извинялся за продажу Аляски, а Сталин пришел, чтобы «испугать врага».

Певец SHAMAN трижды перекрестился, прежде чем бросить бюллетень в урну. А муфтий республики Ахмед Абдулаев вместе с супругой устроил коллективную молитву на избирательном участке в Дагестане.

На УИК в Новосибирском государственном университете его обошел кандидат от партии «Новые люди» — Владислав Даванков. Правда, на участке в алтайском Барнауле, где победу сначала одержал Николай Харитонов от КПРФ, после сообщений об этом в СМИ голоса решили пересчитать в пользу Путина. Во Владивостоке, по данным экзитпола штаба Надеждина, Владислав Даванков набрал 41% голосов, а Владимир Путин — 19% в Дальневосточном федеральном университете.
translation:
The presidential elections in Russia lasted three days. From March 15 to 17, Russians doused trash cans with green paint, set tablecloths on fire, dressed up as emperors and tsars, and even prayed. While the election commissions were adjusting the results to the “required” level, “7x7” also decided to count the election results.

They poured brilliant green, iodine, paint and ink into the ballot boxes to ruin the ballots. According to the head of the Central Election Commission, they were promised money for this and instructed by telephone from abroad. We noticed such cases in 16 regions. The rating is headed by the Voronezh region and Moscow. There, residents painted the ballot boxes three times; see our map for more details. In 33 cases, the Ministry of Internal Affairs opened criminal cases under the article on “obstruction of the exercise of electoral rights.”

Voters burned ballot boxes, tablecloths, voting booths and other items at polling stations. They threw smoke bombs, Molotov cocktails and firecrackers. In seven cases the arson fires were successful.

The reasons for the arrests are different: the security forces did not like the scarf with an Orwell quote, the attempt to throw Navalny’s photo into the ballot box, and children’s scribbles on the ballot papers of a mother who came to the station with her one-and-a-half-year-old child.

A third of them are under the article “on obstructing the work of the election commission” (Article 141 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation).

Depicting or mentioning any candidate at a polling station is considered illegal campaigning. In the Altai Territory and the Murmansk Region they refused to remove the portraits because they are a “state symbol.”

In Krasnodar, PEC member Ruslan Khubaev and observer Dmitry Korolev were detained after reporting the stuffing and several administrative protocols were drawn up against them. Khubaev was accused of petty hooliganism and displaying extremist symbols on social networks, and Korolev was accused of disobeying the police.

Pavel Sychev, an observer in Voronezh, persuaded the commission to remove the thrown ballots from the ballot box.

One of them was Nadezhda Pinegina, a voting member of the commission. On March 15, she poured greenery onto an electronic ballot box. The head of the Central Election Commission, Ella Pamfilova, called her a “freak.”

In the Trans-Baikal Territory, voters came to the polls in the images of Ivan the Terrible, Joseph Stalin, Catherine II, Alexander II, Alexander Nevsky and Peter I. In Chita, Alexander II the Liberator apologized for the sale of Alaska, and Stalin came to “scare the enemy.”

Singer SHAMAN crossed himself three times before throwing his ballot into the ballot box. And the mufti of the republic, Akhmed Abdulaev, together with his wife, organized a collective prayer at a polling station in Dagestan.

At the PEC at Novosibirsk State University, he was beaten by the candidate from the New People party, Vladislav Davankov. True, at the polling station in Altai Barnaul, where Nikolai Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation first won, after reports about this in the media, they decided to count the votes in Putin’s favor. In Vladivostok, according to the exit poll of Nadezhdin’s headquarters, Vladislav Davankov received 41% of the votes, and Vladimir Putin - 19% at the Far Eastern Federal University.

title: 克宫：普京尚未就是否参加2024年俄总统选举发表任何声明
content:
据环球网援引塔斯社11月6日报道，对于路透社援引消息人士的话称“普京已决定参加下一届俄罗斯总统竞选”，俄罗斯总统新闻秘书、克宫发言人佩斯科夫回应说，普京尚未就是否参加2024年总统选举发表任何声明。
此前，有六名消息人士向外界透露称，普京已决定参加于明年3月举行的俄罗斯总统大选，而此举将使其至少能够执政至2030年。上述消息人士同时表示，普京的顾问已经开始为大选做准备，预计将很快宣布这一消息。佩斯科夫对此回应称：“普京尚未就此发表任何声明。竞选活动本身也尚未正式宣布。”
根据俄罗斯方面消息，俄罗斯总统选举预计将于2024年3月17日举行。俄罗斯联邦委员会（议会上院）将于2023年12月正式确定选举日期，之后各政党将召开选前会议并正式提名候选人。
translation:
According to a report by TASS on November 6, quoted by Global Network, in response to Reuters citing sources who said that "Putin has decided to participate in the next Russian presidential election", Russian Presidential Press Secretary and Kremlin Palace Spokesperson Peskov responded that Putin has not yet made any decision. Make any statement whether to run in the 2024 presidential election.
Previously, six sources revealed to the outside world that Putin has decided to participate in the Russian presidential election to be held in March next year, and this move will allow him to be in power until at least 2030. The above-mentioned sources also said that Putin's advisers have begun preparations for the election and are expected to make an announcement soon. Peskov responded: "Putin has not yet made any statement on this. The campaign itself has not yet been officially announced."
According to Russian news, the Russian presidential election is expected to be held on March 17, 2024. The Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament) will officially set the election date in December 2023, after which political parties will hold pre-election meetings and formally nominate candidates.
input:
According to a report by TASS on November 6, quoted by Global Network, in response to Reuters citing sources who said that "Putin has decided to participate in the next Russian presidential election", Russian Presidential Press Secretary and Kremlin Palace Spokesperson Peskov responded that Putin has not yet made any decision. Make any statement whether to run in the 2024 presidential election.
Previously, six sources revealed to the outside world that Putin has decided to participate in the Russian presidential election to be held in March next year, and this move will allow him to be in power until at least 2030. The above-mentioned sources also said that Putin's advisers have begun preparations for the election and are expected to make an announcement soon. Peskov responded: "Putin has not yet made any statement on this. The campaign itself has not yet been officially announced."
According to Russian news, the Russian presidential election is expected to be held on March 17, 2024. The Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament) will officially set the election date in December 2023, after which political parties will hold pre-election meetings and formally nominate candidates.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
content:
此外，斯卢茨基还表示：“我希望在特别军事行动中获胜。但打败普京——不，我并不期望做到这一点。为什么？普京是世界上最有影响力的政治家。”
哈里托诺夫：最年长候选人，曾参与俄总统竞选
尼古拉·哈里托诺夫1948年出生于俄罗斯新西伯利亚州的一处村庄，是俄共党员。从1994年起，哈里托诺夫成为历届国家杜马议员，2021年开始担任俄罗斯国家杜马远东和北极发展委员会主席。
1972年，哈里托诺夫毕业于新西伯利亚农业学院（现新西伯利亚国立农业大学）。1995年，哈里托诺夫在俄罗斯政府下属的国民经济学院获得经济学副博士学位。
在1991年苏联解体前，哈里托诺夫是苏共党员。1976-1994年，哈里托诺夫一直担任“加林斯基”国营农场场长。1993年2月，哈里托诺夫参与创建了俄罗斯农业党。同年，他首次当选俄罗斯国家杜马议员。1999年，在俄罗斯农业党内部出现分裂后，他第一次出现在俄共的杜马议员名单中。
2004年，哈里托诺夫曾代表俄共参加当年的俄罗斯总统大选，并且以13.69%的得票率位居第二，仅次于普京（71.31%）。
2022年俄乌冲突爆发后，哈里托诺夫因支持顿涅茨克、卢甘斯克独立以及俄对乌“特别军事行动”而受到西方国家制裁。
2024年1月18日，哈里托诺夫提交了自己的竞选纲领。他的竞选口号是：“我们已经玩儿过了资本主义，现在够了！”他呼吁俄罗斯经济“向左转”，主张改变社会经济政策、发展工业和农业、提高养老金及工资等，并称俄罗斯的发展关键在远东地区。此外，他还表示，当前的主要问题是“战争与和平”。他说，俄共“带着和平、面包和善意而来”，将帮助国家走出“系统性危机”。
2月，哈里托诺夫与俄共领导人久加诺夫在列宁国营农场与“特别军事行动”的参与者举行会面。
translation:
In addition, Slutsky also said: "I hope to win in special military operations. But defeating Putin - no, I do not expect to do this. Why? Putin is the most influential politician in the world."
Kharitonov: The oldest candidate to have participated in the Russian presidential election
Nikolai Kharitonov was born in a village in Novosibirsk Oblast, Russia, in 1948. He is a member of the Russian Communist Party. Kharitonov has been a member of the State Duma since 1994, and will serve as chairman of the Russian State Duma's Far East and Arctic Development Committee in 2021.
In 1972, Kharitonov graduated from the Novosibirsk Agricultural College (now Novosibirsk State Agricultural University). In 1995, Kharitonov received an associate doctorate in economics from the Institute of National Economics under the Russian government.
Before the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Kharitonov was a member of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. From 1976 to 1994, Kharitonov served as the director of the "Galinsky" state farm. In February 1993, Kharitonov co-founded the Russian Agricultural Party. In the same year, he was elected to the Russian State Duma for the first time. In 1999, after a split within the Russian Agricultural Party, he first appeared on the list of Duma members of the Russian Communist Party.
In 2004, Kharitonov represented the Russian Communist Party in the Russian presidential election that year and ranked second with 13.69% of the vote, second only to Putin (71.31%).
After the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in 2022, Kharitonov was sanctioned by Western countries for supporting the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk and Russia's "special military operations" against Ukraine.
On January 18, 2024, Kharitonov submitted his campaign platform. His campaign slogan is: "We have played with capitalism, now enough!" He called on the Russian economy to "turn to the left" and advocated changing social and economic policies, developing industry and agriculture, increasing pensions and wages, and Said that the key to Russia's development lies in the Far East. In addition, he also said that the main issue at present is "war and peace." He said that the Russian Communist Party "came with peace, bread and goodwill" and would help the country get out of the "systemic crisis."
In February, Kharitonov and the leader of the Russian Communist Party Zyuganov met with participants of the "Special Military Operation" at the Lenin State Farm.

In February 1993, Kharitonov co-founded the Russian Agricultural Party. In the same year, he was elected to the Russian State Duma for the first time. In 1999, after a split within the Russian Agricultural Party, he first appeared on the list of Duma members of the Russian Communist Party.
In 2004, Kharitonov represented the Russian Communist Party in the Russian presidential election that year and ranked second with 13.69% of the vote, second only to Putin (71.31%).
After the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in 2022, Kharitonov was sanctioned by Western countries for supporting the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk and Russia's "special military operations" against Ukraine.
On January 18, 2024, Kharitonov submitted his campaign platform. His campaign slogan is: "We have played with capitalism, now enough!" He called on the Russian economy to "turn to the left" and advocated changing social and economic policies, developing industry and agriculture, increasing pensions and wages, and Said that the key to Russia's development lies in the Far East. In addition, he also said that the main issue at present is "war and peace." He said that the Russian Communist Party "came with peace, bread and goodwill" and would help the country get out of the "systemic crisis."
