title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
content:
俄乌冲突已持续两年多，3月15日-17日俄罗斯迎来6年一度的总统大选。此次大选是俄罗斯2020年通过宪法修正案后的首次总统大选，也是该国首次“战时选举”。
全俄社会舆论研究中心主席瓦列里·费罗多夫此前在谈到大选前的俄罗斯社会情绪时表示，从2018年宣布延迟退休，到新冠疫情，再到俄乌冲突，俄罗斯所面临的风险和威胁正在日益增多，焦虑已经成为俄罗斯社会的基本情绪。但与此同时，适应的过程也在进行之中。大多数人对谁是始作俑者以及为什么会发生战争等问题并不感兴趣。最关键的问题是，这一切何时才能结束，能够通过何种方式尽快结束。
费罗多夫认为，对于每一个俄罗斯人而言，“特别军事行动”都可能有着不同的意义。它可能是一次期待已久的行动，也可能是获得体面收入的契机，还可能是一次冲击和创伤，又或是移民的诱因。但无论如何，除去已经离开俄罗斯的人们，仍然留在国内的俄罗斯人仍然将普京视为保护者。
“每个人都意识到，我们在同一条船上，如果我们现在朝着不同的方向奔跑，情况只会变得更糟。”费罗多夫说道。
当地时间2024年3月13日，顿涅茨克地区马里乌波尔，市民在俄罗斯总统选举提前投票中投票。
translation:
The conflict between Russia and Ukraine has lasted for more than two years. From March 15th to 17th, Russia ushered in the six-year presidential election. This election is Russia’s first presidential election since the adoption of constitutional amendments in 2020, and it is also the country’s first “wartime election.”
Valery Ferodov, chairman of the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center, previously talked about Russian social sentiment before the election and said that from the announcement of delayed retirement in 2018, to the new crown epidemic, to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, the risks Russia faces and threats are increasing day by day, anxiety has become a basic emotion in Russian society. But at the same time, the process of adaptation is also underway. Most people are not interested in who started the war and why it happened. The most critical question is when will all this end and how can it end as soon as possible.
Ferodov believes that "special military operations" may have different meanings for every Russian. It may be a long-awaited move, an opportunity to earn a decent income, a shock and trauma, or an inducement to emigrate. But in any case, apart from those who have left Russia, Russians who remain in the country still regard Putin as their protector.
"Everyone realizes that we are in the same boat and if we run in a different direction now, the situation will only get worse," Ferodov said.
On March 13, 2024 local time, citizens voted in early voting for the Russian presidential election in Mariupol, Donetsk region.
input:
The conflict between Russia and Ukraine has lasted for more than two years. From March 15th to 17th, Russia ushered in the six-year presidential election. This election is Russia’s first presidential election since the adoption of constitutional amendments in 2020, and it is also the country’s first “wartime election.”
Valery Ferodov, chairman of the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center, previously talked about Russian social sentiment before the election and said that from the announcement of delayed retirement in 2018, to the new crown epidemic, to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, the risks Russia faces and threats are increasing day by day, anxiety has become a basic emotion in Russian society. But at the same time, the process of adaptation is also underway. Most people are not interested in who started the war and why it happened. The most critical question is when will all this end and how can it end as soon as possible.
Ferodov believes that "special military operations" may have different meanings for every Russian. It may be a long-awaited move, an opportunity to earn a decent income, a shock and trauma, or an inducement to emigrate. But in any case, apart from those who have left Russia, Russians who remain in the country still regard Putin as their protector.
"Everyone realizes that we are in the same boat and if we run in a different direction now, the situation will only get worse," Ferodov said.
On March 13, 2024 local time, citizens voted in early voting for the Russian presidential election in Mariupol, Donetsk region.

title: Putin basks in election win that was never in doubt even as Russians quietly protest  : NPR
content:
Among those heeding call was Yulia Navalnaya, Navalny's widow, who joined a long line in Berlin as some in the crowd applauded and chanted her name.
She spent more than five hours in the line and told reporters after casting her vote that she wrote her late husband's name on the ballot.
Asked whether she had a message for Putin, Navalnaya replied: "Please stop asking for messages from me or from somebody for Mr. Putin. There could be no negotiations and nothing with Mr. Putin, because he's a killer, he's a gangster."
But Putin brushed off the effectiveness of the apparent protest.
"There were calls to come vote at noon. And this was supposed to be a manifestation of opposition. Well, if there were calls to come vote, then ... I praise this," he said at a news conference after polls closed.
Unusually, Putin referenced Navalny by name for the first time in years at the news conference. And he said he was informed of an idea to release the opposition leader from prison, days before his death. Putin said that he agreed to the idea, on condition that Navalny didn't return to Russia.
Some Russians waiting to vote in Moscow and St. Petersburg told The Associated Press that they were taking part in the protest, but it wasn't possible to confirm whether all of those in line were doing so.
One woman in Moscow, who said her name was Yulia, told the AP that she was voting for the first time.
"Even if my vote doesn't change anything, my conscience will be clear ... for the future that I want to see for our country," she said. Like others, she didn't give her full name because of security concerns.
Another Moscow voter, who also identified himself only by his first name, Vadim, said he hoped for change, but added that "unfortunately, it's unlikely."
Meanwhile, supporters of Navalny streamed to his grave in Moscow, some bringing ballots with his name written on them.
Meduza, Russia's biggest independent news outlet, published photos of ballots it received from their readers, with "killer" inscribed on one, "thief" on another and "The Hague awaits you" on yet another. The last refers to an arrest warrant for Putin from the International Criminal Court that accuses him of personal responsibility for abductions of children from Ukraine.
Some people told the AP that they were happy to vote for Putin — unsurprising in a country where independent media have been hobbled, state TV airs a drumbeat of praise for the Russian leader and voicing any other opinion is risky.

Another Moscow voter, who also identified himself only by his first name, Vadim, said he hoped for change, but added that "unfortunately, it's unlikely."
Meanwhile, supporters of Navalny streamed to his grave in Moscow, some bringing ballots with his name written on them.
Meduza, Russia's biggest independent news outlet, published photos of ballots it received from their readers, with "killer" inscribed on one, "thief" on another and "The Hague awaits you" on yet another. The last refers to an arrest warrant for Putin from the International Criminal Court that accuses him of personal responsibility for abductions of children from Ukraine.
Some people told the AP that they were happy to vote for Putin — unsurprising in a country where independent media have been hobbled, state TV airs a drumbeat of praise for the Russian leader and voicing any other opinion is risky.

title: Votes, protests and arrests in final day of Russian election
content:
The stories you need to start your day: What Putin’s landslide reelection means, March Madness brackets and more in today’s edition of The Yodel newsletter
The number of startups in India's electric two-wheeler market has surged to over 150 from 54 in 2021, driven by government incentives to promote clean vehicles and cut oil imports, according to a new analysis.  The influx has intensified competition in a segment expected to grow 15-20 times to annual sales of 15-20 million units over the next decade, Bernstein said in a report late Tuesday.  "Most are competing in the mainstream, and 85% of the 65 models launched last year were such products: high-speed as against speed and range-constrained products, which used to be a feature of the startups," Bernstein analysts wrote.
You need to see where Zion caught this alley-oop.
Rather than grimly assembling data about cancer deaths to predict outcomes in treatment, the founders of Cure51 had another idea.  Instead, the company assembles data about long term survivors of cancer, thus hoping to crack the code on what keeps people alive.  It’s now raised a €15 million Seed round led by Paris-based Sofinnova Partners.
How will the remaining resistance to Biden and Trump shape the general election? And is a MAGA Senate nominee the GOP's best bet in Ohio?
Howard needed just one 3-pointer to send the game to overtime. They missed three in a row during the wild finish.
Former President Donald Trump says he may be forced to sell off his “Great Assets” at “Fire Sale prices” in order to raise the $464 million bond required as he appeals the judgment in his New York financial fraud trial.
The former five-star recruit and freshman starter appears to be returning to Alabama.
More than 1 million abortions occurred in 2023, a new report found. The rise was driven by medication abortions.
Cowboy is better known for its sleek electric bikes that you can see in many major cities across Europe.  Similarly, Cowboy is betting on a fully integrated design with as little maintenance as possible.  There’s no (physical) gear, braking cables are hidden as much as possible and the company uses carbon fiber belts.
Stand in line for TSA to pick your lock, or grab this affordable and easy-to-use gadget — we know what we plan to do.

title: 普京胜选后欧盟援乌调门依旧坚定，但准备好真金白银了吗？
content:
当地时间2024年3月17日，俄罗斯莫斯科，俄罗斯总统候选人、现任总统普京在竞选总部向媒体发表讲话。视觉中国 图

俄罗斯总统大选结束，结果没有任何意外，普京成功连任。对于欧盟来说，这是大家都早就预料到的结果。各国估计也早就准备好了对应的说辞。3月17日晚间欧盟各国就已经开始就联合公报的措辞进行谈判。3月18日，欧盟各国外长齐聚布鲁塞尔，其中东欧各国的外长对于俄罗斯选举的评价一如以往的尖锐。立陶宛外长是当天第一个接受记者采访的外长，当记者提及他对普京成功获得连任有什么看法时，他的第一反应是：“您的措辞真是宽容大度。”随后他表示，欧盟各国自然会刊发针对俄罗斯大选的联合声明，不过眼下的当务之急是继续探讨怎样支持乌克兰。
普京愈发牢固的权力是欧盟各国对此次大选的一个共识——俄罗斯短期内是不可能改变方向的。在这样的情况，以及俄乌冲突的长期化的背景下，前一段时间法国总统马克龙提出不排除派出法国士兵前往乌克兰就不足为奇了。如果欧盟继续支持乌克兰的决心不动摇，而普京又将继续掌舵俄罗斯，那么，为了继续支持乌克兰，欧盟各国的手段自然要加码。
但是，坚持继续援助乌克兰背后，欧盟面对的困境也是明显的：乌克兰在人口、实力等等方面都明显弱于俄罗斯。新的国际形势也决定了，即便不依靠西方，俄罗斯也可以保持经济增长。西方国家青睐的“民主明星”印度，更是明目张胆地帮助俄罗斯绕开西方的制裁。
同时，在国际上，欧盟肯定不能引起世界大战；在欧盟内部，欧盟民众自然是不准备为了乌克兰献出自己的生命的。同时，特朗普在今年年底美国总统大选中胜选的可能性也让布鲁塞尔的外交官们紧张。
普京的当选，欧盟早有预期，但对欧盟来说，“硬仗”从现在才开始。
当地时间2024年3月18日，比利时布鲁塞尔，欧盟成员国外长会议举行。欧盟外交与安全事务高级代表博雷利出席。东方IC 图

对乌克兰的持续资助以及支持，是18日的欧盟外长会议的重点。欧盟外交与安全事务高级代表博雷利认为，在18日的会议上欧盟各国可以达成新一轮的对俄制裁的主要条款，以及针对俄罗斯反对派领袖阿列克谢·纳瓦利内之死通过对俄罗斯的追加制裁。
translation:
On March 17, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, Russian presidential candidate and current President Putin addressed the media at the campaign headquarters. Visual China Map

The Russian presidential election ended without any surprises. Putin was successfully re-elected. For the EU, this is a result that everyone has expected. Countries have probably already prepared corresponding rhetoric. On the evening of March 17, EU countries had begun negotiations on the wording of the joint communiqué. On March 18, the foreign ministers of the European Union gathered in Brussels. Among them, the foreign ministers of the Eastern European countries were as sharp as ever in their evaluation of the Russian election. The Lithuanian Foreign Minister was the first foreign minister to be interviewed by reporters that day. When the reporter mentioned his views on Putin's successful re-election, his first reaction was: "Your wording is really tolerant and generous." He then said that the EU Countries will naturally issue a joint statement on the Russian election, but the top priority right now is to continue to discuss how to support Ukraine.
Putin's increasingly solid power is a consensus among EU countries regarding this election - Russia is unlikely to change direction in the short term. Under such circumstances, and against the background of the protracted conflict between Russia and Ukraine, it is not surprising that French President Macron said some time ago that he would not rule out sending French soldiers to Ukraine. If the EU's determination to continue to support Ukraine remains unchanged and Putin will continue to be at the helm of Russia, then, in order to continue to support Ukraine, EU countries will naturally increase their measures.
However, behind its insistence on continuing to assist Ukraine, the dilemma faced by the EU is also obvious: Ukraine is significantly weaker than Russia in terms of population, strength, etc. The new international situation also determines that Russia can maintain economic growth even without relying on the West. India, the "democratic star" favored by Western countries, has blatantly helped Russia circumvent Western sanctions.
At the same time, internationally, the EU certainly cannot cause a world war; within the EU, EU people are naturally not prepared to sacrifice their lives for Ukraine. At the same time, the possibility of Trump winning the US presidential election at the end of this year has also made diplomats in Brussels nervous.
The EU has long expected Putin's election, but for the EU, the "hard battle" only begins now.
On March 18, 2024 local time, the Foreign Ministers’ Meeting of EU member states was held in Brussels, Belgium. EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Affairs Josep Borrell attended the meeting. Oriental IC map

Continued funding and support for Ukraine is the focus of the EU Foreign Ministers' Meeting on the 18th. EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Borrell believes that at the meeting on the 18th, EU countries can reach the main terms of a new round of sanctions against Russia, as well as the death of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. Pass additional sanctions against Russia.

title: Inside the Kremlin's party as Putin celebrates election win
content:
MOSCOW — For a few hours, it appeared that Russian President Vladimir Putin would break the habit of 24 years in power and arrive early for his triumphant post-election news conference.
The Kremlin had brought forward the arrival time for journalists at its election night celebration in central Moscow — that it would be a celebration was, of course, never in doubt, given the absence of any true opposition in the stage-managed vote and Putin’s sustained popularity. 
But the Russian leader ultimately stayed true to his reputation and didn’t arrive at the event until almost midnight Sunday. 
The first indication of Putin’s presence was presidential protection officers running to assume their positions in a cavernous hall next door to the Kremlin. 
The security around the Russian leader was so intense that everyone attending, including NBC News, had to be tested for Covid and flu hours earlier. Journalists accredited by the Kremlin were ushered into a room and held back by a temporary barrier. It was removed just before Putin walked in. There were strict instructions not to rush forward, with security hawkishly overlooking the camera crews and reporters.
input:
MOSCOW — For a few hours, it appeared that Russian President Vladimir Putin would break the habit of 24 years in power and arrive early for his triumphant post-election news conference.
The Kremlin had brought forward the arrival time for journalists at its election night celebration in central Moscow — that it would be a celebration was, of course, never in doubt, given the absence of any true opposition in the stage-managed vote and Putin’s sustained popularity. 
But the Russian leader ultimately stayed true to his reputation and didn’t arrive at the event until almost midnight Sunday. 
The first indication of Putin’s presence was presidential protection officers running to assume their positions in a cavernous hall next door to the Kremlin. 
The security around the Russian leader was so intense that everyone attending, including NBC News, had to be tested for Covid and flu hours earlier. Journalists accredited by the Kremlin were ushered into a room and held back by a temporary barrier. It was removed just before Putin walked in. There were strict instructions not to rush forward, with security hawkishly overlooking the camera crews and reporters.

title: Yes, the Russian election is rigged – but there could still be surprises in store for Putin | The Independent
content:
Russian voters’ choice of candidates is also as circumscribed as it mostly was. On the ballot paper, along with Putin – who is standing, by the way, as an independent – are just three whose support registers at more than 1 per cent. There is Leonid Slutsky – heir to the late firebrand, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, of the far-right Liberal Democratic Party (LDPR); Nikolai Kharitonov of the Communist Party, and Vladislav Davankov of the New People party, and deputy chairman of the State Duma (the Russian parliament).
This has been a standard lineup in Russian presidential elections for years. The nationalist right, the old Communists on the left, and a novelty candidate whose platform plays to contemporary concerns as a sort of safety valve. In Davankov’s case, this means being critical – but not too critical – of the Ukraine war, including support for negotiations.
In terms of the election’s democratic credentials, of course, it is at least as significant who is not on the ballot paper, as who is. Boris Nadezhdin had been hoping to stand as the anti-war candidate, and had enjoyed some campaigning success. Perhaps too much, because he was barred in time-honoured fashion, after too many of his endorsing signatures were ruled invalid.
The prominent opposition figure, and anti-corruption campaigner, Alexei Navalny, had also been excluded by dint of a string of prison sentences. Indeed, he had been kept out of all elections since a better-than-forecast 27 per cent in the Moscow mayoral election of 2013. His sudden death in the Polar Wolf prison camp last month, however, may not mark the end of the Navalny effect on Russian politics.
As for those who will be on the ballot paper, the latest Russian polls forecast as follows: Putin – 75 per cent; Slutsky – 3 per cent; Kharitonov – 4 per cent, and Davankov – 6 per cent. What is more, the awkward truth is that those figures do not have to have been manipulated. Unpopular though the war may be in some quarters, Putin’s support has held up (along with living standards and national morale), and all despite the strange mutiny by Yevgeny Prigozhin and the Wagner mercenaries last June.

title: ﻿普京成功连任 得票率逾87% _大公网
content:
图：俄总统普京以压倒性优势再次赢得连任。俄罗斯中央选举委员会18日公布的初步计票结果显示，现任总统普京以超过87%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人，赢得此次总统选举。普京表示，选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望。分析人士认为，普京连任后，俄内政外交将延续既有政策，包括着力加强技术自主，促进经济多元，积极发展与亚洲、非洲、中东和拉美等地区友好国家的关系，推动世界多极化发展。
　　俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。根据俄总统选举规则，在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会18日公布了对100%选票的统计结果，普京得票率为87.28%，以巨大优势赢得第五个总统任期；俄共产党候选人哈里托诺夫以约4%的得票率排名第二；新人党候选人达万科夫和自民党候选人斯卢茨基分别排在第三及第四位。
　　俄媒称，普京的得票率创下俄罗斯当代史最高纪录；本次选举投票率超过73%，亦创新高。中国、印度、古巴、朝鲜、玻利维亚等国向普京表示祝贺，天主教教宗方济各亦祝贺普京再次当选俄罗斯总统。美国、英国、乌克兰等国则指控俄大选“不公正”。俄总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫表示，俄民众对普京的高支持率表明西方国家关于俄大选不公的言论毫无依据。
translation:
Picture: Russian President Vladimir Putin won re-election again with an overwhelming advantage. Preliminary vote counting results announced by Russia's Central Election Commission on the 18th showed that current President Putin won the presidential election with more than 87% of the vote, significantly ahead of other candidates. Putin said that the election results reflected the trust and expectations of voters. Analysts believe that after Putin's re-election, Russia's domestic and foreign affairs will continue its existing policies, including focusing on strengthening technological independence, promoting economic diversification, actively developing relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, and promoting the development of a multi-polar world. .
The official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission announced the results of 100% of the votes on the 18th. Putin received 87.28% of the votes, winning the fifth presidential term with a huge advantage; the Russian Communist Party candidate Kharitonov ranked third with about 4% of the votes. 2; New People’s Party candidate Davankov and Liberal Democratic Party candidate Slutsky ranked third and fourth respectively.
Russian media said that Putin’s vote share set a record in contemporary Russian history; the turnout rate in this election exceeded 73%, also a new high. China, India, Cuba, North Korea, Bolivia and other countries congratulated Putin. Catholic Pope Francis also congratulated Putin on his re-election as president of Russia. The United States, Britain, Ukraine and other countries accused the Russian election of being "unfair". Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that the Russian people's high support rate for Putin shows that Western countries' remarks about the unfairness of the Russian election are groundless.
​

Russian media said that Putin’s vote share set a record in contemporary Russian history; the turnout rate in this election exceeded 73%, also a new high. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that the Russian people's high support rate for Putin shows that Western countries' remarks about the unfairness of the Russian election are groundless.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
content:
此外，普京还表示俄战略核力量处于全面准备状态，任何武装干涉俄罗斯者将遭遇前所未有的惨败，将遭遇使用核武器的冲突。俄总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫表示，普京的此次讲话在很大程度上可被视为其竞选纲领。
大选前夕，普京团队还发布了一系列竞选视频。在其中一则视频中，出现了极具俄罗斯特色的熊与针叶林的图像。普京本人并未在视频中出现，而是以画外音的方式为视频配音。普京表示，总有人想要给生活在针叶林中的熊拴上锁链、拔掉熊的牙齿和爪子，但熊“绝不会把自己的针叶林交给任何人”。
达万科夫：最年轻候选人，强调通过谈判解决俄乌冲突
弗拉季斯拉夫·达万科夫1984年出生于斯摩棱斯克，是俄罗斯新人党党员，国家杜马副主席，曾活跃于商界。今年2月8日俄罗斯舆论研究中心以电话访谈方式进行了一次民调，共调查了1600名18岁以上俄罗斯公民。在打算参加投票的受访者中，75%的人表示将在大选中支持普京，5%的受访者表示将支持新人党候选人达万科夫。
达万科夫的祖父瓦季姆·达万科夫是一位化学家，父亲安德烈·达万科夫是一名军事飞行员，叔叔亚历山大·达万科夫则是俄罗斯著名化妆品公司Faberlic的创始人之一。在从当地中学毕业后，达万科夫进入莫斯科国立罗蒙诺索夫大学历史系学习，专业为美国历史，并于2006年毕业。2008年，达万科夫获得了俄罗斯国立社会大学社会学副博士学位。毕业后，达万科夫选择从商。2013年起，他在叔叔创立的Faberlic公司担任副总裁。另据俄媒报道，达万科夫还曾涉足金融、制造、IT等多个领域。
达万科夫的政治生涯始于2020年。当时，他的叔叔亚历山大·达万科夫与Faberlic公司的另一位创始人阿列克谢·涅恰耶夫共同创建了新人党（новые люди）。达万科夫本人也参与了该党的组建工作，主要负责该党地区支部的工作以及管理竞选活动。
translation:
In addition, Putin also stated that Russia's strategic nuclear forces are in a state of full readiness, and any armed intervention in Russia will suffer an unprecedented defeat and encounter a conflict involving the use of nuclear weapons. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that Putin’s speech can be regarded as his campaign platform to a large extent.
On the eve of the election, Putin's team also released a series of campaign videos. In one of the videos, a very Russian image of a bear and a taiga appears. Putin himself does not appear in the video, but provides a voiceover for the video. Putin said that there are always people who want to chain the bears living in the taiga and remove their teeth and claws, but the bears "will never give their taiga to anyone."
Davankov: The youngest candidate, emphasizing the resolution of the Russia-Ukraine conflict through negotiation
Vladislav Davankov was born in Smolensk in 1984. He is a member of the Russian New People's Party and Vice Chairman of the State Duma. He was once active in the business community. On February 8 this year, the Russian Public Opinion Research Center conducted a poll by telephone interview, surveying a total of 1,600 Russian citizens over the age of 18. Among those who plan to vote, 75% said they would support Putin in the general election, and 5% said they would support New People's Party candidate Davankov.
Davankov's grandfather Vadim Davankov is a chemist, his father Andrei Davankov is a military pilot, and his uncle Alexander Davankov is the owner of the famous Russian cosmetics company Faberlic. One of the founders. After graduating from local high school, Davankov entered the History Department of Lomonosov Moscow State University, majoring in American history, and graduated in 2006. In 2008, Davankov received an associate doctorate in sociology from the Russian State Social University. After graduation, Davankov chose to go into business. Since 2013, he has served as vice president of Faberlic, a company founded by his uncle. According to Russian media reports, Davankov has also been involved in many fields such as finance, manufacturing, and IT.
Davankov's political career began in 2020. At that time, his uncle Alexander Davankov co-founded the New People's Party (новые люди) with Alexei Nechaev, another founder of Faberlic company. Davankov himself also participated in the formation of the party and was mainly responsible for the work of the party's regional branches and managing campaign activities.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
content:
这是一场并没有太大悬念的选举，现年71岁的现任俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京在3月15日开始的投票中几乎肯定会赢得连任。
不过，根据2020年的宪法修正案“任期清零”条款（于2021年4月5日签署），既有总统当选次数“清零”并重新计算。在这种情况下，3月15日至17日的选举在“法律意义”上算是一次“全新的”选举。
即便没有意外，不会有人否认这是一场不同寻常的选举，在俄乌军事冲突前景仍未现停火曙光的情况下，从小心翼翼动员征召军人到全国视察地点的选择和设计，从选战议题设置的侧重、避险到对未来愿景的描绘、宣介……无不透露俄罗斯国内政治生活的微妙变化和该国政治精英对国际环境的异常敏感。
外界一直密切关注普京过去数月里的竞选和造势动向，力图从中窥见俄罗斯最高领导人下一任执政目标的蛛丝马迹，洞察俄罗斯统治体系当下的稳固状态。
当地时间2023年12月8日，俄罗斯总统普京在克里姆林宫举行的“祖国英雄日”颁奖仪式上发表讲话。 本文图均为  视觉中国 资料图

竞选活动主打民生牌，国内政治稳定获保证
去年12月，在装饰华丽的克里姆林宫大厅一场精心设计的“祖国英雄日”颁奖仪式上，与身着完美制服、饰有奖章的“顿涅茨克人民共和国”人民委员会主席阿尔乔姆·佐加交谈时，普京宣布了自己的参选。
“我不会隐瞒这一点，我在不同时期有着不同的想法，” 表情冷峻的普京总统说道，“但现在，到了必须做出决定的时刻。我将竞选俄罗斯总统。”
translation:
This is an election without much suspense. The 71-year-old current Russian President Vladimir Putin is almost certain to win re-election in the voting that starts on March 15.
However, according to the "term clearing" clause of the 2020 Constitutional Amendment (signed on April 5, 2021), the number of times the existing president has been elected is "cleared" and recalculated. In this case, the election from March 15 to 17 was considered a "new" election in a "legal sense".
Even if there are no surprises, no one will deny that this is an unusual election. With the prospect of a ceasefire in the Russian-Ukrainian military conflict still unclear, everything from careful mobilization of soldiers to the selection and design of nationwide inspection sites, from election issues The focus of the setting, the avoidance of risks, the description of the future vision, and the publicity... all reveal the subtle changes in Russia's domestic political life and the country's political elite's unusual sensitivity to the international environment.
The outside world has been paying close attention to Putin's campaign and campaign trends in the past few months, trying to get a glimpse of the Russian top leader's next governing goals and gain insight into the current stable state of Russia's ruling system.
On December 8, 2023 local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a speech at the "Heroes of the Motherland Day" award ceremony held in the Kremlin. The pictures in this article are all Visual China data maps

The election campaign focuses on people's livelihood, and domestic political stability is guaranteed
Last December, at an elaborate "Heroes of the Motherland Day" award ceremony in the ornately decorated hall of the Kremlin, I met with Artyom, Chairman of the People's Committee of the "Donetsk People's Republic" who was dressed in perfect uniforms and decorated with medals. While talking with Dzoga, Putin announced his candidacy.
"I won't hide it. I had different ideas at different times," President Putin said with a grim expression. "But now, the moment has come when a decision must be made. I will run for president of Russia."
input:
This is an election without much suspense. The 71-year-old current Russian President Vladimir Putin is almost certain to win re-election in the voting that starts on March 15.
However, according to the "term clearing" clause of the 2020 Constitutional Amendment (signed on April 5, 2021), the number of times the existing president has been elected is "cleared" and recalculated. In this case, the election from March 15 to 17 was considered a "new" election in a "legal sense".
Even if there are no surprises, no one will deny that this is an unusual election. With the prospect of a ceasefire in the Russian-Ukrainian military conflict still unclear, everything from careful mobilization of soldiers to the selection and design of nationwide inspection sites, from election issues The focus of the setting, the avoidance of risks, the description of the future vision, and the publicity... all reveal the subtle changes in Russia's domestic political life and the country's political elite's unusual sensitivity to the international environment.
The outside world has been paying close attention to Putin's campaign and campaign trends in the past few months, trying to get a glimpse of the Russian top leader's next governing goals and gain insight into the current stable state of Russia's ruling system.
On December 8, 2023 local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a speech at the "Heroes of the Motherland Day" award ceremony held in the Kremlin. The pictures in this article are all Visual China data maps

The election campaign focuses on people's livelihood, and domestic political stability is guaranteed
Last December, at an elaborate "Heroes of the Motherland Day" award ceremony in the ornately decorated hall of the Kremlin, I met with Artyom, Chairman of the People's Committee of the "Donetsk People's Republic" who was dressed in perfect uniforms and decorated with medals. While talking with Dzoga, Putin announced his candidacy.
"I won't hide it. I had different ideas at different times," President Putin said with a grim expression. "But now, the moment has come when a decision must be made. I will run for president of Russia."

title: 西方指责俄总统选举不公正 中朝贺普京当选 | 俄罗斯 | 中国 | 乌克兰 | 大纪元
content:
自两年多前克里姆林宫发动战争以来，习近平对发展他与普京的关系殚精竭虑，在加强贸易、安全和外交关系的同时，拒绝放弃在入侵前几周与俄罗斯宣布的“无上限”伙伴关系。
中方为此付出了代价。中共声称保持中立，拒绝谴责入侵行动，这引起了欧洲对其动机的怀疑。北约组织上周四发布的年度报告反映了该组织对中共的强硬立场，北约秘书长延斯‧斯托尔滕贝格（Jens Stoltenberg）称北京“不认同我们的价值观”，“挑战我们的利益”，同时指出北京日益与莫斯科保持一致。
伦敦大学亚非学院（SOAS）中国研究所所长曾锐生（Steve Tsang）在俄罗斯大选结果公布前表示，“习近平将普京视为真正的战略伙伴。”
印度总理纳伦德拉‧莫迪（Narendra Modi）也对俄罗斯的选举结果表示认同，称他期待着加强新德里与莫斯科“久经考验的特殊、优越的战略伙伴关系”。印度与中、俄同属金砖国家（BRICS）新兴经济体集团。
目前，印度一方面加强与美国的关系，呼吁乌克兰和平，一方面从与俄罗斯购买打折的石油。
据朝鲜国家媒体报导，朝鲜领导人金正恩周一迅速祝贺普京获胜。金正恩被西方指责向俄罗斯供应武器，他强调希望进一步扩大与莫斯科的双边关系。去年9月，他在俄罗斯远东地区会见了普京。这是普京罕见的海外之行，华盛顿称此行的重点是莫斯科向平壤购买军火，而金正恩迫切需要顶住美国和韩国的协调压制，继续发展核武器，与普京的紧密联系是支撑其摇摇欲坠的经济的一个重要机会。
受制裁打击的伊朗政府一直在扩大与俄罗斯的合作，并向其提供无人机和弹药。伊朗总统易卜拉欣‧莱西（Ebrahim Raisi）也向普京表示祝贺。
translation:
Xi Jinping has worked hard to develop his relationship with Putin since the Kremlin launched the war more than two years ago, strengthening trade, security and diplomatic ties while refusing to abandon the "uncapped" partnership with Russia announced weeks before the invasion.
China has paid the price for this. China claims to remain neutral and refuses to condemn the invasion, raising suspicion in Europe about its motives. NATO's annual report released last Thursday reflected the organization's tough stance on China, with NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg saying Beijing "does not share our values" and "challenges our interests." ” while noting that Beijing is increasingly aligned with Moscow.
Steve Tsang, director of the China Institute at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), University of London, said before the results of the Russian election were announced, "Xi Jinping regards Putin as a true strategic partner."
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi also acknowledged Russia's election results, saying he looked forward to strengthening New Delhi's "special, time-tested and superior strategic partnership" with Moscow. India, China and Russia belong to the BRICS emerging economy group.
At present, India is strengthening its relations with the United States and calling for peace in Ukraine, while on the other hand it is purchasing discounted oil from Russia.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un was quick to congratulate Putin on his victory on Monday, according to North Korean state media. Kim Jong-un, accused by the West of supplying arms to Russia, has stressed his desire to further expand bilateral ties with Moscow. In September last year, he met with Putin in the Russian Far East. This is Putin's rare overseas trip. Washington said the focus of this trip is Moscow's purchase of arms from Pyongyang. Kim Jong-un urgently needs to withstand coordinated suppression by the United States and South Korea and continue to develop nuclear weapons. Close ties with Putin are to support his shaky economy. an important opportunity.
The sanctions-hit Iranian government has been expanding cooperation with Russia and supplying it with drones and munitions. Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi also congratulated Putin.
input:
Xi Jinping has worked hard to develop his relationship with Putin since the Kremlin launched the war more than two years ago, strengthening trade, security and diplomatic ties while refusing to abandon the "uncapped" partnership with Russia announced weeks before the invasion.
China has paid the price for this. China claims to remain neutral and refuses to condemn the invasion, raising suspicion in Europe about its motives. NATO's annual report released last Thursday reflected the organization's tough stance on China, with NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg saying Beijing "does not share our values" and "challenges our interests." ” while noting that Beijing is increasingly aligned with Moscow.
Steve Tsang, director of the China Institute at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), University of London, said before the results of the Russian election were announced, "Xi Jinping regards Putin as a true strategic partner."
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi also acknowledged Russia's election results, saying he looked forward to strengthening New Delhi's "special, time-tested and superior strategic partnership" with Moscow. India, China and Russia belong to the BRICS emerging economy group.

title: ﻿俄大选投票三天 普京支持率86% _大公网
content:
俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票3月15日至17日举行。俄罗斯现任总统普京和其他三名候选人将竞选下一届总统。俄乌冲突持续超过两年，在西方制裁的重重围堵之下，俄罗斯经济展现韧性，去年GDP增长3.6%，高于全球平均水平。分析指，俄罗斯众多选民满意经济表现，也有人认为只有普京才能维护社会稳定。俄知名民调机构列瓦达中心统计显示，普京目前支持率为86%，远高于俄乌冲突之前的71%，普京有望获得超过80%的选票。

　　【大公报讯】本次大选是自2020年通过宪法修正案后的首次总统大选，也是俄罗斯首次战时选举。约有1.1亿俄公民具有选举权，2022年9月并入俄罗斯的乌东四地民众也可参加投票。这是俄首次举行投票时间为期三天的总统选举，投票时间为3月15日至17日每日8时开始，20时结束。
　　本届选举首次引入远程电子投票方式。在一些偏远和交通不便地区，选民已于2月25日开始提前投票；居住在国外的选民从3月1日开始提前投票。截至3月14日，已有约200万选民完成投票。 
　　普京被视为俄“危机管理者”
　　共有四名候选人参加此次总统选举，包括俄现任总统普京、俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基、俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫和俄新人党的达万科夫。俄罗斯2020年公投修宪后将总统任期届数归零，允许普京从2024年起再多连任两届至2036年。
　　全俄社会舆论研究中心3月11日的民调结果显示，本届总统选举的投票率将超过70%，其中82%的受访者准备投票给普京，其他三名候选人的支持率在6%左右。媒体预计，普京有望以超过80%的得票率轻松获胜，超越2018年76.7%的得票率。
　　72岁的杜什科15日把票投给了普京，称自己“选择了一位可以信任的人出任国家领导人”。
translation:
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin and three other candidates will run for the next president. The conflict between Russia and Ukraine has lasted for more than two years. Under heavy restrictions from Western sanctions, the Russian economy has shown resilience. Last year, its GDP grew by 3.6%, higher than the global average. Analysts point out that many voters in Russia are satisfied with the economic performance, while some believe that only Putin can maintain social stability. According to statistics from the Levada Center, a well-known Russian polling agency, Putin's current support rate is 86%, which is much higher than the 71% before the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Putin is expected to obtain more than 80% of the votes.

[Ta Kung Pao News] This election is the first presidential election since the adoption of the constitutional amendment in 2020, and it is also Russia’s first wartime election. About 110 million Russian citizens have the right to vote, and people in the four regions of eastern Ukraine that will be merged into Russia in September 2022 can also participate in voting. This is the first presidential election held in Russia with a three-day voting period. Voting will start at 8:00 and end at 20:00 every day from March 15 to 17.
This election introduced remote electronic voting for the first time. In some remote and inaccessible areas, voters began voting in advance on February 25; voters living abroad began voting in advance on March 1. As of March 14, approximately 2 million voters had completed voting. 
Putin is regarded as Russia’s “crisis manager”
A total of four candidates participated in this presidential election, including current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russian Liberal Democratic Party's Slutsky, Russian Federation Communist Party's Kharitonov and Russian New People's Party's Davankov. After Russia's 2020 referendum to amend the constitution, the number of presidential terms will be reset to zero, allowing Putin to serve two more terms from 2024 to 2036.
A poll conducted by the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center on March 11 showed that the turnout rate for this presidential election will exceed 70%, of which 82% of the respondents are ready to vote for Putin, and the support rate for the other three candidates is 6. %about. The media predicts that Putin is expected to easily win with more than 80% of the vote, surpassing the 76.7% vote rate in 2018.
The 72-year-old Dushko voted for Putin on the 15th, saying that he "chose a trustworthy person to be the leader of the country."

title: 俄罗斯大选普京连任 西方各国指责“不公、不合法” | 俄罗斯总统 | 执政时间最长 | 斯大林 | 新唐人电视台
content:
【新唐人北京时间2024年03月19日讯】俄罗斯总统大选落幕，普京以压倒性优势“高票”连任，西方各国批评选举不公正，不合法。
俄罗斯大选周日（3月17日）结束，总统普京以87.28%的得票率赢得这场“没有真正的反对派候选人的选举”，再次连任。
周一（18日），美国和欧盟等西方各国纷纷批评俄罗斯选举。
美国白宫国家安全委员会发言人表示，“由于普京囚禁反对派，并阻止其他人竞选总统，这次选举既不自由也不公平。”
北约秘书长斯托尔滕贝格（Jens Stoltenberg）：“俄罗斯在格鲁吉亚和乌克兰被占领地区，组织选举是完全非法的。”
欧盟委员会副主席约瑟夫·博雷利（Josep Borrell）：“更重要的是，这次选举是在镇压和恐吓的基础上进行的，是在乌克兰被占领土上举行的，侵犯了乌克兰的主权。”
德国外交部在社媒平台X上发表声明说：“普京的统治是专制的，他依靠的是审查、镇压和暴力。”
英国外交部部长卡梅伦（David CAMERON）在X平台上文说：“在乌克兰领土上非法举行选举，选民缺乏选择。”
在西方国家齐声谴责这场选举的同时，中共、古巴、朝鲜和委内瑞拉等则向普京获得连任表达祝贺。
而分析人士担忧，普京以压倒性优势获得连任后，会在俄罗斯实施更大规模的镇压行动。
“查塔姆研究所”俄罗斯与欧亚计划高级研究员娜塔莉·萨巴纳茨：“事实上，就在俄罗斯在乌克兰发动战争的同时，普京正在俄罗斯境内发动一场特别行动。在这87%（普京得票率）之后，我预计俄罗斯国内会有更大的镇压。”
普京如果成功连任，任期将到2030年，同时，他将超越斯大林，成为200多年来执政时间最长的俄罗斯领导人。
新唐人电视台记者赵凤华、明玉综合报导
translation:
[New Tang Dynasty News, Beijing time, March 19, 2024] The Russian presidential election ended. Putin was re-elected with an overwhelming majority of votes. Western countries criticized the election as unfair and illegal.
The Russian election ended on Sunday (March 17). President Putin won this "election without a real opposition candidate" with 87.28% of the vote and was re-elected.
On Monday (18th), Western countries such as the United States and the European Union criticized the Russian election.
A spokesman for the White House National Security Council said, "With Putin imprisoning the opposition and preventing others from running for president, this election was neither free nor fair."
NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg: "It is completely illegal for Russia to organize elections in the occupied areas of Georgia and Ukraine."
European Commission Vice-President Josep Borrell: “More importantly, this election was based on repression and intimidation, was held in occupied Ukrainian territory and violated Ukraine’s sovereignty. "
The German Foreign Ministry issued a statement on the social media platform X: "Putin's rule is authoritarian. He relies on censorship, repression and violence."
British Foreign Minister David CAMERON said on the X platform: "The election was illegally held on Ukrainian soil and voters lacked choice."
While Western countries unanimously condemned the election, the Communist Party of China, Cuba, North Korea and Venezuela expressed congratulations to Putin on his re-election.
Analysts worry that after Putin is re-elected with an overwhelming majority, he will implement larger-scale repression in Russia.
Natalie Sabanatz, senior fellow at Chatham House's Russia and Eurasia Program: "In fact, at the same time that Russia was launching a war in Ukraine, Putin was launching a special operation inside Russia. In these 87 % (Putin’s vote share), I expect there will be greater repression in Russia.”
If Putin is successfully re-elected, his term will be until 2030. At the same time, he will surpass Stalin and become the Russian leader with the longest reign in more than 200 years.
Comprehensive reporting by NTDTV reporters Zhao Fenghua and Mingyu

title: «Россия – это Путин»: политические последствия 87% президента
content:
Но все тщетно, все бесполезно. Экономика России не просто не рушится, а растет. Страна мужественно и спокойно переносит все тяготы немирного времени, все его беды и лишения. А что же до перспективы внутриполитического раскола, то вот вам – 87% за действующего президента. Выкусите – и клевещите сколько вам угодно, что эти 87% якобы «не настоящие». Настоящие они. И близкие к 75% данные по явке тоже настоящие. Не зря же в очереди на голосование в российское посольство в Берлине можно было заметить таких совсем не симпатизирующих Путину персонажей как Юлия Навальная и Михаил Ходорковский.( признаны иностранными агентами в РФ,)

Даже совсем радикальная и совсем несистемная оппозиция признает – пусть не своими словами, но своими делами -легитимность выборов. Короче, выборы состоялись и продемонстрировали небывалую консолидацию общества, его небывалое сплочение вокруг действующего президента и проводимого им политического курса. И это не просто слова. Это слова, которые будут иметь большие политические последствия. Владимир Путин получил гигантский мандат доверия – мандат, который дает ему право на абсолютно любые политические действия, любые политические инициативы и любые политические маневры – как внутри страны, так и за ее пределами. Разумеется, такое право и такой мандат были у ВВП и до выборов 2024 года. Но теперь этот мандат обновлен, укреплен и формализован. Эра Путина в российской политике официально продлена, как минимум, до 2030 года.
translation:
But everything is in vain, everything is useless. The Russian economy is not only not collapsing, but growing. The country courageously and calmly endures all the hardships of non-peaceful times, all its troubles and deprivations. As for the prospect of an internal political split, here you go - 87% for the current president. Take a bite and slander as much as you like that these 87% are supposedly “not real.” They are real. And the turnout figures close to 75% are also real. It’s not for nothing that in the voting queue at the Russian embassy in Berlin one could notice such characters as Yulia Navalnaya and Mikhail Khodorkovsky, who are not at all sympathetic to Putin. (recognized as foreign agents in the Russian Federation,)

Even a completely radical and completely non-systemic opposition recognizes - if not in its words, but in its deeds - the legitimacy of the elections. In short, the elections took place and demonstrated the unprecedented consolidation of society, its unprecedented unity around the current president and the political course he is pursuing. And it is not just words. These are words that will have great political consequences. Vladimir Putin received a gigantic mandate of trust - a mandate that gives him the right to absolutely any political actions, any political initiatives and any political maneuvers - both within the country and abroad. Of course, the GDP had such a right and such a mandate even before the 2024 elections. But now this mandate has been renewed, strengthened and formalized. The Putin era in Russian politics has been officially extended until at least 2030.
input:

The country courageously and calmly endures all the hardships of non-peaceful times, all its troubles and deprivations. As for the prospect of an internal political split, here you go - 87% for the current president. Take a bite and slander as much as you like that these 87% are supposedly “not real.” They are real. And the turnout figures close to 75% are also real. It’s not for nothing that in the voting queue at the Russian embassy in Berlin one could notice such characters as Yulia Navalnaya and Mikhail Khodorkovsky, who are not at all sympathetic to Putin. (recognized as foreign agents in the Russian Federation,)

Even a completely radical and completely non-systemic opposition recognizes - if not in its words, but in its deeds - the legitimacy of the elections. In short, the elections took place and demonstrated the unprecedented consolidation of society, its unprecedented unity around the current president and the political course he is pursuing. And it is not just words. These are words that will have great political consequences. Vladimir Putin received a gigantic mandate of trust - a mandate that gives him the right to absolutely any political actions, any political initiatives and any political maneuvers - both within the country and abroad. Of course, the GDP had such a right and such a mandate even before the 2024 elections. But now this mandate has been renewed, strengthened and formalized. The Putin era in Russian politics has been officially extended until at least 2030.

title: «Россия – это Путин»: политические последствия 87% президента
content:
Какой она будет – новая путинская шестилетка? Мы не знаем и не можем даже предположить. Кто, например, по итогам прошлых российских президентских выборов 2018 года мог предугадать те бурные события, которые произошли в феврале 2022 года и те не менее бурные события, которые происходит сейчас? Никто. Президент Франции Макрон чуть ли не в ежедневном режиме обещает сейчас отправить войска на борьбу с Россией. Шесть лет тому подобный прогноз мог бы запросто отправить своего автора в сумасшедший дом. Давайте поэтому прямо признаем неадекватность, ограниченность и несостоятельность нашей фантазии и нашей способности предсказывать и предугадывать. Все вокруг предполагают, а Путин (бога мы, естественно, не трогаем и выводим за скобки политических уравнений) располагает.

Ограничусь поэтому предсказанием, в котором можно не сомневаться на 100 (ну ладно, на 87) процентов. Победа над Харитоновым, Даванковым и Слуцким – это самое легкое из тех испытаний, которые Владимиру Путину довелось и еще доведется пережить в 2024 году. Над такими персонажами как Байден, Зеленский, Макрон, Сунак, Шольц, Боррель и далее по списку можно, конечно, при желании насмехаться. Но эти деятели точно не готовы проиграть с таким разгромным счетом. 17 марта 2024 года Россия Путина выполнила пусть важную, но самую простую политическую задачу из тех, что ей предстоят.
translation:
What will it be like – Putin’s new six-year plan? We don't know and can't even guess. Who, for example, based on the results of the last Russian presidential elections in 2018, could have predicted the turbulent events that occurred in February 2022 and the equally turbulent events that are happening now? Nobody. French President Macron almost daily promises to send troops to fight Russia. Six years ago, such a forecast could easily send its author to a madhouse. Let us therefore directly acknowledge the inadequacy, limitations and failure of our imagination and our ability to predict and anticipate. Everyone around is speculating, but Putin (we, of course, do not touch God and take him out of the political equations) has it.

Therefore, I will limit myself to a prediction that can be 100 (okay, 87) percent certain. Victory over Kharitonov, Davankov and Slutsky is the easiest of the tests that Vladimir Putin has had and will still have to go through in 2024. Such characters as Biden, Zelensky, Macron, Sunak, Scholz, Borrell and further down the list can, of course, be mocked if desired. But these figures are definitely not ready to lose with such a devastating score. On March 17, 2024, Putin’s Russia completed, albeit an important, but the simplest political task of those that lie ahead of it.
input:
What will it be like – Putin’s new six-year plan? We don't know and can't even guess. Who, for example, based on the results of the last Russian presidential elections in 2018, could have predicted the turbulent events that occurred in February 2022 and the equally turbulent events that are happening now? Nobody. French President Macron almost daily promises to send troops to fight Russia. Six years ago, such a forecast could easily send its author to a madhouse. Let us therefore directly acknowledge the inadequacy, limitations and failure of our imagination and our ability to predict and anticipate. Everyone around is speculating, but Putin (we, of course, do not touch God and take him out of the political equations) has it.

Therefore, I will limit myself to a prediction that can be 100 (okay, 87) percent certain. Victory over Kharitonov, Davankov and Slutsky is the easiest of the tests that Vladimir Putin has had and will still have to go through in 2024. Such characters as Biden, Zelensky, Macron, Sunak, Scholz, Borrell and further down the list can, of course, be mocked if desired. But these figures are definitely not ready to lose with such a devastating score. On March 17, 2024, Putin’s Russia completed, albeit an important, but the simplest political task of those that lie ahead of it.

title: 俄罗斯大选：精心控制的投票将让普京获得第五任期 - BBC News 中文
content:
奥夫钦尼科夫不仅用他的艺术来评论当下，也用其揭示俄罗斯黑暗的过去——斯大林时代的镇压。他批评乌克兰战争的涂鸦并没有得到当局的青睐，很快就被涂掉了。
“我的画让人们思考：在这场冲突中，我们是对还是错？”奥夫钦尼科夫告诉我。“我认为这是侵犯邻国领土完整的罪行。如果我保持沉默，就是在纵容这种行为。”
“很多人确实保持了沉默，因为他们害怕受到打压，害怕失去工作，害怕被别人批评。”
俄罗斯反对派领袖纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）死于狱中后，奥夫钦尼科夫将纳瓦尔尼的肖像画在了当地一座纪念政治镇压受害者的纪念碑上。
“就在当天，有人把它擦掉了。”奥夫钦尼科夫告诉我。“但在家里，我在硬纸板上画了一个草稿。所以后来我把它放在纪念碑旁。”
奥夫钦尼科夫如何看待俄罗斯的未来？
“有人预测会有更多的镇压。”他说。“我们正在走向极权主义和全面独裁。”
奥夫钦尼科夫告诉我，他从不看电视。
一旦打开电视，他就会在官方媒体上看到一幅截然不同的俄罗斯的画面。
那是普京版的俄罗斯。
没有堆积如山的人头骨，没有绞肉机，没有提到纳瓦尔尼。
这不是一个对外扩张、对内镇压的俄罗斯，而是一个有着辉煌过去和同样辉煌未来的俄罗斯。这个国家英雄辈出，爱国者团结在国旗下保卫祖国不受外来侵略。
这是一个热爱现任领导人的俄罗斯。
几天前，俄罗斯《第一频道》（Channel 1）的晚间新闻播报显示，普京的粉丝们似乎像追星一样向总统问好。
“保重身体。”一位女士在亲吻总统之前喊道。
“健康长寿！”一名男子喊道。
如果你仅依靠《第一频道》获取新闻，你可能会得出这样的结论：普京大有希望在总统大选中大获全胜。
但是，就像绘画一样，背景很重要。这里的背景至关重要。
克里姆林宫不仅控制着俄罗斯的电视，还控制着包括选举在内的整个政治体系。
普京总统在寻求第五个任期时没有面临严峻挑战。他最尖锐的批评者要么流亡国外，要么在国内锒铛入狱。他最激烈的对手纳瓦尔尼已经身亡。
translation:
Ovchinnikov uses his art not only to comment on the present, but also to shed light on Russia’s dark past – the repression of the Stalinist era. His graffiti criticizing the war in Ukraine did not go over well with the authorities and was quickly painted over.
“My paintings make people think: Are we right or wrong in this conflict?” Ovchinnikov told me. "I consider this a crime against the territorial integrity of neighboring countries. If I remain silent, I condone this behavior."
"A lot of people do stay silent because they're afraid of being repressed, they're afraid of losing their jobs, they're afraid of being criticized."
After Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny died in prison, Ovchinnikov painted Navalny's portrait on a local monument commemorating victims of political repression.
“That same day, someone wiped it off,” Ovchinnikov told me. "But at home, I drew a rough sketch on cardboard. So I later placed it next to the memorial."
How does Ovchinnikov see the future of Russia?
"There are predictions of more repression," he said. “We are moving towards totalitarianism and total dictatorship.”
Ovchinnikov told me that he never watches television.
Once he turned on the TV, he saw a very different picture of Russia on state media.
That’s Putin’s version of Russia.
There were no mountains of human skulls, no meat grinders, no mention of Navalny.
This is not a Russia that expands externally and suppresses internally, but a Russia with a glorious past and an equally glorious future. This country has many heroes, and patriots unite under the national flag to defend the motherland from foreign aggression.
This is a Russia that loves its current leader.
A few days ago, Russia's Channel 1's evening news broadcast showed Putin's fans greeting the president as if they were star-struck.
"Take care of yourself," one woman shouted before kissing the president.
"Long and healthy!" a man shouted.
If you relied solely on Channel 1 for your news, you might conclude that Putin has a good shot at a landslide victory in the presidential election.
But, like painting, context is important. Context here is crucial.
The Kremlin controls not only Russian television but the entire political system, including elections.
President Putin faces no serious challenges as he seeks a fifth term. His most strident critics are in exile abroad or in jail at home. Navalny, his fiercest rival, is dead.

"A lot of people do stay silent because they're afraid of being repressed, they're afraid of losing their jobs, they're afraid of being criticized."
After Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny died in prison, Ovchinnikov painted Navalny's portrait on a local monument commemorating victims of political repression.

title: Putin says he supported prisoner swap for Navalny days before his death | AP News
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin said early Monday that he supported an idea to release opposition leader Alexei Navalny in a prisoner exchange just days before the man who was his biggest foe died.
In his first comments to address Navalny’s death, Putin said of the dissident’s demise: “It happens. There is nothing you can do about it. It’s life.”
The remarks were unusual in that he repeatedly referenced Navalny by his name for the first time in years. They came at a late-night news conference as results poured in from a presidential election which extended his rule for another six years after the Kremlin ruthlessly suppressed the opposition and crippled independent media. 
Navalny’s allies last month said that talks with Russian and Western officials about a prisoner swap involving Navalny were underway. The politician’s longtime associate Maria Pevchikh said the talks involving a swap with a Russian held in Germany and two U.S. citizens were in their final stages just days before the Kremlin critic’s sudden and unexplained death in an Arctic penal colony. 
She accused Putin of “getting rid of” Navalny in order not to exchange him, but offered no evidence to back her claims, and they could not be independently confirmed. 
Putin said Monday, also without offering any evidence, that several days before Navalny’s death, “certain colleagues, not from the (presidential) administration” told him about “an idea to exchange Navalny for certain people held in penitentiary facilities in Western countries.” He said he supported the idea. 
“Believe it or not, but the person talking to me didn’t even finish their sentence when I said: ‘I agree,’” Putin said in response to a question from a journalist about Navalny’s death. He added that his one condition was that Navalny wouldn’t return to Russia.
“But unfortunately, whatever happened, happened,” Putin said.
input:

In his first comments to address Navalny’s death, Putin said of the dissident’s demise: “It happens. There is nothing you can do about it. It’s life.”
The remarks were unusual in that he repeatedly referenced Navalny by his name for the first time in years. Navalny’s allies last month said that talks with Russian and Western officials about a prisoner swap involving Navalny were underway. The politician’s longtime associate Maria Pevchikh said the talks involving a swap with a Russian held in Germany and two U.S. citizens were in their final stages just days before the Kremlin critic’s sudden and unexplained death in an Arctic penal colony. 
She accused Putin of “getting rid of” Navalny in order not to exchange him, but offered no evidence to back her claims, and they could not be independently confirmed. 
Putin said Monday, also without offering any evidence, that several days before Navalny’s death, “certain colleagues, not from the (presidential) administration” told him about “an idea to exchange Navalny for certain people held in penitentiary facilities in Western countries.” He said he supported the idea. 
“Believe it or not, but the person talking to me didn’t even finish their sentence when I said: ‘I agree,’” Putin said in response to a question from a journalist about Navalny’s death. He added that his one condition was that Navalny wouldn’t return to Russia.
“But unfortunately, whatever happened, happened,” Putin said.

title: 俄罗斯总统普京欢呼选举胜利与选举被批评为非法 | 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京在选举中以压倒性胜利巩固了自己的权力，这场选举被广泛批评为缺乏民主合法性。
在选举后的新闻发布会上，普京称这一结果证明了他反抗西方并入侵乌克兰的决定是正确的。
普京周一清晨在竞选总部发表讲话时表示：“无论他们想恐吓谁，无论他们有多么想恐吓我们，无论他们想压制我们、我们的意志、我们的意识，无论他们有多么想压制我们，我们的意志、我们的意识，历史上从来没有人在这样的事情上取得过成功。”
“它现在不起作用，将来也不会起作用。 绝不。”
周日最后一次民意调查结束后不久，早期的民意调查结果得出了每个人都预期的结论：普京将把他近四分之一个世纪的统治再延长六年。
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会的数据，他获得了约 87% 的选票，其中约 60% 的选区已计票。这一结果意味着71岁的普京将超越约瑟夫·斯大林，成为俄罗斯200多年来任职时间最长的领导人。
初步结果显示，共产党候选人尼古拉·哈里托诺夫 (Nikolay Kharitonov) 以略低于 4% 的得票率位居第二，新人弗拉迪斯拉夫·达万科夫 (Vladislav Davankov) 排名第三，极端民族主义者列昂尼德·斯卢茨基 (Leonid Slutsky) 排名第四。
选举官员表示，投票结束时全国投票率为 74.22%，超过 2018 年 67.5% 的水平。
普京的胜利毫无悬念，因为他的批评者大多入狱、流亡或死亡，而公众对他领导力的批评却受到压制。
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin consolidated his power with a landslide victory in an election widely criticized as lacking democratic legitimacy.
At a post-election press conference, Putin said the results vindicated his decision to defy the West and invade Ukraine.
"No matter who they want to intimidate, no matter how much they want to intimidate us, no matter how much they want to suppress us, our will, our consciousness, no matter how much they want to suppress us, our consciousness," Putin said in a speech at his campaign headquarters early Monday morning. The will, our consciousness, no one in history has ever succeeded in anything like this.”
"It doesn't work now and it won't work in the future. Never."
Shortly after the last polls closed on Sunday, early polls concluded what everyone expected: Putin will extend his nearly quarter-century rule for another six years.
He received about 87% of the vote, with about 60% of precincts counted, according to Russia's Central Election Commission. The result means that the 71-year-old Putin will surpass Joseph Stalin and become Russia's longest-serving leader in more than 200 years.
Preliminary results showed Communist candidate Nikolay Kharitonov in second place with just under 4% of the vote, with newcomer Vladislav Davankov in third , ultranationalist Leonid Slutsky ranked fourth.
Election officials said polls closed with a national turnout of 74.22%, exceeding 2018's level of 67.5%.
Putin's victory was by no means certain as most of his critics were in prison, exiled or dead, while public criticism of his leadership was suppressed.
input:
Russian President Vladimir Putin consolidated his power with a landslide victory in an election widely criticized as lacking democratic legitimacy.
At a post-election press conference, Putin said the results vindicated his decision to defy the West and invade Ukraine.
"No matter who they want to intimidate, no matter how much they want to intimidate us, no matter how much they want to suppress us, our will, our consciousness, no matter how much they want to suppress us, our consciousness," Putin said in a speech at his campaign headquarters early Monday morning. The will, our consciousness, no one in history has ever succeeded in anything like this.”
"It doesn't work now and it won't work in the future. Never."
Shortly after the last polls closed on Sunday, early polls concluded what everyone expected: Putin will extend his nearly quarter-century rule for another six years.
He received about 87% of the vote, with about 60% of precincts counted, according to Russia's Central Election Commission. The result means that the 71-year-old Putin will surpass Joseph Stalin and become Russia's longest-serving leader in more than 200 years.
Preliminary results showed Communist candidate Nikolay Kharitonov in second place with just under 4% of the vote, with newcomer Vladislav Davankov in third , ultranationalist Leonid Slutsky ranked fourth.
Election officials said polls closed with a national turnout of 74.22%, exceeding 2018's level of 67.5%.
Putin's victory was by no means certain as most of his critics were in prison, exiled or dead, while public criticism of his leadership was suppressed.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content:
Ну а что же сам победитель выборов? В своем триумфальном выступлении Владимир Путин поблагодарил избирателей за высокое доверие, пообещал и дальше отстаивать национальные интересы России и обеспечивать ее суверенитет и безопасность. При этом он жестко осудил попытки Запада вмешиваться во внутренние дела страны и "раскачивать лодку" под видом борьбы за демократию.

"Россия сама определяет свою судьбу и выбирает свой путь развития. И мы не позволим никому диктовать нам свои условия или навязывать чуждые ценности", - подчеркнул президент. Что ж, похоже, внешнеполитический курс Москвы останется неизменным и после 2024.

Так что, несмотря на все претензии и вопросы, итоги голосования нельзя списывать исключительно на фальсификации и административное давление. У Владимира Путина действительно немало искренних сторонников, особенно среди людей старшего возраста, бюджетников, силовиков и жителей провинции. Многие из них верят, что только он способен защитить страну от внешних угроз, обеспечить порядок и социальную стабильность. Кто-то поддерживает существующую внешнюю политику и амбиции Кремля.

Конечно, реальный уровень поддержки президента вряд ли достигает официальных 87,28%. Но то, что за него готовы голосовать больше половины избирателей - это факт, с которым нужно считаться. Оппозиции еще предстоит долгая работа, чтобы предложить обществу привлекательную альтернативу и завоевать симпатии большинства. А пока Путин остается самым популярным и влиятельным политиком России.
translation:
Well, what about the election winner himself? In his triumphant speech, Vladimir Putin thanked voters for their high trust and promised to continue to defend Russia’s national interests and ensure its sovereignty and security. At the same time, he harshly condemned the West’s attempts to interfere in the country’s internal affairs and “rock the boat” under the guise of a struggle for democracy.

“Russia itself determines its own destiny and chooses its own path of development. And we will not allow anyone to dictate their terms to us or impose alien values,” the president emphasized. Well, it seems that Moscow’s foreign policy course will remain unchanged after 2024.

So, despite all the complaints and questions, the voting results cannot be attributed solely to fraud and administrative pressure. Vladimir Putin really has many sincere supporters, especially among older people, state employees, security officials and residents of the provinces. Many of them believe that only he is able to protect the country from external threats, ensure order and social stability. Some support the existing foreign policy and ambitions of the Kremlin.

Of course, the real level of support for the president is unlikely to reach the official 87.28%. But the fact that more than half of the voters are ready to vote for him is a fact that must be taken into account. The opposition still has a long way to go to offer society an attractive alternative and win the sympathy of the majority. In the meantime, Putin remains the most popular and influential politician in Russia.

“Russia itself determines its own destiny and chooses its own path of development. And we will not allow anyone to dictate their terms to us or impose alien values,” the president emphasized. Well, it seems that Moscow’s foreign policy course will remain unchanged after 2024.

So, despite all the complaints and questions, the voting results cannot be attributed solely to fraud and administrative pressure. Vladimir Putin really has many sincere supporters, especially among older people, state employees, security officials and residents of the provinces. Many of them believe that only he is able to protect the country from external threats, ensure order and social stability. Some support the existing foreign policy and ambitions of the Kremlin.

title: Spotlight: Putin wins presidential election with record support rate
content:
Incumbent Russian President Vladimir Putin was elected president for the fourth time in a landslide victory on Sunday, gaining "unprecedented" public support throughout his campaigns.

Putin won more than 76.6 percent of ballots after 99.83 percent of votes have been counted in Sunday's presidential election, the Central Election Commission (CEC) Chair Ella Pamfilova said, citing preliminary data.

In accordance with the law, a candidate garnering more than half of the votes goes to the Kremlin. Putin got 52.9 percent of votes in 2000, 71.3 percent in 2004 and 63.6 percent in 2012.

According to the CEC, Communist Party candidate Pavel Grudinin, Putin's nearest rival, got 11.9 percent of votes, while the head of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, received 5.66 percent. Five other candidates gained substantially less support.

Some 73.4 million Russians, or 67.5 percent of the whole population, cast their ballots, and possible loopholes had been avoided by lawmakers to ensure transparency and openness of the presidential campaigns, said Valentina Matvienko, Russian parliament's upper house speaker.

About 275,000 law enforcement officers were deployed to ensure law and order at the polling stations, the Interior Ministry said in a statement, adding that there were no violations that could affect the course or results of the election.

Putin, 65, first became Russian president in 2000, re-elected in 2004, and became president for the third time in 2012 after serving as prime minister for four years. He announced seeking a fourth term in late 2017 under the campaign slogan of "Strong President, Strong Russia."

At a rally outside the Red Square in Moscow on Sunday night, Putin thanked his supporters across the country and stressed the importance of preserving national unity.

At his campaign headquarters, Putin chanted "Russia! Russia! Russia!" with the personnel there, saying that "We will think about the future of our great motherland and the future of our children."

He called on all Russian political forces to work together on the "very complicated" state tasks guided by national interests, urging extraordinary efforts to make new breakthroughs.

The president said he plans to reshuffle the government after his inauguration on May 7 and will consider prime minister and other government members from now on. When asked if people will see a new Putin in the next six years, he said "We are all changing."

When asked about Russia's relationship with China, Putin said China is Russia's strategic partner and bilateral relations are at an "unprecedentedly high" level, which Russia values very much.

He said his country will make every effort to expand cooperation with China, including the connection between the Belt and Road Initiative and the Eurasian Economic Union.

The Belt and Road Initiative -- the initiative on the construction of the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road -- aims to build trade and infrastructure networks connecting Asia with Europe and Africa along the ancient Silk Road routes. It comprises the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road.

As for relations with the European countries, Putin said Russia is ready to work with them to settle any disputes, citing the allegations that Russia was involved in the chemical attack against ex-spy Sergei Skripal in Britain as "complete nonsense."

Since Putin was elected president for the first time in 2000, Russia has recovered from the collapse of the former Soviet Union and cemented its status as a big power.

With actions such as anti-terrorist operations in Syria, Putin has built up his prestige among Russians and gained additional influence in the global arena.

He has created a political system necessary to respond to any challenges, said Alexei Mukhin, director general of the Center for Political Information, a Moscow-based think tank.

title: ﻿俄罗斯大选 普京呼吁民众投票 _大公网
content:
图：俄罗斯总统普京14日呼吁民众积极投票。\路透社

　　【大公报讯】综合路透社、美联社报道：俄罗斯将于本月15至17日连续三天举行总统选举投票，争取连任的总统普京14日发表视频讲话，呼吁民众投票。与此同时，乌克兰加大对俄边境的袭击，别尔哥罗德州地方官员14日表示，乌方发射至少8枚导弹，导致2人死亡12人受伤，部分购物中心须关闭。
　　在周四的视频讲话中，普京呼吁俄罗斯民众积极投票，参与大选，以展现爱国主义情怀。他指出，选举结果将直接影响国家未来几年的发展。他强调，在这个困难时期，俄罗斯在各个领域都面临着复杂的挑战。为了克服所有这些困难，俄罗斯人民必须团结一致、充满自信。
　　普京还指出，前线的战士们也将参与投票，他们在保卫祖国的过程中表现出了勇气和英雄主义。他们参加选举，为所有人树立了榜样。
　　根据俄罗斯联邦委员会，总统选举投票由本月15至17日连续三天进行，包括普京在内共有4名候选人登记角逐总统。俄罗斯总统当选人将于5月7日就职，每届任期6年，若没有候选人获得参加投票的选民过半数选票，会在21天后由获得最多票数的两名候选人进行第二轮投票。
　　在俄罗斯即将举行总统选举投票之际，乌克兰加大对俄乌边境的攻击火力。克里姆林宫指控乌克兰干扰俄罗斯选举，指其向别尔哥罗德边境地区发射了至少8枚导弹，造成2人死亡12人受伤。乌军还试图在库尔斯克边境地区进行跨境袭击，被俄军击退。乌克兰的重型无人机13日向俄罗斯本土炼油厂发动攻击，导致俄罗斯石油公司最大的炼油厂起火。
translation:
Picture: Russian President Putin called on people to vote actively on the 14th. \Reuters

[Ta Kung Pao News] Comprehensive reports from Reuters and the Associated Press: Russia will hold voting in the presidential election for three consecutive days from the 15th to the 17th of this month. President Putin, who is seeking re-election, issued a video speech on the 14th, calling on the people to vote. At the same time, Ukraine intensified its attacks on the Russian border. Local officials in Belgorod Region stated on the 14th that Ukraine launched at least 8 missiles, killing 2 people and injuring 12 others. Some shopping malls had to be closed.
In a video speech on Thursday, Putin called on the Russian people to actively vote and participate in the general election to show their patriotism. He pointed out that the election results will directly affect the country's development in the next few years. He emphasized that in this difficult period, Russia faces complex challenges in various fields. To overcome all these difficulties, the Russian people must be united and confident.
Putin also pointed out that frontline soldiers who have shown courage and heroism in defending their homeland will also participate in the vote. They participated in elections and set an example for everyone.
According to the Russian Federation Council, voting in the presidential election will be held for three consecutive days from the 15th to the 17th of this month. A total of four candidates, including Putin, have registered to compete for the president. The Russian president-elect will take office on May 7 and will serve a six-year term. If no candidate obtains more than half of the votes of voters participating in the voting, a second round of voting will be held 21 days later by the two candidates with the most votes.
As Russia is about to hold a presidential election vote, Ukraine has increased its attack power on the Russian-Ukrainian border. The Kremlin accused Ukraine of interfering in Russia's elections, saying it fired at least eight missiles at the Belgorod border area, killing two people and injuring 12 others. The Ukrainian army also tried to conduct a cross-border attack in the Kursk border area, but was repelled by the Russian army. Ukrainian heavy drones launched an attack on Russia's local oil refinery on the 13th, causing a fire at Rosneft's largest refinery.

Picture: Russian President Putin called on people to vote actively on the 14th. \Reuters

[Ta Kung Pao News] Comprehensive reports from Reuters and the Associated Press: Russia will hold voting in the presidential election for three consecutive days from the 15th to the 17th of this month. President Putin, who is seeking re-election, issued a video speech on the 14th, calling on the people to vote. At the same time, Ukraine intensified its attacks on the Russian border. Local officials in Belgorod Region stated on the 14th that Ukraine launched at least 8 missiles, killing 2 people and injuring 12 others. Some shopping malls had to be closed.
In a video speech on Thursday, Putin called on the Russian people to actively vote and participate in the general election to show their patriotism. He pointed out that the election results will directly affect the country's development in the next few years. He emphasized that in this difficult period, Russia faces complex challenges in various fields. To overcome all these difficulties, the Russian people must be united and confident.
Putin also pointed out that frontline soldiers who have shown courage and heroism in defending their homeland will also participate in the vote. They participated in elections and set an example for everyone.

A total of four candidates, including Putin, have registered to compete for the president. The Russian president-elect will take office on May 7 and will serve a six-year term. If no candidate obtains more than half of the votes of voters participating in the voting, a second round of voting will be held 21 days later by the two candidates with the most votes.
As Russia is about to hold a presidential election vote, Ukraine has increased its attack power on the Russian-Ukrainian border. The Kremlin accused Ukraine of interfering in Russia's elections, saying it fired at least eight missiles at the Belgorod border area, killing two people and injuring 12 others. The Ukrainian army also tried to conduct a cross-border attack in the Kursk border area, but was repelled by the Russian army. Ukrainian heavy drones launched an attack on Russia's local oil refinery on the 13th, causing a fire at Rosneft's largest refinery.

title: In Russian presidential election, voting is forced at gunpoint in occupied Ukraine - The Washington Post
content:
Natalia Petrenko, head of the military administration for Shulhyne, an occupied village in Luhansk region said that election officials and soldiers were targeting vulnerable elderly pensioners in house-to-house visits. Petrenko has left the occupied area but is in touch with friends and family still living in the village.
Days before the election they visited the pensioners with gifts, Petrenko said, “and at the same time they told them that the commission will come to your home and you must put a mark for Putin.”
“A soldier in a balaclava came in with an automatic [weapon],” she said. “And now I just calmly imagine: an old woman is sitting, who remembers the Second World War, and a soldier with an automatic enters her house again.”
‘What will she write down [on the ballot] What will she do? There’s this fear of the gun, the weapon,” Petrenko added. “And they are on every corner.”
In this Ukrainian village, almost no men are left
Halyna, who last year fled her home in Kakhovka, an occupied city in the southern Kherson region, said she spoke this week to her niece, 32, who is still there and described two soldiers accompanying a woman with a ballot box going from house to house, claiming they were carrying out “preliminary voting” because of shelling.
“I wish these elections would pass quickly,” the niece told her aunt in a message reviewed by The Post, adding that Ukrainian artillery fire had given the Russians an excuse to force people to vote at home. “They’re aiming at the military,” she wrote, “But when those rockets fly over, it’s so terrifying. I cover my ears but fear still overwhelms me. And now, I’m crying again.”
As the forced voting was underway, successive Russian ballistic missile strikes on Friday hit the southern port city of Odessa, killing 21 people, including rescuers who had arrived to help after the initial explosion. Dozens more were injured and hospitalized.
Among the dead were a former deputy mayor of Odessa, Serhii Tetyukhin, and a former head of the Odessa regional police, Oleksandr Hostishchev, who was also the head of a National Guard regiment, officials said.
The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, said on Friday that Russia’s pattern of holding sham elections in occupied Ukraine was a cynical attempt to “legitimize Putin’s illegal attempt at a land grab.”
“Let’s call this what this is,” she said.

title: Yes, the Russian election is rigged – but there could still be surprises in store for Putin | The Independent
content:
Will Putin reach that forecast 75 per cent of votes cast? And if he does, on what turnout? This election is being run across three days (Friday to Sunday) and there is also the possibility of e-voting.
Both the extended time and the e-voting can be seen as ways of upping the turnout. But they also, of course, offer abundant opportunities for rigging (much easier to doctor the computer, for instance, than “stuff” the ballot-box or bus trusted voters to multiple polling stations). But social media also offers new opportunities for independent monitoring, and turnout could be a better gauge of Putin’s support than the actual vote. Will people stay away, either through apathy or hostility?
Then again, could there be overt protests? This might have seemed improbable before hundreds of thousands of Russians turned out to pay their last respects to Navalny, either at his grave in Moscow or at designated places of memorial all over Russia. His widow, Yulia, has reiterated her late husband’s request to his supporters to mass at polling stations at midday on Sunday as a protest. Will they? Was the attack on his chief of staff, Leonid Volkov, in Lithuania, this week, intended as a warning? Will it have a deterrent effect?
And how will the authorities police these elections? Another surprise, barely noted outside Russia, was the hands-off policing of the Navalny obsequies. A few people were arrested later, but calm and dignity were preserved. Was this because the Kremlin had qualms about riot police beating mourners? Or was it rather for fear of escalating protests? And which will be the authorities’ greater fear through these elections: of dissent itself, or of the risk that trying to quash that dissent by force could rebound?
It is not completely wrong to describe this Russian presidential election as, to an extent, a referendum on Putin’s current term as president and/or on Russia’s war against Ukraine. But it may also be seen as a reflection, albeit partial and imperfect, of the state of Russia after almost a quarter-century of Putin – the reflection of a monolith that may be starting to show cracks.
