title: А президент-то рисованный
content:
Владимир Путин в пятый раз победил на президентских выборах и избрался на очередной шестилетний срок. Действующий президент набрал 87% голосов при явке 77%. Примерно на такие показатели рассчитывали в Кремле и ориентировали на них региональные администрации по всей России. До этого момента подобные цифры на выборах фиксировали только в республиках Северного Кавказа — регионах с самым высоким уровнем электоральных фальсификаций в пользу кандидатов от власти. «Новая-Европа» рассказывает, как оценить вбросы при помощи статистики.

Без учета электронного голосования, по итогам обработки 97% протоколов, в выборах приняли участие 74,5 млн избирателей. Из них 64,7 млн человек, по данным ЦИК, проголосовали за Путина. Однако это не единственный рекордный показатель прошедших президентских выборов. По уровню фальсификаций эти выборы превзошли все предыдущие президентские и парламентские выборы (исключение — голосование по поправкам в Конституцию), причем отличались и способы рисовки результатов. 

Ранее мы опубликовали оценку фальсификаций в 31,6 миллиона, которая основана на методе физика и эксперта по электоральной статистике Сергея Шпилькина. Но в этом году выборы настолько «грязные», что стандартные методы анализа фальсификаций работают с оговорками.

На распределении участков по явке и результату победителя в случае честного голосования должно быть одно «облако» относительно ровной формы. В случае, когда вбрасывают бюллетени, у лидера повышается и явка, и результат, и таким образом у «облака» вырастает «хвост». 

Почти всегда при этом остается видным «честное ядро», взяв которое за точку отсчета, можно оценить фальсификации. Это было возможным на всех голосованиях федерального уровня в России до этого года.

Однако в 2024 году идентифицировать «честное» ядро результатов практически невозможно: больше всего голосов сконцентрировано в области, которую обычно считают вбросами.

Причиной этого могут быть не только прямые фальсификации, такие как вбросы, но и «административный ресурс», то есть принуждение бюджетников к голосованию. Всё это размывает «облако» и затрудняет анализ. Почти все голоса за Путина находятся в области, где результат возрастает вместе с явкой, в то время как для альтернативных кандидатов (особенно для Даванкова) эта зависимость обратная.
translation:
Vladimir Putin won the presidential election for the fifth time and was elected to another six-year term. The incumbent president received 87% of the vote with a turnout of 77%. The Kremlin was counting on approximately these indicators and regional administrations throughout Russia were focusing on them. Until this moment, similar numbers in elections were recorded only in the republics of the North Caucasus - regions with the highest level of electoral fraud in favor of government candidates. “New-Europe” tells how to evaluate stuffing using statistics.

Without taking into account electronic voting, based on the results of processing 97% of the protocols, 74.5 million voters took part in the elections. Of these, 64.7 million people, according to the Central Election Commission, voted for Putin. However, this is not the only record indicator of the past presidential elections. In terms of the level of fraud, these elections surpassed all previous presidential and parliamentary elections (with the exception of voting on amendments to the Constitution), and the methods of depicting the results also differed.

We previously published an estimate of fraud at 31.6 million, which is based on the method of physicist and election statistics expert Sergei Shpilkin. But this year’s elections are so “dirty” that standard methods of analyzing fraud work with reservations.

In the case of fair voting, the distribution of polling stations based on turnout and the result of the winner should have one “cloud” of relatively even shape. In the case when ballots are stuffed, both the turnout and the result increase for the leader, and thus the “cloud” grows a “tail.”

Almost always, in this case, the “honest core” remains visible, taking which as a starting point, one can evaluate falsifications. This was possible at all federal level votes in Russia until this year.

However, in 2024, it is almost impossible to identify the “honest” core of results: most of the votes are concentrated in the area that is usually considered to be fake.

The reason for this may be not only direct falsifications, such as stuffing, but also “administrative resources,” that is, forcing state employees to vote. All this blurs the “cloud” and makes analysis difficult. Almost all votes for Putin are in the area where the result increases with turnout, while for alternative candidates (especially Davankov) this relationship is reversed.
input:
Vladimir Putin won the presidential election for the fifth time and was elected to another six-year term. The incumbent president received 87% of the vote with a turnout of 77%. The Kremlin was counting on approximately these indicators and regional administrations throughout Russia were focusing on them. Until this moment, similar numbers in elections were recorded only in the republics of the North Caucasus - regions with the highest level of electoral fraud in favor of government candidates. “New-Europe” tells how to evaluate stuffing using statistics.

Without taking into account electronic voting, based on the results of processing 97% of the protocols, 74.5 million voters took part in the elections. Of these, 64.7 million people, according to the Central Election Commission, voted for Putin. However, this is not the only record indicator of the past presidential elections. In terms of the level of fraud, these elections surpassed all previous presidential and parliamentary elections (with the exception of voting on amendments to the Constitution), and the methods of depicting the results also differed.

We previously published an estimate of fraud at 31.6 million, which is based on the method of physicist and election statistics expert Sergei Shpilkin. But this year’s elections are so “dirty” that standard methods of analyzing fraud work with reservations.

In the case of fair voting, the distribution of polling stations based on turnout and the result of the winner should have one “cloud” of relatively even shape. In the case when ballots are stuffed, both the turnout and the result increase for the leader, and thus the “cloud” grows a “tail.”

Almost always, in this case, the “honest core” remains visible, taking which as a starting point, one can evaluate falsifications. This was possible at all federal level votes in Russia until this year.

However, in 2024, it is almost impossible to identify the “honest” core of results: most of the votes are concentrated in the area that is usually considered to be fake.

The reason for this may be not only direct falsifications, such as stuffing, but also “administrative resources,” that is, forcing state employees to vote. All this blurs the “cloud” and makes analysis difficult. Almost all votes for Putin are in the area where the result increases with turnout, while for alternative candidates (especially Davankov) this relationship is reversed.

title: 快讯！拿下87％选票 普京宣布连任总统-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
content:
俄罗斯总统选举投票结束，官方公布点算近72％选票后，现任总统普京获得87.17％的选票。普京本人在竞选总部宣布胜选连任，俄罗斯强人总统将继续主宰国家6年。
综合外电报道，普京此次选举的得票率，是历届总统选举中最高的一次，上一届2018年总统选举时，他当时以76.7％的得票率连任，是此前他参与的总统选举中，得票率最高的一次。
2000年代至今是属于普京的时代，他该年首次当选总统，执政至今长达24年，这次再度连任，将有望超越前苏联领导人斯大林，成为俄罗斯200年来执政最久的统治者。
俄罗斯总统选举投票天数不只一天，自15日起投票，17日结束，本次投票率超过73％，逾800万人在网络上投票，目前官方已点算的选票中，普京获得压倒性的票数，其他3名总统候选人得票率大约落在3％至4％。
translation:
Voting in the Russian presidential election has ended. Officials announced that after nearly 72% of the votes were counted, current President Putin won 87.17% of the votes. Putin himself announced at his campaign headquarters that he had won the re-election, and that Russia's strongman president would continue to dominate the country for another six years.
Comprehensive foreign news reports indicate that Putin’s vote share in this election is the highest in all previous presidential elections. In the last presidential election in 2018, he was re-elected with 76.7% of the vote, which was the highest vote share in any previous presidential election in which he participated. The highest rate ever.
The 2000s to the present are the era of Putin. He was elected president for the first time that year and has been in power for 24 years. If he is re-elected this time, he is expected to surpass the former Soviet leader Stalin and become Russia's longest-ruling ruler in 200 years.
The Russian presidential election has more than one voting day. Voting started on the 15th and ended on the 17th. The turnout rate exceeded 73%. More than 8 million people voted online. Among the officially counted votes, Putin received an overwhelming number of votes. , the vote rates of the other three presidential candidates fell around 3% to 4%.
input:
Voting in the Russian presidential election has ended. Officials announced that after nearly 72% of the votes were counted, current President Putin won 87.17% of the votes. Putin himself announced at his campaign headquarters that he had won the re-election, and that Russia's strongman president would continue to dominate the country for another six years.
Comprehensive foreign news reports indicate that Putin’s vote share in this election is the highest in all previous presidential elections. In the last presidential election in 2018, he was re-elected with 76.7% of the vote, which was the highest vote share in any previous presidential election in which he participated. The highest rate ever.
The 2000s to the present are the era of Putin. He was elected president for the first time that year and has been in power for 24 years. If he is re-elected this time, he is expected to surpass the former Soviet leader Stalin and become Russia's longest-ruling ruler in 200 years.
The Russian presidential election has more than one voting day. Voting started on the 15th and ended on the 17th. The turnout rate exceeded 73%. More than 8 million people voted online. Among the officially counted votes, Putin received an overwhelming number of votes. , the vote rates of the other three presidential candidates fell around 3% to 4%.

title: Russian voters, answering Navalny’s call, protest as Putin extends his rule to 2030 - The Washington Post
content:
At one polling station next to Polyanka metro station in central Moscow, a line of dozens extended around the block by 12:30 p.m., mainly Muscovites in their 20s and 30s. A police van and two patrol cars hovered nearby, and the entrance to the polling station was guarded by several police officers and security agents.
“We came here to vote against Putin,” said Elizaveta, 21. “We are going to put three crosses to show that we are for everyone but him. Literally anyone else is better than him.”
The Washington Post is not fully identifying her or other voters interviewed for this article because of the risk of serious repercussions from Russian authorities, including criminal prosecution.
Elizaveta’s mother, Marina, added: “He has been in the same place for too long.”
In Belgorod, Russian city hit hardest by war, Putin is still running strong
The Noon Against Putin demonstration is the third recent sign of significant Russian protest or political dissent through long lines.
In January, citizens formed long lines to sign petitions required for Nadezhdin, the antiwar candidate, to secure a place on the ballot. He was later barred by authorities, who cited irregularities with the signatures.
This month, thousands waited in huge lines to attend Navalny’s funeral and for days afterward to lay flowers and leave letters at his grave.
In Russia’s climate of political fear, protests are largely symbolic, with authorities expected to maintain tight control in the months ahead, amid a war exacting massive Russian casualties.
Still, the signs of public anger are unmistakable. Some frustrated Russians did not even wait for the Sunday protest and instead expressed their anger as soon as voting started on Friday, by setting fire to polling stations or ballots or dumping liquid into ballot boxes.

“We came here to vote against Putin,” said Elizaveta, 21. “We are going to put three crosses to show that we are for everyone but him. Literally anyone else is better than him.”
The Washington Post is not fully identifying her or other voters interviewed for this article because of the risk of serious repercussions from Russian authorities, including criminal prosecution.
Elizaveta’s mother, Marina, added: “He has been in the same place for too long.”
In Belgorod, Russian city hit hardest by war, Putin is still running strong
The Noon Against Putin demonstration is the third recent sign of significant Russian protest or political dissent through long lines.
In January, citizens formed long lines to sign petitions required for Nadezhdin, the antiwar candidate, to secure a place on the ballot. He was later barred by authorities, who cited irregularities with the signatures.
This month, thousands waited in huge lines to attend Navalny’s funeral and for days afterward to lay flowers and leave letters at his grave.
In Russia’s climate of political fear, protests are largely symbolic, with authorities expected to maintain tight control in the months ahead, amid a war exacting massive Russian casualties.

title: 普京连任后将首访中国？克宫：正在筹备总统的数次出访活动
content:
据环球网报道，2024年俄罗斯总统选举投票已结束，普京成功当选俄罗斯联邦总统，将开启第五个总统任期，任期为6年。普京于当地时间3月19日表示，他考虑将中国作为新任期内首次出访的国家。
据路透社3月19日报道，一名知情人士透露，俄罗斯总统普京将访问中国，相关细节得到另外四名消息人士的证实。其中一名消息人士称，普京将于5月前往中国。这可能是普京在新任期内的首次海外之行。
克里姆林宫在被问及普京是否会访问中国的问题时，俄罗斯总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫回应，“目前正在对总统的数次出访、数个最高层接触进行筹备工作，随着日期临近，我们会向你们通报。”
据新华社3月18日消息，国家主席习近平致电普京，祝贺他当选连任俄罗斯联邦总统。习近平指出，中方高度重视中俄关系发展，愿同俄方保持密切沟通，推动中俄新时代全面战略协作伙伴关系持续健康稳定深入发展，造福两国和两国人民。
3月15日至17日，俄罗斯举行总统选举。根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会网站当地时间3月18日发布的数据，本次选举全部选票均已计票完成。初步数据显示，现任总统普京获得76277708张选票，得票率为87.28%。
3月18日，俄罗斯总统选举中国观察员团团长、中国政府欧亚事务特别代表李辉向中俄媒体提交了俄罗斯总统选举中国观察员团观察声明。声明称，中方观察员团认为，本次俄罗斯总统选举民主、透明、公正，选举过程顺利平静，未发现违规情况。选举结果是俄罗斯人民的自主选择。中方尊重俄罗斯人民的选择，衷心祝贺普京总统再次当选俄罗斯总统，相信并坚定支持俄罗斯实现国家稳定和发展振兴。
环球网援引俄罗斯塔斯社最新消息称，在19日与议会各党派会议上，俄罗斯联邦共产党中央委员会主席久加诺夫请求普京选择北京作为首访目的地。“我希望您（新任期）首访是去东方，而不是西方。”塔斯社援引久加诺夫的话说。普京对此微笑回应，“我一定会认真考虑你说的话，没有开玩笑。”
translation:
According to Global Network, the voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election has ended. Putin was successfully elected as the President of the Russian Federation and will start his fifth presidential term of six years. Putin said on March 19, local time, that he was considering making China the country he would visit for the first time in his new term.
According to a Reuters report on March 19, a person familiar with the matter revealed that Russian President Vladimir Putin will visit China, and the relevant details were confirmed by four other sources. One of the sources said Putin will travel to China in May. This may be Putin's first overseas trip in his new term.
When the Kremlin was asked whether Putin would visit China, Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov responded, "Preparations are currently being made for several visits by the president and several top-level contacts. As the date approaches, we will Inform you.”
According to Xinhua News Agency on March 18, President Xi Jinping called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of the Russian Federation. Xi Jinping pointed out that China attaches great importance to the development of China-Russia relations and is willing to maintain close communication with Russia to promote the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era to the benefit of the two countries and their peoples.
From March 15th to 17th, Russia held a presidential election. According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission website on March 18, local time, all votes in this election have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 76,277,708 votes, with a vote rate of 87.28%.
On March 18, Li Hui, head of the Chinese Observer Group for the Russian presidential election and the Chinese government’s special representative for Eurasian affairs, submitted a statement on the Chinese Observer Group’s observation of the Russian presidential election to the Chinese and Russian media. The statement stated that the Chinese observer team believed that the Russian presidential election was democratic, transparent, and fair, and that the election process was smooth and calm, and no irregularities were found. The election results are the independent choice of the Russian people. China respects the choice of the Russian people, sincerely congratulates President Putin on his re-election as Russian president, and believes in and firmly supports Russia in achieving national stability, development and revitalization.
Global Network quoted the latest news from Russia's TASS news agency that at a meeting with various parties in parliament on the 19th, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Zyuganov asked Putin to choose Beijing as the destination for his first visit. "I hope your first visit (of the new term) will be to the East, not the West." TASS quoted Zyuganov as saying. Putin responded with a smile, "I will definitely consider what you said seriously, I am not joking."

According to a Reuters report on March 19, a person familiar with the matter revealed that Russian President Vladimir Putin will visit China, and the relevant details were confirmed by four other sources. One of the sources said Putin will travel to China in May. This may be Putin's first overseas trip in his new term.
When the Kremlin was asked whether Putin would visit China, Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov responded, "Preparations are currently being made for several visits by the president and several top-level contacts. As the date approaches, we will Inform you.”
According to Xinhua News Agency on March 18, President Xi Jinping called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of the Russian Federation. Xi Jinping pointed out that China attaches great importance to the development of China-Russia relations and is willing to maintain close communication with Russia to promote the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era to the benefit of the two countries and their peoples.
From March 15th to 17th, Russia held a presidential election. According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission website on March 18, local time, all votes in this election have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 76,277,708 votes, with a vote rate of 87.28%.
On March 18, Li Hui, head of the Chinese Observer Group for the Russian presidential election and the Chinese government’s special representative for Eurasian affairs, submitted a statement on the Chinese Observer Group’s observation of the Russian presidential election to the Chinese and Russian media. The statement stated that the Chinese observer team believed that the Russian presidential election was democratic, transparent, and fair, and that the election process was smooth and calm, and no irregularities were found. The election results are the independent choice of the Russian people. China respects the choice of the Russian people, sincerely congratulates President Putin on his re-election as Russian president, and believes in and firmly supports Russia in achieving national stability, development and revitalization.
Global Network quoted the latest news from Russia's TASS news agency that at a meeting with various parties in parliament on the 19th, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Zyuganov asked Putin to choose Beijing as the destination for his first visit. "I hope your first visit (of the new term) will be to the East, not the West." TASS quoted Zyuganov as saying. Putin responded with a smile, "I will definitely consider what you said seriously, I am not joking."

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
content:
普京作为俄罗斯总统的现任任期将于2024年5月7日结束。根据俄罗斯宪法，普京可以在此次任期结束后寻求连任两届至2036年。
2023年12月的祖国英雄日颁奖仪式上，普京宣布将参加2024年总统选举。当时，“顿涅茨克人民共和国”人民委员会主席阿尔乔姆·佐加在仪式结束后与普京进行交谈，并表示整个顿巴斯地区都希望普京参与大选。普京回应称：“我在不同的时期有不同的想法，但现在到了必须做出决定的时刻。我将竞选俄罗斯总统。”
在此次俄罗斯大选中，普京是唯一一名以独立候选人身份参选的总统候选人。有分析认为，在普京4次参选经历中，有3次均以独立候选人身份参选，这种方式将有助于其塑造自己作为全俄罗斯代表的形象，而非仅仅代表某一党派。
与此前历次选举时一样，普京不会参与在电视和广播节目中进行的选前辩论活动。俄总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫表示，普京是现任国家元首，日程非常繁忙，这使得他与其他候选人之间存在根本性的不同。总统本人每天都会出现在媒体上，俄罗斯人每天都有机会看到普京关于生活各方面的言论。
尽管不参加选前辩论活动，但在俄罗斯大选进行前，普京频繁出现在国内的各类活动中。在宣布参选后，2023年年底，普京自俄乌冲突爆发以来首次举办“直播连线”活动及年度记者会，在4个多小时中回答了俄罗斯民众以及国内外记者的约80个问题，涉及内容十分广泛。在该场活动中，普京指出俄经济已从下滑势头中恢复，强调俄“特别军事行动”目标未变，同时还提到了俄罗斯需要回归传统价值观。
进入2024年后，普京国内行程较为密集，从其此前从未到访的俄罗斯远东地区楚科奇自治区，到俄罗斯西部飞地加里宁格勒，普京在对多地的访问行程中谈及地区经济发展、社会保障等民生问题，并曾参观包括乌拉尔机车车辆厂（UralVagonZavod，俄罗斯最大的军事装备开发商和制造商之一）、喀山航空厂在内的多家工业企业，了解企业经营情况。
2月初，普京接受美国记者塔克·卡尔森专访，这也是普京自2022年2月俄乌冲突爆发以来首次接受西方媒体的一对一采访。他在接受采访时强调，俄罗斯不会将俄乌冲突扩大至欧洲其他地区，并称只有美国方面停止向乌克兰提供武器，才有可能和平解决这场冲突。
在2月29日长达两小时、创下时长新纪录的国情咨文讲话中，普京聚焦民生问题，多次强调俄罗斯应解决人口问题、促进经济发展、实现技术独立。
translation:
Putin's current term as President of Russia will end on May 7, 2024. According to the Russian constitution, Putin can seek re-election for two terms until 2036 after this term ends.
At the Heroes of the Motherland Day award ceremony in December 2023, Putin announced that he would participate in the 2024 presidential election. At that time, Artem Zoga, chairman of the People's Committee of the "Donetsk People's Republic", talked with Putin after the ceremony and said that the entire Donbas region hopes that Putin will participate in the election. Putin responded: "I had different ideas at different times, but now the moment has come when I have to make a decision. I will run for president of Russia."
In this Russian election, Putin is the only presidential candidate running as an independent candidate. Some analysts believe that Putin has run as an independent candidate in three of his four elections. This approach will help him shape his image as a representative of all Russia, rather than just representing a certain party.
As in previous elections, Putin will not participate in pre-election debates on television and radio programs. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that Putin is the current head of state and has a very busy schedule, which makes him fundamentally different from other candidates. The president himself appears in the media every day, and Russians have a daily opportunity to see what Putin has to say about all aspects of life.
Although he did not participate in the pre-election debates, Putin frequently appeared in various domestic activities before the Russian election. After announcing his candidacy, at the end of 2023, Putin held his first "live connection" event and annual press conference since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict. In more than 4 hours, he answered about 80 questions from the Russian people and domestic and foreign reporters. The content covered is very wide. At the event, Putin pointed out that the Russian economy had recovered from the downward trend, emphasized that the goals of Russia's "special military operations" had not changed, and also mentioned the need for Russia to return to traditional values.
After entering 2024, Putin’s domestic itinerary is relatively intensive. From the Chukotka Autonomous Region in Russia’s Far East, which he has never visited before, to the enclave of Kaliningrad in western Russia, Putin talked about the regional economy during his visits to many places. Development, social security and other livelihood issues, and visited a number of industrial enterprises including Ural Vagon Zavod (one of the largest military equipment developers and manufacturers in Russia) and Kazan Aviation Plant to understand the business operations of the enterprises.
In early February, Putin accepted an exclusive interview with American journalist Tucker Carlson. This was Putin's first one-on-one interview with Western media since the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in February 2022. In an interview, he emphasized that Russia would not expand the Russia-Ukraine conflict to other parts of Europe, and said that only if the United States stops providing weapons to Ukraine can a peaceful solution to the conflict be possible.
In his two-hour State of the Union address on February 29, which set a new record in length, Putin focused on people's livelihood issues and repeatedly emphasized that Russia should solve population problems, promote economic development, and achieve technological independence.
input:
Putin's current term as President of Russia will end on May 7, 2024. According to the Russian constitution, Putin can seek re-election for two terms until 2036 after this term ends.
At the Heroes of the Motherland Day award ceremony in December 2023, Putin announced that he would participate in the 2024 presidential election. At that time, Artem Zoga, chairman of the People's Committee of the "Donetsk People's Republic", talked with Putin after the ceremony and said that the entire Donbas region hopes that Putin will participate in the election. Putin responded: "I had different ideas at different times, but now the moment has come when I have to make a decision. I will run for president of Russia."
In this Russian election, Putin is the only presidential candidate running as an independent candidate. Some analysts believe that Putin has run as an independent candidate in three of his four elections. This approach will help him shape his image as a representative of all Russia, rather than just representing a certain party.
As in previous elections, Putin will not participate in pre-election debates on television and radio programs. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that Putin is the current head of state and has a very busy schedule, which makes him fundamentally different from other candidates. The president himself appears in the media every day, and Russians have a daily opportunity to see what Putin has to say about all aspects of life.
Although he did not participate in the pre-election debates, Putin frequently appeared in various domestic activities before the Russian election. After announcing his candidacy, at the end of 2023, Putin held his first "live connection" event and annual press conference since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict. In more than 4 hours, he answered about 80 questions from the Russian people and domestic and foreign reporters. The content covered is very wide. At the event, Putin pointed out that the Russian economy had recovered from the downward trend, emphasized that the goals of Russia's "special military operations" had not changed, and also mentioned the need for Russia to return to traditional values.
After entering 2024, Putin’s domestic itinerary is relatively intensive. From the Chukotka Autonomous Region in Russia’s Far East, which he has never visited before, to the enclave of Kaliningrad in western Russia, Putin talked about the regional economy during his visits to many places. Development, social security and other livelihood issues, and visited a number of industrial enterprises including Ural Vagon Zavod (one of the largest military equipment developers and manufacturers in Russia) and Kazan Aviation Plant to understand the business operations of the enterprises.
In early February, Putin accepted an exclusive interview with American journalist Tucker Carlson. This was Putin's first one-on-one interview with Western media since the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in February 2022. In an interview, he emphasized that Russia would not expand the Russia-Ukraine conflict to other parts of Europe, and said that only if the United States stops providing weapons to Ukraine can a peaceful solution to the conflict be possible.
In his two-hour State of the Union address on February 29, which set a new record in length, Putin focused on people's livelihood issues and repeatedly emphasized that Russia should solve population problems, promote economic development, and achieve technological independence.

title: U.S. Says Ready to 'Deal With' Putin Despite 'Unfair' Election - The Moscow Times
content:
The United States said Monday that it recognizes President Vladimir Putin as the leader of Russia and is prepared to deal with him for another six years, while also emphasizing the March 15-17 presidential election was neither free nor fair. 
“Nothing about the election outcome was unpredictable because Putin had closed the political space, had locked up political opponents. Some of his political opponents had tragically died,” White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said at a press briefing. 
Russian election authorities said Monday that Putin won the race with 87.28% of the votes. 
But independent observers and Western leaders have decried the results, pointing to widespread reports of fraud, as well as an unrelenting crackdown on any dissent within Russia that has only worsened since Moscow invaded Ukraine in 2022. 
“There was nothing free or fair about this election, and the outcome was preordained,” Sullivan said, but noted that “the reality is that President Putin is the President of Russia.”
“We’ve had to deal with that reality throughout the war in Ukraine, throughout the other aggression Russia has undertaken, throughout the other steps contrary to U.S. national interests that we have seen from this President and from the Russian Federation under his leadership,” he said. 
“And we will continue to deal with that reality,” Sullivan added.
At the same time, Western leaders have condemned the Kremlin for holding elections in parts of occupied Ukraine that Moscow claims to have annexed.
Putin hailed the results of the 2024 presidential campaign as evidence that Russian society has thrown its “trust” and “hope” behind what he and the Russian authorities call a “special military operation.”
input:
The United States said Monday that it recognizes President Vladimir Putin as the leader of Russia and is prepared to deal with him for another six years, while also emphasizing the March 15-17 presidential election was neither free nor fair. 
“Nothing about the election outcome was unpredictable because Putin had closed the political space, had locked up political opponents. Some of his political opponents had tragically died,” White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan said at a press briefing. 
Russian election authorities said Monday that Putin won the race with 87.28% of the votes. 
But independent observers and Western leaders have decried the results, pointing to widespread reports of fraud, as well as an unrelenting crackdown on any dissent within Russia that has only worsened since Moscow invaded Ukraine in 2022. 
“There was nothing free or fair about this election, and the outcome was preordained,” Sullivan said, but noted that “the reality is that President Putin is the President of Russia.”
“We’ve had to deal with that reality throughout the war in Ukraine, throughout the other aggression Russia has undertaken, throughout the other steps contrary to U.S. national interests that we have seen from this President and from the Russian Federation under his leadership,” he said. 
“And we will continue to deal with that reality,” Sullivan added.
At the same time, Western leaders have condemned the Kremlin for holding elections in parts of occupied Ukraine that Moscow claims to have annexed.
Putin hailed the results of the 2024 presidential campaign as evidence that Russian society has thrown its “trust” and “hope” behind what he and the Russian authorities call a “special military operation.”

title: Russian voters, answering Navalny’s call, protest as Putin extends his rule to 2030 - The Washington Post
content:
“Pretending that the enemy is weak is a manifestation of your weakness,” he said. “The opponent is strong and smart and can make strong moves.”
Stanislav Andreyshuk, co-chairman of Golos, an independent election watchdog that was declared a foreign agent by Russian authorities, said there had been many reports of apparent ballot stuffing, with bundles of voting papers in the official boxes. He said signs of anomalies also were seen in the turnout data published by the Central Election Commission.
By midafternoon Sunday, Golos mapped more than 1,400 reports of potential violations. The group’s co-chairman, Grigory Melkonyants, is in detention awaiting trial.
In one report to Golos, a state employee in Chechnya, in southern Russia, complained that he and others were bused from one polling station to another to vote multiple times. The employee said he voted seven times in the first two days.
Since taking power on Dec. 31, 1999, Putin has steadily destroyed Russia’s fledgling democracy, curbed rights and crushed dissent. His main political rivals have been jailed, killed or forced to flee the country, while protesters risk long prison terms for criticizing the war or Putin.
Why does Putin always win? What to know about Russia’s pseudo election.
Putin has repeatedly found ways to defy term limits to stay in power, starting in 2008 when he swapped jobs with Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev while remaining the country’s supreme political authority. Four years later, they swapped again. In 2020, Putin engineered constitutional changes that would allow him stay in power until 2036. The term he will claim after this weekend’s vote runs to 2030.
Unlike in Ukraine, which has had five presidents elected during Putin’s time in power, the Russian election offers no democratic choice. The Kremlin blocks genuine opposition candidates from the ballot, controls media coverage and, critics allege, falsifies results.
Independent Russian media, such as Dozhd television, which was shuttered by Russian authorities and now operates from Amsterdam, described the current balloting as a “so-called election.”
Most civil servants and employees of state-owned enterprises were ordered by their managers to vote on Friday and were strongly discouraged from voting on Sunday, according to numerous reports in independent Russian-language media, including Faridaily, the Telegram channel of journalist Farida Rustamova, who said she received hundreds of reports from state employees.
In Russia’s tightly controlled society, even just seeing fellow protesters attend Noon Against Putin felt empowering, Arina said.
“I love the atmosphere here,” she said, “because I feel strong and I’m surrounded by like-minded people, and that’s so rare nowadays. Maybe I will even make new friends today, with people who think like me.”
Her friend Maryana echoed that optimism but said she was also realistic about the slender hope for change.
“I think that today’s protest was a success in that it gave people a bit of a lift. It supports people mentally,” she said. “But of course it won’t affect the authorities in any way.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Как обеспечивается безопасность
В приграничных с Украиной областях выборы проходят на фоне продолжающихся атак дронов. В Белгороде с 12 марта каждый день объявляли ракетную опасность.

В Белгородской, Курской, Ростовской областях и в Крыму избиратели могут проголосовать дистанционно. В Белгородской области на избирательных участках приняты повышенные меры безопасности: в помещениях для голосования имеются указатели «Место для укрытия», окна обложены мешками с песком. В Курской области на участках также усилены меры безопасности.

Губернатор Белгородской области Вячеслав Гладков утром 15 марта сообщил, что более 80% избирателей в девяти приграничных муниципалитетах региона проголосовали досрочно. «В связи с возникновением угрозы жизни и здоровью избирателей» региональный избирком разрешил провести с 10 по 14 марта в девяти приграничных районах области досрочное голосование.
translation:
How security is ensured
In regions bordering Ukraine, elections are being held against the backdrop of ongoing drone attacks. In Belgorod, since March 12, a missile danger was declared every day.

In the Belgorod, Kursk, Rostov regions and Crimea, voters can vote remotely. In the Belgorod region, increased security measures have been taken at polling stations: in the voting premises there are signs “Place for shelter”, the windows are lined with sandbags. In the Kursk region, security measures have also been strengthened at sites.

The governor of the Belgorod region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, reported on the morning of March 15 that more than 80% of voters in nine border municipalities of the region voted early. “Due to a threat to the life and health of voters,” the regional election commission allowed early voting to be held from March 10 to 14 in nine border districts of the region.
input:
How security is ensured
In regions bordering Ukraine, elections are being held against the backdrop of ongoing drone attacks. In Belgorod, since March 12, a missile danger was declared every day.

In the Belgorod, Kursk, Rostov regions and Crimea, voters can vote remotely. In the Belgorod region, increased security measures have been taken at polling stations: in the voting premises there are signs “Place for shelter”, the windows are lined with sandbags. In the Kursk region, security measures have also been strengthened at sites.

The governor of the Belgorod region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, reported on the morning of March 15 that more than 80% of voters in nine border municipalities of the region voted early. “Due to a threat to the life and health of voters,” the regional election commission allowed early voting to be held from March 10 to 14 in nine border districts of the region.

title: В США раскрыли причину ненависти лидеров стран НАТО к Путину
content:
МОСКВА, 4 июня/ Радио Sputnik. Лидеры стран НАТО избегают налаживания отношений с Россией, поскольку в руководстве этих стран нет политиков уровня президента РФ Владимира Путина, считает американский профессор, специалист по международным отношениям Майкл Бреннер.
«
"Путин явно превосходит их (западных лидеров, – ред.) по уровню интеллекта и знаниям, он имеет широкий кругозор и глубокие познания в различных темах. А (президент США Джо) Байден, к примеру, с трудом может связать три предложения. Путин обладает превосходными дипломатическими и политическими навыками. Не говоря уже о том, что при нем Россия вернулась на международную арену в роли крупного игрока", – сказал эксперт в интервью YouТube-каналу Dialogue Works.

Бреннер также заявил, что Запад предпочитает избегать прямого контакта с президентом России и испытывает к нему неприязнь еще со времен президентства Барака Обамы.
По его оценкам, в прошлом США и страны Европы проводили больше переговоров с руководством Советского Союза, чем они сейчас проводят с Путиным или с кем-либо еще в России. По его словам, такая ситуация может привести "к плачевным последствиям".
translation:
MOSCOW, June 4/ Radio Sputnik. The leaders of NATO countries avoid establishing relations with Russia, since the leadership of these countries does not have politicians of the level of Russian President Vladimir Putin, says American professor and international relations specialist Michael Brenner.
"
"Putin clearly surpasses them (Western leaders - ed.) in intelligence and knowledge, he has a broad outlook and deep knowledge in various topics. And (US President Joe) Biden, for example, can hardly connect three sentences. Putin has excellent diplomatic and political skills. Not to mention the fact that under him Russia returned to the international arena as a major player,” the expert said in an interview with the Dialogue Works YouTube channel.

Brenner also said that the West prefers to avoid direct contact with the Russian president and has disliked him since the presidency of Barack Obama.
He estimates that in the past the United States and European countries have held more talks with the leadership of the Soviet Union than they currently hold with Putin or anyone else in Russia. According to him, such a situation could lead “to disastrous consequences.”
input:
MOSCOW, June 4/ Radio Sputnik. The leaders of NATO countries avoid establishing relations with Russia, since the leadership of these countries does not have politicians of the level of Russian President Vladimir Putin, says American professor and international relations specialist Michael Brenner.
"
"Putin clearly surpasses them (Western leaders - ed.) in intelligence and knowledge, he has a broad outlook and deep knowledge in various topics. And (US President Joe) Biden, for example, can hardly connect three sentences. Putin has excellent diplomatic and political skills. Not to mention the fact that under him Russia returned to the international arena as a major player,” the expert said in an interview with the Dialogue Works YouTube channel.

Brenner also said that the West prefers to avoid direct contact with the Russian president and has disliked him since the presidency of Barack Obama.
He estimates that in the past the United States and European countries have held more talks with the leadership of the Soviet Union than they currently hold with Putin or anyone else in Russia. According to him, such a situation could lead “to disastrous consequences.”

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content:
Зато хватало скандалов и нарушений. Наблюдатели и оппозиционеры зафиксировали сотни нарушений по всей стране - от вбросов бюллетеней и "каруселей" до давления на избирателей и фальсификаций протоколов. Особенно жаркая обстановка была в Москве и Питере, где полиция жестко задерживала участников протестных акций, а некоторые горячие головы даже нападали на избирательные участки.

По поводу фальсификаций. Привожу расчеты аналитиков, которые сделаны по методу математика Сергея Шпилькина. Они оценили долю «аномальных» голосов на прошедших выборах и утверждают, что Путин получил не меньше 31,6 млн голосов с помощью фальсификаций. А это примерно половина голосов избирателей. Они утверждают, что фальсификаций было настолько много, что область «честных» голосов статистическими методами выделить практически невозможно (листайте фото).
Впрочем вряд ли эти доводы примут во внимание. Ну вы, конечно, поняли.
translation:
But there were plenty of scandals and violations. Observers and oppositionists have recorded hundreds of violations throughout the country - from ballot stuffing and “carousels” to pressure on voters and falsification of protocols. The situation was especially hot in Moscow and St. Petersburg, where the police harshly detained protest participants, and some hotheads even attacked polling stations.

Regarding falsifications. I present the calculations of analysts, which were made using the method of mathematician Sergei Shpilkin. They estimated the share of “anomalous” votes in the last elections and claim that Putin received at least 31.6 million votes through fraud. And this is approximately half of the votes. They claim that there was so much falsification that it is almost impossible to identify the area of “honest” votes using statistical methods (scroll through the photo).
However, these arguments are unlikely to be taken into account. Well, of course, you understand.
input:
But there were plenty of scandals and violations. Observers and oppositionists have recorded hundreds of violations throughout the country - from ballot stuffing and “carousels” to pressure on voters and falsification of protocols. The situation was especially hot in Moscow and St. Petersburg, where the police harshly detained protest participants, and some hotheads even attacked polling stations.

Regarding falsifications. I present the calculations of analysts, which were made using the method of mathematician Sergei Shpilkin. They estimated the share of “anomalous” votes in the last elections and claim that Putin received at least 31.6 million votes through fraud. And this is approximately half of the votes. They claim that there was so much falsification that it is almost impossible to identify the area of “honest” votes using statistical methods (scroll through the photo).
However, these arguments are unlikely to be taken into account. Well, of course, you understand.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
据俄罗斯媒体分析报道，2023年，俄国防工业和其他与军队需求相关行业的生产同比增长了35%，涉及军事基建和重建的建筑业增长率也达到15%。如此大规模的战争经济扩张自然将乡村地区牵入。从2022年底开始，A村里不断有人离开家，成为军工生产的工人，或者到新占领的地区加入建筑施工队。
但所谓战争让俄罗斯“经济过热”似乎更多是一种困境中的戏谑，一种不幸中的万幸。至少在俄主要城市，西方施加的制裁影响是显而易见的。外国品牌纷纷离去，公司和个人的跨国金融交易都受到严重影响。在普通人中间，尼基塔原先的同事们就是受到冲击最大的人群之一。
2022年以来的西方制裁主要是对准俄罗斯中产或更富有的人，意在分化俄精英层和殷实中产阶级的凝聚力。比如，中高收入阶层不能去欧美旅游的制裁。赴欧美的留学生被遣返、中断学业的现象普遍发生。原来有志于赴西方留学的俄罗斯年轻人今年以来已失去了申请的资格。
然而，在像A村这样的地方，这种力度不可谓不强的措施似乎带来了某种反效果：
“现在那些莫斯科的有钱人不能动不动带家人孩子往国外跑了吧！”“是啊，俄罗斯有什么不好的，非要跑到敌人那里去？”“去巴黎、伦敦度假购物难道不算资敌吗？”这些是街头巷尾常常可以听到的议论。
尼基塔发现不能用自己此前所在圈子的遭遇来试图取得新邻居的理解。而且时间长了，他也认为，抛开这些评论中夹杂的沙文主义和民族主义的东西，邻居们的观点并非全然无稽。
“其实不得不承认，所谓的都市精英们在战前是很格格不入的。他们，不，是我们，”尼基塔发出有些羞涩的笑声，仓促改变了主语，“总是购买西方品牌，去西方度假，使用西方网站，和西方人打交道，仿佛忘记了俄罗斯还有乡村的存在。但现在，似乎大家又被拉到了一块儿，使用同样品牌的产品，看同样的电视节目，在同一片土地上忙碌和休息。也就是说，在村民们眼中，战争让俄罗斯终于变得更像俄罗斯了。”
俄罗斯堡垒
一场战争带来如此令人始料未及的作用，未免有些荒诞和讽刺，交战双方的战略分析者们或许都会对此感到意外。然而，在广袤的俄罗斯国土上，A村的情况远非意料之外的偶然，相反，它仅是千千万万个地处俄罗斯腹地的小村镇的缩影。
translation:
According to Russian media analysis reports, in 2023, the production of the Russian defense industry and other industries related to military needs will increase by 35% year-on-year, and the growth rate of the construction industry involving military infrastructure and reconstruction will also reach 15%. Such a large-scale war economic expansion naturally involves rural areas. Starting from the end of 2022, people in Village A have been leaving their homes to become workers in military production, or to join construction teams in newly occupied areas.
But the so-called "economic overheating" of Russia due to the war seems to be more of a joke in a difficult situation, a blessing in misfortune. At least in major Russian cities, the impact of sanctions imposed by the West is obvious. Foreign brands have left one after another, and cross-border financial transactions of companies and individuals have been severely affected. Among ordinary people, Nikita's former colleagues were among the most affected.
Western sanctions since 2022 have mainly targeted the Russian middle class or wealthier people, aiming to divide the cohesion between the Russian elite and the wealthy middle class. For example, middle- and high-income people are prohibited from traveling to Europe and the United States. It is common for international students going to Europe and the United States to be deported and have their studies interrupted. Young Russians who originally wanted to study in the West have lost their qualifications to apply this year.
However, in places like Village A, this rather strong measure seems to have had some counter-effects:
"Now those rich people in Moscow can't just take their families and children abroad!" "Yeah, what's so bad about Russia that they have to go to the enemy?" "Isn't going to Paris and London a holiday shopping trip? To support the enemy?" These are comments that can often be heard on the streets.
Nikita found that she could not use the experience of her previous circle to try to gain the understanding of her new neighbors. And as time went by, he also believed that, aside from the jingoism and nationalism mixed in these comments, the neighbors’ views were not entirely unfounded.
"Actually, I have to admit that the so-called urban elites were very out of place before the war. They, no, it was us," Nikita let out a shy laugh and hastily changed the subject, "Always buy Western brands, go When we go on vacation in the West, use Western websites, and interact with Westerners, we seem to have forgotten that there is still a countryside in Russia. But now, it seems that everyone is brought together again, using the same brand of products, watching the same TV programs, and in the same land. "Business and rest. In other words, in the eyes of the villagers, the war finally made Russia more like Russia."
russian fortress
It is somewhat absurd and ironic that a war has such unexpected effects, and strategic analysts on both sides of the war may be surprised by this. However, in the vast Russian land, the situation in Village A is far from unexpected and accidental. On the contrary, it is just a microcosm of thousands of small villages and towns located in the hinterland of Russia.
input:
According to Russian media analysis reports, in 2023, the production of the Russian defense industry and other industries related to military needs will increase by 35% year-on-year, and the growth rate of the construction industry involving military infrastructure and reconstruction will also reach 15%. Such a large-scale war economic expansion naturally involves rural areas. Starting from the end of 2022, people in Village A have been leaving their homes to become workers in military production, or to join construction teams in newly occupied areas.
But the so-called "economic overheating" of Russia due to the war seems to be more of a joke in a difficult situation, a blessing in misfortune. At least in major Russian cities, the impact of sanctions imposed by the West is obvious. Foreign brands have left one after another, and cross-border financial transactions of companies and individuals have been severely affected. Among ordinary people, Nikita's former colleagues were among the most affected.
Western sanctions since 2022 have mainly targeted the Russian middle class or wealthier people, aiming to divide the cohesion between the Russian elite and the wealthy middle class. For example, middle- and high-income people are prohibited from traveling to Europe and the United States. It is common for international students going to Europe and the United States to be deported and have their studies interrupted. Young Russians who originally wanted to study in the West have lost their qualifications to apply this year.
However, in places like Village A, this rather strong measure seems to have had some counter-effects:
"Now those rich people in Moscow can't just take their families and children abroad!" "Yeah, what's so bad about Russia that they have to go to the enemy?" "Isn't going to Paris and London a holiday shopping trip? To support the enemy?" These are comments that can often be heard on the streets.
Nikita found that she could not use the experience of her previous circle to try to gain the understanding of her new neighbors. And as time went by, he also believed that, aside from the jingoism and nationalism mixed in these comments, the neighbors’ views were not entirely unfounded.
"Actually, I have to admit that the so-called urban elites were very out of place before the war. They, no, it was us," Nikita let out a shy laugh and hastily changed the subject, "Always buy Western brands, go When we go on vacation in the West, use Western websites, and interact with Westerners, we seem to have forgotten that there is still a countryside in Russia. But now, it seems that everyone is brought together again, using the same brand of products, watching the same TV programs, and in the same land. "Business and rest. In other words, in the eyes of the villagers, the war finally made Russia more like Russia."
russian fortress
It is somewhat absurd and ironic that a war has such unexpected effects, and strategic analysts on both sides of the war may be surprised by this. However, in the vast Russian land, the situation in Village A is far from unexpected and accidental. On the contrary, it is just a microcosm of thousands of small villages and towns located in the hinterland of Russia.

title: Putin extends rule in preordained Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era - ABC News
content:
Putin appeared Monday evening on Red Square in the heart of Moscow at a concert to mark the tenth year since he annexed Crimea from Ukraine. Putin’s three token challengers for the presidency appeared on stage beside him and publicly supported him after campaigns in which none of them criticized him.
Putin has led Russia as president or prime minister since December 1999. At the end of his fifth term, he would be the longest-serving Russian leader since Catherine the Great, who ruled during the 18th century.
Emboldened by his sweeping victory, Putin said he planned to carve out a buffer zone in Ukraine to protect Russia from cross-border shelling and attacks. Asked if an open clash could erupt between Russia and NATO, Putin responded curtly by saying: “Everything is possible in today’s world.” He added, “It’s clear to everyone that it will put us a step away from full-scale World War III."
Russian officials said they recruited over 500,000 volunteers for the army last year, but many expect Putin to mobilize more forces to attempt to push deeper into Ukraine. Analysts say that in the post-election period, Russian authorities could also introduce unpopular measures such as raising taxes. 
The Kremlin is now “increasingly confident,” because it has “learned just how passive the population is and how effective their own repression is," said Nigel Gould-Davies, a senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.
Russia’s Central Election Commission said Monday that with all the precincts counted, Putin got 87% of the vote. Central Election Commission chief Ella Pamfilova said that nearly 76 million voters cast their ballots for Putin.
In illegally annexed regions of Ukraine, at least 249 people were detained for refusing to take part in the vote and for criticizing Russian authorities according to the Ukrainian Eastern Human Rights Group.
“Voting in the occupied territories took place literally at gunpoint, when members of election commissions walked from door to door accompanied by military men with weapons,” said Pavlo Lysianskyi, head of the group.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy slammed the election and voting in the illegally annexed regions saying "everything Russia does on the occupied territory of Ukraine is a crime.”

title: 普京刚胜选,给了中方一个明确信号,拜登的指责,看起来荒唐可笑
content:
普京胜选引发中西方关注
3月17日晚8点,在俄罗斯举行的总统选举中,普京以87.21%的高得票率蝉联总统,将开启第五个总统任期。获胜后,普京在竞选总部发表讲话,提到了新任期的规划,对俄乌局势做出展望。分析认为,这次选举结果将深刻影响俄罗斯未来发展走向,尤其是将左右俄罗斯在乌克兰冲突中的立场和未来发展方向。同时,在一连串的表态中,普京还给了中方一个明确的信号,强调俄中关系将继续深化发展。
1、普京胜选的国际影响
俄罗斯大选的结果显示,普京得到了高达87.21%的选票支持,这一结果无疑将引起国际社会的广泛关注。普京胜选意味着俄罗斯政局稳定,这对于国际局势将会有着深远的影响。尤其在当前国际形势下,普京再次掌权将引发中西方的不同看法和对待态度。美西方对中俄联盟的担忧和不安也将会加剧。
translation:
Putin’s victory draws attention from China and the West
At 8 pm on March 17, in the presidential election held in Russia, Putin was re-elected as president with a high vote rate of 87.21%, and will start his fifth presidential term. After his victory, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters, mentioning plans for the new term and looking forward to the situation in Russia and Ukraine. Analysts believe that the results of this election will profoundly affect Russia's future development, especially its stance and future development direction in the Ukrainian conflict. At the same time, in a series of statements, Putin also gave China a clear signal, emphasizing that Russia-China relations will continue to deepen and develop.
1. The international impact of Putin’s victory
The results of the Russian election showed that Putin received as much as 87.21% of the votes. This result will undoubtedly attract widespread attention from the international community. Putin's victory means that Russia's political situation is stable, which will have a profound impact on the international situation. Especially under the current international situation, Putin's return to power will trigger different views and attitudes between China and the West. The US and the West’s concerns and uneasiness about the Sino-Russian alliance will also intensify.

1. The international impact of Putin’s victory

Putin's victory means that Russia's political situation is stable, which will have a profound impact on the international situation. Especially under the current international situation, Putin's return to power will trigger different views and attitudes between China and the West. The US and the West’s concerns and uneasiness about the Sino-Russian alliance will also intensify.

title: Russian election: White House says Putin's victory was 'preordained'
content:
WASHINGTON – The White House said Monday the outcome of Russia’s presidential election was “preordained” and that nothing about the process that handed Vladimir Putin a fifth term in office was “free or fair.”
“Nothing about the election outcome was unpredictable,” said Jake Sullivan, the White House national security adviser.
Sullivan noted Putin had locked up his political opponents and that some had died tragic deaths ahead of this week’s elections. Most prominently, opposition leader Alexei Navalny died last month at an Arctic Circle prison camp.
Still, Putin is Russia’s president, and the U.S. is prepared for another six years of fraught relations, Sullivan said.
“We’ve had to deal with that reality throughout the war in Ukraine, throughout the other aggression Russia has undertaken, throughout the other steps contrary to U.S. national interests that we have seen from this president and from the Russian federation under his leadership,” Sullivan said.
Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide
But, “that reality doesn't deny the fact that this election was not something that met any kind of benchmark of being free or fair,” he said.
Putin gets fifth term:Russia leader declared winner in vote with no credible opposition
Russia's Central Election Commission said Monday that Putin, the country's longest-serving leader since Soviet dictator Josef Stalin, had won by a landslide in an election in which he faced no credible opposition and cracked down on free speech.
With nearly 100% of all precincts counted, Putin received 87.29% of the vote, Central Election Commission chief Ella Pamfilova said. Nearly 76 million voters cast their ballots for Putin, his highest vote tally ever, Pamfilova said.
Putin hailed the results as a clear indication of Russia's "trust" and "hope" in him. But his many critics saw them as another illustration of the preordained nature of the election.
Putin's fiercest political foe, Navalny, died in an Arctic prison last month. Other Putin opponents are either in jail or in exile.
Michael Collins covers the White House. Follow him on X, formerly Twitter, @mcollinsNEWS.
Russian election:Putin hails preordained electoral win as a sign of Russia's 'trust' in him: Updates
'Putin chose this war':Biden vows to make Russian president 'a pariah' after Ukraine invasion

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
content:
Украинские вооруженные формирования в дни выборов продолжили попытки прорваться на российскую территорию, которые они начали еще 12 марта. 16 марта сообщалось о попытках диверсантов прорваться на российскую территорию в районах населенных пунктов Сподарюшино и Козинка. ДРГ заходила с территории Сумской области Украины, все попытки, по официальным данным, были отражены. По бойцам ВСУ отработала российская авиация и артиллерия. Диверсанты потеряли до 30 человек личного состава, а также 3 танка, 2 единицы прочей бронетехники и 2 машины РСЗО.

Пресс-секретарь президента России Дмитрий Песков заявил, что потери ВСУ при попытке вторгнуться в Россию в Белгородской и Курской областях в ночь на 16 марта составили 60-70 процентов.

17 марта руководитель Главного управления разведки (ГУР) Минобороны Украины Кирилл Буданов (внесен в перечень террористов и экстремистов Росфинмониторинга) впервые прокомментировал атаки на приграничные российские регионы, пообещав, что они в ближайшее время продолжатся.

Также 17 марта российские военные сбили вертолет ВСУ, на борту которого могли находиться 20 украинских десантников. Отмечается, что противник планировал высадку в российской Козинке Белгородской области с целью «создания видимости контроля над населенным пунктом».
translation:
During the election days, Ukrainian armed forces continued their attempts to break into Russian territory, which they began on March 12. On March 16, it was reported that saboteurs were attempting to break into Russian territory in the areas of the settlements of Spodaryushino and Kozinka. The DRG entered from the territory of the Sumy region of Ukraine, all attempts, according to official data, were repulsed. Russian aviation and artillery targeted the Ukrainian Armed Forces fighters. The saboteurs lost up to 30 personnel, as well as 3 tanks, 2 other armored vehicles and 2 MLRS vehicles.

Press Secretary of the Russian President Dmitry Peskov said that the losses of the Ukrainian Armed Forces during the attempt to invade Russia in the Belgorod and Kursk regions on the night of March 16 amounted to 60-70 percent.

On March 17, the head of the Main Intelligence Directorate (GUR) of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine, Kirill Budanov (listed as terrorists and extremists by Rosfinmonitoring), commented for the first time on the attacks on Russian border regions, promising that they would continue in the near future.

Also on March 17, the Russian military shot down a Ukrainian Armed Forces helicopter, which could have carried 20 Ukrainian paratroopers. It is noted that the enemy planned a landing in the Russian Kozinka, Belgorod region, with the aim of “creating the appearance of control over the populated area.”
input:
During the election days, Ukrainian armed forces continued their attempts to break into Russian territory, which they began on March 12. On March 16, it was reported that saboteurs were attempting to break into Russian territory in the areas of the settlements of Spodaryushino and Kozinka. The DRG entered from the territory of the Sumy region of Ukraine, all attempts, according to official data, were repulsed. Russian aviation and artillery targeted the Ukrainian Armed Forces fighters. The saboteurs lost up to 30 personnel, as well as 3 tanks, 2 other armored vehicles and 2 MLRS vehicles.

Press Secretary of the Russian President Dmitry Peskov said that the losses of the Ukrainian Armed Forces during the attempt to invade Russia in the Belgorod and Kursk regions on the night of March 16 amounted to 60-70 percent.

On March 17, the head of the Main Intelligence Directorate (GUR) of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine, Kirill Budanov (listed as terrorists and extremists by Rosfinmonitoring), commented for the first time on the attacks on Russian border regions, promising that they would continue in the near future.

Also on March 17, the Russian military shot down a Ukrainian Armed Forces helicopter, which could have carried 20 Ukrainian paratroopers. It is noted that the enemy planned a landing in the Russian Kozinka, Belgorod region, with the aim of “creating the appearance of control over the populated area.”

title: Putin’s vote share nears outer limits but still the only way is up | Vladimir Putin | The Guardian
content:
Vladimir Putin is approaching the electoral outer limits. Claiming a record landslide on Sunday of 87.28% of the vote on a 77.44% turnout, Putin has launched himself into the stratosphere of post-Soviet election results.
It is a mathematical axiom for any president-for-life: support should never go down, only up; turnout should never go down, only up. And as Putin’s one-man rule extends past a quarter of a century, Russian officials retain straight faces even as they post astronomical numbers that would make many convinced autocrats blush.
The Russian president is now enshrined in the firmament with the late autocrats Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan and Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan, whose personality cult regimes were backed up by carefully controlled electoral landslides in the high 80s and low 90s right up until their deaths.
Yet Putin can still go further, into full orbit with men such as Kazakhstan’s Nursultan Nazarbayev, who posted above 95% in his last two elections, or Turkmenistan’s Gurbanguly Berdymukhamedov, who won more than 97% in his own last two elections.
The record holder is Saparmurat Niyazov, the Turkmenistan leader who won 99.5% of a 1992 vote.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Как проходило голосование
В онлайн-голосовании в 28 регионах (без Москвы), по данным Минцифры, приняли участие 94% зарегистрированных на ДЭГ избирателей. Голоса онлайн отдали 4,499 млн человек.
В Москве, по предварительным данным, явка превысила 66%, сообщает Мосгоризбирком. При этом 47,9% зарегистрированных в городе избирателей (3,666 млн человек) голосовали дистанционно.
В Санкт-Петербурге на 18:00 мск явка составила 69,87%.
Самая высокая явка в Чечне: там к 18:00 мск проголосовали 96,46% избирателей. Самая низкая — в Алтайском крае (51,65%).
По данным на 18:00 мск, за рубежом проголосовали более 249 тыс. россиян, сообщил МИД.
translation:
How did the voting take place?
According to the Ministry of Digital Development, 94% of voters registered on the DEG took part in online voting in 28 regions (excluding Moscow). 4.499 million people cast their votes online.
In Moscow, according to preliminary data, turnout exceeded 66%, the Moscow City Election Commission reports. At the same time, 47.9% of registered voters in the city (3.666 million people) voted remotely.
In St. Petersburg at 18:00 Moscow time the turnout was 69.87%.
The highest turnout was in Chechnya: by 18:00 Moscow time, 96.46% of voters had voted. The lowest is in the Altai Territory (51.65%).
As of 18:00 Moscow time, more than 249 thousand Russians voted abroad, the Foreign Ministry reported.
input:
How did the voting take place?
According to the Ministry of Digital Development, 94% of voters registered on the DEG took part in online voting in 28 regions (excluding Moscow). 4.499 million people cast their votes online.
In Moscow, according to preliminary data, turnout exceeded 66%, the Moscow City Election Commission reports. At the same time, 47.9% of registered voters in the city (3.666 million people) voted remotely.
In St. Petersburg at 18:00 Moscow time the turnout was 69.87%.
The highest turnout was in Chechnya: by 18:00 Moscow time, 96.46% of voters had voted. The lowest is in the Altai Territory (51.65%).
As of 18:00 Moscow time, more than 249 thousand Russians voted abroad, the Foreign Ministry reported.

title: 普京：任何内部或外部干涉俄罗斯选举的企图都将受到抵制
content:
据《参考消息》援引俄罗斯《消息报》网站11月15日报道，俄罗斯总统普京15日在莫斯科郊外的官邸与中央选举委员会成员举行会议。普京在会上表示，任何干涉俄罗斯选举的企图都将受到抵制。
普京说：“至于国家行动，我们将继续尽一切努力，排除任何非法干涉选举进程的行为。”
普京同时强调，“来自外部和内部干涉的企图以及对选举进程施加的压力”都将受到抵制。
普京 澎湃影像 图

此前，普京于当地时间11月14日签署总统选举法修正案，该修正案规定禁止使用所有被冻结的资源进行竞选活动。据央视新闻报道，俄罗斯联邦委员会宪法委员会第一副主席弗拉基米尔·波莱塔耶夫在解释新的修正案时表示，根据俄罗斯联邦中央选举委员会与俄罗斯国防部的协商结果，处于战时状态的俄罗斯联邦主体仍旧可以进行选举投票。而对于俄罗斯海外选民，俄驻外大使馆负责人可以视情况改变投票的开始、结束和持续时间。
根据俄罗斯方面消息，俄罗斯总统选举预计将于2024年3月17日举行。俄罗斯联邦委员会（议会上院）将于2023年12月正式确定选举日期，之后各政党将召开选前会议并正式提名候选人。
此前有消息人士透露称，普京已决定参加明年3月的大选，普京的顾问已经开始为大选做准备，预计将很快宣布这一消息。但俄罗斯总统新闻秘书、克宫发言人佩斯科夫回应称，普京尚未就是否参加2024年总统选举发表任何声明，竞选活动本身也尚未正式宣布。
translation:
According to a report by Reference News citing the Russian "Izvestia" website on November 15, Russian President Vladimir Putin held a meeting with members of the Central Election Commission at his official residence outside Moscow on the 15th. Putin said at the meeting that any attempt to interfere in Russia's elections would be resisted.
"As for state action, we will continue to make every effort to rule out any illegal interference in the electoral process," Putin said.
Putin also stressed that "attempts from external and internal interference and pressure on the electoral process" will be resisted.
Putin The Paper Image Pictures

Previously, Putin signed an amendment to the Presidential Election Law on November 14, local time, which prohibited the use of all frozen resources for campaign activities. According to CCTV News, First Vice Chairman of the Constitutional Committee of the Russian Federation Council Vladimir Poletaev said when explaining the new amendment that according to the results of negotiations between the Central Election Committee of the Russian Federation and the Russian Ministry of Defense, in wartime Subjects of the Russian Federation can still vote in elections. For Russian overseas voters, the head of the Russian embassy abroad can change the start, end and duration of voting depending on the situation.
According to Russian news, the Russian presidential election is expected to be held on March 17, 2024. The Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament) will officially set the election date in December 2023, after which political parties will hold pre-election meetings and formally nominate candidates.
Earlier, sources revealed that Putin has decided to participate in the general election in March next year. Putin's advisers have begun preparing for the election and are expected to announce the news soon. However, Russian Presidential Press Secretary and Kremlin Palace Spokesperson Peskov responded that Putin has not made any statement on whether to participate in the 2024 presidential election, and the campaign itself has not yet been officially announced.

Previously, Putin signed an amendment to the Presidential Election Law on November 14, local time, which prohibited the use of all frozen resources for campaign activities. According to CCTV News, First Vice Chairman of the Constitutional Committee of the Russian Federation Council Vladimir Poletaev said when explaining the new amendment that according to the results of negotiations between the Central Election Committee of the Russian Federation and the Russian Ministry of Defense, in wartime Subjects of the Russian Federation can still vote in elections. For Russian overseas voters, the head of the Russian embassy abroad can change the start, end and duration of voting depending on the situation.
According to Russian news, the Russian presidential election is expected to be held on March 17, 2024. The Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament) will officially set the election date in December 2023, after which political parties will hold pre-election meetings and formally nominate candidates.
Earlier, sources revealed that Putin has decided to participate in the general election in March next year. Putin's advisers have begun preparing for the election and are expected to announce the news soon. However, Russian Presidential Press Secretary and Kremlin Palace Spokesperson Peskov responded that Putin has not made any statement on whether to participate in the 2024 presidential election, and the campaign itself has not yet been officially announced.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
content:
В Государственной Думе захотели ужесточить наказание за попытку сорвать выборы (следующие президентские выборы пройдут через шесть лет, в 2030 году). В частности, депутат Яна Лантратова заявила, что законодатели в ближайшее время разработают новую редакцию соответствующей статьи Уголовного кодекса. Новые положения закона можно было бы применять в отношении лиц, признанных виновными в попытке срыва выборов общественно опасным способом или действовавших в интересах иностранных государств, пояснила она.

На границе продолжались попытки прорыва диверсантов ВСУ
Украинские военные в дни проведения выборов существенно увеличили число обстрелов приграничных российских регионов. В частности, только 17 марта губернатор Белгородской области Вячеслав Гладков сообщил, что в результате атак Вооруженных сил Украины (ВСУ) в Белгороде разрушения были выявлены в 36 квартирах и 9 частных домовладениях, а также в трех хозяйственных субъектах.

«К большому сожалению, есть погибший... 11 человек получили ранения различной степени тяжести. 8 человек находятся в городской больнице №2», — сообщил он.

Также в Белгороде 15 марта из-за ракетной опасности пришедшим голосовать россиянам пришлось покинуть избирательный участок и спуститься в укрытие, рассказал журналистам очевидец. После отмены ракетной опасности люди вернулись и продолжили голосовать.
translation:
The State Duma wanted to toughen the punishment for trying to disrupt the elections (the next presidential elections will be held in six years, in 2030). In particular, deputy Yana Lantratova said that legislators will soon develop a new edition of the relevant article of the Criminal Code. The new provisions of the law could be applied to persons found guilty of attempting to disrupt elections in a socially dangerous manner or acting in the interests of foreign states, she explained.

Attempts to break through the Ukrainian Armed Forces saboteurs continued at the border
During the election days, the Ukrainian military significantly increased the number of attacks on Russian border regions. In particular, only on March 17, the governor of the Belgorod region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, reported that as a result of attacks by the Armed Forces of Ukraine (AFU) in Belgorod, destruction was detected in 36 apartments and 9 private households, as well as in three business entities.

“Unfortunately, there is a fatality... 11 people were injured of varying degrees of severity. 8 people are in city hospital No. 2,” he said.

Also in Belgorod on March 15, due to the missile threat, Russians who came to vote had to leave the polling station and go down to the shelter, an eyewitness told reporters. After the missile threat was lifted, people returned and continued voting.
input:
The State Duma wanted to toughen the punishment for trying to disrupt the elections (the next presidential elections will be held in six years, in 2030). In particular, deputy Yana Lantratova said that legislators will soon develop a new edition of the relevant article of the Criminal Code. The new provisions of the law could be applied to persons found guilty of attempting to disrupt elections in a socially dangerous manner or acting in the interests of foreign states, she explained.

Attempts to break through the Ukrainian Armed Forces saboteurs continued at the border
During the election days, the Ukrainian military significantly increased the number of attacks on Russian border regions. In particular, only on March 17, the governor of the Belgorod region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, reported that as a result of attacks by the Armed Forces of Ukraine (AFU) in Belgorod, destruction was detected in 36 apartments and 9 private households, as well as in three business entities.

“Unfortunately, there is a fatality... 11 people were injured of varying degrees of severity. 8 people are in city hospital No. 2,” he said.

Also in Belgorod on March 15, due to the missile threat, Russians who came to vote had to leave the polling station and go down to the shelter, an eyewitness told reporters. After the missile threat was lifted, people returned and continued voting.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜普京获近九成选票，胜选后抨击美式民主
content:
普京：俄在线投票透明且绝对客观
在18日凌晨选举初步结果公布后，普京在竞选总部发表讲话，感谢所有选民的支持。他表示，俄罗斯是一个大家庭，本次选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望，国家的所有任务都将完成。俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展，变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。
在胜选讲话中，普京还驳斥了西方国家对此次选举的批评，并告诉他的支持者，这是“意料之中的”。
“你想要什么，让他们为我们鼓掌？他们正在武装冲突中与我们作战……他们的目标是遏制我们的发展。当然，他们已经准备好说什么。”普京说。
普京在接受记者提问时称赞俄罗斯的总统竞选比美国先进得多，并指出俄罗斯使用了在线投票，俄官员们称在线投票在2024年俄罗斯总统选举中吸引了800万选民。
“这是透明且绝对客观的。”他“建议”道，“不像美国的邮寄投票……你可以花10美元购买一张选票。”
当被问及俄罗斯和北约之间是否有可能爆发全面冲突时，普京回答说，他认为当今世界“一切皆有可能”。
普京表示，“每个人都清楚，距离第三次世界大战全面爆发只有一步之遥。我认为几乎没有人会对此感兴趣。”他补充称，北约军事人员已经在乌克兰，我们已经在战场上听到有人说英语和法语，“这样做没有什么好处，尤其是对他们而言，因为他们正在那里死去，大量地死去。”
在回应法国总统马克龙此前称“将要求俄在奥运期间停火”的言论时，普京表示，“我不了解法国总统的言论。我们准备考虑任何提议，但在任何情况下，我们都将从俄罗斯的利益出发。” 
普京指出，俄罗斯已经准备并愿意通过谈判和平解决俄乌冲突，但前提是基辅希望与俄罗斯建立友好睦邻关系，而不是获得时间重新武装遭受重创的乌克兰军队。普京称，他正在确保俄边境免受亲乌克兰武装组织最近袭击的影响，并表示他作为俄罗斯总统的主要任务将是在俄乌冲突中“加强国防能力和（俄罗斯）军队” 。
普京还在记者会上表示，他将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。他说，国家发展的所有主要任务都已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述，将竭尽所能完成既定目标。
普京：本已批准用纳瓦利内换囚
值得注意的是，普京还在记者会上首次对俄罗斯反对派人士纳瓦利内之死一事作出回应。普京称，在纳瓦利内于2024年2月16日在狱中去世前不久，他已批准用纳瓦利内换取西方国家释放俄罗斯籍囚犯。
普京说，“我同意了，但有一个条件：我们交换他，而且他不会回来。不幸的是，已发生的事情确实是发生了，但这就是命。”
translation:
Putin: Russian online voting is transparent and absolutely objective
After the preliminary results of the election were announced in the early morning of the 18th, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters and thanked all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
In his victory speech, Putin also dismissed Western criticism of the election, telling his supporters that this was "expected."
"What do you want, for them to applaud us? They are fighting us in an armed conflict... Their goal is to contain our development. Of course, they are ready to say something," Putin said.
When asked by reporters, Putin praised Russia's presidential campaign as being much more advanced than the United States and pointed out that Russia used online voting, which Russian officials said attracted 8 million voters in the 2024 Russian presidential election.
"This is transparent and absolutely objective." He "suggested", "Unlike mail-in voting in the United States... you can buy a ballot for $10."
Asked whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO was possible, Putin responded that he believed "anything is possible" in today's world.
Putin said, "Everyone knows that we are only one step away from the outbreak of full-scale World War III. I think almost no one will be interested in this." He added that NATO military personnel are already in Ukraine and we are already on the battlefield. Someone was heard speaking in English and French, "It would do no good, especially for them, because they are dying there, dying in large numbers."
In response to French President Macron's previous remarks that he would ask Russia for a ceasefire during the Olympics, Putin said, "I am not aware of the French President's remarks. We are ready to consider any proposal, but in any case, we will start from Russia." based on interests.”
Putin pointed out that Russia is ready and willing to peacefully resolve the Russian-Ukrainian conflict through negotiations, but only if Kyiv hopes to establish friendly and good-neighborly relations with Russia rather than gain time to rearm the battered Ukrainian army. Putin said he was securing Russia's borders against recent attacks by pro-Ukrainian armed groups and said his main task as Russian president would be to "strengthen defense capabilities and the (Russian) military" in the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
Putin also said at the press conference that he will continue to promote national development in the new term. He said that all major tasks for national development have been spelled out in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of Parliament and that every effort will be made to achieve the set goals.
Putin: Already approved the prisoner exchange for Navalny
It is worth noting that Putin also responded to the death of Russian opposition figure Navalny for the first time at a press conference. Putin said that shortly before Navalny died in prison on February 16, 2024, he had approved the exchange of Navalny for the release of Russian prisoners in Western countries.
"I agreed, but on one condition: we exchange him and he will not come back. Unfortunately, what happened happened, but that's life," Putin said.
