title: Путин набрал рекордные 87,29% голосов после обработки почти 100% протоколов
content:
Действующий глава государства, самовыдвиженец Владимир Путин побеждает на выборах президента России и набирает 87,29% голосов после обработки почти 100% протоколов. Об этом сообщает Центральная избирательная комиссия (ЦИК) РФ.

«Это рекордный показатель», — отметила глава комиссии Элла Памфилова в ходе брифинга.

Путина уже поздравили президент Венесуэлы Николас Мадуро и лидер КНДР Ким Чен Ын.

Президентские выборы в России проходили с 15 по 17 марта 2024 года. Явка в ряде регионов превысила 90%. Особое мужество проявили жители Белгородской области — люди не побоялись прийти на участки, несмотря на обстрелы со стороны Украины и попытки прорыва через границу. Явка там тоже очень высокая — выше 80%.

Впервые в истории в выборах президента России приняли участие новые регионы — ЛНР, ДНР, Херсонская и Запорожская области. Несмотря на угрозы со стороны киевского режима, местные жители также проявили мужество, показали хорошую явку и выразили свою гражданскую позицию.
translation:
The current head of state, self-nominated Vladimir Putin, wins the Russian presidential election and gains 87.29% of the votes after processing almost 100% of the protocols. This was reported by the Central Election Commission (CEC) of the Russian Federation.

“This is a record figure,” noted the head of the commission, Ella Pamfilova, during a briefing.

Putin has already been congratulated by Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

The presidential elections in Russia took place from March 15 to March 17, 2024. Turnout in a number of regions exceeded 90%. Residents of the Belgorod region showed particular courage - people were not afraid to come to the polling stations, despite shelling from Ukraine and attempts to break through the border. The turnout there is also very high - above 80%.

For the first time in history, new regions took part in the Russian presidential elections - LPR, DPR, Kherson and Zaporozhye regions. Despite the threats from the Kyiv regime, local residents also showed courage, showed a good turnout and expressed their civic position.
input:
The current head of state, self-nominated Vladimir Putin, wins the Russian presidential election and gains 87.29% of the votes after processing almost 100% of the protocols. This was reported by the Central Election Commission (CEC) of the Russian Federation.

“This is a record figure,” noted the head of the commission, Ella Pamfilova, during a briefing.

Putin has already been congratulated by Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

The presidential elections in Russia took place from March 15 to March 17, 2024. Turnout in a number of regions exceeded 90%. Residents of the Belgorod region showed particular courage - people were not afraid to come to the polling stations, despite shelling from Ukraine and attempts to break through the border. The turnout there is also very high - above 80%.

For the first time in history, new regions took part in the Russian presidential elections - LPR, DPR, Kherson and Zaporozhye regions. Despite the threats from the Kyiv regime, local residents also showed courage, showed a good turnout and expressed their civic position.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
像大多数莫斯科人一样，他的祖父辈曾在苏联旗帜下浴血奋战，留下很多家族传奇。大家庭的成员身上则体现出那个庞大的多民族联盟留下的世界主义印记：俄罗斯人、白俄罗斯人、乌克兰人、鞑靼人、犹太人……都曾走入过这个家庭，这在那个年代也是司空见惯的事。
从小耳濡目染之下，尼基塔对俄罗斯作为多民族国家的一面比较习惯，加之他又有很多国际旅行经验，所以很少去主动谈论和夸耀俄罗斯民族自身的伟大和光荣。
当地时间2024年2月21日，顿涅茨克地区，俄军索马里独立突击营的军人在俄罗斯特种军事行动区接受训练。

按照如今历史课本的描述，从15世纪以来，俄罗斯民族作为基辅罗斯的正统继承者，先后打败了蒙古帝国，吞并喀山汗国、克里米亚汗国、西伯利亚汗国等，向西伯利亚方向扩张，近代又打败拿破仑和希特勒，作为世界上领土面积最大的超级大国，与美国并肩。苏联解体仅是插曲，普京总统正带领俄罗斯重新崛起为新的超级大国。
但在一次外校教师旁听的公开课中，尼基塔不小心犯了个“小错”。讲授早期基辅罗斯历史的时候，他没有按照新版历史教材的说法，淡化来自北欧的维京人对基辅罗斯，乃至之后沙俄历史的影响，而是不经意引用了乌克兰历史和考古学家的说法，用一些乌克兰境内的考古发现佐证维京人对基辅建城的作用。不仅如此，他还提到了波兰-立陶宛文化和基辅罗斯之间的一些联系。
“有两个外校老师提出了反对意见，还跟校长说了这件事。还好校长比较包容，提了一嘴就过去了。”尼基塔苦笑着说。
微妙的变化不只发生在历史课上。
translation:
Like most Muscovites, his grandfathers fought bloody battles under the Soviet flag, leaving behind many family legends. The members of the extended family reflect the cosmopolitan imprint left by that huge multi-ethnic alliance: Russians, Belarusians, Ukrainians, Tatars, Jews... they all once entered this family, which was also true in that era. Commonplace thing.
Having been exposed to it since childhood, Nikita is more accustomed to Russia as a multi-ethnic country. In addition, he has a lot of international travel experience, so he rarely takes the initiative to talk about and boast about the greatness and glory of the Russian nation.
On February 21, 2024 local time, in the Donetsk region, soldiers from the Russian Somali Independent Assault Battalion received training in the Russian Special Military Operations Zone.

According to the description in today’s history textbooks, since the 15th century, the Russian nation, as the orthodox successor of Kievan Rus, has successively defeated the Mongol Empire, annexed the Kazan Khanate, Crimean Khanate, Siberian Khanate, etc., and expanded towards Siberia. , and in modern times defeated Napoleon and Hitler, becoming the world's largest superpower by territorial area, alongside the United States. The collapse of the Soviet Union was just an episode, and President Putin is leading Russia to reemerge as a new superpower.
But in a public class attended by teachers from other schools, Nikita accidentally made a "little mistake." When teaching the history of early Kievan Rus, he did not follow the new version of the history textbook and downplay the influence of the Vikings from Northern Europe on Kievan Rus and even the subsequent history of Tsarist Russia. Instead, he inadvertently quoted Ukrainian history and archaeologists and used the phrase Some archaeological finds in Ukraine support the role of the Vikings in the founding of Kiev. Not only that, he also mentioned some connections between Polish-Lithuanian culture and Kievan Rus.
"Two teachers from other schools raised objections and told the principal about it. Fortunately, the principal was more tolerant and let it pass after he mentioned it." Nikita said with a wry smile.
Subtle changes aren't just happening in history classes.
input:
Like most Muscovites, his grandfathers fought bloody battles under the Soviet flag, leaving behind many family legends. The members of the extended family reflect the cosmopolitan imprint left by that huge multi-ethnic alliance: Russians, Belarusians, Ukrainians, Tatars, Jews... they all once entered this family, which was also true in that era. Commonplace thing.
Having been exposed to it since childhood, Nikita is more accustomed to Russia as a multi-ethnic country. In addition, he has a lot of international travel experience, so he rarely takes the initiative to talk about and boast about the greatness and glory of the Russian nation.
On February 21, 2024 local time, in the Donetsk region, soldiers from the Russian Somali Independent Assault Battalion received training in the Russian Special Military Operations Zone.

According to the description in today’s history textbooks, since the 15th century, the Russian nation, as the orthodox successor of Kievan Rus, has successively defeated the Mongol Empire, annexed the Kazan Khanate, Crimean Khanate, Siberian Khanate, etc., and expanded towards Siberia. , and in modern times defeated Napoleon and Hitler, becoming the world's largest superpower by territorial area, alongside the United States. The collapse of the Soviet Union was just an episode, and President Putin is leading Russia to reemerge as a new superpower.
But in a public class attended by teachers from other schools, Nikita accidentally made a "little mistake." When teaching the history of early Kievan Rus, he did not follow the new version of the history textbook and downplay the influence of the Vikings from Northern Europe on Kievan Rus and even the subsequent history of Tsarist Russia. Instead, he inadvertently quoted Ukrainian history and archaeologists and used the phrase Some archaeological finds in Ukraine support the role of the Vikings in the founding of Kiev. Not only that, he also mentioned some connections between Polish-Lithuanian culture and Kievan Rus.
"Two teachers from other schools raised objections and told the principal about it. Fortunately, the principal was more tolerant and let it pass after he mentioned it." Nikita said with a wry smile.
Subtle changes aren't just happening in history classes.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
content:
根据新华社消息，俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃21日正式宣布俄总统选举结果，俄现任总统普京在选举中获胜。帕姆菲洛娃表示，2024年俄罗斯总统选举的最终投票率为77.49%，普京的最终得票率为 87.28%，获得76277708张选票。（哈里托诺夫4.31%，达万科夫3.85%，斯卢茨基3.2%）根据俄罗斯宪法，普京将执政至2030年，此后若再度胜选，则可连任至2036年。
投票结束后的初步数据显示，在普京支持率最高的前十个地区之中，其得票率均超过90%。克里米亚以及顿涅茨克、卢甘斯克、扎波罗热三个“新地区”也进入了普京支持率前十的地区名单。在赫尔松，普京的支持率也达到了88.12%。有俄媒观察称，除首次举行大选投票的地区外，普京几乎在全部地区都实现了对自己2018年大选成绩的超越，唯一未出现增长态势的地区是海外。今年，72.3%的海外俄选民投票支持普京。六年前，这一数据为85.02%。
2024年大选中，超七成的投票率与普京近九成的得票率均在俄大选的历史上创下新纪录。有俄学者认为，这与俄社会渴求胜利的集体情绪、高涨的爱国主义情绪、对发展的需求与期待、希望以强硬姿态应对西方施压等因素有关，同时也与俄政府在此次大选中重视改善选民动员机制、增强动员力度有关。还有分析称，前所未有的投票率与支持率基于持续性的社会整合，而这将赋予普京接下来采取任何行动的“全权”。
translation:
According to Xinhua News Agency, Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced the results of the Russian presidential election on the 21st. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin won the election. Pamfilova said that the final turnout rate for the 2024 Russian presidential election was 77.49%, and Putin's final vote rate was 87.28%, with 76,277,708 votes. (Kharitonov 4.31%, Davankov 3.85%, Slutsky 3.2%) According to the Russian constitution, Putin will be in power until 2030. If he wins the election again, he can be re-elected until 2036.
Preliminary data after the vote showed that among the top ten regions with the highest support for Putin, his vote rates exceeded 90%. Crimea and the three "new regions" of Donetsk, Luhansk and Zaporozhye have also entered the top ten list of regions with Putin's approval rating. In Kherson, Putin's approval rating also reached 88.12%. Some Russian media observed that, except for the areas where general elections were held for the first time, Putin surpassed his 2018 election results in almost all areas. The only area that did not show a growth trend was overseas. This year, 72.3% of Russian voters abroad voted for Putin. Six years ago, this figure was 85.02%.
In the 2024 general election, the turnout rate of over 70% and Putin's vote rate of nearly 90% both set new records in the history of Russian general elections. Some Russian scholars believe that this is related to factors such as Russian society’s collective mood for victory, rising patriotism, demand and expectations for development, and the hope of taking a tough stance in response to Western pressure. It is also related to the Russian government’s decision in this election. It is related to the importance of improving the voter mobilization mechanism and strengthening mobilization efforts. Some analysts say that the unprecedented turnout and support are based on continued social integration, which will give Putin "full power" to take any next action.

title: 俄罗斯人没的选 专家斥普京当选太荒谬 | 俄罗斯大选 | 普京连任 | 选举制度 | 新唐人电视台
content:
虽然普京以压倒性优势，第五度当选俄罗斯总统，但选举结果的合法性却遭到各国的质疑。
尽管普京自称俄罗斯的选举制度透明，但美国表示，这次俄罗斯大选“既不自由也不公正”，因为普京监禁了他的政治对手，并阻止其他人挑战他。
美国国务院副发言人帕特尔：“俄罗斯人民应该拥有一次自由和公正的选举，能够在持有不同政见的候选人中进行选择，不同的观点。俄罗斯人应该像所有人一样获得公正的信息，以帮助他们选择他们想要的领袖，决定国家的未来，但在这种既不自由也不公平的选举中，情况显然并非如此。”
外界普遍认为，在高压环境下，普京的连任并不合法，因为俄罗斯人别无选择。
欧盟外交政策负责人约瑟夫‧博雷尔：“这次选举是基于镇压和恐吓，并在乌克兰被占领土上举行，侵犯了乌克兰的主权。”
德国外交部长贝尔博克：“俄罗斯的选举是一场没有选择的选举。选举过程不仅显示了普京对本国人民的鲁莽行径，也违反了《联合国宪章》。”
俄罗斯问题专家指出，普京当局是将荒谬的选举数据强加给了俄罗斯人民。
柏林卡内基俄罗斯问题专家舒尔曼：“我认为俄罗斯人是很难承认这样的结果的，但俄罗斯当局公布如此荒谬的数据，极大‘帮助’了人们做出艰难抉择。”
translation:
Although Putin was elected president of Russia for the fifth time with an overwhelming advantage, the legitimacy of the election results has been questioned by various countries.
Despite Putin's claims that Russia's electoral system is transparent, the United States said the Russian election was "neither free nor fair" as he jailed his political opponents and prevented others from challenging him.
U.S. State Department Deputy Spokesperson Patel: "The Russian people deserve a free and fair election and the ability to choose among candidates with different political views, different viewpoints. Russians deserve access to unbiased information, like everyone else, "To help them choose the leader they want to decide the future of their country, but that is clearly not the case in an election that is neither free nor fair."
It is widely believed that in a high-pressure environment, Putin's re-election is not legitimate because Russians have no choice.
EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell: "This election was based on repression and intimidation and was held in occupied Ukrainian territory, violating Ukraine's sovereignty."
German Foreign Minister Berbock: "The election in Russia is an election without choice. The election process not only shows Putin's reckless behavior towards his own people, but also violates the Charter of the United Nations."
Experts on Russia pointed out that the Putin administration imposed ridiculous election data on the Russian people.
Schulman, a Russia expert at Carnegie Berlin: "I think it is difficult for the Russians to admit such a result, but the Russian authorities released such ridiculous data, which greatly 'helped' people make difficult choices."
input:
Although Putin was elected president of Russia for the fifth time with an overwhelming advantage, the legitimacy of the election results has been questioned by various countries.
Despite Putin's claims that Russia's electoral system is transparent, the United States said the Russian election was "neither free nor fair" as he jailed his political opponents and prevented others from challenging him.
U.S. State Department Deputy Spokesperson Patel: "The Russian people deserve a free and fair election and the ability to choose among candidates with different political views, different viewpoints. Russians deserve access to unbiased information, like everyone else, "To help them choose the leader they want to decide the future of their country, but that is clearly not the case in an election that is neither free nor fair."
It is widely believed that in a high-pressure environment, Putin's re-election is not legitimate because Russians have no choice.
EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell: "This election was based on repression and intimidation and was held in occupied Ukrainian territory, violating Ukraine's sovereignty."
German Foreign Minister Berbock: "The election in Russia is an election without choice. The election process not only shows Putin's reckless behavior towards his own people, but also violates the Charter of the United Nations."
Experts on Russia pointed out that the Putin administration imposed ridiculous election data on the Russian people.
Schulman, a Russia expert at Carnegie Berlin: "I think it is difficult for the Russians to admit such a result, but the Russian authorities released such ridiculous data, which greatly 'helped' people make difficult choices."

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
content:
据央视新闻报道，俄罗斯总统选举正式投票于3月15日至17日进行，包括现任总统普京在内的4名候选人参选。此前据新华社报道，俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃2月8日表示，2024年俄总统选举候选人登记工作已完成，届时总统选举的选票上将有包括现任总统普京在内的四名候选人。他们是现任总统普京(以独立候选人身份参选)，斯卢茨基（俄自由民主党），哈里托诺夫（俄联邦共产党）以及达万科夫（俄新人党）。
帕姆菲洛娃表示，作为独立候选人，普京已成功收集了超过30万个支持者签名，议会各政党提名的候选人则根据法律规定免除了这一程序。
根据目前的公开信息，在所有参选者中，来自俄共的哈里托诺夫最年长（75岁），新人党的达万科夫最年轻（40岁）。普京曾4次参与总统大选，哈里托诺夫曾在2004年参与大选，其他两人则是首次参选。除普京外，其他3名候选人均为国家杜马（议会下院）议员，并在杜马内担任一定职务。
根据全俄社会舆论研究中心3月4日公布的民调结果，在1600名通过电话访谈接受民调的18岁以上俄罗斯公民中，70%的受访者表示肯定会参加投票，10%的受访者表示可能参加投票，4%的人表示可能不参加投票，6%的人表示肯定不参加投票。
在计划参加投票的受访者中，75%的人表示将在大选中支持普京，新人党候选人达万科夫以6%的支持率位列第二，俄共候选人哈里托诺夫支持率为4%，另有3%的受访者表示将支持自由民主党候选人斯卢茨基。
translation:
According to CCTV News, official voting for the Russian presidential election was held from March 15 to 17. Four candidates, including current President Putin, ran for the election. Previously, Xinhua News Agency reported that Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said on February 8 that the registration of candidates for the 2024 Russian presidential election has been completed. By then, four candidates, including current President Putin, will be on the presidential election ballot. candidates. They are current President Putin (running as an independent candidate), Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian New People's Party).
Pamfilova said that as an independent candidate, Putin has successfully collected more than 300,000 signatures from supporters, and candidates nominated by various parliamentary parties are exempt from this procedure in accordance with the law.
According to current public information, among all the candidates, Kharitonov from the Russian Communist Party is the oldest (75 years old), and Davankov from the New People's Party is the youngest (40 years old). Putin has participated in the presidential election four times, Kharitonov participated in the election in 2004, and the other two are running for the first time. Except for Putin, the other three candidates are all members of the State Duma (lower house of parliament) and hold certain positions in the Duma.
According to the results of a poll released by the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center on March 4, among 1,600 Russian citizens over the age of 18 who were polled through telephone interviews, 70% of the respondents said they would definitely participate in the vote, and 10% Respondents said they might participate in voting, 4% said they might not participate in voting, and 6% said they would definitely not participate in voting.
Among the respondents who planned to vote, 75% said they would support Putin in the general election. The candidate of the New People's Party Davankov ranked second with 6% support, and the candidate of the Russian Communist Party Kharitonov supported The rate was 4%, and another 3% of respondents said they would support the Liberal Democratic Party candidate Slutsky.

By then, four candidates, including current President Putin, will be on the presidential election ballot. candidates. They are current President Putin (running as an independent candidate), Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian New People's Party).
Pamfilova said that as an independent candidate, Putin has successfully collected more than 300,000 signatures from supporters, and candidates nominated by various parliamentary parties are exempt from this procedure in accordance with the law.
According to current public information, among all the candidates, Kharitonov from the Russian Communist Party is the oldest (75 years old), and Davankov from the New People's Party is the youngest (40 years old). Putin has participated in the presidential election four times, Kharitonov participated in the election in 2004, and the other two are running for the first time. title: 中俄独裁者互祝连任 “友谊”会突变吗？ | 普京 | 习近平 | 俄罗斯 | 大纪元
content:
俄罗斯总统大选落下帷幕，普京获得第五届总统任期。一年多前获普京祝连任的中共党魁习近平，第一时间向普京发贺电。两个独裁者互祝连任，对地缘政治已紧张的世界的影响引人关注。但专家认为，中共目前意在北方“维稳”，中俄“友谊”也随时会突变。
据俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间3月18日发布的计票结果，现任总统普京（Vladimir Putin）以87.19%的得票率获得第五届任期，他对俄罗斯联邦长达24年的统治将再“续”6年。
西方国家一致对普京在大选中取得的所谓“压倒性”胜利表示谴责，指出此次选举不公平、不民主。而中共党魁习近平在第一时间致电普京，祝贺他连任俄罗斯联邦总统。习称，“你再次当选，充分体现了俄罗斯人民对你的支持。”
普京2022年10月23日也曾祝贺习近平连任中共党魁。
淡江大学国际事务与战略研究所教授翁明贤3月19日对大纪元表示，习近平第一时间祝贺普京当选，背后是中俄对抗美国的战略考量。不过习和普京的“祝贺连任”还有一种用意，就是标榜中俄自己的所谓“民主体制”不同于西方国家的民主，因为普京“当选”的得票率是87.8%，相较于习近平的得票率也不遑多让。
在中共吹嘘的所谓“全过程民主”的幌子下，习近平去年3月在被称为“橡皮图章”的全国人大会议上“全票当选”国家主席。
故此，虽然外界多视俄罗斯这场大选为“假选举”，但不少中国网民透过微博讨论选情，讽刺说:“至少俄罗斯人还能投票选总统，自己连选票长啥模样，都没见过。”
值得注意的是，中共新华社18日发布了一个“俄罗斯总统选举中国观察员团观察声明”。声明称，3月15日至17日，中共的观察员团“应邀”对俄罗斯联邦总统选举的准备和实施过程进行了观察，声明说选举“民主、透明、公正”，选举过程顺利平静，未发现违规情况。
对此，独立时评人蔡慎坤在X上表示，俄罗斯总统大选，中共高调派遣观察团，一方面是学点经验，另一方面是为普京背书。
台湾励志协会执行长、大学兼任助理教授赖荣伟3月19日对大纪元表示，习已经多次表示很欣赏普京。
translation:
The Russian presidential election has come to an end, with Putin winning his fifth presidential term. Xi Jinping, leader of the Communist Party of China, who was congratulated by Putin for re-election more than a year ago, immediately sent a congratulatory message to Putin. The two dictators wished each other re-election, raising concerns about the impact on a world already tense in geopolitics. However, experts believe that the CCP currently intends to "maintain stability" in the north, and the "friendship" between China and Russia may change at any time.
According to the vote counting results released by the Russian Central Election Commission on March 18, local time, current President Vladimir Putin won the fifth term with 87.19% of the vote. His 24-year rule over the Russian Federation will be "continued" "6 years.
Western countries unanimously condemned Putin's so-called "overwhelming" victory in the election, pointing out that the election was unfair and undemocratic. The leader of the Communist Party of China, Xi Jinping, immediately called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of the Russian Federation. "Your re-election fully reflects the Russian people's support for you," Xi said.
Putin also congratulated Xi Jinping on his re-election as leader of the Communist Party of China on October 23, 2022.
Ong Mingxian, a professor at the Institute of International Affairs and Strategy at Tamkang University, told The Epoch Times on March 19 that Xi Jinping immediately congratulated Putin on his election because of the strategic considerations of China and Russia against the United States. However, Xi and Putin's "congratulations on re-election" also have another intention, which is to show off that China and Russia's own so-called "democratic system" is different from the democracy of Western countries, because Putin's "elected" vote rate was 87.8%, compared with Xi Jinping's vote The rate is no less generous.
Under the guise of so-called "whole-process democracy" boasted by the CCP, Xi Jinping was "unanimously elected" as president of the country in March last year at the so-called "rubber stamp" session of the National People's Congress.
Therefore, although the outside world views the Russian election as a "fake election," many Chinese netizens discussed the election on Weibo and sarcastically said: "At least Russians can still vote for the president. I don't even know what the ballot looks like." never seen it."
It is worth noting that the Xinhua News Agency of the Communist Party of China issued a "Statement on the Observation of the Chinese Observer Group on the Russian Presidential Election" on the 18th. The statement stated that from March 15th to 17th, the Chinese Communist Party’s observer team was “invited” to observe the preparation and implementation process of the Russian Federation’s presidential election. The statement said that the election was “democratic, transparent, and fair” and that the election process was smooth and calm. No incidents were discovered. Violations.
In this regard, independent commentator Cai Shenkun said on
Lai Rongwei, CEO of the Taiwan Inspirational Association and adjunct assistant professor at the university, told The Epoch Times on March 19 that Xi has expressed his admiration for Putin many times.

In this regard, independent commentator Cai Shenkun said on
Lai Rongwei, CEO of the Taiwan Inspirational Association and adjunct assistant professor at the university, told The Epoch Times on March 19 that Xi has expressed his admiration for Putin many times.

title: How Russians are protesting the election
content:
On Saturday, wives of mobilized soldiers attempted to lay flowers outside the Kremlin before being blocked by secret service agents, according to activist group The Way Home, which campaigns for Russian men to be allowed to return from the front lines.
The women were forced to move their protest to Victory Park, in southwest-central Moscow, the group said on Telegram Saturday, and were harassed by police who were “breathing down their necks.”
It was not clear how many people turned out at that protest. The organization said simultaneous actions were staged by military wives across the country.
The Kremlin is treating voter turnout in the presidential election as a referendum on the Ukraine war, with a high turnout to vote for Putin potentially indicating continued support for the president despite ongoing Western sanctions and growing diplomatic isolation.
In 2018, 67% of eligible voters came out to vote, and the Kremlin will want to boast it has topped that number.
In the Russian-ruled republic of Chechnya, turnout on Saturday reached 75%, according to the local election commission’s Telegram channel. In Ukraine’s southern city of Mariupol, the city council posted on Telegram accusing authorities of working with construction companies to bus in teams of “Russian builders” to vote in the precinct, inflating turnout in the area.
Numerous reports from parts of occupied Ukraine, such as  Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson and Zaporizhzhia, included accusations from locals that members of the Russian military went door to door and forced Ukrainian citizens to vote at gunpoint.
Photos uploaded to Telegram by Mariupol’s city council on Saturday claimed to show small-scale acts of protest by Ukrainians coerced into voting, including spoiling ballots.
Only one of the three candidates who oppose Putin in the election, Vladislav Davankov, supports peace negotiations with Ukraine.
Davankov, a former businessman, has called for a peace deal with Ukraine that is “on our terms and with no rollback,” while saying that Russia should not cede to Ukraine any territory it has already occupied.
More than 114 million Russians are eligible to vote in the election, including nearly 2 million abroad. Results are expected to be announced on Sunday, with a landslide for Putin functionally guaranteed.

title: Российские «выборы»: взгляд изнутри и со стороны
content:
Реакция Запада

Госсекретарь Энтони Блинкен, комментируя итоги президентских выборов, отметил стремление российских властей маргинализировать тех, кто выступает за верховенство закона.

«Кремль лишил своих граждан транспаретного и полноценного демократического процесса», и выборы в России «можно назвать только недемократическими», – подчеркивается в опубликованном ранее заявлении госсекретаря.

«Кремль провел фиктивные президентские выборы на временно оккупированных частях Украины в качестве откровенной пропаганды, надеясь, что это укрепит незаконные притязания России на те части Украины, которые она незаконно захватила и теперь оккупирует, – отметил он. – За несколько недель до выборов умер в колонии Адексей Навальный после многих лет преследований и жестокого обращения со стороны российских властей за его постоянные усилия по развитию подлинной демократии в России».

«Владимир Путин лишает граждан России доступа к информации, в том числе к информации, необходимой для участия в политической жизни. Независимо от предрешенного исхода этих выборов, Соединенные Штаты будут и впредь поддерживать тех, кто стремится к светлому будущему России», – констатировал Блинкен.

Исход президентских выборов не удивил администрацию Джо Байдена, эти выборы не были ни честными, ни свободными, однако реальным фактом является то, что Владимир Путин остается у власти и США, как и прежде, считают его российским лидером. Об этом в понедельник заявил Джейк Салливан, советник Белого дома по вопросам национальной безопасности.

Отвечая на просьбу журналиста рассказать о том, признает ли администрация Байдена победу Путина на выборах, Салливан сказал:

«Во-первых, ничто не предвещало неожиданного исхода выборов, поскольку Путин закрыл политическое пространство, посадил политических оппонентов. Некоторые из его политических оппонентов, к сожалению, умерли. Так что, эти выборы не были ни свободными, ни честными, и их исход был предрешен».

«Во-вторых, реальность такова, что президент Путин является президентом России. Мы сталкивались с этой реальностью на протяжении всей войны в Украине, во время других агрессивных действий России, других шагов, противоречащих интересам США, которые исходили от этого президента и от Российской Федерации под его руководством. И мы будем продолжать иметь дело с этой реальностью», - заявил Салливан, добавив, что данная реальность не отменяет факта того, что «эти выборы не соответствовали никаким критериям свободы или справедливости».

Пресс-секретарь Белого дома Карин Жан-Пьер, отвечая на вопрос журналиста о том, считает ли администрация, что Путин является «законно избранным президентом», выразила согласие с позицией Джейка Салливана.

«Очевидно, что господин Путин остается лидером России… Результаты [выборов] очевидно, также были предопределены. Никто не удивлен результатами этих выборов», - добавила Жан-Пьер.

Европейский Союз заявил, что российские выборы прошли в условиях «с крайне ограниченными возможностями» избирателей, «усугубленными незаконной агрессивной войной, которую Россия развязала против Украины». Франция заявила в понедельник, что переизбрание президента России Владимира Путина произошло на фоне репрессий, и похвалила многих россиян, которые мирно протестовали против переизбрания Владимира Путина.
translation:
Western reaction

Secretary of State Antony Blinken, commenting on the results of the presidential election, noted the desire of the Russian authorities to marginalize those who advocate the rule of law.

“The Kremlin has deprived its citizens of a transparent and full-fledged democratic process,” and the elections in Russia “can only be called undemocratic,” the Secretary of State emphasized in a previously published statement.

“The Kremlin held sham presidential elections in temporarily occupied parts of Ukraine as blatant propaganda, hoping it would strengthen Russia’s illegal claims to parts of Ukraine it illegally seized and now occupies,” he said. “A few weeks before the elections, Adeksei Navalny died in prison after years of persecution and mistreatment by Russian authorities for his ongoing efforts to develop genuine democracy in Russia.”

“Vladimir Putin is depriving Russian citizens of access to information, including information necessary to participate in political life. Regardless of the predetermined outcome of this election, the United States will continue to support those who strive for a bright future for Russia,” Blinken stated.

The outcome of the presidential election did not surprise the Joe Biden administration; the election was neither fair nor free, but the real fact is that Vladimir Putin remains in power and the United States, as before, considers him the Russian leader. Jake Sullivan, White House national security adviser, said this on Monday.

Responding to a journalist’s request to talk about whether the Biden administration would recognize Putin’s victory in the election, Sullivan said:

“Firstly, nothing foreshadowed the unexpected outcome of the elections, since Putin closed the political space and imprisoned political opponents. Some of his political opponents have unfortunately died. So, this election was neither free nor fair, and its outcome was a foregone conclusion.”

“Secondly, the reality is that President Putin is the president of Russia. We have faced this reality throughout the war in Ukraine, during other aggressive actions by Russia, other steps contrary to US interests that have come from this president and from the Russian Federation under his leadership. And we will continue to deal with that reality,” Sullivan said, adding that this reality does not change the fact that “this election did not meet any criteria of freedom or justice.”

White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre, responding to a journalist’s question about whether the administration believes that Putin is a “legitimately elected president,” expressed agreement with Jake Sullivan’s position.

“It is obvious that Mr. Putin remains the leader of Russia... The results [of the elections] were obviously also predetermined. Nobody is surprised by the results of these elections,” Jean-Pierre added.

The European Union said the Russian elections took place under conditions of “extremely limited voting power,” “exacerbated by the illegal war of aggression that Russia has waged against Ukraine.” France said Monday that Russian President Vladimir Putin's re-election came amid repression and praised the many Russians who peacefully protested Vladimir Putin's re-election.

The European Union said the Russian elections took place under conditions of “extremely limited voting power,” “exacerbated by the illegal war of aggression that Russia has waged against Ukraine.” France said Monday that Russian President Vladimir Putin's re-election came amid repression and praised the many Russians who peacefully protested Vladimir Putin's re-election.

title: Western leaders denounce Putin's election 'victory,' fall short of refusing to recognize results
content:
It's currently unknown what consequences would Russian officials face.
The previous Russian presidential election in 2018, which Putin won handily, also included voting in the illegally annexed Ukrainian territory of Crimea. Then U.S. President Donald Trump called Putin after to congratulate him on the results.
And while, this time around, Putin would have to settle for a smaller support group, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan didn't shy away from congratulating the Russian president.
Chinese President Xi Jinping also sent his congratulations, while West's arsenal to punish Putin for his war against Ukraine, occupation of the country's territories, and conducting a sham vote at gunpoint remains limited.
Following the blatantly rigged 2020 Belarusian election that handed dictator Alexander Lukashenko another term in the presidential office, EU and U.S. officials, said they would not consider Lukashenko to be the legitimately elected leader. 
Many have urged the West do the same with Putin. 
Jailed Russian dissident Vladimir Kara-Murza wrote an op-ed for the Washington Post arguing that the West should declare Putin to be illegitimate and the election illegal. 
Kara-Murza cited the government's crackdown on free press, the inability of meaningful opposition candidates to participate, and rules set out in Russia's own constitution as key reasons to explicitly not recognize Putin's reelection. 
Yet, there are also crucial differences between the regimes of Lukashenko and Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, who is also viewed as illegitimate by the U.S., and Putin. 
Both Belarus and Venezuela have opposition figures – Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya and Juan Guaido, respectively – who were recognized by some countries as legitimate leaders and have a base of support. 
While neither leader has so far been able to actually take the reins, they presented an alternate possibility that does not exist in Russia.
input:
It's currently unknown what consequences would Russian officials face.
The previous Russian presidential election in 2018, which Putin won handily, also included voting in the illegally annexed Ukrainian territory of Crimea. Then U.S. President Donald Trump called Putin after to congratulate him on the results.
And while, this time around, Putin would have to settle for a smaller support group, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan didn't shy away from congratulating the Russian president.
Chinese President Xi Jinping also sent his congratulations, while West's arsenal to punish Putin for his war against Ukraine, occupation of the country's territories, and conducting a sham vote at gunpoint remains limited.
Following the blatantly rigged 2020 Belarusian election that handed dictator Alexander Lukashenko another term in the presidential office, EU and U.S. officials, said they would not consider Lukashenko to be the legitimately elected leader. 
Many have urged the West do the same with Putin. 
Jailed Russian dissident Vladimir Kara-Murza wrote an op-ed for the Washington Post arguing that the West should declare Putin to be illegitimate and the election illegal. 
Kara-Murza cited the government's crackdown on free press, the inability of meaningful opposition candidates to participate, and rules set out in Russia's own constitution as key reasons to explicitly not recognize Putin's reelection. 
Yet, there are also crucial differences between the regimes of Lukashenko and Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, who is also viewed as illegitimate by the U.S., and Putin. 
Both Belarus and Venezuela have opposition figures – Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya and Juan Guaido, respectively – who were recognized by some countries as legitimate leaders and have a base of support. 
While neither leader has so far been able to actually take the reins, they presented an alternate possibility that does not exist in Russia.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
content:
澎湃新闻：2024年总统大选是俄罗斯首次战时选举。此次战时选举有何重要意义？普京希望借此向外界传递怎样的信号？
安德烈·科尔图诺夫：最近举行的总统选举再次证明了俄罗斯政治体制的整体稳定性。投票率超过77%，普京获得了前所未有的高支持率（87.28%，而2018年大选时普京的支持率为76.69%）。显然，这些结果表明，有人对俄罗斯可能发生“政权更迭”的担忧——或者说希望——是没有根据的。同样值得注意的是，俄罗斯联邦共产党的一名代表（注：哈里托诺夫）在所有候选人中得票率排名第二，这表明公众要求社会公正和“左转”。
澎湃新闻：俄乌冲突爆发后，面对西方制裁，俄罗斯经济仍然保持了一定的增长势头，但同时面临劳动力资源短缺、高通胀等问题。目前，军事相关支出是支撑俄经济增长的重要因素之一。怎样看待这种战时经济的可持续性？
安德烈·科尔图诺夫：正如我已经提到的，俄罗斯经济在过去两年中表现出了高度的韧性。我们应该赞扬俄罗斯政府的专业精神，它成功地控制了局势。我相信，至少在不久的将来，我们不会面临经济意外崩溃并带来相应负面社会后果的危险。尽管如此，俄罗斯仍存在许多经济问题，我们必须加以解决。这不仅仅是通货膨胀或劳动力资源短缺的问题：俄罗斯需要转向新的技术模式，以跟上发达国家的步伐。
俄西方关系难回过去，存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能"
translation:
The Paper: The 2024 presidential election is Russia’s first wartime election. What is the significance of this wartime election? What signal does Putin hope to send to the outside world?
Andrei Kortunov: The recently held presidential elections once again proved the overall stability of the Russian political system. The turnout exceeded 77%, and Putin received an unprecedented high support rate (87.28%, compared with 76.69% in the 2018 election). Clearly, these results suggest that fears — or hopes — about possible “regime change” in Russia are unfounded. It is also worth noting that a representative of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation (Note: Kharitonov) received the second highest vote share among all candidates, indicating public demands for social justice and a "turn to the left."
The Paper: After the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict and in the face of Western sanctions, the Russian economy still maintained a certain growth momentum, but it also faced problems such as labor resource shortages and high inflation. At present, military-related expenditures are one of the important factors supporting Russia's economic growth. How do you view the sustainability of this wartime economy?
Andrei Kortunov: As I already mentioned, the Russian economy has shown a high degree of resilience over the past two years. We should commend the professionalism of the Russian government, which successfully controlled the situation. I believe that, at least in the near future, we are not in danger of an unexpected economic collapse with corresponding negative social consequences. Still, Russia has many economic problems that we must solve. This is not just a matter of inflation or labor shortages: Russia needs to move to new technological models to keep up with developed countries.
It is difficult for Russia-Western relations to return to the past, and there is a possibility of direct conflict with NATO."
input:
The Paper: The 2024 presidential election is Russia’s first wartime election. What is the significance of this wartime election? What signal does Putin hope to send to the outside world?
Andrei Kortunov: The recently held presidential elections once again proved the overall stability of the Russian political system. The turnout exceeded 77%, and Putin received an unprecedented high support rate (87.28%, compared with 76.69% in the 2018 election). Clearly, these results suggest that fears — or hopes — about possible “regime change” in Russia are unfounded. It is also worth noting that a representative of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation (Note: Kharitonov) received the second highest vote share among all candidates, indicating public demands for social justice and a "turn to the left."
The Paper: After the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict and in the face of Western sanctions, the Russian economy still maintained a certain growth momentum, but it also faced problems such as labor resource shortages and high inflation. At present, military-related expenditures are one of the important factors supporting Russia's economic growth. How do you view the sustainability of this wartime economy?
Andrei Kortunov: As I already mentioned, the Russian economy has shown a high degree of resilience over the past two years. We should commend the professionalism of the Russian government, which successfully controlled the situation. I believe that, at least in the near future, we are not in danger of an unexpected economic collapse with corresponding negative social consequences. Still, Russia has many economic problems that we must solve. This is not just a matter of inflation or labor shortages: Russia needs to move to new technological models to keep up with developed countries.
It is difficult for Russia-Western relations to return to the past, and there is a possibility of direct conflict with NATO."

title: 普京：北约若与俄罗斯冲突，距第三次世界大战仅一步之遥
content:
普京在过去二十年内建立了对国内镇压异己、与西方对抗的体系。2022年乌克兰战争爆发后，他进一步加强集权，有效地压制了公众对战争的异议。最著名的普廷批评者阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）上个月在北极监狱突然逝世，其他反对人士则被监禁或者流亡海外。
轻松连任的普京星期一在投票结果底定后发表谈话。除了表达感谢，普廷还表示，俄罗斯“不会退缩”。
“当然，我们还有许多任务。但我想向所有人表明，当我们团结一致时，没有人能够吓倒我们，没有人能压制我们的意志和良知。他们过去失败，未来也不会起作用，”普京说。
在为期三天的投票中，乌克兰加强了对俄罗斯的攻击，包括炮击边境地区城市与无人机袭击，还有亲乌克兰团体试图突破俄罗斯边境。
不排除在乌克兰领土建立缓冲区
当被问及是否有必要占领乌克兰的哈尔科夫地区时，普京表示，如果（乌克兰的）攻击持续发生，俄罗斯将在更多的乌克兰领土上建立缓冲区，以保卫俄罗斯领土。
普京说：“考虑到所发生的悲剧事件，我不排除在合适的时候，被迫在基辅政权统治的领土上建立某种‘安全区’（sanitary zone）。”
普京拒绝透露更多细节，但表示这一个区域必须大到足以阻止外国制造的武器进入俄罗斯领土。
普京还表示，希望法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙（Emmanuel Macron）不要加剧乌克兰战争，而是在寻求和平方面发挥作用。“法国似乎可以扮演追求和平的角色，现在为时未晚。”
translation:
Putin has spent the past two decades establishing a system of suppressing dissidents at home and confronting the West. After the war in Ukraine broke out in 2022, he further strengthened centralization of power and effectively suppressed public dissent against the war. Alexei Navalny, the most prominent Putin critic, died suddenly in an Arctic prison last month, while other opponents are imprisoned or in exile.
Putin, who was easily re-elected, spoke on Monday after the results of the vote were finalized. In addition to expressing his gratitude, Putin also said that Russia "will not back down."
"Of course, we still have many tasks to do. But I want to show everyone that when we are united, no one can intimidate us, no one can suppress our will and conscience. They failed in the past and they will not work in the future ," Putin said.
During the three-day vote, Ukraine stepped up its attacks on Russia, including shelling border cities and drone strikes, as well as pro-Ukrainian groups trying to breach the Russian border.
Do not rule out the creation of a buffer zone on Ukrainian territory
When asked whether it was necessary to occupy the Kharkiv region of Ukraine, Putin said that if the attacks (in Ukraine) continued, Russia would establish a buffer zone on more Ukrainian territory to defend Russian territory.
Putin said: “Given the tragic events that have occurred, I do not rule out the possibility that at the appropriate time we will be forced to establish some kind of ‘sanitary zone’ on the territory governed by the Kiev regime.”
Putin declined to give further details, but said the area must be large enough to prevent foreign-made weapons from entering Russian territory.
Putin also expressed hope that French President Emmanuel Macron would not intensify the war in Ukraine and instead play a role in seeking peace. "It seems that France can play a role in pursuing peace and it is not too late."
input:

After the war in Ukraine broke out in 2022, he further strengthened centralization of power and effectively suppressed public dissent against the war. Alexei Navalny, the most prominent Putin critic, died suddenly in an Arctic prison last month, while other opponents are imprisoned or in exile.
Putin, who was easily re-elected, spoke on Monday after the results of the vote were finalized. In addition to expressing his gratitude, Putin also said that Russia "will not back down."
"Of course, we still have many tasks to do. But I want to show everyone that when we are united, no one can intimidate us, no one can suppress our will and conscience. They failed in the past and they will not work in the future ," Putin said.
During the three-day vote, Ukraine stepped up its attacks on Russia, including shelling border cities and drone strikes, as well as pro-Ukrainian groups trying to breach the Russian border.
Do not rule out the creation of a buffer zone on Ukrainian territory
When asked whether it was necessary to occupy the Kharkiv region of Ukraine, Putin said that if the attacks (in Ukraine) continued, Russia would establish a buffer zone on more Ukrainian territory to defend Russian territory.
Putin said: “Given the tragic events that have occurred, I do not rule out the possibility that at the appropriate time we will be forced to establish some kind of ‘sanitary zone’ on the territory governed by the Kiev regime.”
Putin declined to give further details, but said the area must be large enough to prevent foreign-made weapons from entering Russian territory.
Putin also expressed hope that French President Emmanuel Macron would not intensify the war in Ukraine and instead play a role in seeking peace. "It seems that France can play a role in pursuing peace and it is not too late."

title: Итоги выборов президента: Победа Путина, второе место КПРФ, рекордная явка
content:
На втором месте - председатель комитета Госдумы по развитию Дальнего Востока и Арктики Николай Харитонов, который шел на выборы с программой КПРФ и лозунгом "Поиграли в капитализм и хватит".

Коммунисты брали "серебро" и на всех предыдущих президентских выборах (в разные годы - Геннадий Зюганов, Николай Харитонов, Павел Грудинин). На самых первых выборах в 1991 году основным оппонентом Бориса Ельцина был представитель КПСС - недавно ушедший из жизни Николай Рыжков. В этот раз партия сократила как отрыв от ближайшего соперника, так и общий уровень поддержки. Так, Харитонов боролся за пост президента и в 2004 году - тогда он финишировал вторым, набрав 13,69% голосов избирателей.

Путин поблагодарил всех проголосовавших на выборах россиян
Самый молодой кандидат в президенты - 40-летний вице-спикер Госдумы Владислав Даванков - занял третью строчку в итоговом зачете. При этом в Москве он стал вторым, опередив Николая Харитонова. В сентябре прошлого года Даванков участвовал в выборах мэра Москвы, по их итогам набрал 5,34% (174,8 тысячи голосов). В этом смысле его "президентский" результат (в абсолютных цифрах более 3,3 млн голосов) - очевидный успех и для него, и для партии "Новые люди", сделавшей ставку на новые лица в политике.

Замыкает четверку лидер ЛДПР Леонид Слуцкий, построивший свою избирательную кампанию на тезисе "дело Жириновского живет". Для него это первый опыт участия в выборах такого уровня. Выдвинувшись в декабре, Слуцкий заявил, что мечтает поучаствовать в выборах президента, а не победить Путина.
translation:
In second place is the Chairman of the State Duma Committee for the Development of the Far East and the Arctic, Nikolai Kharitonov, who went to the elections with the program of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and the slogan “We’ve played at capitalism and that’s enough.”

The communists took silver in all previous presidential elections (in different years - Gennady Zyuganov, Nikolai Kharitonov, Pavel Grudinin). At the very first elections in 1991, Boris Yeltsin’s main opponent was a representative of the CPSU, Nikolai Ryzhkov, who recently passed away. This time, the party reduced both the gap from its closest rival and the overall level of support. Thus, Kharitonov competed for the presidency in 2004 - then he finished second, gaining 13.69% of the votes.

Putin thanked all Russians who voted in the elections
The youngest presidential candidate, 40-year-old State Duma Deputy Speaker Vladislav Davankov, took third place in the final standings. At the same time, in Moscow he became second, ahead of Nikolai Kharitonov. Last September, Davankov participated in the elections for the mayor of Moscow, and according to the results he received 5.34% (174.8 thousand votes). In this sense, his “presidential” result (in absolute numbers, more than 3.3 million votes) is an obvious success both for him and for the New People party, which relied on new faces in politics.

The leader of the LDPR, Leonid Slutsky, closes the top four, having built his election campaign on the thesis “Zhirinovsky’s cause lives on.” This is his first experience of participating in elections of this level. When he nominated in December, Slutsky said that he dreamed of participating in the presidential elections, and not defeating Putin.
input:
In second place is the Chairman of the State Duma Committee for the Development of the Far East and the Arctic, Nikolai Kharitonov, who went to the elections with the program of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and the slogan “We’ve played at capitalism and that’s enough.”

The communists took silver in all previous presidential elections (in different years - Gennady Zyuganov, Nikolai Kharitonov, Pavel Grudinin). At the very first elections in 1991, Boris Yeltsin’s main opponent was a representative of the CPSU, Nikolai Ryzhkov, who recently passed away. This time, the party reduced both the gap from its closest rival and the overall level of support. Thus, Kharitonov competed for the presidency in 2004 - then he finished second, gaining 13.69% of the votes.

Putin thanked all Russians who voted in the elections
The youngest presidential candidate, 40-year-old State Duma Deputy Speaker Vladislav Davankov, took third place in the final standings. At the same time, in Moscow he became second, ahead of Nikolai Kharitonov. Last September, Davankov participated in the elections for the mayor of Moscow, and according to the results he received 5.34% (174.8 thousand votes). In this sense, his “presidential” result (in absolute numbers, more than 3.3 million votes) is an obvious success both for him and for the New People party, which relied on new faces in politics.

The leader of the LDPR, Leonid Slutsky, closes the top four, having built his election campaign on the thesis “Zhirinovsky’s cause lives on.” This is his first experience of participating in elections of this level. When he nominated in December, Slutsky said that he dreamed of participating in the presidential elections, and not defeating Putin.

The number of startups in India's electric two-wheeler market has surged to over 150 from 54 in 2021, driven by government incentives to promote clean vehicles and cut oil imports, according to a new analysis.  The influx has intensified competition in a segment expected to grow 15-20 times to annual sales of 15-20 million units over the next decade, Bernstein said in a report late Tuesday.  "Most are competing in the mainstream, and 85% of the 65 models launched last year were such products: high-speed as against speed and range-constrained products, which used to be a feature of the startups," Bernstein analysts wrote.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content:
Мысли и прогнозы возникающие по итогам прошедших выборов
1. Несмотря на все нарушения и скандалы, итоги выборов вряд ли будут пересмотрены или оспорены. Слишком велик масштаб победы Путина и слишком прочны его позиции во власти. Оппозиция и западные страны могут сколько угодно критиковать результаты голосования, но изменить их не в силах.

2. В то же время, столь высокий результат Путина и явка избирателей могут иметь обратный эффект. Часть общества воспримет эти цифры как нереалистичные и сфальсифицированные, что подорвет доверие к власти и выборным процедурам как таковым. А это, в свою очередь, чревато ростом протестных настроений и политической апатии.

3. Интересно посмотреть, как будут развиваться отношения России с Западом после этих выборов. Вряд ли стоит ожидать потепления и снятия санкций, скорее наоборот - конфронтация может усилиться. Многое будет зависеть от действий самого Путина и его готовности идти на компромиссы по ключевым вопросам - от Украины до прав человека.

4. Отдельного упоминания заслуживает фактор новых регионов - ДНР, ЛНР, Херсонской и Запорожской областей. Их участие в выборах и почти стопроцентная поддержка Путина добавили ему легитимности внутри страны, но вызвали резкое отторжение на Западе. Теперь эти территории станут еще одним яблоком раздора между Россией и международным сообществом.

5. Наконец, остается открытым вопрос о будущем самого Путина и российской политической системы. Сможет ли действующий президент за свой новый срок подготовить себе преемника и обеспечить транзит власти? Или он останется у руля после 2030 года, согласно переделанной Конституции, в которой ему можно выдвигаться еще раз? От этого будет зависеть траектория развития страны на десятилетия вперед.
translation:
Thoughts and forecasts arising from the results of the past elections
1. Despite all the violations and scandals, the election results are unlikely to be revised or disputed. The scale of Putin’s victory is too great and his position in power is too strong. The opposition and Western countries can criticize the voting results as much as they want, but they cannot change them.

2. At the same time, such a high result for Putin and voter turnout may have the opposite effect. Part of society will perceive these figures as unrealistic and falsified, which will undermine confidence in the authorities and election procedures as such. And this, in turn, is fraught with an increase in protest sentiments and political apathy.

3. It will be interesting to see how Russia's relations with the West will develop after these elections. It is unlikely that we should expect a warming up and the lifting of sanctions; rather, on the contrary, confrontation may intensify. Much will depend on the actions of Putin himself and his willingness to compromise on key issues - from Ukraine to human rights.

4. The factor of new regions - the DPR, LPR, Kherson and Zaporozhye regions - deserves special mention. Their participation in the elections and almost one hundred percent support for Putin added legitimacy to him within the country, but caused sharp rejection in the West. Now these territories will become another bone of contention between Russia and the international community.

5. Finally, the question remains open about the future of Putin himself and the Russian political system. During his new term, will the current president be able to prepare a successor and ensure the transition of power? Or will he remain at the helm after 2030, under a redrawn Constitution that would allow him another run? The country’s development trajectory for decades to come will depend on this.
input:
Thoughts and forecasts arising from the results of the past elections
1. Despite all the violations and scandals, the election results are unlikely to be revised or disputed. The scale of Putin’s victory is too great and his position in power is too strong. The opposition and Western countries can criticize the voting results as much as they want, but they cannot change them.

2. At the same time, such a high result for Putin and voter turnout may have the opposite effect. Part of society will perceive these figures as unrealistic and falsified, which will undermine confidence in the authorities and election procedures as such. And this, in turn, is fraught with an increase in protest sentiments and political apathy.

3. It will be interesting to see how Russia's relations with the West will develop after these elections. It is unlikely that we should expect a warming up and the lifting of sanctions; rather, on the contrary, confrontation may intensify. Much will depend on the actions of Putin himself and his willingness to compromise on key issues - from Ukraine to human rights.

4. The factor of new regions - the DPR, LPR, Kherson and Zaporozhye regions - deserves special mention. Their participation in the elections and almost one hundred percent support for Putin added legitimacy to him within the country, but caused sharp rejection in the West. Now these territories will become another bone of contention between Russia and the international community.

5. Finally, the question remains open about the future of Putin himself and the Russian political system. During his new term, will the current president be able to prepare a successor and ensure the transition of power? Or will he remain at the helm after 2030, under a redrawn Constitution that would allow him another run? The country’s development trajectory for decades to come will depend on this.

title: Putin wins Russian election and talks about Navaln
content:
The Moscow Times noted last month that since as far back as 2017, Putin has not referred directly to the Kremlin's biggest opponent, instead alluding to Navalny as "that character," "this gentleman," "a poor excuse for a politician" and "a certain political force."
The Russian media had followed Putin's cue, airbrushing Navalny out of their media coverage. Last night, when reporting Putin's comments, they described the opposition leader as a "blogger." The opposition leader's death was barely mentioned in the Russian press at all.
During Putin's 24 years in power, opposition figures have been harassed, intimidated and imprisoned, with a number dying in mysterious circumstances.
The erasure of political opponents has made the reelection of Putin a foregone conclusion in recent elections, and in 2024 the Kremlin was seen to be looking for a landslide victory to legitimize Putin's foreign policies, particularly the war against Ukraine.
"We have many tasks ahead. But when we are consolidated — no matter who wants to intimidate us, suppress us — nobody has ever succeeded in history, they have not succeeded now, and they will not succeed ever in the future," he said as he addressed supporters and the media late Sunday night, according to comments translated by Reuters.
Russian pro-Kremlin media hailed Putin's record win, with news agency RIA Novosti describing it as "a record in the history of modern Russia." By the end of Putin's next term in power, in 2030, Putin will have overtaken Soviet dictator Josef Stalin as the longest-serving leader in Russia's modern history.
The U.S., U.K. and Ukraine were among the countries decrying the latest Russian ballot as "neither free nor fair."
Thousands of Russians living abroad queued up at polling stations outside Russian embassies to vote, with many participating in the "noon against Putin" protests following a call from Navalny's widow Yulia Navalnaya for voters to spoil their votes or to vote for any candidate apart from Putin.
input:
The Moscow Times noted last month that since as far back as 2017, Putin has not referred directly to the Kremlin's biggest opponent, instead alluding to Navalny as "that character," "this gentleman," "a poor excuse for a politician" and "a certain political force."
The Russian media had followed Putin's cue, airbrushing Navalny out of their media coverage. Last night, when reporting Putin's comments, they described the opposition leader as a "blogger." The opposition leader's death was barely mentioned in the Russian press at all.
During Putin's 24 years in power, opposition figures have been harassed, intimidated and imprisoned, with a number dying in mysterious circumstances.
The erasure of political opponents has made the reelection of Putin a foregone conclusion in recent elections, and in 2024 the Kremlin was seen to be looking for a landslide victory to legitimize Putin's foreign policies, particularly the war against Ukraine.
"We have many tasks ahead. But when we are consolidated — no matter who wants to intimidate us, suppress us — nobody has ever succeeded in history, they have not succeeded now, and they will not succeed ever in the future," he said as he addressed supporters and the media late Sunday night, according to comments translated by Reuters.
Russian pro-Kremlin media hailed Putin's record win, with news agency RIA Novosti describing it as "a record in the history of modern Russia." By the end of Putin's next term in power, in 2030, Putin will have overtaken Soviet dictator Josef Stalin as the longest-serving leader in Russia's modern history.
The U.S., U.K. and Ukraine were among the countries decrying the latest Russian ballot as "neither free nor fair."
Thousands of Russians living abroad queued up at polling stations outside Russian embassies to vote, with many participating in the "noon against Putin" protests following a call from Navalny's widow Yulia Navalnaya for voters to spoil their votes or to vote for any candidate apart from Putin.

title: Путин набрал 87,28% голосов по итогам обработки 100% бюллетеней
content:
Действующий глава государства самовыдвиженец Владимир Путин по итогам обработки 100% протоколов победил на выборах президента России с 87,28% голосов. Об этом свидетельствуют данные Центризбиркома (ЦИК) на 18 марта.

По итогам подсчета всех бюллетеней Путин набрал 87,28% голосов, депутат Госдумы от КПРФ Николай Харитонов — 4,31%, депутат Госдумы и председатель ЛДПР Леонид Слуцкий — 3,2%, а зампред Госдумы Владислав Даванков («Новые люди») — 3,85%.

Основное всероссийское голосование на выборах президента РФ проходило в течение трех дней — с 15 по 17 марта.
translation:
The current head of state, self-nominated Vladimir Putin, based on the results of processing 100% of the protocols, won the presidential elections in Russia with 87.28% of the votes. This is evidenced by data from the Central Election Commission (CEC) as of March 18.

Based on the results of counting all ballots, Putin received 87.28% of the votes, State Duma deputy from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolai Kharitonov - 4.31%, State Duma deputy and LDPR Chairman Leonid Slutsky - 3.2%, and State Duma Deputy Chairman Vladislav Davankov (New People) - 3.85%.

The main all-Russian voting in the presidential elections of the Russian Federation took place over three days - from March 15 to 17.
input:
The current head of state, self-nominated Vladimir Putin, based on the results of processing 100% of the protocols, won the presidential elections in Russia with 87.28% of the votes. This is evidenced by data from the Central Election Commission (CEC) as of March 18.

Based on the results of counting all ballots, Putin received 87.28% of the votes, State Duma deputy from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolai Kharitonov - 4.31%, State Duma deputy and LDPR Chairman Leonid Slutsky - 3.2%, and State Duma Deputy Chairman Vladislav Davankov (New People) - 3.85%.

The main all-Russian voting in the presidential elections of the Russian Federation took place over three days - from March 15 to 17.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
content:
自由民主党在俄罗斯政坛的立场一直以极右翼和极端民族主义著称，专家分析称，斯卢茨基是一个典型的自由民主党党员。
1990年，斯卢茨基毕业于莫斯科机床工具学院（即今天的莫斯科国立工业大学“斯坦金”）。1996年，他在莫斯科经济与统计大学获得经济学博士学位。
1992-1993年，斯卢茨基担任莫斯科市长尤里·卢日科夫的顾问，并在1994年成为国家杜马秘书处负责人。1999年，斯卢茨基成为日里诺夫斯基（创立自由民主党并长期担任该党领导人，该党被认为是极端民族主义的右翼政党）集团内的国家杜马议员。
此后，斯卢茨基分别在2003年、2007年、2011年、2016年和2021年多次当选国家杜马议员。2016年，斯卢茨基担任俄罗斯国家杜马国际事务委员会主席。2020年，斯卢茨基担任莫斯科国立大学世界政治学院院长。2022年，在日里诺夫斯基因病去世后，斯卢茨基成为俄罗斯自由民主党的新一任领导人。
2014年，斯卢茨基积极支持克里米亚加入俄罗斯。公投后，他成为首批受到美国、欧盟以及加拿大等西方国家制裁的俄罗斯政治家之一。此后，斯卢茨基曾因“为加强克里米亚的统一、发展和繁荣做出的个人贡献”而被授予勋章。2022年，斯卢茨基还曾是俄罗斯与乌克兰就“特别军事行动”展开谈判的谈判小组成员。
2024年2月，在欧盟批准决议、为利用俄央行被冻结资产产生的利息援乌铺平道路之际，斯卢茨基提出，俄罗斯应利用“特别军事行动”前每年向欧安组织议会预算划拨的3300万欧元，用以支持参与特别军事行动者及其亲人。在乌克兰自乌东重镇阿夫杰耶夫卡撤军后，斯卢茨基呼吁奖励参与该地区军事行动的士兵，并称自己相信“敌人的战线很快就会崩溃”。
斯卢茨基选择在2月21日公布自己的竞选纲领。据他解释，他选择这一天并非偶然，因为正是在两年前的2月21日，俄罗斯宣布承认乌克兰东部的“顿涅茨克人民共和国”和“卢甘斯克人民共和国”独立。
斯卢茨基在其竞选纲领中强调，俄罗斯必须在特别军事行动中取得彻底的、迅速的胜利，与此同时，纲领主要内容还包括住房和公用事业、教育、医疗、对多子女家庭的支持等民生问题。
translation:
The Liberal Democratic Party's stance in Russian politics has always been known for its extreme right-wing and ultra-nationalism. Experts analyzed that Slutsky is a typical member of the Liberal Democratic Party.
In 1990, Slutsky graduated from the Moscow Machine Tool Institute (today's Moscow State Polytechnic University "Stankin"). In 1996, he received his PhD in Economics from the Moscow University of Economics and Statistics.
In 1992-1993, Slutsky served as an adviser to Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov, and in 1994 he became head of the State Duma Secretariat. In 1999, Slutsky became a member of the State Duma within the group of Zhirinovsky (who founded the Liberal Democratic Party and served as its long-term leader, which is considered an ultra-nationalist right-wing party).
Since then, Slutsky has been elected to the State Duma several times in 2003, 2007, 2011, 2016 and 2021. In 2016, Slutsky served as Chairman of the Russian State Duma Committee on International Affairs. In 2020, Slutsky served as dean of the School of World Politics at Moscow State University. In 2022, after Zhirinovsky passed away due to illness, Slutsky became the new leader of the Russian Liberal Democratic Party.
In 2014, Slutsky actively supported Crimea's accession to Russia. After the referendum, he became one of the first Russian politicians to be sanctioned by Western countries such as the United States, the European Union, and Canada. Since then, Slutsky has been awarded the medal for his "personal contribution to strengthening the unity, development and prosperity of Crimea." In 2022, Slutsky was also a member of the negotiating team for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine on "special military operations."
In February 2024, when the EU approved a resolution paving the way for using the interest generated by the frozen assets of the Russian Central Bank to assist Ukraine, Slutsky proposed that Russia should use the "special military operations" to submit annual contributions to the OSCE parliamentary budget before 33 million euros have been allocated to support those involved in special military operations and their relatives. After Ukraine withdrew its troops from the eastern Ukrainian town of Avdeyevka, Slutsky called for rewards for soldiers involved in military operations in the region, saying he believed "the enemy's front will soon collapse."
Slutsky chose to announce his campaign platform on February 21. According to his explanation, it was no accident that he chose this day, because it was on February 21, two years ago, that Russia announced its recognition of the independence of the "Donetsk People's Republic" and the "Luhansk People's Republic" in eastern Ukraine.
Slutsky emphasized in his campaign platform that Russia must achieve a complete and rapid victory in special military operations. At the same time, the main contents of the platform also include housing and public utilities, education, medical care, and support for families with many children. and other livelihood issues.
input:
The Liberal Democratic Party's stance in Russian politics has always been known for its extreme right-wing and ultra-nationalism. Experts analyzed that Slutsky is a typical member of the Liberal Democratic Party.
In 1990, Slutsky graduated from the Moscow Machine Tool Institute (today's Moscow State Polytechnic University "Stankin"). In 1996, he received his PhD in Economics from the Moscow University of Economics and Statistics.
In 1992-1993, Slutsky served as an adviser to Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov, and in 1994 he became head of the State Duma Secretariat. In 1999, Slutsky became a member of the State Duma within the group of Zhirinovsky (who founded the Liberal Democratic Party and served as its long-term leader, which is considered an ultra-nationalist right-wing party).
Since then, Slutsky has been elected to the State Duma several times in 2003, 2007, 2011, 2016 and 2021. In 2016, Slutsky served as Chairman of the Russian State Duma Committee on International Affairs. In 2020, Slutsky served as dean of the School of World Politics at Moscow State University. In 2022, after Zhirinovsky passed away due to illness, Slutsky became the new leader of the Russian Liberal Democratic Party.
In 2014, Slutsky actively supported Crimea's accession to Russia. After the referendum, he became one of the first Russian politicians to be sanctioned by Western countries such as the United States, the European Union, and Canada. Since then, Slutsky has been awarded the medal for his "personal contribution to strengthening the unity, development and prosperity of Crimea." In 2022, Slutsky was also a member of the negotiating team for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine on "special military operations."
In February 2024, when the EU approved a resolution paving the way for using the interest generated by the frozen assets of the Russian Central Bank to assist Ukraine, Slutsky proposed that Russia should use the "special military operations" to submit annual contributions to the OSCE parliamentary budget before 33 million euros have been allocated to support those involved in special military operations and their relatives. After Ukraine withdrew its troops from the eastern Ukrainian town of Avdeyevka, Slutsky called for rewards for soldiers involved in military operations in the region, saying he believed "the enemy's front will soon collapse."
Slutsky chose to announce his campaign platform on February 21. According to his explanation, it was no accident that he chose this day, because it was on February 21, two years ago, that Russia announced its recognition of the independence of the "Donetsk People's Republic" and the "Luhansk People's Republic" in eastern Ukraine.
Slutsky emphasized in his campaign platform that Russia must achieve a complete and rapid victory in special military operations. At the same time, the main contents of the platform also include housing and public utilities, education, medical care, and support for families with many children. and other livelihood issues.

title: 专访｜亚美尼亚政经战略研究中心主席谈亚俄关系生变：不是“脱钩”，应扩大多元外交
content: 据中新网报道，当地时间3月18日，俄罗斯中央选举委员会发布数据，在俄总统选举统计完成的85%选票中，现任总统普京以87.19%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人，实际已经赢得此次总统选举。当天凌晨普京召开记者会，感谢选民信任和支持，表示将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。
translation: According to China News Service, on March 18, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission released data. Among the 85% of the votes counted in the Russian presidential election, the current President Putin led other candidates by a large margin with 87.19% of the votes. He actually won this presidential election. Putin held a press conference in the early morning of the same day, thanking voters for their trust and support, and stated that he would continue to promote national development in the new term.
input: According to China News Service, on March 18, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission released data. Among the 85% of the votes counted in the Russian presidential election, the current President Putin led other candidates by a large margin with 87.19% of the votes. He actually won this presidential election. Putin held a press conference in the early morning of the same day, thanking voters for their trust and support, and stated that he would continue to promote national development in the new term.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
content:
养娃的程序员奶爸：“养育一个孩子太难了”
2024年2月29日，普京发表了其任职总统期间最长的一次国情咨文讲话。此次讲话不仅包括俄罗斯政府近期的任务，也涉及对国家长期发展至关重要的问题。俄罗斯总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫表示，普京的此次国情咨文在很大程度上可以被视为其竞选纲领。
在国情咨文讲话中，普京再度强调俄乌冲突并非由俄罗斯挑起，同时重申俄罗斯将尽一切努力以结束战斗行动、根除纳粹、完成特别行动的所有任务。针对西方，普京则强调俄战略武器“处于完全准备状态”。而在涉及国内议题的讲话内容中，普京提到了经济、技术、基础设施建设等议题。其中，他首先提到并贯穿全程的议题则是俄罗斯当前所面临的人口危机。
2024年是俄罗斯大选年，也是俄罗斯的家庭年。普京在讲话中多次强调支持多子女家庭、传承传统价值观的重要性以及为国家培养人才的紧迫性，所提出的“家庭”、“俄罗斯青年”、“长寿及积极的生活”等项目均与人口问题息息相关。为在六年内实现俄罗斯出生率稳步增长的任务，普京还提出了包括将“母亲资本”计划至少延长至2030年、提高对多子女家庭的减税力度等多项措施。
25岁的德米特里正是“母亲资本”的受益者。年轻的他已经有了一个孩子，目前和家人一起生活在莫斯科周边地区。开始养育孩子之后，德米特里一家的支出明显增多了。不过，通过“母亲资本”计划，德米特里一家拿到了约50万卢布（约合人民币3.96万元）。在他的妻子休产假期间，每个月还有3万卢布（约合人民币2373元）的补贴金。
诚然，这些补贴与养育一个孩子的成本相比仍相去甚远，但确实在一定程度上减轻了初为人父的德米特里身上的压力：“在我的印象中，我们应该还拿到过一次性的现金补贴，大概是10万卢布左右（约合人民币7910元）。有了这些钱，我们可以为孩子置办一些家具用品。此外，我们现在还能免费拿到一些乳制品、果泥一类的给孩子的食品。从这一点上来讲，政府做的很不错。”
平日里，作为程序员的德米特里工作极其忙碌。回到家中后，疲惫的他只想早点休息。但为了照看孩子，他不得不每天夜里起来很多次。每次成功将孩子哄睡时，都是德米特里最幸福、最自由的时刻。现在，他正期待着自己五年来的首次国外旅行。他笑着说，为了好好休息，这次他和妻子会把孩子交给长辈和保姆照看。
尽管过上了较之大多数普通人而言更为优渥的生活，但当被问到是否还想要养育更多子女时，初为人父的手忙脚乱以及繁重的工作仍然让德米特里有些犹豫。“养育一个孩子太难了”，已经成为了他的口头禅。而在谈到为何俄罗斯出生率仍在下降时，德米特里无奈地表示，高昂的住房成本以及相较之下微薄的工资使得许多俄罗斯年轻人对于生养子女顾虑重重。
2023年，俄罗斯许多地区的房租出现大幅上涨。
translation:
Programmer dad raising a child: “It’s too difficult to raise a child”
On February 29, 2024, Putin delivered the longest State of the Union address during his tenure as president. The speech not only covered the Russian government's immediate tasks, but also addressed issues crucial to the country's long-term development. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that Putin’s State of the Union address can be regarded as his campaign platform to a large extent.
In his State of the Union address, Putin once again emphasized that the Russian-Ukrainian conflict was not initiated by Russia, and reiterated that Russia will make every effort to end combat operations, eradicate Nazis, and complete all tasks of special operations. Regarding the West, Putin emphasized that Russia's strategic weapons are "in a state of complete readiness." In his speech involving domestic issues, Putin mentioned issues such as economy, technology, and infrastructure construction. Among them, the issue he mentioned first and continued throughout was the demographic crisis currently facing Russia.
2024 is the year of the Russian election and the year of the family in Russia. In his speech, Putin repeatedly emphasized the importance of supporting families with many children, inheriting traditional values, and the urgency of cultivating talents for the country. The proposed projects such as "Family", "Russian Youth", and "Longevity and Active Life" are all related to Demographic issues are closely related. In order to achieve the task of steadily increasing Russia's birth rate within six years, Putin also proposed a number of measures, including extending the "Mother Capital" program to at least 2030 and increasing tax cuts for families with many children.
25-year-old Dmitry is the beneficiary of "mother capital". The young man already has a child and currently lives with his family in the surrounding areas of Moscow. After starting to raise children, Dmitry's family's expenses increased significantly. However, through the "Mother Capital" program, Dmitry's family received about 500,000 rubles (approximately RMB 39,600). While his wife is on maternity leave, there is also a monthly subsidy of 30,000 rubles (approximately RMB 2,373).
Admittedly, these subsidies are still far from the cost of raising a child, but they do alleviate the pressure on Dmitry, a first-time father, to a certain extent: “In my impression, we should have received The one-time cash subsidy is about 100,000 rubles (approximately RMB 7,910). With this money, we can buy some furniture and supplies for our children. In addition, we can now get some dairy products and fruit purees for free. Food for children. From this point of view, the government has done a good job.”
On weekdays, Dmitri is extremely busy as a programmer. After returning home, he was tired and just wanted to rest early. But in order to look after the children, he had to get up many times every night. Every time he successfully puts a child to sleep, it is Dmitry's happiest and freest moment. Now he's looking forward to his first trip abroad in five years. He smiled and said that in order to have a good rest, he and his wife would leave their children to the care of elders and nannies this time.
Although he has lived a more prosperous life than most ordinary people, when asked whether he still wants to raise more children, the hecticness and heavy work of a new father still make Dmitri hesitate. . "Raising a child is too difficult" has become his mantra. When talking about why Russia's birth rate is still declining, Dmitry said helplessly that high housing costs and relatively low wages make many young Russians worried about having children.
In 2023, rents will rise significantly in many regions of Russia.
