title: Путин набрал 87,28% голосов по итогам обработки 100% бюллетеней
content:
С победой Путина уже поздравили лидеры стран СНГ, председатель КНР Си Цзиньпин, президент Ирана Эбрахим Раиси, лидер КНДР Ким Чен Ын и другие зарубежные главы государств. Кроме того, Слуцкий охарактеризовал прошедшую кампанию по выборам президента РФ как историческую и отметил, что она «подтвердила устойчивый авторитет лидера нации». Он также назвал победу Путина уникальной и убедительной.

Общая явка на выборах президента России составила 74,22%, а на дистанционное электронное голосование — 94%, отметил 17 марта зампред Центризбиркома РФ Николай Булаев. Глава ЦИК Элла Памфилова назвала эти показатели рекордными в новейшей истории страны. Она также сообщила, что заседание комиссии, посвященное официальному подведению итогов выборов президента РФ, состоится в четверг, 21 марта, в 11:00.
translation:
Putin has already been congratulated on his victory by the leaders of the CIS countries, Chinese President Xi Jinping, Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and other foreign heads of state. In addition, Slutsky described the past campaign for the presidential elections in the Russian Federation as historical and noted that it “confirmed the stable authority of the leader of the nation.” He also called Putin's victory unique and convincing.

The overall turnout in the Russian presidential elections was 74.22%, and for remote electronic voting - 94%, Nikolai Bulaev, deputy chairman of the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation, noted on March 17. The head of the Central Election Commission, Ella Pamfilova, called these figures a record in the country’s recent history. She also said that the commission meeting dedicated to the official summing up of the results of the presidential elections in the Russian Federation will take place on Thursday, March 21, at 11:00.
input:
Putin has already been congratulated on his victory by the leaders of the CIS countries, Chinese President Xi Jinping, Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and other foreign heads of state. In addition, Slutsky described the past campaign for the presidential elections in the Russian Federation as historical and noted that it “confirmed the stable authority of the leader of the nation.” He also called Putin's victory unique and convincing.

The overall turnout in the Russian presidential elections was 74.22%, and for remote electronic voting - 94%, Nikolai Bulaev, deputy chairman of the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation, noted on March 17. The head of the Central Election Commission, Ella Pamfilova, called these figures a record in the country’s recent history. She also said that the commission meeting dedicated to the official summing up of the results of the presidential elections in the Russian Federation will take place on Thursday, March 21, at 11:00.

title: 国际观察｜普京胜选 俄罗斯发展有哪些看点
content:
新华社莫斯科3月18日电（记者陈汀 刘恺 安晓萌）据俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间18日凌晨发布的数据,在俄总统选举统计完成的85%选票中,现任总统普京以87.19%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人,实际已经赢得此次总统选举。
分析人士认为,普京连任后,俄内政外交将延续既有政策,包括着力加强技术自主,促进经济多元,积极发展与亚洲、非洲、中东和拉美等地区友好国家的关系,推动世界多极化发展。

获胜
俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行,共4位候选人参选,包括俄现任总统普京、俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基、俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫和俄新人党的达万科夫。
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会数据,在俄总统选举统计完成的85%选票中,普京、哈里托诺夫、达万科夫、斯卢茨基分别获得87.19%、4.24%、3.99%、3.16%的选票。
根据俄总统选举规则,在选举中获得50％以上选票者当选总统,因此普京实际上已经赢得选举。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举结果,并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
18日凌晨,普京在竞选总部发表讲话,感谢所有选民的支持。他说,俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展,变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。

技术自主　经济多元
俄经济在乌克兰危机升级初期遭遇震荡后,逐步展现出韧性。俄罗斯联邦国家统计局今年2月初发布的数据显示,2023年俄国内生产总值增长3.6%。但西方国家对俄在金融、投资、技术产品进口等领域的封锁给俄经济长远发展带来困难。如何继续对冲西方制裁影响是普京执政的一个任务。
普京在2月底向议会两院发表的国情咨文中表示,缺乏人才和自有先进技术不足等因素可能会导致经济增长减速。因此,国家将大力加强教育、科技等领域发展,让技术自主成为产业升级的动力,以提高俄经济的效率和竞争力。
他提出,到2030年,俄高技术产品和服务在本国市场所占份额应增加50%,非原料、非能源产品出口至少增加三分之二。俄罗斯应在涉及公民健康、粮食安全等领域拥有关键技术,并在机床、机器人、运输、无人驾驶、航空、海洋、数字经济、新材料和化学等能够促进经济可持续发展的领域实现技术自主,重点领域投资额应增长70%,至少再新建100个科技园区。
普京说,当前非资源产业在俄经济增长结构中所占的比重超过90%,俄经济正在变得更加多元化、更可持续。
俄国家杜马（议会下院）金融市场委员会主席阿克萨科夫说,俄经济逐渐适应西方制裁,并迅速发生变化。西方压迫促使俄罗斯大力推进经济内部重组,使其加速摆脱对资源依赖。

延续外交政策
俄专家认为,抵制西方围堵打压、团结友好国家、实现既定外交目标将成为普京今后外交政策的着力点。
普京曾表示,无论谁在2024年的美国总统选举中获胜,美国对俄外交政策都不太可能发生根本性变化,美方仍将视俄罗斯为敌。
俄政治信息中心主任穆欣表示,普京将继续对不友好国家采取强硬立场。俄罗斯国际事务理事会专家科尔图诺夫说,接下来一段时间,俄美将继续深度对抗,但双方仍将保持一定克制,以避免发生核战争等意外。
俄专家认为,普京将延续此前外交政策,积极发展与亚洲、非洲、中东和拉美等地区友好国家的关系,扩大朋友圈,加强在国际及区域组织中的影响力并推动世界多极化。
此外,有分析认为,普京今后将更加重视俄罗斯与其他金砖国家的关系,并将这种关系拓展到包括贸易在内的多个领域。穆欣认为,俄罗斯将继续在金砖合作机制和上合组织等框架内发挥重要作用。
translation:
Xinhua News Agency, Moscow, March 18 (Reporter Chen Ting, Liu Kai, An Xiaomeng) According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin won 87.19% of the votes. He is significantly ahead of other candidates and has actually won the presidential election.
Analysts believe that after Putin's re-election, Russia's domestic and foreign affairs will continue its existing policies, including focusing on strengthening technological independence, promoting economic diversification, actively developing relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, and promoting the development of a multi-polar world. .

win
The official voting for Russia's eighth presidential election was held from the 15th to the 17th. A total of four candidates participated in the election, including the current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russia's Liberal Democratic Party's Slutsky, the Russian Federation's Communist Party's Kharitonov and the Russian newcomer Davankov of the party.
According to data from the Russian Central Election Commission, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, Putin, Kharitonov, Davankov, and Slutsky received 87.19%, 4.24%, 3.99%, and 3.16% of the votes respectively. .
According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president, so Putin has actually won the election. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed.
In the early morning of the 18th, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters and thanked all voters for their support. He said that Russia will move forward further and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.

Technological independence and economic diversification
After the Russian economy suffered shocks in the early stages of the escalation of the Ukraine crisis, it has gradually shown resilience. Data released by the Russian Federal State Statistics Service in early February this year show that Russia’s GDP will grow by 3.6% in 2023. However, Western countries' blockade of Russia in the fields of finance, investment, and technological product imports has brought difficulties to the long-term development of the Russian economy. How to continue to hedge against the impact of Western sanctions is a task for Putin's administration.
In his State of the Union address delivered to both houses of parliament at the end of February, Putin stated that factors such as a lack of talent and insufficient own-owned advanced technology may lead to a slowdown in economic growth. Therefore, the country will vigorously strengthen the development of education, science and technology and other fields, and let technological independence become the driving force for industrial upgrading to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of the Russian economy.
He proposed that by 2030, the share of Russia's high-tech products and services in the domestic market should increase by 50%, and the export of non-raw materials and non-energy products should increase by at least two-thirds. Russia should possess key technologies in fields involving citizens' health and food security, and achieve technological independence in fields that can promote sustainable economic development, such as machine tools, robots, transportation, unmanned driving, aviation, oceans, digital economy, new materials and chemistry. , investment in key areas should increase by 70%, and at least 100 more science and technology parks should be built.
Putin said that the current non-resource industries account for more than 90% of Russia's economic growth structure, and the Russian economy is becoming more diversified and sustainable.
Aksakov, chairman of the Financial Markets Committee of the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament), said that the Russian economy is gradually adapting to Western sanctions and is changing rapidly. Western oppression has prompted Russia to vigorously promote the internal restructuring of its economy and speed up its transition away from resource dependence.

continuation of foreign policy
Russian experts believe that resisting Western containment and suppression, uniting friendly countries, and achieving established diplomatic goals will become the focus of Putin's future foreign policy.
Putin has said that no matter who wins the U.S. presidential election in 2024, the U.S. foreign policy toward Russia is unlikely to undergo fundamental changes, and the U.S. will still regard Russia as its enemy.
Mukhin, director of the Russian Political Information Center, said that Putin will continue to take a tough stance against unfriendly countries. Kortunov, an expert at the Russian Council for International Affairs, said that in the coming period, Russia and the United States will continue to have in-depth confrontation, but both sides will still maintain a certain degree of restraint to avoid accidents such as nuclear war.
Russian experts believe that Putin will continue his previous foreign policy, actively develop relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, expand his circle of friends, strengthen his influence in international and regional organizations, and promote world multipolarity.
In addition, some analysts believe that Putin will pay more attention to the relationship between Russia and other BRICS countries in the future and expand this relationship to multiple areas including trade. Mukhin believes that Russia will continue to play an important role within frameworks such as the BRICS cooperation mechanism and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.
input:
Xinhua News Agency, Moscow, March 18 (Reporter Chen Ting, Liu Kai, An Xiaomeng) According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin won 87.19% of the votes. He is significantly ahead of other candidates and has actually won the presidential election.
Analysts believe that after Putin's re-election, Russia's domestic and foreign affairs will continue its existing policies, including focusing on strengthening technological independence, promoting economic diversification, actively developing relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, and promoting the development of a multi-polar world. .

win
The official voting for Russia's eighth presidential election was held from the 15th to the 17th. A total of four candidates participated in the election, including the current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russia's Liberal Democratic Party's Slutsky, the Russian Federation's Communist Party's Kharitonov and the Russian newcomer Davankov of the party.
According to data from the Russian Central Election Commission, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, Putin, Kharitonov, Davankov, and Slutsky received 87.19%, 4.24%, 3.99%, and 3.16% of the votes respectively. .
According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president, so Putin has actually won the election. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed.
In the early morning of the 18th, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters and thanked all voters for their support. He said that Russia will move forward further and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.

Technological independence and economic diversification
After the Russian economy suffered shocks in the early stages of the escalation of the Ukraine crisis, it has gradually shown resilience. Data released by the Russian Federal State Statistics Service in early February this year show that Russia’s GDP will grow by 3.6% in 2023. However, Western countries' blockade of Russia in the fields of finance, investment, and technological product imports has brought difficulties to the long-term development of the Russian economy. How to continue to hedge against the impact of Western sanctions is a task for Putin's administration.
In his State of the Union address delivered to both houses of parliament at the end of February, Putin stated that factors such as a lack of talent and insufficient own-owned advanced technology may lead to a slowdown in economic growth. Therefore, the country will vigorously strengthen the development of education, science and technology and other fields, and let technological independence become the driving force for industrial upgrading to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of the Russian economy.
He proposed that by 2030, the share of Russia's high-tech products and services in the domestic market should increase by 50%, and the export of non-raw materials and non-energy products should increase by at least two-thirds. Russia should possess key technologies in fields involving citizens' health and food security, and achieve technological independence in fields that can promote sustainable economic development, such as machine tools, robots, transportation, unmanned driving, aviation, oceans, digital economy, new materials and chemistry. , investment in key areas should increase by 70%, and at least 100 more science and technology parks should be built.
Putin said that the current non-resource industries account for more than 90% of Russia's economic growth structure, and the Russian economy is becoming more diversified and sustainable.
Aksakov, chairman of the Financial Markets Committee of the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament), said that the Russian economy is gradually adapting to Western sanctions and is changing rapidly. Western oppression has prompted Russia to vigorously promote the internal restructuring of its economy and speed up its transition away from resource dependence.

continuation of foreign policy
Russian experts believe that resisting Western containment and suppression, uniting friendly countries, and achieving established diplomatic goals will become the focus of Putin's future foreign policy.
Putin has said that no matter who wins the U.S. presidential election in 2024, the U.S. foreign policy toward Russia is unlikely to undergo fundamental changes, and the U.S. will still regard Russia as its enemy.
Mukhin, director of the Russian Political Information Center, said that Putin will continue to take a tough stance against unfriendly countries. Kortunov, an expert at the Russian Council for International Affairs, said that in the coming period, Russia and the United States will continue to have in-depth confrontation, but both sides will still maintain a certain degree of restraint to avoid accidents such as nuclear war.
Russian experts believe that Putin will continue his previous foreign policy, actively develop relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, expand his circle of friends, strengthen his influence in international and regional organizations, and promote world multipolarity.
In addition, some analysts believe that Putin will pay more attention to the relationship between Russia and other BRICS countries in the future and expand this relationship to multiple areas including trade. Mukhin believes that Russia will continue to play an important role within frameworks such as the BRICS cooperation mechanism and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.

title: Putin’s vote share nears outer limits but still the only way is up | Vladimir Putin | The Guardian
content:
In 1998 he erected a 12-metre-tall gold-plated statue of himself that rotated to always face the sun.
“An official result of 87% support might seem ridiculous but it’s a logical outcome for the personalist authoritarian system Vladimir Putin has built,” said Ben Noble, an associate professor of Russian politics at University College London.
As he described it, the pressure to improve the results comes from above and below. “The official voting figures are the result both of clear signalling from the presidential administration to produce an even better result than in 2018 and efforts by lower-level officials to impress their superiors, two factors that push the results higher and higher.”
Putin this year needed to make a statement as he faces one of the most turbulent periods of his 25-year rule. These were the first elections since he launched the full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Tensions with the west are at their highest since the cold war. And Russia is facing unprecedented sanctions as its economy becomes dominated by state industries, especially the defence sector.
In his victory speech, Putin drew a direct line between the war and his landslide electoral win. The victory was “due to the drama of the events that the country is going through … due to the fact that we are literally forced to defend the interests of our citizens, our people, with weapons in our hands, to create a future for the full-fledged, sovereign, secure development of the Russian Federation, our homeland,” he said. “The results, and above all the turnout, show that ordinary people feel this and understand that a lot depends on them.”
That is his narrative. Not everyone is buying it. European nations delivered unprecedented criticism of the elections on Monday. Germany said it did not recognise the results as “legitimate” and a spokesperson did not directly address a question about whether Putin would be referred to as “president”. “We don’t have a dialogue with Vladimir Putin so it’s not a question right now,” the spokesperson said.
David Cameron, the UK foreign secretary, said the scale of the victory claimed by Putin “starkly underline[s] the depth of repression under President Putin’s regime, which seeks to silence any opposition to his illegal war”. He said: “Putin removes his political opponents, controls the media and then crowns himself the winner. This is not democracy.”
Members of the Russian opposition had called on the international community to declare the results illegitimate. Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the former oligarch who now lives in exile, said before the vote that one of Putin’s main goals was to show foreign leaders that his control of Russia was strong. He urged them not to endorse the results.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
content:
边境小城的青年：“我希望他能活下来”
顿河畔罗斯托夫坐落于俄罗斯西南部，现拥有110万左右（2015年统计）的人口，是该地区的经济、文化、教育中心，被誉为俄罗斯南方之都，也被视为通向北高加索地区的门户，曾经走出了肖洛霍夫、索尔仁尼琴等文学巨匠。
如今，漫步在城市街头，人们很难想到，它在诞生之初曾是一座为了保护俄罗斯南部边境而设置的要塞，也曾是俄罗斯二战期间受到最严重冲击的城市之一。
当地时间2023年12月5日，俄罗斯顿河畔罗斯托夫。2022年2月后，距离俄乌边境仅有100公里的顿河畔罗斯托夫再度被战火带入了人们的视线。俄乌冲突爆发后，这里成为许多乌东地区民众撤离至俄罗斯境内的第一站。2023年6月，一场“叛乱”又让顿河畔罗斯托夫再起波澜。当时，瓦格纳集团创始人普里戈任从这里起事，一度控制了该市的军事设施，并自此一路前往莫斯科。
安德烈自小生活在这座城市，平日里在家具公司工作，闲暇时则会通过摄影这一爱好赚一点外快。尽管近两年来一直生活在俄乌冲突的阴云之下，但乐观的安德烈在谈到自己的生活和未来的计划时总是充满希望。今年，23岁的他拿到了比去年更高的工资，并且正在物色更合心意的新工作。
“对我个人而言，生活越来越好了。”安德烈对澎湃新闻（www.thepaper.cn）说道。
translation:
Young man from a small border town: "I hope he can survive"
Rostov-on-Don is located in southwestern Russia. It currently has a population of about 1.1 million (statistics in 2015). It is the economic, cultural and educational center of the region. It is known as the capital of the south of Russia and is also regarded as the gateway to the north. The gateway to the Caucasus region once produced literary giants such as Sholokhov and Solzhenitsyn.
Nowadays, when walking on the streets of the city, it is difficult for people to think that it was a fortress set up to protect Russia's southern border when it was first born. It was also one of the cities that was hardest hit by Russia during World War II.
On December 5, 2023 local time, Rostov-on-Don, Russia. After February 2022, Rostov-on-Don, which is only 100 kilometers away from the Russian-Ukrainian border, was once again brought into people's sight by the flames of war. After the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out, this became the first stop for many people from eastern Ukraine to evacuate to Russia. In June 2023, a "rebellion" caused another disturbance in Rostov-on-Don. At that time, Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner Group, started a rebellion here and once took control of the city's military facilities, and then went all the way to Moscow.
Andre has lived in this city since he was a child. He works in a furniture company on weekdays and earns a little extra money through photography as a hobby in his spare time. Although he has been living under the cloud of the Russia-Ukraine conflict for nearly two years, the optimistic Andrei is always full of hope when talking about his life and future plans. This year, the 23-year-old has received a higher salary than last year and is looking for a new job that is more satisfying.
“For me personally, life is getting better and better.” Andre told The Paper (www.thepaper.cn).

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
content:
一是铁腕铲除恐怖势力,还俄国民一个安全的社会环境。

2000年48岁的普京首次担任总统时,俄面临的最大问题是国家面临分裂、国内恐怖活动猖獗,其中骇人听闻的是,2002年10月23日,莫斯科剧院发生人质事件,最终造成129名人质死亡,2004年9月1日车臣分离主义武装分子在俄南部北奥塞梯共和国别斯兰市第一中学制造一起人质事件,最后造成333名人质死亡。

蔓延俄罗斯的恐怖事件灭杀人性,让广大民众生活在极端的恐怖之中,使得俄罗斯民族的精神面临崩溃,也震惊了世界。俄媒体曾称,当时的俄罗斯比其黑暗的中世纪还要恐怖。

恐怖事件的根源是车臣分裂分子。普京以非凡的决心,重拳出击,指令10万大军使用新型武器、装备,历时三年时间,先后以空袭和地面平扫的方式,揣掉了分裂势力的“老窝”,随后便转向铲除流窜各地的恐怖分子。普京最鼓舞人心的誓言“我们必须把恐怖分子从躲藏的地窖和洞穴里赶出来”,“在机场抓住就在机场枪毙,在厕所抓住,就把他们溺死在马桶里”。在他的指挥下,俄武装警察和特种部队,及时包围歼灭了所有恐怖分子,使得俄罗斯民众获得了安全的社会环境,恢复了正常的和谐生活,看到了国家的希望。初试牛刀的普京赢得了民心,威望大增。
translation:
The first is to eradicate terrorist forces with an iron fist and restore a safe social environment to the Russian people.

When the 48-year-old Putin first became president in 2000, the biggest problems facing Russia were the division of the country and rampant domestic terrorist activities. The shocking thing was that on October 23, 2002, a hostage incident occurred in a Moscow theater, resulting in the death of 129 hostages. , On September 1, 2004, Chechen separatist militants caused a hostage incident at the No. 1 Middle School in Beslan City, North Ossetia Republic in southern Russia, resulting in the death of 333 hostages.

The terrorist incidents spreading in Russia have killed humanity and caused the general public to live in extreme terror, causing the Russian nation's spirit to collapse and shocking the world. Russian media once said that Russia at that time was more terrifying than the dark Middle Ages.

The root cause of the terrorist incident is Chechen separatists. With extraordinary determination, Putin struck hard and ordered the 100,000-strong army to use new weapons and equipment. Over a period of three years, he used air strikes and ground sweeps to get rid of the "nests" of the separatist forces, and then turned to eradicating the fleeing forces. Terrorists everywhere. Putin’s most inspiring vows are that “we must drive terrorists out of cellars and caves where they are hiding” and “shoot them if they are caught at the airport, and drown them in the toilet if they are caught in the toilet.” Under his command, the Russian armed police and special forces promptly surrounded and annihilated all terrorists, allowing the Russian people to obtain a safe social environment, restore normal and harmonious life, and see the hope of the country. Putin, who was trying his best for the first time, won the hearts and minds of the people and his prestige increased greatly.
input:
The first is to eradicate terrorist forces with an iron fist and restore a safe social environment to the Russian people.

When the 48-year-old Putin first became president in 2000, the biggest problems facing Russia were the division of the country and rampant domestic terrorist activities. The shocking thing was that on October 23, 2002, a hostage incident occurred in a Moscow theater, resulting in the death of 129 hostages. , On September 1, 2004, Chechen separatist militants caused a hostage incident at the No. 1 Middle School in Beslan City, North Ossetia Republic in southern Russia, resulting in the death of 333 hostages.

The terrorist incidents spreading in Russia have killed humanity and caused the general public to live in extreme terror, causing the Russian nation's spirit to collapse and shocking the world. Russian media once said that Russia at that time was more terrifying than the dark Middle Ages.

The root cause of the terrorist incident is Chechen separatists. With extraordinary determination, Putin struck hard and ordered the 100,000-strong army to use new weapons and equipment. Over a period of three years, he used air strikes and ground sweeps to get rid of the "nests" of the separatist forces, and then turned to eradicating the fleeing forces. Terrorists everywhere. Putin’s most inspiring vows are that “we must drive terrorists out of cellars and caves where they are hiding” and “shoot them if they are caught at the airport, and drown them in the toilet if they are caught in the toilet.” Under his command, the Russian armed police and special forces promptly surrounded and annihilated all terrorists, allowing the Russian people to obtain a safe social environment, restore normal and harmonious life, and see the hope of the country. Putin, who was trying his best for the first time, won the hearts and minds of the people and his prestige increased greatly.

title: 俄罗斯大选 普京获得连任 白宫回应 | 大纪元
content:
他的政治反对派连名字都无法出现在选票上，因为他们不是被迫流亡国外就是已经被普京投入监狱。普京最著名的政治对手奥列克西·纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）上个月在西伯利亚北极圈内的一个监狱中突然离奇死亡。
俄罗斯大选选票上的候选人名单，除了普京外，的确还有其他三位候选人，但是这三人都是遵循克里姆林宫路线的象征性小反对党提出的名不见经传的候选人。

美联社引述观察人士的话说，他们基本或完全不期待俄罗斯举行自由公正的选举。

欧洲理事会主席夏尔·米歇尔（Charles Michel）星期五在社媒X平台上贴文，“祝贺”普京已在俄罗斯总统大选中大获全胜。

“很想祝贺弗拉迪米尔·普京在今天开始的选举中获得压倒性的大胜。没有反对派，没有自由，没有选择，”米歇尔说。

美联社在报道中指出，俄罗斯选民这次除了票投普京之外别无选择，而且对选务和投票的独立监督也形同虚设。

主要的国际观选代表团无一到场。欧洲安全与合作组织（OSCE）的观察员也没有受到邀请。只有登记参选的候选人或政府认可的咨询机构可以向投票所派遣观察员。俄罗斯全国开设了将近10万个投票所，而且投票所开放三天投票，即使真正的独立监督本身就很困难。

“俄罗斯选举整体来看就是一个骗局。克里姆林宫决定什么人可以出现在选票上。克里姆林宫决定这些人如何竞选。掌控投票的方方面面以及整个点票的过程更是不在话下，”美联社引述华盛顿智库欧洲政策分析中心民主韧性计划主任塞缪尔·格林（Sam Greene）的话说。

乌克兰和西方国家强烈谴责普京在俄军占领的乌克兰领土上也举行俄罗斯大选的投票活动。

俄罗斯本来有两名政治人物希望以反战的主题投入大选，而且获得相当多民众真心的支持，但是克里姆林宫禁止这两人参选。

俄罗斯相当分散的反对派呼吁对普京发动入侵乌克兰战争不满的选民在投票最后一天的星期天中午前往投票所表达抗议。纳瓦尔尼生前曾经赞同这一策略。

不过根据纽约时报的报道，莫斯科检察官办公室星期四警告说，抗议是非法的。而且组织或参与抗议有可能导致最高五年监禁的处罚。

美联社认为，普京也是希望利用他这次完全可以预定的胜选表明他对乌克兰发动战争以及他对战事的处理得到绝大多数选民的支持。
translation:
His political opponents cannot even be named on the ballot because they are either forced into exile or have been jailed by Putin. Putin's most prominent political rival, Alexei Navalny, died suddenly and mysteriously in a prison above the Siberian Arctic Circle last month.
Apart from Putin, there are indeed three other candidates on the list of candidates on the Russian election ballot, but these three are all unknown candidates put forward by small, symbolic opposition parties that follow the Kremlin line.

The Associated Press quoted observers as saying they had little or no expectation that Russia would hold free and fair elections.

European Council President Charles Michel posted on the social media platform X on Friday to "congratulate" Putin on his resounding victory in the Russian presidential election.

"I would like to congratulate Vladimir Putin on his landslide victory in the elections that start today. There is no opposition, there is no freedom, there is no choice," Michel said.

The Associated Press pointed out in its report that Russian voters had no choice but to vote for Putin this time, and that independent supervision of elections and voting was ineffective.

None of the major international viewing delegations were present. Observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) were also not invited. Only registered candidates or government-recognized advisory bodies can send observers to polling stations. Nearly 100,000 polling stations have been opened across Russia and are open for three days of voting, even though truly independent oversight is inherently difficult.

"The Russian election as a whole is a sham. The Kremlin decides who gets to be on the ballot. The Kremlin decides how those people run. It controls every aspect of the vote and the entire counting process," the Associated Press quoted Those are the words of Sam Greene, director of the Democratic Resilience Program at the Center for European Policy Analysis, a Washington-based think tank.

Ukraine and Western countries have strongly condemned Putin for holding voting in Russian elections in Ukrainian territory occupied by Russian troops.

Two politicians in Russia originally wanted to run in the general election on an anti-war theme, and they received sincere support from quite a lot of people, but the Kremlin banned these two people from running.

Russia's fragmented opposition has called on voters unhappy with Putin's war in Ukraine to go to the polls at noon on Sunday, the last day of voting, to protest. Navalny had endorsed this strategy during his lifetime.

But the Moscow prosecutor's office warned Thursday that the protests were illegal, according to the New York Times. And organizing or participating in protests can result in penalties of up to five years in prison.

The Associated Press believes that Putin also hopes to use his completely predetermined victory to show that his war in Ukraine and his handling of the war have the support of the vast majority of voters.

Only registered candidates or government-recognized advisory bodies can send observers to polling stations. Nearly 100,000 polling stations have been opened across Russia and are open for three days of voting, even though truly independent oversight is inherently difficult.

"The Russian election as a whole is a sham. The Kremlin decides who gets to be on the ballot. The Kremlin decides how those people run. It controls every aspect of the vote and the entire counting process," the Associated Press quoted Those are the words of Sam Greene, director of the Democratic Resilience Program at the Center for European Policy Analysis, a Washington-based think tank.

Ukraine and Western countries have strongly condemned Putin for holding voting in Russian elections in Ukrainian territory occupied by Russian troops.

Two politicians in Russia originally wanted to run in the general election on an anti-war theme, and they received sincere support from quite a lot of people, but the Kremlin banned these two people from running.

Russia's fragmented opposition has called on voters unhappy with Putin's war in Ukraine to go to the polls at noon on Sunday, the last day of voting, to protest. Navalny had endorsed this strategy during his lifetime.

But the Moscow prosecutor's office warned Thursday that the protests were illegal, according to the New York Times. And organizing or participating in protests can result in penalties of up to five years in prison.

The Associated Press believes that Putin also hopes to use his completely predetermined victory to show that his war in Ukraine and his handling of the war have the support of the vast majority of voters.

title: After ''elections'', Putin resorts to scaring world with World War III in the event of conflict between Russia and NATO | Ukrainska Pravda
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin has said after the country’s "elections" that should there be a conflict between Russia and NATO, the world would be "one step away" from World War III.
Source: European Pravda, citing Kremlin-aligned Russian news agency Interfax
Putin's response to the question of whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO is possible: "I think that everything is possible in today's world."
Details: However, the Russian president said "it is unlikely anyone would be interested in this".
"It is clear to everyone that this [Russo-NATO conflict] would be just one step away from a full-scale World War III," he added.
Background: The Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation predicted a record-breaking "election" victory for Vladimir Putin with 87.5% of the vote.
During a speech at his campaign headquarters, Putin vowed that during his new presidential term, he would pursue the war against Ukraine and strengthen Russia's Armed Forces.
Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas has stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin is trying to intimidate Western nations to deter their actions, but in reality he fears a war with NATO.
Support UP or become our patron!

title: Ukraine appeals to citizens under Russian occupation to ignore Putin’s ‘pseudo elections’ | CNN
content:
One video from Luhansk shows an old woman inside her apartment filling out an election paper and putting it in the ballot box, while a man in army fatigues stands over her with a rifle slung across his chest.
    

            Ukrainian officials say intimidation tactics like that are commonplace and are aimed at forcing people to give their vote to Putin.
    

            For their part, Russian-installed officials in the occupied territories reported several explosions close to polling stations on Saturday, at least some of which Ukraine appeared to acknowledge.
    

            Vladimir Rogov, a member of the civilian-military administration in occupied Zaporizhzhia, said an improvised explosive device had been detonated outside a building to be used for voting in the port city of Berdiansk. A wall had been damaged but there were no casualties, he wrote on Telegram.
    

            Responding, a Ukrainian official wrote ironically on social media, “It’s loud in Berdiansk … it seems there was an unpleasant incident.” Later, the same Ukrainian official reported locals hearing a second explosion in the city, also outside a building scheduled for use as a polling station.
    

            Elsewhere, Vladimir Saldo, the Russian-installed head in occupied Kherson, reported a 50-year-old woman had been killed by a drone strike in the town of Kakhovka, which sits on the Dnipro River. Saldo claimed the attack was an “attempt to destabilize the situation in the town during voting.”
    

            On Friday, he accused Ukraine of shelling a building elsewhere in Kakhovka where voting was taking place. There were no casualties from that attack, he said.
    

            Russia’s election officials have been posting updates on what they say is turnout in the various regions. In occupied Kherson, the figure by 5:30 p.m. on Saturday was put at 77.7%, while in occupied Donetsk the figure just after 9 p.m. Saturday stood at 86.5%.
    

            Ukraine says Moscow will fabricate the final results and insists that the majority of people living under Russian occupation are choosing not to take part in the poll.

title: 普京是否值得第五次连任总统？ | 政治 | 半岛电视台
content:
据政治作家亚历山大·诺沃吉洛夫（Alexander Novogilov）告诉半岛电视台的报道，“普京领导俄罗斯时，俄罗斯正处于经济和政治的危险状态，经济陷入衰退，人口贫困。”他补充道，“北高加索分裂主义运动也创建了自己的飞地，这些飞地随着时间的推移不断扩大，使俄罗斯的领土完整受到直接威胁。”
诺沃吉洛夫继续说道：“新国家元首建立的严格政权能够消除这些威胁并恢复国家权力，并实施广泛的地区和行政改革，恢复了中央与地区之间的互动，并加强国家对那里生活各个方面的控制。”
按照他的说法，“普京能够实现两个主要目标：维护俄罗斯的统一和恢复其在世界舞台上的大国地位。此前它几乎被从全球力量平衡中抹去，十五年后又作为最大、最有影响力的地缘政治和军事参与者之一重返全球舞台。”
在内部问题上，作者举了主要指数增长率等例子，“俄罗斯目前在全球平均水平上处于领先地位，加上俄罗斯经济一直遭受的以通货膨胀为代表的祸害，根据繁荣国家的既定指标，达到了后苏联时期的历史新高”。
这位发言者还提到了社会繁荣的切实改善以及犯罪率的显着下降，“例如，预谋谋杀和谋杀未遂的数量减少了五倍以上”。
另一方面，政治作家谢尔盖·苏尔吉科夫表示：“普京一直无法解决他所说的人口收入差距过大、经济长期投资不足以及投资占国内生产总值比重过低的问题。”
他还指出经济和政治局势持续不可预测，并补充道，“在俄罗斯经营的公司通常更愿意在国外注册财产和交易，以避免可能被国家收购或法院不负责任的决定。”
苏尔吉科夫解释称，除了其他因素外，“由于国家需求疲软，缺乏有前途的高薪工作，而且高科技领域几乎没有私营部门，因此该国出现了合格人才外流的情况”。
这位政治作家自己还认为，独联体国家的一体化进程已经失败，包括白俄罗斯和哈萨克斯坦在内，没有一个国家成为俄罗斯真正的战略盟友，无论是军事上还是政治上，并称其为“情境伙伴关系”。他指出，2014年至2018年的危机完美地证明了这一点，“这些国家在叙利亚、克里米亚和乌克兰问题上的支持在哪里？”
translation:
Political writer Alexander Novogilov told Al Jazeera, “When Putin led Russia, it was in a dangerous state economically and politically, with an economy in recession and a population impoverished.” He added, “Northern Russia was in a dangerous state economically and politically. Caucasian separatist movements have also created their own enclaves, which have expanded over time and put Russia’s territorial integrity at direct risk.”
Novojilov continued: "The strict regime established by the new head of state was able to eliminate these threats and restore state power, and implemented extensive regional and administrative reforms, restored interaction between the center and the regions and strengthened the state's influence on life there Control in every aspect.”
According to him, “Putin was able to achieve two main goals: preserving Russia’s unity and restoring its status as a great power on the world stage. After being almost wiped out of the global balance of power, fifteen years later it became the largest and most powerful country in the world. One of the most influential geopolitical and military players returns to the global stage.”
Regarding internal issues, the author gives examples such as the growth rate of major indices, "Russia currently leads the global average, coupled with the scourge that the Russian economy has been suffering from, represented by inflation, according to established indicators of prosperous countries, reaching reached a record high in the post-Soviet period.”
The speaker also cited tangible improvements in social prosperity and a significant drop in crime rates, "for example, the number of premeditated murders and attempted murders has decreased by more than five times".
On the other hand, political writer Sergei Surdhikov said: "Putin has been unable to solve what he calls the problem of too wide a gap in income among the population, chronic underinvestment in the economy and a low share of investment in gross domestic product."
He also pointed to the continued unpredictability of the economic and political situation, adding that "companies operating in Russia often prefer to register properties and transactions abroad to avoid possible state takeovers or irresponsible court decisions."
Surdhikov explained that, among other factors, "the country is experiencing an outflow of qualified brains due to weak national demand, a lack of promising high-paying jobs and an almost non-existent private sector in high-tech areas".
The political writer himself also believes that the integration process of the CIS countries has failed, and no country, including Belarus and Kazakhstan, has become a true strategic ally of Russia, either militarily or politically, calling it " Situational Partnerships”. He pointed out that the crisis from 2014 to 2018 perfectly demonstrated this point, "Where is the support of these countries on Syria, Crimea and Ukraine?"

title: In Russian presidential election, voting is forced at gunpoint in occupied Ukraine - The Washington Post
content:
“It’s a blatant propaganda exercise.”
Russia’s deputy ambassador to the United Nations, Dmitry Polyanskiy, replied that “like it or not,” Russia was conducting “democratic elections on territories which administratively, politically and economically are part of our country.”
Mykhailo Podolyak, a Ukrainian presidential adviser, said in a post on X, formerly Twitter, that international bodies should no longer recognize Putin’s legitimacy and called for Russia’s suspension from global institutions.
In Berdyansk, an occupied Ukrainian city on the Sea of Azov, a 72-year-old woman reached by phone said that election officials were going door to door, urging people to vote.” That’s how they’re trying to get a higher turnout,” the woman said. She spoke on the condition of anonymity for security reasons.
A 45-year-old woman in Berdyansk, who also spoke on the condition of anonymity, said three women with a ballot box accompanied by an armed soldier visited her home and others.” Those who didn’t vote at home, who they didn’t catch, have to go vote at the polling station,” she said. “Whether I’ll go or not is another question.”
As voting begins in Russian presidential election, so do the protests
Election workers in Mariupol told Russian state-owned RIA Novosti news agency that the election was “peaceful,” and the agency broadcast interviews with voters who said they hoped that life would improve with the region as part of Russia.
RIA Novosti also quoted a pro-Kremlin official in Donetsk claiming that residents were voting in the recently Russian-seized city of Avdiivka, which was almost completely destroyed in fighting with most of the population displaced.
In Russia, the authorities have opened at least 15 criminal cases after a wave of protests at Russian polling stations during the first day of voting on Friday.
A voter was detained in Moscow’s Ramenki district on Saturday for writing “Putin is a murderer” on his ballot, RusNews reported, after a policeman saw his ballot.

title: Putin wins Russian election and talks about Navaln
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin was upbeat after winning a fifth term in power in Russia's presidential election over the weekend. He chose the moment to make his first public remarks on the death of his political nemesis, Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, mentioning his name for the first time in years.
Putin won Russia's presidential election with a landslide 87% of the votes, exit polls suggested late Sunday, with votes still being declared Monday morning, both in Russia and from polls of Russians abroad. The head of Russia's electoral authorities stated Monday morning that voter turnout was a "record-breaking, unprecedented" 77%, up from 67.7% in 2018.
In the highly stage-managed election, each of Putin's three "opponents" on the ballot paper — who belonged to Russia's "systemic" opposition — garnered around 3-4% of the vote.
input:
Russian President Vladimir Putin was upbeat after winning a fifth term in power in Russia's presidential election over the weekend. He chose the moment to make his first public remarks on the death of his political nemesis, Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, mentioning his name for the first time in years.
Putin won Russia's presidential election with a landslide 87% of the votes, exit polls suggested late Sunday, with votes still being declared Monday morning, both in Russia and from polls of Russians abroad. The head of Russia's electoral authorities stated Monday morning that voter turnout was a "record-breaking, unprecedented" 77%, up from 67.7% in 2018.
In the highly stage-managed election, each of Putin's three "opponents" on the ballot paper — who belonged to Russia's "systemic" opposition — garnered around 3-4% of the vote.

title: 枪口之下：被占地区的乌克兰人在俄罗斯选举中支持普京 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
“投票没有任何保密性”，马里乌波尔的一位前居民在谈到她的朋友和亲戚在本周三进行的投票时这样告诉半岛电视台记者。
“热爱乌克兰的人们必须屈服于该政权，并假装他们支持正在发生的一切，因为他们担心自己的生命安全。”
不过她补充称，一些主要由年轻人组成的抵抗组织已向乌克兰情报部门泄露了有关俄罗斯士兵和武器存在的数量与位置的信息。
一些当地人希望，参与投票能让他们真正获得离开被占领地区的自由通行证。
居住在乌克兰南部别尔江斯克港的塔季扬娜告诉半岛电视台记者，“我的公公因心脏病发作去世了。因为我们所经历的事情，我婆婆的头发都变白了。我们只想离开，再也不要回头。”需要指出的是，别尔江斯克港已于2022年2月下旬被占领。
她和她的丈夫在本周一提前投票给普京，这并不奇怪，因为他们并不想被俄罗斯任命的当局列入黑名单。
他们计划越境进入俄罗斯南部，然后乘飞机前往哈萨克斯坦，他们的亲戚同意在那里庇护他们。
据东方人权组织称，少数拒绝投票或者在选举中唱衰的乌克兰人已被围捕并被带往“地下室”——在被俄罗斯占领的顿涅茨克、卢甘斯克、扎波罗热和赫尔松地区有着许多的非正式监狱。
该人权组织以及接受半岛电视台采访的3名乌克兰人（出于安全原因不会使用他们的全名），报道了在被占领地区投票站受到枪支威胁的情况。
因此，安全地说“不”的唯一方法，就是对选举官员关上大门，并避开自本周五开放的投票站——这是俄罗斯为期三天的选举的第一天。
被俄罗斯占领的南部城镇埃涅尔戈达尔的一位前居民表示，“没有人接触”那些呆在家里的人。她逃到了基辅，但仍与家人和朋友保持着联系。
原因很简单——操纵选票，这种现象在俄罗斯之前的选举中已有记录，人们普遍预计这种现象将在乌克兰被占领地区发生得更加明显。
这位前居民打趣道，“我认为投票率将会达到120%到150%。”
观察人士对此表示同意，并称由克里姆林宫任命的官员将在投票操纵方面相互竞争，以报告普京的高投票率和高比例选票。
基辅分析师阿列克谢·库什奇告诉半岛电视台记者，“在虚假选举中，将会出现最大程度的舞弊行为，因为当地的‘总督们’将试图超越‘车臣’。”他所指的是在车臣举行的投票中，普京得到了近100%的投票率和支持率。
translation:
“There is no secrecy about the vote,” a former resident of Mariupol told Al Jazeera of her friends and relatives’ vote on Wednesday.
“People who love Ukraine have to give in to the regime and pretend they support what is happening because they fear for their lives.”
But she added that some resistance groups, mostly made up of young people, had leaked information to Ukrainian intelligence about the number and location of Russian soldiers and weapons.
Some locals hope that taking part in the vote will give them a real free pass to leave the occupied areas.
Tatyana, who lives in the port of Berdyansk in southern Ukraine, told Al Jazeera, “My father-in-law died of a heart attack. My mother-in-law’s hair has turned white because of what we have been through. We just want to leave and never go back. Don’t look back either.” It should be noted that the Port of Berdyansk was occupied in late February 2022.
It was no surprise that she and her husband voted early for Putin on Monday, as they did not want to be blacklisted by Russian-appointed authorities.
They planned to cross into southern Russia and then fly to Kazakhstan, where their relatives agreed to shelter them.
According to Eastern Human Rights Group, a small number of Ukrainians who refused to vote or spoke out against the election have been rounded up and taken to "basements" - in Russian-occupied Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhia and Kazakhstan. There are many informal prisons in the Ersun area.
The rights group and three Ukrainians interviewed by Al Jazeera (whose full names will not be used for security reasons) reported gun threats at polling stations in occupied areas.
So the only way to safely say "no" is to close the door to election officials and avoid polling stations that open from Friday - the first day of Russia's three-day election.
A former resident of the Russian-occupied southern town of Enelgodar said "no one has reached out" to those who stayed home. She fled to Kiev but remained in contact with family and friends.
The reason is simple - vote manipulation, a phenomenon that has been documented in previous elections in Russia and is widely expected to become more pronounced in the occupied areas of Ukraine.
The former resident quipped, "I think the turnout will be 120 to 150 percent."
Observers agreed, saying Kremlin-appointed officials would compete with each other in vote manipulation to report high turnout and a high percentage of votes cast for Putin.
"In a sham election, there will be maximum fraud, because the local 'governors' will try to outdo Chechnya," Kyiv analyst Alexei Kuschi told Al Jazeera. In the vote held in Chechnya, Putin received nearly 100% turnout and support.

The former resident quipped, "I think the turnout will be 120 to 150 percent."
Observers agreed, saying Kremlin-appointed officials would compete with each other in vote manipulation to report high turnout and a high percentage of votes cast for Putin.
"In a sham election, there will be maximum fraud, because the local 'governors' will try to outdo Chechnya," Kyiv analyst Alexei Kuschi told Al Jazeera. In the vote held in Chechnya, Putin received nearly 100% turnout and support.

title: 普京得票超87%，就中俄关系、台湾问题表态
content:
值得注意的是，2024年俄罗斯大选是该国首次战时选举。随着乌克兰去年夏季大反攻失利，俄军数月来不断巩固战场优势，上月拿下乌东重镇阿夫杰耶夫卡，并在扎波罗热等方向对乌军发起进攻。乌克兰则多次袭击俄罗斯炼油厂、炮击俄领土，并试图利用代理人武装部队突破边境，制造多起破坏事件。


	普京在讲话中称，乌克兰军队正轻率地发动攻击，如果敌人喜欢“绞肉机”，对我方甚至有利。


	普京还表示，俄罗斯主张就乌克兰问题进行和平谈判。“我们支持和平谈判，但这并不是因为敌人已经没有弹药了，而是因为，如果他们认真地、从长远来看想要建立和平、良好的关系。”普京说道。


普京：俄罗斯的权力来自人民


	讲话中，普京还感谢选民信任和支持，承诺自己将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。


	他说，俄罗斯是一个大家庭，本次选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望，国家的所有任务都将完成。俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展，变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。


	“俄罗斯的权力来源是俄罗斯人民。”他说，选举不是形式主义的事情，每个俄罗斯公民的选票构成了人民的统一意志，这是国家存在、自信发展、国防能力、科教以及所有重要方向的重要支柱。


	普京还就与美国关系、与北约关系等问题表态。


	普京指出，北约向乌克兰派驻军人并不是什么秘密，俄方对情况非常了解，但这些军人的前景不妙。他说：“我们在那儿听到了法语和英语，首先这对他们来说没什么好处，因为他们在大量死去。”


	当被记者问及俄罗斯和北约之间是否有可能爆发全面冲突时，普京回答说，他认为当今世界“一切皆有可能”，距离爆发世界大战仅有一步之遥，但没有人希望发生这样的事。


	普京表示，俄罗斯准备与美国选民投票支持的任何美国总统合作。“我们对任何一位美国总统候选人都没有偏好，将与选民投信任票的人合作。”





多国对普京胜选表示祝贺


	在普京锁定选举胜局后，多名俄政界人士发出祝贺。


	俄国家杜马主席沃洛金在社交媒体Telegram上发文说：“我祝贺普京在总统选举中取得了令人信服的胜利！这是俄罗斯全体公民的胜利！强大的总统就是强大的俄罗斯！”


	俄罗斯安全会议副主席、统一俄罗斯党主席梅德韦杰夫也发文祝贺：“祝贺普京在俄罗斯总统选举中取得辉煌胜利！”他在电报频道中写道。


	多个国家也对普京表示祝贺。


	古巴驻俄大使波特尔表示，古巴领导人劳尔·卡斯特罗祝贺普京赢得俄总统选举。


	委内瑞拉外交部长伊万·希尔表示，委内瑞拉总统马杜罗祝贺普京赢得总统选举，并指出“投票率非常之高”。他说，马杜罗代表委内瑞拉人民祝贺普京总统在选举中取得“压倒性胜利”。


	波黑塞族共和国主席米洛拉德·多迪克称，普京在俄总统选举中获胜也让视其为朋友和靠山的塞族人民感到高兴。他在社交媒体X上称：“在总统选举中以令人信服的胜利获得第五个任期，证明普京总统深受俄罗斯人民信任以及他正带领国家朝正确的方向行进。”


	玻利维亚总统路易斯·阿尔塞在社交媒体X上祝贺俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京连任，并称他的胜利证实了俄罗斯人民的团结。
translation:
It is worth noting that the 2024 Russian election is the country’s first wartime election. Following the failure of Ukraine's major counteroffensive last summer, the Russian army has continued to consolidate its battlefield advantages over the past few months. Last month, it captured the important town of Avdeyevka in eastern Ukraine and launched attacks on the Ukrainian army in Zaporizhia and other directions. Ukraine has repeatedly attacked Russian oil refineries, shelled Russian territory, and tried to use proxy armed forces to break through the border and cause many sabotage incidents.


Putin said in his speech that the Ukrainian army is launching attacks rashly, and if the enemy likes "meat grinders", it will even be beneficial to us.


Putin also said that Russia advocates peace negotiations on the Ukrainian issue. "We support peace talks, but not because the enemies have run out of ammunition, but because if they are serious about establishing peaceful and good relations in the long run," Putin said.


Putin: Russia's power comes from the people


In his speech, Putin also thanked voters for their trust and support and promised that he would continue to promote national development in the new term.


He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.


"The source of power in Russia is the Russian people." He said that elections are not a formality. The votes of every Russian citizen constitute the unified will of the people, which is the basis for national existence, self-confidence and development, national defense capabilities, science and education, and all important directions. important pillar.


Putin also expressed his stance on issues such as relations with the United States and relations with NATO.


Putin pointed out that it is no secret that NATO has sent soldiers to Ukraine. Russia is very aware of the situation, but the prospects for these soldiers are not good. "We heard French and English there, and first of all it didn't do them any good because they were dying in large numbers," he said.


When asked by a reporter whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO was possible, Putin replied that he believed that "everything is possible" in today's world and that a world war is only one step away, but no one wants such a thing to happen. thing.


Putin said Russia was ready to cooperate with any U.S. president American voters voted for. "We have no preference for any one candidate for President of the United States and will work with the one whom voters give their vote of confidence."





Many countries congratulate Putin on his victory


After Putin sealed his victory in the election, many Russian politicians sent congratulations.


Volodin, Chairman of the Russian State Duma, posted on the social media Telegram: "I congratulate Putin on his convincing victory in the presidential election! This is a victory for all Russian citizens! A strong president is a strong Russia!"


Medvedev, deputy chairman of the Russian Security Council and chairman of the United Russia party, also sent a message of congratulations: "Congratulations to Putin on his brilliant victory in the Russian presidential election!" he wrote on the Telegram channel.


Many countries also congratulated Putin.


Cuban Ambassador to Russia Portel said that Cuban leader Raul Castro congratulated Putin on winning the Russian presidential election.


Venezuelan Foreign Minister Ivan Hill said Venezuelan President Maduro congratulated Putin on winning the presidential election and pointed out that "the turnout was very high." He said that on behalf of the Venezuelan people, Maduro congratulated President Putin on his "overwhelming victory" in the election.


Milorad Dodik, chairman of the Republika Srpska of Bosnia and Herzegovina, said that Putin's victory in the Russian presidential election also pleased the Serb people who regard him as a friend and patron. He said on social media


Bolivian President Luis Arce congratulated Russian President Vladimir Putin on his re-election on social media X, saying that his victory confirmed the unity of the Russian people.

title: News: Vladimir Putin wins 2024 Russian presidential election
content:
Putin claimed another six-year term after a presidential contest in which he faced no real competition. He also broke his silence on opposition leader Aleksei Navalny’s death, calling it an “unfortunate incident.” The final results announced by the CEC during a press conference showed that Putin secured 87.28 of the votes in the election. 

According to recent data, 76,277,708 people voted for Putin. Overall, 3,768,470 people voted for the Community Party’s Nikolai Kharitonov, who came second with 4.31%. The New People Party’s Vladislav Davankov received 3,362,484 votes or 3.85%, and the leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, Leonid Slutsky, received 2,797,629 votes or 3.2%. 

Ella Pamifilova, head of the CEC, said the recent election had the highest voter turnout in the country’s modern history. 
She added that around 87.6 million people cast their votes, and the final voter turnout reached 77.49%, according to the CEC. 
The president is expected to be sworn in on May 7.
input:
Putin claimed another six-year term after a presidential contest in which he faced no real competition. He also broke his silence on opposition leader Aleksei Navalny’s death, calling it an “unfortunate incident.” The final results announced by the CEC during a press conference showed that Putin secured 87.28 of the votes in the election. 

According to recent data, 76,277,708 people voted for Putin. Overall, 3,768,470 people voted for the Community Party’s Nikolai Kharitonov, who came second with 4.31%. The New People Party’s Vladislav Davankov received 3,362,484 votes or 3.85%, and the leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, Leonid Slutsky, received 2,797,629 votes or 3.2%. 

Ella Pamifilova, head of the CEC, said the recent election had the highest voter turnout in the country’s modern history. 
She added that around 87.6 million people cast their votes, and the final voter turnout reached 77.49%, according to the CEC. 
The president is expected to be sworn in on May 7.

title: 热点问答｜俄总统选举，普京何以压倒性胜出-新华网
content:
新华社北京3月18日电　热点问答｜俄总统选举，普京何以压倒性胜出
 新华社记者耿鹏宇
 俄罗斯中央选举委员会18日公布了对俄总统选举100%选票的统计结果，现任总统普京得票率为87.28%。普京的得票率不仅大幅领先，还刷新了个人纪录。在俄面临国内和国际复杂局面的情况下，普京何以取得压倒性胜利？

 3月18日，普京在俄罗斯首都莫斯科的竞选总部回答记者提问。新华社记者曹阳摄
 彰显人民团结
 俄罗斯联邦第八届总统选举正式投票于3月15日至17日举行，共有4名候选人参选。根据选举规则，在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选俄总统。

 3月15日，选民在俄罗斯首都莫斯科参加总统选举投票。新华社记者曹阳摄
 除普京外，俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫得票率为4.31%，排名第二；俄新人党的达万科夫得票率为3.85%，排名第三；俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基排名第四，得票率为3.20%。

 这是3月17日在俄罗斯首都莫斯科街头拍摄的屏幕上的总统选举实时统计数据。18日，俄中央选举委员会还公布了俄总统选举的初步统计结果，投票率为77.44%，创俄罗斯史上新高。
 俄中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃说，俄罗斯采取了各种方式让选民更便利地参与投票。她还说，外部企图干涉本次总统选举的力度前所未有，但选举彰显了俄罗斯人民的团结，为俄现任总统普京投票的选民数量也创下新高。
 帕姆菲洛娃还对来俄监督投票的国际观察员表示感谢。她说，俄中央选举委员会将于3月21日正式公布总统选举结果。
 政绩受到认可
 分析人士指出，普京具有十分丰富的执政经验，在当下俄罗斯面临的复杂局面下，选民希望他继续领导俄罗斯、带领俄罗斯向前发展。

 这是2023年12月7日拍摄的俄罗斯总统普京在莫斯科出席第十四届“俄罗斯在呼唤”论坛的视频画面。
translation:
Xinhua News Agency, Beijing, March 18th Hot Questions and Answers｜Russian presidential election: why Putin won overwhelmingly
 Xinhua News Agency reporter Geng Pengyu
 Russia's Central Election Commission announced the results of 100% of the votes in the Russian presidential election on the 18th. The current President Putin received 87.28% of the votes. Putin's vote share not only led by a large margin, but also set a new personal record. How did Putin achieve an overwhelming victory when Russia faced complex domestic and international situations?

 On March 18, Putin answered questions from reporters at the campaign headquarters in Moscow, the Russian capital. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
 Demonstrate people's unity
 The official voting for the eighth presidential election of the Russian Federation was held from March 15 to 17, with a total of four candidates running. According to the election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected as the president of Russia.

 On March 15, voters voted in the presidential election in Moscow, the capital of Russia. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
 In addition to Putin, Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.31% of the vote; Davankov of the New People's Party of Russia ranked third with 3.85% of the vote; Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked third Fourth, the vote rate was 3.20%.

 This is the real-time statistics of the presidential election on a screen taken on the streets of the Russian capital Moscow on March 17. On the 18th, the Russian Central Election Commission also announced the preliminary statistical results of the Russian presidential election. The turnout rate was 77.44%, a new high in Russian history.
 Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that Russia has adopted various methods to make it more convenient for voters to participate in voting. She also said that external attempts to interfere in this presidential election were unprecedented, but the election demonstrated the unity of the Russian people, and the number of voters who voted for the current Russian President Vladimir Putin also reached a new high.
 Pamfilova also expressed her gratitude to the international observers who came to Russia to monitor the voting. She said that the Russian Central Election Commission will officially announce the results of the presidential election on March 21.
 Achievements recognized
 Analysts pointed out that Putin has very rich experience in governing. Under the complex situation currently facing Russia, voters hope that he will continue to lead Russia and lead Russia to move forward.

 This is a video shot of Russian President Putin attending the 14th "Russia is Calling" forum in Moscow on December 7, 2023.

title: Putin cultivates leader for life image in landslide win without competition - The Washington Post
content:
Mark Galeotti, a Russia analyst at University College London’s School of Slavonic and East European Studies, said this outcome of the vote showed that Putin’s regime has shifted from an earlier model of “managed democracy” and is now “heading into its banana republic stage.”
“We should see elections under Putin as not being about popular sovereignty, but about popular subordination,” Galeotti said. “It is about the masses voting to accept Putin as their czar.”
He added: “It’s not just that the Kremlin is no longer embarrassed to rig the election. I think it’s almost, ‘So, what can you do about it?’ — a kind of challenge to civil society, ‘Of course you know we’re lying, but you’re going to have to swallow it because you’ve got no alternative.’”
Russians, by choice or not, are now locked into Putin’s repressive, increasingly totalitarian path — his bloody war in Ukraine and decisions to shun the West, isolate Russia’s economy and escalate hostility toward NATO. Western leaders, meanwhile, face a strident, emboldened adversary in command of a nuclear arsenal.
In autocracies, much of politics ends up revolving around the obsessions of the supreme leader — in Putin’s case, eliminating all personal political competition and destroying Ukraine as a large and thriving Western-leaning democracy on Russia’s border.
It was telling that Putin mentioned both of those threats in his late-night victory address.

“We should see elections under Putin as not being about popular sovereignty, but about popular subordination,” Galeotti said. “It is about the masses voting to accept Putin as their czar.”
He added: “It’s not just that the Kremlin is no longer embarrassed to rig the election. I think it’s almost, ‘So, what can you do about it?’ — a kind of challenge to civil society, ‘Of course you know we’re lying, but you’re going to have to swallow it because you’ve got no alternative.’”
Russians, by choice or not, are now locked into Putin’s repressive, increasingly totalitarian path — his bloody war in Ukraine and decisions to shun the West, isolate Russia’s economy and escalate hostility toward NATO. Western leaders, meanwhile, face a strident, emboldened adversary in command of a nuclear arsenal.
In autocracies, much of politics ends up revolving around the obsessions of the supreme leader — in Putin’s case, eliminating all personal political competition and destroying Ukraine as a large and thriving Western-leaning democracy on Russia’s border.
It was telling that Putin mentioned both of those threats in his late-night victory address.

title: Putin claims a new six-year term in vote condemned as not free or fair - The Washington Post
content:
“Crimea is not only a strategically important territory, with important history and traditions. Crimea is first of all people. Sevastopol residents, Crimeans. They are our pride,” Putin said, pledging to build a railroad connecting Russia with Crimea through Donetsk and Mariupol, other Ukrainian cities occupied by Russia that Putin illegally claims to have annexed.
Putin’s astronomical election win — with almost 90 percent of the vote — has drawn comparisons to other rogue, internationally isolated dictators who blatantly manipulate electoral results to secure their power.
Western nations, including the United States, flocked to condemn the results, which were marred by protests and cases of voting fraud.
“Russia’s election was an election without choice,” German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock said at the start of a summit of European foreign ministers in Brussels on Monday, asserting that the Russian election was not a real election. She said that the European Union would formulate new sanctions against Russia.
In a column for the Telegraph, British Defense Minister Grant Shapps said Putin is behaving like a “modern-day Stalin” after winning an election in which he had practically no opponents.
Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani wrote that the elections were “neither free nor regular” and that they had been held in “illegally occupied Ukrainian territories.”
The Russian electoral watchdog, Golos, which has monitored elections in Russia for 20 years, said in a statement Monday that “never before have we seen a presidential campaign that was so inconsistent with constitutional standards.”

“Crimea is not only a strategically important territory, with important history and traditions. Crimea is first of all people. Sevastopol residents, Crimeans. They are our pride,” Putin said, pledging to build a railroad connecting Russia with Crimea through Donetsk and Mariupol, other Ukrainian cities occupied by Russia that Putin illegally claims to have annexed.
Putin’s astronomical election win — with almost 90 percent of the vote — has drawn comparisons to other rogue, internationally isolated dictators who blatantly manipulate electoral results to secure their power.
Western nations, including the United States, flocked to condemn the results, which were marred by protests and cases of voting fraud.
“Russia’s election was an election without choice,” German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock said at the start of a summit of European foreign ministers in Brussels on Monday, asserting that the Russian election was not a real election. She said that the European Union would formulate new sanctions against Russia.
In a column for the Telegraph, British Defense Minister Grant Shapps said Putin is behaving like a “modern-day Stalin” after winning an election in which he had practically no opponents.
Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani wrote that the elections were “neither free nor regular” and that they had been held in “illegally occupied Ukrainian territories.”
The Russian electoral watchdog, Golos, which has monitored elections in Russia for 20 years, said in a statement Monday that “never before have we seen a presidential campaign that was so inconsistent with constitutional standards.”

title: 俄罗斯大选 普京获得连任 白宫回应 | 大纪元
content:
为期三天的俄罗斯大选周日（3月17日）结束。出口民调显示，普京以逾87%的支持率赢得大选，获得连任。白宫和欧洲多个国家批评这次选举既不自由也不公正。
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会在投票结束后公布的首份官方结果，在完成大约80%选区计票的情况下，现任总统普京获得约87%的得票率。
民调机构民意基金会（FOM）的出口民调显示，普京赢得了87.8%的选票，这是俄罗斯后苏联历史上的最高得票率，超过了普京在2018年选举中获得的77%的支持率；俄罗斯民意研究中心（VCIOM）的出口民调显示，普京获得87%的支持率。
其他三位总统候选人均来自忠于克里姆林宫的政党，在大选中获得的支持率都不到4%。普京最知名的政治对手是上个月在北极流放地去世的阿列克谢‧纳瓦尼（Alexei Navalny）。他的支持者呼吁俄罗斯选民周日到投票站参加“中午反普京”抗议活动，以表达他们异议声音。
普京在莫斯科发表胜选演讲时告诉支持者，他将优先解决他所说的俄罗斯在乌克兰的“特别军事行动”相关任务，并将加强俄罗斯军队。
根据国家电视台显示的中央选举委员会的数据，本次大选初步投票率为74.22%。这是自1991年苏联解体后鲍里斯‧叶利钦（Boris Yeltsin）就任总统以来的最高投票率，远高于2018年记录的67.5%的投票率。至少有6个俄罗斯地区声称投票率超过90%。
国际文传电讯社（Interfax）援引政府数据报导说，近450万人进行了线上投票。
translation:
The three-day Russian general election ends on Sunday (March 17). Exit polls showed that Putin won the election with more than 87% support and was re-elected. The White House and many European countries criticized the election as neither free nor fair.
According to the first official results released by Russia's Central Election Commission after the voting, with about 80% of the votes in precincts completed, current President Vladimir Putin received about 87% of the vote.
Exit polls from the polling agency Public Opinion Foundation (FOM) showed that Putin won 87.8% of the vote, the highest vote share in Russia's post-Soviet history, surpassing the 77% support Putin received in the 2018 election ; Exit polls from the Russian Center for Public Opinion Research (VCIOM) showed that Putin received an approval rating of 87%.
The other three presidential candidates, all from parties loyal to the Kremlin, received less than 4% support in the general election. Putin's most high-profile political rival was Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic exile last month. His supporters called on Russian voters to attend "noon anti-Putin" protests at polling stations on Sunday to express their dissent.
Putin told supporters in a victory speech in Moscow that he would prioritize tasks related to what he called Russia's "special military operations" in Ukraine and would strengthen the Russian military.
According to data from the Central Election Commission shown on state television, the preliminary turnout for this election was 74.22%. It was the highest turnout since Boris Yeltsin became president after the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, and well above the 67.5% turnout recorded in 2018. At least six Russian regions claimed turnout exceeded 90%.
Nearly 4.5 million people voted online, the Interfax news agency reported, citing government data.
input:
The three-day Russian general election ends on Sunday (March 17). Exit polls showed that Putin won the election with more than 87% support and was re-elected. The White House and many European countries criticized the election as neither free nor fair.
According to the first official results released by Russia's Central Election Commission after the voting, with about 80% of the votes in precincts completed, current President Vladimir Putin received about 87% of the vote.
Exit polls from the polling agency Public Opinion Foundation (FOM) showed that Putin won 87.8% of the vote, the highest vote share in Russia's post-Soviet history, surpassing the 77% support Putin received in the 2018 election ; Exit polls from the Russian Center for Public Opinion Research (VCIOM) showed that Putin received an approval rating of 87%.
The other three presidential candidates, all from parties loyal to the Kremlin, received less than 4% support in the general election. Putin's most high-profile political rival was Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic exile last month. His supporters called on Russian voters to attend "noon anti-Putin" protests at polling stations on Sunday to express their dissent.
Putin told supporters in a victory speech in Moscow that he would prioritize tasks related to what he called Russia's "special military operations" in Ukraine and would strengthen the Russian military.
According to data from the Central Election Commission shown on state television, the preliminary turnout for this election was 74.22%. It was the highest turnout since Boris Yeltsin became president after the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, and well above the 67.5% turnout recorded in 2018. At least six Russian regions claimed turnout exceeded 90%.
Nearly 4.5 million people voted online, the Interfax news agency reported, citing government data.

title: Putin basks in election win that was never in doubt even as Russians quietly protest  : NPR
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin basked in a victory early Monday that was never in doubt, as partial election results showed him easily securing a fifth term after facing only token challengers and harshly suppressing opposition voices.
With little margin for protest, Russians crowded outside polling stations at noon Sunday, on the last day of the election, apparently heeding an opposition call to express their displeasure with Putin. Still, the impending landslide underlined that Russian leader would accept nothing less than full control of the country's political system as he extends his nearly quarter-century rule for six more years.
Putin hailed the early results as an indication of "trust" and "hope" in him — while critics saw them as another reflection of the preordained nature of the election.
"Of course, we have lots of tasks ahead. But I want to make it clear for everyone: When we were consolidated, no one has ever managed to frighten us, to suppress our will and our self-conscience. They failed in the past and they will fail in the future," Putin said at a meeting with volunteers after polls closed.
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter: "The polls have closed in Russia, following the illegal holding of elections on Ukrainian territory, a lack of choice for voters and no independent OSCE monitoring. This is not what free and fair elections look like."
Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled. Independent media have been crippled. His fiercest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic prison last month, and other critics are either in jail or in exile.
Beyond the fact that voters had virtually no choice, independent monitoring of the election was extremely limited. According to Russia's Central Election Commission, Putin had some 87% of the vote with about 90% of precincts counted.
In that tightly controlled environment, Navalny's associates urged those unhappy with Putin or the war in Ukraine to go to the polls at noon on Sunday — and lines outside a number of polling stations both inside Russia and at its embassies around the world appeared to swell at that time.

They failed in the past and they will fail in the future," Putin said at a meeting with volunteers after polls closed.
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter: "The polls have closed in Russia, following the illegal holding of elections on Ukrainian territory, a lack of choice for voters and no independent OSCE monitoring. This is not what free and fair elections look like."

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
content:
新人党被认为是一个中右翼政党，受到年轻人的欢迎，主要活跃在俄中西部经济相对发达的地区。2021年，该党越过5%的得票率门槛，进入俄国家杜马。据《参考消息》此前报道，当时任新人党执委会主席一职的达万科夫在接受俄罗斯《观点报》采访时说，新人党能够听到年轻人的心声，这是该党得以进入国家杜马的关键因素之一。他说：“我们的积极分子来自各个城市，都是一些年龄在20岁到27岁之间的年轻人。”
同年，达万科夫当选俄罗斯国家杜马副主席。2022年俄乌冲突爆发后，达万科夫因支持顿涅茨克、卢甘斯克独立以及俄对乌“特别军事行动”而受到西方国家制裁。2023年，达万科夫曾竞选莫斯科市长，但最终未能获胜。当时，他获得了5.34%的选票，在5名候选人中排名第4。
2023年12月24日，新人党和成长党联合提名达万科夫参加俄罗斯总统选举。同日，两党宣布合并。2024年1月5日，俄罗斯中央选举委员会正式批准达万科夫参选。
2月，达万科夫提交了自己的竞选纲领，经济领域内容包括发展创业精神、优化国家开支等，政治领域内容则包括外交政策的“正常化和民主化”，其中的要点之一就是“按照俄罗斯的条件”、通过谈判解决俄乌冲突。据达万科夫介绍，这是一项“和平发展”的纲领。“我曾多次被问及我的立场。我认为首先应该进行谈判。但非常重要的是，这些谈判应当让我们的俄罗斯变得独立和强大。”达万科夫还补充道，“我们都希望我们的国家强大而伟大，但不仅仅是让人畏惧，而是要为其成就、人民、成功和经济增长率感到自豪。”
此外，达万科夫还曾表示，他不会批评其他总统候选人，包括现任总统普京。
斯卢茨基：不梦想打败普京，希望在特别军事行动中获胜
列昂尼德·斯卢茨基1968年出生于莫斯科，自由民主党领导人，现为俄国家杜马国际事务委员会主席。
translation:
The New People's Party is considered a center-right party that is popular among young people and is mainly active in the relatively economically developed regions of central and western Russia. In 2021, the party crossed the 5% vote threshold and entered the Russian State Duma. According to a previous report by "Reference News", Davankov, who was the chairman of the New People's Party's executive committee at the time, said in an interview with the Russian "Viewpoint" newspaper that the New People's Party can hear the voices of young people, which is the reason why the party can enter One of the key elements of the State Duma. He said: "Our activists come from various cities and are young people between the ages of 20 and 27."
In the same year, Davankov was elected deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma. After the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in 2022, Davankov was sanctioned by Western countries for supporting the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk and Russia's "special military operations" against Ukraine. In 2023, Davankov ran for mayor of Moscow, but ultimately failed to win. At that time, he received 5.34% of the votes, ranking 4th among 5 candidates.
On December 24, 2023, the New People Party and the Growth Party jointly nominated Davankov to participate in the Russian presidential election. On the same day, the two parties announced their merger. On January 5, 2024, Russia’s Central Election Commission officially approved Davankov’s candidacy.
In February, Davankov submitted his own campaign platform. The economic content included the development of entrepreneurship and the optimization of national expenditures, while the political content included the "normalization and democratization" of foreign policy. One of the key points was " "According to Russia's terms" and resolve the Russian-Ukrainian conflict through negotiations. According to Davankov, this is a program of "peaceful development". "I have been asked many times about my position. I believe that first of all there should be negotiations. But it is very important that these negotiations should allow our Russia to become independent and strong." Davankov also added, "We all "We want our country to be strong and great, but not just to be feared, but to be proud of its achievements, its people, its success and its economic growth rate."
In addition, Davankov has also stated that he will not criticize other presidential candidates, including current President Putin.
Slutsky: I don’t dream of defeating Putin, I hope to win in special military operations
Leonid Slutsky was born in Moscow in 1968. He is the leader of the Liberal Democratic Party and currently the chairman of the International Affairs Committee of the Russian State Duma.

title: Russia election: Putin basks in electoral victory even as Russians quietly protest | AP News
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin basked in a victory early Monday that was never in doubt, as partial election results showed him easily securing a fifth term after facing only token challengers and harshly suppressing opposition voices.
With little margin for protest, Russians crowded outside polling stations at noon Sunday, on the last day of the election, apparently heeding an opposition call to express their displeasure with Putin. Still, the impending landslide underlined that Russian leader would accept nothing less than full control of the country’s political system as he extends his nearly quarter-century rule for six more years. 
Putin hailed the early results as an indication of “trust” and “hope” in him — while critics saw them as another reflection of the preordained nature of the election.
“Of course, we have lots of tasks ahead. But I want to make it clear for everyone: When we were consolidated, no one has ever managed to frighten us, to suppress our will and our self-conscience. They failed in the past and they will fail in the future,” Putin said at a meeting with volunteers after polls closed.
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter: “The polls have closed in Russia, following the illegal holding of elections on Ukrainian territory, a lack of choice for voters and no independent OSCE monitoring. This is not what free and fair elections look like.”
Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled.
