title: 普京的总统就职仪式将于5月7日举行
content:
综合俄罗斯媒体报道，当地时间3月21日，普京就俄罗斯总统选举结果发表讲话。俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃当日正式宣布，俄罗斯现任总统普京赢得2024年总统选举。
资料图：俄罗斯总统普京。

据俄新社报道，普京表示，“选举表明，今天的俄罗斯是一个友好的大家庭，我们沿着选定的历史道路共同前进。”
普京还称，感谢所有在选举中投票的选民，并称俄罗斯民众投出的每一票都有重要意义。
普京承诺，将尽一切努力不辜负选民的信任。
报道称，许多俄罗斯人认为，普京带来了秩序和稳定。普京自上任以来，在俄罗斯国内长期拥有极高的民众支持率。
“今日俄罗斯”(RT)报道介绍，俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间21日正式宣布，俄罗斯现任总统普京获得87.28%的选票，在选举中获得“压倒性胜利”。普京的总统就职仪式将于5月7日举行。
translation:
According to Russian media reports, on March 21, local time, Putin delivered a speech on the results of the Russian presidential election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced that day that current Russian President Vladimir Putin won the 2024 presidential election.
File photo: Russian President Putin.

According to RIA Novosti, Putin said, “The election showed that today’s Russia is a friendly family and we are moving forward together along the chosen historical path.”
Putin also expressed his gratitude to all voters who voted in the election and said that every vote cast by the Russian people is important.
Putin promised to do everything possible to live up to the trust of voters.
According to reports, many Russians believe that Putin has brought order and stability. Since Putin took office, he has enjoyed extremely high public support in Russia for a long time.
"Russia Today" (RT) reported that Russia's Central Election Commission officially announced on the 21st local time that Russia's current President Vladimir Putin received 87.28% of the votes and won an "overwhelming victory" in the election. Putin's presidential inauguration ceremony will be held on May 7.
input:
According to Russian media reports, on March 21, local time, Putin delivered a speech on the results of the Russian presidential election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced that day that current Russian President Vladimir Putin won the 2024 presidential election.
File photo: Russian President Putin.

According to RIA Novosti, Putin said, “The election showed that today’s Russia is a friendly family and we are moving forward together along the chosen historical path.”
Putin also expressed his gratitude to all voters who voted in the election and said that every vote cast by the Russian people is important.
Putin promised to do everything possible to live up to the trust of voters.
According to reports, many Russians believe that Putin has brought order and stability. Since Putin took office, he has enjoyed extremely high public support in Russia for a long time.
"Russia Today" (RT) reported that Russia's Central Election Commission officially announced on the 21st local time that Russia's current President Vladimir Putin received 87.28% of the votes and won an "overwhelming victory" in the election. Putin's presidential inauguration ceremony will be held on May 7.

title: 欧盟和北约：俄大选既不自由也不公平 | 德国之声 来自德国 介绍德国 | DW | 15.03.2024
content:
（德国之声中文网）俄罗斯总统选举已经开始投票。在其全国投票站开放前一天，欧盟和北约均表示，俄罗斯总统选举既不自由也不公平。
欧盟发言人斯塔诺（Peter Stano）说：“从俄罗斯现任政府如何准备和组织投票的过往记录，我们就能知道这场选举将会是什么样子。”
斯塔诺说：“很难预测这将是一次自由、公正和民主的选举，俄罗斯人民将真正拥有选择权。”
北约秘书长斯托尔滕贝格指出，俄罗斯没有可以存活的反对派或新闻自由。
他说：“我们已经知道，反对派政治家被关进监狱，一些人被杀害，许多人流亡海外，实际上还有一些试图登记参选的人被剥夺了这一权利。”
俄罗斯总统选举在本周末进行，为期三天（3月15日至17日）。
俄罗斯总统普京将与克里姆林宫批准的三名候选人对决。没有真正的反对党候选人获准参选。
背景阅读：普京——昔日克格勃的权力登顶之路
预计选举结果将让普京再次执政六年，这将使他的总任期超过自叶卡捷琳娜大帝以来的任何一位俄罗斯统治者。
 
著名反对党领袖纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）上个月在服刑的监狱中去世，他的妻子纳瓦尔娜亚（Yulia Navalnaya）呼吁在投票站举行抗议活动。
俄罗斯当局警告不要举行任何示威活动。
莫斯科检察官在Telegram上说：“根据现行法律，组织和参与此类群体性活动将受到惩罚。”
虽然俄罗斯的投票周五才开始，但其去年吞并的乌克兰四个地区的投票已于周四开始。
据报道，生活在俄罗斯占领下的乌克兰人被胁迫投票，莫斯科敦促乌克兰人投票“支持他们的总统”，并“参与我们国家的未来”。
俄罗斯当局派出了许多流动投票站，有的就在人们家门口，声称这样投票更安全。
 部分被俄罗斯占领的顿涅茨克州马里乌波尔市的乌克兰市长博伊琴科（Vadym Boychenko）形容俄罗斯在“废墟中进行选举”。
他通报说，一名妇女拿着投票箱出现在他邻居的公寓里，“由两名拿着机关枪的车臣军人陪同”，并明确表示投票不是可选的。
华盛顿欧洲政策分析中心主任格林（Sam Greene）说：“选举是军事占领和战争本身的延伸……而不是民主选举权的行使。”
欧盟表示不会承认这四个地区的投票结果。斯托尔滕贝格说：“俄罗斯试图在乌克兰被占领地区组织的任何选举都是完全非法的，违反了国际法。”
在投票前，乌克兰加强了对俄罗斯边境地区的空中反击。
周四，对别尔哥罗德的袭击造成至少两人死亡。而俄罗斯国民警卫队表示，他们也在库尔斯克击退了亲乌克兰民兵的进攻。  
（法新社、美联社）
©2024年德国之声版权声明：本文所有内容受到著作权法保护，如无德国之声特别授权，不得擅自使用。任何不当行为都将导致追偿，并受到刑事追究。
translation:
(Deutsche Welle Chinese website) Voting has begun in the Russian presidential election. A day before polling stations opened across the country, the European Union and Nato both said Russia's presidential election was neither free nor fair.
EU spokesman Peter Stano said: "We can know what this election will look like from the track record of how the current Russian government prepares and organizes the vote."
"It is difficult to predict that this will be a free, fair and democratic election in which the Russian people will truly have a choice," Stano said.
NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg pointed out that there is no viable opposition or free press in Russia.
"We already know that opposition politicians have been jailed, some have been killed, many have gone into exile, and some who have actually tried to register to run have been denied that right," he said.
The Russian presidential election takes place this weekend and lasts for three days (March 15-17).
Russian President Vladimir Putin will face off against three Kremlin-approved candidates. No real opposition candidate was allowed to run.
Background reading: Putin – the former KGB’s path to power
The election results are expected to give Putin another six years in power, which would make his total term longer than that of any Russian ruler since Catherine the Great.
 
Prominent opposition leader Alexei Navalny died in prison last month, and his wife Yulia Navalnaya called for protests at polling stations.
Russian authorities have warned against any demonstrations.
"Organizing and participating in such group activities will be punished under current law," the Moscow prosecutor said on Telegram.
While voting in Russia only begins on Friday, voting began on Thursday in four Ukrainian regions it annexed last year.
Ukrainians living under Russian occupation were reportedly coerced into voting, with Moscow urging Ukrainians to vote "for their president" and "participate in the future of our country."
Russian authorities have deployed mobile polling stations, some on people's doorsteps, claiming that voting is safer this way.
 Vadym Boychenko, the Ukrainian mayor of Mariupol in the Donetsk Oblast, which is partially occupied by Russia, described Russia as conducting elections "in ruins."
He informed that a woman showed up at his neighbor's apartment with a ballot box "accompanied by two Chechen soldiers with machine guns" and made it clear that voting was not optional.
Sam Greene, director of the Center for European Policy Analysis in Washington, said: "Elections are an extension of military occupation and war itself... rather than an exercise of the democratic right to vote."
The EU said it would not recognize the vote results in the four regions. "Any election that Russia attempts to organize in the occupied areas of Ukraine is completely illegal and violates international law," Stoltenberg said.
Ahead of the vote, Ukraine stepped up its air strikes against Russia's border areas.
At least two people were killed in an attack on Belgorod on Thursday. The Russian National Guard said they also repelled an attack by pro-Ukrainian militias in Kursk. ​
(AFP, AP)
©2024 Deutsche Welle Copyright Statement: All contents of this article are protected by copyright law and may not be used without special authorization from Deutsche Welle. Any misconduct will result in recovery of damages and criminal prosecution.
​

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
content:
n澎湃新闻：近年来，俄与西方关系日益恶化，并在2022年后跌入谷底。未来俄罗斯与西方关系是否还有转圜的余地？美国大选会否令俄罗斯当前所面临的外部环境发生变化？
安德烈·科尔图诺夫：俄罗斯与西方国家关系的恶化是严重的、长期的。在政治上应该避免使用“永远”这个词，但我看不到俄罗斯在不久的将来转向西方的前景。俄罗斯与西方关系的某些层面，例如俄罗斯与欧盟在能源领域的战略伙伴关系，已经遭到不可逆转的破坏。目前的俄乌冲突结束后，某些方面可以恢复，例如正常的外交互动、直航或教育和文化合作，但俄罗斯与西方的关系不会再回到过去的互动模式。
至于美国大选，我不会过高估计其对美俄关系未来的重要性：毕竟，特朗普曾在2017年-2022年期间成为白宫的主人，而在那期间，俄美两国之间的关系不仅没有改善，反而变得更糟。当然，人们希望在美国新一轮政治周期开始后，俄美两国关系至少能趋于稳定。
澎湃新闻：在当前西方持续援乌、欧洲军控体系失效、俄乌和谈前景不明的背景下，俄乌冲突会否演变为一场更大规模的战争？
安德烈·科尔图诺夫：不幸的是，这种危险确实存在。北约国家现在越来越多地被卷入冲突，一些政治家，比如法国总统马克龙，正在谈论向乌克兰派遣西方军队的可能性。冲突事关重大，任何一方都不愿意承认对手的胜利。此外，考虑到技术失误、意料之外的局势升级或其他不利情况，俄罗斯与北约之间发生直接军事冲突的可能性无法完全排除。
translation:
nThe Paper: In recent years, relations between Russia and the West have deteriorated day by day, and will hit rock bottom after 2022. Is there room for improvement in the future relations between Russia and the West? Will the U.S. election change the external environment Russia is currently facing?
Andrei Kortunov: The deterioration of relations between Russia and Western countries is serious and long-term. The word "forever" should be avoided in politics, but I see no prospect of Russia turning to the West in the near future. Some aspects of Russia’s relations with the West, such as Russia’s strategic partnership with the EU in the energy sector, have been irreversibly damaged. After the current Russian-Ukrainian conflict is over, some aspects can resume, such as normal diplomatic interactions, direct flights, or educational and cultural cooperation, but relations between Russia and the West will not return to the past interaction model.
As for the US election, I would not overestimate its importance for the future of US-Russian relations: after all, Trump was the occupant of the White House from 2017 to 2022, and during that period, the relationship between Russia and the US Not only did it not improve, it got worse. Of course, people hope that after the start of a new political cycle in the United States, relations between Russia and the United States can at least stabilize.
The Paper: In the current context of continued Western aid to Ukraine, the failure of the European arms control system, and uncertain prospects for Russia-Ukraine peace talks, will the Russia-Ukraine conflict evolve into a larger-scale war?
Andrei Kortunov: Unfortunately, this danger is real. NATO countries are now increasingly drawn into the conflict, and some politicians, such as French President Emmanuel Macron, are talking about the possibility of sending Western troops to Ukraine. The stakes of the conflict are high, and neither side is willing to concede victory to its opponent. Furthermore, the possibility of a direct military conflict between Russia and NATO cannot be completely ruled out, taking into account technical errors, unexpected escalations, or other adverse circumstances.
input:
nThe Paper: In recent years, relations between Russia and the West have deteriorated day by day, and will hit rock bottom after 2022. Is there room for improvement in the future relations between Russia and the West? Will the U.S. election change the external environment Russia is currently facing?
Andrei Kortunov: The deterioration of relations between Russia and Western countries is serious and long-term. The word "forever" should be avoided in politics, but I see no prospect of Russia turning to the West in the near future. Some aspects of Russia’s relations with the West, such as Russia’s strategic partnership with the EU in the energy sector, have been irreversibly damaged. After the current Russian-Ukrainian conflict is over, some aspects can resume, such as normal diplomatic interactions, direct flights, or educational and cultural cooperation, but relations between Russia and the West will not return to the past interaction model.
As for the US election, I would not overestimate its importance for the future of US-Russian relations: after all, Trump was the occupant of the White House from 2017 to 2022, and during that period, the relationship between Russia and the US Not only did it not improve, it got worse. Of course, people hope that after the start of a new political cycle in the United States, relations between Russia and the United States can at least stabilize.
The Paper: In the current context of continued Western aid to Ukraine, the failure of the European arms control system, and uncertain prospects for Russia-Ukraine peace talks, will the Russia-Ukraine conflict evolve into a larger-scale war?
Andrei Kortunov: Unfortunately, this danger is real. NATO countries are now increasingly drawn into the conflict, and some politicians, such as French President Emmanuel Macron, are talking about the possibility of sending Western troops to Ukraine. The stakes of the conflict are high, and neither side is willing to concede victory to its opponent. Furthermore, the possibility of a direct military conflict between Russia and NATO cannot be completely ruled out, taking into account technical errors, unexpected escalations, or other adverse circumstances.

title:
China and North Korea applaud Putin's election victory -
                        Nikkei Asia
content:
TOKYO -- China and North Korea applauded Russian President Vladimir Putin's victory in a virtually opponent-less election, standing in contrast to the West's condemnation of a poll that the U.S. called "not free nor fair."
In a message to Putin relayed by state media, Chinese President Xi Jinping said: "Your re-election fully reflects the support of the Russian people. I believe that under your leadership, Russia will achieve greater national development."
input:
TOKYO -- China and North Korea applauded Russian President Vladimir Putin's victory in a virtually opponent-less election, standing in contrast to the West's condemnation of a poll that the U.S. called "not free nor fair."
In a message to Putin relayed by state media, Chinese President Xi Jinping said: "Your re-election fully reflects the support of the Russian people. I believe that under your leadership, Russia will achieve greater national development."

title: 俄中央选举委员会：目前有11人将参加2024年总统选举
content:
当地时间11日，俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃表示，目前有11名候选人将参加2024年俄罗斯总统选举，其中8名候选人已通过提名阶段，另外还有3名正式登记的候选人。
帕姆菲洛娃表示，包括俄现任总统普京在内的自荐候选人须向中央选举委员会提交至少30万选民的支持签名，非议会政党的代表则需要10万个支持签名。
2024年俄罗斯总统选举定于3月17日举行。
translation:
On the 11th local time, Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that there are currently 11 candidates who will participate in the 2024 Russian presidential election, of which 8 candidates have passed the nomination stage, and there are 3 officially registered candidates. people.
Pamfilova said that self-recommended candidates, including current Russian President Vladimir Putin, must submit at least 300,000 voters' signatures of support to the Central Election Commission, while representatives of non-parliamentary parties need 100,000 signatures of support.
The 2024 Russian presidential election is scheduled to be held on March 17.
input:
On the 11th local time, Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that there are currently 11 candidates who will participate in the 2024 Russian presidential election, of which 8 candidates have passed the nomination stage, and there are 3 officially registered candidates. people.
Pamfilova said that self-recommended candidates, including current Russian President Vladimir Putin, must submit at least 300,000 voters' signatures of support to the Central Election Commission, while representatives of non-parliamentary parties need 100,000 signatures of support.
The 2024 Russian presidential election is scheduled to be held on March 17.

title: Putin says he supported prisoner swap for Navalny days before his death | AP News
content:
U.S. officials said there had been no discussions between Russian and the United States over swapping Alexei Navalny with prisoners from the West.
National Security advisor Jake Sullivan told reporters during a White House briefing Monday that U.S. officials had spoken to Russia for “months and years” about releasing American detainees but “have not heard a Russian official raise Navalny as part of a prisoner swap in any of these conversations.”
Navalny, 47, Russia’s best-known opposition politician, died last month while serving a 19-year sentence on extremism charges that he rejected as politically motivated. His allies, family members and Western officials blamed the death on the Kremlin, accusations it has rejected. 
The politician’s associates said officials listed “natural causes” on paperwork Navalny’s mother was shown when she was trying to retrieve his body. 
Navalny had been jailed since January 2021, when he returned to Moscow of his own accord after recuperating in Germany from nerve agent poisoning he blamed on the Kremlin. He was immediately arrested. The Kremlin has vehemently denied it was behind the poisoning.
Pevchikh claimed that there was a plan to swap Navalny and two U.S. citizens held in Russia for Vadim Krasikov. He was serving a life sentence in Germany for the 2019 killing in Berlin of Zelimkhan “Tornike” Khangoshvili, a 40-year-old Georgian citizen of Chechen descent. German judges said Krasikov acted on the orders of Russian authorities.
She didn’t identify the U.S. citizens that were supposedly part of the deal. There are several in custody in Russia, including Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, arrested on espionage charges, and Paul Whelan, a corporate security executive from Michigan, convicted of espionage and serving a long prison sentence. They and the U.S. government dispute the charges against them.
Sullivan said Monday the U.S. is in regular communication with senior Russian officials and had made “a series of offers” for the release of the two men. “It remains an utmost priority of ours,” to get the men out of Russia, Sullivan said. 
German officials have refused to comment when asked if there had been any effort by Russia to swap Krasikov.
Putin had earlier said that the Kremlin was open to negotiations on Gershkovich. He pointed to a man imprisoned in a “U.S.-allied country” for “liquidating a bandit” who had allegedly killed Russian soldiers during separatist fighting in Chechnya. Putin didn’t mention names but appeared to refer to Krasikov.

title: 白宫批评俄罗斯选举“不公平”,普京在胜选记者会回应:全世界都在嘲笑美国发生的事
content:
当地时间18日凌晨,俄罗斯中央选举委员会发布数据显示,在俄总统选举统计完成的85%选票中,现任总统普京以87.19%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人,实际已经赢得此次总统选举。综合路透社、今日俄罗斯电视台（RT）报道,普京18日凌晨在竞选总部发表讲话时,对美国白宫有关俄罗斯总统选举“不自由”、“不公平”的批评进行了反驳。

RT称,普京表示,美国政府在批评其他国家民主进程的同时,还动用行政权力和资源打压美国自己的总统参选人之一。RT称,普京提到的“（美国）总统参选人之一”显然指的是特朗普。报道称,特朗普作为美国大选共和党党内领跑者,目前面临着一连串诉讼。

“全世界都在嘲笑那里（美国）发生的事情”,普京说,“这就是一场灾难,这不是民主,那这到底是什么？”

RT提到,普京此前接受采访时表示,俄罗斯不会干涉外国选举,并将与任何当选的美国总统合作。报道称,早前,普京在接受今日俄罗斯国际新闻通讯社社长采访时说,“我想大家都很清楚,美国的政治制度从任何意义上讲都称不上民主”。普京拒绝就当前美国大选进一步评论,但他形容这场大选的氛围正变得“越来越不文明”。

据媒体报道,俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。根据俄总统选举规则,在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举结果,并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。普京18日凌晨在竞选总部发表讲话,感谢所有选民的支持。他表示,俄罗斯是一个大家庭,本次选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望,国家的所有任务都将完成。
translation:
In the early morning of the 18th local time, the Russian Central Election Commission released data showing that among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and actually won the presidential election. According to reports from Reuters and Russia Today Television (RT), Putin refuted the criticism from the US White House that the Russian presidential election was "not free" and "unfair" when he delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th.

RT said that Putin said that while criticizing the democratic process of other countries, the U.S. government also used administrative power and resources to suppress one of the United States' own presidential candidates. RT stated that Putin’s mention of “one of the (U.S.) presidential candidates” obviously refers to Trump. According to reports, Trump, as the front-runner in the Republican Party in the US election, is currently facing a series of lawsuits.

"The whole world is laughing at what is happening there (in the United States)," Putin said. "This is a disaster. This is not democracy. So what is this?"

RT mentioned that Putin stated in a previous interview that Russia will not interfere in foreign elections and will cooperate with any elected US president. According to the report, earlier in an interview with the president of Russia Today International News Agency, Putin said, "I think everyone is very clear that the political system of the United States cannot be called a democracy in any sense." Putin declined to comment further on the current U.S. election, but he described the atmosphere in the election as becoming "increasingly uncivilized."

According to media reports, the official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed. Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed.
input:
In the early morning of the 18th local time, the Russian Central Election Commission released data showing that among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and actually won the presidential election. According to reports from Reuters and Russia Today Television (RT), Putin refuted the criticism from the US White House that the Russian presidential election was "not free" and "unfair" when he delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th.

RT said that Putin said that while criticizing the democratic process of other countries, the U.S. government also used administrative power and resources to suppress one of the United States' own presidential candidates. RT stated that Putin’s mention of “one of the (U.S.) presidential candidates” obviously refers to Trump. According to reports, Trump, as the front-runner in the Republican Party in the US election, is currently facing a series of lawsuits.

"The whole world is laughing at what is happening there (in the United States)," Putin said. "This is a disaster. This is not democracy. So what is this?"

RT mentioned that Putin stated in a previous interview that Russia will not interfere in foreign elections and will cooperate with any elected US president. According to the report, earlier in an interview with the president of Russia Today International News Agency, Putin said, "I think everyone is very clear that the political system of the United States cannot be called a democracy in any sense." Putin declined to comment further on the current U.S. election, but he described the atmosphere in the election as becoming "increasingly uncivilized."

According to media reports, the official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed. Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed.

title: 俄罗斯胜了第五次总统胜选！普京众望所归,对中国有何影响
content:
俄罗斯赢了？普京又当选了第五次总统！他是不是备受欢迎？这对中国有什么影响呢？

2024年成了全球选举年,美国和俄罗斯都在准备总统选举。而在俄罗斯,大选结果已经揭晓:普京以压倒性的87%的得票率成功连任,这也是他的第五个总统任期。普京宣布胜选,开始了他的第五个总统任期。

那普京为何能当选第五次？这背后与俄罗斯的选举法有关。早在2020年,普京就修订了选举法,规定现任国家元首可以连任两届总统,每届总统任期延长至6年。这意味着普京有可能一直担任总统,直至2036年,也就是他84岁退休的时候。

俄罗斯的大选结果显示,普京获得了87%的选票,提前锁定胜局。而这结果也引发了许多关于普京连任的讨论。普京的胜选意味着什么？这对中国又有何影响呢？让我们来探讨这些话题。

目前看来,普京胜选其实很有可能,因为自从他上台以来,得票率每年都在增加。2000年只有52.9%,但今年已经达到了87.15%。这说明在俄罗斯,普京的威望是无可撼动的。

普京的胜选对俄罗斯来说意味着什么呢？首先,对于当前的俄罗斯来说,这是非常必要的。因为俄罗斯现在的情况并不容乐观。

俄乌冲突的爆发意味着俄罗斯实际上是在与美国和整个北约国家对抗。尽管乌克兰出兵,但背后的武器弹药以及作战资金和保养都是由北约提供的。北约已经签署协议,向乌克兰提供价值12亿美元的炮弹。

再加上美国为首的西方国家的制裁,俄罗斯目前处于“乱世”之中。在这种情况下,需要一个有强大号召力的领袖来统领全局,以维持国家的稳定。所以很多国家在战争状态下基本不会更换领导人。

同时,随着北约逐渐介入,俄罗斯面临的军事压力只会增加,不会减少。在经济领域,俄罗斯的制裁仍在不断升级。两年前冲突爆发后,俄罗斯的海外资产被欧盟和美国冻结。不过,只要运作得当,这笔资金其实是可以回收的。

对普京来说,连任对于俄罗斯的战略稳定可是很重要的事情。对中国来说,普京连任其实是个好事。首先,美国早就在明着把中国列为敌对国家了,拜登上台后还对我们进行了各种制裁,特别是在芯片等科技领域。
translation:
Russia won? Putin was elected president for the fifth time! Is he popular? What impact does this have on China?

2024 has become a global election year, and the United States and Russia are both preparing for presidential elections. In Russia, the results of the election have been announced: Putin was successfully re-elected with an overwhelming 87% of the vote. This is also his fifth presidential term. Putin declared victory and began his fifth presidential term.

So why was Putin elected for the fifth time? This has something to do with Russia’s electoral laws. As early as 2020, Putin revised the election law, stipulating that the current head of state can serve two consecutive terms as president, and each presidential term is extended to 6 years. This means that Putin may remain president until 2036, when he retires at the age of 84.

Russia's election results showed that Putin won 87% of the votes, sealing victory in advance. This result also triggered a lot of discussion about Putin's re-election. What does Putin's victory mean? What impact does this have on China? Let’s explore these topics.

At present, it seems that Putin is very likely to win the election, because his vote share has been increasing every year since he came to power. In 2000, it was only 52.9%, but this year it has reached 87.15%. This shows that Putin's prestige in Russia is unshakable.

What does Putin's victory mean for Russia? First of all, this is very necessary for the current Russia. Because the current situation in Russia is not optimistic.

The outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict means that Russia is actually confronting the United States and the entire NATO countries. Although Ukraine sends troops, the weapons, ammunition, combat funds and maintenance behind them are all provided by NATO. NATO has signed an agreement to provide Ukraine with artillery shells worth $1.2 billion.

Coupled with the sanctions imposed by Western countries led by the United States, Russia is currently in "chaotic times." In this case, a leader with strong appeal is needed to lead the overall situation to maintain the stability of the country. Therefore, many countries will basically not change their leaders during a state of war.

At the same time, as NATO gradually intervenes, the military pressure faced by Russia will only increase, not decrease. In the economic field, Russia's sanctions are still escalating. After the conflict broke out two years ago, Russia's overseas assets were frozen by the European Union and the United States. However, as long as it is done properly, the funds can actually be recovered.

For Putin, re-election is very important to Russia's strategic stability. For China, Putin's re-election is actually a good thing. First of all, the United States has long openly listed China as a hostile country. After Biden came to power, he also imposed various sanctions on us, especially in the fields of technology such as chips.

So why was Putin elected for the fifth time? This has something to do with Russia’s electoral laws. As early as 2020, Putin revised the election law, stipulating that the current head of state can serve two consecutive terms as president, and each presidential term is extended to 6 years. This means that Putin may remain president until 2036, when he retires at the age of 84.

Russia's election results showed that Putin won 87% of the votes, sealing victory in advance. This result also triggered a lot of discussion about Putin's re-election. What does Putin's victory mean? What impact does this have on China? Let’s explore these topics.

At present, it seems that Putin is very likely to win the election, because his vote share has been increasing every year since he came to power. In 2000, it was only 52.9%, but this year it has reached 87.15%. This shows that Putin's prestige in Russia is unshakable.

What does Putin's victory mean for Russia? First of all, this is very necessary for the current Russia. Because the current situation in Russia is not optimistic.

The outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict means that Russia is actually confronting the United States and the entire NATO countries. Although Ukraine sends troops, the weapons, ammunition, combat funds and maintenance behind them are all provided by NATO. Therefore, many countries will basically not change their leaders during a state of war.

At the same time, as NATO gradually intervenes, the military pressure faced by Russia will only increase, not decrease. In the economic field, Russia's sanctions are still escalating. title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜五个“首次”，这场选举有何特殊？
content:
与此前历次选举时一样，普京不会参与选前辩论活动。俄总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫解释称，普京是现任国家元首，日程非常繁忙，这使得他与其他候选人之间存在根本性的不同。总统本人每天都会出现在媒体上，俄罗斯人每天都有机会看到普京关于各方面的言论。
对于选民而言，考虑到本次总统大选投票还将采用实地投票和远程电子投票相结合的方式进行，选民可在2024年1月29日至3月11日期间申请进行远程电子投票，正式投票时间为3月15日8时至3月17日20时。
2月25日起，俄罗斯境内偏远及交通不便的地区开始提前投票。3月1日起，身在海外的俄罗斯人也可开始提前投票。正式投票则将在3月15-17日进行，18日起将统计选票，投票结果最迟将在28日统计完毕。任何在投票日年满18岁、具有法律行为能力且未被法院判刑并处在被监禁状态的俄罗斯联邦公民均可投票。
根据俄罗斯法律规定，第一轮投票中如有参选者得到50%以上选票，则将直接当选总统。如无人获得半数以上选票，得票领先的两名候选人将在第一轮投票三周后进入第二轮投票，得票较多者将当选总统。
2024年俄罗斯大选有何特殊之处？
2024年俄罗斯大选是该国2020年通过宪法修正案后的首次总统大选，也是俄罗斯首次战时选举。
2023年11月，普京签署总统选举法修正案。据央视新闻此前报道，俄罗斯联邦委员会宪法委员会第一副主席弗拉基米尔·波莱塔耶夫在解释新的修正案时表示，根据俄罗斯联邦中央选举委员会与俄罗斯国防部的协商结果，处于战时状态的俄罗斯联邦主体仍旧可以进行选举投票。
translation:
As in previous elections, Putin will not participate in pre-election debates. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov explained that Putin is the current head of state and has a very busy schedule, which makes him fundamentally different from other candidates. The president himself appears in the media every day, and Russians have a daily opportunity to see what Putin has to say about everything.
For voters, considering that voting in this presidential election will also be conducted using a combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting, voters can apply for remote electronic voting from January 29 to March 11, 2024, and officially vote. The time is from 8:00 on March 15 to 20:00 on March 17.
Starting from February 25, early voting will begin in remote and inaccessible areas of Russia. Starting from March 1, Russians abroad can also start voting in advance. The formal voting will be held from March 15th to 17th. The votes will be counted from the 18th, and the voting results will be counted by the 28th at the latest. Any citizen of the Russian Federation who is 18 years of age or older on the voting day, has legal capacity, and is not sentenced by a court and is incarcerated may vote.
According to Russian law, if a candidate receives more than 50% of the votes in the first round of voting, he will be directly elected president. If no one obtains more than half of the votes, the two leading candidates will enter the second round of voting three weeks after the first round of voting, and the candidate with more votes will be elected president.
What’s special about the 2024 Russian election?
The 2024 Russian election will be the country’s first presidential election after the adoption of a constitutional amendment in 2020, and it will also be Russia’s first wartime election.
In November 2023, Putin signed an amendment to the presidential election law. According to a previous report by CCTV News, Vladimir Poletaev, the first deputy chairman of the Constitutional Committee of the Russian Federation Council, said when explaining the new amendment that according to the results of negotiations between the Central Election Committee of the Russian Federation and the Russian Ministry of Defense, those in the war Subjects of the Russian Federation in the current state can still vote in elections.

Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov explained that Putin is the current head of state and has a very busy schedule, which makes him fundamentally different from other candidates. The president himself appears in the media every day, and Russians have a daily opportunity to see what Putin has to say about everything.
For voters, considering that voting in this presidential election will also be conducted using a combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting, voters can apply for remote electronic voting from January 29 to March 11, 2024, and officially vote. The time is from 8:00 on March 15 to 20:00 on March 17.
Starting from February 25, early voting will begin in remote and inaccessible areas of Russia. Starting from March 1, Russians abroad can also start voting in advance. The formal voting will be held from March 15th to 17th. The votes will be counted from the 18th, and the voting results will be counted by the 28th at the latest. Any citizen of the Russian Federation who is 18 years of age or older on the voting day, has legal capacity, and is not sentenced by a court and is incarcerated may vote.
According to Russian law, if a candidate receives more than 50% of the votes in the first round of voting, he will be directly elected president. If no one obtains more than half of the votes, the two leading candidates will enter the second round of voting three weeks after the first round of voting, and the candidate with more votes will be elected president.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content: Вспомним хотя бы знаменитые "карусели" и принудительное голосование на предприятиях и в вузах. Наконец, в-третьих, сыграло роль отсутствие реальной конкуренции и сильных оппонентов у Путина. Ни Харитонов от КПРФ, ни Даванков от "Новых людей", ни тем более Слуцкий от ЛДПР не смогли составить достойную альтернативу действующему президенту и набрали в сумме чуть более 10% голосов - капля в море по сравнению с результатом Путина. Так что интриги на этих выборах явно не хватало.
translation: Let us just remember the famous “carousels” and forced voting at enterprises and universities. Finally, thirdly, Putin’s lack of real competition and strong opponents played a role. Neither Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, nor Davankov from the New People, nor even more so Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party were able to form a worthy alternative to the current president and received a total of just over 10% of the votes - a drop in the bucket compared to Putin’s result. So there was clearly a lack of intrigue in these elections.
input: Let us just remember the famous “carousels” and forced voting at enterprises and universities. Finally, thirdly, Putin’s lack of real competition and strong opponents played a role. Neither Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, nor Davankov from the New People, nor even more so Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party were able to form a worthy alternative to the current president and received a total of just over 10% of the votes - a drop in the bucket compared to Putin’s result. So there was clearly a lack of intrigue in these elections.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
content:
日前在举世瞩目的俄总统大选中,没有悬念的在职总统普京以87.26%的得票率再次荣获连任。这让人不免产生一个疑问,为什么普京竟能在俄乌炮火连天冲突中的选举,以空前的高票、绝对的优势获胜？

答案很清晰。24年前普京曾引用政治家斯托雷平的一句话,“给俄罗斯20年内外安定的时间,它将变得让你认不出来。”后来这句话在中国流传为,普京称“给我二十年,还俄罗斯一个奇迹”。普京以自己独特的理念、能力和功绩,营造了一个极不平凡的国家,受到俄罗斯国民的高度认可和赞赏,从其首任总统至今24年来,支持率一直保持在65%以上,世界罕见。
translation:
In the Russian presidential election that attracted worldwide attention a few days ago, the incumbent President Vladimir Putin was re-elected with 87.26% of the vote. This makes people wonder why Putin was able to win the election with an unprecedented high number of votes and an absolute advantage in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

The answer is clear. 24 years ago, Putin quoted the politician Stolypin's words, "Give Russia 20 years to stabilize both internally and externally, and it will become unrecognizable to you." This sentence later spread in China, and Putin said, "Give Russia 20 years to stabilize both internally and externally." I have been a miracle in Russia for twenty years." With his unique ideas, abilities and achievements, Putin has created an extraordinary country, which is highly recognized and appreciated by the Russian people. In the 24 years since he became the first president, his approval rate has remained above 65%, which is rare in the world.
input:
In the Russian presidential election that attracted worldwide attention a few days ago, the incumbent President Vladimir Putin was re-elected with 87.26% of the vote. This makes people wonder why Putin was able to win the election with an unprecedented high number of votes and an absolute advantage in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

The answer is clear. 24 years ago, Putin quoted the politician Stolypin's words, "Give Russia 20 years to stabilize both internally and externally, and it will become unrecognizable to you." This sentence later spread in China, and Putin said, "Give Russia 20 years to stabilize both internally and externally." I have been a miracle in Russia for twenty years." With his unique ideas, abilities and achievements, Putin has created an extraordinary country, which is highly recognized and appreciated by the Russian people. In the 24 years since he became the first president, his approval rate has remained above 65%, which is rare in the world.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民: 至少俄罗斯人能投票
content:
陈破空告诉美国之音:“俄罗斯的一次选举在中国得到报道，对中国清醒的民众可以说是一个启发，或者是他们一个吐槽的机会，但是对小粉红、五毛党这些被洗脑的人并不会有什么清醒或者反省。”
网络反讽留言凸显中国网民权利意识清醒

陈破空说，尽管微博的各种“粉红”论述占有压倒性的优势，但那都是中国官方言论审查后的结果。例如，中国外长王毅在3月“两会”期间召开的记者会报道，留言区有超过1,500条评论，但却只能显示13条，显然其他1,400多条都是官方不愿、也不敢显示的反讽、挖苦，因此陈破空说，中国清醒的人士已经越来越多。

网红作家上官乱则认为，年轻人对国际政治的观感往往取决于自身的处境。例如，中国年轻人深陷失业率攀升、薪资断崖式下降的窘境中，恐对官方的论述不再轻易信服。

台北学者刘萧翔表示，普京跟习近平能长期大权独揽，皆因两国形式不同、但本质相同的独裁体制。普京是在俄罗斯改革失败之际，以“带领国家走向复兴”的口号崛起，而习近平则是藉由反腐，清除异己，逐步集权。

刘萧翔说，中国网民感叹俄罗斯至少还有投票机制，代表他们向往民主，但中国能否走向民主，取决于人民如何坚持诉求，例如，去年底的白纸运动就曾成功迫使中共放弃清零政策。
translation:
Chen Pokong told Voice of America: “A Russian election was reported in China, which can be said to be an inspiration to China’s sober people, or an opportunity for them to complain, but it is not for brainwashed people like Little Pink and the Fifty Cent Party. There will be no sobriety or reflection.”
Internet ironic messages highlight Chinese netizens’ awareness of rights

Chen Pokong said that although various "pink" discussions on Weibo have an overwhelming advantage, they are all the result of China's official censorship of speech. For example, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi reported at a press conference held during the "Two Sessions" in March that there were more than 1,500 comments in the comment area, but only 13 could be displayed. Apparently, the other 1,400-plus comments were officials who were unwilling or afraid to display them. Therefore, Chen Pokong said that there are more and more sober people in China.

Internet celebrity writer Shangguan Luan believes that young people’s perceptions of international politics often depend on their own circumstances. For example, young people in China are trapped in the dilemma of rising unemployment and plummeting wages, and may no longer be easily convinced by official explanations.

Taipei scholar Liu Xiaoxiang said that Putin and Xi Jinping have been able to monopolize power for a long time because the two countries have different forms of autocratic systems, but the essence is the same. Putin rose to power with the slogan of "leading the country to rejuvenation" when Russia's reforms failed, while Xi Jinping gradually centralized power through anti-corruption, eliminating dissidents.

Liu Xiaoxiang said that Chinese netizens lamented that Russia at least still has a voting mechanism, which represents their yearning for democracy. However, whether China can move toward democracy depends on how the people persist in their demands. For example, the White Paper Movement at the end of last year successfully forced the CCP to give up on clearing the country. policy.
input:
Chen Pokong told Voice of America: “A Russian election was reported in China, which can be said to be an inspiration to China’s sober people, or an opportunity for them to complain, but it is not for brainwashed people like Little Pink and the Fifty Cent Party. There will be no sobriety or reflection.”
Internet ironic messages highlight Chinese netizens’ awareness of rights

Chen Pokong said that although various "pink" discussions on Weibo have an overwhelming advantage, they are all the result of China's official censorship of speech. For example, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi reported at a press conference held during the "Two Sessions" in March that there were more than 1,500 comments in the comment area, but only 13 could be displayed. Apparently, the other 1,400-plus comments were officials who were unwilling or afraid to display them. Therefore, Chen Pokong said that there are more and more sober people in China.

Internet celebrity writer Shangguan Luan believes that young people’s perceptions of international politics often depend on their own circumstances. For example, young people in China are trapped in the dilemma of rising unemployment and plummeting wages, and may no longer be easily convinced by official explanations.

Taipei scholar Liu Xiaoxiang said that Putin and Xi Jinping have been able to monopolize power for a long time because the two countries have different forms of autocratic systems, but the essence is the same. Putin rose to power with the slogan of "leading the country to rejuvenation" when Russia's reforms failed, while Xi Jinping gradually centralized power through anti-corruption, eliminating dissidents.

Liu Xiaoxiang said that Chinese netizens lamented that Russia at least still has a voting mechanism, which represents their yearning for democracy. However, whether China can move toward democracy depends on how the people persist in their demands. For example, the White Paper Movement at the end of last year successfully forced the CCP to give up on clearing the country. policy.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Какую позицию заняли западные страны
Страны «Большой семерки» (США, Великобритания, Канада, Германия, Франция, Италия и Япония) и представитель Европейского союза 24 февраля заявили, что проведение выборов в Крыму, ДНР, ЛНР, Запорожской и Херсонской областях нарушают суверенитет Украины и результатов они не признают. Представитель МИДа Мария Захарова назвала это заявление предвзятым: время G7, по ее словам, «безвозвратно ушло».

Европейский союз не будет формулировать единую позицию по российским выборам, каждое государство примет решение самостоятельно, сообщил на брифинге 14 марта Петер Стано, представитель главы дипслужбы ЕС Жозепа Борреля.
translation:
What position did Western countries take?
The G7 countries (USA, UK, Canada, Germany, France, Italy and Japan) and the representative of the European Union announced on February 24 that the holding of elections in Crimea, DPR, LPR, Zaporozhye and Kherson regions violates the sovereignty of Ukraine and they do not recognize the results . Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova called this statement biased: the time of the G7, in her words, is “irretrievably gone.”

The European Union will not formulate a single position on the Russian elections; each state will make its own decision, Peter Stano, a representative of EU diplomatic chief Josep Borrell, said at a briefing on March 14.
input:
What position did Western countries take?
The G7 countries (USA, UK, Canada, Germany, France, Italy and Japan) and the representative of the European Union announced on February 24 that the holding of elections in Crimea, DPR, LPR, Zaporozhye and Kherson regions violates the sovereignty of Ukraine and they do not recognize the results . Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova called this statement biased: the time of the G7, in her words, is “irretrievably gone.”

The European Union will not formulate a single position on the Russian elections; each state will make its own decision, Peter Stano, a representative of EU diplomatic chief Josep Borrell, said at a briefing on March 14.

title: 西方指责俄总统选举不公正 中朝贺普京当选 | 俄罗斯 | 中国 | 乌克兰 | 大纪元
content:
德国外长安娜莱娜‧贝尔博克（Annalena Baerbock）在会议开始时说，“俄罗斯的选举是一次毫无选择的选举。”
法国外长斯特凡纳‧塞茹尔内（Stephane Sejourne）表示，巴黎已经注意到了俄罗斯的“特别选举行动”，藉以嘲讽普京两年前曾把其发动的入侵乌克兰的侵略战争称为“特别军事行动”。他代表法国政府表示，“自由、多元和民主选举的条件均没有得到满足。”
英国外交大臣戴维‧卡梅伦（David Cameron，前英国首相）说，此次选举结果凸显了俄罗斯“镇压的强度”。他表示，“普京清除了他的政治对手，控制了媒体，然后为自己加冕，这不是民主。”
法国、英国和其它国家还共同谴责，俄罗斯在其声称在战争期间吞并的乌克兰被占领地区上举行选举。
白宫发言人周日表示，俄罗斯的选举“显然既不自由，也不公正”。
乌克兰总统泽连斯基说，俄罗斯的选举不具有合法性。他说，“世界上每个人都很清楚，这个人物（普京）……为了权力丧心病狂，正在竭尽全力想要永远统治下去。”
克里姆林宫驳斥了上述批评，称普京在为期三天的选举中赢得了87%的选票，这表明俄罗斯人民正团结在他的周围。
与欧洲形成鲜明对比的是，中共党魁习近平及印度、朝鲜和伊朗的领导人都队普京的连任表示祝贺。
据中共新华社报导，习近平当天在电话中向普京表示祝贺，称他的连任“充分体现了俄罗斯人民……的支持”。他对普京说，“相信在你的领导下，俄罗斯一定能够取得国家发展建设的更大成就。”习近平还向普京承诺，中共愿推动“中俄新时代全面战略协作伙伴关系持续健康稳定深入发展”。
translation:
"The election in Russia is an election without choice," German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock said at the start of the meeting.
French Foreign Minister Stephane Sejourne said Paris had taken note of Russia's "extraordinary electoral actions", mocking Putin for calling his aggressive war in Ukraine two years ago an "extraordinary military campaign" action". Speaking on behalf of the French government, he said, "None of the conditions for free, pluralistic and democratic elections have been met."
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron (former British Prime Minister) said that the election results highlighted the "intensity of repression" in Russia. He said, "Putin eliminated his political opponents, controlled the media, and then crowned himself. This is not democracy."
France, Britain and other countries also jointly condemned Russia for holding elections in occupied areas of Ukraine it said it annexed during the war.
A White House spokesman said Sunday that Russia's election was "clearly neither free nor fair."
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Russia's election had no legitimacy. He said, "It is clear to everyone in the world that this figure (Putin)... is crazy for power and is doing everything he can to rule forever."
The Kremlin dismissed the criticism, saying Putin won 87% of the vote in the three-day election, showing that the Russian people were rallying around him.
In sharp contrast to Europe, Chinese Communist Party leader Xi Jinping and the leaders of India, North Korea and Iran all congratulated Putin on his re-election.
According to the Xinhua News Agency of the Communist Party of China, Xi Jinping congratulated Putin on the phone that day, saying that his re-election "fully reflects the support of the Russian people...". He told Putin, "I believe that under your leadership, Russia will be able to achieve greater achievements in national development and construction." Xi Jinping also promised Putin that the CCP is willing to promote "the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era." ".

title: Vladimir Putin claims landslide Russian election victory | Vladimir Putin | The Guardian
content:
Arrests were also reported in Moscow and St Petersburg.
Russians had made individual acts of protest, including pouring dye into ballot boxes and arson attacks at polling stations, in the preceding days.
Ella Pamfilova, Russia’s election commissioner, said those who spoiled ballots were “bastards”, and the former Russian president Dmitry Medvedev said those responsible could face treason sentences of 20 years. Russia’s interior ministry said it had filed 155 administrative charges and opened 61 criminal cases during the elections, including 21 cases of obstructing voters’ rights.
Stanislav Andreychuk, a co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said the pressure on voters from law enforcement had reached absurd levels.
“It’s the first time in my life that I’ve seen such absurdities and I’ve been observing elections for 20 years,” Andreychuk wrote on Telegram, referring to the actions of police who he said were checking ballots before they were cast.
Under constitutional changes that he orchestrated in 2020, Putin is eligible to seek two more six-year terms after his latest expires next year, potentially allowing him to remain in power until 2036.
By 2029 his tenure will have surpassed that of Joseph Stalin, who ruled the Soviet Union for 29 years, making Putin the country’s longest-serving leader since the Russian empire.

Arrests were also reported in Moscow and St Petersburg.
Russians had made individual acts of protest, including pouring dye into ballot boxes and arson attacks at polling stations, in the preceding days.

Russia’s interior ministry said it had filed 155 administrative charges and opened 61 criminal cases during the elections, including 21 cases of obstructing voters’ rights.
Stanislav Andreychuk, a co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said the pressure on voters from law enforcement had reached absurd levels.
“It’s the first time in my life that I’ve seen such absurdities and I’ve been observing elections for 20 years,” Andreychuk wrote on Telegram, referring to the actions of police who he said were checking ballots before they were cast.

title: 俄大选最后一天：“中午反普京”行动引爆全球-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
content:
俄罗斯为普京胜利连任“量身定做”的选举在周日进入最后一天，反对派发起的“中午反普京"活动如期出现了。人们同时涌向投票站，或扔掉选票或投给其他候选人。也有人去纳瓦尔尼的墓地，将选票投在了那里。
据路透社报道，周日，成千上万的人来到俄罗斯和世界各国首都的投票站，参加俄罗斯反对派所说的“和平但具有象征意义的抗议活动”。
人们同时在中午出现在投票站，不管如何处置选票，就是要通过中午的汇集，显示反对弗拉基米尔-普京连任，而且要显示自己并不孤单。
票投纳瓦尔尼
在这场名为"中午反普京"的行动中，大量俄罗斯人在中午时分前往当地投票站，要么把选票扔掉，要么把票投给另外三位候选人中的任何一位。
还有一些人发誓要在选票上填写上个月死于北极监狱的反对派领导人阿列克谢-纳瓦尔尼的名字，也有人直接去了纳瓦尔尼在莫斯科的墓地，象征性地把票投给了他。法新社说，纳瓦尔尼的坟墓已经看不见，被鲜花盖住了。
纳瓦尔尼的盟友在YouTube上播放了中午时分在俄罗斯各地投票站排队的视频，他们说这些人是为了举行和平抗议。
纳瓦尔尼生前曾在其律师的协助下在社交媒体上发布消息，表示支持 "正午反普京"计划。独立报纸《新消息报》将这一计划称为"纳瓦尔尼的政治遗嘱"。
一位年轻女性在一个投票站说道：“希望渺茫，但如果你能做些什么（像这样），你就应该做。民主已经荡然无存了”。她没有透露自己的姓名，纳瓦尔尼的团队模糊了她的面容。
translation:
Russia's "tailor-made" election for Putin's re-election entered its final day on Sunday, and the "anti-Putin at noon" event launched by the opposition appeared as scheduled. People were rushing to the polls at the same time, either throwing away their ballots or voting for other candidates. Others went to Navalny’s grave and cast their votes there.
Thousands of people came to polling stations in Russia and world capitals on Sunday to take part in what Russia's opposition called "peaceful but symbolic protests," Reuters reported.
People showed up at the polling stations at noon at the same time, no matter how they disposed of their votes, just to show their opposition to Vladimir Putin's re-election by gathering at noon, and to show that they were not alone.
Vote Navalny
In the operation, dubbed "Noontime Against Putin," large numbers of Russians went to local polling stations around noon to either throw away their ballots or vote for any of the three other candidates.
Others vowed to put on their ballots the name of opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month. Others went directly to Navalny’s grave in Moscow to symbolically The vote went to him. Agence France-Presse said Navalny’s grave was no longer visible and was covered with flowers.
Navalny's allies posted videos on YouTube of people queuing up at polling stations across Russia around noon, saying they were staging peaceful protests.
During his lifetime, Navalny posted a message on social media with the assistance of his lawyer, expressing his support for the "Noontime Anti-Putin" plan. The independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta called the plan "Navalny's political testament."
"It's a long shot, but if you can do something [like this], you should do it. Democracy is gone," one young woman said at a polling station. She did not give her name and Navalny's team blurred her face.
input:
Russia's "tailor-made" election for Putin's re-election entered its final day on Sunday, and the "anti-Putin at noon" event launched by the opposition appeared as scheduled. People were rushing to the polls at the same time, either throwing away their ballots or voting for other candidates. Others went to Navalny’s grave and cast their votes there.
Thousands of people came to polling stations in Russia and world capitals on Sunday to take part in what Russia's opposition called "peaceful but symbolic protests," Reuters reported.
People showed up at the polling stations at noon at the same time, no matter how they disposed of their votes, just to show their opposition to Vladimir Putin's re-election by gathering at noon, and to show that they were not alone.
Vote Navalny
In the operation, dubbed "Noontime Against Putin," large numbers of Russians went to local polling stations around noon to either throw away their ballots or vote for any of the three other candidates.
Others vowed to put on their ballots the name of opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month. Others went directly to Navalny’s grave in Moscow to symbolically The vote went to him. Agence France-Presse said Navalny’s grave was no longer visible and was covered with flowers.
Navalny's allies posted videos on YouTube of people queuing up at polling stations across Russia around noon, saying they were staging peaceful protests.
During his lifetime, Navalny posted a message on social media with the assistance of his lawyer, expressing his support for the "Noontime Anti-Putin" plan. The independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta called the plan "Navalny's political testament."
"It's a long shot, but if you can do something [like this], you should do it. Democracy is gone," one young woman said at a polling station. She did not give her name and Navalny's team blurred her face.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民: 至少俄罗斯人能投票
content:
普京连任 中国“官热民冷”

但这帖发文下的评论区却连连“翻车”，有中国网民留言批评：“普京是当代希特勒，发动这场战争是死要面子活受罪，执意把国家和人民拖进灾难深渊中。”另有中国网民不看好普京的下场，留言称:“我承认，我非主流，侵略者必败。”

除了批评声，也有人发出对俄罗斯的不满和质疑，例如有网民留言称：“是时候要跟普京提提被他们掳去的160万平方公里问题了。”另有网民要胡锡进表态，問他“如何看待俄罗斯人高调纪念珍宝岛战役苏联阵亡士兵？”一语道破，中俄官方都不想提的边境争议。

珍宝岛事件指1969年3月前苏联与中共解放军为争夺黑龙江流域的珍宝岛(俄称达曼斯基岛)在岛上爆发的武装冲突，双方互有死伤。虽已时隔55年，但多名中国视频博主为了抗议俄方在俄乌战争期间激发民族主义情绪，而于本月初高调纪念这场实为“苏联侵略中国”的战斗，只不过，中国官方似乎并无意重提此争议，明显刻意保持低调。

原籍中国四川、现移居台湾的作家上官乱在接受美国之音采访时表示，尽管在中国严格的网络审查下很难透过微博声量真正掌握中国网民对俄罗斯和普京个人的看法，但她认为，除了历史观贫乏的小粉红外，不少中国人还是记得中苏交恶的历史，并理性看待目前的中俄外交。

上官乱说:“还有一种更加自由派的，他们就说，如果不是美国天天盯着他看的话，普京的下一个猎物应该是中国，就是对普京的这种狼子野心，还是有高度警惕的(中国)人也很多。”
热议俄罗斯大选 中国网民暗讽: 选票长啥样?

除了对俄罗斯的戒心，部分中国网民还藉由俄罗斯这场国际公认遭到操弄的总统选举，反讽中国人自己连投票选国家领导都没资格。
translation:
Putin’s re-election: China’s officials are hot but the people are cold

However, the comment section under the post continued to overturn. Some Chinese netizens left comments criticizing: "Putin is a modern-day Hitler. He launched this war because he wanted to save face and suffer the consequences, and he insisted on dragging the country and people into the abyss of disaster." Another Chinese netizen commented. Not optimistic about Putin's fate, he left a message saying: "I admit that I am not mainstream, and the aggressor will lose."

In addition to criticism, some people also voiced their dissatisfaction and doubts about Russia. For example, one netizen left a message saying: "It's time to raise the issue of the 1.6 million square kilometers captured by them with Putin." Another netizen asked Hu Xijin to express his position and asked him "What do you think of the Russians' high-profile commemoration of the Soviet Union's fallen soldiers in the Battle of Zhenbao Island?" One sentence put it bluntly. It is a border dispute that neither Chinese nor Russian officials want to mention.

The Zhenbao Island Incident refers to the armed conflict that broke out on the Zhenbao Island (called Damansky Island in Russia) in the Heilongjiang River Basin in March 1969 between the Soviet Union and the Chinese People's Liberation Army. Both sides suffered casualties. Although it has been 55 years, many Chinese video bloggers commemorated this battle in a high-profile manner at the beginning of this month in order to protest against Russia's stimulation of nationalist sentiments during the Russo-Ukrainian War. However, China Officials seem to have no intention of revisiting the controversy, apparently deliberately keeping a low profile.

Shangguan Luan, a writer originally from Sichuan, China, who now immigrated to Taiwan, said in an interview with Voice of America that although it is difficult to truly grasp Chinese netizens' personal views on Russia and Putin through Weibo volume under China's strict Internet censorship, she believes , except for the little pinks who have a poor historical perspective, many Chinese people still remember the history of Sino-Soviet enmity and view the current Sino-Russian diplomacy rationally.

Shangguan Ran said: "There is also a more liberal group. They say that if the United States hadn't been staring at him every day, Putin's next prey would have been China. They are still very wary of Putin's wolfish ambitions ( There are also many people in China.”
With the Russian election hotly debated, Chinese netizens sarcastically asked: What does a ballot look like?

In addition to being wary of Russia, some Chinese netizens also used Russia's presidential election, which is recognized internationally as rigged, to mock the Chinese for not even being qualified to vote for national leaders.

title: 普京出席庆祝克里米亚“入俄”十周年音乐会 领唱国歌 | 文学城
content:
当地时间3月18日，庆祝克里米亚加入俄罗斯十周年音乐会在莫斯科红场举行。综合俄新社、《消息报》等多家俄媒报道，俄罗斯总统普京当天出席音乐会并发表讲话。

综合俄新社等媒体此前报道，俄罗斯总统选举正式投票于3月15日至17日举行，共4名候选人参选，包括俄现任总统普京、俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基、俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫和俄新人党的达万科夫。根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会公布的数据，普京已经赢得此次总统选举。

俄新社报道说，当地时间18日，普京与其他3名候选人一起在红场出席庆祝克里米亚加入俄罗斯十周年音乐会，现场聚集了大量俄民众，普京发表讲话并就这一节日向俄民众表示祝贺。



报道说，普京还在讲话结束后与现场人员齐唱俄罗斯国歌。唱国歌环节结束后，普京说，“我们为俄罗斯感到骄傲！”克里姆林宫网站发布的现场视频显示，普京说完这句话后，现场有俄罗斯民众高喊“俄罗斯”。



综合塔斯社等多家媒体此前报道，2014年3月16日，克里米亚以及塞瓦斯托波尔市举行全民公投，超过九成投票者支持加入俄罗斯。同月18日，普京在莫斯科与克里米亚及塞瓦斯托波尔代表签署文件，允许克里米亚和塞瓦斯托波尔以联邦主体身份加入俄罗斯联邦。对此，乌克兰方面一直表示反对。
translation:
On March 18, local time, a concert celebrating the 10th anniversary of Crimea’s admission to Russia was held in Moscow’s Red Square. According to reports from many Russian media such as RIA Novosti and Izvestia, Russian President Vladimir Putin attended the concert and delivered a speech that day.

According to previous reports from RIA Novosti and other media, the official voting for the Russian presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. A total of four candidates will participate in the election, including current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russian Liberal Democratic Party Slutsky, and the Communist Party of the Russian Federation. Kharitonov and Davankov of the Russian New People's Party. According to data released by Russia's Central Election Commission, Putin has won the presidential election.

RIA Novosti reported that on the 18th local time, Putin and three other candidates attended a concert in Red Square to celebrate the tenth anniversary of Crimea’s accession to Russia. A large number of Russian people gathered at the scene. Putin gave a speech and discussed this festival. Japan congratulates the Russian people.



Reports said that Putin also sang the Russian national anthem with the attendees after his speech. After the singing of the national anthem, Putin said, "We are proud of Russia!" A live video posted on the Kremlin website showed that after Putin said this, Russian people at the scene shouted "Russia".



According to previous reports by TASS and other media, on March 16, 2014, referendums were held in Crimea and Sevastopol, and more than 90% of the voters supported joining Russia. On the 18th of the same month, Putin signed a document with representatives of Crimea and Sevastopol in Moscow, allowing Crimea and Sevastopol to join the Russian Federation as federal subjects. Ukraine has always expressed opposition to this.
input:
On March 18, local time, a concert celebrating the 10th anniversary of Crimea’s admission to Russia was held in Moscow’s Red Square. According to reports from many Russian media such as RIA Novosti and Izvestia, Russian President Vladimir Putin attended the concert and delivered a speech that day.

According to previous reports from RIA Novosti and other media, the official voting for the Russian presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. A total of four candidates will participate in the election, including current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russian Liberal Democratic Party Slutsky, and the Communist Party of the Russian Federation. Kharitonov and Davankov of the Russian New People's Party. According to data released by Russia's Central Election Commission, Putin has won the presidential election.

RIA Novosti reported that on the 18th local time, Putin and three other candidates attended a concert in Red Square to celebrate the tenth anniversary of Crimea’s accession to Russia. A large number of Russian people gathered at the scene. Putin gave a speech and discussed this festival. Japan congratulates the Russian people.



Reports said that Putin also sang the Russian national anthem with the attendees after his speech. After the singing of the national anthem, Putin said, "We are proud of Russia!" A live video posted on the Kremlin website showed that after Putin said this, Russian people at the scene shouted "Russia".



According to previous reports by TASS and other media, on March 16, 2014, referendums were held in Crimea and Sevastopol, and more than 90% of the voters supported joining Russia. On the 18th of the same month, Putin signed a document with representatives of Crimea and Sevastopol in Moscow, allowing Crimea and Sevastopol to join the Russian Federation as federal subjects. Ukraine has always expressed opposition to this.

title: 普京在俄总统选举中得票大幅领先，记者会就新任期、俄乌谈判等答问
content:
当地时间3月17日晚8点，北京时间今天（3月18日）凌晨2点，随着俄罗斯领土最西端的加里宁格勒州投票站关闭，俄罗斯总统选举投票结束。
据最新消息，在已统计的80%的选票中，现任总统普京得票率为87.15%。根据俄罗斯总统选举规则，在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。
俄罗斯中央选举委员会将不晚于本月28日确认此次总统选举结果，并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
截屏图

莫斯科时间17日深夜，普京来到其竞选总部，向所有在选举中投票的俄罗斯公民表示感谢，表示他将在新的任期内继续推动国家发展。普京还就特别军事行动、与乌克兰谈判可能性、与美国关系、与北约关系等问题回答了记者提问。
translation:
At 8 pm local time on March 17 and 2 am Beijing time today (March 18), as the polling stations in Kaliningrad Oblast, the westernmost part of Russian territory, closed, the Russian presidential election voting ended.
According to the latest news, among 80% of the votes that have been counted, current President Putin received 87.15% of the votes. According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president.
The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than the 28th of this month and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
screenshot

Late at night on the 17th, Moscow time, Putin came to his campaign headquarters and expressed his gratitude to all Russian citizens who voted in the election, saying that he would continue to promote national development during the new term. Putin also answered questions from reporters on special military operations, the possibility of negotiations with Ukraine, relations with the United States, relations with NATO and other issues.
input:
At 8 pm local time on March 17 and 2 am Beijing time today (March 18), as the polling stations in Kaliningrad Oblast, the westernmost part of Russian territory, closed, the Russian presidential election voting ended.
According to the latest news, among 80% of the votes that have been counted, current President Putin received 87.15% of the votes. According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president.
The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than the 28th of this month and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
screenshot

Late at night on the 17th, Moscow time, Putin came to his campaign headquarters and expressed his gratitude to all Russian citizens who voted in the election, saying that he would continue to promote national development during the new term. Putin also answered questions from reporters on special military operations, the possibility of negotiations with Ukraine, relations with the United States, relations with NATO and other issues.

title: 新闻人物｜俄罗斯当选总统普京简历
content:
3月15日至17日，俄罗斯举行总统选举正式投票。俄中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃21日宣布选举结果，现任总统普京以87.28%的得票率当选俄罗斯联邦第八届总统。
当地时间2024年3月21日，俄罗斯莫斯科，俄罗斯中央选举委员会会议上，视频屏幕上显示普京的投票结果。视觉中国 图

普京1952年10月7日生于列宁格勒市（今圣彼得堡市），1975年毕业于列宁格勒大学法律系，后获经济学副博士学位。他曾在苏联国家安全机构工作，其中1985年至1990年在民主德国工作。
1990年回国后，普京先后担任列宁格勒大学校长外事助理、圣彼得堡市市长顾问、市政府对外联络委员会主席和圣彼得堡市第一副市长。1996年8月，他出任俄总统事务管理局副局长，1997年3月出任俄总统办公厅副主任兼监察总局局长，1998年5月任总统办公厅第一副主任。1999年3月，普京出任俄联邦安全会议秘书，1999年8月9日被任命为第一副总理兼代总理，8月16日就任总理。1999年12月31日，时任总统叶利钦宣布辞职，普京出任代总统。2000年，普京首次当选总统，2004年成功连任。2008年5月，普京出任俄政府总理。2012年，普京再次当选总统，并于2018年连任至今。2024年3月，普京以独立候选人身份角逐总统一职。
translation:
From March 15th to 17th, Russia held official voting for the presidential election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, announced the election results on the 21st. Current President Putin was elected as the eighth president of the Russian Federation with 87.28% of the vote.
On March 21, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, Putin’s voting results were displayed on the video screen at the meeting of the Russian Central Election Commission. Visual China Map

Putin was born in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg) on ​​October 7, 1952. He graduated from the Law Department of Leningrad University in 1975 and later received an associate doctorate in economics. He worked in the Soviet state security apparatus, including in the GDR from 1985 to 1990.
After returning to China in 1990, Putin successively served as the foreign affairs assistant to the president of Leningrad University, advisor to the mayor of St. Petersburg, chairman of the municipal government's external liaison committee, and first deputy mayor of St. Petersburg. In August 1996, he served as deputy director of the Russian Presidential Affairs Administration, in March 1997, as deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration and director of the General Inspectorate, and in May 1998, he became first deputy director of the presidential administration. In March 1999, Putin served as Secretary of the Security Council of the Russian Federation. On August 9, 1999, he was appointed First Deputy Prime Minister and Acting Prime Minister, and took office as Prime Minister on August 16. On December 31, 1999, then-President Yeltsin announced his resignation and Putin became acting president. In 2000, Putin was elected president for the first time and was successfully re-elected in 2004. In May 2008, Putin became Prime Minister of the Russian government. In 2012, Putin was re-elected as president and has been re-elected in 2018. In March 2024, Putin ran for the presidency as an independent candidate.
input:
From March 15th to 17th, Russia held official voting for the presidential election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, announced the election results on the 21st. Current President Putin was elected as the eighth president of the Russian Federation with 87.28% of the vote.
On March 21, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, Putin’s voting results were displayed on the video screen at the meeting of the Russian Central Election Commission. Visual China Map

Putin was born in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg) on ​​October 7, 1952. He graduated from the Law Department of Leningrad University in 1975 and later received an associate doctorate in economics. He worked in the Soviet state security apparatus, including in the GDR from 1985 to 1990.
After returning to China in 1990, Putin successively served as the foreign affairs assistant to the president of Leningrad University, advisor to the mayor of St. Petersburg, chairman of the municipal government's external liaison committee, and first deputy mayor of St. Petersburg. In August 1996, he served as deputy director of the Russian Presidential Affairs Administration, in March 1997, as deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration and director of the General Inspectorate, and in May 1998, he became first deputy director of the presidential administration. In March 1999, Putin served as Secretary of the Security Council of the Russian Federation. On August 9, 1999, he was appointed First Deputy Prime Minister and Acting Prime Minister, and took office as Prime Minister on August 16. On December 31, 1999, then-President Yeltsin announced his resignation and Putin became acting president. In 2000, Putin was elected president for the first time and was successfully re-elected in 2004. In May 2008, Putin became Prime Minister of the Russian government. In 2012, Putin was re-elected as president and has been re-elected in 2018. In March 2024, Putin ran for the presidency as an independent candidate.

title: 俄中央选举委员会公布2024俄罗斯总统大选候选人名单
content:
当地时间2月8日，俄罗斯中央选举委员会公布消息表示，将有4名候选人参加2024俄罗斯总统大选。
4名候选人分别为，俄罗斯现任总统普京、自民党领导人列昂尼德·斯卢茨基，俄罗斯联邦共产党党员尼古拉·哈里托诺夫，俄罗斯新人党党员弗拉迪斯拉夫·达万科夫。
translation:
On February 8, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission announced that four candidates will participate in the 2024 Russian presidential election.
The four candidates are: current Russian President Vladimir Putin, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party Leonid Slutsky, member of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolay Kharitonov, and member of the Russian New People Party Vladislav Davanko husband.
input:
On February 8, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission announced that four candidates will participate in the 2024 Russian presidential election.
The four candidates are: current Russian President Vladimir Putin, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party Leonid Slutsky, member of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolay Kharitonov, and member of the Russian New People Party Vladislav Davanko husband.

title: 俄罗斯外交部发言人扎哈罗娃回怼西方：想想默克尔干了几届？
content:
如众人所料，俄罗斯现任总统普京成功赢得连任，西方国家的各种指责也抛了过来。很快莫斯科回应了，并点名连续4次出任德国总理、掌舵德国长达16年的默克尔。


	据“今日俄罗斯”3月18日报道，俄罗斯外交部发言人说，北约针对俄罗斯的一系列动作只会帮助普京获得第五个任期。扎哈罗娃表示，西方通过稳固北约在俄罗斯人心目中的“危险敌人”形象，恰恰保证了普京在总统选举中取得历史性胜利。


	据俄媒梳理，德国外交部称俄罗斯总统选举“既不自由也不公平”，“结果并不令人意外”，白宫上周日附和了这一说法。英国国防大臣沙普斯则指控称普京“又一次偷走了选举”，但“偷不走乌克兰”。 


	根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会18日发布的数据，在所有选票都已清点的情况下，现任总统普京的得票率为87.28%，压倒性地赢得了第五个任期。“今日俄罗斯”网站还指出，今年大选投票率高达74%，不但超过了2018年选举的67.47%，也创下历史新高。“顿涅茨克人民共和国”“卢甘斯克人民共和国”以及赫尔松和扎波罗热地区首次参与了选举。





当地时间3月18日，莫斯科，大型音乐集会在红场举行，纪念克里米亚“入俄”十周年。俄罗斯总统普京与三位总统候选人斯卢茨基、哈里托诺夫和达万科夫出席。图自IC Photo


	普京提前锁定胜局之际，扎哈罗娃17日在社交媒体平台Telegram上反驳西方指控说，西方国家不过是不能容忍俄罗斯展示团结罢了，尤其是德国。她还提醒西方，默克尔曾连续4次当选德国总理，她的前辈赫尔穆特·科尔也曾连续执政16年。


	“德国人自己也想知道，这是否符合德国人对民主的理解……出于某种原因，并没有人谈论缺乏自由或不公正。”她写道。


	扎哈罗娃表示，关于俄罗斯选举，她与德国的唯一共识是选举结果“毫不令人意外”：“北约每天对着我们国家吠叫数次，威胁我们，在我们的边境引发冲突……（俄罗斯）全国团结起来反击也就不足为奇了！”


	在另一篇帖子中，她继续驳斥了英国国防大臣关于普京“偷走”选举的说法：“我们没偷他们任何东西，也没有给他们任何东西。所以他们生气了。”


	当地时间3月17日晚，俄罗斯总统选举投票结束，普京在竞选总部发表讲话，就特别军事行动、与乌克兰谈判可能性、与美国关系、与北约关系等问题回答了记者提问。


	普京当天警告西方，俄罗斯与美国领导的北约之间的直接发生冲突，意味着地球距离第三次世界大战“仅一步之遥”，他先是轻松打趣称“现代世界里一切皆有可能”，随后又严肃回应称“几乎没有人希望出现这种情况”。他还透露，北约军事人员实际上已出现在乌克兰，因此俄军士兵已学会在战场上说英语和法语。


	对于美西方国家批评俄大选“不自由”、“不公平”等说法，普京予以了驳斥。他表示，美国的选举才是真正的“不民主”，有人甚至动用国家公权力来对付前总统特朗普。“全世界都在嘲笑那里发生的事情。这只是一场灾难，这不是‘民主’，这到底是什么？”
translation:
As everyone expected, the current Russian President Vladimir Putin successfully won re-election, and various accusations from Western countries were also thrown away. Moscow quickly responded and named Merkel, who has served as German Chancellor for four consecutive times and has been at the helm of Germany for 16 years.


According to a report by "Russia Today" on March 18, a spokesperson for the Russian Foreign Ministry said that a series of NATO actions against Russia will only help Putin win a fifth term. Zakharova said that by consolidating NATO's image as a "dangerous enemy" in the minds of Russians, the West precisely ensured Putin's historic victory in the presidential election.


According to Russian media, the German Foreign Ministry said that the Russian presidential election was "neither free nor fair" and that "the results were not surprising." The White House echoed this statement last Sunday. British Defense Secretary Shapps accused Putin of "stealing the election again" but "cannot steal Ukraine."​


According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission on the 18th, with all votes counted, current President Putin received 87.28% of the vote, overwhelmingly winning his fifth term. The "Russia Today" website also pointed out that the turnout rate in this year's election was as high as 74%, which not only exceeded the 67.47% in the 2018 election, but also set a record high. The "Donetsk People's Republic", the "Luhansk People's Republic" and the Kherson and Zaporizhia regions participated in the elections for the first time.





On March 18, local time, in Moscow, a large-scale music rally was held in Red Square to commemorate the tenth anniversary of Crimea's "entry into Russia". Russian President Vladimir Putin and three presidential candidates Slutsky, Kharitonov and Davankov attended. Image from IC Photo


As Putin sealed the victory in advance, Zakharova refuted Western accusations on the social media platform Telegram on the 17th, saying that Western countries just cannot tolerate Russia's show of unity, especially Germany. She also reminded the West that Merkel had been elected German Prime Minister four times in a row, and her predecessor Helmut Kohl had been in power for 16 consecutive years.


"Germans themselves are wondering whether this fits with the German understanding of democracy... For some reason no one talks about a lack of freedom or injustice," she wrote.


Zakharova said that regarding the Russian elections, the only consensus she has with Germany is that the results are "unsurprising": "NATO barks at our country several times a day, threatening us and causing conflicts on our borders... It’s no surprise that the whole country (Russia) unites to fight back!”


In another post, she went on to refute the British defense secretary's claims that Putin "stole" the election: "We didn't steal anything from them and we didn't give them anything. So they're angry."


On the evening of March 17, local time, the voting for the Russian presidential election ended. Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters and answered questions from reporters on special military operations, the possibility of negotiations with Ukraine, relations with the United States, and relations with NATO.


Putin warned the West that day that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO meant that the earth was "only one step away" from World War III. He first joked lightly that "everything is possible in the modern world," and then He also responded seriously that "almost no one wants this to happen." He also revealed that NATO military personnel are actually present in Ukraine, so Russian soldiers have learned to speak English and French on the battlefield.


Putin refuted criticisms from the United States and Western countries that the Russian election was "unfree" and "unfair." He said that U.S. elections are truly "undemocratic" and some people even use the country's public power to deal with former President Trump. "The whole world is laughing at what happened there. It's just a disaster, it's not 'democracy', what is it?"
