title: Western leaders denounce Putin's election 'victory,' fall short of refusing to recognize results
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin easily cruised to victory in an election ruled neither free nor fair, solidifying his grip on power for another six years. 
Russia's Central Election Commission awarded Putin with 87.2% of the vote in an election that was widely seen as tightly controlled and without the participation of any meaningful opposition.
Western leaders have characterized the vote as fundamentally unfair. Yet, they have stopped short of officially declaring that they will not recognize the results, and Putin as president.
While saying there was "nothing free or fair" about the election, U.S. National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan stopped short of saying it was illegitimate. 
The choice of words was intentional. 
“The reality is that President Putin is the president of Russia, and we've had to deal with that reality throughout the war in Ukraine, during other aggressions by Russia, during other moves that are against U.S. national interests that we've seen from this president of the Russian Federation," Sullivan added.
Speaking the day before the election began, U.S. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said, "The United States does not and will never recognize the legitimacy or outcome of these sham elections held in sovereign Ukraine as part of Russia's presidential elections."
Miller was referring to voting that took place, literally at gunpoint at times, on Ukrainian territory illegally annexed by Russia. 
Josep Borrell, the EU's top diplomat, said that voting on Ukrainian territory was "null and void" and that the election organizers "will face consequences of these illegal actions."
input:
Russian President Vladimir Putin easily cruised to victory in an election ruled neither free nor fair, solidifying his grip on power for another six years. 
Russia's Central Election Commission awarded Putin with 87.2% of the vote in an election that was widely seen as tightly controlled and without the participation of any meaningful opposition.
Western leaders have characterized the vote as fundamentally unfair. Yet, they have stopped short of officially declaring that they will not recognize the results, and Putin as president.
While saying there was "nothing free or fair" about the election, U.S. National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan stopped short of saying it was illegitimate. 
The choice of words was intentional. 
“The reality is that President Putin is the president of Russia, and we've had to deal with that reality throughout the war in Ukraine, during other aggressions by Russia, during other moves that are against U.S. national interests that we've seen from this president of the Russian Federation," Sullivan added.
Speaking the day before the election began, U.S. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said, "The United States does not and will never recognize the legitimacy or outcome of these sham elections held in sovereign Ukraine as part of Russia's presidential elections."
Miller was referring to voting that took place, literally at gunpoint at times, on Ukrainian territory illegally annexed by Russia. 
Josep Borrell, the EU's top diplomat, said that voting on Ukrainian territory was "null and void" and that the election organizers "will face consequences of these illegal actions."

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
content:
对于普京而言，2018年-2024年的第四个总统任期并不轻松。任期开启之初，普京的支持率就曾因俄政府推行延迟退休政策而出现罕见的下滑。消除贫困、实现人口净增长、提振俄经济发展等“痛点”也连续多年在普京的国情咨文中出现。民生问题之外，俄罗斯与西方的关系延续了此前的恶化态势。2022年2月俄发起“特别军事行动”后，西方国家更是对俄实施了前所未有的全方面制裁，双方政治、经贸、人文交流以及军控体系均受到严重冲击。
战火延宕两年后，俄罗斯经济展现了一定的韧性。在经历了2022年2.1%的萎缩后，俄经济在2023年实现了3.6%的增长。有分析认为，创新高的国防支出以及发展势头强劲的军工行业是俄罗斯经济能够在西方制裁之下维持增长的主要推动力。同时，俄长期以来逐步推进的去美元化以及“向东转”、“向南转”的策略也帮助其在一定程度上抵消了西方金融及能源制裁带来的不利影响。不过，面对着通胀高企、劳动力短缺以及长期制裁所带来的不利影响，俄战时经济的可持续性仍然有待观察。
关于未来六年俄罗斯的发展道路，普京在今年2月的国情咨文中已有详细展望。普京在其迄今为止时间最长的国情咨文中提到，俄当前任务是发展国防工业并以此增加国家的科学、技术和工业潜力，要尽可能合理地分配资源，建立有效的战时经济体系。在加快解决俄罗斯的社会、人口、基础设施等问题的同时，也要把陆军和海军的装备提高到新的水平。而根据俄联邦预算计划，2024年俄军事开支将首次超过社会领域开支。
对于正在迈向第五个任期的普京而言，未来的六年依旧难言轻松。俄乌和谈曙光未现，俄西方对立加剧，冲突扩大化的风险仍然存在。而在俄罗斯国内，如何应对民众对于战争延宕的疲劳与不满，于加强国防建设与回应民生所需之间取得平衡，也是普京不得不面对的难题。
translation:
For Putin, the fourth presidential term from 2018 to 2024 will not be easy. At the beginning of his term, Putin's approval rating experienced a rare decline due to the Russian government's implementation of a delayed retirement policy. "Pain points" such as eradicating poverty, achieving net population growth, and boosting Russia's economic development have also appeared in Putin's State of the Union address for many years. In addition to people's livelihood issues, the relationship between Russia and the West has continued its previous deterioration. After Russia launched a "special military operation" in February 2022, Western countries imposed unprecedented all-round sanctions on Russia. The political, economic and trade, cultural exchanges and arms control systems of both parties were severely impacted.
Two years after the war was postponed, the Russian economy has shown some resilience. After experiencing a 2.1% contraction in 2022, the Russian economy will achieve 3.6% growth in 2023. Some analysts believe that record-high defense spending and a strong military industry are the main driving forces behind the Russian economy's ability to maintain growth under Western sanctions. At the same time, Russia's long-term gradual de-dollarization and "turn east" and "turn south" strategies have also helped it offset the adverse effects of Western financial and energy sanctions to a certain extent. However, in the face of high inflation, labor shortages and the adverse effects of long-term sanctions, the sustainability of Russia's wartime economy remains to be seen.
Regarding Russia's development path in the next six years, Putin gave a detailed outlook in his State of the Union address in February this year. In his longest State of the Union address to date, Putin mentioned that Russia’s current task is to develop the defense industry and thereby increase the country’s scientific, technological and industrial potential. It must allocate resources as rationally as possible and establish an effective wartime economic system. . While accelerating the solution of Russia's social, demographic, infrastructure and other problems, we must also raise the equipment of the army and navy to a new level. According to the Russian federal budget plan, Russian military spending will exceed social spending for the first time in 2024.
For Putin, who is entering his fifth term, the next six years will still be difficult to say easy. The dawn of peace talks between Russia and Ukraine has not yet appeared, the confrontation between Russia and the West has intensified, and the risk of conflict expansion still exists. In Russia, how to deal with people's fatigue and dissatisfaction with the delay of the war and strike a balance between strengthening national defense and responding to people's livelihood needs are also difficult problems that Putin has to face.

In addition to people's livelihood issues, the relationship between Russia and the West has continued its previous deterioration. title: ЦИК РФ: Путин побеждает на выборах с рекордным результатом
content:
Задержания и нарушения
По данным ОВД-Инфо, к вечеру воскресенья как минимум 80 человек были задержаны в 20 российских городах. Людей задерживали за надписи на бюллетенях и даже просто за то, что они пришли в полдень, как в Казани.

Независимые наблюдатели отметили многочисленные нарушения в организации голосования. Кроме вбросов и "каруселей", сообщалось и то, что на некоторых участках кабинки для голосования были без шторок: сотрудники полиции следили за тем, что отмечают в бюллетене голосующие, и задерживали их, если им это не нравилось.
translation:
Detentions and violations
According to OVD-Info, by Sunday evening at least 80 people were detained in 20 Russian cities. People were detained for writing on ballots and even simply for showing up at noon, as in Kazan.

Independent observers noted numerous violations in the organization of voting. In addition to stuffing and "carousels", it was also reported that in some areas the voting booths had no curtains: police officers monitored what voters marked on the ballot and detained them if they did not like it.
input:
Detentions and violations
According to OVD-Info, by Sunday evening at least 80 people were detained in 20 Russian cities. People were detained for writing on ballots and even simply for showing up at noon, as in Kazan.

Independent observers noted numerous violations in the organization of voting. In addition to stuffing and "carousels", it was also reported that in some areas the voting booths had no curtains: police officers monitored what voters marked on the ballot and detained them if they did not like it.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜五个“首次”，这场选举有何特殊？
content:
大选有哪些重要节点？
2023年12月7日，俄联邦委员会通过决议，确认了2024年俄罗斯大选时间。俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃8日正式宣布，2024年俄总统选举投票将进行三天，从3月15日持续至17日。
根据俄法律规定，自荐候选人需在2023年12月27日前提交竞选相关材料。2023年12月18日，俄罗斯总统普京来到俄罗斯联邦中央选举委员会，提交了以自荐方式参加2024年总统选举的相关文件。各党派则可在各自的代表大会上推选本党候选人，并在2024年1月1日前提交相关材料。此后，自荐候选人及由未进入国家杜马的党派提名的候选人需要进行签名收集工作，并在1月31日前提交至俄罗斯中央选举委员会并等待认证。
2月10日，在完成对各候选人所提交材料的审核后，现任总统普京、斯卢茨基（俄自由民主党），哈里托诺夫（俄联邦共产党）以及达万科夫（俄新人党）获得参选资格。此后，竞选活动正式拉开序幕。
2月17日起至正式投票开始前，参选人可在媒体上开展选前宣传活动，投放自己的竞选视频。线下，所有参选人都有权进行与选民见面、举行集会等选前活动。同时，由政党提名的参选人最迟需要在投票10天前提交竞选纲领，并在互联网及媒体上公布。
translation:
What are the important nodes in the general election?
On December 7, 2023, the Russian Federation Council passed a resolution confirming the time for the 2024 Russian general election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced on the 8th that voting in the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held for three days, lasting from March 15th to 17th.
According to Russian law, self-recommended candidates must submit campaign-related materials before December 27, 2023. On December 18, 2023, Russian President Vladimir Putin came to the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation and submitted relevant documents for self-recommendation to participate in the 2024 presidential election. Each political party can nominate its party candidates at their respective congresses and submit relevant materials before January 1, 2024. Thereafter, self-recommended candidates and candidates nominated by parties that have not entered the State Duma need to collect signatures and submit them to the Russian Central Election Commission before January 31 and await certification.
On February 10, after completing the review of materials submitted by each candidate, current President Putin, Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian New People's Party) ) is qualified to stand for election. After that, the campaign officially kicked off.
From February 17 until the official voting begins, candidates can carry out pre-election publicity activities in the media and release their own campaign videos. Offline, all candidates have the right to conduct pre-election activities such as meeting with voters and holding rallies. At the same time, candidates nominated by political parties need to submit a campaign platform no later than 10 days before voting and publish it on the Internet and the media.
input:
What are the important nodes in the general election?
On December 7, 2023, the Russian Federation Council passed a resolution confirming the time for the 2024 Russian general election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced on the 8th that voting in the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held for three days, lasting from March 15th to 17th.
According to Russian law, self-recommended candidates must submit campaign-related materials before December 27, 2023. On December 18, 2023, Russian President Vladimir Putin came to the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation and submitted relevant documents for self-recommendation to participate in the 2024 presidential election. Each political party can nominate its party candidates at their respective congresses and submit relevant materials before January 1, 2024. Thereafter, self-recommended candidates and candidates nominated by parties that have not entered the State Duma need to collect signatures and submit them to the Russian Central Election Commission before January 31 and await certification.
On February 10, after completing the review of materials submitted by each candidate, current President Putin, Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian New People's Party) ) is qualified to stand for election. After that, the campaign officially kicked off.
From February 17 until the official voting begins, candidates can carry out pre-election publicity activities in the media and release their own campaign videos. Offline, all candidates have the right to conduct pre-election activities such as meeting with voters and holding rallies. At the same time, candidates nominated by political parties need to submit a campaign platform no later than 10 days before voting and publish it on the Internet and the media.

title: 普京在大选中得票领先，外交部：深信中俄关系将持续向前发展
content:
3月18日，外交部发言人林剑主持例行记者会。俄新社记者提问，俄罗斯总统选举于3月15日至17日举行，现任总统普京得票领先，中方对此有何评论？此次大选将如何影响中俄关系？
林剑表示，中方对此表示祝贺。中俄互为最大邻国和新时代全面战略协作伙伴，我们深信，在习近平主席和普京总统的战略引领下，中俄关系将持续向前发展。
translation:
On March 18, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Lin Jian hosted a regular press conference. A reporter from RIA Novosti asked that the Russian presidential election was held from March 15 to 17. Current President Putin won the vote. What is China’s comment on this? How will this election affect Sino-Russian relations?
Lin Jian said that China congratulates this. China and Russia are each other's largest neighbors and comprehensive strategic partners of coordination in the new era. We are convinced that under the strategic guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin, China-Russia relations will continue to develop.
input:
On March 18, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Lin Jian hosted a regular press conference. A reporter from RIA Novosti asked that the Russian presidential election was held from March 15 to 17. Current President Putin won the vote. What is China’s comment on this? How will this election affect Sino-Russian relations?
Lin Jian said that China congratulates this. China and Russia are each other's largest neighbors and comprehensive strategic partners of coordination in the new era. We are convinced that under the strategic guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin, China-Russia relations will continue to develop.

title: 俄总统选举选票已统计60.01% 普京得票率为87.26%-华龙网
content:
△当地时间3月17日，俄罗斯圣彼得堡，一名女性在投票站为俄总统选举投票。
俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间17日晚宣布，在已统计的60.01%的俄总统选举选票中，现任总统普京得票率为87.26%。据俄总统选举法，获半数以上选票者当选。
translation:
△On March 17, local time, in St. Petersburg, Russia, a woman voted for the Russian presidential election at a polling station.
Russia's Central Election Commission announced on the evening of the 17th local time that out of 60.01% of the Russian presidential election votes that had been counted, current President Vladimir Putin received 87.26% of the votes. According to Russian presidential election law, the person who receives more than half of the votes is elected.
input:
△On March 17, local time, in St. Petersburg, Russia, a woman voted for the Russian presidential election at a polling station.
Russia's Central Election Commission announced on the evening of the 17th local time that out of 60.01% of the Russian presidential election votes that had been counted, current President Vladimir Putin received 87.26% of the votes. According to Russian presidential election law, the person who receives more than half of the votes is elected.

title: Putin's Reelection Confirms Russia Is 'Authoritarian Society,' Says NATO Chief
content:
"The dinar is not banned in Kosovo, but the euro is the only means of payment," Kurti told RFE/RL, echoing the central bank's line that the ban doesn’t stop anyone from accepting money from any country, it just means the money is converted into euros.
Still, the conversion adds a layer of cost and complication to the daily lives of ethnic Serbs still tied to the dinar.
"We cannot allow bagfuls of dinars in cash to enter our country. (It can happen) only through official financial channels with full transparency, who sends money to whom and for what purpose," Kurti said, adding that any disparities on the ground would have time to be smoothed out over the three-month transition period.
"Serbia can send dinars, we will exchange them into euros and Serbs in Kosovo can benefit from that financial aid," Kurti added.
However, the U.S. envoy to the Western Balkans last week warned that the ban had caused problems for some citizens in the region and challenges for the U.S.-Kosovo relationship.
Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Gabriel Escobar told RFE/RL on March 14 that Kosovo's controversial decision on the dinar was "an issue that we need to address immediately."
Escobar said that the issue had presented challenges in the bilateral relationship, although Washington remains Kosovo's most reliable ally.
The U.S. envoy also said that his proposals for resolving the issue had been rejected by Kurti during their meeting.
"It's not me as prime minister to decide about this thing," Kurti told RFE/RL when asked about why he refused Escobar's solutions.
"We're a democracy where powers and duties are separated. Therefore, I can only help the central bank to affect a smooth transition," Kurti said, declining to elaborate on Escobar's proposals.
"Let those who made the proposals speak," he added, reiterating that he cannot cancel the decision of an independent institution.
"No suspension will come out of talking to me, because the bank is an independent institution," he said, adding that its governor reports only to parliament, not the government.
Asked whether he would at least advise the bank to extend the transition period, Kurti replied: "I cannot also advise the central bank of Kosovo. The governor has his own advisers."
Referring to the basic agreement, Kurti said it was Belgrade that was hampering its implementation.
"I want the normalization of relations and I think that the signing of the basic agreement and its implementation annex can certainly cancel previous violations on one hand and, on the other hand can bring legal certainty for the future.
"The problem is that eight out of 11 articles of the basic agreement have been violated by Belgrade," Kurti said, mentioning a letter sent by Serbian Prime Minister Ana Brnabic to the European Union, in which, according to him, her government said they were withdrawing their pledge to the deal "because they will never recognize independence of Kosovo, never accept Kosovo's membership in the United Nations, and likewise they are not going to respect the territorial integrity of our country."
Referring to the forming of the Association of Serb-Majority Municipalities, which is mentioned in Article 7 of the basic agreement, Kurti reiterated his government's statement from October 27, which blamed Serbia for refusing to sign the document endorsed by the leaders of France, Italy, and Germany.
"What more can I do? We are leaders who are supposed to turn the text that we have agreed upon into signed agreements.

title: Putin's Ukraine war ambitions on show at Crimea concert after election win
content:
Putin, in power for the last 24 years, is the only leader they have ever known. They may be well into adulthood before seeing another.
“He has made Russia a lot better than it was,” Maksim Druzhinin, 18, said, speaking in English. Asked whether he expected to turn 30 before Putin might leave office, the teen, who is a student at the capital’s prestigious Higher School of Economics, said: “There is a question: Who else?”
“He has been keeping the country together for many years,” said Alexandra Volkova, a programming student, speaking in Russian. “He is definitely the most reliable candidate out there,” the 18-year-old said.
Of course, the Kremlin’s crackdown on dissent means gauging public opinion in Russia is difficult. And this was an especially pro-Putin crowd, not filled with those who turned out at noon Sunday in a silent show of defiance called for by the opposition, or quietly resigned to life under Putin.
Putin used the occasion to promise to extend the Russian railroad system all the way to occupied Crimea, as an alternative to the bridge connecting the peninsula to the Russian mainland that has come under frequent Ukrainian attacks.
The Russian leader also commended the people of Crimea for what he said was their dedication to Moscow.
“They are our pride,” Putin said. “They never separated themselves from Russia. And this is what allowed Crimea to return to our common family.”
That “return,” which boosted Putin’s approval ratings and set the course for Russia’s expansionism in the decade to follow, is considered an illegal land grab by most of the international community, rather than a historic homecoming.
Crimea, which is crucial to Russia’s naval power, has been used as a major hub and launchpad for the war against Ukraine, which has vowed to reclaim it along with all of its occupied territory and has increasingly targeted Russian military targets on the peninsula.
“Crimea is not Russian,” Tamila Tasheva, Kyiv’s permanent representative in Crimea, told NBC News. “Legally, the territory is Ukrainian. And this, by the way, is very clearly understood subconsciously in Russia itself, and that is why such ‘celebrations’ are held in order to convince themselves of the nonexistent,” she said of the event in Red Square.
Eight years after occupying Crimea, Russia annexed four other regions from Ukraine in 2022: Kherson and Zaporizhzhia in the south, as well as Donetsk and Luhansk in the east. Some of those regions are only partially controlled by Russian troops, though that didn’t stop the Kremlin from holding a vote that saw armed men at some polling stations. 
The Russian electoral commission said that in four out of the five annexed regions, including Crimea, voters gave Putin more than 90% of the vote.
These results are “fictitious” and are devoid of any legitimacy while Ukrainians there who oppose the Kremlin continue to suffer at the hands of the Russians, said Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
Tasheva dismissed the claimed results as “primitive propaganda.”
But for the Kremlin, the message of the three-day election, and its Monday night celebration, was clear. Ukraine will have to fight to keep hold of its territory, with Putin’s eyes now set firmly beyond the Red Square stage to the battlefields that will define his legacy.
Keir Simmons and Natasha Lebedeva reported from Moscow, and Yuliya Talmazan from London.
input:
Putin, in power for the last 24 years, is the only leader they have ever known. They may be well into adulthood before seeing another.
“He has made Russia a lot better than it was,” Maksim Druzhinin, 18, said, speaking in English. Asked whether he expected to turn 30 before Putin might leave office, the teen, who is a student at the capital’s prestigious Higher School of Economics, said: “There is a question: Who else?”
“He has been keeping the country together for many years,” said Alexandra Volkova, a programming student, speaking in Russian. “He is definitely the most reliable candidate out there,” the 18-year-old said.
Of course, the Kremlin’s crackdown on dissent means gauging public opinion in Russia is difficult. And this was an especially pro-Putin crowd, not filled with those who turned out at noon Sunday in a silent show of defiance called for by the opposition, or quietly resigned to life under Putin.
Putin used the occasion to promise to extend the Russian railroad system all the way to occupied Crimea, as an alternative to the bridge connecting the peninsula to the Russian mainland that has come under frequent Ukrainian attacks.
The Russian leader also commended the people of Crimea for what he said was their dedication to Moscow.
“They are our pride,” Putin said. “They never separated themselves from Russia. And this is what allowed Crimea to return to our common family.”
That “return,” which boosted Putin’s approval ratings and set the course for Russia’s expansionism in the decade to follow, is considered an illegal land grab by most of the international community, rather than a historic homecoming.
Crimea, which is crucial to Russia’s naval power, has been used as a major hub and launchpad for the war against Ukraine, which has vowed to reclaim it along with all of its occupied territory and has increasingly targeted Russian military targets on the peninsula.
“Crimea is not Russian,” Tamila Tasheva, Kyiv’s permanent representative in Crimea, told NBC News. “Legally, the territory is Ukrainian. And this, by the way, is very clearly understood subconsciously in Russia itself, and that is why such ‘celebrations’ are held in order to convince themselves of the nonexistent,” she said of the event in Red Square.
Eight years after occupying Crimea, Russia annexed four other regions from Ukraine in 2022: Kherson and Zaporizhzhia in the south, as well as Donetsk and Luhansk in the east. Some of those regions are only partially controlled by Russian troops, though that didn’t stop the Kremlin from holding a vote that saw armed men at some polling stations. 
The Russian electoral commission said that in four out of the five annexed regions, including Crimea, voters gave Putin more than 90% of the vote.
These results are “fictitious” and are devoid of any legitimacy while Ukrainians there who oppose the Kremlin continue to suffer at the hands of the Russians, said Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
Tasheva dismissed the claimed results as “primitive propaganda.”
But for the Kremlin, the message of the three-day election, and its Monday night celebration, was clear. Ukraine will have to fight to keep hold of its territory, with Putin’s eyes now set firmly beyond the Red Square stage to the battlefields that will define his legacy.
Keir Simmons and Natasha Lebedeva reported from Moscow, and Yuliya Talmazan from London.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
在公共生活的所有领域，包括经济、政治、文化、意识形态和宗教等，（俄罗斯）与外界的互动都应相对受限。如此，外部力量（对俄罗斯）的影响将显著小于内部因素的影响。”该文件如此给出了定义。
到了2014年，上一轮乌克兰危机爆发，以美国为首的西方国家在金融和经济等领域对俄罗斯先后进行了90多轮制裁。从那时起，俄罗斯开始按照该文件的理念，尝试建立一套有抵御能力的、自给自足的“堡垒”体系。减持美元，发展自己的支付系统Mir，改变贸易对象国等等，都是“俄罗斯堡垒”在经济领域的体现。而在政治领域，强化意识形态、禁止外国NGO等措施也相继出台。
同时，回到那篇顶层设计“俄罗斯堡垒”的文章，俄政治精英认为，孤立主义意识形态的基底，是通过设计新理念，而不是靠政治禁令来实现的。“俄罗斯堡垒”是对俄经济、社会和外交政策内在的修正。在需要的时候，可以“激活”它让俄罗斯应对下一场冷战或热战。而当外国不再威胁俄罗斯的时候，应该放下该理念，重新回归包括西方在内的国际社会。
此外，“俄罗斯堡垒”应避免让俄罗斯人回想起苏联时期封闭的计划经济体制，毕竟无止尽的排队景象已成为了几代俄罗斯人的噩梦。因此，“俄罗斯堡垒”将是一种尽管相对封闭，却遵循市场原则的运行体系。尽量维系普通人的生计，某种程度上成为决定“堡垒”能否屹立不倒的关键。
尽管目前大量俄罗斯人都高度认同俄罗斯必胜，支持普京政府，出乎了西方舆论的意料，但一些俄方的智库和民调机构也认为，这种认同感未必能长久保持。
按照一些西方分析者的说法，克里姆林宫为此次选举设定了一项艰巨的任务，即普京要获得创纪录的得票率（80％以上）以及选民们非常高的投票率（70％以上）。
战争已成为2022年以来俄罗斯政治的核心，深刻影响着所有重大的政策和决策。但战争并没有成为总统大选压倒一切的主题。
事实上，尽管前线的战火依然激烈，胜负未分，它在大选中的存在却是相对隐性的，没有居于绝对中心位置。这背后的原因是：战场的回声并不是很受欢迎。
translation:
In all areas of public life, including economics, politics, culture, ideology and religion, (Russia's) interaction with the outside world should be relatively limited. In this way, the impact of external forces (on Russia) will be significantly smaller than the impact of internal factors. "This is how the document defines it.
By 2014, the last round of the Ukraine crisis broke out, and Western countries led by the United States imposed more than 90 rounds of sanctions on Russia in the financial and economic fields. Since then, Russia has begun to try to build a resilient and self-sufficient "fortress" system in accordance with the concept of the document. Reducing U.S. dollar holdings, developing its own payment system Mir, changing trade partner countries, etc. are all manifestations of "Russian Fortress" in the economic field. In the political field, measures such as strengthening ideology and banning foreign NGOs have also been introduced.
At the same time, going back to the article about the top-level design of "Russian Fortress", the Russian political elite believes that the foundation of isolationist ideology is achieved by designing new ideas rather than relying on political bans. “Fortress Russia” is an inherent revision of Russia’s economic, social and foreign policy. When needed, it can be "activated" to prepare Russia for the next cold or hot war. When foreign countries no longer threaten Russia, they should put down this concept and return to the international community, including the West.
In addition, "Fortress Russia" should avoid reminding Russians of the closed planned economy system of the Soviet era. After all, the sight of endless queues has been a nightmare for generations of Russians. Therefore, "Fortress Russia" will be an operating system that, although relatively closed, follows market principles. Trying to maintain the livelihood of ordinary people as much as possible has become the key to determining whether the "fortress" can survive.
Although a large number of Russians currently highly agree that Russia will win and support the Putin government, which has exceeded the expectations of Western public opinion, some Russian think tanks and polling agencies also believe that this sense of identification may not be maintained for a long time.
According to some Western analysts, the Kremlin has set a difficult task for this election, that is, Putin must obtain a record vote share (more than 80%) and a very high voter turnout (more than 70%) .
The war has become the core of Russian politics since 2022, profoundly affecting all major policies and decisions. But war did not become the overriding theme of the presidential election.
In fact, although the battle on the frontline is still fierce and the outcome is still unclear, its presence in the general election is relatively invisible and it does not occupy an absolute central position. The reason behind this: Echoes of the Battlefield wasn't very popular.

title: Vladimir Putin will predictably win the Russian election, but it still matters - here's why | World News | Sky News
content:
Within the context of the war with Ukraine, the election in Russia has a new dimension to it this year - even if the result is as predictable as it has been over the past two decades. Russia embarks on three days of voting today to reconfirm the inevitable, which is another six-year presidential term for Vladimir Putin.
Given the fact this is simply a matter of going through the motions for Putin and for the public, why does it matter and why does his administration go to such lengths to try to secure a resounding so-called victory?
First, the war-time context.
If turnout and support flag in line with a generalised anxiety regarding how this war ever reaches a conclusion - particularly a war which is pitched as a never-ending conflict with the West - then it will look as though Putin has made a terrible mistake. This he cannot allow.
"It's like Churchill saying that dictators ride on tigers they dare not dismount," says David Kankia of the Russian electoral monitoring movement, Golos.
"We have a war crisis, a political crisis inside and outside the country. And if he gets less than he did six years ago, that will mean he doesn't have the support of his people and that will crush his system."
It is also a way of proving to those who might feel at the very least some disquiet about the course their country is taking, that they are in the minority.
And a warning, if ever they needed one after the death of Putin's only real political rival Alexei Navalny, that those who might consider acting on those political reservations do so at huge personal risk.
Read more:Everything you need to know about Russia's presidential election
"It is a way of demonstrating that they are outcasts," says Andrei Kolesnikov of the Carnegie Russia Eurasia Centre.
"You must be mainstream, otherwise we will treat you as traitors, as foreign agents, as pariahs in this society.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
content:
我现在在做外贸工作，从德国运来汽车，但也与中国有业务往来。欧洲汽车，不仅是德国汽车，在俄罗斯很受欢迎。但现在也有很多中国汽车在销售。这比以前酷多了，是一个巨大的变化。
西方制裁之后，很难解释，一切都不同了。直接的外贸路线几乎都关闭了。不过，我们和中国的合作越来越紧密了。至于欧洲，我们之前和欧洲有直接贸易，但现在没有了，做生意变得很困难。但还是有路子可走。那就是“平行进口”，这也是我现在的工作。
我得说，制裁打开了许多新的机会之窗，但同时也让一些过去的机会消失不见。在经济稳定的时候，所有的市场都已经被分配好了。如果你不是像马斯克那样的天才，那么白手起家是相当困难的。而变革时代会开辟新的市场，而这些市场很容易进入。举个例子，苏联解体后，什么都奇缺。人们靠口香糖和士力架巧克力赚了数百万美元。危机永远是新的机遇。
战争前我赚得更多，因为我曾经是两家德国公司的进口商和经销商。不过，现在的收入和过去相差也不算太大。但你得知道，卢布近年来已经贬值了三次。这就意味着，即便人们获得了更多的卢布，但实际收入仍然变少了。对于俄罗斯人来说，现在的世界已经不再是过去的样子。
translation:
I am now working in foreign trade, shipping cars from Germany, but I also have business dealings with China. European cars, not only German cars, are very popular in Russia. But there are also a lot of Chinese cars on sale now. It's much cooler than before, a huge change.
After Western sanctions, it's hard to explain that everything is different. Direct foreign trade routes were almost all closed. However, our cooperation with China is getting closer and closer. As for Europe, we used to have direct trade with Europe, but now we don’t, and it has become very difficult to do business. But there is still a way to go. That's "parallel import", which is what I do now.
I would say that sanctions have opened up many new windows of opportunity, but they have also eliminated some past opportunities. When the economy is stable, all markets are already allocated. If you are not a genius like Musk, it is quite difficult to start from scratch. And times of change open up new markets that are easy to enter. For example, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, everything was in short supply. People made millions of dollars from chewing gum and Snickers bars. Crises are always new opportunities.
I made more before the war because I was an importer and distributor for two German companies. However, the difference between current income and past income is not too big. But you have to know that the ruble has devalued three times in recent years. This means that even though people receive more rubles, their real income is still less. For Russians, the world is no longer what it used to be.
input:
I am now working in foreign trade, shipping cars from Germany, but I also have business dealings with China. European cars, not only German cars, are very popular in Russia. But there are also a lot of Chinese cars on sale now. It's much cooler than before, a huge change.
After Western sanctions, it's hard to explain that everything is different. Direct foreign trade routes were almost all closed. However, our cooperation with China is getting closer and closer. As for Europe, we used to have direct trade with Europe, but now we don’t, and it has become very difficult to do business. But there is still a way to go. That's "parallel import", which is what I do now.
I would say that sanctions have opened up many new windows of opportunity, but they have also eliminated some past opportunities. When the economy is stable, all markets are already allocated. If you are not a genius like Musk, it is quite difficult to start from scratch. And times of change open up new markets that are easy to enter. For example, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, everything was in short supply. People made millions of dollars from chewing gum and Snickers bars. Crises are always new opportunities.
I made more before the war because I was an importer and distributor for two German companies. However, the difference between current income and past income is not too big. But you have to know that the ruble has devalued three times in recent years. This means that even though people receive more rubles, their real income is still less. For Russians, the world is no longer what it used to be.

title: 西方指责俄总统选举不公正 中朝贺普京当选 | 俄罗斯 | 中国 | 乌克兰 | 大纪元
content:
在非洲，西方一直在努力争取非洲国家的支持，在乌克兰战争问题上孤立莫斯科。一些报刊认为，普京的连任强化了布基纳法索（Burkina Faso）、马里和尼日尔支持俄罗斯的立场。
上述三个国家位于萨赫勒地区（the Sahel region，指非洲北部撒哈拉沙漠和中部苏丹草原地区之间的一条长度超过3,800公里的地带，西起大西洋，伸延到东部非洲之角），在近年来的政变后加强了与俄罗斯的关系，牺牲了它们的传统盟友法国和美国的利益。
《布基纳法索日报》（Aujourd’hui au Faso）称，“普京连任在非洲听起来似乎无关紧要，但在萨赫勒地区的背景下，则具有特殊的意义，因为普京控制着非洲大陆新的地缘政治力量平衡，俄罗斯的存在和影响力正日益增强。”
虽然普京选举获胜已无悬念，但他能否保持其对权力的铁腕控制，尤其是在乌克兰问题上最终获胜，都远非稳操胜券。他曾经历了一次明显的误判，他的政府对乌克兰的“特别军事行动”并没有如预期那样迅速获胜，还经历了雇佣军瓦格纳集团首领叶夫根尼‧普里戈津（Yevgeny Prigozhin）发动的一次叛乱，并且在战场上接连失利，而西方的制裁则切断了俄罗斯经济与全球市场的大部分联系。
重要的是，美国11月的总统大选很可能会改变俄乌战争局势，普京能否走出困境，还难以预料。美国总统拜登尚未对普京胜选发表评论。
（本文参考了路透社的报导）
责任编辑：李琳#
translation:
In Africa, the West has been trying to win over African countries to isolate Moscow over the war in Ukraine. Some newspapers believe that Putin's re-election has strengthened the pro-Russian stance of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger.
The above three countries are located in the Sahel region (the Sahel region, which refers to a strip of more than 3,800 kilometers long between the Sahara Desert in northern Africa and the Sudanese grassland region in central Africa, starting from the Atlantic Ocean in the west and extending to the Horn of Africa in the east). In recent years, After the coup, they strengthened relations with Russia at the expense of their traditional allies France and the United States.
"Burkina Faso Daily" (Aujourd'hui au Faso) stated that "Putin's re-election may sound insignificant in Africa, but in the context of the Sahel region, it has special significance because Putin controls the African continent. A new geopolitical balance of power, with Russia’s growing presence and influence.”
Although Putin's electoral victory is no longer in doubt, whether he can maintain his iron grip on power, especially his eventual victory on the Ukraine issue, is far from a sure thing. He experienced a clear miscalculation when his government's "Special Military Operation" in Ukraine did not succeed as quickly as expected, as well as the mercenary Wagner Group leader Yevgeny Prigozhin It launched an insurgency and suffered successive battlefield defeats, while Western sanctions cut off much of the Russian economy from global markets.
Importantly, the U.S. presidential election in November is likely to change the situation in the Russia-Ukraine war. Whether Putin can get out of the predicament is difficult to predict. U.S. President Joe Biden has yet to comment on Putin's victory.
(This article refers to reports from Reuters)
Editor in charge: Li Lin#
input:
In Africa, the West has been trying to win over African countries to isolate Moscow over the war in Ukraine. Some newspapers believe that Putin's re-election has strengthened the pro-Russian stance of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger.
The above three countries are located in the Sahel region (the Sahel region, which refers to a strip of more than 3,800 kilometers long between the Sahara Desert in northern Africa and the Sudanese grassland region in central Africa, starting from the Atlantic Ocean in the west and extending to the Horn of Africa in the east). In recent years, After the coup, they strengthened relations with Russia at the expense of their traditional allies France and the United States.
"Burkina Faso Daily" (Aujourd'hui au Faso) stated that "Putin's re-election may sound insignificant in Africa, but in the context of the Sahel region, it has special significance because Putin controls the African continent. A new geopolitical balance of power, with Russia’s growing presence and influence.”
Although Putin's electoral victory is no longer in doubt, whether he can maintain his iron grip on power, especially his eventual victory on the Ukraine issue, is far from a sure thing. He experienced a clear miscalculation when his government's "Special Military Operation" in Ukraine did not succeed as quickly as expected, as well as the mercenary Wagner Group leader Yevgeny Prigozhin It launched an insurgency and suffered successive battlefield defeats, while Western sanctions cut off much of the Russian economy from global markets.
Importantly, the U.S. presidential election in November is likely to change the situation in the Russia-Ukraine war. Whether Putin can get out of the predicament is difficult to predict. U.S. President Joe Biden has yet to comment on Putin's victory.
(This article refers to reports from Reuters)
Editor in charge: Li Lin#

title: 普京宣布将参加2024年俄罗斯总统选举
content:
当地时间12月8日，俄罗斯总统普京宣布将参加2024年总统选举。
普京（资料图）

俄罗斯联邦委员会主席马特维延科当天证实，普京已决定参加俄总统选举。马特维延科说，普京的这一决定是俄罗斯作为强大、安全的主权国家的保障。
俄国家杜马副主席、统一俄罗斯党最高委员会成员涅维罗夫表示，该党将无条件支持普京作为候选人参加总统选举。
此外，俄罗斯中央选举委员会当天宣布，俄总统选举的具体投票日为2024年3月15日、16日和17日。
translation:
On December 8, local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin announced that he would participate in the 2024 presidential election.
Putin (data map)

Russian Federation Council Chairman Matviyenko confirmed on the same day that Putin has decided to participate in the Russian presidential election. Matviyenko said that Putin’s decision is a guarantee for Russia as a strong, secure and sovereign country.
Nevirov, deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma and member of the Supreme Committee of the United Russia Party, said that the party will unconditionally support Putin as a candidate to participate in the presidential election.
In addition, the Russian Central Election Commission announced on the same day that the specific voting days for the Russian presidential election are March 15, 16 and 17, 2024.
input:
On December 8, local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin announced that he would participate in the 2024 presidential election.
Putin (data map)

Russian Federation Council Chairman Matviyenko confirmed on the same day that Putin has decided to participate in the Russian presidential election. Matviyenko said that Putin’s decision is a guarantee for Russia as a strong, secure and sovereign country.
Nevirov, deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma and member of the Supreme Committee of the United Russia Party, said that the party will unconditionally support Putin as a candidate to participate in the presidential election.
In addition, the Russian Central Election Commission announced on the same day that the specific voting days for the Russian presidential election are March 15, 16 and 17, 2024.

title: Inside the Kremlin's party as Putin celebrates election win
content:
In a neighboring room, Putin could be heard addressing election workers. "I want to thank the citizens of Russia," he said, "we’re all one team." As he wrapped up, they chanted “Russia, Russia.” 
Minutes later Putin walked in, jumped up on stage like a Western politician on the campaign trail and personally chose whom to take questions from, mostly soft-ball inquiries from the Kremlin press pool. 
But while the victory he was basking in offered little surprise, the Russian leader did make rare news.
Putin suggested he had agreed to the idea of swapping Alexei Navalny for prisoners held in the West, but offered no explanation for why just days later Navalny was dead.
He was responding to a question from NBC News, which asked whether events such as the jailing of American journalist Evan Gershkovich, the barring of Boris Nadezhdin — a candidate who opposed his war in Ukraine — and the death of Navalny in an Arctic penal colony during the campaign would really have happened in a democracy. 
Russia’s independent media has either been disbanded or forced to work from exile in the wake of the Kremlin’s crackdown.
At another event in central Moscow, Russian politicians, celebrities and journalists had begun to gather for a celebration early Sunday afternoon. 
Eating Russian pancakes from the rooftop venue with a stunning view over Moscow, the crowd watched a live show broadcast online with video feeds from various regions, including those in occupied Ukraine who were voting in this election for the first time. 
An election night logo read “Russia has no borders” — a reference, organizers told NBC News, to the fact that voting had taken place around the world, although in Ukraine those words may carry a different meaning. 
A woman in an elegant gown wore a diamond brooch in the shape of a Z, the ubiquitous pro-war icon of Putin’s Russia. She said the brooch was Chanel, the “Z” repurposed from the piece’s original “N.” She said she was Ukrainian but had renounced her citizenship in 2014, calling Ukraine’s leadership "terrorists" in an echo of a common Kremlin claim.
Everyone there was pro-Putin and pro-war, with musical artists punctuating more serious exchanges throughout the day. 
The pop act Grinkevich, from the Ural mountains city of Yekaterinburg, gleefully sang “Don’t say goodbye!” Later, a panel discussion included allegations of Western interference in the elections, denied by governments in the West.
As the results were announced, the three Kremlin-approved candidates who ran against Putin delivered speeches.
Putin wasn’t there, but he was a constant presence. Many of the speakers repeated his slogans.
input:
In a neighboring room, Putin could be heard addressing election workers. "I want to thank the citizens of Russia," he said, "we’re all one team." As he wrapped up, they chanted “Russia, Russia.” 
Minutes later Putin walked in, jumped up on stage like a Western politician on the campaign trail and personally chose whom to take questions from, mostly soft-ball inquiries from the Kremlin press pool. 
But while the victory he was basking in offered little surprise, the Russian leader did make rare news.
Putin suggested he had agreed to the idea of swapping Alexei Navalny for prisoners held in the West, but offered no explanation for why just days later Navalny was dead.
He was responding to a question from NBC News, which asked whether events such as the jailing of American journalist Evan Gershkovich, the barring of Boris Nadezhdin — a candidate who opposed his war in Ukraine — and the death of Navalny in an Arctic penal colony during the campaign would really have happened in a democracy. 
Russia’s independent media has either been disbanded or forced to work from exile in the wake of the Kremlin’s crackdown.
At another event in central Moscow, Russian politicians, celebrities and journalists had begun to gather for a celebration early Sunday afternoon. 
Eating Russian pancakes from the rooftop venue with a stunning view over Moscow, the crowd watched a live show broadcast online with video feeds from various regions, including those in occupied Ukraine who were voting in this election for the first time. 
An election night logo read “Russia has no borders” — a reference, organizers told NBC News, to the fact that voting had taken place around the world, although in Ukraine those words may carry a different meaning. 
A woman in an elegant gown wore a diamond brooch in the shape of a Z, the ubiquitous pro-war icon of Putin’s Russia. She said the brooch was Chanel, the “Z” repurposed from the piece’s original “N.” She said she was Ukrainian but had renounced her citizenship in 2014, calling Ukraine’s leadership "terrorists" in an echo of a common Kremlin claim.
Everyone there was pro-Putin and pro-war, with musical artists punctuating more serious exchanges throughout the day. 
The pop act Grinkevich, from the Ural mountains city of Yekaterinburg, gleefully sang “Don’t say goodbye!” Later, a panel discussion included allegations of Western interference in the elections, denied by governments in the West.
As the results were announced, the three Kremlin-approved candidates who ran against Putin delivered speeches.
Putin wasn’t there, but he was a constant presence. Many of the speakers repeated his slogans.

title: Putin scores a resounding win, but what’s next for Russia? | CNN
content:
And regardless of how Putin addresses his country’s manpower problem, there is another likely item on the agenda. The crackdown on Russia’s domestic opposition – what’s left of it – can continue unabated.
    

            In remarks following the closing of polls across Russia, Putin made an unusual move: He mentioned the unmentionable, the name of late Russian opposition leader Alexey Navalny.
    

            Putin has long made a habit of not mentioning Navalny, who died last month in a Russian prison north of the Arctic Circle. But in response to a question about Navalny’s death and the exclusion of opposition voices during the election campaign, Putin broke protocol to call Navalny’s death a “sad event,” but dismissed a question about the fairness of the elections by changing the subject, a favorite Putin information tactic.
    

            “As for Mr. Navalny, yes he passed away – it is always a sad event,” Putin said. “And there were other cases when people in prisons passed away. Didn’t this happen in the United States? It did, and not once.”
    

            That might suggest Putin thinks he is on safe ground. But whataboutism is not necessarily a sign of confidence.
    

            Predicting Putin’s post-election course of action is a tricky business. The Russian leader has for the short term sanction-proofed his economy; his ammunition factories are outproducing the US and its European allies and the political landscape has been cleared of all competition.
    

            But war is always unpredictable. And whatever Putin’s efforts to spin things in his favor, Russia’s longer-term problems – demographic decline, the cost of war and sanctions, and the inherent brittleness of one-man rule – are not likely to disappear before Putin stands for a sixth term in office.

title: 俄罗斯总统普京签署总统选举法修正案
content:
普京 澎湃影像 资料图

当地时间11月14日，俄罗斯总统普京签署总统选举法修正案。
修正案规定禁止使用所有被冻结的资源进行竞选活动。俄罗斯联邦委员会宪法委员会第一副主席弗拉基米尔·波莱塔耶夫在解释新的修正案时表示，根据俄罗斯联邦中央选举委员会与俄罗斯国防部的协商结果，处于战时状态的俄罗斯联邦主体仍旧可以进行选举投票。而对于俄罗斯海外选民，俄驻外大使馆负责人可以视情况改变投票的开始、结束和持续时间。
translation:
Putin The Paper Image File Map

On November 14, local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed an amendment to the Presidential Election Law.
The amendment prohibits the use of all frozen resources for campaigning. Explaining the new amendment, First Deputy Chairman of the Constitutional Committee of the Federation Council Vladimir Poletaev said that according to the results of negotiations between the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation and the Russian Ministry of Defense, subjects of the Russian Federation that are in a state of war Election voting is still possible. For Russian overseas voters, the head of the Russian embassy abroad can change the start, end and duration of voting depending on the situation.
input:
Putin The Paper Image File Map

On November 14, local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed an amendment to the Presidential Election Law.
The amendment prohibits the use of all frozen resources for campaigning. Explaining the new amendment, First Deputy Chairman of the Constitutional Committee of the Federation Council Vladimir Poletaev said that according to the results of negotiations between the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation and the Russian Ministry of Defense, subjects of the Russian Federation that are in a state of war Election voting is still possible. For Russian overseas voters, the head of the Russian embassy abroad can change the start, end and duration of voting depending on the situation.

title: 普京赢得俄总统选举，表示将继续推动国家发展
content:
据俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间18日凌晨发布的数据，在俄总统选举统计完成的85%选票中，现任总统普京以87.19%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人，实际已经赢得此次总统选举。
俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫以4.24%的得票率位居第二，俄新人党的达万科夫得票率为3.99%名列第三，俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基以3.16%的得票率位列第四。
普京18日凌晨在竞选总部发表讲话，感谢所有选民的支持。他表示，俄罗斯是一个大家庭，本次选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望，国家的所有任务都将完成。俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展，变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。
普京在随后召开的记者会上表示，他将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。他说，国家发展的所有主要任务都已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述，将竭尽所能完成既定目标。
俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。根据俄总统选举规则，在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举结果，并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
俄中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃17日说，俄方邀请了来自129个国家和地区的1115名国际观察员监督投票，确保选举公正透明。
translation:
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and has actually won the presidential election.
Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.24% of the votes, Davankov of the New People's Party of Russia ranked third with 3.99% of the votes, and Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked third with 3.16% of the votes. The rate ranks fourth.
Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
Putin said at the subsequent press conference that he would continue to promote national development in the new term. He said that all major tasks for national development have been spelled out in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of Parliament and that every effort will be made to achieve the set goals.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said on the 17th that Russia invited 1,115 international observers from 129 countries and regions to monitor the voting to ensure that the election was fair and transparent.

title: 没有对手的选举：俄罗斯展开总统大选投票，普京获胜几无悬念
content:
俄罗斯选民星期五（3月15日）开始陆续前往全国各地的投票所，为选举新一任总统而举行为期三天的投票。但是由于现任总统普京镇压异己，铲除异议与杂音，而且禁止两位反对派候选人参选，这次选举被广泛认为不过只是一场表演，普京将毫无悬念地获得胜选，赢得又一个六年任期。

美联社在报道中指出，俄罗斯大选前，普京肆无忌惮地打压独立媒体和主要的人权团体，已经把俄罗斯的整个政治体系牢牢掌控在自己手中。
俄罗斯大选也是在俄乌战争进入第三个年头之际举行的。莫斯科对基辅而言，在兵员和武器方面占据绝对优势，因此俄军掌握了战场主动权，也在战斗中取得一些细小而缓慢的战果。但是乌克兰斗志不减，乌军常常在敌后发动袭击，甚至对俄罗斯本土直接发动袭击。远程攻击型无人机曾经多次打到莫斯科，而高科技的无人机和无人艇摧毁了俄军黑海舰队将近三分之一的主力舰艇。

由于俄罗斯国土面积超大，横跨11个时区，因此俄罗斯选民从星期五到星期天有三天的时间可以前往投票所投票。被俄罗斯非法吞并的乌克兰领土上的居民也可以投票。俄国人还可以首次上网为总统大选投票。

美联社引述俄罗斯当局的话说，在莫斯科的投票所星期五启动之后，超过20万当地选民很快就完成了投票。

现年71岁的普京是为他的第五个总统任期竞选，而且几乎完全没有挑战的对手。
translation:
Russian voters began to go to polling stations across the country on Friday (March 15) for a three-day vote to elect a new president. However, as the current President Putin suppresses dissent, eradicates dissent and noise, and bans two opposition candidates from running, this election is widely regarded as just a show. Putin will win without any suspense and win another six-year election. year term.

The Associated Press pointed out in its report that before the Russian election, Putin unscrupulously suppressed independent media and major human rights groups, and had firmly controlled Russia's entire political system in his hands.
The Russian election was also held as the Russo-Ukrainian war entered its third year. Moscow has an absolute advantage over Kiev in terms of soldiers and weapons. Therefore, the Russian army has taken the initiative on the battlefield and achieved some small and slow results in the battle. However, Ukraine's fighting spirit has not diminished, and the Ukrainian army often launches attacks behind enemy lines and even directly attacks Russia itself. Long-range attack drones have hit Moscow many times, and high-tech drones and unmanned boats destroyed nearly one-third of the main ships of the Russian Black Sea Fleet.

Because Russia is so large and spans 11 time zones, Russian voters have three days from Friday to Sunday to go to the polls to vote. Residents of Ukrainian territories illegally annexed by Russia can also vote. Russians will also be able to vote online for the first time in a presidential election.

The Associated Press quoted Russian authorities as saying that more than 200,000 local voters completed voting quickly after polling stations in Moscow opened on Friday.

Putin, 71, is running for his fifth presidential term and has faced almost no challenge.

title: Up First briefing: Putin wins Russian election; SCOTUS censorship case : NPR
content:
Good morning. You're reading the Up First newsletter. Subscribe here to get it delivered to your inbox, and listen to the Up First podcast for all the news you need to start your day.
At a news conference in Moscow hours after polls closed, Russian President Vladimir Putin thanked his country for its support following a three-day election. He also commented on the death of the opposition leader Alexei Navalny for the first time. Partial results show Putin easily winning a fifth term. Western countries are saying the vote was neither free nor fair. 
Former President Donald Trump is making headlines again for comments he made about Jan. 6 rioters, immigrants, asylum seekers and the U.S. auto industry at a campaign rally in Ohio this weekend. Trump warned that "it's going to be a bloodbath for the country" if he's not elected — referring to the auto industry and his plans to increase tariffs on foreign-made cars.
The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments today on a case focused on the federal government's ability to combat what it sees as false, misleading, or dangerous information online. The case will be a test of First Amendment rights in the internet age. An appeals court ruled last September that key government officials, including those in the White House, CDC and FBI, could not communicate with social media companies. The court said these officials likely violated First Amendment rights by pressuring the companies to moderate or change content about the COVID pandemic, election interference and more. The court is also expected to hear a case about government influence and First Amendment rights related to the National Rifle Association after it finishes arguments on the social media case.
When Israel launched its military response to the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attacks, it told Palestinians in northern Gaza to evacuate and head south. When the Israeli military operation moved to central Gaza, Palestinians were again ordered to move south. Now, five months into the war, Gaza's southernmost town of Rafah is seeing a mass displacement of an estimated 1.5 million people sheltering there – more than half of Gaza's population. 
Canadian rapper Drake has helped recreate an iconic 1980s art carnival from Hamburg, Germany, in Los Angeles. The original Luna Luna festival, which was the brainchild of Austrian multimedia artist Andre Heller, featured work from the top contemporary artists of the 20th century, including Jean-Michel Basquiat and Roy Lichtenstein
See photos from the revived Luna Luna festival and learn more about this amusement park of art. 
This newsletter was edited by Majd Al-Waheidi. Mansee Khurana contributed.

title: Russia claims US and 'Western countries' are trying to hack its presidential election
content:
As Russia prepares for its presidential election this week, its systems are reportedly being targeted by “massive” cyberattacks, according to local authorities.
Russian President Vladimir Putin is running against three “officially permitted” opponents in the election scheduled to take place from March 15 to 17. It will be Russia's first-ever three-day-long presidential election and the first instance when residents from certain regions, including Moscow, can cast their votes online.
Last week, a Russian state official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced that hackers from “Western countries” are plotting and already orchestrating cyberattacks on Russian election infrastructure.
“It’s good that our electoral system turned out to be resistant to external cyber influence, but this is also an indicator of how great the pressure of enemies is on the Russian state,” said the ministry’s ambassador-at-large Gennady Askaldovich.
The head of the Russian election commission, Ella Pamfilova, also stated last week that Russian "enemies" are attempting to meddle in the presidential elections in the country "to such an extent as never before."
“The Russian electoral system today is experiencing unprecedented attempts at interference; the hacker attacks are ongoing; the purpose of all this is to disrupt the presidential election,” she added.
Pamfilova said that due to cyberattacks on the election commission’s services and websites, electronic voting is allowed only in those regions where "its security is guaranteed.”
Neither Askaldovich nor Pamfilova provided any evidence for alleged election-related cyberattacks.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
content:
二是奋力发展经济,带领国家从“二三流”跃进世界前五。

普京首任俄总统之前 ,在其《千年之交的俄罗斯》一文中指出,“俄罗斯现在面临着十分复杂的经济和社会问题。（上世纪）九十年代俄国内生产总值几乎下降了50%,相当于美国的十分之一,相当于中国的五分之一。1998年危机之后,俄人均国内生产总值降至3500美元,这仅是‘七大国’平均水平的五分之一”。“俄罗斯正处在其数百年来最困难的一个历史时期,大概这是俄罗斯近200-300年以来,首次真正面临沦为世界二流国家、抑或三流国家的危险”。

由于普京客观、正确地看待和评价24年前俄罗斯的经济状况,他上任当年1月批准的《俄罗斯联邦国家安全构想》第二部分“俄罗斯的国家利益”中指出,“俄罗斯在经济领域的国家利益是最主要的国家利益”,俄内政外交政策中最优先的方向是“战胜贫困”。

理念导航,起步维艰。普京的经济战略是在其前任叶利钦时期经济颓势下展开。他一方面调整经济政策,进行税收改革；另一方面,以“强人”作风大力打击寡头政治,恢复国家对经济命脉的掌控,同时从俄罗斯的基本国情出发,提出以资源依赖型经济发展为基础,以追求并实现经济快速增长为目标,从而在其任职的前8年,俄罗斯实现了经济由摆脱危机到恢复性增长、再到逐步振兴的发展历程,保持了平均近7%的增速,迈入世界十大经济体行列。

之后的10多年,尽管俄受到国际经济形势下滑和疫情的严重影响,俄经济遭遇种种困难,但去年俄国民生产总值仍增长3.6%,高于世界平均水平。俄经济形势从2000年排位世界第十六位,落后于西班牙、荷兰,甚至被巴西、印度、韩国等国超越,2023年俄已成为欧洲第一大经济体,国民生产总值位列世界第五位,国内贫困问题得到改善,贫困人口从23年前的4200多万减少到目前的1350万。2014和2018年俄罗斯有实力先后举办了索契冬奥会和世界杯。
translation:
The second is to strive to develop the economy and lead the country from "second or third rate" to the top five in the world.

Before Putin became the first Russian president, he pointed out in his article "Russia at the Turn of the Millennium" that "Russia is now facing very complex economic and social problems. In the 1990s (of the last century), Russia's GDP dropped by almost 50% , equivalent to one-tenth that of the United States and one-fifth that of China. After the 1998 crisis, Russia's per capita GDP dropped to US$3,500, which is only one-fifth of the average level of the 'Seven Big Countries'." . "Russia is in the most difficult historical period in its hundreds of years. This is probably the first time in the past 200-300 years that Russia is truly in danger of becoming a second- or third-rate country in the world."

Because Putin objectively and correctly viewed and evaluated Russia’s economic situation 24 years ago, the second part of the “Russian Federation’s National Security Concept” approved in January of the year he took office, “Russia’s National Interests,” pointed out that “Russia’s national interests in the economic field "Interests are the most important national interests", and the top priority in Russia's domestic and foreign policies is "overcoming poverty."

Concept navigation has a difficult start. Putin's economic strategy was launched amid the economic downturn of his predecessor Yeltsin. On the one hand, he adjusted economic policies and carried out tax reforms; on the other hand, he used a "strongman" style to vigorously combat oligarchy and restore the country's control over the economic lifeline. At the same time, based on Russia's basic national conditions, he proposed resource-dependent economic development as the basis , with the goal of pursuing and achieving rapid economic growth, in the first eight years of his tenure, Russia achieved an economic development process from emerging from crisis to restorative growth, and then to gradual revitalization, maintaining an average growth rate of nearly 7%. Entering the ranks of the world's top ten economies.

In the following 10 years, although Russia was severely affected by the decline of the international economic situation and the epidemic, and the Russian economy encountered various difficulties, Russia's GDP still grew by 3.6% last year, which was higher than the world average. Russia's economic situation has ranked sixteenth in the world since 2000, lagging behind Spain and the Netherlands, and even surpassed by Brazil, India, South Korea and other countries. In 2023, Russia has become the largest economy in Europe, and its gross national product ranks first in the world. Fifth, the domestic poverty problem has been improved, with the number of poor people reduced from more than 42 million 23 years ago to the current 13.5 million. In 2014 and 2018, Russia had the capability to host the Sochi Winter Olympics and the World Cup.

title: Votes, protests and arrests in final day of Russian election
content:
Obama has two No. 1 seeds in the Final Four on the men's side and three top seeds in the women's Final Four.
Threads, the Twitter-like app from Instagram, is rolling out its "trending now" feature widely to all users in the U.S. The official rollout comes a month after the app started testing the feature with a select number of users in the country.  Trending topics are available on the search page and in the app's For You Feed.  In a Threads post, Instagram head Adam Mosseri announced the official launch and noted that the company sees it as "an easy way to see what others are talking about on Threads."
As part of its energy transition strategy, energy giant Shell plans to shed some of its retail locations, including gasoline stations, to focus more on EV charging sites.
The popular 40-ounce cups have gotten a totally tubular '80s-style makeover.
Artificial general intelligence (AGI) -- often referred to as "strong AI," "full AI," "human-level AI" or "general intelligent action" -- represents a significant future leap in the field of artificial intelligence.  Unlike narrow AI, which is tailored for specific tasks, such as detecting product flaws, summarizing the news, or building you a website, AGI will be able to perform a broad spectrum of cognitive tasks at or above human levels.  Addressing the press this week at Nvidia's annual GTC developer conference, CEO Jensen Huang appeared to be getting really bored of discussing the subject — not least because he finds himself misquoted a lot, he says.
The Pokémon Company said it detected hacking attempts against some of its users and reset those user account passwords.  Last week, an alert was visible on Pokémon’s official support website that said, “Following an attempt to compromise our account system, Pokémon proactively locked the accounts of fans who might have been affected.”  The alert about hacking attempts that The Pokémon Company posted on its official support website.
Investors are waiting with baited breath for the Fed's big decision.
We know it's March and you may be more stressed about your bracket this week than your fantasy dynasty shares. Heck, who are we kidding, you definitely have someone you're stressed about after the flurry of free agency moves in the past week. Matt Harmon and Andy Behrens are back to dust off the 'Panic Meter' and provide clarity and calm to all your submissions.
Chase Young signed a one-year, $13 million deal with the Saints on Monday.

Trending topics are available on the search page and in the app's For You Feed.  In a Threads post, Instagram head Adam Mosseri announced the official launch and noted that the company sees it as "an easy way to see what others are talking about on Threads."
As part of its energy transition strategy, energy giant Shell plans to shed some of its retail locations, including gasoline stations, to focus more on EV charging sites.
The popular 40-ounce cups have gotten a totally tubular '80s-style makeover.
Artificial general intelligence (AGI) -- often referred to as "strong AI," "full AI," "human-level AI" or "general intelligent action" -- represents a significant future leap in the field of artificial intelligence.  Unlike narrow AI, which is tailored for specific tasks, such as detecting product flaws, summarizing the news, or building you a website, AGI will be able to perform a broad spectrum of cognitive tasks at or above human levels.  Addressing the press this week at Nvidia's annual GTC developer conference, CEO Jensen Huang appeared to be getting really bored of discussing the subject — not least because he finds himself misquoted a lot, he says.
The Pokémon Company said it detected hacking attempts against some of its users and reset those user account passwords.  Last week, an alert was visible on Pokémon’s official support website that said, “Following an attempt to compromise our account system, Pokémon proactively locked the accounts of fans who might have been affected.”  The alert about hacking attempts that The Pokémon Company posted on its official support website.
Investors are waiting with baited breath for the Fed's big decision.

Heck, who are we kidding, you definitely have someone you're stressed about after the flurry of free agency moves in the past week.
