title: 俄罗斯总统大选：普京为何大费周章举行这次选举 - BBC News 中文
content:
至于反战参选人纳杰日丁（Boris Nadezhdin）获数万名俄罗斯人排队签名支持，但最终未能登记为候选人。
俄罗斯选民将在3月15至17日三天内投票，这在该国总统选举史上尚属首次。
三天投票的形式首次出现在2020年宪法修正案投票，以及在新冠疫情期间就保障公共健康进行的投票。有独立观察员曾提出批评，认为这难以确保投票过程的透明度，但此次选举再次采用这种形式。
此外，这次总统选举将首次采用远程在线投票系统，主要是在以抗议投票闻名或当局难以确保投票率的地区。
俄罗斯还因将乌克兰被占领土纳入此次选举而备受批评，有报道称当地居民受到压力。
欧洲安全与合作组织（OSCE）议会大会自1993年以来向俄罗斯大选派遣观察员，但在过去三年已经停止。
俄罗斯没有独立民意调查，大多数俄罗斯人从国有媒体获取新闻，而国有媒体严重偏袒普京及其政策。
专家认为，对政府持怀疑态度的俄罗斯人比表面上看来要多，但支持反对派的轻微举动都有可能遭到严惩，因此异议民众不敢公开表态。
纳瓦尔尼遗孀尤利娅呼吁同胞抵制投票，并要求外国政府不承认这次选举的结果。
后者不太可能成真，但前者有可能发生。俄罗斯独立媒体《美杜莎》引述一名接近普京的消息人士指，当局确实担心投票率低。“如果人们不怀疑现任总统会获胜，为什么还要去投呢？”
这次选举最有可能的结果，是普京取得令人信服的胜利，至少在纸面上是如此。
但低投票率将意味着对总统的支持减弱，这反过来又可能带来更严格的国家控制，使俄罗斯进一步陷入恐惧和压迫的氛围。
translation:
As for the anti-war candidate Boris Nadezhdin, tens of thousands of Russians lined up to sign in support, but ultimately failed to register as a candidate.
Russian voters will cast their votes over three days, March 15-17, for the first time in the country's presidential election history.
The three-day voting format first appeared in the 2020 constitutional amendment vote and the vote on protecting public health during the new crown epidemic. Independent observers have criticized this approach as making it difficult to ensure transparency in the voting process, but this election has adopted this format again.
In addition, this presidential election will for the first time use remote online voting systems, mainly in areas known for protest voting or where authorities have difficulty ensuring turnout.
Russia has also been criticized for including Ukraine's occupied territories in the election, with reports of pressure on local residents.
The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) Parliamentary Assembly has sent observers to Russian elections since 1993 but has stopped in the past three years.
There are no independent opinion polls in Russia, and most Russians get their news from state-owned media, which is heavily biased in favor of Putin and his policies.
Experts believe that more Russians are skeptical of the government than appears on the surface, but even the slightest move to support the opposition may be severely punished, so dissidents are afraid to speak out publicly.
Navalny's widow, Yulia, called on compatriots to boycott the vote and asked foreign governments not to recognize the results of the election.
The latter is unlikely to come true, but the former is possible. The independent Russian media "Medusa" quoted a source close to Putin as saying that the authorities were indeed worried about low turnout. “Why would people vote if they didn’t have any doubt that the current president would win?”
The most likely outcome of this election, at least on paper, is a convincing victory for Putin.
But low turnout would mean weakening support for the president, which in turn could usher in tighter state controls and plunge Russia further into a climate of fear and oppression.
input:
As for the anti-war candidate Boris Nadezhdin, tens of thousands of Russians lined up to sign in support, but ultimately failed to register as a candidate.
Russian voters will cast their votes over three days, March 15-17, for the first time in the country's presidential election history.
The three-day voting format first appeared in the 2020 constitutional amendment vote and the vote on protecting public health during the new crown epidemic. Independent observers have criticized this approach as making it difficult to ensure transparency in the voting process, but this election has adopted this format again.
In addition, this presidential election will for the first time use remote online voting systems, mainly in areas known for protest voting or where authorities have difficulty ensuring turnout.
Russia has also been criticized for including Ukraine's occupied territories in the election, with reports of pressure on local residents.
The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) Parliamentary Assembly has sent observers to Russian elections since 1993 but has stopped in the past three years.
There are no independent opinion polls in Russia, and most Russians get their news from state-owned media, which is heavily biased in favor of Putin and his policies.
Experts believe that more Russians are skeptical of the government than appears on the surface, but even the slightest move to support the opposition may be severely punished, so dissidents are afraid to speak out publicly.
Navalny's widow, Yulia, called on compatriots to boycott the vote and asked foreign governments not to recognize the results of the election.
The latter is unlikely to come true, but the former is possible. The independent Russian media "Medusa" quoted a source close to Putin as saying that the authorities were indeed worried about low turnout. “Why would people vote if they didn’t have any doubt that the current president would win?”
The most likely outcome of this election, at least on paper, is a convincing victory for Putin.
But low turnout would mean weakening support for the president, which in turn could usher in tighter state controls and plunge Russia further into a climate of fear and oppression.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选：普京为何大费周章举行这次选举 - BBC News 中文
content:
在过去24个月，数十万俄罗斯人离开国土，他们大多是受过教育、家境富裕的年轻人，要么是因为不同意战争，要么是不想被征召入伍。
即使不参与竞选活动，战争也是媒体的重要主题，俄罗斯人无法回避它。
高投票率和对总统的高支持率，将增加其后续决策的合法性，当中很多决策将直接关乎入侵乌克兰。
除了普京，还有另外三名登记在册的候选人： 民族主义保守派候选人斯卢茨基（Leonid Slutsky）丶共产党候选人哈里托诺夫（Nikolai Kharitonov）和新人党的达万科夫（Vladislav Davankov）。新人党新成立，在俄罗斯杜马下议院拥有少量代表。
三人都表示支持普京及俄罗斯在乌克兰的战争，他们都没有构成真正的威胁。
普京真正的挑战者要么已入狱，要么已被消灭，要么已逃离俄罗斯。普京最激烈的反对者纳瓦尔尼今年2月在戒备森严的监狱去世。
BBC记者罗森伯格（Steve Rosenberg）询问候选人哈里托诺夫是否认为自己会成为比普京更好的总统，他回答说这不是他能说的，选民将“决定一切”。他自2022年以来就一直受到西方制裁。
俄罗斯自由民主党（LDPR）议员斯卢茨基（Leonid Slutsky）曾多次被指控性骚扰。他组织了对被占领的克里米亚的国事访问，自2014年以来一直受到国际制裁。
新人党的达万科夫（Vladislav Davankov）在媒体上的曝光率最低。他是一家化妆品公司的共同创始人，2023年在莫斯科市长选举中仅获5%多一点的选票。在与乌克兰的战争中主张“和平与谈判”的同时，达万科夫投票支持吞并乌克兰领土，这也导致他受到国际制裁。
translation:
Over the past 24 months, hundreds of thousands of Russians, mostly educated and well-off young people, have left the country, either because they disagree with the war or because they do not want to be drafted into the army.
Even when not involved in the campaign, war is an important theme in the media and Russians cannot avoid it.
High turnout and high support for the president will increase the legitimacy of his subsequent decisions, many of which will be directly related to the invasion of Ukraine.
In addition to Putin, there are three other registered candidates: the nationalist conservative candidate Leonid Slutsky, the communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov and the New People's Party's Vladislav Davankov). The New People's Party was newly formed and had a small number of representatives in the lower house of the Russian Duma.
All three have expressed support for Putin and Russia's war in Ukraine, and none of them poses a real threat.
Putin's real challengers are either in jail, eliminated or have fled Russia. Navalny, Putin's fiercest opponent, died in a high-security prison in February.
BBC reporter Steve Rosenberg asked candidate Kharitonov if he thought he would be a better president than Putin. He replied that it was not for him to say and that voters would "decide everything." He has been subject to Western sanctions since 2022.
Leonid Slutsky, a member of Russia’s Liberal Democratic Party (LDPR), has been accused of sexual harassment many times. He organized a state visit to occupied Crimea, which has been subject to international sanctions since 2014.
Vladislav Davankov of the New People's Party has the lowest exposure in the media. He is the co-founder of a cosmetics company and received just over 5% of the vote in the 2023 Moscow mayoral election. While advocating for "peace and negotiation" in the war with Ukraine, Davankov voted for the annexation of Ukrainian territory, which also led to him being subject to international sanctions.
input:
Over the past 24 months, hundreds of thousands of Russians, mostly educated and well-off young people, have left the country, either because they disagree with the war or because they do not want to be drafted into the army.
Even when not involved in the campaign, war is an important theme in the media and Russians cannot avoid it.
High turnout and high support for the president will increase the legitimacy of his subsequent decisions, many of which will be directly related to the invasion of Ukraine.
In addition to Putin, there are three other registered candidates: the nationalist conservative candidate Leonid Slutsky, the communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov and the New People's Party's Vladislav Davankov). The New People's Party was newly formed and had a small number of representatives in the lower house of the Russian Duma.
All three have expressed support for Putin and Russia's war in Ukraine, and none of them poses a real threat.
Putin's real challengers are either in jail, eliminated or have fled Russia. Navalny, Putin's fiercest opponent, died in a high-security prison in February.
BBC reporter Steve Rosenberg asked candidate Kharitonov if he thought he would be a better president than Putin. He replied that it was not for him to say and that voters would "decide everything." He has been subject to Western sanctions since 2022.
Leonid Slutsky, a member of Russia’s Liberal Democratic Party (LDPR), has been accused of sexual harassment many times. He organized a state visit to occupied Crimea, which has been subject to international sanctions since 2014.
Vladislav Davankov of the New People's Party has the lowest exposure in the media. He is the co-founder of a cosmetics company and received just over 5% of the vote in the 2023 Moscow mayoral election. While advocating for "peace and negotiation" in the war with Ukraine, Davankov voted for the annexation of Ukrainian territory, which also led to him being subject to international sanctions.

title: 俄大选最后一天：“中午反普京”行动引爆全球-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
content:
今天中午，在俄罗斯驻澳大利亚，日本，亚美尼亚，哈萨克斯坦，德国，英国使领馆的投票站，数百名俄罗斯人排队等候。
纳瓦尔尼遗孀在柏林
在柏林，纳瓦尔尼的遗孀尤利娅与纳瓦尔尼的发言人基拉·亚米什一起出现在俄罗斯大使馆，参加那里的抗议活动。在场的其他俄罗斯人鼓掌并高呼她的名字。
但是，并非所有周日中午前来投票的俄罗斯人都是反对派。在伦敦，一名排队投票的男子穿着一件上衣，上面写着“耶稣是我的救世主”。普京是我的总统”。
其他人则表示抗议。
选民娜塔莉亚·切列德尼科娃在伦敦说：“过去30年来，我们的声音没有被听到。没有人听我们的声音。我们搬家，我们移民，即使在这里，远离俄罗斯，我们也感受到了不被听到的后果”。
她说，“今年对我们自己来说非常重要，尽管我们所有人……都是宿命论的，而且没有人真正关心。我们来到这里只是为了我们自己。我们已经投票了。我们出现了。”
延伸阅读：
普京大选“获胜”虽无悬念，最后投票日见“中午反普京”人潮


2024年3月17日，俄罗斯总统选举期间，在西伯利亚城市新西伯利亚，人们聚集在投票站。
俄罗斯大选历时三天的投票星期天（3月17日）进入最后一天，现任总统弗拉迪米尔·普京（Vladimir Putin）在消除异己打压异议之后，即使没有开票就已经稳获压倒性“胜利”。但是被禁止参选的反对派仍在呼吁民众在投票日最后一天的中午前往投票所表达象征性的示威抗议。
translation:
At noon today, hundreds of Russians were waiting in line at polling stations at Russian embassies and consulates in Australia, Japan, Armenia, Kazakhstan, Germany, and the United Kingdom.
Navalny's widow in Berlin
In Berlin, Navalny's widow Yulia appeared at the Russian embassy to join protests there, along with Navalny's spokesman Kira Yarmish. Other Russians present applauded and chanted her name.
But not all Russians who came to vote at noon on Sunday were in the opposition. In London, a man queuing to vote wore a top that read "Jesus is my savior." Putin is my president."
Others protested.
Voter Natalya Cherednikova said in London: "For the past 30 years, our voices have not been heard. No one has listened to our voices. We move, we emigrate, and even here, far away from Russia, we And also feeling the consequences of not being heard”.
She said, "This year has been very important for ourselves, even though all of us... are fatalistic and no one really cares. We are here just for ourselves. We have voted. We show up."
Further reading:
Although there is no suspense about Putin’s “win” in the general election, “anti-Putin” crowds were seen at noon on the final voting day


On March 17, 2024, during the Russian presidential election, people gathered at a polling station in the Siberian city of Novosibirsk.
The three-day voting in Russia's general election entered the final day on Sunday (March 17). After eliminating dissidents and suppressing dissent, the current President Vladimir Putin has secured an overwhelming "victory" even without counting the votes. But the opposition, which is banned from running in the election, is still calling on people to go to the polls at noon on the last day of voting to express symbolic protests.
input:
At noon today, hundreds of Russians were waiting in line at polling stations at Russian embassies and consulates in Australia, Japan, Armenia, Kazakhstan, Germany, and the United Kingdom.
Navalny's widow in Berlin
In Berlin, Navalny's widow Yulia appeared at the Russian embassy to join protests there, along with Navalny's spokesman Kira Yarmish. Other Russians present applauded and chanted her name.
But not all Russians who came to vote at noon on Sunday were in the opposition. In London, a man queuing to vote wore a top that read "Jesus is my savior." Putin is my president."
Others protested.
Voter Natalya Cherednikova said in London: "For the past 30 years, our voices have not been heard. No one has listened to our voices. We move, we emigrate, and even here, far away from Russia, we And also feeling the consequences of not being heard”.
She said, "This year has been very important for ourselves, even though all of us... are fatalistic and no one really cares. We are here just for ourselves. We have voted. We show up."
Further reading:
Although there is no suspense about Putin’s “win” in the general election, “anti-Putin” crowds were seen at noon on the final voting day


On March 17, 2024, during the Russian presidential election, people gathered at a polling station in the Siberian city of Novosibirsk.
The three-day voting in Russia's general election entered the final day on Sunday (March 17). After eliminating dissidents and suppressing dissent, the current President Vladimir Putin has secured an overwhelming "victory" even without counting the votes. But the opposition, which is banned from running in the election, is still calling on people to go to the polls at noon on the last day of voting to express symbolic protests.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
content:
战争开始后到现在，我发现盗窃的情况增加了。人们开始试图不支付购买费用，因为没有足够的钱来生活。通货膨胀率非常高，但收入增长比却跟不上。总体而言，我们靠信贷生活。一些家庭为贷款支付了全部的收入。现在这还是不够。
我们的权力机构也还是会投票给普京。但越来越贫穷的下层出现了很多怨言，为了生活，这些人过得更加努力了。
战争消灭了斯拉夫人。但只要战争对顶端的人群有利，它就不会结束。
俄罗斯人非常有耐心。那一年（2022年）开始，我们适应了新的现实。仇恨是没有意义的，适应就好。我们就这么活着。
translation:
Between the start of the war and now, I have seen an increase in thefts. People started trying not to pay for their purchases because there wasn't enough money to live on. Inflation is very high, but income growth ratios are not keeping up. In general, we live on credit. Some families paid their entire income into the loan. Now that's not enough.
Our institutions of power will still vote for Putin. But there are a lot of complaints from the increasingly poor lower classes, who are working harder to survive.
The war wiped out the Slavs. But as long as the war benefits those at the top, it won't end.
Russians are very patient. Starting that year (2022), we adapted to the new reality. Hatred is meaningless, just adapt. This is how we live.

Between the start of the war and now, I have seen an increase in thefts. People started trying not to pay for their purchases because there wasn't enough money to live on. Inflation is very high, but income growth ratios are not keeping up. In general, we live on credit. Some families paid their entire income into the loan. Now that's not enough.
Our institutions of power will still vote for Putin. But there are a lot of complaints from the increasingly poor lower classes, who are working harder to survive.
The war wiped out the Slavs. But as long as the war benefits those at the top, it won't end.
Russians are very patient. Starting that year (2022), we adapted to the new reality. Hatred is meaningless, just adapt. This is how we live.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜普京获近九成选票,胜选后抨击美式民主
content:
据新华社消息,俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间3月18日凌晨发布的数据,在俄总统选举统计完成的超95%选票中,现任总统普京以超87%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人,实际已经赢得此次总统选举。
另据环球网援引据俄罗斯卫星通讯社报道,普京18日凌晨在竞选总部发表讲话,他在讲话中感谢选民的信任和支持,并表示将在新的任期内继续推动国家发展。
普京得票率遥遥领先
俄罗斯于3月15日至17日举行总统选举。投票有史以来第一次进行了三天多的时间,并采用了在线投票的方式,该投票方式覆盖了俄罗斯约三分之一的地区。
据央视新闻消息,莫斯科当地时间17日21时（北京时间18日2时）2024俄罗斯总统选举投票结束,俄全境内投票站均已关闭。
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会视频墙上发布的最新计票结果,目前2024年总统选举95.08%的选票已经清点完毕,以独立候选人身份参选的俄罗斯现任总统弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 以87.32%的得票率领先。
俄联邦共产党候选人尼古拉·哈里托诺夫以4.28%的得票率位居第二,其次是俄新人党候选人弗拉迪斯拉夫·达万科夫,得票率为3.85%。俄自由民主党候选人列昂尼德·斯卢茨基排名第四,得票率为3.15%。
俄罗斯政府表示,2024年俄总统选举的投票率为74%,创下历史最高纪录。普京此前的最高的得票纪录是在2018年的总统选举中,彼时普京赢得了76.7%的选票,而当年投票率为67.5%。
根据俄总统选举规则,在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举结果,并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
俄罗斯国家电视台在报道中指出,“这是围绕弗拉基米尔·普京的令人难以置信的支持和团结,也是向西方国家发出的信号”。
俄罗斯联邦委员会（议会上院）副议长康斯坦丁·科萨切夫表示,俄罗斯议员们邀请来监督俄总统选举的国际观察员在三天多的投票期间内没有提出异议。
科萨切夫在社交平台Telegram上称,观察员们的普遍共识是此次俄总统选举符合最高的国际标准；它是公平和诚实的。
普京:俄在线投票透明且绝对客观
在18日凌晨选举初步结果公布后,普京在竞选总部发表讲话,感谢所有选民的支持。他表示,俄罗斯是一个大家庭,本次选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望,国家的所有任务都将完成。俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展,变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。
在胜选讲话中,普京还驳斥了西方国家对此次选举的批评,并告诉他的支持者,这是“意料之中的”。
“你想要什么,让他们为我们鼓掌？他们正在武装冲突中与我们作战……他们的目标是遏制我们的发展。当然,他们已经准备好说什么。”普京说。
普京在接受记者提问时称赞俄罗斯的总统竞选比美国先进得多,并指出俄罗斯使用了在线投票,俄官员们称在线投票在2024年俄罗斯总统选举中吸引了800万选民。
“这是透明且绝对客观的。”他“建议”道,“不像美国的邮寄投票……你可以花10美元购买一张选票。”
当被问及俄罗斯和北约之间是否有可能爆发全面冲突时,普京回答说,他认为当今世界“一切皆有可能”。
普京表示,“每个人都清楚,距离第三次世界大战全面爆发只有一步之遥。我认为几乎没有人会对此感兴趣。”他补充称,北约军事人员已经在乌克兰,我们已经在战场上听到有人说英语和法语,“这样做没有什么好处,尤其是对他们而言,因为他们正在那里死去,大量地死去。”
在回应法国总统马克龙此前称“将要求俄在奥运期间停火”的言论时,普京表示,“我不了解法国总统的言论。我们准备考虑任何提议,但在任何情况下,我们都将从俄罗斯的利益出发。”
普京指出,俄罗斯已经准备并愿意通过谈判和平解决俄乌冲突,但前提是基辅希望与俄罗斯建立友好睦邻关系,而不是获得时间重新武装遭受重创的乌克兰军队。普京称,他正在确保俄边境免受亲乌克兰武装组织最近袭击的影响,并表示他作为俄罗斯总统的主要任务将是在俄乌冲突中“加强国防能力和（俄罗斯）军队” 。
普京还在记者会上表示,他将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。他说,国家发展的所有主要任务都已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述,将竭尽所能完成既定目标。
普京:本已批准用纳瓦利内换囚
值得注意的是,普京还在记者会上首次对俄罗斯反对派人士纳瓦利内之死一事作出回应。普京称,在纳瓦利内于2024年2月16日在狱中去世前不久,他已批准用纳瓦利内换取西方国家释放俄罗斯籍囚犯。
普京说,“我同意了,但有一个条件:我们交换他,而且他不会回来。不幸的是,已发生的事情确实是发生了,但这就是命。”
3月17日中午,有俄罗斯选民在接到纳瓦利内遗孀尤利娅·纳瓦利纳亚 (Yulia Navalnaya)的电话后前往投票站,莫斯科和其他俄罗斯城市的几个投票站前排起了长队。
尤利娅·纳瓦利纳亚自己则在俄罗斯驻德国大使馆前露面,敦促她的支持者集体出现。报道称,17日中午有超过2000名选民参加了俄罗斯驻德国大使馆外的抗议活动。
“你们给了我希望,一切都没有白费,我们仍然会战斗。” 纳瓦利纳亚在17日的一篇帖子中说,自己在选票上写下了“纳瓦利内”。
此前几天,俄罗斯国内也有民众进行抗议活动,包括将染料倒入投票箱和纵火袭击投票站。
俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席埃拉·帕姆菲洛娃 (Ella Pamfilova) 16日表示,由于有选民试图将各种液体倒入投票箱,“总共至少有 214 张选票已经不可挽回地被损坏了。”
帕姆菲洛娃还表示,俄罗斯至少有20个地区的29个投票站报告称有人试图破坏选票:有20个投票站报告称有人企图向选票箱内倒入液体,有8个投票站报告称有人企图纵火,有1个投票站报告称有人企图投掷烟雾弹。
俄罗斯联邦国家安全会议副主席兼统一俄罗斯党主席、俄前总统德米特里·梅德韦杰夫 (Dmitry Medvedev) 表示,肇事者可能面临叛国罪指控,最高可被判处20年监禁。俄罗斯内政部表示,在2024年总统选举期间已提出155项行政指控,并立案61起刑事案件,其中包括21起妨碍选民权利的案件。

普京得票率遥遥领先
俄罗斯于3月15日至17日举行总统选举。投票有史以来第一次进行了三天多的时间,并采用了在线投票的方式,该投票方式覆盖了俄罗斯约三分之一的地区。
据央视新闻消息,莫斯科当地时间17日21时（北京时间18日2时）2024俄罗斯总统选举投票结束,俄全境内投票站均已关闭。
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会视频墙上发布的最新计票结果,目前2024年总统选举95.08%的选票已经清点完毕,以独立候选人身份参选的俄罗斯现任总统弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 以87.32%的得票率领先。
俄联邦共产党候选人尼古拉·哈里托诺夫以4.28%的得票率位居第二,其次是俄新人党候选人弗拉迪斯拉夫·达万科夫,得票率为3.85%。俄自由民主党候选人列昂尼德·斯卢茨基排名第四,得票率为3.15%。
俄罗斯政府表示,2024年俄总统选举的投票率为74%,创下历史最高纪录。普京此前的最高的得票纪录是在2018年的总统选举中,彼时普京赢得了76.7%的选票,而当年投票率为67.5%。
根据俄总统选举规则,在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举结果,并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
俄罗斯国家电视台在报道中指出,“这是围绕弗拉基米尔·普京的令人难以置信的支持和团结,也是向西方国家发出的信号”。
俄罗斯联邦委员会（议会上院）副议长康斯坦丁·科萨切夫表示,俄罗斯议员们邀请来监督俄总统选举的国际观察员在三天多的投票期间内没有提出异议。
科萨切夫在社交平台Telegram上称,观察员们的普遍共识是此次俄总统选举符合最高的国际标准；它是公平和诚实的。
普京:俄在线投票透明且绝对客观
在18日凌晨选举初步结果公布后,普京在竞选总部发表讲话,感谢所有选民的支持。他表示,俄罗斯是一个大家庭,本次选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望,国家的所有任务都将完成。俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展,变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。
在胜选讲话中,普京还驳斥了西方国家对此次选举的批评,并告诉他的支持者,这是“意料之中的”。
“你想要什么,让他们为我们鼓掌？他们正在武装冲突中与我们作战……他们的目标是遏制我们的发展。当然,他们已经准备好说什么。”普京说。
普京在接受记者提问时称赞俄罗斯的总统竞选比美国先进得多,并指出俄罗斯使用了在线投票,俄官员们称在线投票在2024年俄罗斯总统选举中吸引了800万选民。
“这是透明且绝对客观的。”他“建议”道,“不像美国的邮寄投票……你可以花10美元购买一张选票。”
当被问及俄罗斯和北约之间是否有可能爆发全面冲突时,普京回答说,他认为当今世界“一切皆有可能”。
普京表示,“每个人都清楚,距离第三次世界大战全面爆发只有一步之遥。我认为几乎没有人会对此感兴趣。”他补充称,北约军事人员已经在乌克兰,我们已经在战场上听到有人说英语和法语,“这样做没有什么好处,尤其是对他们而言,因为他们正在那里死去,大量地死去。”
在回应法国总统马克龙此前称“将要求俄在奥运期间停火”的言论时,普京表示,“我不了解法国总统的言论。我们准备考虑任何提议,但在任何情况下,我们都将从俄罗斯的利益出发。”
普京指出,俄罗斯已经准备并愿意通过谈判和平解决俄乌冲突,但前提是基辅希望与俄罗斯建立友好睦邻关系,而不是获得时间重新武装遭受重创的乌克兰军队。普京称,他正在确保俄边境免受亲乌克兰武装组织最近袭击的影响,并表示他作为俄罗斯总统的主要任务将是在俄乌冲突中“加强国防能力和（俄罗斯）军队” 。
普京还在记者会上表示,他将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。他说,国家发展的所有主要任务都已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述,将竭尽所能完成既定目标。
普京:本已批准用纳瓦利内换囚
值得注意的是,普京还在记者会上首次对俄罗斯反对派人士纳瓦利内之死一事作出回应。普京称,在纳瓦利内于2024年2月16日在狱中去世前不久,他已批准用纳瓦利内换取西方国家释放俄罗斯籍囚犯。
普京说,“我同意了,但有一个条件:我们交换他,而且他不会回来。不幸的是,已发生的事情确实是发生了,但这就是命。”
3月17日中午,有俄罗斯选民在接到纳瓦利内遗孀尤利娅·纳瓦利纳亚 (Yulia Navalnaya)的电话后前往投票站,莫斯科和其他俄罗斯城市的几个投票站前排起了长队。
尤利娅·纳瓦利纳亚自己则在俄罗斯驻德国大使馆前露面,敦促她的支持者集体出现。报道称,17日中午有超过2000名选民参加了俄罗斯驻德国大使馆外的抗议活动。
“你们给了我希望,一切都没有白费,我们仍然会战斗。” 纳瓦利纳亚在17日的一篇帖子中说,自己在选票上写下了“纳瓦利内”。
此前几天,俄罗斯国内也有民众进行抗议活动,包括将染料倒入投票箱和纵火袭击投票站。
俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席埃拉·帕姆菲洛娃 (Ella Pamfilova) 16日表示,由于有选民试图将各种液体倒入投票箱,“总共至少有 214 张选票已经不可挽回地被损坏了。”
帕姆菲洛娃还表示,俄罗斯至少有20个地区的29个投票站报告称有人试图破坏选票:有20个投票站报告称有人企图向选票箱内倒入液体,有8个投票站报告称有人企图纵火,有1个投票站报告称有人企图投掷烟雾弹。
俄罗斯联邦国家安全会议副主席兼统一俄罗斯党主席、俄前总统德米特里·梅德韦杰夫 (Dmitry Medvedev) 表示,肇事者可能面临叛国罪指控,最高可被判处20年监禁。俄罗斯内政部表示,在2024年总统选举期间已提出155项行政指控,并立案61起刑事案件,其中包括21起妨碍选民权利的案件。

title: Putin extends rule in preordained Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era
content:
Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled.
Putin appeared Monday evening on Red Square in the heart of Moscow at a concert to mark the tenth year since he annexed Crimea from Ukraine. Putin’s three token challengers for the presidency appeared on stage beside him and publicly supported him after campaigns in which none of them criticized him.
Putin has led Russia as president or prime minister since December 1999. At the end of his fifth term, he would be the longest-serving Russian leader since Catherine the Great, who ruled during the 18th century.
Emboldened by his sweeping victory, Putin said he planned to carve out a buffer zone in Ukraine to protect Russia from cross-border shelling and attacks. Asked if an open clash could erupt between Russia and NATO, Putin responded curtly by saying: “Everything is possible in today’s world.” He added, “It’s clear to everyone that it will put us a step away from full-scale World War III."
Russian officials said they recruited over 500,000 volunteers for the army last year, but many expect Putin to mobilize more forces to attempt to push deeper into Ukraine. Analysts say that in the post-election period, Russian authorities could also introduce unpopular measures such as raising taxes.
The Kremlin is now “increasingly confident,” because it has “learned just how passive the population is and how effective their own repression is," said Nigel Gould-Davies, a senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.
Russia’s Central Election Commission said Monday that with all the precincts counted, Putin got 87% of the vote. Central Election Commission chief Ella Pamfilova said that nearly 76 million voters cast their ballots for Putin.
In illegally annexed regions of Ukraine, at least 249 people were detained for refusing to take part in the vote and for criticizing Russian authorities according to the Ukrainian Eastern Human Rights Group.
“Voting in the occupied territories took place literally at gunpoint, when members of election commissions walked from door to door accompanied by military men with weapons,” said Pavlo Lysianskyi, head of the group.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy slammed the election and voting in the illegally annexed regions saying "everything Russia does on the occupied territory of Ukraine is a crime.”
Germany also sharply criticized the vote. “Russia, as the chancellor has already said, is now a dictatorship and is ruled by Vladimir Putin in an authoritarian manner,” said Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokeswoman, Christina Hoffmann.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
在尼基塔的主课英语课上，他注意到一些学生的态度变得不那么认真了。经过几次谈话和询问，他发现，原来问题出在学生家长或祖父母的身上：有些上了年纪的村民开始认为英语是“敌人的语言”，这种观点在家庭谈话中影响了孩子，让他们对英语课也心生反感。
与迟迟不能习惯进入战争的都市中产不同，A村的村民们似乎很快就适应了俄乌冲突下的“新常态”。已经在那里居住了近两年的尼基塔回忆，刚开始村里确实出现了一阵恐慌，但这很快过去，因为大家都相信俄军能够迅速完成克里姆林宫宣布的“特别军事行动”。然而随着形势胶着，“闪击战”告吹，俄军不得不从基辅郊外撤走，人心又开始浮动起来。
“真正看到周围人感到担忧还是2022年的9月左右。”尼基塔提到了俄军在哈尔科夫前线受挫，俄国内开始部分动员的时间点，“因为即便是车臣战争时也没有这种规模的动员”。
不过这种情绪并没有持续很久，毕竟，这是一个对战争记忆并不陌生的村庄，从卫国战争，到阿富汗，再到车臣，村中几代人都有参与。更何况，俄罗斯政府还让战争经济加速运转，使得很多普通人卷入其中，成为利益相关者。
首先是参军人数变多。有至少三个尼基塔的学生家中有人报名参军，另一名学生的哥哥此前已经是俄军的合同兵，作战经验丰富，他在2023年阻击乌军反攻时因摧毁了一辆西式步兵战车而得到额外奖励。
“这让阿列克谢（学生的名字）感到非常自豪。他甚至变得有些不一样了，开始对军事装备特别感兴趣，今年还想报名参加军事夏令营。”尼基塔说
translation:
In Nikita's main English class, he noticed that some students were becoming less serious. After several conversations and inquiries, he discovered that the original problem lay with the parents or grandparents of the students: some elderly villagers began to think that English was the "enemy language." This view influenced the children in family conversations, making them I also feel disgusted with English classes.
Unlike the urban middle class who have been unable to get used to the war, the villagers in Village A seem to have quickly adapted to the "new normal" under the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Nikita, who has lived there for nearly two years, recalled that there was indeed a panic in the village at first, but it passed quickly because everyone believed that the Russian army could quickly complete the "special military operation" announced by the Kremlin. However, as the situation became tense and the "blitzkrieg" failed, the Russian army had to withdraw from the outskirts of Kiev, and people's hearts began to fluctuate again.
"It will be around September 2022 that I really see people around me worried." Nikita mentioned the time when the Russian army suffered a setback on the Kharkov front and began partial mobilization in Russia, "because even during the Chechen War, there was no Mobilization on this scale.”
However, this emotion did not last long. After all, this is a village that is no stranger to war memories. From the Great Patriotic War to Afghanistan to Chechnya, several generations of the village have participated. What's more, the Russian government has accelerated the war economy, causing many ordinary people to become involved and become stakeholders.
First, the number of people joining the military has increased. At least three of Nikita's students have family members who have signed up to join the army. The brother of another student has been a contract soldier of the Russian army and has rich combat experience. In 2023, he was responsible for destroying a Western-style infantry fighting vehicle when blocking the Ukrainian army's counterattack. Get extra rewards for your car.
"This makes Alexei (the student's name) very proud. He has even become a little different. He has become particularly interested in military equipment and wants to sign up for military summer camp this year." Nikita said

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
content:
过去3个月时间里，普京并没有公开发起竞选活动，但俄罗斯国有电视台里经常看到他在全国各地视察的画面——不管是北部城市北德文斯克的核潜艇建造厂，还是首次到访俄罗斯最东部楚科奇自治区（和美国本土隔海相望）的现代化番茄种植农场，或是在莫斯科州新奥加廖沃与多名参加对乌特别军事行动的俄士兵交流并授予配枪和总统旗徽章，在下塔吉尔市参观著名的军备制造商乌拉尔机车车辆厂，以及在近期妇女节前视察克拉斯诺达尔高等军事航空学校为女飞行员们献花……
卡内基俄罗斯与欧亚问题研究柏林中心研究员塔季娅娜·斯塔诺瓦娅观察认为，普京在选举前的行动旨在避免产生任何社会不满情绪。她撰文写道，任何选举都会凸显执政当局与社会之间关系的变化。而现在正值战时，事关重大，克里姆林宫必须慎重考虑任何公众不满情绪的表现。
“保持军事冲突（行动）的连续性，俄罗斯领导层需要一项民众授权（mandate），这就是为什么这场选举对实现这一目标至关重要。”芬兰赫尔辛基大学俄罗斯和欧亚研究教授格尔曼（Vladimir Gel'man）日前告诉澎湃新闻说。
3月11日，俄罗斯卫星通讯社援引全俄社会舆论研究中心预测称，2024年俄罗斯总统选举的投票率将在71%左右，总统候选人弗拉基米尔·普京可能会获得82%的选票。该预测是基于全俄电话调查的数据统计所得。2000年首度当选总统后，他已出任4届总统（2000年–2008年的第3和第4任、2012年–2024年的第6和第7任）。在上次2018年的俄罗斯总统选举中，普京得票率为76.69%，而在2012年、2004年，他得票率分别为63.6%、71.9%。
translation:
In the past three months, Putin has not publicly launched a campaign, but Russian state-owned television has often seen him inspecting various parts of the country - whether it was the nuclear submarine construction plant in the northern city of Severodvinsk or his first visit to Russia A modern tomato farm in the easternmost Chukotka Autonomous Region (across the sea from the mainland of the United States), or communicating with many Russian soldiers who participated in the special military operation against Ukraine in Novo-Ogaryovo, Moscow Region, and receiving rifles and presidential awards flag insignia, visited the famous armaments manufacturer Ural Rolling Stock Plant in Nizhny Tagil, and visited the Krasnodar Higher Military Aviation School to lay flowers for female pilots before Women's Day recently...
Tatyana Stanovaya, a researcher at the Carnegie Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies in Berlin, observed that Putin’s actions before the election were aimed at avoiding any social dissatisfaction. She wrote that any election would highlight changes in the relationship between the ruling authorities and society. And now, in wartime, the stakes are so high that the Kremlin must carefully consider any signs of public discontent.
"To maintain the continuity of military conflict (operations), the Russian leadership needs a popular mandate (mandate), which is why this election is crucial to achieve this goal." Geer, professor of Russian and Eurasian studies at the University of Helsinki, Finland Vladimir Gel'man recently told The Paper.
On March 11, the Russian Satellite News Agency quoted the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center as predicting that the turnout rate for the 2024 Russian presidential election will be around 71%, and presidential candidate Vladimir Putin may receive 82% of the votes. The forecast is based on data from an all-Russian telephone survey. After being elected president for the first time in 2000, he has served four terms as president (the 3rd and 4th terms from 2000 to 2008, the 6th and 7th terms from 2012 to 2024). In the last Russian presidential election in 2018, Putin received 76.69% of the vote. In 2012 and 2004, he received 63.6% and 71.9% of the vote respectively.
input:
In the past three months, Putin has not publicly launched a campaign, but Russian state-owned television has often seen him inspecting various parts of the country - whether it was the nuclear submarine construction plant in the northern city of Severodvinsk or his first visit to Russia A modern tomato farm in the easternmost Chukotka Autonomous Region (across the sea from the mainland of the United States), or communicating with many Russian soldiers who participated in the special military operation against Ukraine in Novo-Ogaryovo, Moscow Region, and receiving rifles and presidential awards flag insignia, visited the famous armaments manufacturer Ural Rolling Stock Plant in Nizhny Tagil, and visited the Krasnodar Higher Military Aviation School to lay flowers for female pilots before Women's Day recently...
Tatyana Stanovaya, a researcher at the Carnegie Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies in Berlin, observed that Putin’s actions before the election were aimed at avoiding any social dissatisfaction. She wrote that any election would highlight changes in the relationship between the ruling authorities and society. And now, in wartime, the stakes are so high that the Kremlin must carefully consider any signs of public discontent.
"To maintain the continuity of military conflict (operations), the Russian leadership needs a popular mandate (mandate), which is why this election is crucial to achieve this goal." Geer, professor of Russian and Eurasian studies at the University of Helsinki, Finland Vladimir Gel'man recently told The Paper.
On March 11, the Russian Satellite News Agency quoted the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center as predicting that the turnout rate for the 2024 Russian presidential election will be around 71%, and presidential candidate Vladimir Putin may receive 82% of the votes. The forecast is based on data from an all-Russian telephone survey. After being elected president for the first time in 2000, he has served four terms as president (the 3rd and 4th terms from 2000 to 2008, the 6th and 7th terms from 2012 to 2024). In the last Russian presidential election in 2018, Putin received 76.69% of the vote. In 2012 and 2004, he received 63.6% and 71.9% of the vote respectively.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民:至少俄罗斯人能投票
content: 俄罗斯总统大选落幕，现任总统普京(Vladimir Putin)赢得五连任，将执政到2030年。普京3月18日发表胜选谈话时强调，俄中关系牢固且互补，也获得中国领导人习近平的贺电回应。虽然外界多视这场大选为“假选举”，但不少中国网民透过微博讨论选情，并语带讽刺地说:“至少俄罗斯人还能投票选总统，自己连选票长啥模样，都没见过。
translation: The Russian presidential election ended with current President Vladimir Putin winning five consecutive terms and will be in power until 2030. In his victory speech on March 18, Putin emphasized that Russia-China relations are strong and complementary, and received a congratulatory message from Chinese leader Xi Jinping in response. Although the outside world mostly regarded this election as a "fake election," many Chinese netizens discussed the election on Weibo and said sarcastically: "At least Russians can still vote for the president. What does it look like to vote for yourself? Never seen it.
input: The Russian presidential election ended with current President Vladimir Putin winning five consecutive terms and will be in power until 2030. In his victory speech on March 18, Putin emphasized that Russia-China relations are strong and complementary, and received a congratulatory message from Chinese leader Xi Jinping in response. Although the outside world mostly regarded this election as a "fake election," many Chinese netizens discussed the election on Weibo and said sarcastically: "At least Russians can still vote for the president. What does it look like to vote for yourself? Never seen it.

title: Russian voters, answering Navalny’s call, protest as Putin extends his rule to 2030 - The Washington Post
content:
The Noon Against Putin protest was designed not only to denounce an election widely condemned as neither free nor fair, but also to demonstrate support for the fragmented, often demoralized critics of Putin and the war, many of whom are now living in exile.
Navalny’s team broadcast a live stream, narrating the day of protest, on his YouTube channel. One of the anchors was Leonid Volkov, Navalny’s longtime top political adviser, who was recently attacked by assailants with a hammer outside of his home in Vilnius, Lithuania. Volkov appeared on the broadcast with his arm in a sling.
Two friends, Arina, 17, and Maryana, 19, arrived at the Polyanka polling station together, to protest Putin.
Arina said the protest offered hope that a “civilized and democratic Russia is possible.”
“We came here so as to not feel alone,” Arina said. “I wanted to show my position in a safe and legal way because there are barely any opportunities to do this anymore.”
She added: “I think this action has been successful because it gives people a feeling of strength and power. People will at least see the queues and hear about it, and that means something.”
Maryana said: “We wanted to do a peaceful protest of the current power, to show that we don’t support it and we won’t support it.”
Nikolai, 28, who was at the same polling station, said he was surprised by the big turnout, though some other protesters said they had hoped for even larger crowds.
“I came here today to express my position and do my part to show that there is still a political life in the country and that there are different opinions,” Nikolai said.

Navalny’s team broadcast a live stream, narrating the day of protest, on his YouTube channel. One of the anchors was Leonid Volkov, Navalny’s longtime top political adviser, who was recently attacked by assailants with a hammer outside of his home in Vilnius, Lithuania. Volkov appeared on the broadcast with his arm in a sling.
Two friends, Arina, 17, and Maryana, 19, arrived at the Polyanka polling station together, to protest Putin.
Arina said the protest offered hope that a “civilized and democratic Russia is possible.”
“We came here so as to not feel alone,” Arina said. “I wanted to show my position in a safe and legal way because there are barely any opportunities to do this anymore.”
She added: “I think this action has been successful because it gives people a feeling of strength and power. People will at least see the queues and hear about it, and that means something.”
Maryana said: “We wanted to do a peaceful protest of the current power, to show that we don’t support it and we won’t support it.”
Nikolai, 28, who was at the same polling station, said he was surprised by the big turnout, though some other protesters said they had hoped for even larger crowds.
“I came here today to express my position and do my part to show that there is still a political life in the country and that there are different opinions,” Nikolai said.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
content:
这里的生活或多或少还算平静，但有时人们会无缘无故地发火，而且不计后果。我指的不是所有的人，只是我在现实生活中和网络视频上看到的一些人。人们会（对生活）感到厌烦、无聊，比起想办法解决问题，他们会变得愤怒，甚至会伤害他人。
我反对战争。这就是我所能回答的。人们正因战争死去，这太可怕了。但大多数人有不同的看法，也有支持战争的人，比如互联网上的一些人，但他们应该永远不会奔赴前线，很虚伪。
对于大选，我非常确定普京会当选。不需要猜测。他担任这个职位已经二十多年了。这里的生活相对还好。我不在乎。我对政治或国家本身都不感兴趣。我只是过我的生活，仅此而已。
但如果可以的话，我希望去美国生活，美国一直很吸引我。英语是我唯一最了解的外语，所以首先我会试着去那里。至少我想试试。
“我不会投票，我也不亲西方”
translation:
Life here is more or less peaceful, but sometimes people get angry for no reason and with no regard for the consequences. I don’t mean everyone, just some I’ve seen in real life and on online videos. People get bored and bored, and instead of trying to solve their problems, they become angry and even hurt others.
I am against war. That's all I can answer. People are dying because of the war, it's terrible. But most people have different views. There are also people who support the war, such as some people on the Internet, but they should never go to the front line. It is very hypocritical.
Regarding the election, I am very sure that Putin will be elected. No guesswork required. He has held this position for more than twenty years. Life here is relatively good. I do not care. I'm not interested in politics or the country itself. I'm just living my life, that's all.
But if possible, I hope to live in the United States. The United States has always attracted me. English is the only foreign language I know best, so first I'll try to get there. At least I want to try.
"I won't vote and I'm not pro-Western"
input:
Life here is more or less peaceful, but sometimes people get angry for no reason and with no regard for the consequences. I don’t mean everyone, just some I’ve seen in real life and on online videos. People get bored and bored, and instead of trying to solve their problems, they become angry and even hurt others.
I am against war. That's all I can answer. People are dying because of the war, it's terrible. But most people have different views. There are also people who support the war, such as some people on the Internet, but they should never go to the front line. It is very hypocritical.
Regarding the election, I am very sure that Putin will be elected. No guesswork required. He has held this position for more than twenty years. Life here is relatively good. I do not care. I'm not interested in politics or the country itself. I'm just living my life, that's all.
But if possible, I hope to live in the United States. The United States has always attracted me. English is the only foreign language I know best, so first I'll try to get there. At least I want to try.
"I won't vote and I'm not pro-Western"

title: 普京无悬念胜选 演说提与习近平友谊 | 德国之声 来自德国 介绍德国 | DW | 18.03.2024
content:
自2022年俄罗斯对乌克兰发动战争以来，中国一直没有公开谴责俄国，且持续与俄国保持贸易关系，遭欧美质疑这让俄国得以维系其战时经济。 今年2月，欧盟也将多家涉嫌提供武器给俄国的中国企业列入制裁黑名单。
对于普京的“胜选”，乌克兰总统泽连斯基批评他“沉迷于权力，正在竭尽所能让自己永远掌权”。 泽连斯基说：“为了延续个人的权柄，他无恶不作，世界上没有人可以幸免于此。”
美国白宫批评，俄罗斯这次选举“既不自由，也不公平”，能够构成威胁的反对派政治家，要么未获准参选，要么已入狱或逃往境外。
德国外交部也表示，俄国选举结果“不会让任何人讶异”。 “普丁的专制统治建立在审查、镇压与暴力之上，俄国在乌克兰被占领区进行的所谓'选举'是无效的，也再一次违反了国际法。”据《每日镜报》报导，德国 总统发言人称德国总统不会致函恭喜普丁。
独立的选举观察员曾表示，俄国选举中存在着系统性的舞弊行为。有报道称，国有企业员工被强迫参加投票，已有数百家企业在社媒上发布了集体投票的照片。据报道，在乌克兰被占领土上，乌克兰民众也被强迫参加投票活动。
本届俄国选举约有1亿1400万选民，其中也纳入俄罗斯占领区的450万乌克兰民众。在2014年已被俄罗斯吞并的克里米亚半岛，当局也组织了投票活动。俄罗斯反对派呼吁国际社会拒绝承认此次选举的结果。
3天投票期最后一天，已故俄国反对派领袖纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）的支持者发起“午”逆普丁行动（Noon against Putin），呼吁民众17日同时在中午12点整前往投票站 集结，以“排长队的形式”瘫痪投票站，或透过在选票上写上纳瓦尔尼的名字、投给其他候选人等做法，表达抗议。
translation:
Since Russia launched war against Ukraine in 2022, China has not publicly condemned Russia and has continued to maintain trade relations with Russia. This has been questioned by Europe and the United States, which has allowed Russia to maintain its wartime economy. In February this year, the European Union also added a number of Chinese companies suspected of providing weapons to Russia to its sanctions blacklist.
Regarding Putin's "win", Ukrainian President Zelensky criticized him for being "addicted to power and doing everything he can to keep himself in power forever." Zelensky said: "In order to maintain his personal power, he does all kinds of evil, and no one in the world is immune to this."
The White House criticized Russia's election as "neither free nor fair" and said opposition politicians who could pose a threat were either not allowed to run, were imprisoned or fled abroad.
The German Foreign Ministry also stated that the Russian election results "will not surprise anyone." "Putin's autocratic rule is based on censorship, repression and violence. The so-called 'elections' conducted by Russia in the occupied territories of Ukraine are invalid and once again violate international law." According to the "Daily Mirror", Germany A presidential spokesman said the German president would not send a letter to congratulate Putin.
Independent election observers have said there was systemic fraud in Russia's elections. There are reports that employees of state-owned enterprises were forced to vote, and hundreds of companies have posted photos of collective voting on social media. According to reports, Ukrainian people were also forced to participate in voting activities in the occupied territories of Ukraine.
There are approximately 114 million voters in this Russian election, including 4.5 million Ukrainians in the Russian-occupied territories. In the Crimean peninsula, which was annexed by Russia in 2014, the authorities also organized voting activities. The Russian opposition called on the international community to refuse to recognize the election results.
On the last day of the three-day voting period, supporters of the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny launched the "Noon" anti-Putin operation, calling on people to go to the polling stations at 12 noon on the 17th. Rally to paralyze polling stations with "long queues", or express protest by writing Navalny's name on the ballot and voting for other candidates.
input:

Regarding Putin's "win", Ukrainian President Zelensky criticized him for being "addicted to power and doing everything he can to keep himself in power forever." Zelensky said: "In order to maintain his personal power, he does all kinds of evil, and no one in the world is immune to this."

The German Foreign Ministry also stated that the Russian election results "will not surprise anyone." "Putin's autocratic rule is based on censorship, repression and violence. The so-called 'elections' conducted by Russia in the occupied territories of Ukraine are invalid and once again violate international law." According to the "Daily Mirror", Germany A presidential spokesman said the German president would not send a letter to congratulate Putin.
Independent election observers have said there was systemic fraud in Russia's elections. There are reports that employees of state-owned enterprises were forced to vote, and hundreds of companies have posted photos of collective voting on social media. According to reports, Ukrainian people were also forced to participate in voting activities in the occupied territories of Ukraine.
There are approximately 114 million voters in this Russian election, including 4.5 million Ukrainians in the Russian-occupied territories. In the Crimean peninsula, which was annexed by Russia in 2014, the authorities also organized voting activities. The Russian opposition called on the international community to refuse to recognize the election results.
On the last day of the three-day voting period, supporters of the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny launched the "Noon" anti-Putin operation, calling on people to go to the polling stations at 12 noon on the 17th. title: Russian presidential election 2024: Putin extends one-man rule after stage-managed election devoid of credible opposition | CNN
content:
Putin’s critics accuse him of inventing foreign policy problems to distract from his government’s inability to solve Russia’s myriad domestic problems, from low life expectancy to widespread poverty.
    

            While Russia weathered sanctions imposed by Western countries better than expected, the conflict has warped its economy by sucking resources into military production. Inflation has spiked, basic goods like eggs have become unaffordable, and tens of thousands of young professionals have left the country.
    

            Gauging popular opinion is difficult in authoritarian countries like Russia, where monitoring organizations operate under strict surveillance and many fear criticizing the Kremlin.
    

            But the Levada Center, a non-governmental polling organization, reports that nearly half of Russians strongly support the war in Ukraine and more than three quarters are somewhat supportive. Levada also reports Putin’s approval rating at over 80% – a figure virtually unknown among Western politicians and a substantial increase compared to the three years before the full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
input:
Putin’s critics accuse him of inventing foreign policy problems to distract from his government’s inability to solve Russia’s myriad domestic problems, from low life expectancy to widespread poverty.

Inflation has spiked, basic goods like eggs have become unaffordable, and tens of thousands of young professionals have left the country.
    

            Gauging popular opinion is difficult in authoritarian countries like Russia, where monitoring organizations operate under strict surveillance and many fear criticizing the Kremlin.
    

            But the Levada Center, a non-governmental polling organization, reports that nearly half of Russians strongly support the war in Ukraine and more than three quarters are somewhat supportive. Levada also reports Putin’s approval rating at over 80% – a figure virtually unknown among Western politicians and a substantial increase compared to the three years before the full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

title: 俄罗斯大选 普京获得连任 白宫回应 | 大纪元
content:
俄罗斯29个地区首次在总统选举中使用这一投票系统。
上个月，俄罗斯反对派领导人阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）在北极监狱去世，周日中午，数千名反对者在俄罗斯境内外的投票站抗议普京。
普京在胜选后，首次对纳瓦尔尼去世发表评论，他表示纳瓦尔尼的去世是一个“悲伤的事件”，并确认他已准备好与反对派政客进行囚犯交换。
白宫国家安全委员会发言人说：“鉴于普京先生监禁政治反对派并阻止其他人与他竞选，这次选举显然既不自由也不公平。”
德国外交部在社交媒体平台X上发表声明说，“俄罗斯的伪选举既不自由也不公正，其结果不会让任何人感到意外。普京的统治是专制的，他依靠的是审查、镇压和暴力。在乌克兰被占领土上的‘选举’是无效的，又一次违反了国际法。”
英国外交部长卡梅伦在X平台上说， “在乌克兰领土上进行非法选举、选民缺乏选择以及没有独立的欧安组织监督后，俄罗斯的投票已经结束。这不是一个自由公正选举应该有的样子。”
乌克兰总统泽连斯基表示，普京希望永远执政，而这次投票是非法的。
在这次选举中，超过1.14亿的俄罗斯人有资格投票，其中包括被俄罗斯宣称为“新领土”上的选民。2022年10月，俄罗斯宣布吞并4个乌克兰地区。乌克兰表示，在那里举行的俄罗斯选举是非法且无效的。
波兰外交部发表声明说，俄罗斯举行了所谓的总统选举，“投票是在社会受到极端镇压的情况下进行的，不可能做出自由、民主的选择”。 
这次大选是在俄乌战仍在持续的大背景下进行的。分析人士指出，克里姆林宫希望在这次选举中看到高投票率，并希望普京取得重大胜利，以使战争合法化。
咨询公司Teneo中欧和东欧顾问安德烈亚斯‧图尔萨（Andreas Tursa）周四（3月14日）评论说：“克里姆林宫寻求这样一个选举结果：它将显示公众对普京以及他的国内和外交政策议程的压倒性支持。 ”
普京轻松拿下第五个任期，意味着他在俄罗斯的统治至少要到2030年。这将使他超越约瑟夫‧斯大林（Josef Stalin），成为俄罗斯二百多年来在位时间最长的领导人。
translation:
For the first time, 29 Russian regions are using this voting system in presidential elections.
Thousands of opponents of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month, showed up at polling stations in Russia and abroad to protest against Putin at noon on Sunday.
Putin commented on Navalny's death for the first time after winning the election, calling Navalny's death a "sad event" and confirming that he was ready for a prisoner swap with opposition politicians.
"Given that Mr. Putin imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running against him, it is clear that this election was neither free nor fair," a White House National Security Council spokesman said.
The German Foreign Ministry issued a statement on social media platform Violence. The 'elections' in the occupied territories of Ukraine are invalid and another violation of international law."
British Foreign Minister David Cameron said on the ”
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Putin wanted to stay in power forever and that the vote was illegal.
In this election, more than 114 million Russians are eligible to vote, including voters in what Russia claims as "new territories." In October 2022, Russia announced the annexation of four Ukrainian regions. Ukraine says the Russian elections held there are illegal and invalid.
Poland's Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement saying that Russia held so-called presidential elections and "the voting took place under conditions of extreme repression in society, making it impossible to make a free and democratic choice." 
This election was held against the background of the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine. Analysts pointed out that the Kremlin hopes to see high turnout in this election and hopes for a major victory for Putin to legitimize the war.
Andreas Tursa, consultant for Central and Eastern Europe at consulting firm Teneo, commented on Thursday (March 14): “The Kremlin seeks an election result that will show public opinion of Putin and his domestic and overwhelming support for the foreign policy agenda.”
Putin easily won a fifth term, which means that his rule in Russia will last until at least 2030. This would make him surpass Josef Stalin to become Russia's longest-serving leader in more than 200 years.

title: Putin's Ukraine war ambitions on show at Crimea concert after election win
content:
MOSCOW — Vladimir Putin took to the Red Square stage Monday for an election celebration that seemed to carry a grander message for the flag-waving crowd of thousands, and for the world: Having extended his rule over Russia, his focus would be tightening his grip on Ukrainian territory.
“Together, hand in hand — we will move on,” he proclaimed before singing along to the national anthem, just hours after claiming a landslide win in a stage-managed election with no opposition.
Flanked by his favorite musical acts, pro-war celebrities and the three officially approved figures put on the ballot with him, he led this celebratory event to mark the 10th anniversary of his annexation of the Crimean Peninsula. Ukrainian officials told NBC News that the party was nothing but propaganda, and decried as illegal coercion the votes held for the first time in four newly annexed regions.
After three days of voting, Russia’s electoral commission said Putin had received 87% of the ballots, the biggest win of his political career, in what the Kremlin painted as an unequivocal public stamp of approval for his invasion of Ukraine, even though critics of the war were barred from running.
Just hours later, the Russian leader was in Red Square, where his face was beamed onto huge screens so that it could be seen from Lenin’s mausoleum and beyond.
From a stage beneath the colorful domes of St. Basil’s Cathedral, the music was at times as loud as thunder and the red-brick walls of the Kremlin flickered with the lights of the stage. The crowd — mostly students, some of whom said they had been given free tickets to the event — cheered and sang along as Russian stars performed patriotic ballads.
Mostly under 20 years old, many had their faces painted in the colors of the Russian flag.

Flanked by his favorite musical acts, pro-war celebrities and the three officially approved figures put on the ballot with him, he led this celebratory event to mark the 10th anniversary of his annexation of the Crimean Peninsula. Ukrainian officials told NBC News that the party was nothing but propaganda, and decried as illegal coercion the votes held for the first time in four newly annexed regions.
After three days of voting, Russia’s electoral commission said Putin had received 87% of the ballots, the biggest win of his political career, in what the Kremlin painted as an unequivocal public stamp of approval for his invasion of Ukraine, even though critics of the war were barred from running.
Just hours later, the Russian leader was in Red Square, where his face was beamed onto huge screens so that it could be seen from Lenin’s mausoleum and beyond.
From a stage beneath the colorful domes of St. Basil’s Cathedral, the music was at times as loud as thunder and the red-brick walls of the Kremlin flickered with the lights of the stage. title: Putin basks in election win that was never in doubt even as Russians quietly protest  : NPR
content:
Dmitry Sergienko, who cast his ballot in Moscow, said, "I am happy with everything and want everything to continue as it is now."
Voting took place over three days at polling stations across the vast country, in illegally annexed regions of Ukraine and online. As people voted Sunday, Russian authorities said Ukraine launched a massive new wave of attacks on Russia, killing two people — underscoring the challenges facing the Kremlin.
Despite tight controls, several dozen cases of vandalism at polling stations were reported across the voting period.
Several people were arrested, including in Moscow and St. Petersburg, after they tried to start fires or set off explosives at polling stations while others were detained for throwing green antiseptic or ink into ballot boxes.
Stanislav Andreychuk, co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said that pressure on voters from law enforcement had reached unprecedented levels.
Russians, he said in a social media post, were searched when entering polling stations, there were attempts to check filled-out ballots before they were cast, and one report said police demanded a ballot box be opened to remove a ballot.
"It's the first time in my life that I've seen such absurdities," Andreychuk wrote on the messaging app Telegram, adding that he started monitoring elections in Russia 20 years ago.
The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that 80 people were arrested in 20 cities across Russia on Sunday.
That left little room for people to express their displeasure, but Ivan Zhdanov, the head of Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation, said that the opposition's call to protest had been successful.
Beyond Russia, huge lines also formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris, Milan, Belgrade and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin's invasion of Ukraine.
Protesters in Berlin displayed a figure of Putin bathing in a bath of blood with the Ukrainian flag on the side, alongside shredded ballots in ballot boxes.
Russian state television and officials said the lines abroad showed strong turnout.
In Tallinn, where hundreds stood in a line snaking around the Estonian capital's cobbled streets leading to the Russian Embassy, 23-year-old Tatiana said she came to take part in the protest.
"If we have some option to protest I think it's important to utilize any opportunity," she said, only giving her first name.
Boris Nadezhdin, a liberal politician who tried to join the race on an anti-war platform but was barred from running by election officials, voiced hope that many Russians cast their ballots against Putin.
"I believe that the Russian people today have a chance to show their real attitude to what is happening by voting not for Putin, but for some other candidates or in some other way, which is exactly what I did," he said after voting in Dolgoprudny, a town just outside Moscow.
input:
Dmitry Sergienko, who cast his ballot in Moscow, said, "I am happy with everything and want everything to continue as it is now."
Voting took place over three days at polling stations across the vast country, in illegally annexed regions of Ukraine and online. As people voted Sunday, Russian authorities said Ukraine launched a massive new wave of attacks on Russia, killing two people — underscoring the challenges facing the Kremlin.
Despite tight controls, several dozen cases of vandalism at polling stations were reported across the voting period.
Several people were arrested, including in Moscow and St. Petersburg, after they tried to start fires or set off explosives at polling stations while others were detained for throwing green antiseptic or ink into ballot boxes.
Stanislav Andreychuk, co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said that pressure on voters from law enforcement had reached unprecedented levels.
Russians, he said in a social media post, were searched when entering polling stations, there were attempts to check filled-out ballots before they were cast, and one report said police demanded a ballot box be opened to remove a ballot.
"It's the first time in my life that I've seen such absurdities," Andreychuk wrote on the messaging app Telegram, adding that he started monitoring elections in Russia 20 years ago.
The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that 80 people were arrested in 20 cities across Russia on Sunday.
That left little room for people to express their displeasure, but Ivan Zhdanov, the head of Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation, said that the opposition's call to protest had been successful.
Beyond Russia, huge lines also formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris, Milan, Belgrade and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin's invasion of Ukraine.
Protesters in Berlin displayed a figure of Putin bathing in a bath of blood with the Ukrainian flag on the side, alongside shredded ballots in ballot boxes.
Russian state television and officials said the lines abroad showed strong turnout.
In Tallinn, where hundreds stood in a line snaking around the Estonian capital's cobbled streets leading to the Russian Embassy, 23-year-old Tatiana said she came to take part in the protest.
"If we have some option to protest I think it's important to utilize any opportunity," she said, only giving her first name.
Boris Nadezhdin, a liberal politician who tried to join the race on an anti-war platform but was barred from running by election officials, voiced hope that many Russians cast their ballots against Putin.
"I believe that the Russian people today have a chance to show their real attitude to what is happening by voting not for Putin, but for some other candidates or in some other way, which is exactly what I did," he said after voting in Dolgoprudny, a town just outside Moscow.

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
content:
此次大选中，还有包括莫斯科在内的29个地区可以进行在线投票，占到全国三分之一的选区。据统计，线上投票的投票率达到94%。
 
有分析认为，俄罗斯此次总统选举投票持续三天，是因为普京希望提高投票率，以彰显俄罗斯国内对他的全面支持。
 
战火下的大选
 
这场大选是俄罗斯首次举行的战时选举。两年前的2月24日，普京对乌克兰发起了“特别军事行动”。如今，这场冲突已经进入第三年。
 
在为期三天的俄罗斯总统选举期间，战争的阴影也并未散去。据路透社3月18日报道，过去几天内，乌克兰多次袭击俄罗斯的炼油厂，炮击俄罗斯的一些地区，同时试图突破俄罗斯边境。
 
据“今日俄罗斯”报道，俄罗斯此次大选期间出现了一些试图干扰投票的事件。俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃称，俄罗斯20个地区发生了大约30起试图干扰投票的事件，有人试图焚烧投票箱，有人试图将染色液体倒进投票箱。在圣彼得堡，还有人向投票站投掷了燃烧弹，但并未造成人员伤亡。
 
在俄控赫尔松地区和扎波罗热地区，俄罗斯中央选举委员会也报告了乌克兰针对投票站的几起袭击事件，包括无人机袭击和炮击，这些袭击导致一些人受伤。
 
对于乌克兰在俄大选期间的袭击，普京在胜选后的记者会上予以回应。据塔斯社报道，普京在记者会上说，乌克兰在边境地区集结了大约5000名士兵开展跨境袭击，对此俄罗斯可能被迫建立“某种缓冲区”，这个缓冲区将相当难以穿越。
translation:
In this general election, online voting is available in 29 regions, including Moscow, accounting for one-third of the country's electoral districts. According to statistics, the turnout rate for online voting reached 94%.
 
Some analysts believe that voting in Russia's presidential election lasted for three days because Putin hoped to increase turnout to demonstrate Russia's comprehensive support for him.
 
Election under fire
 
This election was the first wartime election held in Russia. Two years ago, on February 24, Putin launched a "special military operation" against Ukraine. Now the conflict is entering its third year.
 
The shadow of war has not dissipated during the three-day Russian presidential election. According to a Reuters report on March 18, in the past few days, Ukraine has repeatedly attacked Russian oil refineries, shelled some areas of Russia, and tried to break through the Russian border.
 
According to "Russia Today", there were some attempts to interfere with voting during the Russian election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that there were about 30 incidents of attempts to interfere with voting in 20 regions of Russia. Some people tried to burn ballot boxes and some tried to pour dyeing liquid into the ballot boxes. In St. Petersburg, Molotov cocktails were thrown at polling stations, but there were no casualties.
 
In the Russian-controlled Kherson and Zaporozhye regions, Russia's Central Election Commission also reported several Ukrainian attacks on polling stations, including drone strikes and shelling, which injured some people.
 
Regarding Ukraine's attacks during the Russian election, Putin responded at the press conference after winning the election. According to the TASS news agency, Putin said at a press conference that Ukraine has assembled about 5,000 soldiers in the border area to carry out cross-border attacks. In this regard, Russia may be forced to establish "some kind of buffer zone", which will be quite difficult to cross.
input:
In this general election, online voting is available in 29 regions, including Moscow, accounting for one-third of the country's electoral districts. According to statistics, the turnout rate for online voting reached 94%.
 
Some analysts believe that voting in Russia's presidential election lasted for three days because Putin hoped to increase turnout to demonstrate Russia's comprehensive support for him.
 
Election under fire
 
This election was the first wartime election held in Russia. Two years ago, on February 24, Putin launched a "special military operation" against Ukraine. Now the conflict is entering its third year.
 
The shadow of war has not dissipated during the three-day Russian presidential election. According to a Reuters report on March 18, in the past few days, Ukraine has repeatedly attacked Russian oil refineries, shelled some areas of Russia, and tried to break through the Russian border.
 
According to "Russia Today", there were some attempts to interfere with voting during the Russian election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that there were about 30 incidents of attempts to interfere with voting in 20 regions of Russia. Some people tried to burn ballot boxes and some tried to pour dyeing liquid into the ballot boxes. In St. Petersburg, Molotov cocktails were thrown at polling stations, but there were no casualties.
 
In the Russian-controlled Kherson and Zaporozhye regions, Russia's Central Election Commission also reported several Ukrainian attacks on polling stations, including drone strikes and shelling, which injured some people.
 
Regarding Ukraine's attacks during the Russian election, Putin responded at the press conference after winning the election. According to the TASS news agency, Putin said at a press conference that Ukraine has assembled about 5,000 soldiers in the border area to carry out cross-border attacks. In this regard, Russia may be forced to establish "some kind of buffer zone", which will be quite difficult to cross.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出，普京迎接“硬核”挑战_新闻频道_中国青年网
content:
当地时间3月18日，俄罗斯中央选举委员会发布数据，在俄总统选举统计完成的85%选票中，现任总统普京以87.19%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人，实际已经赢得此次总统选举。
　　当天凌晨普京召开记者会，感谢选民信任和支持，表示将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。
　　当下，俄罗斯面临极为复杂的形势，普京将如何带领俄罗斯迎接“硬核”挑战，外界都在关注。
　　临危受命
　　2023年，全俄社会舆论研究中心面向18岁以上俄罗斯人进行了一项调查，受访者就普京形象和政绩给出最多的评价是：冷静、有活力、坚决果断和智慧。近3/4受访者认为，普京有能力确保俄罗斯的稳定和发展。
　　这些特质，在普京步入政坛初期就逐步显露。
　　二十世纪90年代的“休克疗法”和经济危机令俄罗斯经济跌入谷底，社会问题突出。普京在《千年之交的俄罗斯》一文中写道，“俄罗斯国内生产总值(GDP)几乎下降50% ……俄罗斯正处于数百年来最困难的历史时期之一。这大概是俄罗斯近两三百年来首次真正面临沦为世界二三流国家的危险。”他意识到，稳定和发展经济，是当时的“头等任务”。
　　2000年入主克里姆林宫后，普京一方面调整经济政策、进行税收改革；另一方面，他的“强人”作风开始展露，大力打击寡头政治，恢复国家对经济命脉的把控。

资料图：莫斯科市中心的克里姆林宫。中新社发 田冰 摄
　　这一时期，恰逢国际油价攀升，相对稳定的政治经济环境下，俄罗斯抓住机会，快速发展。21世纪的前八年，俄罗斯GDP增长约70%，工业增长75%；2005年，俄罗斯跻身世界前十大经济体。
　　随着经济实力提升，俄罗斯的国际影响力也逐渐提高。2014年索契冬奥会、2018年世界杯相继在俄举办。
　　这些年来，俄罗斯贫困问题得到改善，从2000年到2023年，贫困人口从至少4200万减少到1350万。普京还提出，到2030年，俄罗斯的贫困水平要进一步下降至7%以下。
　　“普京的这些政绩给俄罗斯民众带来了实实在在的利益，得到了民众的喜爱和支持。”中国国际问题研究院研究员陈玉荣向中新网表示。
　　考验重重
　　2022年乌克兰危机升级后，俄罗斯遭到西方超万项制裁，大量西方企业退出俄市场。随后普京签令决定与“不友好国家”改用卢布结算天然气账单，俄经济表现出“稳定性和韧性”，抵御住了冲击，GDP在2023年扭转颓势，实现3.6%的增长。
　　陈玉荣指出，当下俄罗斯面临着复杂的国际环境，其经济面临持续稳定发展问题。这就意味着，在新的任期内，普京还将面对西方全方位经济制裁带来的各种难题，例如，俄内外经济结构调整等问题。
　　在2024年的国情咨文中，普京提出了很多具体的目标，如增加本国高科技产品和服务在国内市场的份额、提高非资源非能源出口、降低进口比重、实现更多技术自主等。
translation:
On March 18, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission released data. Among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and actually won the presidential election.
Putin held a press conference in the early morning of the same day, thanking voters for their trust and support, and stated that he would continue to promote national development in the new term.
At present, Russia is facing an extremely complex situation. The outside world is paying attention to how Putin will lead Russia to meet the "hard core" challenge.
Take orders in times of danger
In 2023, the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center conducted a survey among Russians over the age of 18. The most common comments given by respondents to Putin's image and political achievements were: calm, energetic, decisive and wise. Nearly three-quarters of the respondents believe that Putin has the ability to ensure Russia's stability and development.
These characteristics were gradually revealed when Putin entered the political arena.
The "shock therapy" and economic crisis in the 1990s caused the Russian economy to hit rock bottom and social problems became prominent. Putin wrote in the article "Russia at the Turn of the Millennium" that "Russia's gross domestic product (GDP) has dropped by almost 50%...Russia is in one of the most difficult historical periods in hundreds of years. This is probably Russia's last two years. For the first time in three hundred years, it was truly in danger of becoming a second- or third-rate country in the world.” He realized that stabilizing and developing the economy was the “top priority” at that time.
After taking over the Kremlin in 2000, Putin adjusted economic policies and carried out tax reforms on the one hand; on the other hand, he began to reveal his "strongman" style, vigorously combating oligarchy and restoring the country's control over the economic lifeline.

File photo: The Kremlin in central Moscow. Photo by Tian Bing issued by China News Service
During this period, which coincided with the rise in international oil prices and a relatively stable political and economic environment, Russia seized the opportunity and developed rapidly. In the first eight years of the 21st century, Russia's GDP grew by about 70% and its industry grew by 75%; in 2005, Russia ranked among the top ten economies in the world.
With the improvement of economic strength, Russia's international influence has gradually increased. The 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics and the 2018 World Cup were held in Russia.
Over the years, Russia's poverty problem has improved. From 2000 to 2023, the number of poor people decreased from at least 42 million to 13.5 million. Putin also proposed that Russia’s poverty level should be further reduced to below 7% by 2030.
"Putin's political achievements have brought tangible benefits to the Russian people and have won their love and support." Chen Yurong, a researcher at the China Institute of International Studies, told China News Service.
Many tests
After the Ukrainian crisis escalated in 2022, Russia was subject to more than 10,000 Western sanctions, and a large number of Western companies withdrew from the Russian market. Subsequently, Putin signed an order to switch to using rubles to settle natural gas bills with "unfriendly countries". The Russian economy showed "stability and resilience" and withstood the impact. GDP reversed the decline in 2023 and achieved 3.6% growth.
Chen Yurong pointed out that Russia is currently facing a complex international environment and its economy is facing the problem of sustained and stable development. This means that during his new term of office, Putin will also face various difficulties brought about by Western all-round economic sanctions, such as the adjustment of economic structure inside and outside Russia.
In his 2024 State of the Union address, Putin proposed many specific goals, such as increasing the share of the country's high-tech products and services in the domestic market, increasing non-resource and non-energy exports, reducing the proportion of imports, and achieving more technological independence.
​

title: Russian presidential election 2024: Putin extends one-man rule after stage-managed election devoid of credible opposition | CNN
content:
“No matter how hard anyone tries to frighten us, whoever tries to suppress us, our will, our consciousness, no one has ever managed to have done such a thing in history, and it won’t happen now and it won’t happen in the future. Never,” he said.
    

            Putin’s fiercest opponents have died in recent months.
    

            After leading a failed uprising in June, Wagner mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin was killed two months later after his plane crashed while traveling from Moscow to St. Petersburg. The Kremlin denied any involvement in Prigozhin’s death.
    

            The elections were held a month after Alexey Navalny, Putin’s most formidable opponent, died in an Arctic penal colony. Navalny’s family and supporters have accused Putin of being responsible for his death, a claim rejected by the Kremlin.
    

            In his Sunday evening address, Putin made an unprecedented break with his tradition of not uttering Navalny’s name, discussing his death and confirming discussions over a potential prisoner swap involving the opposition figure. Navalny’s allies had previously claimed he was “days away” from being exchanged before his death.
    

            “As for Mr. Navalny – yes, he passed away. It is always a sad event. And there were other cases when people in prisons passed away. Didn’t this happen in the United States? It did, and not once,” he said.
    

            Putin said a few days before Navalny’s death, he was told of a proposal to exchange him for prisoners held in Western countries. “The person who spoke to me had not finished his sentence yet when I said I agree,” Putin said. “But, unfortunately, what happened [Navalny’s death] happened. There was only one condition that we will exchange him for him not to come back. Let him sit there. Well, such things happen. There’s nothing you can do about it, that’s life.”
