            In his Sunday evening address, Putin made an unprecedented break with his tradition of not uttering Navalny’s name, discussing his death and confirming discussions over a potential prisoner swap involving the opposition figure. Navalny’s allies had previously claimed he was “days away” from being exchanged before his death.
    

            “As for Mr. Navalny – yes, he passed away. It is always a sad event. And there were other cases when people in prisons passed away. Didn’t this happen in the United States? It did, and not once,” he said.
    

            Putin said a few days before Navalny’s death, he was told of a proposal to exchange him for prisoners held in Western countries. “The person who spoke to me had not finished his sentence yet when I said I agree,” Putin said. “But, unfortunately, what happened [Navalny’s death] happened. There was only one condition that we will exchange him for him not to come back. Let him sit there. Well, such things happen. There’s nothing you can do about it, that’s life.”

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
content:
总的来说，我个人的生活没有太大变化，当然，战争影响了每个俄罗斯人的生活，很多国家对俄罗斯实施了很多制裁，不同的品牌和产品离开了俄罗斯，所以很多东西在我们国家买不到，或者价格上涨了几倍，这对我们的日常生活和生活质量造成了很大影响。
但在那些离开的品牌和公司之后，又出现了新的品牌和公司，俄罗斯国内的经济也开始迅速发展，小企业蓬勃发展，出现了许多优秀的国内品牌！我真心希望它们也能尽快迈上新台阶，走向国际！
我对战争的态度是非常消极的，因为我本人是一个非常热爱和平的人！老实说，很难明确回答这个问题，因为我并不了解所有的背景情况。到处都有很多信息，我很难对它们进行过滤，有些是假的，有些是真的。当然，作为一个人，我希望世界上没有战争、冲突和苦难，这样下一代就不会害怕任何事情，并期待着光明的未来。
至于普京，我当然觉得他很好，因为他是我们国家的总统。他会在大选中获胜。正如我妈妈所说，正是随着他的掌权，俄罗斯才变成了现在的样子。在21世纪初，多亏了他的努力，俄罗斯的政治和经济开始迅速发展，因为在（上世纪）90年代，许多国家发生了一波经济危机。我觉得他多年来在世界政治领导人中一直占据着强有力的地位，我们俄罗斯人可以依靠他。他对外创造了我们的国家形象和俄罗斯的形象，这与他的个性有关。
“英语教学网站正在增多”
translation:
In general, my personal life has not changed much, of course, the war affected the life of every Russian, many countries imposed a lot of sanctions on Russia, different brands and products left Russia, so a lot of things in our country Unavailability or the price has increased several times, which has a great impact on our daily life and quality of life.
But after those brands and companies that left, new brands and companies appeared. Russia's domestic economy also began to develop rapidly, small businesses flourished, and many excellent domestic brands appeared! I sincerely hope that they can also reach a new level and go international as soon as possible!
My attitude towards war is very negative, because I am a very peace-loving person! Honestly, it's hard to answer this question definitively because I don't know all the context. There is a lot of information out there and it's hard for me to filter it all, some are false and some are true. Of course, as a human being, I wish for a world without war, conflict and suffering so that the next generation would not be afraid of anything and look forward to a bright future.
As for Putin, of course I think he is very good because he is the president of our country. He will win the election. As my mother said, it was with his rise to power that Russia became what it is now. At the beginning of the 21st century, thanks to his efforts, Russia's political and economic development began to develop rapidly, since in the 1990s a wave of economic crises occurred in many countries. I feel that he has held a strong position among world political leaders for many years and that we Russians can rely on him. He created the image of our country and Russia externally, which is related to his personality.
“English teaching websites are increasing”
input:
In general, my personal life has not changed much, of course, the war affected the life of every Russian, many countries imposed a lot of sanctions on Russia, different brands and products left Russia, so a lot of things in our country Unavailability or the price has increased several times, which has a great impact on our daily life and quality of life.
But after those brands and companies that left, new brands and companies appeared. Russia's domestic economy also began to develop rapidly, small businesses flourished, and many excellent domestic brands appeared! I sincerely hope that they can also reach a new level and go international as soon as possible!
My attitude towards war is very negative, because I am a very peace-loving person! Honestly, it's hard to answer this question definitively because I don't know all the context. There is a lot of information out there and it's hard for me to filter it all, some are false and some are true. Of course, as a human being, I wish for a world without war, conflict and suffering so that the next generation would not be afraid of anything and look forward to a bright future.
As for Putin, of course I think he is very good because he is the president of our country. He will win the election. As my mother said, it was with his rise to power that Russia became what it is now. At the beginning of the 21st century, thanks to his efforts, Russia's political and economic development began to develop rapidly, since in the 1990s a wave of economic crises occurred in many countries. I feel that he has held a strong position among world political leaders for many years and that we Russians can rely on him. He created the image of our country and Russia externally, which is related to his personality.
“English teaching websites are increasing”

title: 俄罗斯总统普京实现其第五次总统选举的胜选
content:
【普京阵营宣布获得总统大选胜利,在迄今开票率70.03%中普京获得87.17%选票。针对普京总统实现第五次胜选,美国和乌克兰等国批评选举毫无民主性可言。】3月18日,综合塔斯社、AP时事、路透社、AFP、每日电讯等多家外媒报道——莫斯科当地时间本月17日晚些时候,根据根据俄罗斯中央选举管理委员会的初步统计:截至当晚的总统选举投票率为70.03%,其中普京在4名候选人中的得票率为87.17%,获胜当选已无悬念,普京将继续执掌今后6年的俄罗斯政权。71岁的普京在确定第5次连任后宣布胜利,他在竞选总部说:“首先要感谢俄罗斯人民,我们是一个整体。虽然眼前有很多课题,但我们的团结是毋庸置疑的。选举结果是国民的信任,也是国民对我们一切按计划进行的希望。”
此次选举,除了在全俄8个联邦管区进行投票外,在普京政权于2014年3月起实际控制的克里米亚半岛,2022年9月单方面宣布合并的乌克兰东部和南部的顿涅茨克州、卢甘斯克州、扎波罗热州和赫尔松州4个州也进行了投票。上述4个州在2023年9月俄罗斯统一地方选举时也曾举行过“州议会选举”。不过美国等西方国家和与俄罗斯交战的乌克兰对此次总统选举持强烈批判态度——白宫在华盛顿当地时间本月17日发表评论称:“考虑到普京将政敌投入监狱,并阻止对手参选,选举显然既不自由也不公正。”乌克兰总统泽伦斯基批判称:“这种选举行为在俄罗斯历史上反复出现过,没有正当性,也不可能存在。这个男人被权力所束缚,为了永远统治俄罗斯不惜做出一切事情。”其他西方国家纷纷对俄罗斯选举结果进行批判。
支持普京再次当选的选民态度也是异乎寻常的坚定。3月16日在距莫斯科东北60公里的谢尔盖耶夫波萨德投票站,当地居民正在为选出适合的人选而投票。谢尔盖耶夫波萨德受东正教影响强烈,拥有重要的东正教修道院。当地选民对法新社说:他们相信投票给普京,可以结束目前的武装冲突。54岁的爱德华多把票投给了普京。“我要为在世界上消除纷争而竭尽全力的人投票,因此我来到了这里。普京是能够拯救世界的人物。”爱德华多对普京展示了充分信任。77岁的正教会修女亚历山德拉就俄罗斯武力攻击乌克兰一事指出:“并不矛盾,最终可以挽救更多生命。”普京的出生地圣彼得堡选民也表示了与上述看法同样的意见。46岁的公务员康斯坦丁说,“希望早晨醒世界没有战斗或死亡就好了。即使如此,老实说,我认为还没有人能取代普京,所以我投他一票。”
translation:
[Putin’s camp declared victory in the presidential election. Putin received 87.17% of the votes so far, with a vote count of 70.03%. In response to President Putin's fifth victory, the United States, Ukraine and other countries criticized the election as being undemocratic. 】On March 18, a combination of TASS, AP Current Affairs, Reuters, AFP, Daily Telegraph and other foreign media reported that later on the 17th of this month, Moscow local time, according to preliminary statistics from the Russian Central Election Management Committee: As of that night, the turnout rate for the presidential election was 70.03%, of which Putin received 87.17% of the votes among the four candidates. There is no suspense about his victory. Putin will continue to rule the Russian government for the next six years. The 71-year-old Putin declared victory after confirming his fifth re-election. He said at the campaign headquarters: "First of all, I want to thank the Russian people. We are one. Although there are many issues at hand, our unity is beyond doubt. The election results are The trust of the people is also the people’s hope that everything will go according to plan.”
In addition to voting in the eight federal districts across Russia, this election will also take place in the Crimean Peninsula, which the Putin regime has actually controlled since March 2014, and Donne in eastern and southern Ukraine, which unilaterally announced the merger in September 2022. Voting also took place in four oblasts: Tsk, Lugansk, Zaporizhia and Kherson. The above-mentioned four states have also held "state parliamentary elections" in Russia's unified local elections in September 2023. However, the United States and other Western countries and Ukraine, which is at war with Russia, have strongly criticized the presidential election. The White House commented on the 17th local time in Washington, DC, saying: "Considering that Putin puts political opponents in jail and prevents them from running for election, The election is obviously neither free nor fair. "Ukrainian President Zelensky criticized: "This kind of election behavior has happened repeatedly in Russian history. It has no legitimacy and cannot exist. This man is bound by power for eternity. Rule Russia at all costs." Other Western countries have criticized Russia's election results.
The attitude of voters who support Putin's re-election is also unusually firm. On March 16, at the Sergeyev Posad polling station, 60 kilometers northeast of Moscow, local residents were voting for suitable candidates. Sergeyev Posad is strongly influenced by Orthodox Christianity and has an important Orthodox monastery. Local voters told AFP: They believe voting for Putin can end the current armed conflict. Eduardo, 54, voted for Putin. "I want to vote for someone who does his best to eliminate strife in the world, so I'm here. Putin is a person who can save the world." Eduardo showed full trust in Putin. Alexandra, a 77-year-old Orthodox nun, said regarding Russia's military attack on Ukraine: "It is not contradictory, and it will ultimately save more lives." Voters in St. Petersburg, Putin's birthplace, also expressed the same opinion as above. Konstantin, a 46-year-old civil servant, said, "I hope it will be nice to wake up in the morning to a world without fighting or death. Even so, to be honest, I don't think anyone can replace Putin, so I vote for him."

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
content:
我目前在学中文。在俄罗斯现在汉语变得比英语更重要。
我家就住在莫斯科附近，几乎可以说是就住在莫斯科，乌克兰的无人机在我家附近被打下来过几次。我有想过离开现在住的地方。你有听说过普里戈任政变吗？他是雇佣军的领导人，然后他背叛了，并且试图来到莫斯科，这令人毛骨悚然。
俄罗斯总统大选即将到来，并且当然，普京会连任。前几天纳瓦利内在监狱里去世了，但我们不知道真正的死因。我不会参加投票；但另一方面，我也不亲西方。欧洲和美国为乌克兰提供了很多武器。我对战争有复杂的想法。我们有理由发动这场战争，但这一切的发生还是很可悲的。但我确信我们必须赢。
我现在非常想念一些现场的音乐会。Depeche Mode和我想看的很多乐队现在都在世界各地巡演。但是，因为有制裁，他们不会来俄罗斯。我之前买了2019年Gorillaz、Killers乐队演出的门票，但是表演被取消了。一开始是因为新冠疫情，然后是战争…...
“制裁打开了许多新的机会之窗”
translation:
I am currently learning Chinese. Chinese is now more important than English in Russia.
My family lives near Moscow, almost in Moscow. Ukrainian drones have been shot down near my house several times. I have thought about leaving the place where I live now. Have you heard about the Prigozhin coup? He was the leader of the mercenaries, and then he betrayed and tried to come to Moscow, which was creepy.
The Russian presidential election is coming and, of course, Putin will be re-elected. Navalny died in prison a few days ago, but we don’t know the real cause of death. I won't vote; but on the other hand, I'm not pro-Western either. Europe and the United States provide Ukraine with a lot of weapons. I have mixed thoughts about war. We had reasons to start this war, but it is still very sad that this happened. But I'm sure we have to win.
I really miss some live concerts right now. Depeche Mode and a lot of the bands I want to see are touring around the world right now. But they will not come to Russia because of the sanctions. I previously bought tickets for the Gorillaz and Killers performances in 2019, but the performances were cancelled. First it was the COVID-19 pandemic, then the war...
“Sanctions open many new windows of opportunity”
input:
I am currently learning Chinese. Chinese is now more important than English in Russia.
My family lives near Moscow, almost in Moscow. Ukrainian drones have been shot down near my house several times. I have thought about leaving the place where I live now. Have you heard about the Prigozhin coup? He was the leader of the mercenaries, and then he betrayed and tried to come to Moscow, which was creepy.
The Russian presidential election is coming and, of course, Putin will be re-elected. Navalny died in prison a few days ago, but we don’t know the real cause of death. I won't vote; but on the other hand, I'm not pro-Western either. Europe and the United States provide Ukraine with a lot of weapons. I have mixed thoughts about war. We had reasons to start this war, but it is still very sad that this happened. But I'm sure we have to win.
I really miss some live concerts right now. Depeche Mode and a lot of the bands I want to see are touring around the world right now. But they will not come to Russia because of the sanctions. I previously bought tickets for the Gorillaz and Killers performances in 2019, but the performances were cancelled. First it was the COVID-19 pandemic, then the war...
“Sanctions open many new windows of opportunity”

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出,普京迎接“硬核”挑战
content:
外交破局
“你什么时候邀请俄罗斯加入北约？”普京2001年造访北约总部时,曾向时任北约秘书长罗伯逊询问。
俄罗斯与北约一度有过“蜜月期“。但随着北约不断东扩,双方关系几番起落,2014年克里米亚事件发生后,北约停止与俄一切军事交往,关系全面恶化。
时至今日,北约已实现新一轮扩张,吸纳了俄罗斯的邻国芬兰和瑞典。加上美西方不断“拱火”乌克兰危机,地缘政治博弈愈演愈烈,俄与美西方关系一跌再跌,滑入冰谷。
陈玉荣指出,当前俄美、俄欧关系陷于冷战后最糟糕的境地。普京连任后,短期内,俄西方紧张对峙关系很难改变。“未来俄西方关系的变化,很大程度上还要取决于乌克兰危机如何解决。”

不过,面对西方的围堵,俄罗斯努力破局,积极拓展与全球南方国家关系。
2023年12月,普京顶住美国和欧洲一些国家竭力孤立俄的压力,出访阿联酋和沙特,商讨石油合作与巴以冲突问题；这一年,俄罗斯继续与独联体国家密切合作,与印度开展密集政治对话,召开俄罗斯-非洲峰会与非洲多国互动。
在普京2023年批准的新版《外交政策构想》中,俄罗斯还计划将优先发展同伊朗、土耳其、沙特阿拉伯、埃及和叙利亚的关系,在经济、安全等领域与东盟国家加强合作。
“多极化的国际关系体系正在形成,是不可逆的过程。”普京多次表示,“我们会努力联合世界大多数国家,以应对全球性挑战。”
translation:
Diplomacy breaks down
"When will you invite Russia to join NATO?" Putin asked then NATO Secretary-General Robertson when he visited NATO headquarters in 2001.
Russia and NATO once had a "honeymoon period." However, as NATO continues to expand eastward, relations between the two sides have experienced ups and downs. After the Crimea incident in 2014, NATO stopped all military exchanges with Russia, and relations deteriorated overall.
Today, NATO has achieved a new round of expansion, absorbing Russia's neighbors Finland and Sweden. Coupled with the fact that the United States and the West continue to "fire up" the Ukraine crisis, the geopolitical game has intensified, and the relationship between Russia and the United States and the West has fallen again and again, slipping into an icy valley.
Chen Yurong pointed out that the current relations between Russia, the United States, and Russia and Europe are in the worst situation since the Cold War. After Putin's re-election, it will be difficult to change the tense confrontation between Russia and the West in the short term. "The future changes in Russia-Western relations will largely depend on how the Ukraine crisis is resolved."

However, in the face of Western containment, Russia has worked hard to break through the situation and actively expanded its relations with countries in the Global South.
In December 2023, Putin withstood the pressure of the United States and some European countries to isolate Russia and visited the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia to discuss oil cooperation and the Palestinian-Israeli conflict; this year, Russia continued to cooperate closely with the CIS countries and carried out cooperation with India. Intensive political dialogue, convening a Russia-Africa summit to interact with many African countries.
In the new version of the "Foreign Policy Concept" approved by Putin in 2023, Russia also plans to give priority to developing relations with Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria, and strengthen cooperation with ASEAN countries in economic, security and other fields.
"A multipolar international relations system is taking shape, which is an irreversible process." Putin has said many times, "We will work hard to unite most countries in the world to respond to global challenges."
input:
Diplomacy breaks down
"When will you invite Russia to join NATO?" Putin asked then NATO Secretary-General Robertson when he visited NATO headquarters in 2001.
Russia and NATO once had a "honeymoon period." However, as NATO continues to expand eastward, relations between the two sides have experienced ups and downs. After the Crimea incident in 2014, NATO stopped all military exchanges with Russia, and relations deteriorated overall.
Today, NATO has achieved a new round of expansion, absorbing Russia's neighbors Finland and Sweden. Coupled with the fact that the United States and the West continue to "fire up" the Ukraine crisis, the geopolitical game has intensified, and the relationship between Russia and the United States and the West has fallen again and again, slipping into an icy valley.
Chen Yurong pointed out that the current relations between Russia, the United States, and Russia and Europe are in the worst situation since the Cold War. After Putin's re-election, it will be difficult to change the tense confrontation between Russia and the West in the short term. "The future changes in Russia-Western relations will largely depend on how the Ukraine crisis is resolved."

However, in the face of Western containment, Russia has worked hard to break through the situation and actively expanded its relations with countries in the Global South.
In December 2023, Putin withstood the pressure of the United States and some European countries to isolate Russia and visited the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia to discuss oil cooperation and the Palestinian-Israeli conflict; this year, Russia continued to cooperate closely with the CIS countries and carried out cooperation with India. Intensive political dialogue, convening a Russia-Africa summit to interact with many African countries.
In the new version of the "Foreign Policy Concept" approved by Putin in 2023, Russia also plans to give priority to developing relations with Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria, and strengthen cooperation with ASEAN countries in economic, security and other fields.
"A multipolar international relations system is taking shape, which is an irreversible process." Putin has said many times, "We will work hard to unite most countries in the world to respond to global challenges."

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
content:
“今日俄罗斯”指出，普京的主要政策目标包括解决贫困问题、支持有孩子的家庭，同时加强俄罗斯的经济独立性。
 
根据当前的计票结果，普京已成功锁定第五个总统任期。此前，他于2000年、2004年、2012年、2018年四次参加总统选举皆获胜。路透社指出，随着第五个任期即将到来，普京将超越苏联前领导人斯大林，成为俄罗斯历史上在任时间最长的领导人。
 
俄罗斯2008年将总统任期延长至6年，连续任职不得超过两届。2021年，俄罗斯联邦委员会通过关于总统任期的法律。根据这项法律，普京可以在现任期结束后再连任两届。这也就意味着，在这一个6年任期结束后，普京还可以竞选连任一个任期。
 
创纪录的投票率
 
俄罗斯此次大选举行前，外界认为普京获得压倒性胜利基本没有悬念，唯一可能会凸显俄罗斯国内对普京态度的是投票率。
 
此前，俄罗斯知名反对派人士阿列克谢·纳瓦利内在狱中突然死亡，引发国际社会瞩目。纳瓦利内的妻子尤利娅·纳瓦尔纳亚指控普京应对此负责，同时呼吁纳瓦利内的支持者对大选发起抗议，要么不参加投票，要么支持另外几位候选人，或者在选票上写纳瓦利内的名字。
translation:
"Russia Today" pointed out that Putin's main policy goals include solving poverty and supporting families with children while strengthening Russia's economic independence.
 
According to the current vote count, Putin has successfully locked in a fifth presidential term. Previously, he won four presidential elections in 2000, 2004, 2012, and 2018. Reuters pointed out that as his fifth term is approaching, Putin will surpass former Soviet leader Stalin and become the longest-serving leader in Russian history.
 
In 2008, Russia extended the presidential term to six years, and the president cannot serve more than two consecutive terms. In 2021, the Russian Federation Council passed a law on the presidential term. Under this law, Putin can serve two more terms after his current term ends. This also means that after the end of this six-year term, Putin can run for re-election for one term.
 
record turnout
 
Before the Russian election, the outside world believed that there was basically no suspense about Putin's overwhelming victory. The only thing that might highlight Russia's domestic attitude towards Putin was the turnout.
 
Previously, the sudden death of Alexei Navalny, a well-known Russian opposition figure in prison, attracted the attention of the international community. Navalny’s wife, Yulia Navalnaya, accused Putin of being responsible and called on Navalny’s supporters to protest against the election, either by not participating in the vote, by supporting other candidates, or by being on the ballot. Write Navalny’s name.
input:
"Russia Today" pointed out that Putin's main policy goals include solving poverty and supporting families with children while strengthening Russia's economic independence.
 
According to the current vote count, Putin has successfully locked in a fifth presidential term. Previously, he won four presidential elections in 2000, 2004, 2012, and 2018. Reuters pointed out that as his fifth term is approaching, Putin will surpass former Soviet leader Stalin and become the longest-serving leader in Russian history.
 
In 2008, Russia extended the presidential term to six years, and the president cannot serve more than two consecutive terms. In 2021, the Russian Federation Council passed a law on the presidential term. Under this law, Putin can serve two more terms after his current term ends. This also means that after the end of this six-year term, Putin can run for re-election for one term.
 
record turnout
 
Before the Russian election, the outside world believed that there was basically no suspense about Putin's overwhelming victory. The only thing that might highlight Russia's domestic attitude towards Putin was the turnout.
 
Previously, the sudden death of Alexei Navalny, a well-known Russian opposition figure in prison, attracted the attention of the international community. Navalny’s wife, Yulia Navalnaya, accused Putin of being responsible and called on Navalny’s supporters to protest against the election, either by not participating in the vote, by supporting other candidates, or by being on the ballot. Write Navalny’s name.

title: 枪口之下：被占地区的乌克兰人在俄罗斯选举中支持普京 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
自2月25日以来，在乌克兰四个被俄罗斯占领的地区，带着名牌和大堆文件的妇女不断敲门，或者尝试接近公寓楼或房屋外的居民。
这些文件都是选民名单，而这些妇女（很少有男性）则是选举官员，她们通常在附近的学校内任教，收水电费或担任政府文员。
被占领地区的前居民及现居民告诉半岛电视台记者，她们要求居民们出示身份证件，并敦促他们填写一份早期选票表格，其中包含俄罗斯总统选举中4位候选人的名字。
其中一位候选人是弗拉基米尔·普京，他几乎肯定会赢得第五次选举，其余3位总统候选人都是亲克里姆林宫政党的傀儡领导人。观察人士普遍认为，他们的参与是为了营造一种拥有选择的幻觉。
半岛电视台获悉，乌克兰人很少会以非常具有说服力的理由拒绝填写选票——一名蒙面、持枪的俄罗斯军人就站在选举官员旁边，而附近一辆汽车内坐着更多的武装人员。
“投票”通常会在公寓入口附近进行，选举官员和武装士兵都可以看到选票上勾选了谁的名字。
translation:
Since February 25, in four Russian-occupied regions of Ukraine, women armed with name tags and piles of documents have been knocking on doors or trying to approach residents outside apartment buildings or houses.
The documents were voter lists, and the women (and rarely men) were elected officials, who often taught in nearby schools, collected utility bills, or worked as government clerks.
Former and current residents of the occupied areas told Al Jazeera reporters that they asked residents to show their identification documents and urged them to fill out an early voting form containing the names of the four candidates in Russia's presidential election.
One of the candidates is Vladimir Putin, who is almost certain to win the fifth election, and the remaining three presidential candidates are all figureheads of pro-Kremlin parties. Observers generally believe their involvement is designed to create the illusion of choice.
Al Jazeera has learned that Ukrainians rarely give very convincing reasons for refusing to fill out their ballots - a masked, gun-toting Russian soldier stood next to election officials, while more armed men sat in a car nearby. personnel.
The "poll" usually takes place near the apartment entrance, where election officials and armed soldiers can see whose names are checked on the ballot.
input:
Since February 25, in four Russian-occupied regions of Ukraine, women armed with name tags and piles of documents have been knocking on doors or trying to approach residents outside apartment buildings or houses.
The documents were voter lists, and the women (and rarely men) were elected officials, who often taught in nearby schools, collected utility bills, or worked as government clerks.
Former and current residents of the occupied areas told Al Jazeera reporters that they asked residents to show their identification documents and urged them to fill out an early voting form containing the names of the four candidates in Russia's presidential election.
One of the candidates is Vladimir Putin, who is almost certain to win the fifth election, and the remaining three presidential candidates are all figureheads of pro-Kremlin parties. Observers generally believe their involvement is designed to create the illusion of choice.
Al Jazeera has learned that Ukrainians rarely give very convincing reasons for refusing to fill out their ballots - a masked, gun-toting Russian soldier stood next to election officials, while more armed men sat in a car nearby. personnel.
The "poll" usually takes place near the apartment entrance, where election officials and armed soldiers can see whose names are checked on the ballot.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Как проходила агитация
Разрешенный период предвыборной агитации начался 17 февраля (за 28 дней до начала голосования согласно законодательству) и закончился в полночь по местному времени в первый день голосования, 15 марта. «День тишины», когда агитацию необходимо было прекращать за сутки до дня голосования, для многодневных выборов был отменен в мае 2021 года. В случае однодневных выборов правило тишины сохраняется.

Агитацию можно было вести на телеканалах (в форме публичных дебатов, дискуссий, круглых столов и так далее), в печатных и сетевых изданиях, распространяя агитматериалы, а также проводя публичные мероприятия. Кандидатам и партиям, их выдвинувшим, предоставлялось бесплатное эфирное время на телеканалах, а также бесплатные печатные площади в периодических изданиях. В этой кампании кандидатам отвели семь часов телевизионного эфира, в том числе 3 часа 30 минут для дебатов. Путин отказался от бесплатного эфирного времени для участия в дебатах.

Кроме того, кандидаты могли закупать и платную рекламу на телевидении. Как писал РБК, платная телереклама оказалась маловостребованной в этой предвыборной гонке. Харитонов сделал упор на дебаты в рамках бесплатных эфиров и встречи с избирателями, а также на размещение наружной рекламы на билбордах; Слуцкий использовал бесплатное эфирное время на телевидении и радио, проводил «баннерную кампанию»; Даванков покупал рекламу на ТВ и наружных средствах размещения, а кроме того, пользовался бесплатным эфирным временем. Предвыборные ролики Путина демонстрировались на федеральных каналах, а в регионах были размещены билборды в поддержку кандидата.

Согласно законодательству, печатные материалы, которые кандидаты использовали для агитации, например листовки или плакаты, в том числе размещенные на рекламных конструкциях, с началом голосования снимать не нужно.
translation:
How did the campaign go?
The permitted campaign period began on February 17 (28 days before the start of voting according to law) and ended at midnight local time on the first day of voting, March 15. The “Day of Silence,” when campaigning had to stop 24 hours before voting day, was abolished for multi-day elections in May 2021. In the case of one-day elections, the rule of silence remains.

Campaigning could be carried out on television channels (in the form of public debates, discussions, round tables, and so on), in print and online publications, distributing campaign materials, and also holding public events. Candidates and the parties that nominated them were provided with free airtime on television channels, as well as free print space in periodicals. In this campaign, candidates were given seven hours of television time, including 3 hours and 30 minutes for debates. Putin refused free airtime to participate in the debate.

In addition, candidates could purchase paid advertising on television. As RBC wrote, paid television advertising turned out to be of little demand in this election race. Kharitonov focused on free-to-air debates and meetings with voters, as well as outdoor advertising on billboards; Slutsky used free airtime on television and radio and conducted a “banner campaign”; Davankov bought advertising on TV and outdoor media, and in addition, enjoyed free airtime. Putin's election videos were shown on federal channels, and billboards in support of the candidate were placed in the regions.

According to the law, printed materials that candidates used for campaigning, such as leaflets or posters, including those placed on advertising structures, do not need to be removed when voting begins.
input:
How did the campaign go?
The permitted campaign period began on February 17 (28 days before the start of voting according to law) and ended at midnight local time on the first day of voting, March 15. The “Day of Silence,” when campaigning had to stop 24 hours before voting day, was abolished for multi-day elections in May 2021. In the case of one-day elections, the rule of silence remains.

Campaigning could be carried out on television channels (in the form of public debates, discussions, round tables, and so on), in print and online publications, distributing campaign materials, and also holding public events. Candidates and the parties that nominated them were provided with free airtime on television channels, as well as free print space in periodicals. In this campaign, candidates were given seven hours of television time, including 3 hours and 30 minutes for debates. Putin refused free airtime to participate in the debate.

In addition, candidates could purchase paid advertising on television. As RBC wrote, paid television advertising turned out to be of little demand in this election race. Kharitonov focused on free-to-air debates and meetings with voters, as well as outdoor advertising on billboards; Slutsky used free airtime on television and radio and conducted a “banner campaign”; Davankov bought advertising on TV and outdoor media, and in addition, enjoyed free airtime. Putin's election videos were shown on federal channels, and billboards in support of the candidate were placed in the regions.

According to the law, printed materials that candidates used for campaigning, such as leaflets or posters, including those placed on advertising structures, do not need to be removed when voting begins.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
content:
普京在竞选获胜的当天晚上,在俄竞选总部发表讲话,明确指出,当前中俄两国的关系非常稳定,成为维护国际舞台稳定的重要因素,未来中俄关系还将进一步得到强化。他还特别强调,台湾地区是中国不可分割的一部分,那些对中国“不友好者”企图利用台湾问题挑衅中国的计划注定会彻底失败。

作为我国最大的邻国、联合国常任理事国、军事实力几乎能与美国齐肩的国家首脑,在我国核心利益问题上作出如此明确的表态,它的意义,它的分量,它的作用,不言而喻。
translation:
On the evening of the day he won the election, Putin delivered a speech at the Russian campaign headquarters, clearly stating that the current relationship between China and Russia is very stable and has become an important factor in maintaining stability on the international stage. Sino-Russian relations will be further strengthened in the future. He also particularly emphasized that the Taiwan region is an inalienable part of China, and the plans of those who are "unfriendly" to China to use the Taiwan issue to provoke China are doomed to fail completely.

As my country's largest neighbor, a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, and a head of state whose military strength is almost as strong as that of the United States, to make such a clear statement on the issue of my country's core interests, its significance, its weight, and its role cannot be overstated. And metaphor.
input:
On the evening of the day he won the election, Putin delivered a speech at the Russian campaign headquarters, clearly stating that the current relationship between China and Russia is very stable and has become an important factor in maintaining stability on the international stage. Sino-Russian relations will be further strengthened in the future. He also particularly emphasized that the Taiwan region is an inalienable part of China, and the plans of those who are "unfriendly" to China to use the Taiwan issue to provoke China are doomed to fail completely.

As my country's largest neighbor, a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, and a head of state whose military strength is almost as strong as that of the United States, to make such a clear statement on the issue of my country's core interests, its significance, its weight, and its role cannot be overstated. And metaphor.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content: Но если внутри страны Путин одержал безоговорочную победу, то на международной арене все оказалось не так однозначно. Западные лидеры, как и ожидалось, раскритиковали итоги выборов и назвали их несвободными и нечестными. Особенно их возмутило голосование в Крыму и новых регионах - ДНР, ЛНР, Херсонской и Запорожской областях. Мол, это нарушает суверенитет Украины и международное право.
translation: But if Putin won an unconditional victory domestically, on the international stage everything was not so clear. Western leaders, as expected, criticized the election results and called them unfree and unfair. They were especially outraged by the voting in Crimea and new regions - the DPR, LPR, Kherson and Zaporozhye regions. They say this violates the sovereignty of Ukraine and international law.
input: But if Putin won an unconditional victory domestically, on the international stage everything was not so clear. Western leaders, as expected, criticized the election results and called them unfree and unfair. They were especially outraged by the voting in Crimea and new regions - the DPR, LPR, Kherson and Zaporozhye regions. They say this violates the sovereignty of Ukraine and international law.

title: Putin ‘wins’ rigged Russian election with 87 percent of the vote – POLITICO
content:
Vladimir Putin tightened his grip on power, claiming another six-year term as Russian president after a brutally distorted election in which all serious challengers were wiped out before voting began. 
With 50 percent of ballots counted, Putin’s tally stood at 87.3 percent of the vote, election officials announced. Turnout was 73.33 percent, according to the latest figures from Russian authorities. 
Putin’s victory was never in doubt but this is the biggest share of the vote he has claimed in any of his five presidential election wins since his first in 2000. At 71, he is already the longest serving Russian leader since Josef Stalin and could go on to beat that record. An official celebration is scheduled for Monday. 
Speaking after the early results were announced, Putin vowed to lead Russia to victory in achieving his goals, saying “nobody in history has ever succeeded” in suppressing the will of Russians. “They failed now and they will fail in the future,” he said.
input:
Vladimir Putin tightened his grip on power, claiming another six-year term as Russian president after a brutally distorted election in which all serious challengers were wiped out before voting began. 
With 50 percent of ballots counted, Putin’s tally stood at 87.3 percent of the vote, election officials announced. Turnout was 73.33 percent, according to the latest figures from Russian authorities. 
Putin’s victory was never in doubt but this is the biggest share of the vote he has claimed in any of his five presidential election wins since his first in 2000. At 71, he is already the longest serving Russian leader since Josef Stalin and could go on to beat that record. An official celebration is scheduled for Monday. 
Speaking after the early results were announced, Putin vowed to lead Russia to victory in achieving his goals, saying “nobody in history has ever succeeded” in suppressing the will of Russians. “They failed now and they will fail in the future,” he said.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出,普京迎接“硬核”挑战
content:
中新网3月18日电(张乃月)当地时间3月18日,俄罗斯中央选举委员会发布数据,在俄总统选举统计完成的85%选票中,现任总统普京以87.19%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人,实际已经赢得此次总统选举。
当天凌晨普京召开记者会,感谢选民信任和支持,表示将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。
当下,俄罗斯面临极为复杂的形势,普京将如何带领俄罗斯迎接“硬核”挑战,外界都在关注。

临危受命
2023年,全俄社会舆论研究中心面向18岁以上俄罗斯人进行了一项调查,受访者就普京形象和政绩给出最多的评价是:冷静、有活力、坚决果断和智慧。近3/4受访者认为,普京有能力确保俄罗斯的稳定和发展。
这些特质,在普京步入政坛初期就逐步显露。
二十世纪90年代的“休克疗法”和经济危机令俄罗斯经济跌入谷底,社会问题突出。普京在《千年之交的俄罗斯》一文中写道,“俄罗斯国内生产总值(GDP)几乎下降50% ……俄罗斯正处于数百年来最困难的历史时期之一。这大概是俄罗斯近两三百年来首次真正面临沦为世界二三流国家的危险。”他意识到,稳定和发展经济,是当时的“头等任务”。
2000年入主克里姆林宫后,普京一方面调整经济政策、进行税收改革；另一方面,他的“强人”作风开始展露,大力打击寡头政治,恢复国家对经济命脉的把控。
translation:
China News Service, March 18 (Zhang Naiyue) On March 18, local time, Russia's Central Election Commission released data. Among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes. man, has actually won this presidential election.
Putin held a press conference in the early morning of the same day, thanking voters for their trust and support, and stated that he would continue to promote national development in the new term.
At present, Russia is facing an extremely complex situation. The outside world is paying attention to how Putin will lead Russia to meet the "hard core" challenges.

Take orders in times of danger
In 2023, the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center conducted a survey among Russians over the age of 18. Respondents gave the most comments on Putin's image and achievements as: calm, energetic, decisive and wise. Nearly three-quarters of the respondents believe that Putin has the ability to ensure Russia's stability and development.
These characteristics were gradually revealed when Putin entered the political arena.
The "shock therapy" and economic crisis in the 1990s caused the Russian economy to hit rock bottom and social problems became prominent. Putin wrote in the article "Russia at the Turn of the Millennium" that "Russia's gross domestic product (GDP) has dropped by almost 50%...Russia is in one of the most difficult historical periods in hundreds of years. This is probably Russia's last two years. For the first time in three hundred years, it was really facing the danger of becoming a second- or third-rate country in the world." He realized that stabilizing and developing the economy was the "top priority" at that time.
After taking office in the Kremlin in 2000, Putin adjusted economic policies and carried out tax reforms on the one hand; on the other hand, he began to reveal his "strongman" style, vigorously combating oligarchy and restoring the country's control over the economic lifeline.

At present, Russia is facing an extremely complex situation. The outside world is paying attention to how Putin will lead Russia to meet the "hard core" challenges.

Take orders in times of danger

Nearly three-quarters of the respondents believe that Putin has the ability to ensure Russia's stability and development.
These characteristics were gradually revealed when Putin entered the political arena.
The "shock therapy" and economic crisis in the 1990s caused the Russian economy to hit rock bottom and social problems became prominent. Putin wrote in the article "Russia at the Turn of the Millennium" that "Russia's gross domestic product (GDP) has dropped by almost 50%...Russia is in one of the most difficult historical periods in hundreds of years. This is probably Russia's last two years. For the first time in three hundred years, it was really facing the danger of becoming a second- or third-rate country in the world." He realized that stabilizing and developing the economy was the "top priority" at that time.
After taking office in the Kremlin in 2000, Putin adjusted economic policies and carried out tax reforms on the one hand; on the other hand, he began to reveal his "strongman" style, vigorously combating oligarchy and restoring the country's control over the economic lifeline.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
“萨沙他们是顿涅茨克的英雄。天知道他们没有把乌克兰人从马林卡和阿夫杰耶夫卡赶走的话，我们还得挨多少炮击。”卡丽娜说。
当然，并非所有当地人都像卡丽娜一般将这场并无多少悬念的大选视为必须参与的盛事。卡丽娜坦言，有的邻居没有去投票站，而他们往往会受到选举工作人员的拜访。这些人带着投票箱，上门劝告未赴投票站的居民行使选举权。
大选仅仅是俄罗斯深度嵌入当地政治和公共生活的一个环节。在总统选举以前，俄罗斯政府一直在鼓励新占领地区的居民更换俄罗斯护照和身份文件，一些社会福利的发放也与此挂钩。如今，不仅仅是护照，一切个人文件都要更换，驾照、不动产权证明、公证材料等等。当地小学和中学的老师早已开始使用俄罗斯教材。
新“领土”与俄罗斯腹地的交流同样变得更加深入。一名正在卢甘斯克读大学的当地女学生告诉澎湃新闻，自从俄乌冲突爆发以来，她所在的大学常常暂停正常教学，改为在线上课。不过，从2023年下半年开始，由于炮击频率下降，学校又开始了线下授课。不仅如此，校方还频繁组织学生去莫斯科、圣彼得堡等城市游学，参观博物馆、历史遗迹等等，接受俄罗斯爱国主义教育。
“冲突爆发前我在学校还有几个认同乌克兰的朋友，她们有的去了基辅，有的在欧洲当了难民。她们离开家乡，忘却自己的身份，斩断和家乡的联系。我不想过那样的日子。”她回忆说，同时坦言自己在选举中将把票投给普京。
“我出生时普京就是总统。参加投票唯一的理由是我可以确认自己的身份。就像那些十年前在基辅的广场上自豪喊出自己是乌克兰人的年轻人一样，我只是想拥有同样的权利，选择我认同的文化，并且不受他人置喙。”
translation:
"Sasha and the others are the heroes of Donetsk. God knows how much more shelling we would have had to endure if they had not driven the Ukrainians away from Malinka and Avdeevka," Karina said.
Of course, not all locals are like Karina who regard this election, which is not much suspense, as a must-attend event. Karina admitted that some neighbors did not go to the polling stations, and they were often visited by election workers. These people brought ballot boxes and visited residents to advise residents who did not go to the polling stations to exercise their right to vote.
The election is just one step in Russia’s deep embeddedness in local politics and public life. Before the presidential election, the Russian government has been encouraging residents of newly occupied areas to replace their Russian passports and identity documents, and the payment of some social benefits has also been linked to this. Nowadays, not only passports, but also all personal documents need to be replaced, including driver's licenses, real estate certificates, notarized documents, etc. Teachers at local primary and secondary schools have already started using Russian textbooks.
The new “territory” also became more deeply connected with the Russian hinterland. A local female student studying at university in Luhansk told The Paper that since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, her university has often suspended normal teaching and switched to online classes. However, starting from the second half of 2023, due to the decrease in the frequency of shelling, the school began offline teaching again. Not only that, the school also frequently organizes students to study in cities such as Moscow and St. Petersburg, visit museums, historical sites, etc., and receive Russian patriotism education.
"Before the conflict broke out, I had a few friends in school who identified with Ukraine. Some of them went to Kiev, and some became refugees in Europe. They left their hometowns, forgot their identities, and severed ties with their hometowns. I didn't want to think about it. Those days,” she recalled, admitting that she would vote for Putin in the election.
"Putin was president when I was born. The only reason to vote was so that I could identify myself. Like those young people who proudly shouted out that they were Ukrainian in the squares of Kiev a decade ago, I just want to have the same The right to choose a culture that I identify with and not be judged by others.”

title: Реакция мировых СМИ на победу Владимира Путина
content:
Американский телеканал CNN попытался спрогнозировать, что победа Путина значит для его союзников и для всего мира:
Председатель Китайской Народной Республики Си Цзиньпин и другие лидеры, которым выгодно, чтобы Путин отверг мировой порядок, возглавляемый Западом, будут радоваться его победе.
Северокорейский лидер Ким Чен Ын недавно встретился с Путиным во время визита в Россию. Для Кима это укрепление связей — серьезная возможность поддержать свою испытывающую трудности экономику в условиях тесной кооперации между США и Южной Кореей.
Пострадавшее от санкций правительство Ирана, которое расширяет свою сотрудничество с Россией, также выигрывает от того, что Путин и дальше будет находиться у власти.
Даже Индия, которая выстраивает отношения с США, извлекает пользу из торговли с Россией, особенно в сфере энергоносителей.
translation:
The American TV channel CNN tried to predict what Putin's victory means for his allies and for the whole world:
People's Republic of China President Xi Jinping and other leaders who benefit from Putin's rejection of the Western-led world order will rejoice in his victory.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un recently met with Putin during a visit to Russia. For Kim, this strengthening of ties is a major opportunity to bolster his struggling economy amid close cooperation between the United States and South Korea.
Iran's sanctions-hit government, which is expanding its cooperation with Russia, also benefits from Putin remaining in power.
Even India, which is building relations with the US, benefits from trade with Russia, especially in the energy sector.
input:
The American TV channel CNN tried to predict what Putin's victory means for his allies and for the whole world:
People's Republic of China President Xi Jinping and other leaders who benefit from Putin's rejection of the Western-led world order will rejoice in his victory.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un recently met with Putin during a visit to Russia. For Kim, this strengthening of ties is a major opportunity to bolster his struggling economy amid close cooperation between the United States and South Korea.
Iran's sanctions-hit government, which is expanding its cooperation with Russia, also benefits from Putin remaining in power.
Even India, which is building relations with the US, benefits from trade with Russia, especially in the energy sector.

title: Russian election 2024: What could Putin do over the next six years?
content:
It was among the least surprising political events so far this year, but Vladimir Putin's reelection to a fifth term in office comes at a time of geopolitical and economic uncertainty for Russia, prompting questions as to what we can expect from another six years of the Russian strongman's leadership.
With Putin winning the vote by a huge margin, according to the Kremlin and its the Central Election Commission, the 2024 Russian election aimed to demonstrate that Russian society was "consolidated" around the president and that his domestic and foreign policies had the blessing of Russians both within the country and in its claimed "new" territories illegally annexed from Ukraine, as well as abroad.
That message was meant to be encapsulated neatly in the "landslide" 87% of voters that elected him, according to the electoral authorities, and the "record-breaking, unprecedented" voter turnout of 77.4%, up from 67.7% in 2018.
Analysts share their views on what we can expect now that Putin has strengthened his grip on power, with the Ukraine war, domestic economic reforms and a possible government reshuffle key factors to watch.
Russia's strategy in the war in Ukraine will be a major focus for the Kremlin in the immediate and near-term future, analysts say, with Russia appearing to have a military advantage on the battlefield in recent months.
input:
It was among the least surprising political events so far this year, but Vladimir Putin's reelection to a fifth term in office comes at a time of geopolitical and economic uncertainty for Russia, prompting questions as to what we can expect from another six years of the Russian strongman's leadership.
With Putin winning the vote by a huge margin, according to the Kremlin and its the Central Election Commission, the 2024 Russian election aimed to demonstrate that Russian society was "consolidated" around the president and that his domestic and foreign policies had the blessing of Russians both within the country and in its claimed "new" territories illegally annexed from Ukraine, as well as abroad.
That message was meant to be encapsulated neatly in the "landslide" 87% of voters that elected him, according to the electoral authorities, and the "record-breaking, unprecedented" voter turnout of 77.4%, up from 67.7% in 2018.
Analysts share their views on what we can expect now that Putin has strengthened his grip on power, with the Ukraine war, domestic economic reforms and a possible government reshuffle key factors to watch.
Russia's strategy in the war in Ukraine will be a major focus for the Kremlin in the immediate and near-term future, analysts say, with Russia appearing to have a military advantage on the battlefield in recent months.

title: Russian election 2024: What could Putin do over the next six years?
content:
The U.S. presidential election later this year, meanwhile, puts the future of military aid for Ukraine into doubt.
Russia could look to push home its advantage over the next year, sending more manpower to the front, although that could have ramifications back home.
"In his post-election speech on Sunday night, Putin said that the main goals of his next six years include the special military operation and strengthening the country's defence capabilities. The war is popular in Russia but mobilisations of the population are not and the wide election victory could embolden Putin to step up the military effort," Liam Peach, senior emerging markets economist at Capital Economics, said in analysis Monday.
The Russian government has already put the economy on a war footing and has laid out plans to increase military spending significantly in 2024.
Finance Minister Anton Siluanov announced last fall that Russia's spending on national defense will be almost 11 trillion rubles ($117 billion), with plans to divert almost 30% of the entire budget toward strengthening the country's defense capability and the "special military operation," or war in Ukraine.
Russia's recent successes on the battlefield in Ukraine have prompted some to ask whether Putin might also order another round of partial mobilization after the election or whether he might feel safe to hold fire on a contentious move.
"For now, this appears unlikely as the ongoing recruitment of contract soldiers is proving sufficient to replace Russian losses in Ukraine," Andrius Tursa, Central and Eastern Europe advisor at consultancy Teneo, said in a pre-election note.
Opinion polls show that a majority of Russians do not expect mobilization in the near term, Tursa noted, and "given that the previous round of mobilization proved highly unpopular and triggered considerable public anxiety, Putin will try to avoid this for as long as possible," he added.
Adeline Van Houtte, senior Europe consultant at the Economist Intelligence Unit, said that the U.S. election, expected to be held in November, will be an event that Russia is watching closely.

title: 热点问答｜俄总统选举，普京何以压倒性胜出-新华网
content:
普京当日在论坛上表示，全球经济体系正在发生“根本性的、不可逆转的”变化，俄罗斯希望建立一种所有参与者真正公平竞争的世界经济发展模式。新华社发（亚历山大摄）
 20世纪90年代，成为独立国家的俄罗斯政局跌宕起伏、持续不稳，“休克疗法”导致经济严重衰退，物价飞涨、民生凋敝。普京一度忧心忡忡地认为，俄罗斯面临沦为世界二流国家，甚至三流国家的危险。
 自2000年入主克里姆林宫后，普京大力打击寡头政治，恢复国家对经济命脉的把控。同时，他积极调整经济政策，推动结构性改革，打击影子经济。21世纪初，俄罗斯利用国际油价攀升的时机一步步走出困境，实现经济快速发展。随着经济实力提升，俄罗斯的国际影响力也逐渐提高。
 2014年乌克兰危机爆发，面对西方的制裁威胁，俄罗斯开始长期布局，实施进口替代战略，努力摆脱能源出口依赖，强化金融安全建设，持续推动经济去美元化。俄罗斯经受住了2022年年初西方发起的全面制裁，并从2022年下半年开始取得经济增长。
 俄政治学家奥列格·马特维切夫说，正是在普京的带领下，俄罗斯化解了一个又一个危机。
 莫斯科市民伊琳娜说，她为国家和总统普京感到自豪。正是普京让俄罗斯变成一个不会被随意欺侮的国家。西方总是企图利用经济制裁等各种手段孤立俄罗斯，但他们的阴谋并没有得逞。
 对抗西方打压
 在本次俄总统大选投票开始前不久，瑞典成为北约第32个成员国，北约完成新一轮扩张。与此同时，美西方继续不断对乌克兰危机“拱火浇油”，俄罗斯与西方的地缘政治博弈愈演愈烈。

 3月11日，在位于比利时布鲁塞尔的北约总部，瑞典首相克里斯特松（左）和北约秘书长斯托尔滕贝格出席联合新闻发布会。北约当日在其总部举行瑞典加入北约仪式。瑞典成为北约第32个成员国。新华社记者赵丁喆摄
 普京在不同场合多次表态对北约的挑衅绝不会坐视不管，并强调维护国家领土主权的决心。他的警告言辞直白，凸显俄在国家安全问题上不妥协的底线。
 普京今年发表国情咨文时表示，西方企图让俄罗斯陷入纷争和内乱，但并未得逞。俄罗斯不容许任何人干涉俄内政，任何武装干涉都将遭遇前所未有的惨败。
 俄政治学家谢尔盖·马尔科夫说，民众支持普京是因为在西方打压俄罗斯的形势下，普京是主权独立的象征。人们认识到，普京有能力领导俄罗斯反击美国霸权、维护国家利益。
 俄选民维切斯拉夫说，俄罗斯人视普京为对抗美国霸权的领袖，愿与普京一起反对北约东扩、捍卫国家安全。
translation:
Putin said at the forum that day that the global economic system is undergoing "fundamental and irreversible" changes, and Russia hopes to establish a world economic development model with truly fair competition for all participants. Published by Xinhua News Agency (Photo by Alexander)
 In the 1990s, when Russia became an independent country, the political situation was ups and downs and continued to be unstable. "Shock therapy" led to a severe economic recession, soaring prices, and poor people's livelihood. Putin once worriedly believed that Russia was in danger of becoming a second- or even third-rate country in the world.
 Since taking over the Kremlin in 2000, Putin has vigorously cracked down on the oligarchy and restored the country's control over the economic lifeline. At the same time, he actively adjusted economic policies, promoted structural reforms, and combated the shadow economy. At the beginning of the 21st century, Russia took advantage of the rising international oil prices to step out of its predicament and achieve rapid economic development. As its economic strength increases, Russia's international influence gradually increases.
 When the Ukraine crisis broke out in 2014, facing the threat of Western sanctions, Russia began to make long-term plans, implement an import substitution strategy, strive to get rid of its dependence on energy exports, strengthen financial security construction, and continue to promote economic de-dollarization. Russia withstood the comprehensive sanctions initiated by the West in early 2022 and began to achieve economic growth in the second half of 2022.
 Russian political scientist Oleg Matvechev said that it is under Putin's leadership that Russia has resolved one crisis after another.
 Moscow citizen Irina said she was proud of the country and President Putin. It was Putin who made Russia a country that would not be bullied at will. The West always attempts to use various means such as economic sanctions to isolate Russia, but their plots have not succeeded.
 Fighting Western Suppression
 Shortly before the start of voting in this Russian presidential election, Sweden became the 32nd member of NATO, completing a new round of expansion of NATO. At the same time, the United States and the West continue to "add fuel to the fire" to the Ukraine crisis, and the geopolitical game between Russia and the West is intensifying.

 On March 11, Swedish Prime Minister Kristersson (left) and NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg attended a joint press conference at the NATO headquarters in Brussels, Belgium. NATO held a ceremony for Sweden to join NATO at its headquarters on the same day. Sweden becomes the 32nd member of NATO. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Zhao Dingzhe
 Putin has stated on many occasions on different occasions that he will never sit idly by and ignore NATO's provocations, and emphasized his determination to safeguard the country's territorial sovereignty. His warning was straightforward, highlighting Russia's uncompromising bottom line on national security issues.
 When Putin delivered his State of the Union address this year, he said that the West had failed in its attempts to plunge Russia into strife and civil strife. Russia does not allow anyone to interfere in Russia's internal affairs, and any armed intervention will suffer an unprecedented defeat.
 Russian political scientist Sergei Markov said that people support Putin because Putin is a symbol of sovereignty and independence in the face of Western pressure on Russia. People realize that Putin has the ability to lead Russia to fight back against U.S. hegemony and safeguard national interests.
 Russian voter Vycheslav said that Russians regard Putin as a leader who fights against U.S. hegemony and are willing to work with Putin to oppose NATO's eastward expansion and defend national security.

title: With Russian opposition exiled, Berlin becomes center of anti-Putin protest  - The Washington Post
content:
Closer to the embassy were the counterprotesters: a group of men and women in their 50s and 60s holding the Russian tricolor and a Soviet flag. They began singing the Russian national anthem to drown out the voices from across the road — youthful activists screaming into their microphones that Putin was a “murderer” for continuing his onslaught in Ukraine.
When a silver-haired woman urged a young couple standing behind her in line to join in the singing, they gave her a sour look; when activists confronted Putin supporters over how they could support the president amid such a destructive war, they replied that he was “defending Russia from NATO.”
As people waited for hours in the German capital to cast their ballots Sunday, in an election where Putin faces no real opposition en route to a fifth presidential term, Russia’s vast ideological divisions were on full display. Younger Russians, many of whom fled their homeland shortly after the invasion of Ukraine, were pitted against older generations who were born or grew up in communist East Germany, or moved to the country after the fall of the Soviet Union.
“People don’t actually have real arguments about why Putin is good, they just come out with these boorish accusations that we are too young and we don’t understand anything,” said Diana, 31.
Like others in this report, she spoke on the condition that she be identified only by her first name, fearing that family members in Russia could be targeted by the authorities.
“Putin’s government is conducting an aggressive war, and our entire country has been equated with murderers even though being Russian doesn’t equal Putin and here in this line, we can see at least a thousand examples of that,” Diana said.
In the background, her friends were loudly arguing with another group of older Russians who came to vote for Putin.
“I lived in Russia, I know what oppression and repression are, and now I live in Germany, a great country where we are enjoying our freedoms,” one friend said to a woman in her 60s, who laughed in his face.
When a Washington Post reporter approached the woman to ask why she was voting for Putin, she said she “stands with Russia.”
“Democracy is a dirty word, an empty word for me. I’ve lived a long life, and I know what this ‘democracy’ is,” she said. Her companions then whisked her away and told her not to talk to Western media.
Diana drove several hours from southern Germany to cast her vote. Last year, Germany closed down four of five Russian consulates in response to Moscow’s decision to limit the number of German officials in Russia, leaving the embassy in Berlin and the remaining consulate in Bonn as the only places in Germany where Russian citizens could vote.
Hundreds of voters waited up to six hours in a line that wrapped around the embassy for a whole block and zigzagged along barricaded corridors set up by police.
Many understood that Putin’s win was preordained, yet they said it was important to exercise their right to vote.
“I want to cast my vote so that it is not cast for me, and it’s clear that this often happens in our country,” said Elizaveta, a young student, in reference to widespread reports of voter fraud and ballot stuffing that have plagued previous Russian elections. “I was thrilled to see so many people even though I think it’s safe to say we know who will win.”"
input:
Closer to the embassy were the counterprotesters: a group of men and women in their 50s and 60s holding the Russian tricolor and a Soviet flag. They began singing the Russian national anthem to drown out the voices from across the road — youthful activists screaming into their microphones that Putin was a “murderer” for continuing his onslaught in Ukraine.
When a silver-haired woman urged a young couple standing behind her in line to join in the singing, they gave her a sour look; when activists confronted Putin supporters over how they could support the president amid such a destructive war, they replied that he was “defending Russia from NATO.”
As people waited for hours in the German capital to cast their ballots Sunday, in an election where Putin faces no real opposition en route to a fifth presidential term, Russia’s vast ideological divisions were on full display. Younger Russians, many of whom fled their homeland shortly after the invasion of Ukraine, were pitted against older generations who were born or grew up in communist East Germany, or moved to the country after the fall of the Soviet Union.
“People don’t actually have real arguments about why Putin is good, they just come out with these boorish accusations that we are too young and we don’t understand anything,” said Diana, 31.
Like others in this report, she spoke on the condition that she be identified only by her first name, fearing that family members in Russia could be targeted by the authorities.
“Putin’s government is conducting an aggressive war, and our entire country has been equated with murderers even though being Russian doesn’t equal Putin and here in this line, we can see at least a thousand examples of that,” Diana said.
In the background, her friends were loudly arguing with another group of older Russians who came to vote for Putin.
“I lived in Russia, I know what oppression and repression are, and now I live in Germany, a great country where we are enjoying our freedoms,” one friend said to a woman in her 60s, who laughed in his face.
When a Washington Post reporter approached the woman to ask why she was voting for Putin, she said she “stands with Russia.”
“Democracy is a dirty word, an empty word for me. I’ve lived a long life, and I know what this ‘democracy’ is,” she said. Her companions then whisked her away and told her not to talk to Western media.
Diana drove several hours from southern Germany to cast her vote. Last year, Germany closed down four of five Russian consulates in response to Moscow’s decision to limit the number of German officials in Russia, leaving the embassy in Berlin and the remaining consulate in Bonn as the only places in Germany where Russian citizens could vote.
Hundreds of voters waited up to six hours in a line that wrapped around the embassy for a whole block and zigzagged along barricaded corridors set up by police.
Many understood that Putin’s win was preordained, yet they said it was important to exercise their right to vote.
“I want to cast my vote so that it is not cast for me, and it’s clear that this often happens in our country,” said Elizaveta, a young student, in reference to widespread reports of voter fraud and ballot stuffing that have plagued previous Russian elections. “I was thrilled to see so many people even though I think it’s safe to say we know who will win.”"

title: 西方冷对俄大选结果 普京再提“第三次世界大战” | 德国之声 来自德国 介绍德国 | DW | 18.03.2024
content:
（德国之声中文网）据中国央视报道，3月18日，中国国家主席习近平致电普京，祝贺他当选连任俄罗斯联邦总统。习近平说，普京再次当选，充分体现了俄罗斯人民对他的支持。他强调中国高度重视中俄关系发展，愿同俄罗斯保持密切沟通，推动中俄新时代全面战略协作伙伴关系持续健康稳定深入发展。
据朝中社18日报道，朝鲜领导人金正恩也向普京致电祝贺。向俄罗斯总统连任发出祝贺的还有委内瑞拉总统马杜罗，以及尼加拉瓜和塔吉克斯坦的国家领导人。
根据出口民调，普京获得了近88%的选票。有关结果出炉后，普京在莫斯科举行新闻发布会，感谢俄罗斯民众的支持，并再次对北约发出"世界大战"的威胁。
在被记者问到俄罗斯与北约发生冲突的风险和可能性时，普京回应称"现代世界一切都有可能"。他说："每个人都很清楚，（若北约和俄罗斯发生冲突），距离第三次世界大战只有一步之遥。我想没有人希望看到这种情况。"
普京还表示，莫斯科知道已经有北约的军人被部署在乌克兰。但他没有提供明确的证据，只是说俄军在战场上听见有人讲英语和法语。
西方各国纷纷指责俄罗斯总统选举缺乏自由公正。美国白宫国家安全委员会发言人周日表示，俄罗斯总统普京"监禁其政治对手并阻止其他人与其竞争"，这场总统选举"显然既不自由也不公正。"
德国外交部的X账号发文称，"这场假选举既不自由也不公正，其结果不会让任何人感到意外。"贴文还指出："普京的专制统治建立在审查、镇压与暴力之上，俄罗斯在乌克兰被占领区进行的所谓'选举'是无效的，也再一次违反了国际法。"
德国总统发言人对柏林《每日镜报》证实，联邦总统施泰因迈尔不会致函祝贺普京当选。2018年普京上一次胜选连任的时候，施泰因迈尔曾向他表示祝贺。
法国外交部指出，普京的再次当选是在压制公民社会的背景下发生的，并赞扬了"对其基本政治权力受到侵犯进行和平抗争的众多俄罗斯民众的勇气"。
英国外交大臣卡梅伦周日也批评俄罗斯的选举缺乏"自由和公正"。卡梅伦在X平台发文称，在乌克兰领土举行的"非法"选举，表明俄罗斯对寻找和平之路不感兴趣。
波兰外交部周日在一份声明中表示，"俄罗斯的总统选举不合法、不自由、不公平"，声明称，投票是在"严厉镇压的背景下"在被占领的乌克兰地区进行的，此举违反了国际法。
乌克兰总统泽连斯基称，普京"再次模拟了一场选举"，并认为"为了延续他个人的权力"，普京会不择手段。泽连斯基表示，这位"俄罗斯独裁者"必须被送上海牙国际刑事法庭。
（综合报道）
© 2024年德国之声版权声明：本文所有内容受到著作权法保护，如无德国之声特别授权，不得擅自使用。任何不当行为都将导致追偿，并受到刑事追究。
translation:
(Deutsche Welle Chinese website) According to China Central Television, on March 18, Chinese President Xi Jinping called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of the Russian Federation. Xi Jinping said that Putin's re-election fully demonstrated the Russian people's support for him. He stressed that China attaches great importance to the development of China-Russia relations and is willing to maintain close communication with Russia to promote the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era.
According to the KCNA report on the 18th, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un also sent a congratulatory message to Putin. Also congratulating the Russian President on his re-election were Venezuelan President Maduro, as well as the national leaders of Nicaragua and Tajikistan.
According to exit polls, Putin received nearly 88% of the vote. After the results came out, Putin held a press conference in Moscow to thank the Russian people for their support and once again threatened NATO with a "world war."
When asked by reporters about the risks and possibilities of conflict between Russia and NATO, Putin responded that "everything is possible in the modern world." He said: "Everyone knows that (if there is a conflict between NATO and Russia), it is only one step away from World War III. I don't think anyone wants to see this situation."
Putin also said that Moscow knew that NATO troops were deployed in Ukraine. But he did not provide clear evidence, only saying that the Russian army heard people speaking English and French on the battlefield.
Western countries have accused Russia of lacking free and fair presidential elections. A spokesman for the White House National Security Council said on Sunday that Russian President Vladimir Putin "has imprisoned his political opponents and prevented others from running against him" and that the presidential election was "clearly neither free nor fair."
The German Foreign Ministry’s "The so-called 'elections' conducted by Russia in the occupied territories of Ukraine are invalid and once again violate international law."
A spokesman for the German president confirmed to Berlin's Tagesspiegel that Federal President Steinmeier would not send a letter to congratulate Putin on his election. When Putin was last re-elected in 2018, Steinmeier congratulated him.
The French Foreign Ministry pointed out that Putin's re-election took place against the background of repression of civil society and praised "the courage of the many Russian people who peacefully protested against the violation of their basic political rights."
British Foreign Secretary Cameron also criticized Russia's election on Sunday as lacking "free and fair". Cameron posted on the X platform that the "illegal" election held on Ukrainian soil showed that Russia is not interested in finding a path to peace.
"Russia's presidential election was illegitimate, not free and unfair," Poland's Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Sunday, saying the vote was taking place "in the context of severe repression" in occupied Ukraine. The move violated international law.
Ukrainian President Zelensky said that Putin "has once again simulated an election" and believed that Putin would do whatever it takes "in order to maintain his personal power." Zelensky said the "Russian dictator" must be sent to the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
(comprehensive report)
© 2024 Deutsche Welle Copyright Statement: All contents of this article are protected by copyright law and may not be used without special authorization from Deutsche Welle. Any misconduct will result in recovery of damages and criminal prosecution.
​

title: ЦИК объявил о победе Путина с 87% голосов
content:
МОСКВА, 17 мар (Рейтер) - Действующий президент России Владимир Путин побеждает на выборах главы государства с 87,17% голосов по итогам обработки 80,93% протоколов, свидетельствуют данные Центральной избирательной комиссии.

Явка на выборах составила 74,22% процента.

На втором месте идет кандидат от КПРФ Николай Харитонов с 4,22% голосов, на третьем - Владислав Даванков от «Новых людей» с 4,03%, на четвертом - Леонид Слуцкий от ЛДПР с 3,16%.

Опросы прочили Путину безоговорочную победу на пятых для него выборах.

Находящийся у власти почти четверть века Путин в ближайшие шесть лет обещает снизить уровень бедности, увеличить продолжительность жизни населения, нарастить несырьевой экспорт, повысить производительность труда и обеспечить рост инвестиций.

В марте он оценил свои инициативы на ближайшие шесть лет в 14 триллионов рублей.
translation:
MOSCOW, March 17 (Reuters) - Current Russian President Vladimir Putin wins the presidential election with 87.17% of the votes based on the results of processing 80.93% of the protocols, data from the Central Election Commission shows.

The turnout in the elections was 74.22% percent.

In second place is the candidate from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolai Kharitonov with 4.22% of the votes, in third is Vladislav Davankov from “New People” with 4.03%, in fourth is Leonid Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party with 3.16%.

Polls predicted an unconditional victory for Putin in his fifth election.

In power for almost a quarter of a century, Putin promises in the next six years to reduce poverty, increase life expectancy, increase non-resource exports, increase labor productivity and ensure growth in investment.

In March, he estimated his initiatives for the next six years at 14 trillion rubles.
input:
MOSCOW, March 17 (Reuters) - Current Russian President Vladimir Putin wins the presidential election with 87.17% of the votes based on the results of processing 80.93% of the protocols, data from the Central Election Commission shows.

The turnout in the elections was 74.22% percent.

In second place is the candidate from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolai Kharitonov with 4.22% of the votes, in third is Vladislav Davankov from “New People” with 4.03%, in fourth is Leonid Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party with 3.16%.

Polls predicted an unconditional victory for Putin in his fifth election.

In power for almost a quarter of a century, Putin promises in the next six years to reduce poverty, increase life expectancy, increase non-resource exports, increase labor productivity and ensure growth in investment.

In March, he estimated his initiatives for the next six years at 14 trillion rubles.

title: How Russians are protesting the election
content:
Russian citizens poured dye into ballot boxes, lit explosives and attempted arson in sporadic acts of protest during a presidential election guaranteed to deliver President Vladimir Putin his fifth term in office.
The incidents occurred on the first day of a three-day voting period across Russia and parts of occupied Ukraine on Friday. Officials said the incidents would have no impact on the election, in which Putin is competing against three candidates who have little chance of winning.
With no doubt around the outcome of the election, the focus for both protesters and officials is on turnout and the number of legitimate ballots. High turnout, including votes for a candidate who is running against Putin, is seen as beneficial to the Kremlin as it gives the appearance of legitimacy to the election results.
Two women were arrested after pouring green dye into ballot boxes on the outskirts of Moscow with the aim of destroying voting slips, according to Russian media, in an act of protest that is punishable by imprisonment of up to five years, authorities said.
“These are the methods used by our traitors who fled the country, who are used both in the tail and in the mane by those who fight Russia,” said Ella Pamfilova, chair of Russia’s Election Commission, at an election briefing on Friday in which she described the protesters as “scum.”

title: 俄罗斯总统选举：普京、权力与抗议的可能性 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
普京的支持者还称他为“俄罗斯土地的收集者”，因为他在2008年对前苏联加盟共和国格鲁吉亚发动了战争，并且承认了两个脱离格鲁吉亚的小国，在2014年吞并了克里米亚，还在2022年吞并了乌克兰另外4个地区的部分区域。
今年2月16日，普京最直言不讳的政治对手阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼在北极地区的一座监狱内去世，他的家人、支持者和国际社会的许多人士都称这为“政治谋杀”。
纳瓦尔尼在2018年的总统选举中被拒绝登记，而普京则以近78%的选票获胜。
另外两名反对派人士——伊利亚·雅辛、弗拉基米尔·卡扎-穆尔扎，则因批评普京在乌克兰的战争而分别被判处8年半和25年的监禁。
还有数千人——反对派人士、批评人士以及在网上发表反战评论或者只是点赞或分享评论的普通俄罗斯人——面临着刑事指控。
数万人被逮捕、受到罚款或者被迫离境。
此外，在战争爆发后——尤其是在2022年9月俄罗斯宣布“动员”之后，至少有100万俄罗斯男性逃离该国。
32 岁的网页设计师德米扬逃到了格鲁吉亚，然后又于2022年底逃到了葡萄牙南部，他告诉半岛电视台记者，“我与这场闹剧无关。他们想让我死，他们想让我的儿子成为孤儿。”
当局基本上不会阻止他们的外流。但是他们通过了一项法律，允许因为“批评特别军事行动”而没收他们的财产。“特别军事行动”是克里姆林宫对乌克兰战争的首选委婉说法。
translation:
Putin's supporters also call him the "collector of Russian lands" for launching war against the former Soviet republic of Georgia in 2008, recognizing two smaller states that broke away from Georgia, and annexing Crimea in 2014 , and also annexed parts of four other Ukrainian regions in 2022.
On February 16 this year, Putin's most outspoken political opponent Alexei Navalny died in a prison in the Arctic region. His family, supporters and many people in the international community called this a "political murder" .
Navalny was denied registration in the 2018 presidential election, which Putin won with nearly 78% of the vote.
Two other opposition figures, Ilya Yashin and Vladimir Kaza-Murza, were sentenced to eight and a half years and 25 years in prison respectively for criticizing Putin's war in Ukraine.
Thousands more - opposition figures, critics and ordinary Russians who posted anti-war comments online or simply liked or shared them - face criminal charges.
Tens of thousands have been arrested, fined or forced to leave the country.
In addition, after the outbreak of the war - especially after Russia announced its "mobilization" in September 2022, at least 1 million Russian men fled the country.
Demyan, a 32-year-old web designer who fled to Georgia and then to southern Portugal in late 2022, told Al Jazeera, “I have nothing to do with this farce. They want me dead, they want my son to be orphan."
The authorities have done little to prevent their exodus. But they passed a law allowing their property to be confiscated for "criticism of special military operations." “Special military operations” is the Kremlin’s preferred euphemism for its war in Ukraine.
input:
Putin's supporters also call him the "collector of Russian lands" for launching war against the former Soviet republic of Georgia in 2008, recognizing two smaller states that broke away from Georgia, and annexing Crimea in 2014 , and also annexed parts of four other Ukrainian regions in 2022.
On February 16 this year, Putin's most outspoken political opponent Alexei Navalny died in a prison in the Arctic region. His family, supporters and many people in the international community called this a "political murder" .
Navalny was denied registration in the 2018 presidential election, which Putin won with nearly 78% of the vote.
Two other opposition figures, Ilya Yashin and Vladimir Kaza-Murza, were sentenced to eight and a half years and 25 years in prison respectively for criticizing Putin's war in Ukraine.
Thousands more - opposition figures, critics and ordinary Russians who posted anti-war comments online or simply liked or shared them - face criminal charges.
Tens of thousands have been arrested, fined or forced to leave the country.
In addition, after the outbreak of the war - especially after Russia announced its "mobilization" in September 2022, at least 1 million Russian men fled the country.
Demyan, a 32-year-old web designer who fled to Georgia and then to southern Portugal in late 2022, told Al Jazeera, “I have nothing to do with this farce. They want me dead, they want my son to be orphan."
The authorities have done little to prevent their exodus. But they passed a law allowing their property to be confiscated for "criticism of special military operations." “Special military operations” is the Kremlin’s preferred euphemism for its war in Ukraine.

title: Putin extends rule in preordained Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era
content:
Chinese President Xi Jinping, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan congratulated Putin, as did North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and the presidents of nations that have historic and current ties to Russia, such as Azerbaijan and Belarus.
Navalny's associates urged those unhappy with Putin or the war to go to the polls at noon Sunday — and lines outside a number of polling stations both inside Russia and at its embassies around the world appeared to swell at that time.
Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, who spent more than five hours in the line at the Russian Embassy in Berlin, told reporters that she wrote her late husband’s name on her ballot.
Asked whether she had a message for Putin, Navalnaya replied: “Please stop asking for messages from me or from somebody for Mr. Putin. There could be no negotiations and nothing with Mr. Putin, because he’s a killer, he’s a gangster.”
Putin referenced Navalny by name for the first time in years at the news conference, declaring that he had been ready to release him in a swap for unidentified inmates in Western custody just days before the opposition leader’s death.
Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, disputed those claims. He told reporters during a White House briefing Monday that U.S. officials had spoken to Russia for “months and years” about releasing American detainees but “have not heard a Russian official raise Navalny as part of a prisoner swap in any of these conversations."
Supporters of Navalny streamed to his grave in Moscow, some bringing ballots with his name written on them.
The Russian leader brushed off the effectiveness of the apparent protest and rejected Western criticism of the vote. Instead, he tried to turn the tables on the West, charging that the four criminal cases against former President Donald Trump were a use of the judiciary for political aims.
“The whole world is laughing at it,” he said.
Some people told the AP that they were happy to vote for Putin — unsurprising in a country where state TV airs a drumbeat of praise for the Russian leader and voicing any other opinion is risky.
Dmitry Sergienko, who cast his ballot in Moscow, said, “I am happy with everything and want everything to continue as it is now.”
Voting took place over three days at polling stations across the vast country, in illegally annexed regions of Ukraine and online.
Several people were arrested, including in Moscow and St. Petersburg, after they tried to start fires or set off explosives at polling stations while a few others were detained for throwing green antiseptic or ink into ballot boxes. Many more were rounded up by police for attempting to protest.
The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that about 90 people were arrested in 22 cities across Russia on Sunday.
Stanislav Andreychuk, co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said Russians were searched when entering polling stations, there were attempts to check filled-out ballots before they were cast, and one report said police demanded a ballot box be opened to remove a ballot.
Huge lines formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin's invasion of Ukraine.
