This protest couldn’t have had any direct implications for the Kremlin and the election’s outcome, but it did show that such “silent resistance” — both inside the country and abroad — will continue, said Andrei Kolesnikov, senior fellow at the Carnegie Russia Eurasia Center.
“The message to political manipulators has been sent: ‘We are here, this is what we are like, we’re not giving up, we’re prepared to be creative in using unexpected windows (of opportunity to protest),’” Kolesnikov said.
In a post-election news conference, Putin looked relaxed, Gallyamov noted, probably realizing that “he has secured his future for at least six years ahead.” 
Demonstrating his confidence, Putin even referenced Navalny by name -– something he had made a point of not doing in public in years -– and revealed that days before his foe’s death, he supported the idea of releasing him from prison in a prisoner exchange.

title: 普京：俄中关系将继续深化发展_新闻频道_央视网(cctv.com)
content:
俄罗斯总统普京18日表示，俄中关系将继续深化发展，取得新成就，并造福两国人民。

 　3月18日，普京在俄罗斯首都莫斯科的竞选总部回答记者提问。新华社记者曹阳摄
　　当地时间18日凌晨，普京在竞选总部发表讲话，感谢选民支持。他在接受新华社记者提问时表示，俄中关系经过多年发展，非常稳定，具有很强互补性。
　　普京指出，俄中两国在经济、外交等领域有诸多契合点。就亚欧地区发展而言，俄中关系是一个重要稳定因素，中方提出的共建“一带一路”倡议非常重要。

 3月18日，在俄罗斯首都莫斯科，新华社记者向俄总统普京提问。新华社记者曹阳摄
　　普京积极评价中国的发展成就。他认为，中国正在非常自信地实现飞速发展，并向创新型经济转型；中国在国际舞台上日益活跃并取得巨大成功，在世界各地拥有许多朋友。
　　普京强调，台湾是中国不可分割的一部分；那些在台湾周围进行挑衅并采取种种措施迟滞中国发展的企图，无疑会彻底失败。
　　据俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间18日凌晨公布的数据，在此次总统选举已统计完成的85％选票中，普京以87.19％的得票率大幅领先其他候选人，实际已经赢得总统选举。
　　俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。根据俄总统选举规则，获得50％以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举的最终结果，并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin stated on the 18th that Russia-China relations will continue to deepen and develop, achieve new achievements, and benefit the people of both countries.

 On March 18, Putin answered questions from reporters at the campaign headquarters in Moscow, the Russian capital. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
In the early morning of the 18th local time, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters, thanking voters for their support. When accepting questions from Xinhua News Agency reporters, he said that after years of development, Russia-China relations are very stable and highly complementary.
Putin pointed out that Russia and China have many points of convergence in economic, diplomatic and other fields. As far as the development of the Eurasian region is concerned, Russia-China relations are an important stabilizing factor, and the joint construction of the "Belt and Road" initiative proposed by China is very important.

 On March 18, in Moscow, the capital of Russia, a Xinhua News Agency reporter asked Russian President Vladimir Putin a question. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
Putin spoke positively of China’s development achievements. He believes that China is achieving rapid development with great confidence and transforming into an innovative economy; China is increasingly active on the international stage and has achieved great success, and has many friends around the world.
Putin emphasized that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China; those attempts to provoke provocations around Taiwan and take various measures to retard China's development will undoubtedly fail completely.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time, of the 85% of votes that have been counted in this presidential election, Putin is significantly ahead of other candidates with 87.19% of the votes, and has actually won the presidential election.
The official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the final results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.

title: 路透社：普京新任期将首访北京 — 普通话主页
content:
有消息透露，在俄罗斯总统大选中再次“当选”的普京将在5月份上任后，首先访问北京。普京近日还对外表示，俄罗斯和中国拥有相似的全球观，未来几年莫斯科与北京的关系将进一步发展。但普京的获胜却被西方国家批评为不民主的选举。
普京即将访华的消息，由路透社本周二引述五位不具名人士披露。报道还强调，这可能是普京新任期内的首次出国访问。
但目前，有关普京访华的具体行程外界还无法得知。克里姆林宫告诉路透社，具体时间将稍后公布。
普京超越斯大林
普京再次“当选”，外界并不惊讶。根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会的数据，普京在大选中获得了约 87% 的选票，这也是他在历届俄罗斯总统选举中得票率最高的一次。
半岛电视台在报道中指出，这一结果也意味着71岁的普京将超越前苏共领导人斯大林，成为俄罗斯200多年来任职时间最长的领导人。
西方社会也对此次俄罗斯选举普遍表达了批评。美国白宫安全委员会发言人周一表示，鉴于普京监禁政治对手并阻止他人与其竞争，这次选举显然不自由也不公平。
美国国务院也在周二发出声明强调，克里姆林宫在乌克兰暂时占领的地区进行了虚假的总统选举，这实际上是一次宣传活动，旨在加强俄罗斯对其非法占领乌克兰部分地区的不合法主张。
英国外交大臣戴维·卡梅伦则在社交媒体X上发帖表示，这次俄罗斯大选投票“不是自由公平选举的样子”。
但中国、朝鲜、伊朗和印度等国的领导人向普京表示了祝贺。中国领导人习近平在贺电中说，普京再次当选，充分体现了俄罗斯人民对他的支持。他还说，中方高度重视中俄关系发展，愿同俄方保持密切沟通，推动中俄新时代全面战略协作伙伴关系持续健康稳定深入发展。
普习相似的世界观
普京对俄中关系的定位，似乎与习近平高度一致。据路透社报道，在选举结束当天的周日（3月17日），普京对媒体表示，俄罗斯和中国拥有相似的全球观，并享有坚固的关系，部分原因是他与习近平的良好个人关系，莫斯科和北京将在未来几年进一步发展关系。


报道指出，普京和习近平拥有相似的世界观，他们都认为西方正在衰落；而中国也正在科技、间谍活动和硬实力等各个领域挑战着美国的霸权。
与普京相似的是，习近平在去年全国人大上打破惯例，开启了他的第三届国家主席的任期。外界普遍估计，习近平有可能持续连任。而普京本次“当选”也是在俄罗斯的新宪法框架下的举动。中国媒体财新网在报道中指出，这次大选为普京在2030年再次谋求连任铺平了道路。
值得注意的是，习近平在去年3月获得连任之后，也把首次出访的目的地定在了莫斯科。
多种迹象表明，中俄双边的贸易关系还在继续发展。据中国海关的数据，2023年，中俄货物及服务双边贸易额为2401亿美元，比2022年同比增长了26.3%。该数额超过了两国设定的双边贸易在2024年超过2000亿美元的年目标。
上个月，在中国农历新年前夕，习近平与普京通话时特别强调，双方要密切战略协作，捍卫各自国家主权、安全、发展利益，坚决反对外部势力干涉内政。路透社在报道中指出，这是在暗指美国。
在俄乌战争的问题上，中国则一直表态模糊。今年1月，瑞士提出举办乌克兰和会，但不打算邀请俄罗斯参加。克里姆林宫对此表示，这一会议毫无意义，也注定会失败。截至目前，中方也对此没有作出明确回应。
中国驻瑞士大使王世廷周一（3月18日）对《新苏黎世报》(Neue Zürcher Zeitung)表示：中方正在密切关注瑞士即将主办的乌克兰会议，并正在研究参会的可能性。但中国外交部发言人林剑周二（3月19日）在记者会上又表示，中方支持适时召开俄乌双方认可、各方平等参与、对所有和平方案公正讨论的国际和会。
translation:
It is reported that Putin, who was re-elected in the Russian presidential election, will first visit Beijing after taking office in May. Putin also recently stated that Russia and China share similar global views and that the relationship between Moscow and Beijing will further develop in the next few years. But Putin's victory was criticized by Western countries as an undemocratic election.
News of Putin's upcoming visit to China was disclosed by Reuters on Tuesday, citing five unnamed people. The report also emphasized that this may be Putin's first overseas visit in his new term.
However, at present, the specific itinerary of Putin's visit to China is not known to the outside world. The Kremlin told Reuters the exact time would be announced later.
Putin surpasses Stalin
The outside world was not surprised that Putin was "elected" again. Putin received about 87% of the vote in the election, his highest share of the vote in any Russian presidential election, according to Russia's Central Election Commission.
Al Jazeera pointed out in the report that this result also means that the 71-year-old Putin will surpass the former leader of the Soviet Communist Party Stalin and become the longest-serving leader of Russia in more than 200 years.
Western society has also generally expressed criticism of this Russian election. A spokesman for the White House Security Council said on Monday that the election was clearly neither free nor fair given that Putin imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from competing against him.
The U.S. State Department also issued a statement on Tuesday stressing that the Kremlin conducted a sham presidential election in areas temporarily occupied by Ukraine, which was actually a propaganda campaign designed to strengthen Russia's illegitimate claims that it illegally occupied parts of Ukraine.
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron posted on social media X that the Russian election vote "is not a free and fair election."
But leaders from China, North Korea, Iran and India, among others, congratulated Putin. Chinese leader Xi Jinping said in his congratulatory message that Putin's re-election fully demonstrated the Russian people's support for him. He also said that China attaches great importance to the development of China-Russia relations and is willing to maintain close communication with Russia to promote the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era.
A similar worldview
Putin’s positioning on Russia-China relations seems to be highly consistent with Xi Jinping’s. According to Reuters, on Sunday (March 17), the day after the election, Putin told the media that Russia and China share a similar global outlook and enjoy a strong relationship, partly due to his good personal relationship with Xi Jinping, Moscow and Beijing will further develop relations in the coming years.


The report pointed out that Putin and Xi Jinping have similar world views. They both believe that the West is declining; and China is also challenging the hegemony of the United States in various fields such as technology, espionage and hard power.
Similar to Putin, Xi Jinping broke with convention at last year's National People's Congress and began his third term as president. It is generally estimated by the outside world that Xi Jinping is likely to be re-elected. Putin's "election" this time is also within the framework of Russia's new constitution. Chinese media Caixin pointed out in a report that this election paves the way for Putin to seek re-election in 2030.
It is worth noting that after Xi Jinping was re-elected in March last year, he also set the destination of his first overseas visit in Moscow.
There are various signs that the bilateral trade relations between China and Russia continue to develop. According to data from China Customs, the bilateral trade volume of goods and services between China and Russia in 2023 will be US$240.1 billion, a year-on-year increase of 26.3% from 2022. The amount exceeds the annual target set by the two countries for bilateral trade to exceed US$200 billion by 2024.
Last month, on the eve of the Chinese Lunar New Year, Xi Jinping specifically emphasized during a phone call with Putin that the two sides should intensify strategic coordination, defend their respective national sovereignty, security, and development interests, and resolutely oppose external forces interfering in internal affairs. Reuters pointed out in the report that this was an allusion to the United States.
On the issue of the Russia-Ukraine war, China has always taken a vague stance. In January this year, Switzerland proposed hosting a peace conference in Ukraine, but did not intend to invite Russia to participate. The Kremlin said the meeting was meaningless and destined to fail. So far, China has not made a clear response to this.
Wang Shiting, Chinese Ambassador to Switzerland, told the Neue Zürcher Zeitung on Monday (March 18): China is paying close attention to the Ukraine conference that Switzerland will host and is studying the possibility of participating. However, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian stated at a press conference on Tuesday (March 19) that China supports the timely convening of an international peace conference recognized by Russia and Ukraine, with equal participation by all parties, and fair discussion of all peace plans.

title: Президентские выборы в России: «Давайте не будем признавать легитимность Путина как президента», – заявил председатель ПАСЕ
content:
После президентских выборов в России председатель ПАСЕ Теодорос Русопулос сделал сегодня следующее заявление:

«Несколько минут назад избирательные участки, организованные для так называемых "выборов" в Российской Федерации, закрылись, и были объявлены данные экзитполов. Результаты не вызвали особого удивления. На самом деле, мы все уже не один месяц знали об этотом результате. Владимир Путин подтвердил еще один срок полномочий.

Эти выборы не считаются легитимными. Не было ни настоящих альтернативных кандидатов, ни свободных СМИ, ни заслуживающих доверия наблюдателей. Гражданское общество принуждают к молчанию. И самое главное, эти выборы также проводились на незаконно оккупированной и аннексированной территории Украины. Вся политическая оппозиция жестоко подавлена, а все критики режима либо заключены в тюрьму, либо изгнаны из страны. К глубочайшему сожалению, самый слышимый и популярный лидер оппозиции Алексей Навальный был убит в тюрьме месяц назад после того, как в течение нескольких месяцев подвергался пыткам и бесчеловечному обращению.

В таких обстоятельствах не может быть свободных и честных выборов. Г-н Путин явно не имеет никакой демократической легитимности.

Это было подтверждено Венецианской комиссией Совета Европы, которая установила, что процедура предоставления Путину еще большего срока полномочий нарушает российское конституционное право и противоречит давно устоявшимся международным правовым принципам.
translation:
Following the presidential elections in Russia, PACE President Theodoros Roussopoulos made the following statement today:

“A few minutes ago, the polling stations organized for the so-called “elections” in the Russian Federation closed and the exit polls were announced. The results were not particularly surprising. In fact, we have all known about this result for months. Vladimir Putin confirmed another term of office.

These elections are not considered legitimate. There were no real alternative candidates, no free media, no credible observers. Civil society is forced into silence. And most importantly, these elections were also held on the illegally occupied and annexed territory of Ukraine. All political opposition is brutally suppressed, and all critics of the regime are either imprisoned or expelled from the country. Tragically, the most vocal and popular leader of the opposition, Alexei Navalny, was killed in prison a month ago after being subjected to months of torture and inhumane treatment.

In such circumstances there can be no free and fair elections. Mr. Putin clearly has no democratic legitimacy.

This was confirmed by the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe, which found that the procedure for granting Putin an even longer term of office violates Russian constitutional law and is contrary to long-established international legal principles.
input:
Following the presidential elections in Russia, PACE President Theodoros Roussopoulos made the following statement today:

“A few minutes ago, the polling stations organized for the so-called “elections” in the Russian Federation closed and the exit polls were announced. The results were not particularly surprising. In fact, we have all known about this result for months. Vladimir Putin confirmed another term of office.

These elections are not considered legitimate. There were no real alternative candidates, no free media, no credible observers. Civil society is forced into silence. And most importantly, these elections were also held on the illegally occupied and annexed territory of Ukraine. All political opposition is brutally suppressed, and all critics of the regime are either imprisoned or expelled from the country. Tragically, the most vocal and popular leader of the opposition, Alexei Navalny, was killed in prison a month ago after being subjected to months of torture and inhumane treatment.

In such circumstances there can be no free and fair elections. Mr. Putin clearly has no democratic legitimacy.

This was confirmed by the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe, which found that the procedure for granting Putin an even longer term of office violates Russian constitutional law and is contrary to long-established international legal principles.

title: 普京胜选！最新讲话回应这些问题
content:
据新华社报道,俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间18日凌晨发布的数据显示,在俄总统选举统计完成的85%选票中,现任总统普京以87.19%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人,实际已经赢得此次总统选举。
俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。根据俄总统选举规则,在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举结果,并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
公开信息显示,现年71岁的普京作为俄现任总统的任期将于2024年5月7日结束。根据俄罗斯宪法,普京可以在此次任期结束后寻求连任两届至2036年。

胜选
据新华社报道,普京18日凌晨在竞选总部发表讲话,感谢所有选民的支持。他表示俄罗斯是一个大家庭,本次选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望,国家的所有任务都将完成。俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展,变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。
在讲话中,普京也提及了未来的挑战。他首先感谢身处冲突前线的战士,表示目前俄罗斯的首要任务肯定是完成特别军事行动。他称,俄军已掌握战争主导权,如果西方军队出现在乌克兰,就可能会将世界推向第三次世界大战的边缘。普京还强调,只要国家团结,没有人可以压制俄罗斯。
另外,普京也谈到俄罗斯与中国的关系,表示中俄关系是稳定因素,中国在全球舞台上非常成功,他确信未来几年两国关系将会更加牢固。
相较于此前的选举,此次大选拥有多个“首次”的纪录,比如首次采用多日持续投票,首次采用实地投票和远程电子投票相结合的方式进行。同时在此次选举期间,民意调查也多天开放。
除了普京以外,此次选举还有3位候选人。最新结果显示,俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫以4.24%的得票率位居第二,俄新人党的达万科夫得票率为3.99%名列第三,俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基以3.16%的得票率位列第四。
值得注意的是,根据目前不完全的统计结果,普京的得票率已远远超过2018年大选结果。当时,普京的得票率为76.69%。

未来六年还有这些挑战
普京还表示,将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。他说,国家发展的所有主要任务都已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述,将竭尽所能完成既定目标。
在选前的年度国情咨文演说中,普京详细勾勒了未来六年俄罗斯在政治经济领域的目标。比如,在未来六年内,俄罗斯非资源和非能源出口应该增加三分之二；到2030年,俄罗斯进口占GDP的比重应下降至17%；俄罗斯国产高新技术产品在国内市场的份额应提高1.5倍。同时,普京也提到俄罗斯要大力发展AI。
对于这份国情咨文,中国社会科学院俄罗斯东欧中亚研究所研究员张弘告诉第一财经记者:“普京通过介绍内政和外交的未来规划,给俄选民传递信心,勾勒俄社会的整体规划。”
俄联邦国家统计局日前公布的最新数据显示,2023年俄经济同比增速为3.6%,规模达171.04万亿卢布；俄罗斯民众实际工资同比增长7.8%；实际可支配收入同比增长5.4%。后两者为近5年来最高。此外,俄去年失业率为3.2%,为1992年以来最低水平。
展望未来,兰州大学政治与国际关系学院副教授韦进深认为,对于未来六年,俄罗斯面临的主要挑战不少,比如如何应对因俄乌冲突而恶化的国际和地区环境,从而为俄罗斯的发展创造较为有利的空间；同时俄罗斯政府还需要考虑,如何推动国内经济结构的优化和调整,以应对因制裁而受到冲击的国内经济,将目前的战时经济转变为常态经济。
此外,采取什么样的措施进行社会动员,加强俄罗斯国内社会的团结,也是未来普京新政府的重任之一。
translation:
According to Xinhua News Agency, data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time showed that among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and actually won the election. presidential election.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed.
Public information shows that the 71-year-old Putin’s term as the current president of Russia will end on May 7, 2024. According to the Russian constitution, Putin can seek re-election for two terms until 2036 after the end of this term.

Win the election
According to Xinhua News Agency, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
In his speech, Putin also mentioned the challenges ahead. He first thanked the soldiers on the front lines of the conflict and said that Russia's current priority must be to complete special military operations. He said that the Russian army has taken the lead in the war, and if Western troops appear in Ukraine, it may push the world to the brink of World War III. Putin also emphasized that as long as the country is united, no one can suppress Russia.
In addition, Putin also talked about the relationship between Russia and China, saying that Sino-Russian relations are a stabilizing factor and that China is very successful on the global stage. He is convinced that the relationship between the two countries will be stronger in the next few years.
Compared with previous elections, this election has a number of "firsts" records, such as the first multi-day continuous voting and the first combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting. At the same time, during this election, opinion polls will also be open on multiple days.
In addition to Putin, there are three candidates in this election. The latest results show that Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.24% of the vote, Davankov of the Russian New People's Party ranked third with 3.99% of the vote, and Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked third. Ranked fourth with 3.16% of the vote.
It is worth noting that according to the current incomplete statistical results, Putin's vote share has far exceeded the results of the 2018 general election. At that time, Putin's vote rate was 76.69%.

There are still these challenges in the next six years
Putin also said that he will continue to promote national development in the new term. He said that all the main tasks of national development have been elaborated in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of parliament, and he will do his best to achieve the set goals.
In his annual State of the Union address before the election, Putin outlined in detail Russia's political and economic goals for the next six years. For example, in the next six years, Russia's non-resource and non-energy exports should increase by two-thirds; by 2030, Russia's imports as a share of GDP should drop to 17%; and the share of Russian domestic high-tech products in the domestic market should increase by 1.5 times. At the same time, Putin also mentioned that Russia should vigorously develop AI.
Regarding this State of the Union address, Zhang Hong, a researcher at the Institute of Russian, Eastern European and Central Asian Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, told China Business News: "By introducing future plans for domestic and foreign affairs, Putin conveys confidence to Russian voters and outlines the overall plan for Russian society."
The latest data released by the Russian Federal State Statistics Service show that the Russian economy will grow by 3.6% year-on-year in 2023, reaching 171.04 trillion rubles; the real wages of Russian people will increase by 7.8% year-on-year; the real disposable income will increase by 5.4% year-on-year. The latter two are the highest in the past five years. In addition, Russia's unemployment rate was 3.2% last year, the lowest level since 1992.
Looking to the future, Wei Jinshen, associate professor at the School of Politics and International Relations at Lanzhou University, believes that Russia will face many major challenges in the next six years, such as how to deal with the international and regional environment worsened by the Russia-Ukraine conflict, thereby creating a better environment for Russia's development. Favorable space; at the same time, the Russian government also needs to consider how to promote the optimization and adjustment of the domestic economic structure to cope with the impact of sanctions on the domestic economy and transform the current wartime economy into a normal economy.
In addition, what measures to take for social mobilization and strengthening the unity of Russian domestic society are also one of the important tasks of Putin's new government in the future.

title: 中俄独裁者互祝连任 “友谊”会突变吗？ | 普京 | 习近平 | 俄罗斯 | 大纪元
content:
“现在全世界在进行一波转型，比如在经济上要求具有人权、绿色的供应链，很多国家都以国家安全的理由开始对中国的东西保持警惕。大家都在强调对中（共）国要去风险，我想对俄罗斯也是。”
尽管中俄高调宣扬其战略伙伴关系，但俄罗斯近日再高调纪念涉中俄边境冲突的“达曼斯基岛”保卫战胜利55周年。
俄罗斯纪念的“达曼斯基岛”保卫战，在中国被称为“珍宝岛自卫反击战”或珍宝岛事件。
珍宝岛是中俄界河乌苏里江主航道中心线的中国一侧小岛，二战结束后，一度被苏联占领。1969年3月间，中苏在边境珍宝岛上发生三次武装流血冲突，双方死伤惨重。冲突后，中方实际控制了珍宝岛。珍宝岛事件致使当时的中苏彻底翻脸。
俄罗斯纪念的“达曼斯基岛”保卫战，是在大陆微博、抖音以及微信群内热议的一个话题，但中共官方沉默。
翁明贤表示，中共对俄罗斯的纪念议题保持沉默，因为中共认为最大的威胁来源在于中印边界，还有在南海领土上跟东盟的越南、菲律宾的争议，再加上美国在南海的公海自由航行，这些是重点，所以中共要稳住北方。
赖荣伟表示，中共和俄罗斯现在的矛盾不是主要的矛盾，但也暗藏冲突因素。
他举例说，在俄乌战争问题上，中共实际上在经济上、政治上帮助俄罗斯，但是在表面上要维持假中立，因为它也知道，如果太挺俄罗斯的话，在国际社会的正当性就很糟糕。但中共这种假中立的做法，也让俄方不高兴，“难道俄罗斯的普京、俄罗斯的政治人物看不出来吗？”
英国《金融时报》本月初报导一份泄漏的俄军机密文件，文件揭示了俄军应对中共入侵的演习场景，并描述了何时用核武对抗中共。
国家安全威胁专家克雷格‧胡珀在《福布斯》上撰文说，泄漏文件表明，俄罗斯敏锐地意识到边境“友谊”可能会迅速改变。
translation:
"Now the world is undergoing a wave of transformation, such as requiring human rights and green supply chains in the economy. Many countries have begun to be wary of Chinese products on the grounds of national security. Everyone is emphasizing the need to protect China. De-risking, I think for Russia too.”
Although China and Russia have high-profilely promoted their strategic partnership, Russia recently commemorated the 55th anniversary of the victory of the "Damansky Island" defense battle involving the border conflict between China and Russia in a high-profile manner.
The "Damansky Island" defense battle commemorated by Russia is called the "Zhenbao Island Self-Defense Counterattack" or the Zhenbao Island Incident in China.
Zhenbao Island is a small island on the Chinese side of the center line of the main channel of the Ussuri River, the Sino-Russian boundary river. After the end of World War II, it was once occupied by the Soviet Union. In March 1969, three bloody armed conflicts broke out between China and the Soviet Union on Zhenbao Island on the border, resulting in heavy casualties on both sides. After the conflict, China actually took control of Zhenbao Island. The Zhenbao Island incident caused a complete fallout between China and the Soviet Union at that time.
The "Damansky Island" defense battle commemorated by Russia is a hotly discussed topic in mainland China's Weibo, Douyin and WeChat groups, but the Chinese Communist Party is officially silent.
Weng Mingxian said that the CCP has remained silent on Russia’s commemorative issues because the CCP believes that the biggest source of threats lies in the Sino-Indian border, as well as the territorial disputes with ASEAN’s Vietnam and the Philippines in the South China Sea, coupled with the United States’ freedom of navigation on the high seas in the South China Sea. These are the key points, so the CCP must stabilize the north.
Lai Rongwei said that the current contradiction between the CCP and Russia is not the main contradiction, but there are also hidden conflict factors.
He gave an example: On the issue of the Russia-Ukraine war, the CCP actually helped Russia economically and politically, but on the surface it maintained false neutrality because it also knew that if it supported Russia too much, its legitimacy in the international community would be compromised. very bad. But the CCP’s false neutrality also makes Russia unhappy. “Can’t Russia’s Putin and Russian politicians see this?”
Earlier this month, the British Financial Times reported on a leaked confidential Russian military document, which revealed Russian military drill scenarios in response to an invasion by the Chinese Communist Party and described when to use nuclear weapons against the Chinese Communist Party.
National security threat expert Craig Hooper wrote in Forbes that the leaked documents show that Russia is acutely aware that border "friendships" can change quickly.

Many countries have begun to be wary of Chinese products on the grounds of national security. Everyone is emphasizing the need to protect China. De-risking, I think for Russia too.”

After the end of World War II, it was once occupied by the Soviet Union. In March 1969, three bloody armed conflicts broke out between China and the Soviet Union on Zhenbao Island on the border, resulting in heavy casualties on both sides. After the conflict, China actually took control of Zhenbao Island. The Zhenbao Island incident caused a complete fallout between China and the Soviet Union at that time.
The "Damansky Island" defense battle commemorated by Russia is a hotly discussed topic in mainland China's Weibo, Douyin and WeChat groups, but the Chinese Communist Party is officially silent.
Weng Mingxian said that the CCP has remained silent on Russia’s commemorative issues because the CCP believes that the biggest source of threats lies in the Sino-Indian border, as well as the territorial disputes with ASEAN’s Vietnam and the Philippines in the South China Sea, coupled with the United States’ freedom of navigation on the high seas in the South China Sea. These are the key points, so the CCP must stabilize the north.
Lai Rongwei said that the current contradiction between the CCP and Russia is not the main contradiction, but there are also hidden conflict factors.

title: Результаты выборов президента России–2024. Главные цифры
content:
ЦИК России подвел итоги выборов президента. Число отданных за Владимира Путина голосов по стране немного не доходит до 90%, а в некоторых регионах превысило эту отметку. Также зафиксирована беспрецедентная явка. Основные цифры, тенденции, рекорды — в материале «Ъ».

Рекордная явка
По заявлению главы ЦИК РФ Эллы Памфиловой, явка на выборах президента РФ в 2024 году стала рекордной в новейшей истории России. Она составила 77,49% (87,6 млн избирателей). До этого 70-процентная отметка была превышена лишь однажды — в 1991 году.

Явка на зарубежных участках также была значительной. По неокончательным данным, оглашенным МИД РФ, проголосовали не менее 372 тыс. человек. На прошлых выборах за границей проголосовали 474 тыс. россиян, но и участков тогда было значительно больше — 401 против 295.

Топ российских регионов по явке возглавляет Чечня, самый низкий показатель — в Республике Коми.

Итоговая явка на федеральной платформе ДЭГ — 94%. Этим способом голосования воспользовались 4,4 млн человек в 28 регионах. В Москве, которая использует свою платформу, проголосовали онлайн почти 3,7 млн человек, или половина всех избирателей.

Явка среди военнослужащих ВС РФ составила 99,8%. 100%-ную явку продемонстрировали полярники на всех станциях и научно-экспедиционных судах в Арктике и Антарктике. В московских СИЗО проголосовали почти 100%, все, кто изъявил желание. Всего в системе ФСИН реализовали свое право 77 тыс. содержащихся под стражей и около 40 тыс., имеющих ограничения и запреты, препятствующие посещению избирательных участков.

Выдающиеся результаты
После обработки 100% протоколов Владимир Путин набрал 87,28% (76,3 млн голосов). Он улучшил свой последний результат более чем на 10 п.п., или 19,9 млн голосов.

Чечня вернулась на первую строчку в топе регионов, оказавших наибольшую поддержку действующему президенту. Лидер 2018 года Кабардино-Балкария — на пятом месте. Кроме того, в первой десятке — Крым, Севастополь и три из четырех новых субъектов. В четвертом, Херсонской области, Владимир Путин также получил внушительные 88,12%, однако у всех участников топ-10 его результат ушел за 90%, а в Чечне вообще приблизился к 100% (98,99%).
translation:
The Russian Central Election Commission summed up the results of the presidential election. The number of votes cast for Vladimir Putin in the country does not reach 90%, and in some regions it has exceeded this mark. An unprecedented turnout was also recorded. The main figures, trends, records are in the Kommersant material.

Record turnout
According to the head of the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation, Ella Pamfilova, the turnout in the presidential elections of the Russian Federation in 2024 was a record in the modern history of Russia. It amounted to 77.49% (87.6 million voters). Before this, the 70 percent mark was exceeded only once - in 1991.

The turnout at overseas sites was also significant. According to inconclusive data announced by the Russian Foreign Ministry, at least 372 thousand people voted. In the last elections, 474 thousand Russians voted abroad, but there were significantly more polling stations then - 401 versus 295.

The top Russian regions in terms of turnout are headed by Chechnya, the lowest figure is in the Komi Republic.

The final turnout on the federal DEG platform is 94%. This voting method was used by 4.4 million people in 28 regions. In Moscow, which uses its platform, almost 3.7 million people, or half of all voters, voted online.

The turnout among military personnel of the Russian Armed Forces was 99.8%. Polar explorers demonstrated 100% turnout at all stations and scientific expedition vessels in the Arctic and Antarctic. In Moscow pre-trial detention centers, almost 100% voted, everyone who expressed a desire. In total, 77 thousand people in custody and about 40 thousand people who have restrictions and prohibitions that prevent them from visiting polling stations exercised their rights in the FSIN system.

Outstanding results
After processing 100% of the protocols, Vladimir Putin scored 87.28% (76.3 million votes). He improved his last result by more than 10 percentage points, or 19.9 million votes.

Chechnya returned to first place in the top regions that provided the greatest support to the current president. The leader of 2018, Kabardino-Balkaria, is in fifth place. In addition, the top ten includes Crimea, Sevastopol and three out of four new regions. In the fourth, Kherson region, Vladimir Putin also received an impressive 88.12%, but for all participants in the top 10 his result was over 90%, and in Chechnya it was generally close to 100% (98.99%).

title: Putin claims victory in election with no serious competition – DW – 03/17/2024
content:
Supporters of Putin's most prominent opponent Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month, had called on the public to come out at a "Noon against Putin" protest to show their anger at Putin's crackdown.
News agencies reported an increase in younger voters at noon at polling stations in Moscow, St Petersburg and Yekaterinburg, with queues of several hundred people and even thousands.
At least 80 people were arrested for protesting on Sunday across Russia, according to OVD-Info, a group that monitors crackdowns on dissent.
Navalny's widow, Yulia, appeared at the Russian embassy in Berlin to cheers and chants of "Yulia, Yulia." 
She said she had written her late husband's name on her ballot.
Meanwhile, President Putin said he had agreed to a prisoner swap involving Navalny prior to his death, adding it is "sad" when someone dies.
Putin said the main condition for the exchange was that the opposition figure would not return to Russia.
Navalny was Putin's fiercest domestic opponent. His allies and Yulia accuse Putin of having him murdered, something the Kremlin denies.
A concert on Moscow's Red Square is being staged on Monday to mark 10 years since Russia's annexation of Ukraine's Crimea peninsula — an event that is also expected to serve as a victory celebration for Putin.
Putin also said a conflict with NATO cannot be ruled out at a press conference in Moscow to mark his victory.
"Everything is possible in the modern world," the Russian president said when questioned about the possibility of such an event, warning such a conflict "will be one step away from a full-scale World War Three."
"I think hardly anyone is interested in this," he said.
Last month, French President Emmanuel Macron said he could not rule out deploying ground troops in Ukraine in the future.
While many Western nations distanced themselves from Macron's views, some in Eastern Europe expressed support.
Putin in his press conference said Moscow knows that NATO soldiers are already deployed in Ukraine. The Russian leader did not provide any proofs for his assertions.
He also thankedRussian troops fighting in Ukraine saying, "No matter who or how much they want to intimidate us… It has not worked now and will not work in the future. Never."

At least 80 people were arrested for protesting on Sunday across Russia, according to OVD-Info, a group that monitors crackdowns on dissent.
Navalny's widow, Yulia, appeared at the Russian embassy in Berlin to cheers and chants of "Yulia, Yulia." 
She said she had written her late husband's name on her ballot.
Meanwhile, President Putin said he had agreed to a prisoner swap involving Navalny prior to his death, adding it is "sad" when someone dies.
Putin said the main condition for the exchange was that the opposition figure would not return to Russia.
Navalny was Putin's fiercest domestic opponent. His allies and Yulia accuse Putin of having him murdered, something the Kremlin denies.
A concert on Moscow's Red Square is being staged on Monday to mark 10 years since Russia's annexation of Ukraine's Crimea peninsula — an event that is also expected to serve as a victory celebration for Putin.

"I think hardly anyone is interested in this," he said.

title: 普京大选“获胜”虽无悬念，最后投票日见“中午反普京”人潮
content:
两位反对乌克兰战争并且真正得到许多俄罗斯民众支持的候选人被克里姆林宫禁止参选，而对普京威胁最大的反对派领导人奥列克西·纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）上个月在西伯利亚北极圈内的一个监狱中突然离奇死亡。

纳瓦尔尼的支持者呼吁俄罗斯民众在投票日的最后一天中午前往各地的投票所，但是不投票，只是现身表达无声的抗议。这项得到纳瓦尔尼生前认可的抗议行动被称为“中午反普京”示威活动。

“今天我们要对我们大家说 – 中午仅仅是个开始，”路透社引述“中午反普京”示威倡议活动星期天一早在社媒电报上的贴文说。

“是的，我们中的一些人感到害怕。是的，做这样的选择并不轻松。但是我们是人民。我们直面我们的选择和责任，”倡议活动的贴文说。
路透社报道说，在前两天的投票中，俄罗斯各地发生了一些零星的抗议事件。有些投票点被放火，有的投票箱被喷洒颜料。而俄罗斯官员则称做这些举动的人为“败类”和“叛徒”。

根据路透社的报道，在俄罗斯远东的新西伯利亚市的一个投票所，星期天中午约有100人出来排队。而俄罗斯在海外从泰国到悉尼、从比什凯克到塔什干开设的投票所前面，星期天中午也出现大排长龙的人群。但是目前并不清楚，这些人是前往投票还是现身抗议的。

普京两年多前发动乌克兰战争并在俄罗斯国内发布动员令时，很多俄罗斯役龄年轻人都已经逃往国外，而许多反对普京的俄罗斯人也离开。普京虽然在俄罗斯国内表现得像个强人，西方对他看法普遍负面，称他为独裁者、战争罪犯和屠夫。
translation:
Two candidates who oppose the war in Ukraine and have real support from many Russians have been banned from running by the Kremlin, while Alexei Navalny, the opposition leader who poses the greatest threat to Putin, was in the Siberian Arctic last month. A sudden and mysterious death occurred in a prison within the circle.

Navalny's supporters called on Russian people to go to polling stations around noon on the last day of voting, but not to vote, but to show up to express silent protest. This protest action, which was approved by Navalny during his lifetime, was called the "Noon Anti-Putin" demonstration.

“Today we say something to all of us – noon is just the beginning,” Reuters quoted the “Noon Against Putin” demonstration initiative as saying in a post on social media Telegram early Sunday morning.

"Yes, some of us are scared. Yes, making this choice is not easy. But we are the people. We face our choices and responsibilities head-on," the initiative's post said.
Reuters reported that there were sporadic protests across Russia during the first two days of voting. Some polling places were set on fire and some ballot boxes were sprayed with paint. Russian officials have called those responsible for these actions "scum" and "traitors."

According to Reuters, at a polling station in the city of Novosibirsk in Russia's Far East, about 100 people came out to queue at noon on Sunday. In front of the polling stations opened by Russia overseas from Thailand to Sydney, from Bishkek to Tashkent, long lines of people also appeared at noon on Sunday. But it is unclear whether these people went to vote or showed up to protest.

When Putin launched the Ukraine war more than two years ago and issued a mobilization order in Russia, many young Russians of military age had already fled abroad, and many Russians who opposed Putin also left. Although Putin behaves like a strongman in Russia, the West generally views him negatively, calling him a dictator, a war criminal and a butcher.
input:
Two candidates who oppose the war in Ukraine and have real support from many Russians have been banned from running by the Kremlin, while Alexei Navalny, the opposition leader who poses the greatest threat to Putin, was in the Siberian Arctic last month. A sudden and mysterious death occurred in a prison within the circle.

Navalny's supporters called on Russian people to go to polling stations around noon on the last day of voting, but not to vote, but to show up to express silent protest. This protest action, which was approved by Navalny during his lifetime, was called the "Noon Anti-Putin" demonstration.

“Today we say something to all of us – noon is just the beginning,” Reuters quoted the “Noon Against Putin” demonstration initiative as saying in a post on social media Telegram early Sunday morning.

"Yes, some of us are scared. Yes, making this choice is not easy. But we are the people. We face our choices and responsibilities head-on," the initiative's post said.
Reuters reported that there were sporadic protests across Russia during the first two days of voting. Some polling places were set on fire and some ballot boxes were sprayed with paint. Russian officials have called those responsible for these actions "scum" and "traitors."

According to Reuters, at a polling station in the city of Novosibirsk in Russia's Far East, about 100 people came out to queue at noon on Sunday. In front of the polling stations opened by Russia overseas from Thailand to Sydney, from Bishkek to Tashkent, long lines of people also appeared at noon on Sunday. But it is unclear whether these people went to vote or showed up to protest.

When Putin launched the Ukraine war more than two years ago and issued a mobilization order in Russia, many young Russians of military age had already fled abroad, and many Russians who opposed Putin also left. Although Putin behaves like a strongman in Russia, the West generally views him negatively, calling him a dictator, a war criminal and a butcher.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举：普京、权力与抗议的可能性 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
俄罗斯总统普京几乎肯定会赢得第五次选举。
但根据2020年的宪法修正案，他之前的任期被“废除”，在这样的情况下，3月15日至17日的选举将是他的“第一次”选举。
去年12月，普京在装饰华丽的克里姆林宫大厅举行的一场精心设计的仪式上，与来自乌克兰东南部顿巴斯地区的分裂主义“上校”阿尔乔姆·佐加交谈时，宣布了自己的候选资格。
当时，身着完美制服、饰有奖章的阿尔乔姆告诉普京，“我代表我们全体人民、我们的顿巴斯、与俄罗斯重新统一的土地，请您参加这次选举。”
对此，面无表情的普京回答称，“我不会隐瞒这一点，我在不同时期有着不同的想法，但现在，是做出决定的时候了，我会参加竞选。”
普京已经担任了四届总统任期。他于2000年当选总统，并于2004年、2012年和2018年三度连任。
由于宪法修正案延长了任期，如果普京如预期般获胜，那么他将再任职六年。而这也将标志着他的第五个总统任期。
他还可以在2030年再次当选，从而第六次连任。
这意味着他可以执政到2036年，届时他将年满83岁。
这位今年71岁的前克格勃特工，已经是自苏联时期领导人斯大林以来任职时间最长的俄罗斯领导人。
人们普遍将普京针对反对派、批评者和反战抗议者日益铁腕的对待，与斯大林时期的“大恐怖”运动相比较。
但是对于克里姆林宫的忠诚者而言，普京是一位政治“天才”，他阻止了俄罗斯的解体，统治了亿万富翁寡头，并且镇压了车臣的分裂分子。
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin is almost certain to win his fifth election.
But according to the 2020 constitutional amendment, his previous term was "abolished". Under such circumstances, the election from March 15 to 17 will be his "first" election.
Putin announced his plans in December during an elaborate ceremony in the ornate Kremlin hall while speaking to Artyom Zoga, a separatist "colonel" from Ukraine's southeastern Donbass region. Candidacy.
At the time, Artem, perfectly uniformed and adorned with medals, told Putin, "On behalf of all our people, our Donbass, the land reunited with Russia, I ask you to participate in this election."
In response, an expressionless Putin replied, "I will not hide this. I have different ideas at different times, but now it is time to make a decision and I will run for office."
Putin has served four terms as president. He was elected president in 2000 and was re-elected three times in 2004, 2012 and 2018.
If Putin wins, as expected, he will remain in office for another six years, thanks to a constitutional amendment that extends his term. And this will also mark his fifth presidential term.
He can also be re-elected in 2030 for a sixth term.
This means he can rule until 2036, when he will be 83 years old.
The 71-year-old former KGB agent is already the longest-serving Russian leader since Soviet-era leader Stalin.
Putin's increasingly heavy-handed treatment of opponents, critics and anti-war protesters has been widely compared to Stalin's "Great Terror" campaign.
But to Kremlin loyalists, Putin is a political "genius" who has prevented the disintegration of Russia, ruled over billionaire oligarchs and crushed separatists in Chechnya.

Russian President Vladimir Putin is almost certain to win his fifth election.
But according to the 2020 constitutional amendment, his previous term was "abolished". Under such circumstances, the election from March 15 to 17 will be his "first" election.
Putin announced his plans in December during an elaborate ceremony in the ornate Kremlin hall while speaking to Artyom Zoga, a separatist "colonel" from Ukraine's southeastern Donbass region. Candidacy.
At the time, Artem, perfectly uniformed and adorned with medals, told Putin, "On behalf of all our people, our Donbass, the land reunited with Russia, I ask you to participate in this election."
In response, an expressionless Putin replied, "I will not hide this. I have different ideas at different times, but now it is time to make a decision and I will run for office."
Putin has served four terms as president. He was elected president in 2000 and was re-elected three times in 2004, 2012 and 2018.
If Putin wins, as expected, he will remain in office for another six years, thanks to a constitutional amendment that extends his term. And this will also mark his fifth presidential term.
He can also be re-elected in 2030 for a sixth term.
This means he can rule until 2036, when he will be 83 years old.
The 71-year-old former KGB agent is already the longest-serving Russian leader since Soviet-era leader Stalin.
Putin's increasingly heavy-handed treatment of opponents, critics and anti-war protesters has been widely compared to Stalin's "Great Terror" campaign.
But to Kremlin loyalists, Putin is a political "genius" who has prevented the disintegration of Russia, ruled over billionaire oligarchs and crushed separatists in Chechnya.

title: Putin wins Russia election in landslide with no serious competition
content:
MOSCOW: President Vladimir Putin won a record post-Soviet landslide in Russia’s election on Sunday, cementing his already tight grip on power in a victory he said showed Moscow had been right to stand up to the West and send its troops into Ukraine.
Putin, a former KGB lieutenant colonel who first rose to power in 1999, made it clear that the result should send a message to the West that its leaders will have to reckon with an emboldened Russia, whether in war or in peace, for many more years to come.
The outcome means Putin, 71, is set to embark on a new six-year term that will see him overtake Josef Stalin and become Russia’s longest-serving leader for more than 200 years if he completes it.
Putin won 87.8% of the vote, the highest ever result in Russia’s post-Soviet history, according to an exit poll by pollster the Public Opinion Foundation (FOM). The Russian Public Opinion Research Centre (VCIOM) put Putin on 87%. First official results indicated the polls were accurate. The United States, Germany, the United Kingdom and other nations have said the vote was neither free nor fair due to the imprisonment of political opponents and censorship.
Communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov finished second with just under 4%, newcomer Vladislav Davankov third, and ultra-nationalist Leonid Slutsky fourth, partial results suggested.
input:
MOSCOW: President Vladimir Putin won a record post-Soviet landslide in Russia’s election on Sunday, cementing his already tight grip on power in a victory he said showed Moscow had been right to stand up to the West and send its troops into Ukraine.
Putin, a former KGB lieutenant colonel who first rose to power in 1999, made it clear that the result should send a message to the West that its leaders will have to reckon with an emboldened Russia, whether in war or in peace, for many more years to come.
The outcome means Putin, 71, is set to embark on a new six-year term that will see him overtake Josef Stalin and become Russia’s longest-serving leader for more than 200 years if he completes it.
Putin won 87.8% of the vote, the highest ever result in Russia’s post-Soviet history, according to an exit poll by pollster the Public Opinion Foundation (FOM). The Russian Public Opinion Research Centre (VCIOM) put Putin on 87%. First official results indicated the polls were accurate. The United States, Germany, the United Kingdom and other nations have said the vote was neither free nor fair due to the imprisonment of political opponents and censorship.
Communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov finished second with just under 4%, newcomer Vladislav Davankov third, and ultra-nationalist Leonid Slutsky fourth, partial results suggested.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content: В Белгороде все три дня выборов прошли под обстрелами. Во время обстрелов объявлялась воздушная тревога, из-за ракетной опасности люди, которые приходили голосовать на выборах, покидали избирательный участок и спускались в укрытие. Всего во время проведения выборов, пострадали более 60 россиян (из них шестеро погибли) приграничных районов в результате ракетных атак ВСУ.
translation: In Belgorod, all three election days were under fire. During the shelling, an air raid alert was announced, and due to the missile threat, people who came to vote in the elections left the polling station and went down to the shelter. In total, during the elections, more than 60 Russians were injured (six of them died) in border areas as a result of missile attacks by the Armed Forces of Ukraine.
input: In Belgorod, all three election days were under fire. During the shelling, an air raid alert was announced, and due to the missile threat, people who came to vote in the elections left the polling station and went down to the shelter. In total, during the elections, more than 60 Russians were injured (six of them died) in border areas as a result of missile attacks by the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

title: 大选投票期间，俄称边境城市别尔哥罗德遭乌军炮击致2死3伤
content:
据央视新闻客户端3月16日报道，当日，俄罗斯别尔哥罗德州州长发布消息称，别尔哥罗德市遭到了乌军的炮击，造成2人死亡、3人受伤。
在俄罗斯大选进入投票阶段的背景下，位于俄乌边境地区的别尔哥罗德州近日已成为乌军攻击的目标。俄罗斯总统普京15日说，乌克兰军队近日多次试图进攻俄罗斯本土均未取得成功，乌军试图通过袭击扰乱俄总统选举投票。
普京称，从12日至今，乌方主要利用特种部队、外国雇佣兵和乌军支援部队多次试图进入俄领土，制造了多起破坏和恐怖袭击事件，其中4起发生在别尔哥罗德方向，一起发生在库尔斯克方向。
普京说，乌军为此动用了超过2500人、35辆坦克和40辆装甲车，但未取得成功，且因此损失60%的人员和超过50%的装甲装备。
他还强调，乌军上述行动从军事角度看“毫无意义”，从人道角度看则是“犯罪行为”，其目的是扰乱俄总统选举投票进程，对与乌克兰接壤地区的俄平民进行“恐吓”。
2024年俄罗斯总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。据俄总统网站消息，普京15日以在线形式参与了总统选举投票。
translation:
According to a report on the CCTV News Client on March 16, on that day, the governor of Russia's Belgorod Region announced that the city of Belgorod was shelled by the Ukrainian army, resulting in 2 deaths and 3 injuries.
As the Russian general election enters the voting stage, Belgorod Oblast, located in the border area between Russia and Ukraine, has recently become the target of attacks by the Ukrainian army. Russian President Vladimir Putin said on the 15th that the Ukrainian army had repeatedly attempted to attack the Russian mainland in recent days without success, and that the Ukrainian army was trying to disrupt the Russian presidential election voting through attacks.
Putin said that from the 12th to the present, Ukraine has mainly used special forces, foreign mercenaries and Ukrainian army support troops to repeatedly try to enter Russian territory and cause many sabotage and terrorist attacks, four of which occurred in Belgorod. direction, together took place in the direction of Kursk.
Putin said that the Ukrainian army used more than 2,500 men, 35 tanks and 40 armored vehicles for this purpose, but failed, and as a result, it lost 60% of its personnel and more than 50% of its armored equipment.
He also emphasized that the above-mentioned actions of the Ukrainian army are "meaningless" from a military perspective and "criminal acts" from a humanitarian perspective. Their purpose is to disrupt the Russian presidential election voting process and "terrorize Russian civilians in areas bordering Ukraine" ".
Official voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to the Russian President’s website, Putin participated in the presidential election vote online on the 15th.

Their purpose is to disrupt the Russian presidential election voting process and "terrorize Russian civilians in areas bordering Ukraine" ".

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
content:
根据俄联邦预算计划，2024年俄国防开支将较2023年增加近70%，防务和安全开支加在一起预计将占到全部预算开支的40%左右，而这也是俄军事开支首次超过社会领域开支。
国防开支和与军事行动相关的制造业大幅增长，在很大程度上起到了推动俄经济发展的作用。根据俄官方数据，截至2023年年底，俄罗斯国内生产总值较2022年增幅达到3.6%。除消费需求增长、对西方制裁日渐适应外，制造业的增长也是俄经济增长的重要助力。
据俄外贸银行资本公司经济学家亚历山大·伊萨科夫估算，制造业增长对2023年俄国内生产总值增长的贡献为1.2个百分点，而其中约有一半来自与军工综合体关系最密切的金属、电子器材及运输工具制造等领域。
在此背景下，俄罗斯军工企业对人员的需求迅速上升。普京今年2月表示，俄军工综合体目前包括6000家企业，共有350万从业人员。在仅一年半的时间内，俄罗斯军工综合体就已创造了52万个新的工作岗位。
据尤里介绍，由于主要的钢材买家还是西方国家，军事需求与之相比较少，所以他所在公司的整体营业额仍出现了一定程度的下滑。不过，尤里的工资并未因此而下降。恰恰相反，他的收入正在增加。尤里解释说，这与俄罗斯目前所面临的劳动力短缺问题密不可分。
作为较早受到俄罗斯延迟退休政策影响的一批人以及一名军工相关行业从业者，今年56岁的尤里对俄罗斯的长期人口危机以及当前的劳动力短缺问题有着深刻的感受。原本应在60岁退休的他，如今还需要继续工作9年。
尤里提到，退休后继续工作的情况在俄罗斯十分常见。通过这种方式，人们可以在退休金之外赚到更多的钱。而在延迟退休后，他们能够领取“双份工资”的时间被缩短了。
在人口危机之外，受到俄乌冲突后军事动员及新一波“移民潮”的影响，俄劳动力短缺情况愈发严重。根据俄罗斯科学院发布的一份最新研究报告，2023年俄罗斯劳动力缺口已达480万人，而这一问题正在成为俄经济发展的掣肘。
“劳动力短缺的现象使得雇主们不得不支付更高的薪水，以便留住员工。”尤里这样解释道。
根据俄罗斯劳动力市场相关数据，目前俄军工厂的机械师、焊工等从业人员的薪资水平已超过许多普通白领。为追求更优待遇，此前从事民用生产的人员正流向包括军工部门在内的机械制造领域等相关企业。即便如此，俄罗斯劳动与社会政策部前部长奥克萨纳·德米特里耶娃曾表示，当前军工、机械制造、金属加工等领域劳动力短缺问题仍然最为突出。
translation:
According to the Russian federal budget plan, Russia's defense spending in 2024 will increase by nearly 70% compared with 2023. Defense and security spending combined are expected to account for about 40% of all budget spending. This is the first time that Russia's military spending has exceeded social spending. .
The substantial growth in defense spending and manufacturing related to military operations has largely played a role in promoting Russia's economic development. According to Russian official data, as of the end of 2023, Russia's GDP will increase by 3.6% compared with 2022. In addition to growing consumer demand and increasing adaptation to Western sanctions, the growth of manufacturing is also an important driver of Russia's economic growth.
According to estimates by Alexander Isakov, an economist at VTB Capital, manufacturing growth will contribute 1.2 percentage points to Russia’s GDP growth in 2023, and about half of this will come from companies closest to the military-industrial complex. Metal, electronic equipment and transportation manufacturing and other fields.
Against this background, Russian military-industrial enterprises’ demand for personnel has increased rapidly. Putin said in February this year that the Russian military-industrial complex currently includes 6,000 companies with a total of 3.5 million employees. In just one and a half years, the Russian military-industrial complex has created 520,000 new jobs.
According to Yuri, since the main buyers of steel are still Western countries and military demand is relatively small, his company's overall turnover has still declined to a certain extent. However, Yuri's salary did not decrease as a result. On the contrary, his income is increasing. Yuri explained that this is inseparable from the labor shortage problem that Russia is currently facing.
As one of the early people affected by Russia's delayed retirement policy and a practitioner in military-related industries, 56-year-old Yuri has a deep understanding of Russia's long-term demographic crisis and the current labor shortage. He was supposed to retire at the age of 60, but now he still needs to continue working for 9 years.
Yuri mentioned that continuing to work after retirement is very common in Russia. This way people can earn more money on top of their pension. After delaying retirement, the time during which they can receive "double salary" is shortened.
In addition to the demographic crisis, Russia's labor shortage has become increasingly serious due to the impact of military mobilization after the Russian-Ukrainian conflict and a new wave of "immigration." According to a latest research report released by the Russian Academy of Sciences, Russia's labor gap will reach 4.8 million people in 2023, and this problem is becoming a constraint on Russia's economic development.
"The shortage of labor forces employers to pay higher wages in order to retain employees." Yuri explained.
According to relevant data on the Russian labor market, the current salary levels of mechanics, welders and other employees in Russian military factories have exceeded that of many ordinary white-collar workers. In pursuit of better treatment, personnel previously engaged in civilian production are moving to related companies in the machinery manufacturing field, including the military industry sector. Even so, Oksana Dmitrieva, the former minister of the Russian Ministry of Labor and Social Policy, once said that the current labor shortage problem in military industry, machinery manufacturing, metal processing and other fields is still the most prominent.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Происшествия в ходе голосования
Избирком Херсонской области в пятницу сообщил об ударах по помещениям в городе Каховке и в селе Брилёвка Алешкинского района, в которых располагались участковые комиссии. «В Каховке жертв удалось избежать. В Брилёвке есть пострадавшие, им оказывают помощь», — отметили в избиркоме.
В воскресенье в Перми на территории избирательного участка в Доме культуры произошел взрыв, сообщило краевое министерство территориальной безопасности. Женщина пронесла в здание большую петарду и взорвала в туалете. По данным Baza, женщине 64 года, ей оторвало руку.
В Петербурге в пятницу девушка бросила «коктейль Молотова» в вывеску одной из участковых комиссий, сообщил глава местного избиркома Максим Мейксин. Пожар потушили.
Кроме того, в Когалыме Ханты-Мансийского автономного округа женщина попыталась поджечь стационарный ящик для голосования при помощи бутылки с зажигательной смесью (видеокадры с участка — ниже). Ее задержали, а возгорание потушили. Бюллетени и оборудование не повреждены, уточнили в пресс-службе избиркома Югры.

На юго-востоке Москвы женщина на одном из избирательных участков подожгла с помощью легковоспламеняющейся жидкости кабинку для голосования, сообщил СК. Возбуждено уголовное дело по ст. 141 (воспрепятствование работе избирательных комиссий).
На другом участке в Москве девушка вылила красящее вещество в урну для бюллетеней. На нее тоже завели дело по ст. 141 УК. Как сообщил зампредседателя Мосгоризбиркома Дмитрий Реут, в этой урне было около 100 бюллетеней.

Утром 15 марта аналогичные случаи произошли в Борисоглебске в Воронежской области. Как пишет «Блокнот Борисоглебск», зеленкой залили урны в Юго-Восточном и Северном микрорайонах города. В борисоглебской ТИК сообщили, что члены участковой комиссии заклеили прорези ящиков и установили другие урны, голосование продолжилось. Позднее они проверят, можно ли считать окрашенные бюллетени действительными.
В Екатеринбурге профессор Уральского федерального университета Эмилия Носова попыталась испортить бюллетени на одном из избирательных участков города. С собой у нее была зеленка. Источник Ura.ru в силовых структурах утверждает, что профессор УрФУ пришла на избирательный участок с зеленкой под давлением неизвестных лиц, которым перед этим перечислила 15 млн руб.
translation:
Incidents during voting
The Electoral Commission of the Kherson region on Friday reported attacks on premises in the city of Kakhovka and in the village of Brilyovka, Aleshkinsky district, where precinct commissions were located. “We managed to avoid casualties in Kakhovka. There are victims in Brilyovka, they are being provided with assistance,” the election commission noted.
On Sunday in Perm, an explosion occurred on the territory of a polling station in the House of Culture, the regional Ministry of Territorial Security reported. A woman brought a large firecracker into the building and exploded it in the toilet. According to Baza, the woman is 64 years old and her arm was torn off.
In St. Petersburg on Friday, a girl threw a Molotov cocktail at the sign of one of the precinct commissions, said the head of the local election commission, Maxim Meiksin. The fire was put out.
In addition, in Kogalym, Khanty-Mansiysk Autonomous Okrug, a woman tried to set fire to a stationary ballot box using a Molotov cocktail (video footage from the polling station is below). She was detained and the fire was extinguished. The ballots and equipment were not damaged, the press service of the Ugra Electoral Commission clarified.

In the south-east of Moscow, a woman at one of the polling stations set fire to a voting booth with a flammable liquid, the Investigative Committee reported. A criminal case has been initiated under Art. 141 (obstruction of the work of election commissions).
At another polling station in Moscow, a girl poured a dye into a ballot box. A case was also opened against her under Art. 141 of the Criminal Code. According to Deputy Chairman of the Moscow City Election Commission Dmitry Reut, there were about 100 ballots in this ballot box.

On the morning of March 15, similar incidents occurred in Borisoglebsk in the Voronezh region. According to Notebook Borisoglebsk, trash cans in the South-Eastern and Northern microdistricts of the city were filled with green paint. The Borisoglebsk TEC reported that members of the precinct commission sealed the slots in the boxes and installed other ballot boxes, and voting continued. They will later check to see if the colored ballots can be considered valid.
In Yekaterinburg, a professor at the Ural Federal University, Emilia Nosova, tried to spoil the ballots at one of the city’s polling stations. She had some brilliant green with her. A Ura.ru source in law enforcement agencies claims that the UrFU professor came to the polling station with brilliant green under pressure from unknown persons, to whom she had previously transferred 15 million rubles.

title: ЦИК РФ: Путин побеждает на выборах с рекордным результатом
content:
"Полдень против Путина"
Несмотря на угрозы прокуратуры, предложения проголосовать через интернет и фейки об отмене мероприятия, тысячи россиян пришли в 12 часов в воскресенье на избирательные участки. Ранее оппозиция призвала несогласных с политикой действующего президента РФ принять участие в акции "Полдень против Путина".

В Москве очереди из желающих проголосовать в полдень наблюдались на нескольких участках. В МФТИ, где преподавал и проголосовал Борис Надеждин, студенты стали скандировать его имя. Его не допустили на выборы после того, как в феврале ЦИК признал недействительными часть собранных в его поддержку подписей.

За границей, у российских диппредставительств, к полудню собрались многочасовые очереди из желающих проголосовать россиян. В некоторых городах им приходилось ждать в очереди по 6-7 часов.

Одна из крупнейших акций за рубежом прошла в Берлине. По некоторым оценкам, в ней приняли участие около двух тысяч человек.

Вдова Алексея Навального Юлия пришла в полдень к посольству РФ в Германии, чтобы проголосовать, как и десятки других россиян. На акции также был замечен Михаил Ходорковский.
translation:
"Noon against Putin"
Despite threats from the prosecutor's office, offers to vote via the Internet and fakes about the cancellation of the event, thousands of Russians came to the polling stations at 12 o'clock on Sunday. Earlier, the opposition called on those who disagree with the policies of the current President of the Russian Federation to take part in the “Noon against Putin” action.

In Moscow, queues of people wishing to vote at noon were observed at several polling stations. At MIPT, where Boris Nadezhdin taught and voted, students began chanting his name. He was not allowed to participate in the elections after the Central Election Commission invalidated part of the signatures collected in his support in February.

Abroad, at Russian diplomatic missions, by midday there were hours-long queues of Russians wanting to vote. In some cities they had to wait in line for 6-7 hours.

One of the largest events abroad took place in Berlin. According to some estimates, about two thousand people took part in it.

Alexei Navalny's widow Yulia came to the Russian Embassy in Germany at noon to vote, like dozens of other Russians. Mikhail Khodorkovsky was also seen at the rally.
input:
"Noon against Putin"
Despite threats from the prosecutor's office, offers to vote via the Internet and fakes about the cancellation of the event, thousands of Russians came to the polling stations at 12 o'clock on Sunday. Earlier, the opposition called on those who disagree with the policies of the current President of the Russian Federation to take part in the “Noon against Putin” action.

In Moscow, queues of people wishing to vote at noon were observed at several polling stations. At MIPT, where Boris Nadezhdin taught and voted, students began chanting his name. He was not allowed to participate in the elections after the Central Election Commission invalidated part of the signatures collected in his support in February.

Abroad, at Russian diplomatic missions, by midday there were hours-long queues of Russians wanting to vote. In some cities they had to wait in line for 6-7 hours.

One of the largest events abroad took place in Berlin. According to some estimates, about two thousand people took part in it.

Alexei Navalny's widow Yulia came to the Russian Embassy in Germany at noon to vote, like dozens of other Russians. Mikhail Khodorkovsky was also seen at the rally.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
在俄罗斯独立导演为德国电视台摄制的一档纪录片中，另一个名叫叶利尼亚的小镇同样展示出当代“深层俄罗斯社会”的一些风貌。
在那里，苏联卫国战争遗产占据了镇子里的公共生活，几乎所有的节日、仪式和集会都围绕着那场战争。80多年前，为了给关乎苏联存亡的莫斯科保卫战赢得准备时间，红军部队在绝对劣势下坚守叶利尼亚多日，为此付出极大伤亡。激战过后，红军终于拖慢了纳粹德国军队前进的脚步，在一排排倒下的红军士兵身后，拱卫莫斯科的防线得以构筑起来。
不过，80多年前的事情毕竟太过遥远，直接当事人大多已经离世。多年以来，小镇逐渐走向衰朽破败，年轻人不断流失，苏联时期的基础设施早已严重老化。对于仍然留在那里的居民而言，时间仿佛冻结了。
但俄乌冲突打破了这个状态。2022年2月24日以后，不断有俄罗斯媒体踏入这座原本安静的小镇。他们的报道目的很明确：聚焦小镇的光荣历史，用苏联红军的牺牲来唤起俄罗斯公众的爱国主义热情。于是小镇的人气又开始聚集，一些人还专程旅行过来参观战争遗迹。
也就是说，在乌克兰燃烧的战火仿佛让沉寂数十年的叶利尼亚镇复活了，居民们感到外界，甚至全国的注意力都重新集中到了叶利尼亚。
“他们说从军不是女人的事，但没有什么工作天生就是男人的事。我们能挖战壕，我们能治伤患，是我们带来了战斗力！”
十六岁的叶利尼亚女孩玛莎身着迷彩服，唱着这首献给卫国战争苏联女兵的《穿军装的女人》，在小镇的胜利日演出上收获了阵阵掌声。她是小镇中学里无可置疑的好学生，上课总是坐在第一排，每每老师提问，她都抢着举手回答问题。而她最擅长的，是在历史课上复述伟大卫国战争的历程，那些重大战役的时间、地点、经过她都烂熟于心。
带着父母、老师和镇民的寄托，玛莎一直在辛苦排练，希望在城里的青少年歌曲大赛中拿得名次，并给莫斯科来的权威评委们留下良好印象。然而，在一众流行音乐节目的竞争之下，首次参加大赛的玛莎有些紧张，最后没能取得预想的好成绩。和那些唱着西方歌曲，穿着性感时髦的同龄女孩在一起，身着军装、别着圣乔治丝带的玛莎在登台前还不忘在胸口划十字祷告，她的气质显得十分格格不入。
translation:
In a documentary filmed by an independent Russian director for German television, another town named Yelniya also shows some features of contemporary "deep Russian society."
There, the legacy of the Soviet Patriotic War dominates the town’s public life, with almost all festivals, ceremonies and gatherings centered around that war. More than 80 years ago, in order to buy time to prepare for the battle to defend Moscow, which was crucial to the survival of the Soviet Union, the Red Army troops held on to Yelniya for many days at an absolute disadvantage, and suffered heavy casualties. After the fierce battle, the Red Army finally slowed down the advance of the Nazi German army. Behind rows of fallen Red Army soldiers, a defense line to defend Moscow was built.
However, what happened more than 80 years ago is too far away after all, and most of the direct parties have passed away. Over the years, the town has gradually declined and become dilapidated, losing young people and its Soviet-era infrastructure has become seriously outdated. For the residents who remain there, time seems frozen.
But the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke this state. After February 24, 2022, Russian media continued to enter this originally quiet town. The purpose of their reporting was clear: to focus on the glorious history of the town and to use the sacrifices of the Soviet Red Army to arouse the patriotic enthusiasm of the Russian public. As a result, the popularity of the town began to gather again, and some people even made special trips to visit the war relics.
In other words, the war burning in Ukraine seems to have revived the town of Yelnya, which has been dormant for decades. Residents feel that the attention of the outside world, and even the whole country, has returned to Yelniya.
"They say the military is not a woman's job, but no job is inherently a man's job. We can dig trenches, we can treat the wounded, and we bring combat effectiveness!"
Masha, a 16-year-old girl from Yelniya, wore a camouflage uniform and sang "Women in Uniform" dedicated to the Soviet female soldiers in the Great Patriotic War. She received bursts of applause at the Victory Day performance in the town. She is an undoubted good student in the small town middle school. She always sits in the front row in class. Whenever the teacher asks a question, she rushes to raise her hand to answer the question. What she is best at is retelling the course of the Great Patriotic War in history classes. She knows the time, place, and course of those major battles by heart.
With the support of her parents, teachers and townspeople, Masha has been rehearsing hard, hoping to win a place in the city's youth song competition and leave a good impression on the authoritative judges from Moscow. However, under the competition of many popular music programs, Martha, who participated in the competition for the first time, was a little nervous, and in the end she failed to achieve the good results expected. Alongside girls of the same age who sang Western songs and wore sexy and fashionable clothes, Martha, who was wearing a military uniform and a St. George ribbon, did not forget to cross her chest and pray before going on stage. Her temperament seemed very out of place.

title: ‘Noon against Putin’ protests as Russian leader set to extend rule in polls | Elections News | Al Jazeera
content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin is poised to tighten his grip on power in an election that is certain to deliver him a landslide victory, though thousands of opponents have staged a symbolic noon protest at polling stations.
Supporters of Putin’s fiercest political foe Alexey Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month, had called on Russians to come out for a “Noon against Putin” protest to show their dissent against a leader they cast as a corrupt autocrat.
Navalny’s associates, including his widow Yulia Navalnaya, have urged those unhappy with Putin, 71, or the ongoing war with Ukraine to protest by coming to the polls at noon on Sunday, a strategy endorsed by Navalny shortly before his death.
Team Navalny described it as a success, releasing pictures and videos of people crowding near polling stations in cities across Russia around noon.
At a polling station in southwest Moscow, Leonid, an 18-year-old student, said there were “not that many people” taking part in the protest but he was “just happy that some people came”.
The polling station was in a school where Navalny scored his highest result – 70 percent – in his failed bid to become Moscow mayor in 2013. He later attempted to run against Putin in the 2018 presidential election but his candidacy was rejected.
After casting his ballot at a polling station where Navalny used to vote, IT worker Alexander said he came because this was one of the few ways he could protest.
“If I hadn’t done this, I would have felt like a coward,” the 29-year-old said.
Elena, 52, said people were “too afraid” to come out in large numbers. “I don’t want Russia, my homeland, to be like this … I love my country; I want it to be free.”
Putin, who rose to power in 1999, is set to win a new six-year term that would enable him to overtake Josef Stalin and become Russia’s longest-serving leader for more than 200 years.
While Putin’s re-election is not in doubt given his control over Russia and the absence of any real challengers, the former KGB spy wants to show that he has the overwhelming support of Russians.
Several hours before polls were due to close at 18:00 GMT, the nationwide turnout surpassed 2018 levels of 67.5 percent.

Putin, who rose to power in 1999, is set to win a new six-year term that would enable him to overtake Josef Stalin and become Russia’s longest-serving leader for more than 200 years.

title: Takeaways from the predictable Russian election that gave Putin another 6 years in power | AP News
content:
To no one’s surprise, President Vladimir Putin secured another six years in power in a preordained election landslide that comes amid the harshest crackdown on the opposition and free speech since Soviet times.
The three days of balloting, in which Putin faced three token contenders but none offering voters any real choice, went ahead with barely any independent monitoring and were marked by a level of pressure unseen in previous Russian elections. That left little room for protests, but some Russians still tried to defy authorities.
Some key takeaways from the election:
The Central Election Commission said Putin received 87.28% of the vote, the highest number for any president in post-Soviet Russia. It said turnout was 77.44% of the electorate, also the biggest. Others on the ballot all finished in single digits, and anti-war candidates were not allowed to run.
The state news agency RIA Novosti said the vote “as expected ... took place in an atmosphere of unprecedented national unity.”
There was no video from CCTV cameras at polling stations depicting voter fraud or ballot-box stuffing -– access to the footage was more heavily restricted than in previous elections -– and hardly any independent monitors were on hand to document irregularities.
There still was voter intimidation, however, according to Golos, Russia’s prominent independent election watchdog, noting it received reports of citizens being pressured to vote in over 60 Russian regions. On Sunday, voters were searched at polling stations, and some reported police checking their ballots before they were cast or peering over their shoulder while they filled them out, Golos said. 
“Nothing like that has happened on such a scale at elections in Russia before,” Golos said in a statement Monday. A total of 89 people were detained Sunday in 22 cities, said OVD-Info, a rights group that monitors political arrests.
The 71-year-old Russia leader “chose to show his adversaries his power,” said political analyst Abbas Gallyamov, a former Putin’s speechwriter.
Vandalism also was reported at polling stations, with arson attempts or some pouring ink into ballot boxes. On Sunday, a woman who set off a firecracker in a polling station bathroom was injured. At least 34 people were detained on vandalism charges over the weekend, according to Russian independent news outlet Verstka.
The Kremlin has severely crippled the Russian opposition in recent years. Top figures are either in jail or in exile abroad, and the death last month of Alexei Navalny, who was Putin’s most vocal opponent, raised even more questions about what lies ahead for them.
