title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content:
С другой стороны, традиционные партнеры и союзники России, такие как Китай, Индия, Турция, Иран и страны СНГ, поспешили поздравить Путина с переизбранием и высоко оценили уровень организации выборов. Лидеры КНДР, Узбекистана, Таджикистана, Никарагуа и Венесуэлы и вовсе назвали победу Путина вкладом в стабильность и безопасность во всем мире.

Что любопытно, в некоторых западных столицах и мегаполисах - от Гааги и Вильнюса до Тель-Авива и Нью-Йорка - на зарубежных участках победу одержал не Путин, а кандидат от "Новых людей" Владислав Даванков. Впрочем, в масштабах всей российской диаспоры за рубежом (около 2 млн избирателей) это погоды не сделало - Путин и там набрал более 70%, согласно данным ГАС «Выборы».

МИД РФ назвал «беспрецедентной» явку за границей — 372 тысячи человек. Ниже на фото очередь из желающих проголосовать у посольства в Берлине.
translation:
On the other hand, Russia's traditional partners and allies, such as China, India, Turkey, Iran and the CIS countries, rushed to congratulate Putin on his re-election and praised the level of organization of the elections. The leaders of the DPRK, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Nicaragua and Venezuela even called Putin’s victory a contribution to stability and security throughout the world.

Interestingly, in some Western capitals and megacities - from The Hague and Vilnius to Tel Aviv and New York - it was not Putin who won in foreign polls, but the candidate from the “New People”, Vladislav Davankov. However, this did not make a difference for the entire Russian diaspora abroad (about 2 million voters) - Putin scored more than 70% there too, according to the State Automated Information System “Vybory”.

The Russian Foreign Ministry called the turnout abroad “unprecedented” - 372 thousand people. Below is a photo of a line of people wishing to vote outside the embassy in Berlin.
input:
On the other hand, Russia's traditional partners and allies, such as China, India, Turkey, Iran and the CIS countries, rushed to congratulate Putin on his re-election and praised the level of organization of the elections. The leaders of the DPRK, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Nicaragua and Venezuela even called Putin’s victory a contribution to stability and security throughout the world.

Interestingly, in some Western capitals and megacities - from The Hague and Vilnius to Tel Aviv and New York - it was not Putin who won in foreign polls, but the candidate from the “New People”, Vladislav Davankov. However, this did not make a difference for the entire Russian diaspora abroad (about 2 million voters) - Putin scored more than 70% there too, according to the State Automated Information System “Vybory”.

The Russian Foreign Ministry called the turnout abroad “unprecedented” - 372 thousand people. Below is a photo of a line of people wishing to vote outside the embassy in Berlin.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·现场｜战时选举的低调氛围与稳步推进的政治进程
content:
又是龙年，又有机会现场观摩俄罗斯大选。笔者在3月15日选举首日起了个大早，在莫斯科city walk，暴走两万步进行城市观察，先后前往地铁站“白俄罗斯站”、特维尔大街以及米秋林街附近的三个选举投票站，也没有落下市中心和红场正在举办的各类文化活动。与2012年相比，这次选举本质上有未曾改变的部分，然而一切又与12年前有了诸多不同。
难以接近的投票站和热闹的“谢肉节”
首先能感受到的，是对外来观察者而言，投票站点的封闭程度加强、开放程度降低。12年前的大选投票站点可能会设置在大学主楼公共区域，或是居民区内部，外国人进出不会受到限制，除了进入站内投票会拉上帘子之外，即使不去投票也可以跟随人流走进投票站内部观摩情况。除此之外，2012年的大选日当天胜利公园还有聚集拉票的集会活动，乌泱泱的人群甚至从地铁站通道就开始排队，在公园空地上有党派进行演讲，热闹非凡。
如今，公园广场上人群寥落，常见的多是中国游客或是来进行爱国主义教育的俄罗斯学生团队，投票站点也不再完全开放、进出自由。需要输入准确到门牌号的居住地址才能在联邦选举委员会官网上查找到对应的投票站地址，选择“观测样本”的过程变得比较复杂。
除此之外，投票站往往设置在公立教育机构（即国家预算教育机构ГБОУ，例如今天挑选到的三个投票站都是市立小学或是艺术学校），本身自带门禁和安保设施，天然隔绝好奇围观的目光。特维尔大街附近的投票站设在一栋历史建筑的底层，但门口有刷卡门禁和保安驻守，看到异国面孔突然闪现就出声询问，在笔者表示不投票的话能否出于好奇进来看看之后，马上收到了礼貌但果断的拒绝。
白俄罗斯站附近的投票点相对热闹，不时有人进出，但从大门到站点门口的长路上有保安驻守，只能守在门口，偶尔逮住刚投完票出来的民众询问情况。有的年轻人大方表示“投给了普京”，但有的中年夫妇面对我们的问题则略带警惕地开玩笑说“这是我们的秘密”（Это тайна наша）。
地铁站白俄罗斯站附近的投票点。
translation:
It’s the Year of the Dragon again, and I have another opportunity to watch the Russian election live. The author got up early on the first day of the election on March 15, walked 20,000 steps in Moscow city walk to observe the city, and went to three election sites near the subway station "Belarussky Station", Tverskaya Street and Michiulin Street. The polling stations also did not miss the various cultural activities being held in the city center and Red Square. Compared with 2012, this election has essentially unchanged parts, but everything is very different from 12 years ago.
Inaccessible polling stations and bustling "Malaysian Days"
The first thing that can be felt is that to outside observers, voting sites are becoming more closed and less open. The general election voting sites 12 years ago may be set up in the public areas of the main university building or inside residential areas. Foreigners will not be restricted in entry and exit. In addition to the curtains being drawn when entering the station to vote, they can follow the flow of people even if they are not voting. Go inside the polling station to observe the situation. In addition, on the 2012 election day, there was a rally gathering to canvass votes in Victory Park. Thousands of people even started queuing from the subway station passage. Parties gave speeches in the open space of the park, which was very lively.
Today, there are only a few crowds in the park square, mostly Chinese tourists or Russian student groups who come for patriotic education. The voting sites are no longer fully open and free to enter and exit. You need to enter your residential address accurate to the house number to find the corresponding polling station address on the Federal Election Commission's official website, and the process of selecting "observation samples" becomes more complicated.
In addition, polling stations are often set up in public educational institutions (i.e., state budget education institutions, for example, the three polling stations selected today are all municipal elementary schools or art schools), with their own access control and security facilities, and are naturally isolated. The curious gazes of the crowd. The polling station near Tver Street is located on the ground floor of a historical building, but there are card access controls and security guards at the door. When I saw a sudden flash of an exotic face, I asked if I could come in out of curiosity if I said I would not vote. Immediately afterwards, I received a polite but decisive rejection.
The polling place near the Belarus station was relatively lively, with people coming in and out from time to time. However, there were security guards stationed on the long road from the gate to the station entrance. They could only guard the door and occasionally catch people who had just cast their votes to ask about the situation. Some young people generously said that they "voted for Putin", but some middle-aged couples faced our questions and joked with a little caution, "This is our secret" (Это тайна наша).
Polling place near metro station Belorussky.

You need to enter your residential address accurate to the house number to find the corresponding polling station address on the Federal Election Commission's official website, and the process of selecting "observation samples" becomes more complicated.
In addition, polling stations are often set up in public educational institutions (i.e., state budget education institutions, for example, the three polling stations selected today are all municipal elementary schools or art schools), with their own access control and security facilities, and are naturally isolated. The curious gazes of the crowd. The polling station near Tver Street is located on the ground floor of a historical building, but there are card access controls and security guards at the door. When I saw a sudden flash of an exotic face, I asked if I could come in out of curiosity if I said I would not vote. Immediately afterwards, I received a polite but decisive rejection.
The polling place near the Belarus station was relatively lively, with people coming in and out from time to time. However, there were security guards stationed on the long road from the gate to the station entrance. They could only guard the door and occasionally catch people who had just cast their votes to ask about the situation. Some young people generously said that they "voted for Putin", but some middle-aged couples faced our questions and joked with a little caution, "This is our secret" (Это тайна наша).
Polling place near metro station Belorussky.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Памфилова заявила, что «никакой большевистской замены» выборов на участках онлайн-голосованием «не предполагается и быть не может». «Они будут сосуществовать вместе», — сказала она.
61 уголовное дело возбудили в период выборов, сообщил первый замглавы МВД Александр Горовой в ЦИК. Больше всего дел завели по статьям о заведомо ложном сообщении о теракте и о воспрепятствовании осуществлению прав избирателей. Составлено также 155 административных протоколов.
Роскомнадзор заявил, что заблокировал или удалил 1,3 тыс. ресурсов и публикаций с призывами поучаствовать в несогласованных акциях во время выборов.
В нескольких регионах арестованы граждане, пытавшиеся помешать выборам. Так, в Петербурге суд арестовал девушку, бросившую «коктейль Молотова» во вход на избирательный участок. В Москве арестована девушка, которая вылила жидкость в урну с бюллетенями. В Екатеринбурге суд арестовал профессора Уральского федерального университета по аналогичной причине: женщина была задержана 16 марта после попытки испортить бюллетени на одном из избирательных участков города. С собой у нее была зеленка.
Мужчина бросил две бутылки с зажигательной смесью во двор посольства России в Кишиневе. В дипмиссии идет голосование на выборах президента России. Мужчину задержали, избирательный участок продолжил работу.
translation:
Pamfilova stated that “no Bolshevik replacement” of elections at polling stations with online voting “is not expected and cannot be.” “They will coexist together,” she said.
61 criminal cases were opened during the election period, First Deputy Head of the Ministry of Internal Affairs Alexander Gorovoy reported to the Central Election Commission. The majority of cases were brought under articles of knowingly false reporting of a terrorist attack and obstruction of the exercise of voters' rights. 155 administrative protocols were also drawn up.
Roskomnadzor said it blocked or deleted 1.3 thousand resources and publications with calls to participate in uncoordinated actions during the elections.
In several regions, citizens who tried to interfere with the elections were arrested. Thus, in St. Petersburg, a court arrested a girl who threw a Molotov cocktail at the entrance to a polling station. A girl was arrested in Moscow for pouring liquid into a ballot box. In Yekaterinburg, the court arrested a professor at the Ural Federal University for a similar reason: a woman was detained on March 16 after attempting to spoil ballots at one of the city’s polling stations. She had some brilliant green with her.
A man threw two Molotov cocktails into the courtyard of the Russian Embassy in Chisinau. Voting is underway in the Russian presidential election at the diplomatic mission. The man was detained, the polling station continued to work.

The majority of cases were brought under articles of knowingly false reporting of a terrorist attack and obstruction of the exercise of voters' rights. 155 administrative protocols were also drawn up.
Roskomnadzor said it blocked or deleted 1.3 thousand resources and publications with calls to participate in uncoordinated actions during the elections.
In several regions, citizens who tried to interfere with the elections were arrested. In Yekaterinburg, the court arrested a professor at the Ural Federal University for a similar reason: a woman was detained on March 16 after attempting to spoil ballots at one of the city’s polling stations. She had some brilliant green with her.
A man threw two Molotov cocktails into the courtyard of the Russian Embassy in Chisinau. Voting is underway in the Russian presidential election at the diplomatic mission. The man was detained, the polling station continued to work.

title: 俄罗斯大选 海内外投票处现抗议活动 | 普京 | 大纪元
content:
周日（3月17日），俄罗斯大选进入最后一个投票日，海内外投票所涌现反对现总统普京的“中午反普京”抗议活动，不过外界普遍认为这将不会影响普京的连任。
普京最知名的政治对手是上个月在北极流放地去世的阿列克谢‧纳瓦尼（Alexei Navalny）。他的支持者呼吁俄罗斯选民周日到投票站参加“中午反普京”抗议活动，以表达他们异议声音。
海内外抗议人士周日中午前往所在地区的投票站，参加反对派所宣称的“和平但具有像征意义”的抗议活动，反对普京连任。活动的目的是要拉低普京的得票数，建议方式包括投无效票，弄坏他们的选票，或者把票投给普京以外其他3名候选人其中一人。但反对派知道，这3名候选人没有一人能够对普京构成任何可信的挑战。这3人被称为“体制内的反对派”，只是象征性的对手，他们所在政党普遍支持普京领导的政府。
纳瓦尼的盟友在YouTube上播放的视频显示，周日中午，人们在俄罗斯各地不同投票站排队的情况。而在亚洲和欧洲的中午时段，海外抗议者聚集在俄罗斯外交使团的投票站。纳瓦尼的遗孀尤利娅（Yulia）出现在俄罗斯驻柏林大使馆，参加中午抗议活动。
纳瓦尼去世前曾通过律师在社交媒体上发布信息，表明自己支持“中午反普京”计划。
俄罗斯外交部发言人玛丽亚‧扎哈罗娃（Maria Zakharova）质疑那些在驻外国大使馆投票的选民是否都是普京的反对者，并指责西方媒体散布有关这些事件的宣传。
她表示，这些人都是来投票的，“投给谁以及如何投票是他们的自由选择”。
克里姆林宫将纳瓦尼的政治盟友（其中大部分在俄罗斯境外）视为危险的极端分子，指控他们代表西方国家破坏俄罗斯的稳定。
由于俄罗斯幅员辽阔，横跨11个时区，抗议选民分散而不是集中在一起，因此很难估计有多少人参加了抗议活动。
尽管很多人参加了反普京的中午投票活动，但并非所有前往投票的选民都是反对人士。
为期三天的选举笼罩着乌克兰战争的阴影：乌克兰多次袭击俄罗斯的炼油厂，炮击俄罗斯地区，并试图用代理人部队突破俄罗斯边境。普京表示将进行报复。
自1999年年底以来一直担任俄罗斯总统或总理的普京，在这次大选中拿下新的六年任期几无悬念。这将使他超越约瑟夫‧斯大林（Josef Stalin），成为俄罗斯二百多年来在位时间最长的领导人。
translation:
On Sunday (March 17), the Russian election entered the last voting day. "Noon anti-Putin" protests against current President Vladimir Putin took place at polling stations at home and abroad. However, it is generally believed that this will not affect Putin's re-election.
Putin's most high-profile political rival was Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic exile last month. His supporters called on Russian voters to attend "noon anti-Putin" protests at polling stations on Sunday to express their dissent.
Protesters at home and abroad went to polling stations in their regions at noon on Sunday to participate in what the opposition claimed was a "peaceful but symbolic" protest against Putin's re-election. The purpose of the activity is to reduce Putin's vote count. The suggested methods include casting invalid votes, spoiling their votes, or voting for one of the three other candidates besides Putin. But the opposition knows that none of the three candidates can pose any credible challenge to Putin. These three people are called "opposition within the system" and are just symbolic opponents. Their parties generally support the government led by Putin.
Videos posted on YouTube by Navalny's allies showed people lining up at different polling stations across Russia at noon on Sunday. And during the midday hour in Asia and Europe, overseas protesters gathered at polling stations at Russian diplomatic missions. Navalny's widow, Yulia, showed up at the Russian embassy in Berlin for a midday protest.
Before his death, Navalny posted a message on social media through his lawyer, indicating his support for the "Noontime Anti-Putin" plan.
Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova questioned whether those voting at foreign embassies were all Putin opponents and accused Western media of spreading propaganda about the events.
She said that these people came to vote and "it is their free choice who to vote for and how to vote."
The Kremlin views Navalny's political allies, most of whom are outside Russia, as dangerous extremists, accusing them of destabilizing Russia on behalf of Western countries.
Because Russia is so vast, spanning 11 time zones, protest voters are dispersed rather than concentrated, making it difficult to estimate how many people took part in the protests.
Although many people turned out for the anti-Putin midday vote, not all voters who went to the polls were opponents.
The three-day election is looming over the shadow of war in Ukraine: Ukraine has repeatedly attacked Russian oil refineries, shelled Russian regions and tried to breach Russia's borders with proxy forces. Putin said he would retaliate.
Putin, who has served as Russia's president or prime minister since the end of 1999, has little doubt that he will win a new six-year term in this election. This would make him surpass Josef Stalin to become Russia's longest-serving leader in more than 200 years.
input:

title: Six more years of Putin will worry many countries. But not China | CNN
content:
Editor’s Note: Sign up for CNN’s Meanwhile in China newsletter which explores what you need to know about the country’s rise and how it impacts the world.


            For leaders across the West, Vladimir Putin’s inevitable landslide win in an election without true opposition was a reminder of his tight control over Russia’s political arena as his war against Ukraine grinds on.
    

            But Chinese leader Xi Jinping, and other leaders benefiting from Putin’s rejection of a Western-led global order, will be cheering his victory.
    

            With 99.8% of ballots counted, Putin amassed 87.3% of the vote, according to preliminary results reported Monday morning by Russia’s Central Election Commission.
    

            Xi congratulated the Russian leader in a call that day, saying his re-election “fully reflected the support of the Russian people,” Chinese state media reported. He also pledged that China would promote the “sustained” and “in-depth” development of the two countries’ strategic partnership, the report said.
    

            Xi has staked much on his relationship with Putin since the start of the Kremlin’s war more than two years ago, refusing to back away from the “no limits” partnership he declared with the Russian leader weeks before the invasion, while strengthening trade, security, and diplomatic ties.
input:

            With 99.8% of ballots counted, Putin amassed 87.3% of the vote, according to preliminary results reported Monday morning by Russia’s Central Election Commission.
    

            Xi congratulated the Russian leader in a call that day, saying his re-election “fully reflected the support of the Russian people,” Chinese state media reported. He also pledged that China would promote the “sustained” and “in-depth” development of the two countries’ strategic partnership, the report said.
    

            Xi has staked much on his relationship with Putin since the start of the Kremlin’s war more than two years ago, refusing to back away from the “no limits” partnership he declared with the Russian leader weeks before the invasion, while strengthening trade, security, and diplomatic ties.

title: How Russians are protesting the election
content:
In a separate update, she said there had been eight attempts at arson and that 214 ballots had been “irretrievably” damaged, according to Russian state news agency Tass.
Elsewhere, in a remote region of the Urals and in Putin’s hometown of St. Petersburg, protesters attempted to destroy ballot boxes using homemade Molotov cocktails in separate incidents, according to state media.
Tensions around the election have been growing in Russia since the death of primary opposition figure Alexei Navalny in an Arctic penal colony last month.
Navalny, an outspoken critic of Putin and of the Kremlin’s ongoing war in Ukraine, “lost consciousness” and died on a walk while imprisoned, according to authorities. Navalny’s wife, Yulia Navalnaya, alongside numerous international governments including the U.S., blamed Putin for his death.
A local election official in Moscow was detained for visiting a polling station wearing a T-shirt with “Navalny” written on it, according to Russian civil rights organization OVD-Info.
On Sunday, crowds of people appeared outside polling stations in Moscow and across Russia in a protest action called “Noon against Putin,” which was proposed by Navalny in one of his last public messages before his death.
The action, posthumously promoted by Navalny’s wife, was aimed at overwhelming polling stations, making it more difficult to vote or record voting data.
The action was designed to “help millions of people see like-minded people and realize that we are not alone,” Navalnaya said in a March YouTube address announcing the plans for polling day. “We are surrounded by people who are also against war, against corruption and against lawlessness.”
A Telegram post from Navalny’s team showed Yulia Navalnaya at a “Noon against Putin” event at the Russian Embassy in Berlin on Sunday, alongside crowds of supporters.
But the intended effects of the action remain vague, with little guidance from Navalny or his wife about whether assembled protesters should stage a sit-in, vote and spoil ballots, or attempt to block access to polling sites.
NBC News was not able to independently verify images of people crowding polling stations, nor was it able to determine if crowds were there to vote or had the intention of overwhelming election officials.
input:

Navalny, an outspoken critic of Putin and of the Kremlin’s ongoing war in Ukraine, “lost consciousness” and died on a walk while imprisoned, according to authorities. Navalny’s wife, Yulia Navalnaya, alongside numerous international governments including the U.S., blamed Putin for his death.
A local election official in Moscow was detained for visiting a polling station wearing a T-shirt with “Navalny” written on it, according to Russian civil rights organization OVD-Info.

The action was designed to “help millions of people see like-minded people and realize that we are not alone,” Navalnaya said in a March YouTube address announcing the plans for polling day. “We are surrounded by people who are also against war, against corruption and against lawlessness.”

title: 俄罗斯总统普京欢呼选举胜利与选举被批评为非法 | 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
这位俄罗斯领导人最著名的竞争对手阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼上个月在北极监狱去世。
对于1999年首次掌权的前克格勃中校普京来说，这一结果旨在向西方强调，无论是在战争还是和平时期，其领导人将不得不面对一个胆大妄为的俄罗斯。
美国表示，这次投票既不自由也不公平。
白宫国家安全委员会发言人表示：“鉴于普京先生如何监禁政治对手并阻止其他人与他竞选对手，这次选举显然不自由也不公平。”
英国外交大臣戴维·卡梅伦在 X 上发帖称，这次投票“不是自由公平选举的样子”。
乌克兰总统泽连斯基表示，“这种选举舞弊行为没有合法性，也不可能有任何合法性”。
这次选举距离普京于 2022 年 2 月发动俄乌战争已有两年多，这是二战以来欧洲最严重的冲突。
周日，数千名普京的反对者举行了针对他的抗议活动，尽管没有独立统计俄罗斯1.14亿选民中有多少人参加了示威活动。
纳瓦尔尼的支持者呼吁俄罗斯人出来参加“中午反对普京”抗议活动。
在新闻发布会上，普京自纳瓦尔尼去世以来首次提及他的名字，称他支持释放纳瓦尔尼以换取西方国家关押的囚犯的提议。
普京说：“跟我说话的人还没说完，我就说‘我同意’。”
俄罗斯前总统鲍里斯·叶利钦辞职后，普京首次被提名为代总统。 随后，他于 2000 年 3 月赢得了第一次总统选举，并于 2004 年赢得了第二个任期。
在担任两届总统后，普京于 2008 年重新担任总理，以规避宪法禁止连续担任两届以上国家元首的禁令。
但他于2012年重返总统宝座，并于2018年赢得第四个任期。
translation:
The Russian leader's most prominent rival, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic prison last month.
For Putin, a former KGB lieutenant colonel who first came to power in 1999, the result was intended to emphasize to the West that its leaders will have to face an emboldened Russia, both in war and in peace.
The United States said the vote was neither free nor fair.
"Given how Mr. Putin has imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running against him, it is clear that this election was neither free nor fair," a White House National Security Council spokesman said.
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron posted on X that the vote was "not what a free and fair election looks like."
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said, "This kind of electoral fraud has no legitimacy and cannot have any legitimacy."
The election comes more than two years after Putin launched the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022, Europe's worst conflict since World War II.
Thousands of Putin's opponents staged protests against him on Sunday, although there was no independent tally of how many of Russia's 114 million voters took part in the demonstrations.
Navalny's supporters called on Russians to come out and take part in the "Noon Against Putin" protest.
At a news conference, Putin mentioned Navalny's name for the first time since his death, saying he supported proposals to free Navalny in exchange for prisoners held by Western countries.
"I said 'I agree' before the person who spoke to me had finished speaking," Putin said.
Putin was nominated as acting president for the first time after former Russian President Boris Yeltsin resigned. He subsequently won his first presidential election in March 2000 and his second term in 2004.
After two terms as president, Putin returned as prime minister in 2008 to circumvent a constitutional ban on serving more than two consecutive terms as head of state.
But he returned to the presidency in 2012 and won a fourth term in 2018.

The Russian leader's most prominent rival, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic prison last month.
For Putin, a former KGB lieutenant colonel who first came to power in 1999, the result was intended to emphasize to the West that its leaders will have to face an emboldened Russia, both in war and in peace.
The United States said the vote was neither free nor fair.
"Given how Mr. Putin has imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running against him, it is clear that this election was neither free nor fair," a White House National Security Council spokesman said.
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron posted on X that the vote was "not what a free and fair election looks like."
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said, "This kind of electoral fraud has no legitimacy and cannot have any legitimacy."
The election comes more than two years after Putin launched the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022, Europe's worst conflict since World War II.
Thousands of Putin's opponents staged protests against him on Sunday, although there was no independent tally of how many of Russia's 114 million voters took part in the demonstrations.
Navalny's supporters called on Russians to come out and take part in the "Noon Against Putin" protest.
At a news conference, Putin mentioned Navalny's name for the first time since his death, saying he supported proposals to free Navalny in exchange for prisoners held by Western countries.
"I said 'I agree' before the person who spoke to me had finished speaking," Putin said.
Putin was nominated as acting president for the first time after former Russian President Boris Yeltsin resigned. He subsequently won his first presidential election in March 2000 and his second term in 2004.
After two terms as president, Putin returned as prime minister in 2008 to circumvent a constitutional ban on serving more than two consecutive terms as head of state.
But he returned to the presidency in 2012 and won a fourth term in 2018.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民: 至少俄罗斯人能投票
content:
中国外交部3月18日发布新闻稿称，中国国家主席习近平已致贺电给普京。习近平通过贺电表示:“你(普京)再次当选，充分体现了俄罗斯人民对你的支持。”他还重申，中方高度重视中俄关系发展，愿同俄方保持密切沟通，“推动中俄新时代全面战略协作伙伴关系持续健康稳定深入发展”。

中国外交部发言人林剑也于同日的例行记者会称:“中俄关系在习近平和普京的战略引领下，将持续向前发展。”

当然，早在中国政府表态前，普京已先一步向中国示好。

据官媒新华社报道，普京发表胜选谈话时表示，俄中关系是国际关系中的稳定因素，两国的国家利益一致，在经济和外交政策上也有许多共通点。普京说:“我们(俄中)的关系在过去二十年里不断成形，非常牢固，而且我们是互补的。我相信这种关系将会维持下去。”

对于中国最在意的台湾问题，普京也重申：“台湾是中国不可分割的一部分”。
中俄关系升级? 学者:习近平维持“表面中立”

虽然普京笃定执政至2030年，但在台北的国防安全研究院国家安全研究所副研究员刘萧翔认为，对习近平而言，中俄两国的现况十分微妙。

他说，中国至今都未对普京发动俄乌战争明确表态，是因为习近平很清楚，若在俄乌战事上与俄罗斯靠得太近，恐遭国际制裁，对中国不利，虽然他仍乐见普京继续执政，维持两国既有的“无上限”伙伴关系。

刘萧翔分析，俄乌战争仍将是影响中俄关系最重要的议题，且随着普京胜选，战事不会轻易终止。

刘萧翔告诉美国之音:“中国也会持续目前这个表面中立，(在)不违反制裁规定，、不会连累自己的前提下，提供俄国需要的支持，因为在美俄中三角关系里面，俄国还是唯一能够让中国依靠的伙伴。”

相对于北京官方的送暖，中国网民对普京的胜选看法略显分歧。

前《环球时报》总编辑胡锡进一向是支持中国官方立场的微博大V，他3月18日也发文祝贺普京并表态:“赞赏俄罗斯强硬对抗美西方的路线......支持国家尽最大努力平衡好在乌克兰问题上同西方的关系。”
translation:
The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a press release on March 18 stating that Chinese President Xi Jinping had sent a congratulatory message to Putin. Xi Jinping said in a congratulatory message: "Your (Putin) re-election fully reflects the support of the Russian people for you." He also reiterated that China attaches great importance to the development of Sino-Russian relations and is willing to maintain close communication with Russia to "promote a new era of China-Russia The comprehensive strategic partnership of cooperation continues to develop in a healthy, stable and in-depth manner."

Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian also said at a regular press conference on the same day: "China-Russia relations will continue to move forward under the strategic guidance of Xi Jinping and Putin."

Of course, Putin had already shown goodwill to China long before the Chinese government expressed its stance.

According to the official Xinhua News Agency, Putin said in his victory speech that Russia-China relations are a stabilizing factor in international relations. The two countries have consistent national interests and have many commonalities in economic and foreign policies. Putin said: "Our (Russia-China) relationship has been taking shape over the past two decades, is very strong, and we are complementary. I believe that this relationship will be maintained."

Regarding the Taiwan issue that China cares most about, Putin also reiterated: "Taiwan is an inalienable part of China."
Escalation of Sino-Russian relations? Scholar: Xi Jinping maintains "surface neutrality"

Although Putin is determined to stay in power until 2030, Liu Xiaoxiang, an associate researcher at the National Security Institute of the National Defense Security Institute in Taipei, believes that for Xi Jinping, the current situation between China and Russia is very delicate.

He said that China has not made a clear position on Putin’s launch of the Russia-Ukraine war because Xi Jinping is very clear that if he gets too close to Russia in the Russia-Ukraine war, he may be subject to international sanctions, which will be detrimental to China, although he is still happy to see Putin Continue to be in power and maintain the existing "unlimited" partnership between the two countries.

Liu Xiaoxiang analyzed that the Russia-Ukraine war will still be the most important issue affecting Sino-Russian relations, and with Putin's victory, the war will not end easily.

Liu Xiaoxiang told Voice of America: "China will continue its current superficial neutrality and provide the support Russia needs (under the premise of not violating sanctions and not compromising itself, because in the triangular relationship between the United States, Russia and China, Russia is still the only partner that China can rely on.”

Compared with Beijing's official support, Chinese netizens have slightly different views on Putin's victory.

Former "Global Times" editor-in-chief Hu Xijin has always been a Weibo influencer who supports China's official position. He also posted a message to congratulate Putin on March 18 and stated: "I appreciate Russia's tough line against the United States and the West...support the country to do its best. Try to balance the relationship with the West on the Ukraine issue.”

title: 俄罗斯大选普京获连任 国际指责选举不公 | 普京连任 | 威权统治 | 纳瓦尔尼 | 新唐人电视台
content:
【新唐人北京时间2024年03月19日讯】俄罗斯大选计票结果出炉，现任总统普京获得五连任。白宫和欧洲多个国家批评，选举违背自由公正原则，只是象征性的走过场。
上周日（3月17日），俄罗斯大选结束。俄选举委员会官方确认计票接近尾声，现任总统普京获得超过87%的选票，将第五次出任俄罗斯总统。
美国及欧洲民主国家普遍认为，普京进行威权统治，迫害并阻止竞选对手参选。上个月，其最大的竞选对手纳瓦尔尼在监狱猝逝。
德国外交部长贝尔博克：“俄罗斯的选举是一场没有选择的选举。”
欧盟外交政策负责人博雷尔：“这次选举是基于镇压和恐吓，并在乌克兰被占领土上举行，侵犯了乌克兰主权。”
英国外相卡梅伦周日发推文，谴责在乌克兰境内的投票非法，表示选举缺乏欧安组织的独立监督。
乌克兰总统泽连斯基：“这种选举没有一点合法性，也不可能有。”
被俄罗斯占领的乌克兰地区也要求民众参加投票。普京当选后声称，他派兵占领该地区，是得到当地民众的支持。
普京还想要在乌俄之间建立军事缓冲区，再通过和谈实现停火，遭到基辅民众的反对。
乌克兰基辅居民Antonina Khrypushkina：“我认为他（普京）会被自己的话噎住。（乌克兰）哈尔科夫永远不会成为灰色地带。”
在巴黎、伦敦、柏林、拉脱维亚等全球多地，包括俄罗斯民众，也举着标语集会，抗议普京当选，表达对乌克兰的支持。
俄罗斯选民：“俄罗斯的选举大多是伪造的。”
俄罗斯选民：“我不信任普京。我不信任普京的团队，我不同意这次选举的结果。”
translation:
[New Tang Dynasty News, Beijing time, March 19, 2024] The vote counting results of the Russian general election are out, and the current President Putin won a fifth term. The White House and many European countries criticized that the election violated the principles of freedom and fairness and was just a symbolic formality.
Last Sunday (March 17), the Russian election ended. The Russian Election Commission officially confirmed that the vote count is nearing completion. Current President Vladimir Putin received more than 87% of the votes and will serve as President of Russia for the fifth time.
The United States and European democracies generally believe that Putin rules authoritarianally and persecutes and prevents his opponents from running. Last month, his biggest election rival Navalny died suddenly in prison.
German Foreign Minister Berbock: "The election in Russia is an election without choice."
EU foreign policy chief Borrell said: "This election was based on repression and intimidation and was held in the occupied territories of Ukraine, violating Ukraine's sovereignty."
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron tweeted on Sunday that the vote in Ukraine was illegal and said the election lacked independent oversight by the OSCE.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky: "This kind of election has no legitimacy at all, and it cannot be possible."
People in regions of Ukraine occupied by Russia are also asking people to vote. After Putin was elected, he claimed that he had the support of the local people when he sent troops to occupy the area.
Putin also wanted to establish a military buffer zone between Ukraine and Russia and then achieve a ceasefire through peace talks, which was opposed by the people of Kiev.
Antonina Khrypushkina, resident of Kyiv, Ukraine: "I think he (Putin) will choke on his own words. Kharkiv (Ukraine) will never become a gray area."
People in Paris, London, Berlin, Latvia and other places around the world, including Russians, also held banners and rallied to protest Putin's election and express support for Ukraine.
Russian voters: “Russian elections are mostly fake.”
Russian Voter: “I don’t trust Putin. I don’t trust Putin’s team and I don’t agree with the outcome of this election.”
input:
[New Tang Dynasty News, Beijing time, March 19, 2024] The vote counting results of the Russian general election are out, and the current President Putin won a fifth term. The White House and many European countries criticized that the election violated the principles of freedom and fairness and was just a symbolic formality.
Last Sunday (March 17), the Russian election ended. The Russian Election Commission officially confirmed that the vote count is nearing completion. Current President Vladimir Putin received more than 87% of the votes and will serve as President of Russia for the fifth time.
The United States and European democracies generally believe that Putin rules authoritarianally and persecutes and prevents his opponents from running. Last month, his biggest election rival Navalny died suddenly in prison.
German Foreign Minister Berbock: "The election in Russia is an election without choice."
EU foreign policy chief Borrell said: "This election was based on repression and intimidation and was held in the occupied territories of Ukraine, violating Ukraine's sovereignty."
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron tweeted on Sunday that the vote in Ukraine was illegal and said the election lacked independent oversight by the OSCE.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky: "This kind of election has no legitimacy at all, and it cannot be possible."
People in regions of Ukraine occupied by Russia are also asking people to vote. After Putin was elected, he claimed that he had the support of the local people when he sent troops to occupy the area.
Putin also wanted to establish a military buffer zone between Ukraine and Russia and then achieve a ceasefire through peace talks, which was opposed by the people of Kiev.
Antonina Khrypushkina, resident of Kyiv, Ukraine: "I think he (Putin) will choke on his own words. Kharkiv (Ukraine) will never become a gray area."
People in Paris, London, Berlin, Latvia and other places around the world, including Russians, also held banners and rallied to protest Putin's election and express support for Ukraine.
Russian voters: “Russian elections are mostly fake.”
Russian Voter: “I don’t trust Putin. I don’t trust Putin’s team and I don’t agree with the outcome of this election.”

title: Vladimir Putin claims landslide Russian election victory | Vladimir Putin | The Guardian
content:
At an appearance at the Russian embassy in Berlin, Yulia Navalnaya urged her supporters to appear en masse in the symbolic show of strength, labelled “noon against Putin”. Her husband endorsed the plan before he died suddenly in an Arctic prison a month ago.
Navalnaya was greeted with huge applause and chants from voters and thanked people for turning up to honour her husband. “You give me hope that everything is not in vain, that we will still fight,” she said in a post on Sunday. She said she had written “Navalny” on her ballot paper.
The elections were quickly criticised by western countries. The US national security council spokesperson, John Kirby, said: “The elections are obviously not free nor fair given how Mr Putin has imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running against him.”
The Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, in an address on Sunday evening, said Putin had become “addicted to power”.
“This imitation of ‘elections’ has no legitimacy and cannot have any,” he said. “This person must end up in the dock in The Hague. This is what we must ensure, anyone in the world who values life and decency.”
The German foreign ministry wrote in a post on X that the “pseudo-election in #Russia is neither free nor fair, the result will surprise nobody. Putin’s rule is authoritarian, he relies on censorship, repression & violence.
input:

title: Путин победил на выборах даже в Германии
content:
Президент России Владимир Путин одержал победу на голосовании на территории Германии. Ему отдали предпочтение 44% избирателей. Вторым в гонке оказался Владислав Даванков. Об этом свидетельствуют официальные данные Центризбиркома.

Статистическое ведомство подвело итоги голосования за президента РФ не только на территории России, но и за ее пределами. Избирательные участки находились в том числе и в европейских странах. Сделать свой выбор могли граждане России за рубежом.

По результатам выборов, даже в Германии победу одержал действующий президент Владимир Путин. За него отдали свои голоса 44% пришедших на участок в Берлине избирателей. 37% голосов заработал Владислав Даванков, представляющий партию «Новые люди». В Бонне за Путина проголосовали более 65% граждан РФ, за Даванкова — меньше 20%, пишет «Главный региональный».

Официальные власти Германии решили, что не будет поздравлять с победой президента России Владимира Путина. Соответствующее сообщение распространила канцелярия правительства ФРГ.

Мировые лидеры не слишком охотно поздравили с переизбранием на пост. Это сделали его коллеги, с которыми Россия находится в теплых отношениях. Среди них — главы Гондураса, Никарагуа, Венесуэлы, Боливии, Кубы, Таджикистана, КНДР.
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin won the vote in Germany. He was preferred by 44% of voters. Vladislav Davankov was second in the race. This is evidenced by official data from the Central Election Commission.

The statistical agency has summed up the results of voting for the President of the Russian Federation not only on the territory of Russia, but also abroad. Polling stations were also located in European countries. Russian citizens abroad could make their choice.

According to the election results, even in Germany the current President Vladimir Putin won. 44% of voters who came to the polling station in Berlin voted for him. Vladislav Davankov, representing the New People party, earned 37% of the votes. In Bonn, more than 65% of Russian citizens voted for Putin, less than 20% voted for Davankov, writes “Chief Regional”.

German officials decided that they would not congratulate Russian President Vladimir Putin on his victory. The corresponding message was distributed by the German government office.

World leaders were reluctant to congratulate him on his re-election to office. This was done by his colleagues, with whom Russia has warm relations. Among them are the heads of Honduras, Nicaragua, Venezuela, Bolivia, Cuba, Tajikistan, and the DPRK.
input:
Russian President Vladimir Putin won the vote in Germany. He was preferred by 44% of voters. Vladislav Davankov was second in the race. This is evidenced by official data from the Central Election Commission.

The statistical agency has summed up the results of voting for the President of the Russian Federation not only on the territory of Russia, but also abroad. Polling stations were also located in European countries. Russian citizens abroad could make their choice.

According to the election results, even in Germany the current President Vladimir Putin won. 44% of voters who came to the polling station in Berlin voted for him. Vladislav Davankov, representing the New People party, earned 37% of the votes. In Bonn, more than 65% of Russian citizens voted for Putin, less than 20% voted for Davankov, writes “Chief Regional”.

German officials decided that they would not congratulate Russian President Vladimir Putin on his victory. The corresponding message was distributed by the German government office.

World leaders were reluctant to congratulate him on his re-election to office. This was done by his colleagues, with whom Russia has warm relations. Among them are the heads of Honduras, Nicaragua, Venezuela, Bolivia, Cuba, Tajikistan, and the DPRK.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举开启，普京呼吁“团结和自信”
content:
【环球时报综合报道】俄罗斯15日至17日举行总统选举正式投票，包括现任总统普京在内的4名候选人参选。俄中央选举委员会14日称，选举初步结果将于18日上午公布。这是俄罗斯自1991年以来第八次举行总统选举。外界普遍预测，普京将顺利赢得连任，开启新一届6年总统任期。

普京14日通过俄罗斯第一频道向俄民众发表讲话，指出本次选举结果将直接影响国家未来几年的发展。“我深信，你们知道我们的国家正在经历一个多么艰难的时期、我们在几乎所有领域都面对何其复杂的挑战。”他在讲话中说：“让我坦诚地说吧，如今参与选举（投票）就是爱国情感的体现。”“为了继续有尊严地应对这些挑战并成功克服困难，我们要继续保持团结和自信。”
据俄媒报道，今年大选4名候选人分别是：以自提名方式登记参选的普京、自民党领导人斯卢茨基、俄共党员哈里托诺夫，以及俄国家杜马副主席、新人党成员达万科夫。4名总统候选人中有2人曾参加过大选。普京曾4次参加大选，哈里托诺夫曾在2004年参与过一次大选。斯卢茨基和达万科夫今年则是第一次参选。在年龄方面，最年长的哈里托诺夫目前75岁；最年轻的是达万科夫，刚满40岁。全俄社会舆论研究中心3月进行的一项民调显示，75%的受访者称自己会投票给普京。其他几位候选人的支持率都低于10%。
俄塔社14日报道称，俄罗斯数字发展部部长沙达耶夫当天称，在俄总统选举投票期间，预计选举系统将遭到大量网络攻击，但该部已准备好应对这些攻击。俄中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃称，自今年选举活动开始以来，委员会网站已遭到1200万次攻击。俄中央选举委员会成员鲍里索夫14日称，西方这种“恐吓战术”同时针对前来俄罗斯观察选举的外国观察员，这是其在俄罗斯总统选举中“首次使用”。
translation:
[Global Times Comprehensive Report] Russia will hold formal voting for the presidential election from the 15th to the 17th. Four candidates, including current President Vladimir Putin, are running. Russia's Central Election Commission said on the 14th that the preliminary results of the election will be announced on the morning of the 18th. This is the eighth presidential election held in Russia since 1991. It is widely predicted by the outside world that Putin will successfully win re-election and start a new six-year presidential term.

Putin delivered a speech to the Russian people through Russia's Channel 1 on the 14th, pointing out that the results of this election will directly affect the country's development in the next few years. "I am convinced that you know what a difficult time our country is going through and how complex the challenges we face in almost every area." He said in his speech: "Let me be honest, participating in the election (voting) today ) is the embodiment of patriotic sentiment. "In order to continue to face these challenges with dignity and successfully overcome difficulties, we must continue to maintain unity and confidence."
According to Russian media reports, the four candidates for this year’s election are: Putin, who registered to run through self-nomination, Slutsky, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, Kharitonov, a member of the Russian Communist Party, and the deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma and the New People’s Party Member Davankov. Two of the four presidential candidates have participated in the general election. Putin has participated in the general election four times, and Kharitonov participated in the election once in 2004. Slutsky and Davankov are candidates for the first time this year. In terms of age, the eldest Kharitonov is currently 75 years old; the youngest is Davankov, who has just turned 40. A poll conducted by the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center in March showed that 75% of respondents said they would vote for Putin. Several other candidates have support ratings below 10%.
Itar-Tass news agency reported on the 14th that Russia’s Minister of Digital Development Shadayev said on the same day that the election system is expected to be subject to a large number of cyber attacks during the Russian presidential election voting, but the ministry is prepared to deal with these attacks. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that since the start of this year’s election campaign, the committee’s website has been attacked 12 million times. Borisov, a member of the Russian Central Election Commission, said on the 14th that this kind of "intimidation tactic" by the West also targets foreign observers who come to Russia to observe the election. This is the "first time" it has been used in the Russian presidential election.
input:
[Global Times Comprehensive Report] Russia will hold formal voting for the presidential election from the 15th to the 17th. Four candidates, including current President Vladimir Putin, are running. This is the eighth presidential election held in Russia since 1991. It is widely predicted by the outside world that Putin will successfully win re-election and start a new six-year presidential term.

Putin delivered a speech to the Russian people through Russia's Channel 1 on the 14th, pointing out that the results of this election will directly affect the country's development in the next few years. "I am convinced that you know what a difficult time our country is going through and how complex the challenges we face in almost every area." He said in his speech: "Let me be honest, participating in the election (voting) today ) is the embodiment of patriotic sentiment. "In order to continue to face these challenges with dignity and successfully overcome difficulties, we must continue to maintain unity and confidence."
According to Russian media reports, the four candidates for this year’s election are: Putin, who registered to run through self-nomination, Slutsky, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, Kharitonov, a member of the Russian Communist Party, and the deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma and the New People’s Party Member Davankov. Two of the four presidential candidates have participated in the general election. Putin has participated in the general election four times, and Kharitonov participated in the election once in 2004. Slutsky and Davankov are candidates for the first time this year. In terms of age, the eldest Kharitonov is currently 75 years old; the youngest is Davankov, who has just turned 40. A poll conducted by the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center in March showed that 75% of respondents said they would vote for Putin. Several other candidates have support ratings below 10%.
Itar-Tass news agency reported on the 14th that Russia’s Minister of Digital Development Shadayev said on the same day that the election system is expected to be subject to a large number of cyber attacks during the Russian presidential election voting, but the ministry is prepared to deal with these attacks. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that since the start of this year’s election campaign, the committee’s website has been attacked 12 million times. Borisov, a member of the Russian Central Election Commission, said on the 14th that this kind of "intimidation tactic" by the West also targets foreign observers who come to Russia to observe the election. title: Putin's Reelection Confirms Russia Is 'Authoritarian Society,' Says NATO Chief
content:
PRISTINA -- Kosovar Prime Minister Albin Kurti says he will not suspend a move by the central bank to ban the circulation of the Serbian dinar in parts of the country with Serbian majorities but will accept the forming of an Association of Serb-Majority Municipalities once Belgrade agrees to sign a basic agreement on bilateral relations.
The basic agreement for the normalization of relations with Serbia was reached in February 2023, and includes the formation of the association, which is expected to more adequately represent predominantly ethnic Serb areas in Kosovo.
Kosovo is not a member of the European Union or its common currency area, the eurozone, but it unilaterally adopted the euro in 2002 to help bring monetary stability and to simplify and reduce transaction costs inside and outside the country.
Serbia, which has never acknowledged its former province's 2008 declaration of independence, still pays many ethnic Serbs at institutions in Serb-dominated parts of Kosovo in dinars. Many also hold their pensions and get child allowances in dinars.
"Regarding the Serbian-dinar-versus-euro issue, it is Kosovo's central bank that decides and they have already decided on December 27 last year," Kurti told RFE/RL's Balkan Service in an interview on March 19, arguing that the ban, which came into force on February 1, was meant to fight financial crime and terrorism.
"We have, thanks to them, a new regulation that is going to enhance the integrity of the financial system to fight illicit activities financing terrorism," Kurti said in Pristina on the same day top Serbian and Kosovar negotiators were holding bilateral meeting in Brussels with EU special envoy Miroslav Lajcak.
The Serbian dinar ban was reported to be high on the agenda, although no joint trilateral meeting has been confirmed so far.
The ban ratcheted up already high tensions between Serbia and Kosovo and threatened to scupper efforts by Washington and Brussels to get the dialogue between Pristina and Belgrade back on track.

The ban ratcheted up already high tensions between Serbia and Kosovo and threatened to scupper efforts by Washington and Brussels to get the dialogue between Pristina and Belgrade back on track.

title: Putin ‘wins’ rigged Russian election with 87 percent of the vote – POLITICO
content:
From the moment the planned demonstration was announced, the Russian state mounted a concerted attempt to undermine it. Local authorities in Russia organized counterfeit public events at noon to distract voters.
In addition, there were several rounds of deceptive mailings targeted at opposition voters in Russia. The first, on Wednesday, falsely claimed to be from Navalny’s team, announcing a postponement of the action. Navalny’s team quickly denied any delay.
The second mailing, sent on Saturday, aimed to intimidate voters with a message saying, “Hi! Despite the fact that you support the ideas of an extremist organization, we are pleased you will vote in Moscow, as every vote matters! We urge you not to succumb to the ideas of those seeking to deceive you, and to vote calmly, without queues or provocations.”
Yekaterina Duntsova and Boris Nadezhdin — two potential candidates who advocated for immediate peace negotiations and an end to the war — were barred from running against Putin in the contest.
Foreign governments voiced their derision at the staged pro-Putin vote. “The pseudo-election in #Russia is neither free nor fair, the result will surprise nobody,” Germany’s foreign ministry posted on X. “Putin’s rule is authoritarian, he relies on censorship, repression & violence. The ‘election’ in the occupied territories of #Ukraine are null and void & another breach of international law.”
The White House National Security Council spokesperson said: “The elections are obviously not free nor fair given how Mr. Putin has imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running against him.”
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said: “These days, the Russian dictator is simulating another election. It is clear to everyone in the world that this figure, as it has already often happened in the course of history, is simply sick for power and is doing everything to rule forever.”
This developing story is being updated. Eva Hartog contributed reporting from Brussels and Tim Ross contributed reporting from London. Denis Leven is hosted at POLITICO under the EU-funded EU4FreeMedia residency program.

In addition, there were several rounds of deceptive mailings targeted at opposition voters in Russia. The first, on Wednesday, falsely claimed to be from Navalny’s team, announcing a postponement of the action. Navalny’s team quickly denied any delay.
The second mailing, sent on Saturday, aimed to intimidate voters with a message saying, “Hi! Despite the fact that you support the ideas of an extremist organization, we are pleased you will vote in Moscow, as every vote matters! We urge you not to succumb to the ideas of those seeking to deceive you, and to vote calmly, without queues or provocations.”
Yekaterina Duntsova and Boris Nadezhdin — two potential candidates who advocated for immediate peace negotiations and an end to the war — were barred from running against Putin in the contest.
Foreign governments voiced their derision at the staged pro-Putin vote. “The pseudo-election in #Russia is neither free nor fair, the result will surprise nobody,” Germany’s foreign ministry posted on X. “Putin’s rule is authoritarian, he relies on censorship, repression & violence. The ‘election’ in the occupied territories of #Ukraine are null and void & another breach of international law.”
The White House National Security Council spokesperson said: “The elections are obviously not free nor fair given how Mr. Putin has imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running against him.”
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said: “These days, the Russian dictator is simulating another election. It is clear to everyone in the world that this figure, as it has already often happened in the course of history, is simply sick for power and is doing everything to rule forever.”

title: Putin claims a new six-year term in vote condemned as not free or fair - The Washington Post
content:
“The elections took place in conditions where the state apparatus, which is obliged to be politically neutral and act in the interests of society, actually became involved in propaganda, coercion and control over voters,” read the statement. “Military censorship actually arose in the country which was implemented through fear and force.”
Golos added that politics in Russia have ceased to be a subject of discussion, “even with neighbors and loved ones.”
The country’s Central Election Commission claimed that in occupied areas of Ukraine’s Kherson and Zaporizhzhia regions, Putin won 88.12 percent and 92.95 percent of votes, respectively. Russia controls only parts of Kherson and Zaporizhzhia — two of four Ukrainian regions it illegally claims to have annexed — and many residents are displaced. In those occupied areas, Russian electoral teams accompanied by soldiers forced residents to cast ballots at gunpoint.
In Russia, voting took place from Friday through Sunday, a three-day window that critics said provided ample opportunity for fraud and manipulation. In many regions, voters were encouraged to use an opaque online voting system with no mechanism to assure accuracy or safeguard against cheating.
Russian independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta estimated that 31.6 million fake votes — almost half the total number of votes cast — were added to the count.
In remarks after midnight following the release of preliminary results late Sunday, Putin claimed broad public support and made clear that he would continue the war in Ukraine.
At Monday’s massive concert in Red Square, presenters onstage praised the election’s record turnout.
“I don’t remember the last time we have such a high turnout. … Even those who didn’t want to vote turned up,” said Ruslan Ostashko, a Russian TV presenter, apparently referring to the long lines of anti-Putin protesters who gathered at midday in a protest vote.
“My friends, in both Crimea and Sevastopol, more than 90 percent of voters voted for Putin, because he is our president and we trust in him,” added Yulia Baranovskaya, Ostashko’s co-presenter.
Putin, who took power upon Boris Yeltsin’s resignation on Dec. 31, 1999, has defied term limits since 2008, when, after serving the maximum two full terms, he swapped jobs with Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev. Four years later, they swapped again. In 2020, Putin engineered constitutional amendments allowing him to rule until 2036.
The three-day vote took place one month after the sudden death of Alexei Navalny, Putin’s most formidable political rival, in an Arctic prison colony.
The election was marked by signs of public fury, with several Russian citizens setting fire to voting urns and polling stations, and throwing liquid dye on ballots. On Sunday, thousands of people in Russia and abroad joined a noon protest, forming long lines at polling stations to vote against Putin. Navalny had called for the midday action before he died.
Meanwhile on Monday, six people died and eight were injured in a strike in Belgorod, the Russian city on the border with Ukraine where Ukrainian attacks have intensified in recent days, authorities said. According to the region’s governor, Vyacheslav Gladkov, a shell hit a private residential building in the village of Nikolskoye, killing four members of a family. A fifth member, a girl, survived.
“The girl is under the close attention of doctors in intensive care under a ventilator. She has a closed craniocerebral injury,” Gladkov said Monday evening.

title: 普京：北约若与俄罗斯冲突，距第三次世界大战仅一步之遥
content:
俄罗斯总统弗拉迪米尔·普京（Vladimir Putin）星期一（3月18日）警告西方说，若俄罗斯和北约之间发生直接冲突，那代表着世界距离第三次世界大战只有一步之遥。普京同时表示，没有人希望看到这种情况发生。
北约若与俄罗斯冲突，距离“三战”仅一步之遥
乌克兰战争引发了自1962年古巴导弹危机以来，莫斯科与西方关系的最严重危机。普京经常警告核战争的风险，但表示从未觉得有必要在乌克兰动用核武。
普京在“赢得”后苏联时代俄罗斯选举史上最大胜利后召开新闻发布会，当被问及法国上个月表示不排除未来在乌克兰部署地面部队、俄罗斯与北约发生冲突的风险和可能性时，普京先是讥讽回应，“现代世界一切都有可能。”
“每个人都很清楚，（若北约和俄罗斯发生冲突），距离第三次世界大战只有一步之遥。我想没有人乐见如此，”普京警告道。
普京也指称，北约军事人员已经出现在乌克兰了，俄军在战场上听见英语和法语。
“这对他们来说一点好处都没有，他们在战场上大量阵亡，”他说。
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会的数据，经计算约90%的选区，普京在没有实际对手的情况下，获得了87.2%的选票，以压倒性优势“赢得”俄罗斯大选。
在几乎没有抗议余地的情况下，许多俄罗斯人响应了反对派支持的“中午反普京”行动。人们集中在星期日中午投票，拥挤的投票站人潮反映人们对普京的不满。
过去200年主政最长的独裁者
尽管如此，这场可预期的“胜利”让现年71岁的普京对俄罗斯的统治将再延长至少六年。
如此一来，普京在位时间将不仅超越苏联时期的独裁者斯大林，而且成为俄罗斯过去200多年主政时间最长的领导人。
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin warned the West on Monday (March 18) that a direct conflict between Russia and NATO would mean that the world is only one step away from World War III. Putin also said that no one wants to see this happen.
If NATO conflicts with Russia, it will be only one step away from "three wars"
The war in Ukraine triggered the most serious crisis in relations between Moscow and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis. Putin has frequently warned of the risk of nuclear war but said he had never felt the need to use nuclear weapons in Ukraine.
Putin held a press conference after "winning" Russia's biggest electoral victory in the post-Soviet era, and was asked about France's statement last month that it would not rule out future ground troop deployments in Ukraine and the risk and possibility of a conflict between Russia and Nato. First came the sarcastic response, “In the modern world anything is possible.”
"Everyone knows very well that (if there is a conflict between NATO and Russia), World War III is only one step away. I don't think anyone wants to see that," Putin warned.
Putin also claimed that NATO military personnel have appeared in Ukraine and that Russian troops heard English and French on the battlefield.
"It did them no good at all and they were killed in large numbers on the battlefield," he said.
According to data from the Russian Central Election Commission, Putin received 87.2% of the votes in about 90% of the constituencies without actual opponents, "winning" the Russian election with an overwhelming advantage.
With little room for protest, many Russians responded to the opposition-backed "midday anti-Putin" campaign. People concentrated on voting at noon on Sunday, and the crowds at polling stations reflected dissatisfaction with Putin.
The longest dictator in power over the past 200 years
Nonetheless, this predictable "victory" will extend 71-year-old Putin's rule over Russia for at least another six years.
In this way, Putin will not only surpass Stalin, the dictator of the Soviet Union, but also become the longest-serving leader in Russia in the past 200 years.

title: 俄中央选举委员会：俄超半数选民已参加总统选举投票
content:
当地时间2024年3月16日，俄罗斯莫斯科，总统选举第二天，民众在投票站投票。视觉中国 图

据央视新闻3月17日报道，俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间16日发布数据称，截至莫斯科当地时间21时，在不计算提前远程投票的条件下，俄罗斯2024年总统选举的投票率已经达到58.1%。
2024年俄罗斯总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。俄现任总统普京、来自俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基、俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫和俄新人党的达万科夫将竞选下一届总统。
本次总统选举提前投票已于2月25日开始，在俄境内一些交通不便和偏远地区的选民从当天开始投票。旅居国外的俄选民从3月1日开始提前投票。本次俄总统选举投票还首次在多个地区引入远程电子投票方式。15日，克里姆林宫发布消息称，俄罗斯总统普京以在线形式参加俄罗斯总统选举的投票。
根据规定，总统选举计票工作将在投票结束后开始。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认选举最终结果，并在确认后3日内公布。
translation:
On March 16, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, people voted at the polling station on the second day of the presidential election. Visual China Map

According to CCTV News on March 17, Russia’s Central Election Commission released data on the 16th local time saying that as of 21:00 local time in Moscow, the turnout rate for Russia’s 2024 presidential election had reached 58.1%, excluding early remote voting. .
Official voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and Davankov from the New People's Party of Russia will run for the next president.
Early voting for this presidential election began on February 25, and voters in some inaccessible and remote areas in Russia began voting on that day. Russian voters living abroad will begin voting in advance on March 1. This Russian presidential election also introduced remote electronic voting in multiple regions for the first time. On the 15th, the Kremlin announced that Russian President Vladimir Putin will participate in the Russian presidential election online.
According to regulations, the counting of votes for the presidential election will begin after the polls close. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the final results of the election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after confirmation.
input:
On March 16, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, people voted at the polling station on the second day of the presidential election. Visual China Map

According to CCTV News on March 17, Russia’s Central Election Commission released data on the 16th local time saying that as of 21:00 local time in Moscow, the turnout rate for Russia’s 2024 presidential election had reached 58.1%, excluding early remote voting. .
Official voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and Davankov from the New People's Party of Russia will run for the next president.
Early voting for this presidential election began on February 25, and voters in some inaccessible and remote areas in Russia began voting on that day. Russian voters living abroad will begin voting in advance on March 1. This Russian presidential election also introduced remote electronic voting in multiple regions for the first time. On the 15th, the Kremlin announced that Russian President Vladimir Putin will participate in the Russian presidential election online.
According to regulations, the counting of votes for the presidential election will begin after the polls close. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the final results of the election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after confirmation.

title: 普京就俄总统选举结果发表讲话：对未来充满信心
content:
当地时间3月21日，普京就俄罗斯总统选举结果发表讲话。
普京特别感谢了选民对他本人的支持，认为这是对俄罗斯国家政治和经济方针的支持，是对大家共同取得成绩的支持。这些成绩如今已经使得俄罗斯更加强大和独立，但应该继续取得更大的成绩。普京还感谢选民的信任，承诺将尽个人最大努力不负信任。因为他本人深知，这种信任加重了他对俄罗斯和俄罗斯人民福祉的责任，需要其个人和其整个团队更加尽心尽力，更加高效地工作。普京同时表示，将竭尽全力确保近期在一系列讲话中详细谈到的大型国家项目和计划得到实施。
普京强调，选举表明，今天的俄罗斯是一个友好的大家庭。俄罗斯正沿着自己选择的历史道路共同前进，“我们对自己充满信心，对我们的力量充满信心，对我们的未来充满信心”。
俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃当天正式宣布，根据对所有选票的初步统计，俄罗斯现任总统普京获得87.28%的选票，赢得2024年总统选举。
translation:
On March 21, local time, Putin delivered a speech on the results of the Russian presidential election.
Putin especially thanked the voters for their support for him, believing that this is support for Russia's national political and economic policies and support for everyone's joint achievements. These achievements have made Russia stronger and more independent today, but they should continue to achieve greater results. Putin also thanked voters for their trust and promised to do his best to live up to their trust. Because he himself knows very well that this trust increases his responsibility for the well-being of Russia and the Russian people, requiring him and his entire team to work more diligently and efficiently. Putin also said that he will do his best to ensure that large-scale national projects and plans that have been discussed in detail in a series of recent speeches are implemented.
Putin emphasized that the election showed that Russia today is a friendly family. Russia is moving forward together along the historical path of its own choosing. "We are confident in ourselves, in our strength, and in our future."
Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced that day that according to preliminary statistics of all votes, current Russian President Vladimir Putin won 87.28% of the votes and won the 2024 presidential election.
input:
On March 21, local time, Putin delivered a speech on the results of the Russian presidential election.
Putin especially thanked the voters for their support for him, believing that this is support for Russia's national political and economic policies and support for everyone's joint achievements. These achievements have made Russia stronger and more independent today, but they should continue to achieve greater results. Putin also thanked voters for their trust and promised to do his best to live up to their trust. Because he himself knows very well that this trust increases his responsibility for the well-being of Russia and the Russian people, requiring him and his entire team to work more diligently and efficiently. Putin also said that he will do his best to ensure that large-scale national projects and plans that have been discussed in detail in a series of recent speeches are implemented.
Putin emphasized that the election showed that Russia today is a friendly family. Russia is moving forward together along the historical path of its own choosing. "We are confident in ourselves, in our strength, and in our future."
Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced that day that according to preliminary statistics of all votes, current Russian President Vladimir Putin won 87.28% of the votes and won the 2024 presidential election.

title: Putin extends rule in preordained Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era
content:
President Vladimir Putin extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring his determination Monday to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West.
After the harshest crackdown on dissent since Soviet times, it was clear from the earliest returns that Putin's nearly quarter-century rule would continue with a fifth term that grants him six more years. Still, Russians heeded a call to protest Putin’s repression and his war in Ukraine by showing up at polling stations at noon Sunday.
With all the precincts counted Monday, election officials said Putin had secured a record number of votes, underlining his total control over the political system. U.S. and other Western leaders denounced the election as a sham.
U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan said there was “nothing free or fair" about the election but seemingly resisted calls from Russia's opposition to not recognize Putin as the winner.
Ahead of the election, Putin's greatest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic penal colony, anti-war candidates were barred from the ballot and independent voices were silenced in a Kremlin-backed media blockade. No independent monitoring organizations were able to observe the election and analysts said online polling meant the vote was highly susceptible to manipulation.
input:
President Vladimir Putin extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring his determination Monday to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West.
After the harshest crackdown on dissent since Soviet times, it was clear from the earliest returns that Putin's nearly quarter-century rule would continue with a fifth term that grants him six more years. Still, Russians heeded a call to protest Putin’s repression and his war in Ukraine by showing up at polling stations at noon Sunday.
With all the precincts counted Monday, election officials said Putin had secured a record number of votes, underlining his total control over the political system. U.S. and other Western leaders denounced the election as a sham.
U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan said there was “nothing free or fair" about the election but seemingly resisted calls from Russia's opposition to not recognize Putin as the winner.
Ahead of the election, Putin's greatest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic penal colony, anti-war candidates were barred from the ballot and independent voices were silenced in a Kremlin-backed media blockade. No independent monitoring organizations were able to observe the election and analysts said online polling meant the vote was highly susceptible to manipulation.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举最后一天 异议人士呼吁以投票表达抗议
content:
俄罗斯总统选举于星期日（3月17日）进入最后一天，克里姆林宫批评人士呼吁在俄罗斯投票站举行大规模抗议活动。

这场将巩固俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京（Vladimir Putin）权力的投票过程并不平顺，包括乌克兰轰炸的激增、亲乌克兰破坏组织的入侵行动，及投票站出现一系列突发事件。有人向投票箱倾倒染料、有人试图焚烧投票箱、另有炸弹在投票站外爆炸等，各地多人遭到逮捕。

俄罗斯立法者建议出台一项新法律，对选举破坏者处以最高八年的监禁。

曾发起大规模反普京集会的俄罗斯反对派政治家阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼（Alexey Navalny），上个月在北极监狱过世。他曾敦促俄罗斯人在投票日最后一天发动抗议。

“中午反普京”

纳瓦尔尼的支持者发起一项名为“中午反普京”（Noon Against Putin）的行动，号召民众在星期日的中午集体到投票站投票，表达对普京的反对。

纳瓦尔尼的遗孀尤利娅·纳瓦尔纳娅（Yulia Navalnaya）对该行动表达支持。这是合法排队投票，无须担心被捕，又能表达反对意志。她呼吁抗议者同时大量出现，压垮投票所。她也呼吁抗议者在选票上写上“纳瓦尔尼”，或投给普京以外的候选人。

莫斯科当局一再警告民众不要参与异议活动。一名20多岁的俄罗斯公民告诉法新社，他将在当地时间星期日中午12时于莫斯科参与投票抗议活动，“只是为了看到周遭支持的年轻面孔...感受一些支持，看到这条黑暗隧道中的一线曙光。”

这名男子因为安全理由拒绝透露姓名。他说，他希望这场抗议，能向当局展现“这个国家有人反对（乌克兰）这场冲突、反对这个政权。”

与此同时，乌克兰无人机和导弹袭击再次袭击了俄罗斯。星期六（3月16日），乌克兰对与乌克兰接壤的贝尔哥罗德（Belgorod）进行新一波轰炸，造成两人死亡。俄罗斯国防部还表示，它挫败了“乌克兰破坏和侦察团体”从乌克兰苏梅地区进入该国的企图。

星期日，俄罗斯国防部又发布消息称，其防空部队在8个区域拦截并摧毁了35架乌克兰无人机，其中一架引发一家炼油厂起火。

普京矢言对这些攻击做出严厉回应，并指责乌克兰试图“破坏”他争取下一个任期的努力。

现年71岁的普京自1999年以来一直掌权，他在过去二十年中，建立了一个对国内镇压并与西方对抗的统治体系。

俄罗斯当局先前已禁止两名反对俄乌战争的候选人参选，在没有任何实质对手的情形下，普京几乎肯定会赢得这次选举。且由于宪法修正案延长了任期，若普京如预期般获胜，他将再任职6年，至少继续执政到2030年。

这位前克格勃特工，已经是自苏联时期领导人斯大林以来任职时间最长的俄罗斯领导人。

普京在选举前夕的讲话中表示，俄罗斯正经历一个“困难时期”。

“我们需要继续团结和自信，”他说，并将选举描述为俄罗斯人展示“爱国情怀”的一种方式。

俄罗斯声称已并吞的5个乌克兰东部被占领地区也举行了投票，包括克里米亚半岛。

投票将于格林威治标准时间3月17日的18时结束，预计不久后将宣布出口民意调查。

根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会，截至星期六晚间，已有超过6300万选民前往投票站投票。
translation:
Russia's presidential election enters its final day on Sunday (March 17), with Kremlin critics calling for mass protests at Russian polling stations.

The vote that will consolidate the power of Russian President Vladimir Putin has been rocky, marked by a surge in bombings in Ukraine, incursions by pro-Ukrainian sabotage groups and a series of incidents at polling stations. Some people poured dye into ballot boxes, some tried to burn ballot boxes, and bombs exploded outside polling stations. Many people were arrested in various places.

Russian lawmakers have proposed a new law that would punish election saboteurs with up to eight years in prison.

Alexey Navalny, a Russian opposition politician who organized massive anti-Putin rallies, died in an Arctic prison last month. He had urged Russians to stage protests on the final day of voting.

“Anti-Putin at noon”

Navalny's supporters launched an action called "Noon Against Putin" (Noon Against Putin), calling on people to vote collectively at the polling stations at noon on Sunday to express their opposition to Putin.

Navalny's widow, Yulia Navalnaya, expressed support for the action. This is a legal queue to vote without fear of arrest, and you can express your opposition. She called on protesters to show up in large numbers at once and overwhelm polling places. She also called on protesters to write "Navalny" on their ballots or vote for a candidate other than Putin.

Moscow authorities have repeatedly warned people not to participate in dissident activities. A Russian citizen in his 20s told AFP that he would participate in a voting protest in Moscow at 12 noon local time on Sunday, "just to see the supportive young faces around him... to feel some support and see this A ray of light in a dark tunnel.”

The man declined to be named for security reasons. He said he hoped the protest would show authorities that "there are people in this country who are against this conflict (in Ukraine) and against this regime."

Meanwhile, Ukrainian drone and missile strikes hit Russia again. On Saturday (March 16), Ukraine launched a new wave of bombings in Belgorod, which borders Ukraine, killing two people. The Russian Defense Ministry also said it foiled an attempt by "Ukrainian sabotage and reconnaissance groups" to enter the country from Ukraine's Sumy region.

On Sunday, the Russian Ministry of Defense announced that its air defense forces intercepted and destroyed 35 Ukrainian drones in eight areas, one of which caused a fire at an oil refinery.

Putin has vowed to respond harshly to the attacks and accused Ukraine of trying to "sabotage" his bid for another term in office.

Putin, 71, has been in power since 1999 and has spent the past two decades building a system of domestic repression and confrontation with the West.

Russian authorities have previously banned two candidates who oppose the Russo-Ukrainian war from running. Without any real opponents, Putin is almost certain to win this election. And because the constitutional amendment extended the term, if Putin wins as expected, he will serve for another six years, at least until 2030.

The former KGB agent is already the longest-serving Russian leader since Soviet-era leader Joseph Stalin.

In a speech on the eve of the election, Putin said that Russia was going through a "difficult period."

"We need to continue to be united and confident," he said, describing the election as a way for Russians to show their "patriotism."

Voting was also held in five occupied regions of eastern Ukraine that Russia claims to have annexed, including the Crimean peninsula.

Voting will close at 18:00 GMT on March 17, with exit polls expected to be announced shortly.

According to Russia's Central Election Commission, more than 63 million voters had gone to the polls as of Saturday evening.

title: Who congratulated Putin on his election victory and what does it say about global alliances? | Russia | The Guardian
content:
China and Russia are also members of the Brics group of emerging economies, which aim to challenge US domination of the global economy by uniting emerging economies including Brazil, South Africa and India.
After Russia began its war against Ukraine, 141 countries voted in favour of a UN resolution condemning the invasion. However, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU), that headline figure conceals the reality that two-thirds of the world’s population live in countries that were neutral or Russia-leaning.
The EIU’s analysis found countries including Brazil, Saudi Arabia, South Africa – and most importantly India – have done their utmost to avoid picking sides in the conflict.
On Monday, India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, echoed Xi, saying he looked forward to strengthening New Delhi’s “time-tested special and privileged strategic partnership” with Moscow.
Since Russia’s war against Ukraine began in February 2022, Modi has walked a diplomatic tightrope that has seen him refuse to take a forceful stance against the invasion.
In recent years, India has sought to position itself as a global powerhouse. Newly minted as the world’s most populous country – as well as its fifth-largest and fastest-growing economy – western leaders have rolled out the red carpet for Modi, despite his government overseeing a period of democratic backsliding and growing authoritarianism.
At the same time, Modi has positioned himself as a leader of the global south – a loose collection of developing countries and formerly colonised nations – many of which continue to support Russia.
India has also emerged as the single biggest buyer of Russian oil. India’s refineries have taken advantage of vastly reduced prices, after Europe banned Russian oil imports.
