title: Российские «выборы»: взгляд изнутри и со стороны
content:
Независимые эксперты говорят о рекордных фальсификациях в ходе российской президентской кампании-2024

Российская Центральная избирательная комиссия (ЦИК) обнародовала итоги президентских выборов в стране. Их победителем, как и ожидалось, был официально объявлен Владимир Путин, набравший, согласно российскому ЦИК, 87,28% голосов (свыше 76 миллионов человек).

Ничего не изменилось в положении остальных кандидатов в президенты. Они выстроились в прежнем ранжире: Николай Харитонов (КП РФ), Владислав Даванков («Новые люди»), Леонид Слуцкий (ЛДПР). На троих они заработали около 11% и полтора миллиарда бюджетных рублей для своих партий.

Ни один независимый антивоенный кандидат к выборам допущен не был.

Как сообщало «Радио Свобода», почти 22 миллиона голосов, полученных Владимиром Путиным на президентских выборах, были сфальсифицированы. Об этом пишет издание «Важные истории», которое провело расчеты по методу Шпилькина.

К аналогичному выводу о количестве сфальсифицированных голосов пришел исследователь выборов Иван Шукшин. Это самый масштабный вброс на федеральных выборах в истории России, отмечает Движение в защиту прав избирателей «Голос». По словам Шукшина, основным инструментом фальсификаций у избирательных комиссий был калькулятор – когда комиссия вносит в протокол выдуманные данные. Также было замечено занижение цифр одного из конкурентов Путина на выборах Владислава Даванкова – его ставили на третье место с помощью фальсификаций, пишет исследователь.

Ранее «Голос» сообщал о ряде нарушений в ходе голосования и подсчета голосов: в том числе возможных вбросах, «карусельном голосовании» и централизованном голосовании бюджетников. Саму президентскую кампанию «Голос» назвал «самой бессодержательной» в истории современной России.

Суть метода электорального аналитика Сергея Шпилькина заключается в том, что соотношение голосов, отданных за разных кандидатов, не должно меняться в зависимости от явки. Если с увеличением явки результат одного из кандидатов резко растет, это свидетельствует о фальсификациях.
translation:
Independent experts speak of record-breaking fraud during the 2024 Russian presidential campaign

The Russian Central Election Commission (CEC) announced the results of the presidential elections in the country. Their winner, as expected, was officially declared Vladimir Putin, who, according to the Russian Central Election Commission, received 87.28% of the votes (over 76 million people).

Nothing has changed in the position of the other presidential candidates. They lined up in the same ranking: Nikolai Kharitonov (CP RF), Vladislav Davankov (New People), Leonid Slutsky (LDPR). Between the three of them they earned about 11% and one and a half billion budget rubles for their parties.

Not a single independent anti-war candidate was allowed to stand in the elections.

As Radio Liberty reported, almost 22 million votes received by Vladimir Putin in the presidential election were rigged. The publication “Important Stories” writes about this, which carried out calculations using Shpilkin’s method.

Election researcher Ivan Shukshin came to a similar conclusion about the number of fraudulent votes. This is the largest fraud in federal elections in the history of Russia, notes the Movement for the Protection of Voter Rights “Voice”. According to Shukshin, the main tool for falsification of election commissions was a calculator - when the commission enters fictitious data into the protocol. An underestimation of the figures of one of Putin’s competitors in the elections, Vladislav Davankov, was also noticed - he was put in third place with the help of falsifications, the researcher writes.

Previously, Golos reported on a number of violations during voting and vote counting: including possible stuffing, “carousel voting” and centralized voting of state employees. Golos called the presidential campaign itself “the most meaningless” in the history of modern Russia.

The essence of the method of electoral analyst Sergei Shpilkin is that the ratio of votes cast for different candidates should not change depending on the turnout. If, with an increase in turnout, the result of one of the candidates increases sharply, this indicates fraud.

Independent experts speak of record-breaking fraud during the 2024 Russian presidential campaign

The Russian Central Election Commission (CEC) announced the results of the presidential elections in the country. Their winner, as expected, was officially declared Vladimir Putin, who, according to the Russian Central Election Commission, received 87.28% of the votes (over 76 million people).

Nothing has changed in the position of the other presidential candidates. They lined up in the same ranking: Nikolai Kharitonov (CP RF), Vladislav Davankov (New People), Leonid Slutsky (LDPR). Between the three of them they earned about 11% and one and a half billion budget rubles for their parties.

Not a single independent anti-war candidate was allowed to stand in the elections.

As Radio Liberty reported, almost 22 million votes received by Vladimir Putin in the presidential election were rigged. The publication “Important Stories” writes about this, which carried out calculations using Shpilkin’s method.

Election researcher Ivan Shukshin came to a similar conclusion about the number of fraudulent votes. This is the largest fraud in federal elections in the history of Russia, notes the Movement for the Protection of Voter Rights “Voice”. According to Shukshin, the main tool for falsification of election commissions was a calculator - when the commission enters fictitious data into the protocol. An underestimation of the figures of one of Putin’s competitors in the elections, Vladislav Davankov, was also noticed - he was put in third place with the help of falsifications, the researcher writes.

Previously, Golos reported on a number of violations during voting and vote counting: including possible stuffing, “carousel voting” and centralized voting of state employees. Golos called the presidential campaign itself “the most meaningless” in the history of modern Russia.

The essence of the method of electoral analyst Sergei Shpilkin is that the ratio of votes cast for different candidates should not change depending on the turnout. If, with an increase in turnout, the result of one of the candidates increases sharply, this indicates fraud.

title: Inside the Kremlin's party as Putin celebrates election win
content:
Fans took selfies with Vovan and Lexus, two Russian comedians who have humbled world leaders over the years. In 2020, the duo prank called Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., pretending to be Putin. 
Why had they never prank-called the Russian leader himself? “Do you think it’s appropriate to do that in a time of war,” the duo responded to NBC News. “And even before the war, we were not interested … we have had conflict with Ukraine for a very long time.”
Throughout the weekend, there had been small signs of real opposition. 
Earlier in the day, lines of voters appeared to honor Navalny’s call to turn up at polling stations en masse at noon, one of his final ideas to protest against the election and Putin’s rule.
Meanwhile, on the outskirts of Moscow, the barred anti-war hopeful Boris Nadezhdin left his home to vote. 
He was just 20 miles from the election celebrations Sunday, but it may as well have been a world away. 
Flanked by his family, supporters and huge banks of dirty snow, the liberal politician cast his vote at a kindergarten-turned-polling station. 
Nadezhdin brought his two sons, the eldest of whom helped him place his ballot in the box. His mother arrived as cameras waited for Nadezhdin outside. Before talking to the press, he escorted her back inside to help her vote, asking reporters and camera crews to wait a while.
It was a stark contrast to Putin, who voted Friday alone on a computer at his desk.
“Of course, our election is not very fair and not very free,” Nadezhdin told NBC News outside the polling station — a message echoed by Western leaders Monday.
He said he was prevented from running because he would have been a real challenge to Putin. People would have actually voted for him, he said.
Asked if he feared for his life, he said he only worried about his family. “I am sure that [someday] we will have normal, democratic, free and fair elections in the Russian Federation … of course, not on this day ... but I do my best,” Nadezhdin said.
“I hope that I will be alive until the day of free elections in the Russian Federation,” he added.
Keir Simmons and Natasha Lebedeva reported from Moscow and Matthew Bodner from London.

title: 路透：普京“胜选连任”后五月将访华与习近平举行峰会
content:
刚在一场没有真正对手的总统大选中”胜选连任”的俄罗斯总统弗拉迪米尔·普京（Vladimir Putin）将于今年5月再次访华，并与中国国家主席习近平举行双边峰会。
路透社星期二（3月19日）引述五位不愿具名的消息人士的话报道说，这将是普京胜选连任后的首次出国访问，而习近平也很可能将是普京拿下又一个六年任期后会晤的首位外国领导人。
俄罗斯在普京发动的侵略乌克兰战争进入第三个年头之际举行新的总统大选，但是真正受到民意支持的两位反战候选人却被克里姆林宫禁止参选，而普京最害怕的反对派领导人奥列克西·纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）上个月在西伯利亚北极圈内一所监狱中不明不白地死亡，因此普京在星期天结束的选举中取得“压倒性”的胜利并不令人意外。
西方国家政府星期一纷纷发表声明，谴责俄罗斯的这次大选既不公平，又不民主。但是中国、印度和朝鲜领导人则分别向普京发出贺电，祝贺他再次赢得下一个六年任期。
路透社表示，自从普京发动入侵乌克兰的战争以来，国际地缘政治的裂痕正在日益扩大。
“普京将访问中国，”其中一位不愿具名的知情人士向路透社表示。其他四位不相干的知情人士则向路透社证实了此事，只是这四人也不愿表明身份。
消息人士中的一人表示，普京很可能在5月的下半月访华。另两位消息人士认为，普京将在习近平预定的对欧洲访问出发前前往北京访问。
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has just been re-elected in a presidential election without a real opponent, will visit China again in May this year and hold a bilateral summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping.
Reuters reported on Tuesday (March 19), citing five unnamed sources, that this will be Putin’s first overseas visit after his re-election, and Xi Jinping is also likely to be Putin’s candidate for another six-year term. The first foreign leader to meet later.
Russia holds a new presidential election as Putin's war of aggression against Ukraine enters its third year, but two anti-war candidates who are truly supported by public opinion are banned from running by the Kremlin, and the opposition leader Putin fears most Following the mysterious death of Alexei Navalny in a prison above the Siberian Arctic Circle last month, Putin's "landslide" victory in the election that ended on Sunday came as no surprise.
Western governments issued statements on Monday, condemning Russia's election as unfair and undemocratic. However, the leaders of China, India and North Korea sent congratulatory messages to Putin, congratulating him on winning another six-year term.
Reuters stated that since Putin launched the war to invade Ukraine, the rifts in international geopolitics are growing day by day.
"Putin will visit China," one of the people told Reuters on condition of anonymity. Four other unrelated people with knowledge of the matter confirmed the matter to Reuters, but these four people also declined to identify themselves.
One of the sources said Putin is likely to visit China in the second half of May. Two other sources believe Putin will visit Beijing before Xi Jinping's scheduled visit to Europe.

Russia holds a new presidential election as Putin's war of aggression against Ukraine enters its third year, but two anti-war candidates who are truly supported by public opinion are banned from running by the Kremlin, and the opposition leader Putin fears most Following the mysterious death of Alexei Navalny in a prison above the Siberian Arctic Circle last month, Putin's "landslide" victory in the election that ended on Sunday came as no surprise.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
content:
“城市中最焦虑的富人和西方化的俄罗斯人都去了国外，而那些留下来的人则有足够的资源在新的现实中找到自己的方向。”他在撰文中分析道。
赫尔辛基大学教授格尔曼也认为，由于国家推动的支出，一部分不太富裕的人口大大改善了生存状况。至于俄罗斯社会中较富裕阶层，他们往往会以各种方式适应不断变化的环境。
“2023年，俄罗斯形成了新的中产阶级群体。虽然它的核心是受过教育的专家和商人，金融部门的员工和IT行业的代表，但现在军方和安全部门的人加入了进来。”曾就职于俄罗斯央行的亚历山德拉·普罗科彭科在他的分析文章中写道，并对俄罗斯经济过热的体征发出警告。
俄政府的计划草案显示，自特别军事行动爆发以来，俄罗斯通货膨胀加速，卢布下跌，到2024年，国防开支将占俄罗斯总预算开支的近三分之一。
伦敦国王学院的俄罗斯军事问题专家大卫·贝茨教授持不同看法。“虽然俄罗斯在经济、人口、卫生和社会方面都存在许多问题，但与之前相比，它们正在改善，而且实际上改善的速度比预期的要快。”他说。
“在过去的两年里，我从像我这样的分析人士和学者那里听到了一千次‘俄罗斯是这样想的’或‘普京是那样想的’，但事实是，我不知道俄罗斯想要什么，也不知道普京是怎么想的。”大卫·贝茨说，“普京是一个务实的现实主义者。”
translation:
"The most anxious wealthy and Westernized Russians in the city have gone abroad, while those who stayed have enough resources to find their own direction in the new reality." He analyzed in the article.
Professor Gelman of the University of Helsinki also believes that due to state-driven spending, a part of the less wealthy population has greatly improved their living conditions. As for the wealthier segments of Russian society, they tend to adapt to changing circumstances in various ways.
"In 2023, a new middle class group has formed in Russia. While its core is composed of educated experts and businessmen, employees of the financial sector and representatives of the IT industry, it is now joined by people from the military and security services." Zeng Alexandra Prokopenko, who works for the Russian Central Bank, wrote in her analysis and warned of signs of overheating in the Russian economy.
The Russian government's draft plan shows that since the outbreak of special military operations, Russian inflation has accelerated and the ruble has fallen. By 2024, defense spending will account for nearly one-third of Russia's total budget spending.
Professor David Bates, an expert on Russian military affairs at King's College London, takes a different view. "Although Russia has many problems economically, demographically, health-wise and socially, they are improving compared to before, and actually improving faster than expected," he said.
"I've heard a thousand times over the past two years from analysts and academics like me 'Russia thinks this' or 'Putin thinks that' but the truth is, I don't know what Russia wants I don’t know what Putin thinks,” David Bates said, “Putin is a pragmatic realist.”
input:
"The most anxious wealthy and Westernized Russians in the city have gone abroad, while those who stayed have enough resources to find their own direction in the new reality." He analyzed in the article.
Professor Gelman of the University of Helsinki also believes that due to state-driven spending, a part of the less wealthy population has greatly improved their living conditions. As for the wealthier segments of Russian society, they tend to adapt to changing circumstances in various ways.
"In 2023, a new middle class group has formed in Russia. While its core is composed of educated experts and businessmen, employees of the financial sector and representatives of the IT industry, it is now joined by people from the military and security services." Zeng Alexandra Prokopenko, who works for the Russian Central Bank, wrote in her analysis and warned of signs of overheating in the Russian economy.
The Russian government's draft plan shows that since the outbreak of special military operations, Russian inflation has accelerated and the ruble has fallen. By 2024, defense spending will account for nearly one-third of Russia's total budget spending.
Professor David Bates, an expert on Russian military affairs at King's College London, takes a different view. "Although Russia has many problems economically, demographically, health-wise and socially, they are improving compared to before, and actually improving faster than expected," he said.
"I've heard a thousand times over the past two years from analysts and academics like me 'Russia thinks this' or 'Putin thinks that' but the truth is, I don't know what Russia wants I don’t know what Putin thinks,” David Bates said, “Putin is a pragmatic realist.”

title: With Russian opposition exiled, Berlin becomes center of anti-Putin protest  - The Washington Post
content:
nA concert in front of the embassy saw speeches from most major opposition figures, including exiled oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky, highlighting the German capital’s new role as a center for Russia’s opposition in exile.
For Navalny’s team, which now operates from Germany and Lithuania, Sunday was the key day of the three-day election as they urged Russians at home and abroad to come to polling stations for a “Noon Without Putin” demonstration — honoring Navalny’s final call to action before his sudden death last month in a Russian penal colony.
“I see that all these people came to our demonstration at noon because all that time I waited in line, people screamed and chanted words of support, and I thank them all,” Navalnaya said as she exited the embassy. In a recent video address, she said she intends to continue her husband’s work.
“You must all wonder whom I voted for — of course I wrote ‘Navalny’ on the ballot because it cannot just be that Putin’s main opponent, who was already in jail, was killed a month before the election,” she said.
Germany stepped up when Navalny was on the brink of death in 2020, as he fell gravely ill after being poisoned by a nerve agent. Then-Chancellor Angela Merkel immediately offered the Navalny family treatment in Germany and personally visited the politician in the Charite clinic once he woke up from a coma.
In early 2021, Navalny returned to Russia, refusing to become a politician in exile. He was arrested immediately upon landing at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo airport and later sentenced to 19 years in prison on charges related to his anti-corruption work.
He died suddenly in February at age 47 in a remote Arctic prison. Authorities attributed his death to natural causes; his team accused the Russian government of killing him.
A close Navalny associate, Maria Pevchikh, alleged that he was close to being released in a prisoner exchange that would have seen him and two U.S. nationals swapped for Vadim Krasikov, a convicted Russian hit man serving a life sentence in a German prison. But Putin, Pevchikh said, could not tolerate his main rival walking free.
“In my view, [Navalny’s death] is a sign that the system is slowly crumbling,” Elizaveta said. “It seems that everything is going in that direction, that our autocracy is slowly falling apart.”

“You must all wonder whom I voted for — of course I wrote ‘Navalny’ on the ballot because it cannot just be that Putin’s main opponent, who was already in jail, was killed a month before the election,” she said.
Germany stepped up when Navalny was on the brink of death in 2020, as he fell gravely ill after being poisoned by a nerve agent. Then-Chancellor Angela Merkel immediately offered the Navalny family treatment in Germany and personally visited the politician in the Charite clinic once he woke up from a coma.
In early 2021, Navalny returned to Russia, refusing to become a politician in exile. He was arrested immediately upon landing at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo airport and later sentenced to 19 years in prison on charges related to his anti-corruption work.

A close Navalny associate, Maria Pevchikh, alleged that he was close to being released in a prisoner exchange that would have seen him and two U.S. nationals swapped for Vadim Krasikov, a convicted Russian hit man serving a life sentence in a German prison. title: ЦИК РФ: Путин побеждает на выборах с рекордным результатом
content:
Действующий президент России Владимир Путин побеждает на выборах с рекордным результатом. По данным ЦИК РФ, по итогам обработки 70% протоколов он набирает более 87%.

Действующий российский президент Владимир Путин побеждает на президентских выборах с рекордными результатом и явкой.

Как утверждают в Центризбиркоме, по итогам обработки 70% протоколов он набирает 87,17% голосов. На втором месте — Николай Харитонов от КПРФ (4,19%), на третьем — Владислав Даванков от "Новых людей" (4,08%), на четвертом — Леонид Слуцкий от ЛДПР (3,15%).

Явка, с учетом дистанционного голосования, превысила 74%.

Сам Владимир Путин уже выступил на сцене Гостиного двора в Москве перед волонтерами и сотрудниками своего штаба, поблагодарив их за работу.


"Полдень против Путина"
Несмотря на угрозы прокуратуры, предложения проголосовать через интернет и фейки об отмене мероприятия, тысячи россиян пришли в 12 часов в воскресенье на избирательные участки. Ранее оппозиция призвала несогласных с политикой действующего президента РФ принять участие в акции "Полдень против Путина".

В Москве очереди из желающих проголосовать в полдень наблюдались на нескольких участках. В МФТИ, где преподавал и проголосовал Борис Надеждин, студенты стали скандировать его имя. Его не допустили на выборы после того, как в феврале ЦИК признал недействительными часть собранных в его поддержку подписей.

За границей, у российских диппредставительств, к полудню собрались многочасовые очереди из желающих проголосовать россиян. В некоторых городах им приходилось ждать в очереди по 6-7 часов.

Одна из крупнейших акций за рубежом прошла в Берлине. По некоторым оценкам, в ней приняли участие около двух тысяч человек.


Вдова Алексея Навального Юлия пришла в полдень к посольству РФ в Германии, чтобы проголосовать, как и десятки других россиян. На акции также был замечен Михаил Ходорковский. 

Задержания и нарушения
По данным ОВД-Инфо, к вечеру воскресенья как минимум 80 человек были задержаны в 20 российских городах. Людей задерживали за надписи на бюллетенях и даже просто за то, что они пришли в полдень, как в Казани.

Независимые наблюдатели отметили многочисленные нарушения в организации голосования. Кроме вбросов и "каруселей", сообщалось и то, что на некоторых участках кабинки для голосования были без шторок: сотрудники полиции следили за тем, что отмечают в бюллетене голосующие, и задерживали их, если им это не нравилось.
translation:
The current Russian President Vladimir Putin wins the election with a record result. According to the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation, based on the results of processing 70% of protocols, it scores more than 87%.

Incumbent Russian President Vladimir Putin wins the presidential election with record results and turnout.

According to the Central Election Commission, based on the results of processing 70% of the protocols, he gains 87.17% of the votes. In second place is Nikolai Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation (4.19%), in third is Vladislav Davankov from New People (4.08%), in fourth is Leonid Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party (3.15%).

Turnout, taking into account remote voting, exceeded 74%.

Vladimir Putin himself has already spoken on the stage of the Gostiny Dvor in Moscow in front of volunteers and employees of his headquarters, thanking them for their work.


"Noon against Putin"
Despite threats from the prosecutor's office, offers to vote via the Internet and fakes about the cancellation of the event, thousands of Russians came to the polling stations at 12 o'clock on Sunday. Earlier, the opposition called on those who disagree with the policies of the current President of the Russian Federation to take part in the “Noon against Putin” action.

In Moscow, queues of people wishing to vote at noon were observed at several polling stations. At MIPT, where Boris Nadezhdin taught and voted, students began chanting his name. He was not allowed to participate in the elections after the Central Election Commission invalidated part of the signatures collected in his support in February.

Abroad, at Russian diplomatic missions, by midday there were hours-long queues of Russians wanting to vote. In some cities they had to wait in line for 6-7 hours.

One of the largest events abroad took place in Berlin. According to some estimates, about two thousand people took part in it.


Alexei Navalny's widow Yulia came to the Russian Embassy in Germany at noon to vote, like dozens of other Russians. Mikhail Khodorkovsky was also seen at the rally.

Detentions and violations
According to OVD-Info, by Sunday evening at least 80 people were detained in 20 Russian cities. People were detained for writing on ballots and even simply for showing up at noon, as in Kazan.

Independent observers noted numerous violations in the organization of voting. In addition to stuffing and "carousels", it was also reported that in some areas the voting booths had no curtains: police officers monitored what voters marked on the ballot and detained them if they did not like it.

title: Trump says Putin ‘probably’ involved in Navalny’s death – POLITICO
content:
Donald Trump said Russian President Vladimir Putin was “probably” involved in the death of opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month.
“I don’t know, but perhaps, I mean possibly, I could say probably, I don’t know,” the U.S. Republican presidential candidate rambled in an interview with Fox News, when asked whether Putin bears responsibility for Navalny’s death.
“He’s a young man, so statistically he’d be alive for a long time … so something happened that was unusual,” Trump added.
Navalny, the leading figure in Russia’s beleaguered opposition, died Feb. 16 in a penal colony. The EU and the U.S. directly blamed Russia for Navalny’s death, moving toward imposing new sanctions on the Kremlin. 
But Trump, who is dominating the Republican presidential primary and currently leads Democratic incumbent Joe Biden in general election polls across multiple key swing states, has so far maintained a soft line on Putin, who has been waging a full-scale invasion of Ukraine for more than two years now. 
Trump has also repeatedly pledged to stop aid to Ukraine and force Kyiv to the negotiating table with Russia — a stance that is fueling anxiety among Western allies who are wary of a second Trump term.
During the interview, Trump said he hopes he won’t have to choose between Putin “swallowing” Ukraine and sending weapons to Kyiv.
“I hope it doesn’t come to that,” he said, claiming again that the war “never would have happened” under his presidency.
input:
Donald Trump said Russian President Vladimir Putin was “probably” involved in the death of opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month.
“I don’t know, but perhaps, I mean possibly, I could say probably, I don’t know,” the U.S. Republican presidential candidate rambled in an interview with Fox News, when asked whether Putin bears responsibility for Navalny’s death.
“He’s a young man, so statistically he’d be alive for a long time … so something happened that was unusual,” Trump added.
Navalny, the leading figure in Russia’s beleaguered opposition, died Feb. 16 in a penal colony. The EU and the U.S. directly blamed Russia for Navalny’s death, moving toward imposing new sanctions on the Kremlin. 
But Trump, who is dominating the Republican presidential primary and currently leads Democratic incumbent Joe Biden in general election polls across multiple key swing states, has so far maintained a soft line on Putin, who has been waging a full-scale invasion of Ukraine for more than two years now. 
Trump has also repeatedly pledged to stop aid to Ukraine and force Kyiv to the negotiating table with Russia — a stance that is fueling anxiety among Western allies who are wary of a second Trump term.
During the interview, Trump said he hopes he won’t have to choose between Putin “swallowing” Ukraine and sending weapons to Kyiv.
“I hope it doesn’t come to that,” he said, claiming again that the war “never would have happened” under his presidency.

title: Putin wins Russian presidential election with 87.28% of the vote: Commission
content:
Incumbent Russian President Vladimir Putin won the presidential election with 87.28 percent of votes, according to official results announced by the Central Election Commission (CEC) on Thursday.

According to CEC Chair Ella Pamfilova, 76,277,708 voters cast their ballots for Putin and the voter turnout finally stood at 77.49 percent.

Outside of Russia, Pamfilova said Putin won majorities at polling places in the United States, Germany, Australia, Latvia, Estonia and Armenia. The CEC chief claimed 388,791 Russians voted in the election abroad.

Communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov came second with 4.31 percent of the vote, followed by New People party candidate Vladislav Davankov and nationalist Leonid Slutsky at 3."85 percent and 3.20 percent respectively. 

Putin thanked all Russians who voted in presidential election, which was held from March 15 to 17, in a televised address on Thursday after the official results were announced.

"Once again, I thank everyone who took part in the voting, regardless of who you gave your vote to," Putin was quoted as saying by Russia's TASS news agency.

The Russian president said the campaign was tense and had a lot riding on it, because "we were choosing the path Russia will follow going forward, choosing the future for ourselves and our children." 

At his campaign headquarters in Moscow on Monday, Putin said that he would do his best to achieve national development goals in all directions.
input:
Incumbent Russian President Vladimir Putin won the presidential election with 87.28 percent of votes, according to official results announced by the Central Election Commission (CEC) on Thursday.

According to CEC Chair Ella Pamfilova, 76,277,708 voters cast their ballots for Putin and the voter turnout finally stood at 77.49 percent.

Outside of Russia, Pamfilova said Putin won majorities at polling places in the United States, Germany, Australia, Latvia, Estonia and Armenia. The CEC chief claimed 388,791 Russians voted in the election abroad.

Communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov came second with 4.31 percent of the vote, followed by New People party candidate Vladislav Davankov and nationalist Leonid Slutsky at 3."85 percent and 3.20 percent respectively. 

Putin thanked all Russians who voted in presidential election, which was held from March 15 to 17, in a televised address on Thursday after the official results were announced.

"Once again, I thank everyone who took part in the voting, regardless of who you gave your vote to," Putin was quoted as saying by Russia's TASS news agency.

The Russian president said the campaign was tense and had a lot riding on it, because "we were choosing the path Russia will follow going forward, choosing the future for ourselves and our children." 

At his campaign headquarters in Moscow on Monday, Putin said that he would do his best to achieve national development goals in all directions.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Когда будут результаты
На выборах ВЦИОМ и ФОМ проведут экзитполы (опросы граждан на выходе с избирательных участков), результаты которых опубликуют после закрытия избирательных участков в Калининградской области (после 21:00 мск). Тогда же начнут поступать первые результаты после обработки избирательных бюллетеней на Дальнем Востоке.

Окончательно определить результаты выборов ЦИК должна не позднее 28 марта.
translation:
When will the results be available?
During the elections, VTsIOM and FOM will conduct exit polls (surveys of citizens at the exit from polling stations), the results of which will be published after the closing of polling stations in the Kaliningrad region (after 21:00 Moscow time). At the same time, the first results will begin to arrive after the processing of ballots in the Far East.

The CEC must finally determine the election results no later than March 28.
input:
When will the results be available?
During the elections, VTsIOM and FOM will conduct exit polls (surveys of citizens at the exit from polling stations), the results of which will be published after the closing of polling stations in the Kaliningrad region (after 21:00 Moscow time). At the same time, the first results will begin to arrive after the processing of ballots in the Far East.

The CEC must finally determine the election results no later than March 28.

title: Russia sees polling station protests with Putin set to extend long rule | CNN
content:
Russia saw protests at polling stations on Sunday on the final day of voting in an election set to extend Russian President Vladmir Putin’s long hold on power.
    

            Lines at some polling stations in Russia grew suddenly at around 12pm local time Sunday, the hour at which supporters of the deceased opposition leader Alexey Navalny called on people to turn out collectively as a show of opposition support.
    

            A CNN team at a polling station in Moscow said the line grew rapidly over a five- to ten-minute spell at around noon, and estimated 150 people had arrived.
    

            The CNN team said that police were letting people in batches through the gates to pass through security, with metal detectors and bags being checked inside the building.
    

            One 39-year old voter said he had come at noon “to see other people, and they have come too.”
    

            A woman told the CNN team, “This is the first time in my life I have ever seen a queue for elections.” Asked why she had come at that hour, she simply replied: “You know why. I think everybody in this queue knows why.”
    

            It’s unclear how many polling stations across the country saw an increase in people waiting at around noon. The Reuters and AFP news agencies also reported protests taking place.
    

            Social media channels set up by supporters of Navalny showed video clips of lines in several places, including Moscow neighborhoods such as Nekrasovka and at Tverskaya Street and locations in St Petersburg. The Navalny team also posted an image from the city of Novosibirsk with the caption: “Today is #noon. The protest has already taken place in the first cities of Siberia. We are looking forward to seeing you.”
    

            More supporters of the Kremlin critic gathered around his grave to pay their respects on Sunday. Video shows dozens of people gathered around the grave at the Borisovsky Cemetery in Moscow, with some laying flowers while others stand in silence or take pictures.
    

            Russians overseas also responded to the calls by Navalny’s supporters to protest at polling stations, forming long lines outside the Russian embassies in Berlin and London.

            One 39-year old voter said he had come at noon “to see other people, and they have come too.”
    

            A woman told the CNN team, “This is the first time in my life I have ever seen a queue for elections.” Asked why she had come at that hour, she simply replied: “You know why. I think everybody in this queue knows why.”
    

            It’s unclear how many polling stations across the country saw an increase in people waiting at around noon. The Reuters and AFP news agencies also reported protests taking place.

title: 监督组织：俄大选采电子投票 更容易舞弊 | 俄罗斯 | 普京 | 不透明 | 大纪元
content:
【大纪元2024年03月16日讯】（大纪元记者陈霆综合报导）独立投票监督组织警告，本届俄罗斯大选将是该国史上最不透明的选举。各界普遍预期现任总统普京（Vladimir Putin）将在大选中赢得连任。
选举监督组织“发声”（Golos）共同主席安德烈丘克（Stanislav Andreichuk）说，在大选中首次使用电子投票，以及投票分三天进行的事实，都使选举过程更加不透明。
安德烈丘克在接受路透社采访时说：“这是俄罗斯史上最封闭、最不透明的选举。”
克里姆林宫表示，周五开始的选举是一个适当的民主进程，并预测普京将在压倒性的民众支持基础上获胜。
俄罗斯选务机关称，这次大选将由706名外国观选员进行监督，此外由候选人、政党和社会组织提名的100万名俄罗斯观察员中，也有多达1/3参与监督。
安德烈丘克说，选举第一天的投票率很高，这反映了职场主管对人们施压，确保他们去投票。
他说：“大家早上第一件事就是出门投票，因为老板要他们这么做。因为这天是工作日，很容易掌握他们的行踪。”
六名消息人士在选举前夕告诉路透社，国营企业和组织的主管正向员工施压，要求员工去投票。其中四人说，有些人还必须提供证据，证明自己有投票。
一家国有企业的员工说：“在我们工厂，每个人都被告知要在3月15日投票，并给老板发一张自拍照。”
高投票率对克里姆林宫来说非常重要，因为在俄乌战争爆发两年后，普京希望表明全国人民仍支持他。
官方数据显示，周五全国投票率超过33%，但西伯利亚和远东地区超过6成。在俄罗斯占领的乌克兰顿涅茨克（Donetsk）和赫尔松（Kherson）地区，投票率更逼近7成。
反对派政治家纳瓦尼（Alexei Navalny）上个月死在北极的一个监狱中，他的支持者敦促人们在周日中午集体参加投票，以示抗议。
安德烈丘克说，在本次大选中，全国约三分之一地区的民众可采用电子投票。他认为，这是一个特别令人担忧的问题，因为它容易被操纵，而且无法检查投票结果。
他也说，投票时间跨度长达三天，使投票结果可能在一夜之间被篡改。
安德烈丘克还批评，除了普京以外，只有三名候选人，这是过去五次选举中竞争者最少的一次，且不允许公开讨论国家问题。
安德烈丘克说：“当局实施了审查制度，国内存在镇压，部分反对派被送入监牢。因此，这场选举从一开始就是不自由、不民主的。”
“发声”（Golos）被禁止派遣观察员。2013年，“发声”被当局认定为“外国代理人”，因为它公布了2011年议会选举、2012年总统选举存在舞弊行为的证据。
translation:
[The Epoch Times, March 16, 2024] (Comprehensive report by Epoch Times reporter Chen Ting) An independent voting monitoring organization warned that this Russian election will be the most opaque election in the country’s history. Current President Vladimir Putin is widely expected to win re-election in the general election.
Stanislav Andreichuk, co-chairman of the election watchdog group Golos, said the use of electronic voting for the first time in a general election and the fact that voting was spread over three days made the electoral process even more opaque.
"This is the most closed and opaque election in Russia's history," Andreychuk told Reuters in an interview.
The Kremlin says the election, which begins on Friday, is a properly democratic process and predicts Putin will win based on overwhelming popular support.
The Russian election agency stated that this election will be supervised by 706 foreign observers. In addition, as many as 1/3 of the 1 million Russian observers nominated by candidates, political parties and social organizations will participate in supervision.
Andreychuk said the high turnout on the first day of the election reflected workplace supervisors putting pressure on people to ensure they went to the polls.
He said: "Everyone goes out to vote first thing in the morning because their boss wants them to. Because it's a working day, it's easy to track their whereabouts."
Six sources told Reuters on the eve of the election that executives at state-owned companies and organizations were pressuring employees to vote. Some will also have to provide evidence that they voted, four of them said.
An employee of a state-owned enterprise said: "In our factory, everyone was told to vote on March 15 and send a selfie to the boss."
The high turnout is important to the Kremlin as Putin wants to show that the country still supports him two years after the start of the Russo-Ukrainian war.
Official data showed that the national turnout on Friday exceeded 33%, but it exceeded 60% in Siberia and the Far East. In the Russian-occupied Donetsk and Kherson regions of Ukraine, the turnout was closer to 70%.
Supporters of opposition politician Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month, are urging people to vote en masse at noon on Sunday in protest.
Andreichuk said that in this general election, people in about one-third of the country can vote electronically. He believes this is a particular concern because it is easily manipulated and the results of the vote cannot be checked.
He also said that the voting time span was as long as three days, so the results could be tampered with overnight.
Andreichuk also criticized the fact that there were only three candidates besides Putin, the smallest number of contenders in the past five elections, and that public discussion of national issues was not allowed.
"The authorities implemented censorship, there was repression in the country, and some opponents were sent to prison. Therefore, this election was not free and undemocratic from the beginning," Andreychuk said.
Golos were prohibited from sending observers. In 2013, "Voice" was deemed a "foreign agent" by the authorities because it published evidence of fraud in the 2011 parliamentary election and the 2012 presidential election.

title: 普京大选“获胜”虽无悬念，最后投票日见“中午反普京”人潮
content:
另据俄罗斯卫星通讯社的报道，克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫（Dmitri Peskov）向记者表示，星期六凌晨乌克兰“破坏分子”数次尝试入侵俄罗斯别尔哥罗德州和库尔斯克州领土，但是2500名“破坏分子”中有1700人损失，包括550人丧生。

这家俄罗斯通讯社还说，乌克兰“破坏分子”星期六也试图从苏梅州居民点波波夫卡方向以及从别尔哥罗德州斯波达柳什诺和科津卡方向越境向俄罗斯渗透，但是被俄军击退，乌军因此损失30名官兵、两辆装甲车、三辆坦克和两套多管火箭炮发射车。

与此同时，乌克兰七个州星期天凌晨陆续拉响防空警报。俄罗斯对乌克兰关键基础设施实施空袭已经成为家常便饭。

乌克兰军方周日表示，在黑海的港口城市敖德萨，俄罗斯的连夜空袭摧毁了农业企业和几个工业建筑。

乌克兰防空部队在电报社媒平台上说，俄罗斯发动了16架无人机和7枚导弹袭击，14架无人机在敖德萨地区被击落。

路透社说，尽管此次大选的选票上根本没有普京的对手，克里姆林宫还是希望看到超高的投票率，以表明普京发动的乌克兰战争得到绝大多数民众的支持。俄罗斯官员表示，在星期五、六两天的投票中，全国选民的投票率已经冲到60%。
translation:
According to a report from the Russian Satellite News Agency, Kremlin spokesman Dmitri Peskov told reporters that Ukrainian "saboteurs" made several attempts to invade Russia's Belgorod and Kursk regions early Saturday morning. territory, but 1,700 of the 2,500 "saboteurs" suffered losses, including 550 killed.

The Russian news agency also said that Ukrainian "saboteurs" also tried to infiltrate into Russia on Saturday from the direction of Popovka, a settlement in Sumy Oblast, and from the direction of Spotlyushno and Kozinka in Belgorod Oblast, but were blocked by Russia. The army was repelled, and the Ukrainian army lost 30 officers and soldiers, two armored vehicles, three tanks and two sets of multiple rocket launchers.

At the same time, air defense sirens were sounded in seven Ukrainian states early Sunday morning. Russian air strikes on critical infrastructure in Ukraine have become routine.

Ukraine's military said on Sunday that overnight Russian air strikes destroyed agricultural businesses and several industrial buildings in the Black Sea port city of Odessa.

The Ukrainian Air Defense Force said on the Telegram social media platform that Russia launched 16 drones and 7 missile attacks, and 14 drones were shot down in the Odessa area.

Reuters said that although there is no opponent for Putin on the ballot in this election, the Kremlin still hopes to see a very high turnout to show that Putin’s war in Ukraine has the support of the vast majority of the people. Russian officials said that in the two-day voting on Friday and Saturday, the national voter turnout rate had reached 60%.
input:
According to a report from the Russian Satellite News Agency, Kremlin spokesman Dmitri Peskov told reporters that Ukrainian "saboteurs" made several attempts to invade Russia's Belgorod and Kursk regions early Saturday morning. territory, but 1,700 of the 2,500 "saboteurs" suffered losses, including 550 killed.

The Russian news agency also said that Ukrainian "saboteurs" also tried to infiltrate into Russia on Saturday from the direction of Popovka, a settlement in Sumy Oblast, and from the direction of Spotlyushno and Kozinka in Belgorod Oblast, but were blocked by Russia. The army was repelled, and the Ukrainian army lost 30 officers and soldiers, two armored vehicles, three tanks and two sets of multiple rocket launchers.

At the same time, air defense sirens were sounded in seven Ukrainian states early Sunday morning. Russian air strikes on critical infrastructure in Ukraine have become routine.

Ukraine's military said on Sunday that overnight Russian air strikes destroyed agricultural businesses and several industrial buildings in the Black Sea port city of Odessa.

The Ukrainian Air Defense Force said on the Telegram social media platform that Russia launched 16 drones and 7 missile attacks, and 14 drones were shot down in the Odessa area.

Reuters said that although there is no opponent for Putin on the ballot in this election, the Kremlin still hopes to see a very high turnout to show that Putin’s war in Ukraine has the support of the vast majority of the people. Russian officials said that in the two-day voting on Friday and Saturday, the national voter turnout rate had reached 60%.

title: 俄罗斯大选投票率逾7成 普京料高票当选 _大公网
content:
图：俄罗斯别尔哥罗德地区16日遭乌军炮击，多辆汽车被炸毁。\美联社
　　俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票3月15日至17日举行。俄中央选举委员会数据显示，截至莫斯科时间17日下午4时左右，本次大选投票率已经超过70%。然而，自投票开始，出现了约28万起针对电子投票系统的网络攻击，其攻击源主要来自乌克兰、西欧和北美。此外，俄乌战场上，乌军不断使用无人机和导弹袭击俄罗斯境内，甚至对投票站进行炮击，企图干扰选举。
　　本次大选投票定于莫斯科时间17日20时结束。截至投票结束前约4个小时，投票率已经超过70%，高于2018年大选67.5%的投票率。俄中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃表示，来自129个国家的1115名国际观察员和专家正在监督投票。
　　共有4名候选人参加此次总统选举，包括俄现任总统普京、俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基、俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫和俄新人党的达万科夫。俄罗斯2020年公投修宪后将总统任期届数归零，允许普京从2024年起再多连任两届至2036年。外界预计普京将高票当选。
　　梅德韦杰夫斥破坏选举者“叛徒”
　　本次大选首次采用了远程电子投票方式。帕姆菲洛娃17日表示，自15日在线投票开始以来，当局已拦截约28万起针对电子投票系统的恶意分布式拒绝服务（DDoS）攻击。俄罗斯电信公司的数据显示，投票系统在15日就遭受了逾9万次攻击。
　　该公司负责信息安全的副总裁拉普诺夫指出，这些网络攻击的来源IP地址主要位于乌克兰、西欧和北美。他还指出，从网络攻击的专业性来看，这些攻击是由“专业的特殊组织”发起。俄对外情报局在一份声明中称，美国试图通过降低选民投票率破坏选举结果，“在华盛顿的煽动下，反对派正在通过互联网资源传播呼吁俄罗斯公民无视选举的声音”。
　　此外，在投票期间，各投票站共发生逾20起试图通过将各种液体倒入投票箱毁坏选票事件、8起未遂纵火案，以及1起投掷烟雾弹事件，造成214张选票被破坏。多人因在投票站的破坏行为被捕。
　　帕姆菲洛娃指责这些破坏者是“人渣”，“破坏了人们的选票”，并透露一些破坏者承认受人指使，故意扰乱选举，酬金高达10万卢布（约8500港元）。俄罗斯前总统梅德韦杰夫则称这些人为“叛徒”，指责他们帮助国家的敌人，并表示肇事者可能犯下叛国罪，或将面临20年徒刑。有国会议员提出立法，对破坏选举活动的人最高判监8年。
　　乌军加强攻击俄境内目标
　　除了网络战场，乌克兰从选举前就多次袭击俄罗斯境内的炼油厂，并派出部队试图突破俄罗斯边境。俄国防部17日表示，仅过去24小时就击落了乌克兰23枚“吸血鬼”火箭弹和168架无人机。
　　俄总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫称，乌军近日数次尝试入侵别尔哥罗德州和库尔斯克州，但所有袭击都被成功击退，“2500名破坏分子中的1700人折损，550人丧生”。别尔哥罗德州州长格拉德科夫指出，乌军17日再次炮击别尔哥罗德，导致一名男子当场死亡，另有11人不同程度受伤。
　　俄罗斯方面指责乌克兰利用“恐怖活动”，试图扰乱其大选。俄外交部表示，基辅“加强了与选举有关的恐怖活动”，以此向“西方控制者”展示其战斗力，并“乞求”更多的财政援助和致命武器。
translation:
Picture: The Belgorod region of Russia was shelled by the Ukrainian army on the 16th, and many cars were blown up. \Associated Press
The official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. Data from the Russian Central Election Commission show that as of about 4 p.m. Moscow time on the 17th, the turnout rate for this election has exceeded 70%. However, since the beginning of voting, there have been about 280,000 cyber attacks against electronic voting systems, with the attacks mainly originating from Ukraine, Western Europe and North America. In addition, on the Russian-Ukrainian battlefield, the Ukrainian army continued to use drones and missiles to attack Russian territory, and even shelled polling stations in an attempt to interfere with the election.
Voting for this general election is scheduled to end at 20:00 Moscow time on the 17th. As of about four hours before the end of voting, the turnout had exceeded 70%, which was higher than the 67.5% turnout in the 2018 general election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that 1,115 international observers and experts from 129 countries are monitoring the voting.
A total of four candidates participated in this presidential election, including current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, and Davankov of the New People's Party of Russia. After Russia's 2020 referendum to amend the constitution, the number of presidential terms will be reset to zero, allowing Putin to serve two more terms from 2024 to 2036. Putin is expected to be elected with a high vote.
Medvedev calls election saboteurs “traitors”
This election used remote electronic voting for the first time. Pamfilova said on the 17th that since the start of online voting on the 15th, authorities have intercepted approximately 280,000 malicious distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against electronic voting systems. Data from Russian Telecom showed that the voting system suffered more than 90,000 attacks on the 15th.
Lapunov, the company’s vice president for information security, pointed out that the source IP addresses of these network attacks are mainly located in Ukraine, Western Europe and North America. He also pointed out that judging from the professionalism of cyber attacks, these attacks were launched by "professional special organizations." The Russian Foreign Intelligence Service said in a statement that the United States was trying to undermine the election results by reducing voter turnout. "Instigated by Washington, the opposition is spreading calls on Russian citizens to ignore the election through Internet resources."
In addition, during the voting period, there were more than 20 incidents of attempts to destroy ballots by pouring various liquids into ballot boxes, 8 attempted arson incidents, and 1 incident of throwing smoke bombs at various polling stations, resulting in 214 ballots being destroyed. Several people were arrested for vandalism at polling stations.
Pamfilova accused these saboteurs of being "scum" and "destroyed people's votes", and revealed that some saboteurs admitted to being instructed by others to deliberately disrupt the election, and were paid as much as 100,000 rubles (approximately HK$8,500). Former Russian President Medvedev called these people "traitors", accused them of helping the country's enemies, and said that the perpetrators may have committed treason and may face 20 years in prison. Some members of Congress have proposed legislation that would punish those who disrupt election activities with up to eight years in prison.
Ukrainian army steps up attacks on targets in Russia
In addition to the cyber battlefield, Ukraine has repeatedly attacked oil refineries in Russia since before the election and sent troops to try to break through the Russian border. The Russian Ministry of Defense stated on the 17th that it had shot down 23 Ukrainian "Vampire" rockets and 168 drones in the past 24 hours alone.
Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that the Ukrainian army has attempted to invade Belgorod and Kursk regions several times in recent days, but all attacks have been successfully repelled. “1,700 of the 2,500 saboteurs were killed, 550 Loss of life". Belgorod Governor Gladkov pointed out that the Ukrainian army shelled Belgorod again on the 17th, causing one man to die on the spot and 11 others to be injured to varying degrees.
Russia accused Ukraine of using "terrorist activities" to try to disrupt its election. The Russian Foreign Ministry stated that Kiev "intensified election-related terrorist activities" to demonstrate its combat capabilities to "Western controllers" and "begged" for more financial assistance and lethal weapons.
input:
Picture: The Belgorod region of Russia was shelled by the Ukrainian army on the 16th, and many cars were blown up. \Associated Press
The official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. Data from the Russian Central Election Commission show that as of about 4 p.m. Moscow time on the 17th, the turnout rate for this election has exceeded 70%. However, since the beginning of voting, there have been about 280,000 cyber attacks against electronic voting systems, with the attacks mainly originating from Ukraine, Western Europe and North America. In addition, on the Russian-Ukrainian battlefield, the Ukrainian army continued to use drones and missiles to attack Russian territory, and even shelled polling stations in an attempt to interfere with the election.
Voting for this general election is scheduled to end at 20:00 Moscow time on the 17th. As of about four hours before the end of voting, the turnout had exceeded 70%, which was higher than the 67.5% turnout in the 2018 general election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that 1,115 international observers and experts from 129 countries are monitoring the voting.
A total of four candidates participated in this presidential election, including current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, and Davankov of the New People's Party of Russia. After Russia's 2020 referendum to amend the constitution, the number of presidential terms will be reset to zero, allowing Putin to serve two more terms from 2024 to 2036. Putin is expected to be elected with a high vote.
Medvedev calls election saboteurs “traitors”
This election used remote electronic voting for the first time. Pamfilova said on the 17th that since the start of online voting on the 15th, authorities have intercepted approximately 280,000 malicious distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against electronic voting systems. Data from Russian Telecom showed that the voting system suffered more than 90,000 attacks on the 15th.
Lapunov, the company’s vice president for information security, pointed out that the source IP addresses of these network attacks are mainly located in Ukraine, Western Europe and North America. He also pointed out that judging from the professionalism of cyber attacks, these attacks were launched by "professional special organizations." The Russian Foreign Intelligence Service said in a statement that the United States was trying to undermine the election results by reducing voter turnout. "Instigated by Washington, the opposition is spreading calls on Russian citizens to ignore the election through Internet resources."
In addition, during the voting period, there were more than 20 incidents of attempts to destroy ballots by pouring various liquids into ballot boxes, 8 attempted arson incidents, and 1 incident of throwing smoke bombs at various polling stations, resulting in 214 ballots being destroyed. Several people were arrested for vandalism at polling stations.
Pamfilova accused these saboteurs of being "scum" and "destroyed people's votes", and revealed that some saboteurs admitted to being instructed by others to deliberately disrupt the election, and were paid as much as 100,000 rubles (approximately HK$8,500). Former Russian President Medvedev called these people "traitors", accused them of helping the country's enemies, and said that the perpetrators may have committed treason and may face 20 years in prison. Some members of Congress have proposed legislation that would punish those who disrupt election activities with up to eight years in prison.
Ukrainian army steps up attacks on targets in Russia
In addition to the cyber battlefield, Ukraine has repeatedly attacked oil refineries in Russia since before the election and sent troops to try to break through the Russian border. The Russian Ministry of Defense stated on the 17th that it had shot down 23 Ukrainian "Vampire" rockets and 168 drones in the past 24 hours alone.
Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that the Ukrainian army has attempted to invade Belgorod and Kursk regions several times in recent days, but all attacks have been successfully repelled. “1,700 of the 2,500 saboteurs were killed, 550 Loss of life". Belgorod Governor Gladkov pointed out that the Ukrainian army shelled Belgorod again on the 17th, causing one man to die on the spot and 11 others to be injured to varying degrees.
Russia accused Ukraine of using "terrorist activities" to try to disrupt its election. The Russian Foreign Ministry stated that Kiev "intensified election-related terrorist activities" to demonstrate its combat capabilities to "Western controllers" and "begged" for more financial assistance and lethal weapons.

title: Russian voters, answering Navalny’s call, protest as Putin extends his rule to 2030 - The Washington Post
content:
Navalny, who had long crusaded for free and fair elections in Russia and was blocked from running for president in 2018, had urged Russians to vote against Putin at noon Sunday. It turned out to be Navalny’s final political act before his death.
Many voters also posted photographs of their spoiled ballots with protest slogans such as “Navalny is my president,” “No to war, no to Putin,” and “Putin is a murderer.”
Voting took place over three days, beginning Friday, which some critics said would allow greater opportunity for ballot manipulation and other fraud. Voting was also taking place in areas of Ukraine occupied by the Russian military, with reports of electoral teams accompanied by soldiers forcing people to vote at gunpoint. In 27 Russian regions and two in occupied Ukraine, voters were also able to use a widely criticized opaque online voting system, with no way to verify votes or guard against tampering.
But the three days of balloting also gave voters ample opportunity to visit polling stations at a time of their choice, making it all the more obvious that the sudden crowds at midday Sunday had not materialized by accident.
At least 65 people were detained at polling stations in 16 Russian cities on Sunday, according to OVD-Info, a legal rights group. Among them were a Moscow couple arrested because the husband wore a scarf bearing the name Orwell, a reference to George Orwell, whose dystopian novel 1984 was about a repressive totalitarian state.
In addition to Putin, three other candidates were on the ballot, all essentially Kremlin-friendly figures with low profiles, in a highly managed election designed to offer a veneer of legitimacy without posing any serious threat. Two antiwar candidates, Boris Nadezhdin and Yekaterina Duntsova, who might have become flash points for antiwar sentiment, were barred from running.
Putin, in response to a reporter’s question on Sunday night, dismissed Western criticism of the vote. “What did you want? For them to stand up and applaud,” he asked. “They set themselves the goal of restraining our development. Of course, they will tell you whatever they want.”

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content:
Действительно ли Путин пользуется столь высокой поддержкой населения или его результат - продукт административного ресурса и фальсификаций? Насколько легитимны эти выборы в глазах россиян и международного сообщества? И какое будущее ждет страну после очередного переизбрания бессменного лидера?

С одной стороны, мы стали свидетелями настоящего триумфа действующего президента Владимира Путина, который в очередной раз одержал убедительную победу с рекордным результатом. Столь высокий уровень поддержки со стороны населения - это, безусловно, мощный мандат доверия и признание заслуг лидера в деле защиты национальных интересов и укрепления суверенитета России.

С другой стороны, эти выборы обнажили глубокий раскол в российском обществе и вызвали неоднозначную реакцию со стороны международного сообщества. Многочисленные нарушения, скандалы и протесты, зафиксированные в ходе голосования, ставят под сомнение легитимность и честность избирательного процесса. А отказ западных стран признать итоги выборов и обвинения в адрес Москвы грозят новым витком конфронтации и изоляции России на мировой арене.

Так чем же запомнится эта кампания - сплочением нации вокруг своего лидера или углублением внутренних противоречий? Станет ли очередной срок Путина временем стабильности и развития или периодом стагнации и застоя? И какое будущее ждет нашу страну после 2024 года?

Давайте вместе разбираться в этих непростых вопросах и анализировать главные итоги прошедших выборов. Без пропаганды и эмоций, опираясь только на факты и здравый смысл. Так что приготовьтесь к увлекательному и познавательному чтению, которое заставит вас задуматься, сделать выводы и, возможно, пересмотреть свои взгляды на политику и общество.
translation:
Does Putin really enjoy such high support from the population or is his result a product of administrative resources and falsifications? How legitimate are these elections in the eyes of Russians and the international community? And what future awaits the country after the next re-election of the permanent leader?

On the one hand, we witnessed a real triumph of the current President Vladimir Putin, who once again won a landslide victory with a record result. Such a high level of support from the population is, of course, a powerful mandate of trust and recognition of the leader’s merits in protecting national interests and strengthening Russia’s sovereignty.

On the other hand, these elections exposed deep divisions in Russian society and caused mixed reactions from the international community. Numerous irregularities, scandals and protests recorded during the voting call into question the legitimacy and integrity of the electoral process. And the refusal of Western countries to recognize the election results and accusations against Moscow threaten a new round of confrontation and isolation of Russia on the world stage.

So what will this campaign be remembered for - the rallying of the nation around its leader or the deepening of internal contradictions? Will Putin's next term be a time of stability and development or a period of stagnation and stagnation? And what future awaits our country after 2024?

Let's understand these difficult issues together and analyze the main results of the past elections. Without propaganda and emotions, relying only on facts and common sense. So get ready for a fascinating and educational read that will make you think, draw conclusions, and perhaps reconsider your views on politics and society.
